title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: The 2007 MasterCard Memorial Cup was played in May 2007 in Vancouver, British Columbia, at the Pacific Coliseum.

title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: It was the 89th annual Memorial Cup competition and determined the major junior ice hockey champion of the Canadian Hockey League (CHL).

title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: The tournament was competed between the WHL champion Medicine Hat Tigers, the OHL champion Plymouth Whalers, the QMJHL champion Lewiston Maineiacs, and the host team and tournament champion Vancouver Giants, who were competing in their second consecutive national junior championship.

title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: The Memorial Cup tournament was a four team tournament with a round-robin format.

title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: The Giants won their first Memorial Cup, defeating Medicine Hat 3–1 in the second all-WHL final in tournament history (the first was in 1989).

title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: The tournament set a new Memorial Cup attendance record with 121,561 fans attending the nine games.

title: 2007 Memorial Cup
text: The previous record of 84,686 was set at the 2003 tournament in Quebec City.

title: Cedar Rapids Ice Arena
text: The Cedar Rapids Ice Arena is a 3,850-seat multipurpose arena in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, located adjacent to Veterans Memorial Stadium.

title: Cedar Rapids Ice Arena
text: The arena opened on January 8, 2000, and is owned by the city of Cedar Rapids.

title: Cedar Rapids Ice Arena
text: It is home to the Cedar Rapids RoughRiders of the United States Hockey League as well as several local youth hockey teams.

title: Cedar Rapids Ice Arena
text: The University of Iowa Hawkeyes club hockey team plays some of their home games at the facility.

title: Cedar Rapids Ice Arena
text: The arena contains separate sheets of ice for ice hockey games and for public and figure ice skating.

title: 2011–12 QMJHL season
text: The 2011–12 QMJHL season was the 43rd season of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League (QMJHL).

title: 2011–12 QMJHL season
text: The regular season, which consisted of seventeen teams playing 68 games each, began in September 2011 and ended in March 2012.

title: 2011–12 QMJHL season
text: This season was Blainville-Boisbriand Armada's first season in the league, as the team relocated to Boisbriand from Verdun where they played as the Montreal Junior Hockey Club from 2008 to 2011.

title: 2011–12 QMJHL season
text: The league lost one of his charter teams when the Lewiston Maineiacs folded during after the previous season, the QMJHL later announce an expansion team to Sherbrooke for the 2012-2013 season.

title: 2011–12 QMJHL season
text: In the playoffs, the Saint John Sea Dogs became the seventh team in league history to capture consecutive President's Cup championships.

title: Robins Center
text: The Robins Center is a 7,201-seat multi-purpose arena in Richmond, Virginia.

title: Robins Center
text: Opened in 1972, the arena is home to the University of Richmond Spiders basketball.

title: Robins Center
text: It hosted the ECAC South (now known as the Colonial Athletic Association) men's basketball tournament in 1983.

title: Robins Center
text: It is named for E. Claiborne Robins Sr, class of 1931, who, along with his family, have been leading benefactors for the school.

title: Robins Center
text: The opening of the Robins Center returning Spider basketball to an on-campus facility for the first time since the mid-1940s when it outgrew Millhiser Gymnasium.

title: Robins Center
text: In the intervening decades, the Spiders played home games in numerous locations around the Richmond area, including the Richmond Coliseum (1971–1972), the Richmond Arena (1954–1971), the Benedictine High School gymnasium (1951–1954), Grays' Armory (1950–1951) and Blues' Armory (1947–1950).

title: Robins Center
text: The Robins Center arena serves as the location of the University of Richmond's commencement exercises and hosted a 1992 Presidential debate involving Bill Clinton, George H. W. Bush, and Ross Perot.

title: 2006–07 QMJHL season
text: The 2006–07 QMJHL season was the 38th season in the history of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League.

title: 2006–07 QMJHL season
text: The regular season ran from September 14, 2006 to March 18, 2007.

title: 2006–07 QMJHL season
text: Eighteen teams played 70 games each in the schedule.

title: 2006–07 QMJHL season
text: The Lewiston Maineiacs finished first overall in the regular season winning their first Jean Rougeau Trophy.

title: 2006–07 QMJHL season
text: Lewiston won 16 playoff games, losing only one, en route to their first President's Cup, defeating the Val-d'Or Foreurs in the finals.

title: Case Gym
text: Case Gym is a 1,800-seat multi-purpose arena at Boston University in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Case Gym
text: It opened in 1972 as part of the Harold Case Physical Education Center, which is named after the university's fifth president, Harold C. Case.

title: Case Gym
text: The gym is referred to as "The Roof" because it is located on the top level of the building, above Walter Brown Arena.

title: Case Gym
text: It is home to the Boston University Terriers men's and women's basketball teams, as well as the men's wrestling team.

title: Case Gym
text: Basketball games are also played in Agganis Arena, and on occasion Walter Brown Arena.

title: Case Gym
text: When Boston University left the America East Conference for the Patriot League in July 2013, they announced that all home men's basketball conference games would be played at Agganis Arena, with the non-conference games to be played at Case.

title: Billings Bulls
text: The Billings Bulls were a junior ice hockey organization based in Billings, Montana.

title: Billings Bulls
text: They most recently played home games at the 550-seat Centennial Ice Arena and due to the arena's small size, the Bulls frequently sold out games.

title: Billings Bulls
text: They previously played their home games in the Metrapark which had a max capacity of 9,000 for hockey games.

title: Billings Bulls
text: However, a negotiating dispute with arena officials and local county commissioners resulted in the team losing its lease.

title: Gumbo (PJ Morton album)
text: Gumbo is the fourth and first self-released studio album by American singer-songwriter PJ Morton.

title: Gumbo (PJ Morton album)
text: It was released on April 14, 2017, by Morton Records, as the follow-up to his third studio album "New Orleans" (2013).

title: Gumbo (PJ Morton album)
text: The record incorporates R&B styles with elements of older soul music; its lyrics discuss themes of romance and explores political and personal themes.

title: Gumbo (PJ Morton album)
text: The album is entirely produced by Morton himself and features guest appearances by Pell, BJ the Chicago Kid and R&B singer Anthony Hamilton's back-up group, The HamilTones.

title: Gumbo (PJ Morton album)
text: The album features a cover of the Bee Gees' "How Deep Is Your Love".

title: Lady Gaga x Terry Richardson
text: Lady Gaga x Terry Richardson is a photo-book by American singer Lady Gaga and American photographer Terry Richardson, released on November 22, 2011 by Grand Central Publishing.

title: Lady Gaga x Terry Richardson
text: The book features more than 350 pictures of Gaga as taken by Richardson during a ten-month period from Gaga's performance at The Monster Ball Tour till the 2011 Grammy Awards.

title: Lady Gaga x Terry Richardson
text: In addition to photographs, it includes a foreword written by the singer about her relationship with Richardson.

title: Lady Gaga x Terry Richardson
text: The duo had collaborated on other projects prior to the shooting of the book.

title: Piano Girl
text: Piano Girl (Turkish: "Deli Deli Olma" ) is a 2009 Turkish comedy-drama film, directed by Murat Saraçoğlu, starring Tarık Akan and Şerif Sezer as two elderly people forced to question their histories and reveal their big secrets.

title: Piano Girl
text: The film, which went on nationwide general release across Turkey on 17, 2009 (2009--) , was the opening film at the Sinema Burada Film Festival in İzmir, Turkey, and has since been screened in competition at a number of other film festivals, including the 46th Antalya Golden Orange Film Festival, where, according to Terry Richardson, writing for Today's Zaman, "the rapt audience gave it a standing ovation."

title: Snoecks
text: Snoecks is a Belgian magazine.

title: Snoecks
text: The huge, 550-plus-page magazine appears once a year in October and focuses on the most interesting new international developments in the arts, photography and literature.

title: Snoecks
text: In recent editions the book had features on artists such as Anton Corbijn, Larry Sultan, Matthew Barney, Terry Richardson, Ron Mueck, Alberto Garcia-Alix, Peter Lindbergh, Albert Watson, Desiree Dolron, Bettina Rheims, Diana Scheunemann, Timothy Greenfield-Sanders and Andres Serrano.

title: James Joseph Richardson
text: James Joseph Richardson (born December 12, 1935) is an African-American man who was wrongly convicted in 1968 for the October 1967 murders of his seven children.

title: James Joseph Richardson
text: They died after eating a poisoned lunch containing the organic phosphate pesticide parathion.

title: James Joseph Richardson
text: At the time of the murders Richardson, a migrant farm worker, was living in Arcadia, Florida, with his wife Annie Mae Richardson and the children.

title: James Joseph Richardson
text: At a trial in Fort Myers, Florida, an all-white jury found him guilty of murdering the children and sentenced him to death.

title: James Joseph Richardson
text: As a result of the United States Supreme Court's 1972 "Furman v. Georgia" decision finding the death penalty unconstitutional, his sentence was reduced to life imprisonment; he was then exonerated in 1989, after 21 years, when his case was revisited by appointed Miami-Dade County prosecutor Janet Reno.

title: James Joseph Richardson
text: He now lives in Wichita, Kansas.

title: Kenton Richardson
text: Kenton Terry Richardson (born 26 July 1999) is an English professional footballer who plays as a defender for League Two side Hartlepool United.

title: Amanda Lepore
text: Amanda Lepore (born November 21, 1967) is an American transgender model, celebutante, singer, and performance artist.

title: Amanda Lepore
text: The former Club Kid has appeared in advertising for numerous companies.

title: Amanda Lepore
text: Lepore is also noted as a regular subject in photographer David LaChapelle's work, serving as his muse, as well as many other photographers, such as Terry Richardson and .

title: Amanda Lepore
text: She participated in LaChapelle's "Artists and Prostitutes 1985–2005" exhibit in New York City, where she "lived" in a voyeuristic life-sized set.

title: Amanda Lepore
text: Lepore has also released several singles, many written by and/or recorded with Cazwell.

title: Amanda Lepore
text: In 2011, she released her debut studio album, "I..

title: Amanda Lepore
text: Amanda Lepore", on Peace Bisquit.

title: Index Magazine
text: index Magazine was a prominent New York City based publication with in-depth interviews with prominent figures in art and culture.

title: Index Magazine
text: It was created by Peter Halley and Bob Nickas in 1996, running until late 2005.

title: Index Magazine
text: Covering the burgeoning Indie culture of the 1990s, index regularly employed such rising photographers as Juergen Teller, Terry Richardson, Wolfgang Tillmans, and Ryan McGinley, and featured interviews with figures including Björk, Brian Eno, Marc Jacobs, and Scarlett Johansson, mixing new talents and established names in music, film, architecture, fashion, art, and politics.

title: Index Magazine
text: In addition to famous personalities, the publication also featured a mix of interviews with not so-famous New York personalities such as Queen Itchie or Ducky Doolittle.

title: Madonna (book)
text: Madonna is a biography by English author Andrew Morton, chronicling the life of American recording artist Madonna.

title: Madonna (book)
text: The book was released in November 2001 by St. Martin's Press in the United States and in April 2002 by Michael O'Mara Books in the United Kingdom.

title: Madonna (book)
text: Morton decided to write a biography on Madonna in 2000.

title: Madonna (book)
text: The release was announced in April 2001 by St. Martin's Press.

title: Madonna (book)
text: President and publisher Sally Richardson described the biography to contain details about Madonna's ambitions, her relationships and her lifestyle.

title: Annie Morton
text: Annie Morton (born October 8, 1970) is an American model born in Pennsylvania.

title: Annie Morton
text: She has appeared on the covers of "British Vogue", "ID", "Marie Claire", and other magazines.

title: Annie Morton
text: She has been photographed by Helmut Newton; Peter Lindbergh; Annie Leibovitz; Richard Avedon; Juergen Teller; Paul Jasmin, Mary Ellen Mark and Terry Richardson, and modeled for Donna Karan, Givenchy, Guerlain, Chanel, "Harper's Bazaar", "Sports Illustrated" and Victoria's Secret.

title: Annie Morton
text: A long time vegetarian, an advocate for organic lifestyle choices and natural healthcare.

title: Annie Morton
text: She co-founded Tsi-La Organics, a "Green Luxury" company that creates and sells vegan, organic perfume and skin care products.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: The E.R. Hays House, also known as Bybee & Davis Funeral Home, is a historic building located in Knoxville, Iowa, United States.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: Hays was a local lawyer who served briefly in the United States House of Representatives, replacing Edwin H. Conger who resigned to become the United States Ambassador to Brazil.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: Hays died a year after the house was completed.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: The family continued to live here until 1935 when it became the Bybee & Davis Funeral Home.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: The 21⁄2-story brick structure was designed by the Des Moines architectural firm of Foster & Liebbe in a combination of the Late Victorian and Italianate styles.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: Victorian eclecticism is featured in the porch and the trimwork, while the Italianate is found in the building's massing.

title: E.R. Hays House
text: The house was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1984.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The Cresco Opera House, also known as the Cresco Theater, is a historic building located in Cresco, Iowa, United States.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The first known theater in Cresco was the Lyric Hall, which opened in 1875.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: It showed the first movies around 1900.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The Family and the Cozy theaters opened around the turn of the century.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The Lyric was condemned and torn down in 1913, and the other two were considered substandard.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The Cresco Commercial Club held a fundraiser in early 1914 to build an opera house.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The Cresco Opera House Company was organized around the same time.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The building was completed by the end of the year, and it opened in 1915.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: It was designed by local engineer Joseph H. Howe, and constructed by local builder Martin Johnson.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The musical "High Jinks" was the first performance held in the theater.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: The theater, which seats 425, was equipped to show movies and there was a community hall in the basement.

title: Cresco Opera House
text: It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1981.

title: Ophur
text: Ophur was a rock band from the Chicago suburbs in DuPage County.

title: Ophur
text: The band performed in the midwestern United States over the course of seven years with national acts including The Plain White T's, Sum 41, Violent Femmes, Local H, Lucky Boys Confusion, Veruca Salt, Two Skinee J's, Duvall, Sleeping at Last, and others.

title: Ophur
text: Their music has been described as an eclectic amalgamation of U2, Red Hot Chili Peppers, and Pink Floyd.

title: Mendocino County GMO Ban
text: Mendocino County, California, was the first jurisdiction in the United States to ban the cultivation, production or distribution of genetically modified organisms (GMOs).

title: Mendocino County GMO Ban
text: The ordinance, entitled Measure H, was passed by referendum on March 2, 2004.

title: Mendocino County GMO Ban
text: Initiated by the group "GMO Free Mendocino", the campaign was a highly publicized grassroots effort by local farmers and environmental groups who contend that the potential risks of GMOs to human health and the ecosystem have not yet been fully understood.

title: Mendocino County GMO Ban
text: The measure was met with opposition by several interest groups representing the biotechnology industry, The California Plant Health Association (now the Western Plant Health Association) and CropLife America, a Washington-based consortium whose clients represent some of the largest food distributors in the nation, including Monsanto, DuPont and Dow Chemical.

title: Mendocino County GMO Ban
text: Since the enactment of the ordinance, Mendocino County has been added to an international list of "GMO free zones."

title: Mendocino County GMO Ban
text: Pre-emptive statutes banning local municipalities from such ordinances have now become widespread with adoption in sixteen states.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: The Wilford H. Fawcett House is a house in Breezy Point, Minnesota, United States, listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: Wilford H. Fawcett, also known as "Captain Billy", started the book "Captain Billy's Whiz Bang" as a joke book for soldiers during World War I.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: He formed Fawcett Publications in 1919 in Robbinsdale, Minnesota.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: In 1920, he bought a tract of land where the present-day Breezy Point Resort is located, and he began building cottages and a large log lodge.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: The lodge has since burnt down.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: He built the Fawcett House as a private residence within the resort property.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: Fawcett hired the Minneapolis architects of Magney and Tusler and commissioned the design in the Swiss Chateau style.

title: Wilford H. Fawcett House
text: The rustic log style was a bit ironic, since the local logging industry had declined before the resort was built.

title: Suffrajett
text: Suffrajett is a United States rock band from New York City, currently based in Chicago, Illinois, composed of singer/violinist Simi Sernaker, guitarist Jason Chasko, bassist Kevin Roberts, and drummer Danny Severson.

title: Suffrajett
text: Suffrajett has toured with Local H, The Last Vegas, and Bob Schneider, and have opened for the reunited MC5.

title: Suffrajett
text: Suffrajett released their self-titled debut album on February 2, 2003, and their latest album "Black Glitter" was released on January 1, 2007.

title: Suffrajett
text: They recently toured with Juliette and the Licks and Scissors for Lefty.

title: Hallelujah! I'm a Bum (album)
text: Hallelujah!

title: Hallelujah! I'm a Bum (album)
text: I'm A Bum is the seventh studio album by Chicago-based rock band Local H.

title: Hallelujah! I'm a Bum (album)
text: Interviews with the band have revealed that it is a concept album based on politics in the United States.

title: Hallelujah! I'm a Bum (album)
text: Although the album was completed in spring of 2012, the band chose to release it in September as to be closer to the 2012 presidential election.

title: Hallelujah! I'm a Bum (album)
text: The album makes frequent use of the sounds of the El Train in Chicago to transition songs.

title: William H. Cook Water Tank House
text: The William H. Cook Water Tank House is a water tank house located southeast of Jerome, Idaho, United States.

title: William H. Cook Water Tank House
text: The building was constructed circa 1915 and was used to store water for William H. Cook's farm.

title: William H. Cook Water Tank House
text: The rectangular building was constructed with lava rock and contains a metal tank.

title: William H. Cook Water Tank House
text: Although the stone craftsmanship in the building is similar to the work of local stonemason H. T. Pugh, the builder of the house has not been determined.

title: United States Senate election in Illinois, 1978
text: The 1978 United States Senate election in Illinois took place on November 7, 1978.

title: United States Senate election in Illinois, 1978
text: Incumbent Republican United States Senator Charles H. Percy ran for re-election to a third term in the United States Senate.

title: United States Senate election in Illinois, 1978
text: Percy was opposed by Democratic nominee Alex Seith, an attorney who had been appointed to several local government positions.

title: United States Senate election in Illinois, 1978
text: Though Percy had been expected to coast to re-election over Seith, a first-time candidate, the election quickly became competitive.

title: United States Senate election in Illinois, 1978
text: In the last few days of the campaign, a desperate Percy ran a television advertisement that featured him apologizing and acknowledging that, "I got your message and you're right."

title: United States Senate election in Illinois, 1978
text: Percy's last-ditch effort appeared to have paid off, as he was able to edge out Seith to win what would end up being his third and final term in the Senate.

title: Amherst, Massachusetts
text: Amherst ( ) is a town in Hampshire County, Massachusetts, United States, in the Connecticut River valley.

title: Amherst, Massachusetts
text: As of the 2010 census, the population was 37,819, making it the largest municipality in Hampshire County (although the county seat is Northampton).

title: Amherst, Massachusetts
text: The town is home to Amherst College, Hampshire College, and the University of Massachusetts Amherst, three of the Five Colleges.

title: Amherst, Massachusetts
text: The name of the town is pronounced without the "h" ("AM-erst"), giving rise to the local saying, "only the 'h' is silent", in reference both to the pronunciation and to the town's politically active populace.

title: History of the Kansas City metropolitan area
text: The history of the Kansas City metropolitan area begins in the 19th century as Frenchmen from St. Louis, Missouri moved up the Missouri River to trap for furs and trade with the Native Americans.

title: History of the Kansas City metropolitan area
text: The Kansas City metropolitan area, straddling the border between Missouri and Kansas at the confluence of the Kansas and Missouri Rivers, was a strategic point for commerce and security.

title: History of the Kansas City metropolitan area
text: Kansas City, Missouri was founded in 1838 and defeated its rival Westport to become the predominant city west of St. Louis.

title: History of the Kansas City metropolitan area
text: The area played a major role in the westward expansion of the United States.

title: History of the Kansas City metropolitan area
text: The Santa Fe, and Oregon trails ran through the area.

title: History of the Kansas City metropolitan area
text: In 1854, when Kansas was opened to Euro-American settlement, the Missouri-Kansas border became the first battlefield in the conflict in the American Civil War.

title: University of the Incarnate Word
text: The University of the Incarnate Word (UIW) is a private Catholic university whose main campus is located in San Antonio and Alamo Heights, Texas, United States.

title: University of the Incarnate Word
text: Founded in 1881 by the Sisters of Charity of the Incarnate Word, the university's main campus is located on 154 acre .

title: Federal University of Paraíba
text: The Federal University of Paraíba (Portuguese: "Universidade Federal da Paraíba" , UFPB) is a public university whose main campus is located in the city of João Pessoa, Paraíba, Brazil.

title: Federal University of Paraíba
text: Together with the Federal University of Campina Grande, it is the main university of the state of Paraiba, Brazil.

title: Kansas City metropolitan area
text: The Kansas City metropolitan area is a 15-county metropolitan area anchored by Kansas City, Missouri, that straddles the border between the U.S. states of Missouri and Kansas.

title: Kansas City metropolitan area
text: With a population of about 2,340,000, it ranks as the second largest metropolitan area with its core in Missouri (after Greater St. Louis).

title: Kansas City metropolitan area
text: Alongside Kansas City, the area includes a number of other cities and suburbs, the largest being Overland Park, Kansas; Kansas City, Kansas; Olathe, Kansas; and Independence, Missouri; each over 100,000 in population.

title: Kansas City metropolitan area
text: The Mid-America Regional Council (MARC) serves as the Council of Governments and the Metropolitan Planning Organization for the area.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: The University of Missouri–Kansas City (UMKC) is a public research university serving the greater Kansas City metropolitan area.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: Located in Kansas City, Missouri, UMKC is one of four system campuses that collectively constitute the University of Missouri.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: UMKC is spread across multiple locales; the main Volker Campus, home to the majority of university operations, is located in Kansas City's Rockhill neighborhood, east of the Country Club Plaza, and adjacent to both the Stowers Institute for Medical Research and the world-renowned Linda Hall Library.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: In 2017 the University, in collaboration with Truman Medical Center, Children's Mercy Hospital, the Missouri Health Department, the Jackson County Medical Examiners Office, and the Missouri Department of Mental Health Behavioral Medicine, formed the UMKC Health Sciences District on Hospital Hill.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: This district is a first-in-the-nation partnership between local and state governments, the university, and these nationally recognized healthcare faculties, designed to promote collaboration in research, innovation, education, grant funding, and community outreach, for the advancement of health and wellness in the greater Kansas City metropolitan area.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: Also in 2017, the university announced plans to expand its metropolitan identity with the construction of a downtown Campus for the Arts, located near the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts.

title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
text: The university's enrollment as of 2015 exceeded more than 16,600 students.

title: Downtown Kansas City
text: Downtown Kansas City is the central business district (CBD) of Kansas City, Missouri and the Kansas City metropolitan area.

title: Downtown Kansas City
text: It is between the Missouri River in the north, to 31st Street in the south; and from the Kansas–Missouri state line east to Bruce R. Watkins Drive as defined by the Downtown Council of Kansas City; the 2010 Greater Downtown Area Plan formulated by the City of Kansas City defines the Greater Downtown Area to be the city limits of North Kansas City and Missouri to the north, the Kansas–Missouri state line to the west, 31st Street to the south and Woodland Avenue to the east.

title: Downtown Kansas City
text: However, the definition used by the Downtown Council is the most commonly accepted.

title: University of Kansas
text: The University of Kansas, often referred to as KU or Kansas, is a public research university in the U.S. state of Kansas.

title: University of Kansas
text: The main campus in Lawrence, one of the largest college towns in Kansas, is on Mount Oread, the highest elevation in Lawrence.

title: University of Kansas
text: Two branch campuses are in the Kansas City metropolitan area: the Edwards Campus in Overland Park, and the university's medical school and hospital in Kansas City.

title: University of Kansas
text: There are also educational and research sites in Parsons, Topeka, Garden City, Hays, and Leavenworth, and branches of the medical school in Wichita and Salina.

title: University of Kansas
text: The university is one of the 62 members of the Association of American Universities.

title: Kansas City jazz
text: Kansas City jazz is a style of jazz that developed in Kansas City, Kansas and Kansas City, Missouri and the surrounding Kansas City Metropolitan Area during the 1930s and marked the transition from the structured big band style to the musical improvisation style of Bebop.

title: Kansas City jazz
text: The hard-swinging, bluesy transition style is bracketed by Count Basie who in 1929 signed with the Bennie Moten's Kansas City Orchestra and Kansas City native Charlie Parker who was to usher in the Bebop style in the 1940s.

title: Kansas City jazz
text: According to a Kansas City website, "While New Orleans was the birthplace of jazz, America's music grew up in Kansas City".

title: Kansas City jazz
text: Kansas City is known as one of the most popular "cradles of jazz".

title: Kansas City jazz
text: Other cities include New Orleans, Chicago, St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, and New York City.

title: North Kansas City, Missouri
text: North Kansas City is a city in Clay County, Missouri, United States that despite the similarity in name to its larger counterpart, Kansas City, is an independent municipality part of the Kansas City metropolitan area.

title: North Kansas City, Missouri
text: The population was 4,208 at the 2010 census.

title: North Kansas City, Missouri
text: Originally a northern suburb across the Missouri River from Kansas City, Missouri, it is now almost completely surrounded by Kansas City, which has annexed far to the north of North Kansas City's northern city limits.

title: North Kansas City, Missouri
text: North Kansas City also adjoins the small municipality of Avondale.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: Kansas City Scout is one of the United States' largest electronic traffic management systems.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: It was created in 2000 as part of a bi-state initiative between the Missouri Department of Transportation and the Kansas Department of Transportation to provide this system for the Kansas City Metropolitan Area, which is in both Missouri and Kansas (the anchor city of Kansas City is in Missouri).

title: Kansas City Scout
text: The project's cost was $43 million.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: Of that amount, the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) contributed 80-90 percent of the project cost.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: KDOT and MoDOT shared the remaining cost.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: The system employs a system of electronic boards placed on major highways throughout the metropolitan area that display traffic information whenever information needs to be displayed (due to an accident, lane closure, highway closure etc.), and the system also has cameras on those billboards to automatically detect traffic problems.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: While the system has extensive coverage of highways in the Kansas City Metropolitan Area it still has much more to cover.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: Since it would be too expensive to cover all the major highways in the Kansas City metro (which has more miles of highway per person than any other metropolitan area in the United States), studies were conducted to determine which highways or segments of highways have priority due to higher accident rates.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: Since the project's beginning, it has expanded greatly, and will continue to expand.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: Future plans are to extend coverage to I-635 and cover I-435 even more (especially in the northern areas of the metro) as well as other major city highways.

title: Kansas City Scout
text: It was named after the iconic Kansas City Scout Statue that exists in Penn Valley Park, overlooking Downtown Kansas City.

title: Gone in 60 Seconds (2000 film)
text: Gone in 60 Seconds is a 2000 American action heist film, starring Nicolas Cage, Angelina Jolie, Giovanni Ribisi, Christopher Eccleston, Robert Duvall, Vinnie Jones, and Will Patton.

title: Gone in 60 Seconds (2000 film)
text: The film was directed by Dominic Sena, written by Scott Rosenberg, and produced by Jerry Bruckheimer, producer of "The Rock" and "Con Air" (both of which starred Cage) and "Armageddon" (which starred Patton), and is a loose remake of the 1974 H.B. Halicki film of the same name.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: Deadfall is a 1993 crime drama film directed by Christopher Coppola.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: Coppola co-wrote the script with Nick Vallelonga.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: The film stars Michael Biehn, Nicolas Cage, Charlie Sheen, James Coburn, and Peter Fonda.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: It is also the prime influence on the song 'Deadfall', written by the American hardcore punk band Snot.

title: Deadfall (1993 film)
text: A prequel/sequel, "Arsenal", starring Nicolas Cage as his character Eddie King, was released in 2017.

title: Time to Kill (1989 film)
text: Time to Kill (Italian: Tempo di uccidere ) is a 1989 Italian drama film starring Nicolas Cage and Italian actors Ricky Tognazzi and Giancarlo Giannini .

title: Time to Kill (1989 film)
text: It is directed by Giuliano Montaldo.

title: Time to Kill (1989 film)
text: The film is set in 1936, when Ethiopia was an Italian colony, and was filmed in Zimbabwe.

title: Time to Kill (1989 film)
text: It is based on the novel with the same name written by Ennio Flaiano.

title: The Family Man
text: The Family Man is a 2000 American romantic comedy-drama film directed by Brett Ratner, written by David Diamond and David Weissman, and starring Nicolas Cage and Téa Leoni.

title: The Family Man
text: Cage's production company, Saturn Films, helped produce the film.

title: The Family Man
text: The film centers on a man who sees what could have been had he made a different decision 13 years prior.

title: Drive Angry
text: Drive Angry is a 2011 American fantasy action film starring Nicolas Cage and Amber Heard, and directed by Patrick Lussier.

title: Drive Angry
text: It was released on February 25, 2011.

title: Drive Angry
text: Shot in 3-D, the film was met with a mixed reception and grossed almost $29 million.

title: Season of the Witch (2011 film)
text: Season of the Witch is a 2011 American historical fantasy adventure film starring Nicolas Cage and Ron Perlman and directed by Dominic Sena with extensive uncredited reshoots by Brett Ratner.

title: Season of the Witch (2011 film)
text: Cage and Perlman star as Teutonic Knights, who return from the Crusades to find their fatherland ruined by the Black Death.

title: Season of the Witch (2011 film)
text: Two church elders accuse a girl (Claire Foy) of being a witch responsible for the destruction; they command the two knights to transport the girl to a monastery so the monks can lift her curse from the land.

title: Season of the Witch (2011 film)
text: The film draws inspiration from the 1957 film "The Seventh Seal".

title: Season of the Witch (2011 film)
text: It reunited Sena and Cage who had previously worked together on "Gone in 60 Seconds".

title: Bangkok Dangerous (2008 film)
text: Bangkok Dangerous is a 2008 crime thriller film written and directed by the Pang Brothers, and starring Nicolas Cage.

title: Bangkok Dangerous (2008 film)
text: It is a remake of the Pangs' 1999 debut "Bangkok Dangerous", a Thai film, for which Cage's production company, Saturn Films, purchased the remake rights.

title: City of Angels (film)
text: City of Angels is a 1998 American romantic fantasy film directed by Brad Silberling and starring Nicolas Cage and Meg Ryan.

title: City of Angels (film)
text: Set in Los Angeles, California, the film is a loose remake of Wim Wenders' 1987 film "Wings of Desire" ("Der Himmel über Berlin"), which was set in Berlin.

title: City of Angels (film)
text: As with the original, "City of Angels" tells the story of an angel (Cage) who falls in love with a mortal woman (Ryan), and wishes to become human in order to be with her.

title: City of Angels (film)
text: With the guidance of a man (Dennis Franz) who has already made the transition from immortality, the angel falls and discovers the human experience.

title: It Could Happen to You (1994 film)
text: It Could Happen to You is a 1994 American romantic comedy-drama film starring Nicolas Cage and Bridget Fonda.

title: It Could Happen to You (1994 film)
text: It is the story of New York City police officer (Cage) who wins the lottery and splits his winnings with a waitress (Fonda).

title: It Could Happen to You (1994 film)
text: This basic premise was inspired by a real-life incident.

title: Ungod
text: Ungod is the debut album released in 1994 on Columbia Records by the American industrial rock band Stabbing Westward.

title: Ungod
text: The album was recorded in six weeks of 1993 in Chiswick, England, and released on February 15, 1994.

title: Ungod
text: With adequate album sales and touring with the likes of Depeche Mode a second album was warranted, "Wither Blister Burn & Peel".

title: Ungod
text: The guitar line in the chorus of the song "Ungod" was later used in Filter's song "Hey Man, Nice Shot."

title: Ungod
text: Stuart Zechman, who was also playing guitar for Filter at the time, took the riff and showed it to Stabbing Westward who ended up using it as well.

title: Ungod
text: The song "Nothing" appeared in the "Bad Boys" movie starring Will Smith, Martin Lawrence and Téa Leoni, but was not featured on the official soundtrack album.

title: Ungod
text: The song also accompanied the credits of the film "Johnny Mnemonic" and was included on the film's soundtrack, along with the song "Lost".

title: Ungod
text: "Lost", "Lies" and "Can't Happen Here" were used in the film "Mortal Kombat", but Stabbing Westward refused to include it in the official soundtrack.

title: Ungod
text: The "Thread Mix" of "Violent Mood Swings" was included in the Clerks soundtrack.

title: Guns N' Roses discography
text: Guns N' Roses is an American hard rock band formed in Los Angeles, California in 1985 by members of Hollywood Rose and L.A. Guns.

title: Guns N' Roses discography
text: The band has released six studio albums, two live albums, two compilation albums, two extended plays, seven video albums, eighteen singles, twenty four music videos and one video single.

title: Guns N' Roses discography
text: Guns N' Roses signed a deal with Geffen Records in 1986, after the independently released EP "Live ?!

title: Guns N' Roses discography
text: *@ Like a Suicide" a year before.

title: Guns N' Roses discography
text: Its debut studio album "Appetite for Destruction" was released in 1987, reached the top of the "Billboard" 200 and sold 18 million units in the United States and approximately 33 million units worldwide.

title: Get Christie Love!
text: Get Christie Love!

title: Get Christie Love!
text: is a 1974 made-for-television film and subsequent crime drama TV series starring Teresa Graves as an undercover female police detective who is determined to overthrow a drug ring.

title: Get Christie Love!
text: This film is based on Dorothy Uhnak's crime-thriller novel "The Ledger".

title: Get Christie Love!
text: However, the main character "Christie Opara"—a white, New York Police detective—was dropped completely and "Christie Love" emerged.

title: End of Days (film)
text: End of Days is a 1999 American fantasy action horror thriller film directed by Peter Hyams and starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Gabriel Byrne, Robin Tunney, Kevin Pollak, Rod Steiger, CCH Pounder, and Udo Kier.

title: End of Days (film)
text: The film follows former New York Police Department detective Jericho Cane (Schwarzenegger) after he saves a banker (Byrne) from an assassin, finds himself embroiled in a religious conflict, and must protect an innocent young woman (Tunney) who is chosen by evil forces to conceive the Antichrist with Satan.

title: Steven Adler
text: Steven Adler (born Michael Coletti; January 22, 1965) is an American musician.

title: Steven Adler
text: He is best known as the former drummer and co-songwriter of the hard rock band Guns N' Roses, with whom he achieved worldwide success in the late 1980s.

title: Steven Adler
text: Adler was fired from Guns N' Roses over his heroin addiction in 1990, following which he reformed his old band Road Crew and briefly joined BulletBoys, which both proved unsuccessful.

title: Steven Adler
text: During the 2000s, Adler was the drummer of the band Adler's Appetite, and from 2012, he had held the same position in the band Adler.

title: Steven Adler
text: In early 2017, Steven Adler declared that he has no intention to continue with the band, and that the band has now dissolved, and the reason is his lack of interest in performing during poorly attended concerts.

title: Steven Adler
text: He appeared on the second and fifth seasons of the reality TV show "Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew", as well as on the first season of its spin-off "Sober House".

title: Steven Adler
text: He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2012 as a member of Guns N' Roses.

title: Faction Punk
text: Faction With Jason Ellis is an uncensored hard rock, punk, hip hop, and heavy metal music mixed channel on Siruis XM Satellite Radio.

title: Faction Punk
text: Until mid-July 2017, Faction appeared on Sirius XM channel 41.

title: Faction Punk
text: In mid-July 2017, Faction was temporarily replaced by Guns N Roses radio.

title: Faction Punk
text: After August 16, 2017, channel 41 was rebranded to Turbo, Sirius XM's channel for hard rock from the 1990s and 2000s.

title: Faction Punk
text: Faction moved to channel 314, Turbo's previous channel.

title: Faction Punk
text: Faction is currently available on select Sirius XM radios, Sirius XM streaming, and the Sirius XM smartphone app.

title: Hammerjack's
text: Hammerjacks Concert Hall and Nightclub was a large concert hall in downtown Baltimore through the 1980s and into the 1990s owned by Louis J. Principio III The club attracted many big-name national acts, but also showcased many rising stars in the music world.

title: Hammerjack's
text: The bands ranged from punk, glam, and heavy metal acts most commonly associated with the venue (e.g., Guns n Roses, Kix, Ratt, Skid Row or Extreme) to pop (e.g., Badfinger) and alternative rock groups (e.g., Goo Goo Dolls).

title: Hammerjack's
text: The club was often frequented by hard core patrons and musicians donning big hair, leather, lace, spandex, and heavy makeup, and was considered a "hard rock shrine."

title: Hammerjack's
text: Hamerjacks, however, attracted audiences with other attire as well.

title: Hammerjack's
text: It was torn down on June 12, 1997 to make way for M&T Bank Stadium parking lot.

title: Hammerjack's
text: Hammerjacks was billed as "The largest nightclub on the east coast."

title: The Recycler
text: Born in 1973, and relaunched in 2010 as a national website, The Recycler classified newspaper was one of the first online classified sites on the web and helped to launch the careers of many Los Angeles bands including Guns N Roses, Metallica, and Motley Crue.

title: The Recycler
text: The company was sold by the Los Angeles Times to Target Media Partners in 2007 is now located in North Hollywood, California.

title: Last Action Hero
text: Last Action Hero is a 1993 American fantasy action comedy film directed and produced by John McTiernan.

title: Last Action Hero
text: It is a satire of the action genre and associated clichés, containing several parodies of action films in the form of films within the film.

title: Last Action Hero
text: The film stars Arnold Schwarzenegger as Jack Slater, a Los Angeles police detective within the "Jack Slater" action film franchise.

title: Last Action Hero
text: Austin O'Brien co-stars as a boy magically transported into the "Slater" universe.

title: Last Action Hero
text: Schwarzenegger also served as the film's executive producer and plays himself as the actor portraying Jack Slater, and Charles Dance plays an assassin who escapes from the "Slater" world into the real world.

title: True Lies
text: True Lies is a 1994 American action film written, co-produced and directed by James Cameron, starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jamie Lee Curtis, Tom Arnold, Art Malik, Tia Carrere, Bill Paxton, Eliza Dushku, Grant Heslov and Charlton Heston.

title: True Lies
text: It is a loose remake of the 1991 French comedy film "La Totale!

title: True Lies
text: " The film follows U.S. government agent Harry Tasker (Schwarzenegger), who balances his life as a spy with his familial duties.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger filmography
text: Arnold Schwarzenegger is an actor who has appeared in over 30 films, and has also ventured into directing and producing.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger filmography
text: He began his acting career primarily with small roles in film and television.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger filmography
text: For his first film role, he was credited as "Arnold Strong", but was credited with his birth name thereafter.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger filmography
text: He has appeared mainly in action, and comedy films.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger filmography
text: In addition to films and television, he has appeared in music videos for AC/DC, Bon Jovi, and Guns N' Roses.

title: Pershing Square Capital Management
text: Pershing Square Capital Management is an American hedge fund management company founded and run by Bill Ackman, located at 888 7th Avenue in New York.

title: 888 7th Avenue
text: 888 7th Avenue is a 628 ft (191m) tall modern-style office skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan which was completed in 1969 and has 46 floors.

title: 888 7th Avenue
text: Emery Roth & Sons designed the building, which is tied with Central Park Place for the 65th tallest building in New York City.

title: 888 7th Avenue
text: It currently carries the Vornado Realty Trust corporate headquarters.

title: 888 7th Avenue
text: Previously known as the Arlen Building, its namesake being the company responsible for its construction, Arlen Realty & Development Corporation.

title: 888 7th Avenue
text: The Red Eye Grill is located in the building at street level.

title: Villard (imprint)
text: Villard, also known as Villard Books, is a publishing imprint of Random House, one of the largest publishing companies in the world.

title: Villard (imprint)
text: It was founded in 1983.

title: Villard (imprint)
text: Villard began as an independent imprint of Random House and is currently a sub-imprint of Ballantine Books, itself an imprint of Random House.

title: Villard (imprint)
text: It was named after a Stanford White brownstone mansion on Madison Avenue that was the home of Random House for twenty years.

title: Random House Tower
text: The Random House Tower, also known as the Park Imperial Apartments, is a 52-story mixed-use tower in New York City, United States, that is used as the headquarters of book publisher Random House and a luxury apartment complex.

title: Random House Tower
text: The book publisher entrance is on Broadway and goes up to 27 floors, while the apartment complex entrance is on West 56th Street.

title: Carl B. Stokes United States Courthouse
text: The Carl B. Stokes Federal Court House Building is a skyscraper located in downtown Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Carl B. Stokes United States Courthouse
text: It is also known as the Carl B. Stokes Federal Court House Tower, Federal Court House Tower, and the Stokes Tower.

title: Carl B. Stokes United States Courthouse
text: The 23-story building is 430 ft tall and is located at the corner of Huron Road and Superior Avenue.

title: Carl B. Stokes United States Courthouse
text: It is currently the fourth tallest United States courthouse in the country.

title: South Phoenix
text: South Phoenix is a region of Phoenix, Arizona, with the boundaries of the Gila River Indian Community to the south and west, 48th Street or Interstate-10 (Phoenix/Tempe and Phoenix/Chandler borders) to the east, and the Salt River to the north.

title: South Phoenix
text: This area includes Phoenix's following Urban Villages: South Mountain Village (aka South Mountain District) along with Laveen Village and Ahwatukee Village.

title: South Phoenix
text: The area is sometimes simply referred to as "the Southside" by its residents.

title: South Phoenix
text: Major arterial east-west streets include Broadway Road, Southern Avenue, Baseline Road, Dobbins Road, Elliott Road, Warner Road, Chandler Boulevard, and Pecos Road, most of which connect South Phoenix with the suburbs of Tempe and Chandler.

title: South Phoenix
text: Major arterial south-north streets include 24th Street, 16th Street, 7th Street, Central Avenue, 7th Avenue, and 19th Avenue connecting South Mountain Village to Central and North Phoenix; 27th Avenue, 35th Avenue, 43rd Avenue, 51st Avenue, 59th Avenue, 67th Avenue, and 75th Avenue connecting Laveen to west Phoenix; and 32nd Street, 40th Street, and 48th Street connecting South Mountain Village to east Phoenix and Tempe.

title: Real estate benchmarking
text: Real estate benchmarking is the standard of measurement used to analyze the financial characteristics of a real estate investment property.

title: Real estate benchmarking
text: In the general sense, real estate benchmarking refers to the comparison of potential real estate investment properties against a predetermined framework of measurement.

title: Real estate benchmarking
text: In a narrow sense, the term real estate benchmarking refers to the specific real estate indicators used to measure the real estate properties.

title: Hounsfield Heights/Briar Hill, Calgary
text: Hounsfield Heights/Briar Hill is an inner suburban neighbourhood in northwest Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

title: Hounsfield Heights/Briar Hill, Calgary
text: Located north of the Hillhurst and West Hillhurst communities, the boundaries of the district are 16th Avenue N (Trans-Canada Highway)to the north; 14th Street W to the east; Lane north of 7th Avenue N to 19th Street W and 8th Avenue N to the south; and Crowchild Trail, 12th Avenue N, Juniper Road, and 22nd Street W to the west.

title: Hounsfield Heights/Briar Hill, Calgary
text: Lions Park C-Train station is located within the community.

title: Hounsfield Heights/Briar Hill, Calgary
text: The community is built on an escarpment and is popular for its views of downtown to the south and the Rocky Mountains to the west.

title: Real estate technology
text: Real Estate Technology or Property Technology, often referred to as ("RE Tech") or ("Proptech"), is an economic industry composed of companies which use technology to make real estate transactions more efficient.

title: Real estate technology
text: Real estate technology is a sub-category under financial technology as real estate is an asset class which represents a significant investment.

title: Real estate technology
text: Besides for own stay, there are investors who generate income and capital gains by investing in different categories of Real Estate properties over time - They are broadly residential, commercial and industrial.

title: Real estate technology
text: Historically used as a more tactical investment or for providing portfolio alpha, real estate has been used as part of a long-term core strategy due to increased market efficiency and increasing concerns about the future long-term variability of stock and bond returns.

title: Real estate technology
text: In fact, real estate is known for its ability to serve as a portfolio diversifier and inflation hedge.

title: Sir Matt Busby Sports Complex
text: The Sir Matt Busby Sports Complex is a public leisure centre located in Bellshill, North Lanarkshire, Scotland.

title: Sir Matt Busby Sports Complex
text: It is named in honour of Sir Matt Busby, the football manager who was born in Bellshill in 1909, managed Manchester United from 1945 to 1969 and died in 1994.

title: 1995–96 Manchester United F.C. season
text: The 1995–96 season was Manchester United's fourth season in the Premier League, and their 21st consecutive season in the top division of English football.

title: 1995–96 Manchester United F.C. season
text: United finished the season by becoming the first English team to win the Double (league title and FA Cup) twice.

title: 1995–96 Manchester United F.C. season
text: Their triumph was made all the more remarkable by the fact that Alex Ferguson had sold experienced players Paul Ince, Mark Hughes and Andrei Kanchelskis before the start of the season, and not made any major signings.

title: 1995–96 Manchester United F.C. season
text: Instead, he had drafted in young players like Nicky Butt, David Beckham, Paul Scholes and the Neville brothers, Gary and Phil.

title: Alex Ferguson
text: Sir Alexander Chapman Ferguson, CBE (born 31 December 1941) is a Scottish former football manager and player who managed Manchester United from 1986 to 2013.

title: Alex Ferguson
text: He is regarded by many players, managers and analysts to be one of the greatest and most successful managers of all time.

title: David Beckham Academy
text: The David Beckham Academy was a football school founded by England international David Beckham in 2005.

title: David Beckham Academy
text: In 2009 it operated in two locations: in London, United Kingdom, and in Los Angeles, California, United States.

title: David Beckham Academy
text: The academy pulled out of the London site at the end of the lease in October 2009, and the California branch closed soon after.

title: David Beckham's Soccer USA
text: David Beckham's Soccer USA was a football highlights and general discussion show presented by Tim Lovejoy and produced and broadcast in the United Kingdom by Five.

title: David Beckham's Soccer USA
text: The show began following David Beckham's move to Los Angeles Galaxy, and Beckham often contributes to the show in the form of Interviews. Each week there was a special guest in the studio, usually a British sports personality, to whom Lovejoy chatted about their career and their views on Major League Soccer.

title: David Beckham's Soccer USA
text: A slightly different version of the show hosted by Natalie Pinkham and completely devoid of any content derived from British studio footage was broadcast in the USA on Fox Soccer Channel.

title: 1996 FA Charity Shield
text: The 1996 FA Charity Shield (also known as the Littlewoods FA Charity Shield for sponsorship reasons) was the 74th FA Charity Shield, an annual football match played between the winners of the previous season's Premier League and FA Cup competitions.

title: 1996 FA Charity Shield
text: The match was played on 11 August 1996 at Wembley Stadium and contested by Manchester United, who had won the Double of Premier League and FA Cup in 1995–96, and Newcastle United, who had finished as runners-up in the Premier League.

title: 1996 FA Charity Shield
text: Manchester United won the match 4–0 with goals from Eric Cantona, Nicky Butt, David Beckham and Roy Keane.

title: Joshua Parlby
text: Joshua Parlby (born 1855 in Longton, Staffordshire) was an English football manager who managed Manchester City in the 1890s.

title: Ernest Mangnall
text: James Ernest Mangnall (4 January 1866 – 13 January 1932) was an English football manager who started his career with Burnley and managed Manchester United between 1903–1912 and then went on to manage Manchester City from 1912–1924, and is the only man to date to have managed both clubs.

title: The Class of '92
text: The Class of '92 is a 2013 British documentary film, released on 1 December 2013.

title: The Class of '92
text: The film centres on the rise of six young Manchester United footballers – David Beckham, Nicky Butt, Ryan Giggs, Gary Neville, Phil Neville and Paul Scholes – and details their careers for Manchester United starting in 1992.

title: Matt Busby
text: Sir Alexander Matthew Busby, CBE, KCSG (26 May 1909 – 20 January 1994) was a Scottish football player and manager, who managed Manchester United between 1945 and 1969 and again for the second half of the 1970–71 season.

title: Matt Busby
text: He is widely regarded as one of the greatest managers of all time.

title: Matt Busby
text: His managerial records and longevity at the helm of Manchester United are surpassed only by Sir Alex Ferguson.

title: Fishing Lake
text: Fishing Lake is a lake in the Canadian province of Saskatchewan.

title: Fishing Lake
text: The lake is located between highway 5 and highway 16, 22 km north of the town of Foam Lake, Saskatchewan, and 24 km east of the town of Wadena, Saskatchewan.

title: Fishing Lake
text: The lake does not have an effective outlet channel, and so is prone to flooding.

title: Fishing Lake
text: Record floods in 2007 resulted in a plan by the Government of Saskatchewan to lower the level of the lake by digging a drainage channel.

title: Fishing Lake
text: The Fishing Lake First Nation opposed this plan, and instead flood control berms were constructed.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: Neosho State Fishing Lake, also known as Lake McKinley is located in the state of Kansas.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: Located 5 mi north on highway 59 and 4 mi east on 40th Rd from the city of Parsons, Kansas, USA.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: Construction of this lake was completed in 1927.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: The lake covers 92 acre of water.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: There are 124 public use acres surrounding the lake.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: Fishing, camping, and picnicking are popular activities.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: The park has a shelter house, fishing piers, picnic tables, barbecue grills, vault toilets and water hydrant.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: Below Lake McKinley dam is a catch and release youth fishing pond for anglers age 15 and under when with an accompanying adult.

title: Neosho State Fishing Lake
text: The lake is operated by the Kansas Department of Wildlife and Parks.

title: Higgins Lake
text: Higgins Lake is a large recreational and fishing lake in Roscommon County, in the U.S. state of Michigan.

title: Higgins Lake
text: The 9,900 acre (40 km2) lake is known for its deep, clear waters and is the 10th largest in Michigan with a shoreline of 21 mi .

title: Higgins Lake
text: It is named after Sylvester Higgins, the first chief of the topographical department of the Michigan Geological Survey.

title: Higgins Lake
text: It has a maximum width of 4 mi and a length of 7 mi with a maximum depth of 135 ft .

title: Higgins Lake
text: The mean depth is 44 ft and the lake contains almost 20 billion cubic feet (570 million m3) of water.

title: Higgins Lake
text: Its retention time is about 12.5 years.

title: Higgins Lake
text: The lake's watershed covers 19,000 acres (77 km2).

title: Higgins Lake
text: The twin-lobed lake receives half of its water from submerged springs, six percent from incoming streams, and the remainder from direct rainfall and runoff.

title: Higgins Lake
text: It drains into Marl Lake by the Cut River which runs into Houghton Lake and eventually to Lake Michigan.

title: Higgins Lake
text: A mile north of the lake, water flows into the Lake Huron watershed.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: Shawnee State Fishing Lake is approximately eight miles northwest of Topeka, Kansas, and is in northern Shawnee County, Kansas.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: This lake is sometimes confused with Lake Shawnee, on the east side of Topeka.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: It is a 135 acre surface area lake with a maximum depth of 25 ft .

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: This is a manmade freshwater lake, which was constructed in the late 1960s.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: The lake is widest at the dam, which is at the south end of the lake.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: It can be reached by a number of roads.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: The only asphalted road reaching it is on the southeast corner.

title: Shawnee State Fishing Lake
text: To the north is 94th Street and on the west side is Humphrey Road.

title: Brown State Fishing Lake
text: Brown State Fishing Lake (sometimes also known as Brown State Fishing Lake And Wildlife Area) is a protected area in Brown County, Kansas in the United States.

title: Brown State Fishing Lake
text: The lake is 62 acres (0.25 km2) in area and up to 13 feet (4 m) deep.

title: Brown State Fishing Lake
text: The area was formerly known as Brown County State Park, and is 8 miles (13 km) east of Hiawatha, Kansas.

title: Osage State Fishing Lake
text: Osage State Fishing Lake is located in northern Osage County, Kansas.

title: Osage State Fishing Lake
text: It is a mile east of US 75.

title: Osage State Fishing Lake
text: Scranton, Kansas, is to the lake's northwest and Overbrook, Kansas, is to the northeast.

title: Osage State Fishing Lake
text: Osage Lake is a freshwater man-made lake, constructed in 1955.

title: Osage State Fishing Lake
text: It has a surface area of 140 acres, The parkland in which the lake is contained has 366 acreas of land, mostly tall grass prairie with numerous wooded areas.

title: Osage State Fishing Lake
text: The lake is owned by the State of Kansas.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: Higgins Lake is a small unincorporated community along the southern and western shores of Higgins Lake, a recreational and fishing lake in Roscommon County, in the U.S. state of Michigan.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: Higgins Lake is the name of the post office for the area, with ZIP code 48627.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: This ZIP code includes several other small communities and locales along the shores of the lake, including (moving counter-clockwise around the lake) Hillcrest, Lyon Manor, Detroit Park, Cook Corner, Sharps Corner, Almeda Beach, Oak Grove, Ritz Corner, Pine Bluffs, and Cottage Grove.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: Since all have Higgins Lake as a postal address, they are often all considered as part of the Higgins Lake community.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: The lake is situated on the boundary between Lyon Township on the west and Gerrish Township on the east.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: US 127 passes on the west side of the lake while I-75 and M-18 both pass a few miles to the east.

title: Higgins Lake, Michigan
text: Houghton Lake is just a few miles to the south.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: Wilson Lake is located in Iron County, outside of Wilson Creek Flowage.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: It is one of seven lakes in the state with the name Wilson Lake.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: This particular lake is a popular fishing lake 5 mi from the town of Mercer.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: With three bays, it has two islands and water feed and drain in the South Bay of the lake.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: The public boat landing is in the Main Bay on the west side of the lake.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: The North Bay has the most marsh vegetation.

title: Wilson Lake (Iron County, Wisconsin)
text: There are many cabins located on the lake for residents and vacationers to the North Woods.

title: Narrow Hills Provincial Park
text: Narrow Hills Provincial Park is provincial park in Saskatchewan, Canada.

title: Narrow Hills Provincial Park
text: It contains a series of recreational facilities and a variety of lakes within its boundaries.

title: Narrow Hills Provincial Park
text: These include the Gem Lakes, Lower Fishing Lake, Upper Fishing Lake and others.

title: Commanda Lake
text: Commanda Lake (or Lake Commanda) is a lake in central Ontario, Canada.

title: Commanda Lake
text: Located on the border between Patterson Township and Pringle Township, in the Almaguin Highlands region of the District of Parry Sound, it is fed by Gee Creek, Commanda Creek and Beaudry Creek and is drained by the Restoule River.

title: Commanda Lake
text: The Lake is shaped like the number "3", its middle spur is called Deep Bay.

title: Commanda Lake
text: The lake is home to one permanent island, located off a point in its east.

title: Commanda Lake
text: This is a mud bottom lake and its water is "tea coloured."

title: Commanda Lake
text: On the north shore of the lake is the community of Restoule, but cottages line many of the shore lines.

title: Commanda Lake
text: Lots of crown land also surrounds the lake shore making it a very peaceful lake for people of all ages to enjoy.

title: Commanda Lake
text: This lake has one public boat launch towards the southern end of the lake accessible on Commanda Lake Road.

title: Commanda Lake
text: The lake is located at an altitude of 222 m (729 ft) above sea level.

title: Commanda Lake
text: The lake is home to the Northern pike, Walleye, Smallmouth bass and Largemouth bass species of fish.

title: Commanda Lake
text: Ice gets thick in the winter making this lake an all year round fishing lake.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's soccer
text: The Vermont Catamounts men's soccer team represents the University of Vermont in all NCAA Division I men's college soccer competitions.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's soccer
text: The team competes in the America East Conference.

title: 2014–15 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2014–15 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont during the 2014–15 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2014–15 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts, led by fourth year head coach John Becker, played their home games at Patrick Gym and were members of the America East Conference.

title: 2014–15 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 20–14, 12–4 in America East play to finish in a tie for second place.

title: 2014–15 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They advanced to the semifinals of the America East Tournament where they lost to Stony Brook.

title: 2014–15 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They were invited to the College Basketball Invitational where they defeated Hofstra in the first round and Radford in the quarterfinals before losing in the semifinals to Louisiana–Monroe.

title: 2015–16 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2015–16 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont during the 2015–16 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2015–16 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts, led by fifth year head coach John Becker, played their home games at Patrick Gym and were members of the America East Conference.

title: 2015–16 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 23–14, 11–5 in America East play to finish in a tie for third place.

title: 2015–16 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They Maine and New Hampshire to advance to the championship game of the America East Tournament where they lost to Stony Brook.

title: 2015–16 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They were invited to the College Basketball Invitational where they defeated Western Carolina and Seattle to advance to the seminfinals where they lost to Nevada.

title: 2012–13 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2012–13 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont during the 2012–13 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2012–13 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts, led by second year head coach John Becker, played their home games at Patrick Gym and were members of the America East Conference.

title: 2012–13 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 21–12, 11–5 in America East play to finish in a tie for second place.

title: 2012–13 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They advanced to the championship game of the America East Tournament where they lost to Albany.

title: 2012–13 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They were invited to the 2013 College Basketball Invitational where they lost in the first round to Santa Clara.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's basketball
text: The Vermont Catamounts Basketball team is the basketball team that represents the University of Vermont in Burlington, Vermont.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's basketball
text: The school's team currently competes in the America East Conference and plays its home games at Patrick Gym.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's basketball
text: The team has reached the NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament six times, in 2003, 2004, 2005, 2010, 2012, and 2017.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's basketball
text: UVM famously upset Syracuse University in the first round of the 2005 tournament.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's basketball
text: The Catamounts are coached by John Becker.

title: 2010–11 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2010–11 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont in the 2010–11 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2010–11 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts won their third consecutive America East Conference regular season Championship but lost in the semifinals of the conference tournament to Stony Brook.

title: 2010–11 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts got invited to the National Invitation Tournament but lost in the first round to Cleveland State, 63–60.

title: 2013–14 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2013–14 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont during the 2013–14 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2013–14 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts, led by third year head coach John Becker, played their home games at Patrick Gym and were members of the America East Conference.

title: 2013–14 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 22–11, 15–1 in America East play to win the America East regular season championship.

title: 2013–14 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They advanced to the semifinals of the America East Conference Tournament where they lost to Albany.

title: 2013–14 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: As a regular season conference champion who failed to win their conference tournament, the received an automatic bid to the National Invitation Tournament where they lost in the first round to Georgia.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's ice hockey
text: The Vermont Catamounts men's ice hockey team is a National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I college ice hockey program that represents the University of Vermont.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's ice hockey
text: The Catamounts are a member of Hockey East, joining in 2005 after competing in ECAC Hockey from 1974-2005.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's ice hockey
text: They play home games at Gutterson Fieldhouse in Burlington, Vermont.

title: Vermont Catamounts men's ice hockey
text: Vermont has appeared in the NCAA Men's Hockey Championship five times since making the move to Division I in 1974-75 including trips to the Frozen Four in 1996 and 2009.

title: 2011–12 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2011–12 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont during the 2011–12 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2011–12 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts, led by first year head coach John Becker, played their home games at Patrick Gym and are members of the America East Conference.

title: 2011–12 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 24–12, 13–3 in America East play to finish in second place.

title: 2011–12 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They were champions of the America East Basketball Tournament and earned the conference's automatic bid into the 2012 NCAA Tournament.

title: 2011–12 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They defeated Lamar in the "First Four" round before falling to North Carolina in the second round.

title: 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team represented the University of Vermont during the 2016–17 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: The Catamounts, led by sixth-year head coach John Becker, played their home games at Patrick Gym in Burlington, Vermont and were members of the America East Conference.

title: 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 29–6, 16–0 in America East play to win the America East regular season championship.

title: 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: In the America East Tournament, they defeated Maine, New Hampshire and Albany to win the tournament championship.

title: 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: As a result, they received the conference's automatic bid to the NCAA Tournament.

title: 2016–17 Vermont Catamounts men's basketball team
text: As a No. 13 seed in the Midwest region, they lost to No. 4-seeded Purdue in the first round.

title: Mignon
text: Mignon is an "opéra comique" (or opera in its second version) in three acts by Ambroise Thomas.

title: Mignon
text: The original French libretto was by Jules Barbier and Michel Carré, based on Goethe's novel "Wilhelm Meisters Lehrjahre".

title: Mignon
text: The Italian version was translated by Giuseppe Zaffira.

title: Mignon
text: The opera is mentioned in James Joyce's "The Dead" ("Dubliners") and Willa Cather's "The Professor's House".

title: Mignon
text: Thomas's goddaughter Mignon Nevada was named after the main character.

title: Teatro Giuseppe Verdi
text: Teatro Giuseppe Verdi (the Giuseppe Verdi Theatre) is a small opera house located in a wing of the Rocca dei Marchesi Pallavicino on the Piazza Giuseppe Verdi in Busseto, Italy, a town closely associated with the life of the opera composer, Giuseppe Verdi.

title: Teatro Giuseppe Verdi
text: From the 13th century, the “rocca” or “fortress” was the family’s palace; it is now the city hall after being acquired by the municipality in 1856.

title: Teatro Giuseppe Verdi
text: The theatre opened on 15 August 1868 and seats 300.

title: Parma Airport
text: Parma Airport (Italian: "Aeroporto di Parma" , IATA: PMF, ICAO: LIMP ) is located 1.3 NM northwest of Parma, a city in the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy.

title: Parma Airport
text: The airport was opened on 5 May 1991.

title: Parma Airport
text: It is also known as Giuseppe Verdi Airport or Parma "Giuseppe Verdi" Airport, named after Giuseppe Verdi.

title: Verdi, the King of Melody
text: Giuseppe Verdi, released theatrically in the USA as The Life and Music of Giuseppe Verdi and on video as Verdi, the King of Melody, is a 1953 Italian biographical film starring Pierre Cressoy and directed by Raffaello Matarazzo.

title: Verdi, the King of Melody
text: It is based on adult life events of the composer Giuseppe Verdi.

title: Verdi, the King of Melody
text: The film was a commercial success, grossing over 957 million lire at the Italian box office.

title: Armand Castelmary
text: Armand Castelmary, real name Comte Armand de Castan, born Toulouse 16 August 1834, died New York City 10 February 1897, was a French operatic bass.

title: Armand Castelmary
text: He created roles in three major premieres at the Paris Opera – Don Diego in "L'Africaine" by Meyerbeer (1865), the Monk in Verdi's "Don Carlos" (1867), and Horatio in Ambroise Thomas's "Hamlet" (1868).

title: Armand Castelmary
text: Castelmary also appeared at opera houses in England and the United States, and died onstage at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, during a performance of "Martha" by Friedrich von Flotow.

title: Giuseppe Verdi (film)
text: Giuseppe Verdi is a 1938 Italian biographical film directed by Carmine Gallone and starring Fosco Giachetti, Gaby Morlay and Germana Paolieri.

title: Giuseppe Verdi (film)
text: The film portrays the life of the composer Giuseppe Verdi (1813-1901).

title: Giuseppe Verdi (film)
text: The casting of Giachetti as Verdi was intended to emphasise the composer's patriotism, as he had recently played patriotic roles in films such as "The White Squadron".

title: Giuseppe Verdi (film)
text: The film was made at the Cinecittà Studios in Rome.

title: Giuseppe Verdi (film)
text: The film is also known by the alternative title The Life of Giuseppe Verdi.

title: Giuseppe Verdi Monument
text: The Giuseppe Verdi Monument is a sculpture in honor of composer Giuseppe Verdi located in Verdi Square Park (between West 72nd and West 73rd streets, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway) in Manhattan, New York City.

title: Giuseppe Verdi Monument
text: The statue, by Pasquale Civiletti (1858–1952), depicts Verdi flanked by four of his most popular characters: Falstaff (on the west side of the statue of Verdi), Leonora of "La forza del destino" (south side), Aida (north side), and Otello (east side).

title: Ferdinando Provesi
text: Ferdinando Angelo Maria Provesi (1770 – 1833) was a native of Parma, Italy.

title: Ferdinando Provesi
text: He was regarded as one of the greatest Italian opera composers of the era .

title: Ferdinando Provesi
text: Provesi is best known as being an early tutor of Giuseppe Verdi when he was the "Maestro di cappella" (master of music) at the St. Bartolomeo cathedral in Busseto (the town very close to Le Roncole, the village where Verdi was born.)

title: Ferdinando Provesi
text: Provesi was also director of the municipal music school and local Philharmonic Society.

title: Ferdinando Provesi
text: He began teaching Verdi in 1824 when the future composer was 11 years old.

title: Bernhard Bötel
text: Bernhard Bötel (1883–1953) was a German operatic tenor and actor who had an active career in Germany and Austria during the first half of the 20th century.

title: Bernhard Bötel
text: He made recordings for several record labels during the early years of the recording industry, including His Master's Voice, Odeon Records, Polydor Records, Tri-Ergon, and Vox Records.

title: Bernhard Bötel
text: On the stage he sang a variety of roles in operas and operettas from leading parts to comprimario roles.

title: Bernhard Bötel
