text: It was written by White, Aaron Schroeder and Marlon Saunders, and produced by White and Jack Perry.

title: The Longer We Make Love
text: The song was recorded in two versions: as a duet with Lisa Stansfield and as another duet with Chaka Khan.

title: The Longer We Make Love
text: Both versions are in the key of G minor and received positive reviews from music critics.

title: The Longer We Make Love
text: The CD single was released in selected European countries on July 19, 1999.

title: The Longer We Make Love
text: "The Longer We Make Love" was also issued as a promotional single in the United States.

title: The Longer We Make Love
text: The song failed to make any impact on the charts.

title: Shut Up, Make Love
text: "Shut Up, Make Love" is a song by American rock band Poison; released in 2000, it was the first single presented to radio stations from their 2000 "Crack a Smile...and More!

title: Shut Up, Make Love
text: " album.

title: Shut Up, Make Love
text: The song also appears on the second promo single "Be the One" as a B-side.

title: Shut Up, Make Love
text: "Crack a Smile" is Poison's fifth studio album, released on March 14, 2000, and charting at #131 on The Billboard 200.

title: Shut Up, Make Love
text: The song was the first Poison single with lead guitarist Blues Saraceno.

title: Skyscraper National Park
text: Skyscraper National Park is the third album by Canadian singer-songwriter Hayden.

title: Skyscraper National Park
text: It was released on Hardwood Records in Canada, on Badman Recording Co. in the U.S., on Loose Music in the U.K., and on Massive!

title: Skyscraper National Park
text: in the Japan.

title: Skyscraper National Park
text: There were two limited-edition pressings of this album.

title: Skyscraper National Park
text: The first, comprising only 100 copies, was mainly for Hayden's friends and family.

title: Skyscraper National Park
text: The second, comprising 1,500 copies, was sold on Hayden's cross-Canada tour.

title: Atsushi Sakurai
text: Atsushi Sakurai (櫻井 敦司 , Sakurai Atsushi , born March 7, 1966 in Fujioka, Gunma) is a Japanese musician and singer-songwriter.

title: Atsushi Sakurai
text: He has been the vocalist of the rock band Buck-Tick since 1985, previously being their drummer from 1983.

title: Atsushi Sakurai
text: He released the solo album "Ai no Wakusei" in 2004 and was also a member of Schwein alongside Hisashi Imai (Buck-Tick), Sascha Konietzko (KMFDM) and Raymond Watts.

title: Atsushi Sakurai
text: In 2015, he formed a solo project called The Mortal.

title: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School
text: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School , is located in the northern area of Burlington, Ontario, Canada, at 3040 Tim Dobbie Drive.

title: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School
text: It is an English and French immersion school in the Halton District School Board that as of 2015 serves approximately 1400 grade 9-12 students.

title: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School
text: In its first year, Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School served approximately 600 students in grades 9–10.

title: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School
text: The school is named for Special Olympics pioneer Frank Hayden.

title: The Closer I Get
text: The Closer I Get is the second album by Canadian singer-songwriter Hayden.

title: The Closer I Get
text: It is Hayden's first international release.

title: The Closer I Get
text: In Canada it was released on Hardwood Records/Universal, while in the United States it was released on Outpost Recordings/Geffen/Universal.

title: Mild and Hazy
text: Mild and Hazy is a 7" vinyl single by Canadian singer-songwriter Hayden.

title: Mild and Hazy
text: It was released in 1996 on Hayden's own label, Hardwood Records as well as on Lunamoth.

title: Mild and Hazy
text: The cover is a photograph of Hayden as a toddler.

title: Mild and Hazy
text: The song "Gouge Away" is a cover of the Pixies, from their album "Doolittle".

title: Kyo (musician)
text: Kyo (京 , Kyō ) is a Japanese musician, poet and singer-songwriter.

title: Kyo (musician)
text: He is best known as the vocalist of the metal band Dir en grey.

title: Kyo (musician)
text: He has been with the band since its inception in 1997 and was formerly in La:Sadie's.

title: Kyo (musician)
text: Kyo was inspired to become a musician when he saw a picture of Buck-Tick vocalist Atsushi Sakurai on the desk of a junior high school classmate.

title: Kyo (musician)
text: His vocals span a tenor range.

title: Dewey Beard
text: Dewey Beard or Wasú Máza ("Iron Hail", 1858–1955) was a Minneconjou Lakota who fought in the Battle of Little Bighorn as a teenager.

title: Dewey Beard
text: After George Armstrong Custer's defeat, Wasu Maza followed Sitting Bull into exile in Canada and then back to South Dakota where he lived on the Cheyenne River Indian Reservation.

title: Dewey Beard
text: Chief Iron Hail is often mistaken by historians for Chief Iron Tail, being Lakota contemporaries with similar-sounding names.

title: Dewey Beard
text: Most biographies incorrectly report that Chief Iron Tail fought in the Battle of the Little Bighorn and that his family was killed in 1890 at Wounded Knee, when in truth it was Chief Iron Hail who suffered the loss.

title: Masami Tsuchiya
text: Masami Tsuchiya is a Japanese singer-songwriter and musician, coming to prominence in the late 1970s as the lead vocalist and guitarist in the group Ippu-Do.

title: Masami Tsuchiya
text: His subsequent output includes solo work and collaborations.

title: Masami Tsuchiya
text: Tsuchiya has worked with artists as diverse as English new wave rockers Japan and Bill Nelson, Japanese electronica composer Ryuichi Sakamoto, Duran Duran side-project Arcadia, and Japanese rock band Buck-Tick.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: Hailstorm Alley is a colloquial term referring to an area of south and central Alberta, Canada where hail storms are frequently produced.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: These storms frequently produce hail that is damaging to property.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: This area stretches from High River in southern Alberta, northward through Calgary, through Red Deer to Lacombe and then westward to Rocky Mountain House.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: It is known to be one of the worst areas in the world for damaging hail produced by thunderstorms.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: These are regarded as loose boundaries.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: While this area is common for damaging hailstorms, the reality is damaging hailstorms occur over much of central and southern Alberta every summer.

title: Hailstorm Alley
text: The City of Calgary is regarded as the hailstorm capital of Canada.

title: Alberta Hail Project
text: The Alberta Hail Project was a research project sponsored by the Alberta Research Council and Environment Canada to study hailstorm physics and dynamics in order to design and test means for suppressing hail.

title: Alberta Hail Project
text: It ran from 1956 until 1985.

title: Alberta Hail Project
text: The main instrument in this research was an S-band circularly polarized weather radar located at the Red Deer Industrial Airport in central Alberta, Canada.

title: Levasseur PL.8
text: The Levasseur PL.8 was a single engine, two-seat long-distance record-breaking biplane aircraft modified from an existing Levasseur PL.4 carrier-based reconnaissance aircraft produced in France in the 1920s.

title: Levasseur PL.8
text: Levasseur built the aircraft in 1927, specifically for pilots Charles Nungesser and François Coli for a transatlantic attempt to win the Orteig Prize.

title: Levasseur PL.8
text: Only two examples of the type were built, with the first PL.8-01 named "L'Oiseau Blanc" (The White Bird), that gained fame as Nungesser and Coli's aircraft.

title: W. E. Johns
text: William Earl Johns (5 February 189321 June 1968) was an English pilot and writer of adventure stories, usually written under the pen name Captain W. E. Johns.

title: W. E. Johns
text: He is best remembered as the creator of the ace pilot and adventurer Biggles.

title: François Coli
text: François Coli (June 5, 1881 – presumably on or after May 8, 1927) was a French pilot and navigator best known as the one-eyed flying partner of Charles Nungesser in their doomed attempt to fly the Atlantic Ocean on the aircraft known as "L'Oiseau Blanc".

title: Wooster and Davis
text: Wooster and Davis-- Lieutenant Stanton Hall Wooster (April 1, 1895 Connecticut - April 26, 1927) and Lieutenant Commander Noel Guy Davis (December 25, 1891 Salt Lake City, Utah - April 26, 1927) were two United States Navy (USN) airmen who made an attempt to fly the Atlantic Ocean from New York-to-Paris in the spring of 1927.

title: Wooster and Davis
text: The men were trying to win the $25,000 dollar Orteig Prize offered by New York hotelier Raymond Orteig for the first nonstop flight between New York and Paris.

title: Wooster and Davis
text: Competitors for the prize were French World War One ace Rene Fonck and his crew of three, USN Commander Richard Evelyn Byrd, Clarence Chamberlain and a young airmail pilot named Charles Lindbergh.

title: Wooster and Davis
text: On the Paris side of the Atlantic their competitors were another World War One French ace, Charles Nungesser, and his navigator Francois Coli.

title: Gervais Raoul Lufbery
text: Gervais Raoul Victor Lufbery (March 14, 1885 – May 19, 1918) was a French and American fighter pilot and flying ace in World War I. Because he served in both the French Air Force, and later the United States Army Air Service in World War I, he is sometimes listed alternately as a French ace or as an American ace.

title: Gervais Raoul Lufbery
text: Officially, all but one of his 17 combat victories came while flying in French units.

title: L'Oiseau Blanc
text: L'Oiseau Blanc (commonly known in the English-speaking world as The White Bird ) was a French Levasseur PL.8 biplane that disappeared in 1927, during an attempt to make the first non-stop transatlantic flight between Paris and New York City to compete for the Orteig Prize.

title: L'Oiseau Blanc
text: The aircraft was flown by French World War I aviation heroes, Charles Nungesser and François Coli.

title: L'Oiseau Blanc
text: The aircraft took off from Paris on 8 May 1927 and was last seen over Ireland.

title: L'Oiseau Blanc
text: Less than two weeks later, Charles Lindbergh successfully made the New York–Paris journey and claimed the prize, flying the "Spirit of St. Louis".

title: Charles Nungesser
text: Charles Eugène Jules Marie Nungesser, MC (15 March 1892 – presumably on or after 8 May 1927) was a French ace pilot and adventurer, best remembered as a rival of Charles Lindbergh.

title: Charles Nungesser
text: Nungesser was a renowned ace in France, ranking third highest in the country with 43 air combat victories during World War I.

title: Paul Sauvage (aviator)
text: Sergent Paul Joannes Sauvage was a French World War I flying ace credited with eight confirmed and six unconfirmed aerial victories.

title: Paul Sauvage (aviator)
text: He was originally posted to fly a Nieuport for Escadrille 65, and scored his first victory with them on 16 July 1916.

title: Paul Sauvage (aviator)
text: He became the youngest French ace on 2 October, and held that distinction until his death by anti-aircraft fire on January 7, 1917.

title: Georges Madon
text: Georges Félix Madon (July 28, 1892 – November 11, 1924) was the fourth ranked French ace pilot of the First World War.

title: Georges Madon
text: His lengthy career and wide variety of aviation experiences were remarkable.

title: L'Oiseau bleu (Metzinger)
text: L'Oiseau bleu (also known as The Blue Bird and Der Blaue Vogel) is a large oil painting created in 1912–1913 by the French artist and theorist Jean Metzinger (1883–1956); considered by Guillaume Apollinaire and André Salmon as a founder of Cubism, along with Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso.

title: L'Oiseau bleu (Metzinger)
text: "L'Oiseau bleu", one of Metzinger's most recognizable and frequently referenced works, was first exhibited in Paris at the Salon des Indépendants in the spring of 1913 (n. 2087), several months after the publication of the first (and only) Cubist manifesto, "Du «Cubisme»", written by Jean Metzinger and Albert Gleizes (1912).

title: L'Oiseau bleu (Metzinger)
text: It was subsequently exhibited at the 1913 in Berlin (titled "Der blaue Vogel", n. 287).

title: L'Oiseau bleu (Metzinger)
text: Apollinaire described "L'Oiseau bleu" as a 'very brilliant painting' and 'his most important work to date'.

title: L'Oiseau bleu (Metzinger)
text: "L'Oiseau bleu", acquired by the City of Paris in 1937, forms part of the permanent collection at the Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris.

title: Shayne Workman
text: Shayne Workman (born December 5, 1978) is an American author, actor, theatre director and stage manager.

title: Shayne Workman
text: His first work, ':A Journey to the Spirit Realm", was published in late autumn 2014.

title: Shayne Workman
text: It was later added to his anthology, "The Spirit Realm: An Anthology of Fables From The Spirit Realm".

title: Shayne Workman
text: He has also penned, The Diary Of A Vagabond King, an inspiring true account of his personal experiences over the course of two years, where he was faced with impossible odds, and tragic losses.

title: Shayne Workman
text: The royalties from the sale of the book will be going towards the creation and operation of the Blue Purity Fund created for aiding organizations with programs aimed at getting the nations homeless off the streets and back into being full members of society.

title: Hackers (film)
text: Hackers is a 1995 American crime film directed by Iain Softley and starring Jonny Lee Miller, Angelina Jolie, Renoly Santiago, Matthew Lillard, Jesse Bradford, Lorraine Bracco, and Fisher Stevens.

title: Hackers (film)
text: The film follows a group of high school hackers and their involvement in a corporate extortion conspiracy.

title: Hackers (film)
text: Made in the 1990s when the internet was unfamiliar to the general public, it reflects the ideals laid out in the Hacker Manifesto quoted in the film: "This is our world now... the world of the electron and the switch  We exist without skin color, without nationality, without religious bias... and you call us criminals.

title: Hackers (film)
text: Yes, I am a criminal.

title: Hackers (film)
text: My crime is that of curiosity."

title: Hackers (film)
text: "Hackers" has achieved cult classic status.

title: Robin Goldstein
text: Robin Goldstein is an American author, food and wine critic, and economics pundit.

title: Robin Goldstein
text: He is known for his books and articles questioning conventional wisdom and pricing in the food and wine industries, particularly a widely publicized exposé of Wine Spectator magazine, and for his writing on the Freakonomics blog.

title: Robin Goldstein
text: He is author of several books, including "The Wine Trials" (the world's bestselling guide to cheap wine), "The Beer Trials", and an upcoming book tentatively entitled "A Defense of Fast Food".

title: Robin Goldstein
text: Goldstein was also one of the subjects of "Think Like a Freak", the 2014 book by "Freakonomics" authors Steven Levitt and Stephen Dubner.

title: Robin Goldstein
text: He lives in Oakland, California.

title: Psycho Realm
text: The Psycho Realm is an American hip hop group started in 1989 by brown man & brothers Sick Jacken (Joaquin Gonzalez) and Big Duke (Gustavo Gonzalez) from the Downtown, Pico-Union area of Los Angeles.

title: Psycho Realm
text: The first recorded Psycho Realm song, "Scandalous," was released on the soundtrack of the film Mi Vida Loca in 1994.

title: Psycho Realm
text: That same year B-Real of the rap group Cypress Hill saw Psycho Realm performing at Olvera Street for an End Barrio Warfare concert.

title: Psycho Realm
text: Their performance inspired B-Real to the point that he wanted to join the group.

title: Psycho Realm
text: With this time period being the height of Cypress Hill’s career anything Cypress Hill related would get major publicity.

title: Jay Leiderman
text: Jason Scott "Jay" Leiderman (born April 12, 1971) is an American criminal defense lawyer based in Ventura, California. "

title: Jay Leiderman
text: The Atlantic" Magazine called Leiderman the "Hacktivist’s Advocate" for his work defending hacker-activists accused of computer crimes, or so-called (“Hacktivism”) especially people associated with Anonymous.

title: Jay Leiderman
text: Leiderman "keeps an encrypted chat app open at all times so he can dispense ad hoc pro bono legal advice to members of Anonymous" Buzzfeed called Leiderman "The Maserati-Driving Deadhead Lawyer Who Stands Between Hackers And Prison" and stated he was "A medical marijuana and criminal defense lawyer from Southern California  has made himself into the country’s leading defender of hackers."

title: In the Realm of the Hackers
text: In The Realm of the Hackers is a 2003 Australian documentary directed by Kevin Anderson about the prominent hacker community, centered in Melbourne, Australia in the late 1980s until early 1990.

title: In the Realm of the Hackers
text: The storyline is centered on the Australian teenagers going by the hacker names "Electron" and "Phoenix", who were members of an elite computer hacking group called 'The Realm' and hacked into some of the most secure computer networks in the world, including those of the US Naval Research Laboratory, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, a government lab charged with the security of the US nuclear stockpile, and NASA.

title: In the Realm of the Hackers
text: The film runs for 55 minutes and was inspired by the book "Underground", by Melbourne-based writer and academic Suelette Dreyfus.

title: Freakonomics Radio
text: Freakonomics Radio is an American public radio program which discusses socioeconomic issues for a general audience.

title: Freakonomics Radio
text: The show is a spin-off of the 2005 book "Freakonomics".

title: Freakonomics Radio
text: Journalist Stephen Dubner hosts the show, with economist Steven Levitt as a regular guest.

title: Freakonomics Radio
text: The show is also distributed as a podcast, and is among the most popular on iTunes.

title: Freakonomics Radio
text: Created in September 2010, it is a weekly podcast.

title: Freakonomics Radio
text: Twice a year, a series of one-hour "Freakonomics Radio" specials air on public-radio stations around the country.

title: Peter W. Smith
text: Peter W. Smith (February 23, 1936 – May 14, 2017) was an American investment banker from Chicago.

title: Peter W. Smith
text: He had a 40-year career managing corporate acquisitions and venture investments.

title: Peter W. Smith
text: He was active in Republican politics.

title: Peter W. Smith
text: In 1998 he was identified as a major financial supporter of the 1993 Troopergate story, in which several Arkansas state troopers accused U.S. President Bill Clinton of having carried out sexual dalliances while he was Governor of Arkansas.

title: Peter W. Smith
text: In 2017 he confirmed to the "Wall Street Journal" that he had tried in 2016 to contact computer hackers, including Russian hackers, in an attempt to obtain opposition research material to use against Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election.

title: Peter W. Smith
text: Ten days after speaking to the paper, he committed suicide in a hotel room, citing ill health.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: Heidi Ewing is a director, producer, and writer of documentary films.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: She and Rachel Grady founded Loki Films in 2001, and have collaborated on several documentaries together.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: She is best known as the co-director of "Jesus Camp", which was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary in 2006.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: Next came"12th & Delaware" (HBO), which premiered at the 2010 Sundance Film Festival.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: The film "casts a heart-rending light on the abortion divide" (LA Times) and was honored with a Peabody Award.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: "Detropia", a poetic look at Ewing's home town, also won several awards, including Best Editing at Sundance 2012, Outstanding Direction and Outstanding Original Score, at the 2013 Cinema Eye Honors for Nonfiction Filmmaking and a News and Documentary Emmy for editing.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: "Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You" was the opening night selection of the 2016 Sundance Film Festival and premiered on PBS American Masters on October 25, 2016.

title: Heidi Ewing
text: Other films as a director include "The Boys of Baraka", "Freakonomics", and "The Education of Mohammed Hussein".

title: Freakonomics (film)
text: Freakonomics: The Movie is a 2010 American documentary film based on the 2005 book "Freakonomics: A Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything" by economist Steven D. Levitt and writer Stephen J. Dubner.

title: Freakonomics (film)
text: The film premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival in April 2010 with a theatrical release later in the year.

title: Freakonomics (film)
text: The film received a lukewarm reception and a 65% fresh rating at Rottentomatoes.

title: Screaming Trees discography
text: The discography of Screaming Trees, an Ellensburg, Washington-based rock band, consists of seven studio albums, three compilation albums, five extended plays (EP), and six singles, though this does not include any solo material recorded by the individual members of Screaming Trees.

title: Truly
text: Truly is an American rock band formed in the wake of the grunge era.

title: Truly
text: It featured singer-guitarist Robert Roth, bassist Hiro Yamamoto, and drummer Mark Pickerel.

title: Truly
text: Yamamoto and Pickerel were founding members respectively of Soundgarden and Screaming Trees.

title: Truly
text: While not a commercially successful group like some of their Seattle contemporaries, the band lasted a decade with two studio albums to their name.

title: Screaming Trees
text: Screaming Trees was an American rock band formed in Ellensburg, Washington in 1985 by vocalist Mark Lanegan, guitarist Gary Lee Conner, bass player Van Conner and drummer Mark Pickerel.

title: Screaming Trees
text: Pickerel had been replaced by Barrett Martin by the time the band reached its most successful period.

title: Screaming Trees
text: Although widely associated with grunge, the band's sound incorporated hard rock and psychedelic elements.

title: Screaming Trees
text: During Screaming Trees' existence the band released seven studio albums, five EPs, and three compilations.

title: Change Has Come
text: Change Has Come was the only recording the Screaming Trees released through Sub Pop.

title: Change Has Come
text: Released in 1990 the Screaming Trees then moved on to a major label, Epic Records, for their next three albums - "Uncle Anesthesia", "Sweet Oblivion," and "Dust", as well as the "Something About Today" EP.

title: Beat Happening/Screaming Trees
text: Beat Happening/Screaming Trees is an EP and a one-off collaboration between Beat Happening (from Olympia, Washington) and Screaming Trees (from Ellensburg, Washington).

title: Beat Happening/Screaming Trees
text: Originally released on Homestead Records in 1988, it was later reissued as part of Beat Happening's box set "Crashing Through" in 2002.

title: Beat Happening/Screaming Trees
text: The journal of Kurt Cobain contains a draft of a letter sent to Mark Lanegan, in which he described "Polly Pereguin" as his favorite pop song of the 1980s.

title: Jamboree (Beat Happening album)
text: Jamboree is the second album by Beat Happening, released in 1988 through K Records/Rough Trade Records.

title: Jamboree (Beat Happening album)
text: All songs were produced by Steve Fisk with assistance from Screaming Trees members Mark Lanegan and Gary Lee Conner (who plays a brief guitar solo on "Midnight a Go-Go"), except "Cat Walk," produced by Patrick Maley, and "The This Many Boyfriends Club," recorded live by Rich Jensen.

title: Jamboree (Beat Happening album)
text: The album marks a darker approach to the Twee pop for which the band is known, due largely to a thicker production than is present on the group's earlier recordings and the dominance of tracks written by Calvin Johnson, while Heather Lewis only provides vocals on two songs, the uncharacteristically brash "In Between" and the more typically understated "Ask Me."

title: Jamboree (Beat Happening album)
text: At the time of the album's release, Calvin described Jamboree's sound as "dark and sexy."

title: Jamboree (Beat Happening album)
text: Still, the band retained their emphasis on exuberance over musicianship, as Bret Lunsford stated in an interview that, while recording album opener "Bewitched," his guitar string got stuck on a protruding screw and he continued to play through the song, hitting the string a bit harder until it became unstuck.

title: Mad Season (band)
text: Mad Season was an American rock supergroup formed in Seattle, Washington in 1994 by members of three popular Seattle-based bands: Alice in Chains, Pearl Jam and Screaming Trees.

title: Mad Season (band)
text: Mad Season released only one album, "Above", and is best known for the single "River of Deceit".

title: Mad Season (band)
text: The band went on a semi-permanent hiatus in 1996 due to the band members' conflicting schedules and vocalist Layne Staley's problems with substance abuse.

title: Mad Season (band)
text: Attempts were made in the late 1990s to revive the group without Staley; however, the band dissolved following the death of bassist John Baker Saunders in 1999.

title: Mad Season (band)
text: Staley died three years later of a drug overdose.

title: Mark Pickerel
text: Mark Pickerel is an American musician best known as the original drummer for the Screaming Trees, a rock group from Ellensburg, Washington, that formed in 1985.

title: Mark Pickerel
text: Other members of the band included the versatile singer Mark Lanegan and the Conner brothers.

title: Mark Pickerel
text: Pickerel played on the band's extended play and first five albums and left the group in 1992 and was replaced by Barrett Martin.

title: Van Conner
text: Van Conner (born March 17, 1967 in Apple Valley, California) is an American rock musician.

title: Van Conner
text: In 1984 he co-founded the band Screaming Trees with his brother Gary Lee Conner and close friends Mark Lanegan and Mark Pickerel.

title: Van Conner
text: On the 25 June 2000 Screaming Trees announced their official breakup.

title: Van Conner
text: Conner would start a low key band under the name Gardener which released its only album in the 1990s under the name "New Dawning Time".

title: Van Conner
text: Conner has also had brief appearances as a session musician with other known bands such as Queens of the Stone Age and helping Mark Lanegan on his solo album I'll Take Care of You.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: Gary Lee Conner (born Lee Gary Conner on August 22, 1962 in Fort Irwin, California, USA) was the lead guitarist for rock act Screaming Trees, along with his brother Van Conner, who was the band's bassist.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: Conner began his career with Screaming Trees in 1985 which lasted until their disbanding in 2000.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: During that time he released two non-Tree albums: The Purple Outside-Mystery Lane (1990 New Alliance Records) with brother Patrick Conner on Drums and the single Grasshopper's Daydream/Behind The Smile (1999 sub pop) this album also featured Josh Homme from Queens of the Stone Age.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: Appearances on other artists material include, Beat Happening "Indian Summer" and "Midnight a Go-Go" from "Jamboree" as well as "Against the 70s" by Mike Watt from "Ball-Hog or Tugboat?

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: " (1995 Columbia Records).

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: After ten years of seclusion he finally released a new album in 2010 from his band Microdot Gnome.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: The album "4D Sugarcubes" was released on Moonbus International Recordings in April 2010 as was available on CD and MP3.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: At the moment he is planning future releases from Microdot Gnome.

title: Gary Lee Conner
text: In August 2016, Conner released a long-awaited solo album, Ether Trippers, on Strange Earth Records.

title: Alexander Kerensky
text: Alexander Fyodorovich Kerensky (Russian: Алекса́ндр Фёдорович Ке́ренский , ] ; 4 May 1881 – 11 June 1970) was a Russian lawyer and key political figure in the Russian Revolution of 1917.

title: Alexander Kerensky
text: After the February Revolution of 1917 he joined the newly formed Russian Provisional Government, first as Minister of Justice, then as Minister of War, and after July 1917 as the government's second Minister-Chairman.

title: Alexander Kerensky
text: A leader of the moderate-socialist Trudoviks faction of the Socialist Revolutionary Party, he was also vice-chairman of the powerful Petrograd Soviet.

title: Alexander Kerensky
text: On 7 November, his government was overthrown by the Lenin-led Bolsheviks in the October Revolution.

title: Alexander Kerensky
text: He spent the remainder of his life in exile, in Paris and New York City, and worked for the Hoover Institution.

title: Timofey Samsonov
text: Timofey Petrovich Samsonov (Russian: Тимофей Петрович Самсонов ) (9 May 1888 – 28 October 1955) was a Soviet politician and veteran of the Russian Civil War.

title: Timofey Samsonov
text: He was a member of the Central Committee elected by the 15th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks),the Central Committee elected by the 16th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks) and the Central Committee elected by the 17th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks).

title: Timofey Samsonov
text: He was Chief Administrator (1927–1935), head of the Accounting Department (1932–1934).

title: Timofey Samsonov
text: He died in Moscow.

title: Lavr Kornilov
text: Lavr Georgiyevich Kornilov (Russian: Лавр Гео́ргиевич Корни́лов , ] ; 18 August 1870 – 13 April 1918) was a military intelligence officer, explorer, and general in the Imperial Russian Army during World War I and the ensuing Russian Civil War.

title: Lavr Kornilov
text: He is today best remembered for the Kornilov Affair, an unsuccessful endeavor in August/September 1917 that purported to strengthen Alexander Kerensky's Provisional Government, but which led to Kerensky eventually having Kornilov arrested and charged with attempting a coup d'état, and ultimately undermined the rule of Kerensky; strengthening the claims and power of the soviets, and the Bolshevik party.

title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
text: The left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks were a series of rebellions and uprisings against the Bolsheviks by rival left-wing parties that started soon after the October Revolution, continued through the Russian Civil War, and lasted into the first few years of Soviet rule.

title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
text: They were led or supported by left-wing groups such as some factions of the Socialist Revolutionary Party, Left Socialist Revolutionaries, Mensheviks, and anarchists.

title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
text: The uprisings started in 1918 and continued during and after the Civil War until around 1924.

title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
text: The Bolsheviks increasingly abandoned attempts to invite these groups to join the government and instead suppressed them with force.

title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
text: The Socialist Revolutionary Party, or Party of Socialists-Revolutionaries (the SRs; Russian: Партия социалистов-революционеров (ПСР), эсеры , "esery") was a major political party in early 20th century Russia and a key player in the Russian Revolution.

title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
text: Its general ideology was revolutionary socialism of democratic socialist and agrarian socialist forms.

title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
text: After the February Revolution of 1917, it shared power with other liberal and democratic socialist forces within the Russian Provisional Government.

title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
text: In November 1917, it won a plurality of the national vote in Russia's first-ever democratic elections (to the Russian Constituent Assembly), but the October Revolution had changed the political landscape and the Bolsheviks disbanded the Constituent Assembly in January 1918.

title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
text: The SRs soon split into pro-Bolshevik and anti-Bolshevik factions.

title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
text: The anti-Bolshevik faction of this party, known as the Right SRs, which remained loyal to the Provisional Government leader Alexander Kerensky was defeated and destroyed by the Bolsheviks in the course of the Russian Civil War and subsequent persecution.

title: Kerensky–Krasnov uprising
text: Kerensky–Krasnov uprising was an attempt by Alexander Kerensky to regain power after the Bolsheviks overthrew his Provisional Government in Petrograd.

title: Louise Bryant
text: Louise Bryant (December 5, 1885 – January 6, 1936) was an American feminist, political activist, and journalist best known for her sympathetic coverage of Russia and the Bolsheviks during the Russian Revolution.

title: Louise Bryant
text: Bryant, who married writer John Reed, her second husband, in 1916, wrote about Russian leaders such as Katherine Breshkovsky, Maria Spiridonova, Alexander Kerensky, Vladimir Lenin, and Leon Trotsky.

title: Louise Bryant
text: Her news stories, distributed by Hearst during and after her trips to Petrograd and Moscow, appeared in newspapers across the United States and Canada in the years immediately following World War I.

title: Louise Bryant
text: A collection of articles from her first trip was published in book form as "Six Red Months in Russia" in 1918.

title: Louise Bryant
text: During the next year, she defended the revolution in testimony before the Overman Committee, a Senate subcommittee established to investigate Bolshevik influence in the United States.

title: Louise Bryant
text: Later in 1919, she undertook a nationwide speaking tour to encourage public support of the Bolsheviks and to denounce armed U.S. intervention in Russia.

title: Communism in Russia
text: Communism in Russia began after Tsar Nicholas II lost his power during the February Revolution.

title: Communism in Russia
text: The Provisional Government was established under Prince Lvov, however, the Bolsheviks refused to accept the government and revolted in October 1917, taking control of Russia.

title: Communism in Russia
text: Vladmir Lenin, their leader, rose to power and governed between 1917 and 1924.

title: Communism in Russia
text: The Bolsheviks formed the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, marking the beginning of the Russian Civil War between the revolutionary Reds and the counter-revolutionary Whites.

title: Communism in Russia
text: In 1922 the Communist Reds were victorious, and formed the Soviet Union.

title: Communism in Russia
text: Lenin died in 1924, starting a power struggle which ended with Joseph Stalin seizing power.

title: Communism in Russia
text: He was the leader of the Communist Party until 1953.

title: Communism in Russia
text: He encouraged political paranoia and conducted the Great Purge to remove opponents of his dominance.

title: Russian Civil War
text: The Russian Civil War (Russian: Гражда́нская война́ в Росси́и , "Grazhdanskaya voyna v Rossiyi" ; November 1917 – October 1922) was a multi-party war in the former Russian Empire immediately after the Russian Revolutions of 1917, as many factions vied to determine Russia's political future.

title: Russian Civil War
text: The two largest combatant groups were the Red Army, fighting for the Bolshevik form of socialism led by Vladimir Lenin, and the loosely allied forces known as the White Army, which included diverse interests favoring monarchism, capitalism and alternative forms of socialism, each with democratic and antidemocratic variants.

title: Russian Civil War
text: In addition, rival militant socialists and nonideological Green armies fought against both the Bolsheviks and the Whites.

title: Russian Civil War
text: Eight foreign nations intervened against the Red Army, notably the Allied Forces and the pro-German armies.

title: Russian Civil War
text: The Red Army defeated the White Armed Forces of South Russia in Ukraine and the army led by Admiral Aleksandr Kolchak in Siberia in 1919.

title: Russian Civil War
text: The remains of the White forces commanded by Pyotr Nikolayevich Wrangel were beaten in Crimea and evacuated in late 1920.

title: Russian Civil War
text: Lesser battles of the war continued on the periphery for two more years, and minor skirmishes with the remnants of the White forces in the Far East continued well into 1923.

title: Russian Civil War
text: The war ended in 1923 in the sense that Red control of the newly formed Soviet Union was now assured, although armed national resistance in Central Asia was not completely crushed until 1934.

title: Russian Civil War
text: There were an estimated 7,000,000–12,000,000 casualties during the war, mostly civilians.

title: Russian Civil War
text: The Russian Civil War has been described by some as the greatest national catastrophe that Europe had yet seen.

title: Battle of Romanovka
text: The Battle of Romanovka was fought in June 1919 during the Russian Civil War.

title: Battle of Romanovka
text: Russian Bolsheviks of Yakov Triapitsyn launched a surprise attack on an American army camp at Romanovka, Siberia near Vladivostok.

title: Battle of Romanovka
text: As a result of the engagement, the attacks were repelled.

title: Battle of Romanovka
text: Romanovka and the Suchan Valley Campaign that followed were the final major engagements of the Russian Civil War involving the United States.

title: Battle of Romanovka
text: Battles would later break out again between the Americans and Bolsheviks, as well as the Cossacks, on much smaller scales.

title: Battle of Romanovka
text: Likewise, the Americans were invariably victorious.

title: Chiara Nappi
text: Chiara R. Nappi is an Italian physicist.

title: Chiara Nappi
text: Her research areas have included mathematical physics, particle physics, and string theory.

title: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics
text: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics (Italian: "" ) is a short book by the Italian physicist Carlo Rovelli.

title: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics
text: Originally published in Italian in 2014, the book has been translated into 41 languages.

title: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics
text: It is an Italian bestseller, with more than 300,000 copies sold in Rovelli's home country.

title: Aldo Pontremoli
text: Aldo Pontremoli (] ; 19 January 1896 – 25 May 1928) was an Italian physicist who held a chair of theoretical physics at the University of Milan from 1926 and who founded and directed the Institute of Advanced Physics at the University of Milan from 1924 until his disappearance and presumed death in May 1928.

title: Aldo Pontremoli
text: Pontremoli was one of the six men who disappeared with the airborne envelope of the airship "Italia" after it had crashed on the Arctic ice on 25 May 1928.

title: Antonino Lo Surdo
text: Antonino Lo Surdo (4 February 1880 in Syracuse – 7 June 1949 in Rome) was an Italian physicist.

title: Antonino Lo Surdo
text: He was appointed as professor of physics at the Istituto di Fisica in Rome in 1919; upon the death of Orso Mario Corbino in 1937, he became the director.

title: Antonino Lo Surdo
text: Lo Surdo studied terrestrial physics, including seismology and geophysics; the 1908 Messina earthquake caused the death of his parents and other close relatives, except his brother.

title: Antonino Lo Surdo
text: He contributed to the foundation of the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica under the auspices of the Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, when its president was Guglielmo Marconi.

title: Guido Caldarelli
text: Guido Caldarelli (born in Rome on 8 April 1967) is an Italian physicist (statistical physics) and full professor in Theoretical Physics at IMT School for Advanced Studies Lucca.

title: Guido Caldarelli
text: He is married with two children and lives in Lucca.

title: Micropædia
text: The 12-volume Micropædia is one of the three parts of the 15th edition of "Encyclopædia Britannica", the other two being the one-volume "Propædia" and the 17-volume "Macropædia".

title: Micropædia
text: The name "Micropædia" is a neologism coined by Mortimer J. Adler from the ancient Greek words for "small" and "instruction"; the best English translation is perhaps "brief lessons".

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: Claudio Pellegrini (born in Rome on May 9, 1935) is an Italian physicist known for his pioneering work on X-ray free electron lasers and collective effects in relativistic particle beams.

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: He was educated at the Sapienza University of Rome where he received the Laurea in Fisica "summa cum laude" in 1958 and the Libera Docenza, in 1965.

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: From 1958 to 1978, he worked at the Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati for high energy and nuclear physics.

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: In the early 1960s, he was at the Nordic Institute for Theoretical Physics (NORDITA) in Copenhagen, working on an alternative formulation of the theory of general relativity using tetrad fields to obtain, among other things, a better description of the energy-momentum complex.

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: (See "Teleparallelism" for a summary of the theoretical context of this work.)

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: In 1978, he moved to the United States and began work at Brookhaven National Laboratory, where he was an Associate Chairman of the National Synchrotron Light Source and co-director at the Center for Accelerator Physics.

title: Claudio Pellegrini
text: In 1989, he accepted an appointment at the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA) as a professor of physics, and later became a Distinguished Professor.

title: Enrico Fermi
text: Enrico Fermi ( ; ] ; 29 September 1901 – 28 November 1954) was an Italian physicist and the creator of the world's first nuclear reactor, the Chicago Pile-1.

title: Enrico Fermi
text: He has been called the "architect of the nuclear age" and the "architect of the atomic bomb".

title: Enrico Fermi
text: He was one of the very few physicists in history to excel both theoretically and experimentally.

title: Enrico Fermi
text: Fermi held several patents related to the use of nuclear power, and was awarded the 1938 Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on induced radioactivity by neutron bombardment and the discovery of transuranic elements.

title: Enrico Fermi
text: He made significant contributions to the development of quantum theory, nuclear and particle physics, and statistical mechanics.

title: Sergio Ferrara
text: Sergio Ferrara (born May 2, 1945) is an Italian physicist working on theoretical physics of elementary particles and mathematical physics.

title: Sergio Ferrara
text: He is renowned for the discovery of theories introducing supersymmetry as a symmetry of elementary particles (super-Yang–Mills theories, together with Bruno Zumino) and of supergravity, the first significant extension of Einstein's general relativity, based on the principle of "local supersymmetry" (together with Daniel Z. Freedman, and Peter van Nieuwenhuizen).

title: Sergio Ferrara
text: He is an emeritus staff member at CERN and a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Luciano Pietronero
text: Luciano Pietronero (born in Rome on December 15, 1949) is an Italian physicist (statistical physics) and full professor at the department of Physics at University of Rome "Sapienza".

title: Tower Hill Memorial
text: The Tower Hill Memorial is a Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial on the south side of Trinity Square Gardens, in London, England.

title: Tower Hill Memorial
text: The memorial commemorates those from the Merchant Navy and fishing fleets who died during both world wars and have "no grave but the sea".

title: Tower Hill Memorial
text: The memorial was designed by Edwin Lutyens with sculpture work by William Reid Dick, the Second World War extension was designed by Edward Maufe with sculpture work by Charles Wheeler.

title: Rainham War Memorial
text: The Rainham War Memorial commemorates soldiers killed in both World Wars as well as civilian casualties of World War II.

title: Freetown Memorial
text: The Freetown Memorial is a Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial located outside the Secretariate Building in Freetown, Sierra Leone.

title: Freetown Memorial
text: The memorial generally commemorates Soldiers from Sierra Leone who died whilst serving with the Royal West African Frontier Force in West Africa and whose graves are not known.

title: Freetown Memorial
text: The Freetown Memorial commemorates 1,109 First World War casualties and 247 from the Second World War.

title: Monmouth War Memorial
text: The Monmouth War Memorial commemorates the Monmouth fallen of the First and Second World Wars.

title: Arras Flying Services Memorial
text: The Arras Flying Services Memorial Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial in the Faubourg d'Amiens Cemetery, Arras, France.

title: Arras Flying Services Memorial
text: The memorial commemorates nearly 1,000 airmen from forces of the Commonwealth who were killed on the Western Front during World War I and who have no known grave.

title: Arras Flying Services Memorial
text: The memorial was designed by Edwin Lutyens, sculpted by William Reid Dick and unveiled by Hugh Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard, Marshal of the Royal Air Force on 31 July 1932.

title: Livesey Hall War Memorial
text: The Livesey Hall War Memorial commemorates the fallen of World War I and World War II who had been employed by the South Suburban Gas Company of London.

title: Livesey Hall War Memorial
text: It is also a tribute to those employees who served in the wars.

title: Livesey Hall War Memorial
text: The monument was designed and executed by British sculptor Sydney March, of the March family of artists.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The Portsmouth Naval Memorial, sometimes known as Southsea Naval Memorial, is a war memorial in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England, on Southsea Common beside Clarence Esplanade, between Clarence Pier and Southsea Castle.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The memorial commemorates approximately 25,000 British and Commonwealth sailors who were lost in the World Wars, around 10,000 sailors in the First World War and 15,000 in the Second World War.

title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
text: The memorial features a central obelisk, with names of the dead on bronze plaques arranged around the memorial according to the year of death.

title: Masnières Newfoundland Memorial
text: The Masnières Newfoundland Memorial is a Dominion of Newfoundland war memorial that commemorates the actions of the Royal Newfoundland Regiment during the First Battle of Cambrai, of World War I.

title: Masnières Newfoundland Memorial
text: Located at the north end of the town of Masnières, France, the memorial commemorates the participation of the Newfoundlanders in the taking and defense of the town during the First Battle of Cambrai between the 20th of November and 2 December 1917.

title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
text: The War Memorial in Hanoi is located across the Ba Dinh Square, across the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and close to Hanoi Citadel.

title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
text: Constructed in 1993 in a fusion of traditional Vietnamese and modernist architecture, the memorial commemorates men and women who sacrificed themselves during the Second Indochina War.

title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
text: The war is known by many names, e.g. as the American War in Vietnam.

title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
text: The memorial is a focal point for state functions, commemorating the war dead.

title: Alamein Memorial
text: The Alamein Memorial is a Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial in the El Alamein War Cemetery, El Alamein, Egypt.

title: Alamein Memorial
text: The memorial commemorates 11,866 Commonwealth forces members who died during World War II.

title: Alamein Memorial
text: The memorial was designed by Hubert Worthington and unveiled by Viscount Montgomery of Alamein on 24 October 1954.

title: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
text: The Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library is a repository located on the north campus of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.

title: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
text: The library houses archival materials on the life, career, and presidency of Gerald Ford, the 38th President of the United States.

title: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
text: The Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library is a part of the National Archives and Records Administration's presidential library system.

title: Grantley Adams International Airport
text: Grantley Adams International Airport (GAIA) (IATA: BGI, ICAO: TBPB) is the international airport of Barbados, located in Seawell, Christ Church.

title: Grantley Adams International Airport
text: It is the only designated port of entry for persons arriving and departing by air in Barbados and operates as a major gateway to the Eastern Caribbean.

title: Grantley Adams International Airport
text: The airport has direct service to destinations in the United States, Canada, Central America and Europe and serves as the second hub for LIAT.

title: Grantley Adams International Airport
text: In 2016, the airport was the 8th busiest airport in the Caribbean region; and the third busiest airport in the Lesser Antilles; after Queen Beatrix International Airport located in Aruba, and Pointe-à-Pitre International Airport located in the Republic of France within the island of Guadeloupe.

title: Grantley Adams International Airport
text: GAIA, also remains an important air-link for cruise ship passengers departing and arriving at the Port of Bridgetown, and a base of operations for the Regional Security System (RSS), and the Regional (Caribbean) Police Training Centre.

title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
text: A pre-commissioning unit (PRECOMMUNIT) or (PCU) is used by the United States Navy to describe vessels under construction prior to their official commissioning.

title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
text: For example, prior to its commissioning, the aircraft carrier "Gerald R. Ford" (CVN-78) has been described by the Navy as "pre-commissioning unit (PCU) "Gerald R. Ford" ."

title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
text: However, "PCU" is only a descriptive term and is not a prefix or a part of the ship's official name.

title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
text: Until they are commissioned, U.S. Navy vessels are officially identified by their given name and hull number only with no prefix, such as "Gerald R. Ford" (CVN-78).

title: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
text: Gerald R. Ford International Airport (IATA: GRR, ICAO: KGRR, FAA LID: GRR) is a commercial airport in Cascade Township approximately 13 mi southeast of Grand Rapids, Michigan.

title: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
text: The facility is owned by the Kent County Board of Commissioners and managed by an independent authority.

title: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
text: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2017–2021 categorized it as a small hub primary commercial service facility.

title: Gerald R. Ford Freeway
text: The Gerald R. Ford Freeway refers to Interstate Highways named for former President Gerald R. Ford in Omaha (where he was born) and Michigan (where he grew up and was a Congressman):

title: Bishop International Airport
text: Bishop International Airport (IATA: FNT, ICAO: KFNT, FAA LID: FNT) is a commercial and general aviation airport located in Flint, Michigan.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: It is named after banker and General Motors board member Arthur Giles Bishop (April 12, 1851 – January 22, 1944), who donated 220 acres of his farmland for the airport in 1928.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: The third busiest airport in Michigan, it surpassed competitor MBS International Airport in terms of airline operations in 2002.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: In 2007, 1,071,238 passengers used Bishop International Airport; in 2011, 938,914 passengers used the airport.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: It is included in the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2017–2021, in which it is categorized as a small hub primary commercial service facility.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: The airport is currently served by several passenger airlines: Allegiant Air, Southwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines operate mainline service out of the airport, as well as affiliates of Delta Connection, United Express and American Eagle.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: Additionally, FedEx Express and a FedEx Feeder affiliate operate cargo services out of the airport.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: Accompanying the airlines is fixed-base operator Av Flight that handles both general aviation and airline operations and the flight school American Wings Aviation.

title: Bishop International Airport
text: Bishop International Airport is in southwestern Flint, and is surrounded by Flint Township to the north, east and west; and Mundy Township to the south.

title: Raleigh Executive Jetport
text: Raleigh Exec: The Raleigh Executive Jetport @ Sanford-Lee County or Raleigh Exec Jetport at Sanford-Lee CountyFAA Airport Master Record for TTA (Form 5010 ) (ICAO: KTTA, FAA LID: TTA) is a public use airport located seven nautical miles (8 mi, 13 km) northeast of the central business district of Sanford, a city in Lee County, North Carolina, United States.

title: Raleigh Executive Jetport
text: It is owned by the Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport Authority and was previously known as Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport.

title: Raleigh Executive Jetport
text: This airport is included in the National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2011–2015, which categorized it as a "reliever airport" for Raleigh-Durham International Airport.

title: John Glenn Columbus International Airport
text: John Glenn Columbus International Airport (IATA: CMH, ICAO: KCMH, FAA LID: CMH) , is an international airport located 6 mi east of downtown Columbus, Ohio.

title: John Glenn Columbus International Airport
text: Formerly known as Port Columbus International Airport, it is managed by the Columbus Regional Airport Authority, which also oversees operations at Rickenbacker International Airport and Bolton Field.

title: John Glenn Columbus International Airport
text: The airport code 'CMH' stands for "Columbus Municipal Hangar," the original name for the airport.

title: Elko Regional Airport
text: Elko Regional Airport (IATA: EKO, ICAO: KEKO, FAA LID: EKO) , formerly Elko Municipal Airport, is a mile west of downtown Elko, in Elko County, Nevada.

title: Pensacola International Airport
text: Pensacola International Airport (IATA: PNS, ICAO: KPNS, FAA LID: PNS) , formerly Pensacola Gulf Coast Regional Airport and Pensacola Regional Airport (Hagler Field), is a public use airport three nautical miles (6 km) northeast of the central business district of Pensacola, in Escambia County, Florida, United States.

title: Pensacola International Airport
text: It is owned by the City of Pensacola.

title: Pensacola International Airport
text: Despite the name, this airport does not offer direct international flights.

title: Pensacola International Airport
text: This airport is one of the five major airports in North Florida, others being: Northwest Florida Beaches International Airport, Destin-Fort Walton Beach Airport Tallahassee International Airport, and Jacksonville International Airport.

title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
text: The Princeton Neuroscience Institute (PNI) is a center for neuroscience research at Princeton University.

title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
text: PNI was created in 2006 as a partnership of Princeton University's departments of Psychology and Molecular Biology.

title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
text: This partnership was led by psychology professor Jonathan Cohen and molecular biology professor David Tank, who continue to serve as Co-Directors of the Institute.

title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
text: In 2014, PNI moved into a dedicated research complex that houses both PNI and the Department of Psychology.

title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
text: The building is 248,00 square feet, and was designed by Rafael Moneo to meet LEED Silver certification.

title: Abraham Maslow
text: Abraham Harold Maslow ( ; April 1, 1908 – June 8, 1970) was an American psychologist who was best known for creating Maslow's hierarchy of needs, a theory of psychological health predicated on fulfilling innate human needs in priority, culminating in self-actualization.

title: Abraham Maslow
text: Maslow was a psychology professor at Alliant International University, Brandeis University, Brooklyn College, New School for Social Research, and Columbia University.

title: Abraham Maslow
text: He stressed the importance of focusing on the positive qualities in people, as opposed to treating them as a "bag of symptoms."

title: Abraham Maslow
text: A "Review of General Psychology" survey, published in 2002, ranked Maslow as the tenth most cited psychologist of the 20th century.

title: Frank L. Schmidt
text: Frank L. Schmidt is a retired American psychology professor (University of Iowa) known for his work in personnel selection and employment testing.

title: Frank L. Schmidt
text: Schmidt is a researcher in the area of industrial and organizational psychology with the most number of publications in the two major journals in the 1980s.

title: Frank L. Schmidt
text: In the 1990s he was the 4th most published researcher in Journal of Applied Psychology (JAP) and Personnel Psychology (PP), the two principal publications in the field of industrial-organizational psychology.

title: Frank L. Schmidt
text: He is also winner of the first Dunnette Prize, the most prestigious lifetime achievement award given by the Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology "to honor living individuals whose work has significantly expanded knowledge of the causal significance of individual differences through advanced research, development, and/or application"

title: Stephen M. Colarelli
text: Stephen M. Colarelli is an American psychology professor at Central Michigan University, known for his research on evolutionary psychology and the workplace.

title: Stanley Coren
text: Stanley Coren (born 1942) is a psychology professor and neuropsychological researcher who has become best known to the general public for his best selling and award-winning books regarding the intelligence, mental abilities and history of dogs. Through television shows and media coverage that have been broadcast in Canada and the United States as well as overseas, he has become popular with dog owners, while continuing research and instruction in psychology at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Stanley Coren
text: He also writes for "Psychology Today" in the award-winning regular feature series Canine Corner .

title: Kimberly Young
text: Kimberly Young is a psychologist and world expert on Internet addiction disorder and online behaviour.

title: Kimberly Young
text: She founded the Center for Internet Addiction in 1995 and was a psychology professor at the University of Pittsburgh at Bradford with a PhD in Clinical Psychology.

title: Kimberly Young
text: Young is currently a professor of management scientists at St. Bonaventure University.

title: Kimberly Young
text: She has published numerous journal articles and books chapters and served as an expert witness regarding her pioneer research including testimony for the Child Protection Online Act Congressional Committee.

title: Kimberly Young
text: Young is a member of the American Psychological Association, the Pennsylvania Psychological Association, and a founding member of the International Society of Mental Health Online.

title: Ralph Hefferline
text: Ralph Franklin Hefferline (15 February 1910 in Muncie, Indiana – 16 March 1974) was a psychology professor at Columbia University.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: Mathematically Alive: A Story of Fandom is an award-winning 2007 documentary film about fans of the New York Mets.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: Directed, produced and edited by Katherine Foronjy and Joseph Coburn, the film follows a wide variety of fans over the course of the 2005 and 2006 baseball seasons, culminating in an exciting 7 game series against the St. Louis Cardinals in the NLCS.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: "Mathematically Alive" shows the emotional attachment that fans develop for their team and how it can be the source of great joy or tremendous sadness.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: In addition to the hundreds of fans interviewed for the film, Coburn and Foronjy also caught up with former Mets players Bud Harrelson, Ron Swoboda, Ed Charles, Tim Teuffel and legendary broadcaster Ralph Kiner.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: The filmmakers also interviewed Dr. Daniel Wann, a sports psychology professor at Murray State University, who explains many of the psychological characteristics sports fans share.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: Of particular focus in the film are a group of female Mets fans whose favorite player is former catcher Mike Piazza.

title: Mathematically Alive
text: They wait for his arrival outside the Shea stadium parking lot on game days, and travelled around the country to see him play even when he was no longer a player on the Mets.

title: E. Mavis Hetherington
text: E. Mavis Hetherington (born November 27, 1926) is a retired psychology professor at the University of Virginia.

title: E. Mavis Hetherington
text: She is a leading researcher on the impacts of divorce, family as units, and the development of children.

title: E. Mavis Hetherington
text: Throughout her career she has published more than 200 articles and edited 13 books.

title: E. Mavis Hetherington
text: While a professor at the University of Virginia she helped improve their psychology department, making them a nationally ranked program.

title: E. Mavis Hetherington
text: Hetherington also introduced a new method of analyzing observational research as well as help open the field of psychology to women by overcoming discrimination in her early career.

title: David C. Funder
text: David C. Funder (Ph.D., Stanford University, 1979) is a psychology professor who has written a number of important textbooks and research articles pertaining to the field of personality psychology.

title: David C. Funder
text: Funder resides as the chair of the Psychology department at the University of California, Riverside.

title: David C. Funder
text: He used to be a past editor of the "Journal of Research and Personality", as well as being a former secondary editor of the "Journal of Personality and Social Psychology".

title: David C. Funder
text: Funder has been praised for his studies on personality judgment.

title: David C. Funder
text: He had also published research over the attribution theory and the "delay of gratification".

title: Scotch Collie
text: The Scotch Collie is a landrace breed of dog which originated from the highland regions of Scotland.

title: Scotch Collie
text: The breed consisted of both the long-haired (now known as Rough) Collie and the short-haired (now known as Smooth) Collie.

title: Scotch Collie
text: It is generally believed to have descended from a variety of ancient herding dogs, some dating back to the Roman occupation, which may have included Roman Cattle Dogs, Native Celtic Dogs and Viking Herding Spitzes.

title: Scotch Collie
text: Other ancestors include the Gordon and Irish Setters.

title: Collie
text: The collie is a distinctive type of herding dog, including many related landraces and standardised breeds.

title: Collie
text: The type originated in Scotland and Northern England.

title: Collie
text: The collie is a medium-sized, fairly lightly built dog, with a pointed snout.

title: Collie
text: Many types have a distinctive white pattern over the shoulders.

title: Collie
text: Collies are very active and agile, and most types of collies have a very strong herding instinct.

title: Collie
text: Collie breeds have spread through many parts of the world (especially Australia and North America) and have diversified into many varieties, sometimes with mixture from other dog types.

title: Collie
text: Some collie breeds have remained as working dogs, used for herding cattle, sheep and other livestock, while others are kept as pets, show dogs or for dog sports, in which they display great agility, stamina and trainability.

title: Collie
text: While the AKC has a breed they call "Collie", in fact collie dogs are a distinctive type of herding dog including many related landraces and formal breeds.

title: Collie
text: There are usually major distinctions between show dogs and those bred for herding trials or dog sports.

title: Collie
text: They typically display great agility, stamina and trainability and more importantly sagacity.

title: Viol
text: The viol , viola da gamba ] , or (informally) gamba, is any one of a family of bowed, fretted and stringed instruments with hollow wooden bodies and pegboxes where the tension on the strings can be increased or decreased to adjust the pitch of each of the strings.

title: Viol
text: Frets on the viol are usually made of gut, tied on the fingerboard around the instrument's neck, to enable the performer to stop the strings more cleanly.

title: Viol
text: Frets improve consistency of intonation and lend the stopped notes a tone which better matches the open strings.

title: Viol
text: Viols first appeared in Spain in the mid to late 15th century and were most popular in the Renaissance and Baroque (1600-1750) periods.

title: Viol
text: Early ancestors include the Arabic "rebab" and the medieval European vielle, but later, more direct possible ancestors include the Venetian "viole" and the 15th- and 16th-century Spanish "vihuela", a 6-course plucked instrument tuned like a lute (and also like a present-day viol) that looked like but was quite distinct from (at that time) the 4-course guitar (an earlier chordophone).

title: Toy Manchester Terrier
text: The Toy Manchester Terrier is a breed of dog, categorized as a terrier.

title: Toy Manchester Terrier
text: The breed was bred down in size in North America from the Manchester Terrier, and is placed in the Toy Group by the American Kennel Club and the Canadian Kennel Club (the Manchester Terrier is placed in the Terrier Group.)

title: Toy Manchester Terrier
text: Neither the Fédération Cynologique Internationale nor The Kennel Club recognize a Toy variety of the Manchester Terrier.

title: Irish Red and White Setter
text: The Irish Red and White Setter () is a breed of dog, more specifically a setter.

title: Irish Red and White Setter
text: As with all the setters and the Pointer, it is classified as a gundog in the UK and is included in the sporting group in America and Canada.

title: Irish Red and White Setter
text: It is virtually identical in use and temperament to the related Irish Setter and its other setter cousins, the Gordon and English setters, but is more often found as a working gun dog.

title: English Setter
text: The English Setter is a medium size breed of dog.

title: English Setter
text: It is part of the Setter family, which includes the red Irish Setters, Irish Red and White Setters, and black-and-tan Gordon Setters.

title: English Setter
text: The mainly white body coat is of medium length with long silky fringes on the back of the legs, under the belly and on the tail.

title: English Setter
text: The coat features flecks of colour, and the different colour varieties are referred to as belton.

title: Russkiy Toy
text: The Russian Toy (also known as the Russian Toy Terrier, and in Russia as the Russkiy Toy, Toychik,Russian: Русский той, Тойчик ) is a very small breed of dog originally bred in Russia from the English Toy Terrier which is known today as the Manchester Terrier.

title: Russkiy Toy
text: There are two types of coats in the breed: smooth coat and long coat.

title: Russkiy Toy
text: The smooth-coated variety was previously known as the Russian Toy Terrier and long-coated as the Moscow Long Haired Toy Terrier.

title: Russkiy Toy
text: Both were brought together under the same Russian Toy Terrier name in 1988 and the "Terrier" was dropped from the name when the breed was added in 2006 to the official list of breeds registered with the Fédération Cynologique Internationale and has been registered in the Foundation Stock Service of the American Kennel Club since 2008, allowed to compete in AKC companion events since 2010.

title: Russkiy Toy
text: The first official breed standard of the two varieties was written in 1966 in Russia.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: The Teddy Roosevelt Terrier is a small to medium-sized American hunting terrier.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: Lower-set with shorter legs, more muscular, and heavier bone density than its cousin the American Rat Terrier.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: There is much diversity in the history of the Teddy Roosevelt Terrier breed and it shares a common early history with the American Rat Terrier, Fox Paulistinha and Tenterfield Terrier.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: It is said the Rat Terrier background stems from the terriers or other dogs that were brought over by early English and other working class immigrants.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: Since the breed was a farm, hunting and utility dog there was little to no planned breeding other than breeding dogs with agreeable traits to each other in order to produce the desired work ethic in the dog.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: It is assumed that the Feist (dog), Bull Terrier, Smooth Fox Terrier, Manchester Terrier, Whippet, Italian Greyhound, the now extinct English White Terrier, Turnspit dog and or Wry Legged Terrier all share in the Teddy Roosevelt Terrier's ancestry.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: These early Ratting Terriers were then most likely bred to the Beagle or Beagle cross bred dogs (for increased scenting ability) and other dogs.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: Maximizing the influences from these various breeds provides the modern Teddy Roosevelt Terrier with a keen sense of awareness and prey drive, an acute sense of smell and a very high intellect.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
text: Although they tend to be aloof with strangers they are devoted companion dogs with a strong desire to please and be near their owners side at all times.

title: Feist (dog)
text: A Feist is a small hunting dog, descended from the terriers brought over to the United States by English miners and other working class immigrants.

title: Feist (dog)
text: These terriers probably included crosses between the Smooth Fox Terrier, the Manchester Terrier and the now extinct English White Terrier.

title: Feist (dog)
text: These dogs were used as ratters, and gambling on their prowess in killing rats was a favorite hobby of their owners.

title: Feist (dog)
text: Some of these dogs have been crossed with Whippets or Italian Greyhounds (for speed) and Beagles (for hunting ability) - extending the family to include a larger variety of purpose than the original ratter, or Rat Terrier.

title: Florence Nagle
text: Florence Nagle (26 October 1894 – 30 October 1988) was a trainer and breeder of racehorses, a breeder of pedigree dogs, and an active feminist.

title: Florence Nagle
text: Nagle purchased her first Irish Wolfhound in 1913, and went on to own or breed twenty-one United Kingdom Champions.

title: Florence Nagle
text: Best in Show at Crufts in 1960 was awarded to Sulhamstead Merman, who was bred, owned and exhibited by Nagle.

title: Florence Nagle
text: She also competed successfully in field trials with Irish Setters, from the 1920s until the mid-1960s resulting in eighteen Field Trial Champions.

title: Florence Nagle
text: The male dog who was a linchpin in the 1970s revival of the Irish Red and White Setter breed was descended from one of Nagle's Irish Setters.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: Divya S. Menon (born 14 March 1987) is an Indian singer and television anchor from Kerala.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: Divya is a playback singer in Malayalam who has also recorded songs for Tamil and Telugu films.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: Divya started anchoring musical shows in Asianet Cable Vision (Thrissur) and has done musical shows in YesIndiavision(Mementos) and Kairali Channels(Ganamela, Sing 'N' Win and Rain drops).

title: Divya S. Menon
text: She started her film career with Ee Pattanathil Bhootham.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: She was noticed by Shaan Rahman while anchoring music shows and picked her for Vineeth Sreenivasan - Shaan Rahman debut album, Coffee @ MG Road.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: She is associated with Blogswara and have sung in multiple albums in the series.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: Divya has sung in Vineeth Sreenivasan's super hit romantic movie, Thattathin Marayathu composed by Shaan Rahman.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: She has been associated with Vineeth - Shaan ventures, including Malarvadi Arts Club.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: In 2014 the hit wedding song "Thudakkham Maangalyam" from Anjali Menon's Bangalore Days gave her much popularity which she sang along with along with Vijay Yesudas and Sachin Warrier composed by Gopi Sunder.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: In 2015 Divya was noticed more promptly when she sang the song "Puthumazhayai" from Martin Prakkat's Charlie (2015 Malayalam film) composed by Gopi Sundar while the same song was sung by Shreya Ghoshal too.

title: Divya S. Menon
text: She also sang several ad jingles for various music composers both in Malayalam and Tamil.

title: William Connolley
text: William Michael Connolley (born 12 April 1964) is a British software engineer, writer, and blogger on climatology.

title: William Connolley
text: Until December 2007 he was Senior Scientific Officer in the Physical Sciences Division in the Antarctic Climate and the Earth System project at the British Antarctic Survey, where he worked as a climate modeller.

title: William Connolley
text: After this he became a software engineer for Cambridge Silicon Radio.

title: Kanave Kalayathe
text: Kanave Kalayathe (English: Dreams Never Disappear ) is an album sung by Sachin Warrier starring Leon Poulose, Swetha Raj, Akash Thomas, NeethuKrishna VR, Christy Vazhapilly and Althaf.

title: Kanave Kalayathe
text: The soundtrack was composed by Abee Joe.

title: Kanave Kalayathe
text: It was produced by Nidhinsha and distriburted by Muzik247.

title: Kanave Kalayathe
text: The music video is directed by Deen Shifaz and Ashith wilson.

title: Muthuchippi Poloru
text: "Muthuchippy Poloru" is a Malayalam song composed by Shaan Rahman that featured in the film "Thattathin Marayathu".

title: Muthuchippi Poloru
text: Written by Anu Elizabeth Jose.

title: Muthuchippi Poloru
text: It was sung by Sachin Warrier and actress Remya Nambeesan.

title: Muthuchippi Poloru
text: The song was one of the most popular Malayalam songs of 2012 and won several awards.

title: Muthuchippi Poloru
text: It was later reused in the Telugu remake of "Thattathin Marayathu", "Saheba Subramanyam", as "Muddu Muddu".

title: Sachin Warrier
text: Sachin Warrier is a playback singer and composer in the Malayalam cinema industry from Kerala.

title: Sachin Warrier
text: He became notable with the song "Muthuchippi Poloru" from the film Thattathin Marayathu.

title: Sachin Warrier
text: He made his debut with the movie Malarvaadi Arts Club.

title: Sachin Warrier
text: He was working as a software engineer in Tata Consultancy Services in Kochi.

title: Sachin Warrier
text: Later he resigned from the job to concentrate more on music.

title: Sachin Warrier
text: His latest work is as a composer for the movie Aanandam.

title: Alec Muffett
text: Alec David Edward Muffett (born April 22, 1968) is an Anglo-American internet-security evangelist, architect, and software engineer.

title: Alec Muffett
text: He is principally known for his work on Crack, the original Unix password cracker, and for the CrackLib password-integrity testing library; he is also active in the Open Source software community.

title: Alec Muffett
text: He worked as a Software Engineer for Facebook.

title: Wes McKinney
text: Wes McKinney is an American statistician, data scientist and businessman.

title: Wes McKinney
text: He was the CEO and founder of technology startup Datapad.

title: Wes McKinney
text: He is the main author of the open-source Pandas package for data analysis in the Python programming language, and has also written the textbook "Python for Data Analysis" on the topic.

title: Wes McKinney
text: He worked as a software engineer for Cloudera following their acquisition of Datapad in 2014.

title: Wes McKinney
text: He is now a software engineer at Two Sigma Investments.

title: Sachin Bansal
text: Sachin Bansal (born 5 August 1981) is an Indian Software engineer and Internet entrepreneur known for co-founding India's e-commerce platform Flipkart.

title: Sachin Bansal
text: Sachin is from Chandigarh and is an engineering graduate from Indian Institute of Technology Delhi.

title: Lead programmer
text: A lead programmer is a software engineer in charge of one or more software projects.

title: Lead programmer
text: Alternative titles include "development lead", "technical lead", "lead software engineer", "software design engineer lead" (SDE lead), "software development manager", "software manager", or "lead application developer".

title: Lead programmer
text: When primarily contributing in a high-level enterprise software design role, the title "software architect" (or similar) is often used.

title: Kazushige Goto
text: Kazushige Gotō (後藤和茂 , Gotō Kazushige ) is a software engineer specializing in high performance, hand-written, machine code.

title: Kazushige Goto
text: He was a research associate at the Texas Advanced Computing Center at the University of Texas at Austin when he famously hand-optimized assembly routines for supercomputing and PC platforms that outperform the best compiler generated code.

title: Kazushige Goto
text: Several of the fastest supercomputers in the world still use his implementation of the Basic Linear Algebra Subprograms (BLAS) known as GotoBLAS.

title: Kazushige Goto
text: He joined Microsoft's Technical Computing Group in 2010 with the title of Senior Researcher.

title: Kazushige Goto
text: In July 2012 he joined Intel with the title of Software Engineer.

title: Kazushige Goto
text: He continues to write hand-optimized machine code, utilizing detailed knowledge of the architecture to which he has access.

title: Silver Spoon (manga)
