text: The Buffaloes played their home games at Coors Events Center in Boulder, Colorado and were members of the Pac-12 Conference.

title: 2015–16 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 22–12, 10–8 in Pac-12 play to finish in fifth place.

title: 2015–16 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: The defeated Washington State in the first round of the Pac-12 Tournament to advance to the quarterfinals where they lost to Arizona.

title: 2015–16 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: They received an at-large bid to the NCAA Tournament where they lost in the first round to Connecticut.

title: 2014 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The 2014 Colorado Buffaloes football team represented the University of Colorado at Boulder during the 2014 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2014 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Led by second-year head coach Mike MacIntyre, the Buffaloes played their home games on-campus at Folsom Field in Boulder and were members of the South Division of the Pac-12 Conference.

title: 2014 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: They finished the season 2–10, 0–9 in Pac-12 play to finish in last place in the South Division.

title: 2015 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The 2015 Colorado Buffaloes football team represented the University of Colorado at Boulder during the 2015 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2015 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Led by third-year head coach Mike MacIntyre, the Buffaloes played their home games on-campus at Folsom Field in Boulder and were members of the South Division of the Pac-12 Conference.

title: 2015 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: They finished the season 4–9, 1–8 in Pac-12 play to finish in last place in the South Division.

title: 1989 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The 1989 Colorado Buffaloes football team represented the University of Colorado at Boulder during the 1989 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1989 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Colorado finished with the most wins in school history, surpassing the 1971 team, and their first conference championship since 1976.

title: 1989 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The Buffaloes played for the national title but lost to Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl.

title: 1989 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The team dedicated the season to senior and former starting quarterback Sal Aunese, who was diagnosed with stomach cancer in February and died on September 23 due to complications from the disease.

title: 2013 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The 2013 Colorado Buffaloes football team represented the University of Colorado at Boulder during the 2013 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2013 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Led by first-year head coach Mike MacIntyre, the Buffaloes played their home games on-campus at Folsom Field in Boulder and were members of the Pac-12 Conference.

title: 2013 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Head coach Mike MacIntyre was hired after the firing of Jon Embree concluding the 2012 season.

title: 2011 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The 2011 Colorado Buffaloes football team represented the University of Colorado at Boulder in the 2011 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2011 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Led by first-year head coach and alumnus Jon Embree, the Buffaloes played their home games on-campus at Folsom Field in Boulder and were first-year members of the newly expanded Pac-12 Conference.

title: 2011 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: They finished with a record of 3–10, 2–7 in Pac-12 play, in a tie for last place in the South Division.

title: 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: The 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team represented the University of Colorado in the 2014–15 NCAA Division I men's basketball season.

title: 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: This was Tad Boyle's fifth year as head coach at Colorado.

title: 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: The Buffaloes played their home games at the Coors Events Center in Boulder, Colorado as members of the Pac-12 Conference.

title: 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: They finished the season 16–18, 7–11 in Pac-12 play to finish in a three way tie for eighth place.

title: 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: They advanced to the quarterfinals of the Pac-12 Tournament where they lost to Oregon.

title: 2014–15 Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball team
text: They were invited to the College Basketball Invitational where they defeated Gardner–Webb in the first round before losing in the second round to Seattle.

title: 2010 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The 2010 Colorado Buffaloes football team represented the University of Colorado in the 2010 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2010 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The team was coached by fifth-year head coach Dan Hawkins for the first nine games and interim head coach Brian Cabral for the final three games.

title: 2010 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: Colorado played their homes game at Folsom Field.

title: 2010 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: It was also the final season as members the Big 12 Conference in the North Division for Colorado, before joining the Pac-12 Conference for the 2011 season.

title: 2010 Colorado Buffaloes football team
text: The Buffaloes failed to qualify for a bowl game, as they finished the season 5–7, 2–6 in Big 12 play.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: John A. Brown was an Oklahoman department store chain.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: It operated under that name from 1932, when its founder bought out its predecessor and renamed the chain for himself.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: After Mr. Brown died in 1940, his widow took over management until her own death in 1967, forcing a change in ownership.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: Dayton-Hudson, another retail company, but continued operating the chain under its own name, until 1984, when Dayton-Hudson sold the Brown chain to Dillard's, another national chain, which combined all of the Brown stores under its own name.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: The flagship store on West Main Street was closed in 1974 and was subsequently razed as part of an urban renewal project.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: The project was supposed to result in a new shopping center known as the Galleria.

title: John A. Brown (department store)
text: However, the project was never completed, so the Brown chain never returned to downtown.

title: SavaCentre
text: SavaCentre was a chain of 13 hypermarkets and later a further seven discount supermarkets owned and operated jointly by Sainsbury's and BHS, beginning in 1977.

title: SavaCentre
text: Sainsbury's later took full control of the stores alone in 1989, rebranding them as Sainsbury’s SavaCentre, until 2005 when the stores were integrated into the Sainsbury's supermarket brand.

title: SavaCentre
text: The hypermarket stores ranged in size from 66,000 sqft to 117,000 sqft and the discount supermarkets ranged in size from 31,000 sqft to 70,000 sqft .

title: SavaCentre
text: At the time of its inception, it was the only dedicated hypermarket chain in the UK.

title: Uno-X
text: Uno-X is a chain of unmanned fuel stations throughout Norway and Denmark.

title: Uno-X
text: It is operated as the low-cost section of YX Energi.

title: Uno-X
text: The chain was originally created as a low cost chain in Denmark in the late 1950s.

title: Uno-X
text: The rights to use the name in Sweden were sold to Britain's Burmah Oil.

title: Uno-X
text: In 1991 Norsk Hydro acquired the 330 outlets of the Danish operation and five years later it bought the Swedish Uno-X chain from Burmah.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: Holiday Inn Orlando - Disney Springs Area is a resort hotel located on the property of Walt Disney World Resort in Lake Buena Vista, Florida.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: It is near the Disney Springs district on Hotel Plaza Boulevard.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: The hotel opened in February 1973 as a Howard Johnson's; it was expanded in 1978.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: It remained part of the chain until 1994.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: In 1995 it was bought by Host Marriott Corporation and operated as a Courtyard by Marriott hotel until 2003.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: Holiday Inn bought the resort in December 2003.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: The hotel closed on August 14, 2004 after Hurricane Charley caused extensive damage when it blew through Florida.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: It was owned by CIG LBV LLC and stayed under the Holiday Inn brand, part of the InterContinental Hotels Group PLC, when it reopened on February 12, 2010 after a reportedly $35 million renovation.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: On December 9, 2016, the hotel was sold and from then on operated and managed by Interstate Hotels & Resorts, still operating under the Holiday Inn brand.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: The resort has 323 rooms, a heated swimming pool and a hot tub.

title: Holiday Inn Lake Buena Vista Downtown
text: The hotel also has a view of the Disney Springs area and the rest of the Walt Disney World Resort from certain areas of the hotel.

title: Tesco Extra
text: Tesco Extra is a chain of mainly out-of-town hypermarkets, owned and operated by the United Kingdom's largest retailer, Tesco.

title: Tazweed Center
text: Tazweed Center is a chain of independently owned and operated hypermarkets operating in the Syrian refugee camps.

title: Tazweed Center
text: The word "tazweed" translates as "resupply".

title: Euromarché
text: Euromarché ("Euromarket") was a French hypermarket chain.

title: Euromarché
text: The first store opened in 1968 in Saint-Michel-sur-Orge.

title: Euromarché
text: In June 1991, the group was rebought by its rival, Carrefour, for 5,2 billion francs.

title: Selver
text: Selver is a chain of supermarkets and hypermarkets operating in Estonia.

title: Selver
text: Selver is a subsidiary of Tallinna Kaubamaja.

title: Selver
text: The chain was established in 1995 with the opening of Punane Selver in Lasnamäe, Tallinn.

title: Selver
text: Expansion outside of Tallinn began on 10 May 2002 with the opening of Mai Selver in Pärnu.

title: Selver
text: Since 18 December 2008 Selver also operated in Latvia, but in the end of 2009 due to the financial crisis Selver was forced to close all its 6 supermarkets in Latvia.

title: Selver
text: There are currently 44 stores in operation all over Estonia (as of December 2014).

title: Carrefour
text: Carrefour S.A. (] ) is a French multinational retailer headquartered in Boulogne Billancourt, France, in the Hauts-de-Seine Department near Paris.

title: Carrefour
text: It is one of the largest hypermarket chains in the world (with 1,462 hypermarkets at the end of 2016).

title: Carrefour
text: Carrefour operates in more than 30 countries, in Europe, the Americas, Asia and Africa.

title: Carrefour
text: Carrefour means "crossroads" and "public square" in French.

title: Carrefour
text: The company is a component of the Euro Stoxx 50 stock market index.

title: Lewis's
text: Lewis's was a chain of British department stores that operated from 1856 to 2010.

title: Lewis's
text: The parent companies of Lewis's have gone into administration many times over the years, including 1991.

title: Lewis's
text: The first store, which opened in Liverpool city centre, became the flagship of the chain of stores operating under the Lewis's name.

title: Lewis's
text: Several stores in the chain were bought in 1991 by the company Owen Owen and continued to operate under the Lewis's brand name for several years, but after the closure of the Manchester store in 2002, only the original Liverpool store continued to trade under the Lewis's name.

title: Lewis's
text: This store was sold in 2007 to the Vergo Retail Ltd and closed in 2010.

title: Carolina Dodge Dealers 400
text: The Carolina Dodge Dealers 400 was the annual spring NASCAR Sprint Cup race held at Darlington Raceway in Darlington, South Carolina, USA.

title: Carolina Dodge Dealers 400
text: A 100 mi race was held in May at the track in 1952, however the event did not become a regular one on the NASCAR schedule until 1957, as a 300 mi race in the Convertible Division, known as the Rebel 300.

title: Carolina Dodge Dealers 400
text: In 1966, the race was expanded to 400 mi , and in 1973 to 500 mi .

title: Carolina Dodge Dealers 400
text: In 1994, the race was returned to 400 miles.

title: Carolina Dodge Dealers 400
text: In 2005, as part of the settlement of the Ferko lawsuit and as part of a schedule realignment, Darlington was forced to contract to one race date, with the 500 mile race (the famous Southern 500) moving to Mother's Day weekend.

title: Carolina Dodge Dealers 400
text: The 400 mile race was eliminated, although Dodge's sponsorship was transferred to the 500 miler.

title: Johnny Rutherford
text: John Sherman "Johnny" Rutherford III (born March 12, 1938), also known as "Lone Star JR", is an American former automobile racing driver.

title: Johnny Rutherford
text: He is one of ten drivers to win the prestigious Indianapolis 500 mile race at least three times, winning in 1974, 1976, and 1980.

title: 1964 Armstrong 500
text: The 1964 Armstrong 500 was a production car race held on 4 October 1964 at the Mount Panorama Circuit just outside Bathurst in New South Wales, Australia.

title: 1964 Armstrong 500
text: The 500 mile race was open to Australian built production sedans of which 100 examples had been registered.

title: 1964 Armstrong 500
text: It was the fifth Armstrong 500 and the second to be held at Bathurst although it is commonly referred to as the fifth "Bathurst 500".

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: Orange County Fair Speedway is a five-eighths mile dirt oval speedway in Middletown, Orange County, New York.

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: The facility holds weekly stock car races and demolition derbies during the summer months.

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: The track was built in 1857 for horse racing at the Orange County Fair and staged its first automobile race on August 16, 1919.

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: The fair began as an agricultural exhibit in 1843 and was permanently located in the Wallkill–Middletown area in 1857.

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: The speedway is located at 239 Wisner Avenue in Middletown on land which was known as The Ogden Tract in the mid-1850s.

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: It was originally a half-mile horse racing track known as the Harry Clay Oval, named after a race horse that was famous at that time.

title: Orange County Fair Speedway
text: Over the years, the track was widened and lengthened to a true 5/8-mile race track.

title: Lean Horse Ultramarathon
text: The Lean Horse Ultramarathon is run in August every year in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

title: Lean Horse Ultramarathon
text: It was first run in 2005.

title: Lean Horse Ultramarathon
text: It features a 100-mile race, a 50-mile race, and a 50-kilometer race.

title: Lean Horse Ultramarathon
text: Most of the course is on the George S. Mickelson Trail.

title: Lean Horse Ultramarathon
text: It was the 33rd sanctioned 100-mile race in the United States and is known as one of the easiest hundred mile races in the country.

title: Subway 400
text: The Subway 400 was the second race of the NASCAR Winston Cup Series season until 2004, held a week after the Daytona 500.

title: Subway 400
text: This 400-mile (644 km) annual race was sponsored by Subway and was held at North Carolina Speedway ("The Rock") since 1966.

title: Subway 400
text: From 1966 to 1995, a 500-mile (805-km) race was held; the race was known as the Peach Blossom 500 (1966), the Carolina 500 (1967–1985), and the Goodwrench 500 (1986–1995).

title: Subway 400
text: In 1996, the race was shortened to its current distance of 400 miles; the 400 mile race was called the Goodwrench Service 400 (1996–1997), the GM Goodwrench Service Plus 400 (1998), the Dura Lube/Big K 400 (1999), the Dura Lube/Kmart 400 (2000), the Dura Lube 400 (2001), and the Subway 400 (2002–2004).

title: Louis Schwitzer Award
text: The Louis Schwitzer Award is presented annually to an engineer, or a team of engineers, for excellence in the design, development and implementation of new, innovative motorsports technology concepts for use in the Indianapolis 500 Mile Race.

title: Louis Schwitzer Award
text: The focus of this award is on those concepts that improve the performance, safety, or energy efficiency of racing cars, related components and systems, or driver and race track support equipment.

title: Orange County Speedway
text: Orange County Speedway is a 3/8 mile (0.6 km) asphalt oval in Orange County, North Carolina, near Rougemont.

title: Orange County Speedway
text: It first opened in 1966 as 1/4 mile (0.4 km) and 5/8 mile (1.6 km) dirt oval (Trico Speedway), which operated until 1967 and 1973, respectively.

title: Orange County Speedway
text: The facility was reopened and paved in 1983.

title: Orange County Speedway
text: With a slogan of "the fastest 3/8-mile race track in America," the oval features 19 degree banking through the turns and 16 degrees on the straightaways creating three distinct grooves making for very fast turns.

title: Orange County Speedway
text: The aluminum grandstands stretch from Turn 4 all the way down the front straightaway to Turn 1.

title: Orange County Speedway
text: The speedway closed in 2003, but reopened on March 11, 2006 as an American Speed Association member track.

title: Allison Transmission
text: Allison began in 1909 when James A. Allison, along with three business partners, helped found and build the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: Allison Transmission
text: In 1911, Allison’s new track held the first Indianapolis 500 mile race.

title: Allison Transmission
text: In addition to funding several race teams, Jim Allison established his own racing team in 1915 and quickly gained a reputation for his work on race cars and automotive technology in general.

title: Bel Air Racetrack
text: Bel Air Racetrack was a horse racing facility located one mile north of Baltimore Pike and east of Tollgate Road in Bel Air, Maryland.

title: Bel Air Racetrack
text: The 100-acre site was originally plotted in 1870 but was later improved and expanded in 1936 by new owner Ray Bryson to include a 3/4 mile race track, new starting gate, and larger grandstands.

title: Bel Air Racetrack
text: The track flourished until the 1940s when the owners became embroiled in political efforts to close the track.

title: Bel Air Racetrack
text: After Bryson died in 1958, the state legislature eventually prevailed and the track closed in 1960.

title: Bel Air Racetrack
text: The property is now the site of Harford Mall.

title: Jacopo Puccini
text: Jacopo (Giacomo) Puccini (] ; 26 January 1712 16 May 1781) was an 18th-century Italian composer who lived and worked primarily in Lucca, Tuscany.

title: Jacopo Puccini
text: He was the first of five generations of composers, the most famous of whom was his great-great-grandson, the opera composer Giacomo Puccini.

title: La Bohème (1988 film)
text: La bohème (also known as "La bohème de Puccini") is a 1988 Italian-French film of an opera directed by Luigi Comencini.

title: La Bohème (1988 film)
text: It is based on Giacomo Puccini's "La bohème".

title: Cesira Ferrani
text: Cesira Ferrani (May 8, 1863 in Turin – May 4, 1943 in Pollone) was an Italian operatic soprano who is best known for debuting two of the most iconic roles in opera history, Mimì in the original 1896 production of Giacomo Puccini's "La bohème" and the title role in Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" in its 1893 world premiere.

title: Cesira Ferrani
text: Ferrani sang a wide repertoire that encompassed not only verismo opera but the works of composers like Verdi, Gounod, Wagner, and Debussy.

title: La Bohème (2008 film)
text: La bohème (also known as "La bohème de Puccini") is a 2008 Austrian-German film of an opera directed by Robert Dornhelm.

title: La Bohème (2008 film)
text: It is based on Giacomo Puccini's "La bohème".

title: Ron Bottcher
text: Ron Bottcher (11 May 1940 – 12 April 1991) was an American operatic baritone who was actively performing with both the New York City Opera (NYCO) and the Metropolitan Opera during the 1960s.

title: Ron Bottcher
text: A native of Sandpoint, Idaho, he earned music degrees from the University of Montana and the Curtis Institute of Music.

title: Ron Bottcher
text: He made his debut at the Santa Fe Opera in the summer of 1961, where he portrayed the roles of Leopold in Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier", Marcello in Giacomo Puccini's "La bohème", and the Head waiter in Paul Hindemith's "Neues vom Tage".

title: Ron Bottcher
text: His roles at the NYCO included Escamillo in Georges Bizet's "Carmen" and Sharpless in Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" among others.

title: Ron Bottcher
text: At the Met he created roles in the world premieres of Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra" and Marvin David Levy's "Mourning Becomes Electra".

title: Ron Bottcher
text: He died at the age of 50 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan of AIDS related illness.

title: Gianni Schicchi
text: Gianni Schicchi (] ) is a comic opera in one act by Giacomo Puccini to an Italian libretto by Giovacchino Forzano, composed in 1917–18.

title: Gianni Schicchi
text: The libretto is based on an incident mentioned in Dante's "Divine Comedy".

title: Gianni Schicchi
text: The work is the third and final part of Puccini's "Il trittico" (The Triptych)—three one-act operas with contrasting themes, originally written to be presented together.

title: Gianni Schicchi
text: Although it continues to be performed with one or both of the other "trittico" operas, "Gianni Schicchi" is now more frequently staged either alone or with short operas by other composers.

title: Gianni Schicchi
text: The aria "O mio babbino caro" is one of Puccini's best known, and one of the most popular arias in opera.

title: La fanciulla del West
text: La fanciulla del West ("The Girl of the West") is an opera in three acts by Giacomo Puccini to an Italian libretto by and , based on the play "The Girl of the Golden West" by the American author David Belasco.

title: La fanciulla del West
text: "Fanciulla" followed "Madama Butterfly", which was also based on a Belasco play.

title: La fanciulla del West
text: The opera has fewer of the show-stopping highlights that are characteristic of other Puccini works, but is admired for its impressive orchestration and for a score that is more melodically integrated than is typical of his previous work.

title: La fanciulla del West
text: "Fanciulla" displays influences from composers Claude Debussy and Richard Strauss, without being in any way imitative.

title: La fanciulla del West
text: Similarities between the libretto and the work of Richard Wagner have also been found, though some attribute this more to the original plot of the play, and have asserted that the opera remains quintessentially Italian.

title: Festival Puccini
text: The Festival Puccini (Puccini Festival) is an annual summer opera festival held in July and August to present the operas of the famous Italian composer Giacomo Puccini.

title: Lilian Sukis
text: Lilian Sukis (born 29 June 1939, Kaunas) is a Canadian operatic soprano of Lithuanian birth.

title: Lilian Sukis
text: After earning diplomas from the University of Toronto and McMaster University, she made her professional opera debut in 1964 as Kate Pinkerton in Giacomo Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" with the Canadian Opera Company.

title: Lilian Sukis
text: In 1965 she sang the role of Countess Almaviva in Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" at the Stratford Festival.

title: Lilian Sukis
text: That same year she became a pupil at the Metropolitan Opera Studio and School.

title: Lilian Sukis
text: She made her debut at the Met in 1967 as Helen Niles in the world premiere of Marvin David Levy's "Mourning Becomes Electra".

title: Lilian Sukis
text: In 1969 she became a member of the Bavarian State Opera where she remained for more than 20 years.

title: Lilian Sukis
text: She has also appeared as a guest artist with several major opera houses and opera festivals internationally, including the Bayreuth Festival, the Frankfurt Opera, Graz, the Hamburg State Opera, the Salzburg Festival, and the Vienna State Opera among others.

title: O mio babbino caro
text: "O mio babbino caro " ("Oh My Beloved Father") is a soprano aria from the opera "Gianni Schicchi" (1918) by Giacomo Puccini to a libretto by Giovacchino Forzano.

title: O mio babbino caro
text: It is sung by Lauretta after tensions between her father Schicchi and the family of Rinuccio, the boy she loves, have reached a breaking point that threatens to separate her from Rinuccio.

title: O mio babbino caro
text: It provides an interlude expressing lyrical simplicity and single-hearted love in contrast with the atmosphere of hypocrisy, jealousy, double-dealing, and feuding in the medieval Florence of Puccini's only comedy.

title: O mio babbino caro
text: It provides the only set-piece in the through-composed opera.

title: On My Mind (Ellie Goulding song)
text: "On My Mind" is a song by English singer Ellie Goulding from her third studio album "Delirium" (2015).

title: On My Mind (Ellie Goulding song)
text: It was released as the album's lead single on 17 September 2015.

title: On My Mind (Ellie Goulding song)
text: It was written by Goulding, Max Martin, Savan Kotecha and Ilya Salmanzadeh.

title: On My Mind (Ellie Goulding song)
text: "On My Mind" is an electropop and R&B song whose instrumentation consists of scratchy guitars, trap drums, slapped beats and sharp, syncopated electronica.

title: On My Mind (Ellie Goulding song)
text: Lyrically, "On My Mind" talks about a one-night stand with someone the protagonist shouldn't be with, having a dichotomy between heart and head.

title: On My Mind (Ellie Goulding song)
text: Though firmly denied by Goulding, many critics considered it an answer song to Ed Sheeran's "Don't".

title: List of songs recorded by Ellie Goulding

title: List of songs recorded by Ellie Goulding
text: Goulding also collaborated with Jonny Lattimer on the singles "Starry Eyed" and "The Writer", and shared writing credits with Fraser T Smith on "Your Biggest Mistake".

title: List of songs recorded by Ellie Goulding
text: In November 2010, the singer re-released "Lights" as "Bright Lights", which included the standard version of the album and several new songs.

title: List of songs recorded by Ellie Goulding
text: She collaborated with Richard Stannard and Ash Howes on "Lights" and recorded a cover version of Elton John's "Your Song".

title: List of songs recorded by Ellie Goulding
text: At this time, Goulding also contributed guest vocals on the song "Wonderman" for Tinie Tempah's debut studio album "Disc-Overy" (2010).

title: Delirium (Ellie Goulding album)
text: Delirium is the third studio album by English singer and songwriter Ellie Goulding, released on 6 November 2015 by Polydor Records.

title: Delirium (Ellie Goulding album)
text: Music critics were generally impressed by the overall production of the record, although they were ambivalent in regards to its originality.

title: Delirium (Ellie Goulding album)
text: It debuted at number three on the UK Albums Chart and the US "Billboard" 200, earning Goulding her highest-charting record in the latter country and her highest first-week sales figures in both territories.

title: Delirium (Ellie Goulding album)
text: The album spawned three singles: "On My Mind", "Army" and "Something in the Way You Move".

title: Outside (Calvin Harris song)

title: Fay School
text: Fay School is an independent, coeducational day and boarding school, located on a 66 acre campus some 25 mi from Boston in Southborough, Massachusetts, and is the oldest junior boarding school in the United States.

title: Fay School
text: It has 475 students enrolled from Pre-kindergarten through grade 9; the boarding program (grades 7–9) enrolls 120 students from throughout the United States and more than 19 foreign countries.

title: Fay School
text: Fay opened its Primary School (Pre-K to Grade Two) in 2010 and moved its 6th grade into the Lower School program (now 3rd to 6th) in the 2012–13 school year.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: Princeton High School was founded in 1867 and graduated its first class in 1869.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: The school was started as a boarding school and taught subjects as English, mathematics, history, and the sciences.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: The school was enlarged in both 1894 and 1908 in order to accommodate for increases in attendance.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: The school was completely destroyed by fire on December 15, 1924.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: Plans were then drawn up to build a new school, but in the mean time classes were held in City Hall, the Post Office, and the Christian and Mission Covenant Churches in Princeton.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: The new school opened its doors on September 27, 1926.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: The building, 350 ft long and 100 ft wide, contained twenty classrooms; an auditorium seating 1,100; a library; a science lecture room; chemistry, physics and botanical laboratories; and a gymnasium.

title: Princeton High School (Illinois)
text: The building is still in use today, though several additions and remodelings have taken place since then.

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)
text: Cotter High School is the sole Roman Catholic High School in Winona, Minnesota, and is one of the first in the state.

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)
text: Today, Cotter Schools consists of the Cotter High School and Cotter Junior High School.

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)

title: Cotter High School (Winona, Minnesota)
text: In 1992, with help from an endowment from the Hiawatha Education Foundation, the school moved to its current location on the campus of the former College of Saint Teresa, allowing it to add a boarding school component.

title: Sainik School Balachadi, Jamnagar
text: The Sainik School Balachadi ("Hindi: सैनिक शाला बालाचडी" ), Jamnagar, Gujarat, is one of the Top Sainik School in the Chain of 26 Sainik Schools in India.

title: Sainik School Balachadi, Jamnagar

title: Westminster School, Adelaide

title: Concho Indian Boarding School
text: Concho Indian Boarding School (also known as the Cheyenne-Arapaho Boarding School at Concho or Concho Indian School and home to the Concho Demonstration School) was a boarding school for members of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes and later opened to other Native American students.

title: Concho Indian Boarding School

title: PNG solution
text: The Regional Resettlement Arrangement between Australia and Papua New Guinea, colloquially known as the PNG solution, is the name given to an Australian government policy in which any asylum seeker who comes to Australia by boat without a visa will be refused settlement in Australia, instead being settled in Papua New Guinea if they are found to be legitimate refugees.

title: PNG solution
text: The policy includes a significant expansion of the Australian immigration detention facility on Manus Island, where refugees will be sent to be processed prior to resettlement in Papua New Guinea, and if their refugee status is found to be non-genuine, they will be either repatriated, sent to a third country other than Australia or remain in detention indefinitely.

title: PNG solution
text: The policy was announced on 19 July 2013 by Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd and Papua New Guinean Prime Minister Peter O'Neill, effective immediately, in response to a growing number of asylum seeker boat arrivals.

title: PNG solution
text: The then Opposition Leader Tony Abbott initially welcomed the policy, while Greens leader Christine Milne and several human rights advocate groups opposed it, with demonstrations protesting the policy held in every major Australian city after the announcement.

title: Night School: the Web Series

title: Reset button technique
text: The reset button technique (based on the idea of "status quo ante") is a plot device that interrupts continuity in works of fiction.

title: Reset button technique
text: Simply put, use of a reset button device returns all characters and situations to the "status quo" they held before a major change of some sort was introduced.

title: Reset button technique
text: Typically it occurs either in the middle of a program and negates a portion of it, or it occurs at the beginning, or very end, of a program to negate all that came before it.

title: Reset button technique
text: Often used in science fiction television series, animated series, soap operas, and comic books, the device allows elaborate and dramatic changes to characters and the fictional universe that might otherwise invalidate the premise of the show with respect to future episodes or issues continuity.

title: Reset button technique
text: Writers may, for example, use the technique to allow the audience to experience the death of the lead character, which traditionally would not be possible without effectively ending the work.

title: Rising Star (France)
text: Rising Star is a French musical television competition series based on the Rising Star contest series based on the Israeli programme "HaKokhav HaBa".

title: Rising Star (France)

title: Rising Star (France)

title: Iron Man (TV series)

text: The format of the series is a parody of the fly on the wall documentary technique that intersperses traditional situation comedy segments with mock interviews with the show's characters, provides the audience access to the ongoing interior monologues for all of the main characters, as well as occasional insights into other characters within the show.

title: Auger electron spectroscopy
text: Auger electron spectroscopy (AES; pronounced ] in French) is a common analytical technique used specifically in the study of surfaces and, more generally, in the area of materials science.

title: Auger electron spectroscopy
text: Underlying the spectroscopic technique is the Auger effect, as it has come to be called, which is based on the analysis of energetic electrons emitted from an excited atom after a series of internal relaxation events.

title: Auger electron spectroscopy
text: The Auger effect was discovered independently by both Lise Meitner and Pierre Auger in the 1920s.

title: Auger electron spectroscopy
text: Though the discovery was made by Meitner and initially reported in the journal "Zeitschrift für Physik" in 1922, Auger is credited with the discovery in most of the scientific community.

title: Auger electron spectroscopy
text: Until the early 1950s Auger transitions were considered nuisance effects by spectroscopists, not containing much relevant material information, but studied so as to explain anomalies in X-ray spectroscopy data.

title: Auger electron spectroscopy
text: Since 1953 however, AES has become a practical and straightforward characterization technique for probing chemical and compositional surface environments and has found applications in metallurgy, gas-phase chemistry, and throughout the microelectronics industry.

title: Katri, Girl of the Meadows
text: Katri, Girl of the Meadows (牧場の少女カトリ , Makiba no Shōjo Katori ) is an anime series based on the Finnish novel, ""Paimen, piika ja emäntä"" by Auni Nuolivaara.

title: Katri, Girl of the Meadows
text: The series was broadcast originally in Japan in 1984 as part of the children's anthology series "World Masterpiece Theater", also known simply as ""Meisaku" from Nippon Animation.

title: Katri, Girl of the Meadows
text: The anthology had before and after produced a great variety of animated series based on different children's novels from around the world; among them were "" (1983) and "Little Princess Sara" (1985).

title: Katri, Girl of the Meadows
text: In Europe, where "World Masterpiece Theater" series have found huge success, "Katri, Girl of the Meadows" made its way to different countries, including Spain, Italy, France, and Germany.

title: Katri, Girl of the Meadows
text: The series has never been broadcast or published in Finland where it remains mostly unknown.

title: Ken Herock
text: Ken Herock (born July 16, 1941, in Pittsburgh) was an American college and professional football player who played tight end.

title: Ken Herock
text: He played collegiately at West Virginia and professionally in the American Football League, where he played for the AFL Champion Oakland Raiders in the second AFL-NFL World Championship Game, held after the 1967 season.

title: Ken Herock
text: He attended Munhall High School in Pittsburgh.

title: Ken Herock
text: His six-year pro career was spent with the Oakland Raiders, who he helped win the AFL title, the Cincinnati Bengals, and the Boston Patriots.

title: Ken Herock
text: After his playing career ended, Herock was a player personnel executive in the NFL with the Raiders, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Ken Herock

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: The 1989 season was the Houston Oilers 30th season and their 20th in the National Football League (NFL).

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: The franchise scored 365 points while the defense gave up 412 points.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: Their record of 9 wins and 7 losses resulted in a second-place finish in the AFC Central Division.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: The Oilers appeared once on Monday Night Football and appeared in the playoffs for the third consecutive year.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: It would be Jerry Glanville’s final year as the Oilers coach.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: Perhaps one of the lowest points of the season for the Oilers was their second to last game against division rival Bengals.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: The Bengals thumped the Oilers 61-7 in that game.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: This loss marked the worst defeat for the team during its tenure in Houston.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: As of 2017, the worst defeat for the team known either as the Oilers or the Titans was in 2009 when they lost 59-0 to the New England Patriots.

title: 1989 Houston Oilers season
text: It was the second time the Oilers had allowed 61 points to the Bengals, the other being a 61-17 loss at home in 1972.

text: Jerry Glanville was hired to be the team's new coach.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season
text: The franchise changed their helmets from red to black.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season
text: Atlanta looked to improve on its 3-13 record from 1989.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season
text: The team did improve on its 3-13 record, finishing 5-11, but the Falcons missed the playoffs for the eighth straight season.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season
text: The season started out pretty well for Atlanta, as they beat playoff contenders Houston, New Orleans, and Cincinnati at home.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season
text: The team sat at 3-4 after their win against Cincinnati.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season
text: It then lost seven games in a row before winning its last two to end the season.

title: 1990 Atlanta Falcons season

title: 2013 East–West Shrine Game
text: The 2013 East–West Shrine Game was the 88th staging of the all-star college football exhibition game featuring NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision players and a few select invitees from Canadian university football.

title: 2013 East–West Shrine Game
text: The game featured over 100 players from the 2012 college football season, and prospects for the 2013 Draft of the professional National Football League (NFL).

title: 2013 East–West Shrine Game
text: In the week prior to the game, scouts from all 32 NFL teams attended.

title: 2013 East–West Shrine Game
text: The proceeds from the East-West Shrine Game benefit Shriners Hospitals for Children.

title: 2013 East–West Shrine Game
text: Jerry Glanville and Leeman Bennett were named coaches on December 5, 2012.

title: 2013 East–West Shrine Game
text: The West defeated the East 28-13.

title: Keith Bostic (American football)
text: William Keith Bostic (born January 17, 1961) is a former professional American football player who played for seven seasons in the National Football League (NFL).

title: Keith Bostic (American football)
text: During his career he played safety for the Houston Oilers and the Cleveland Browns.

title: Keith Bostic (American football)
text: Bostic served as the Oiler defensive captain under Jerry Glanville.

title: Keith Bostic (American football)
text: He earned one Pro Bowl selection and missed another based on a tiebreaker for the last safety chosen.

title: Keith Bostic (American football)
text: In his Pro Bowl season, he led the American Football Conference in interceptions.

title: Mouse Davis
text: Darrel "Mouse" Davis (born September 6, 1932) is a retired American football coach and former player.

title: Mouse Davis
text: A veteran coach at the high school, college, and professional levels, he last coached with Jerry Glanville at Portland State and with June Jones at the University of Hawaii at Manoa.

title: Mouse Davis
text: Davis served as the head football coach at Portland State University from 1975 to 1980, compiling a record of 42–24.

title: Mouse Davis
text: He has also been a head coach with the Denver Gold of the United States Football League (1985), the New York/New Jersey Knights of the World League of American Football (1991–1992), and the Detroit Fury (2001–2002) and the San Diego Riptide (2003) of the Arena Football League.

title: Mouse Davis
text: A native of Washington, Davis grew up in Oregon, where he started his coaching career as a high school football coach.

title: Mouse Davis
text: Davis is now widely regarded as the 'godfather' of the run and shoot offense.

title: Keith Bostic
text: Keith Bostic is an American Software Engineer and one of the key people in the history of Berkeley Software Distribution UNIX and Open Source software.

title: 1987 Pittsburgh Steelers season
text: The Pittsburgh Steelers are a professional American Football team playing in the National Football League.

title: 1987 Pittsburgh Steelers season
text: Noll was renowned as a stoic character, but in complete contrast was his reaction to Jerry Glanville, the head coach of the Oilers.

title: 1987 Pittsburgh Steelers season

text: This was in reaction to Glanville's earlier comments on how the Oilers field was the 'house of pain' and his prediction that his players would intentionally hurt the Steelers.

title: Lucky to Be Alive (Confederate Railroad album)
text: Lucky to Be Alive is the seventh studio album by the American country music band Confederate Railroad.

text: The project marks the first album release in nine years for the Grammy-nominated group, and was released on July 15 to music retailers nationwide.

title: Willoughton
text: Willoughton is a village and civil parish in the West Lindsey district of Lincolnshire, England.

title: Willoughton
text: It is situated 2 mi west from the A15 road, 13 mi north from Lincoln and 3 mi south from Kirton Lindsey.

title: Willoughton
text: According to the 2001 Census the village had a population of 330, increasing to 341 at the 2011 census.

title: Kirton, Suffolk
text: Kirton is a village and a civil parish in the shire county of Suffolk, England, situated off the A14 road, about 4.5 km from Felixstowe and around 10 km from Ipswich.

title: Kirton, Suffolk
text: The closest train station to Kirton is Trimley.

title: Kirton, Suffolk
text: According to the 2011 census, Kirton had a population of 1,146.

title: Kirton, Suffolk
text: It is located between the River Debben and the River Orwell.

title: Kirton, Suffolk
text: The village of Kirton covers a total area of 8.3 km2 .

title: Kirton, Suffolk
text: As the county of Suffolk lacks quarries, many of the buildings are made from flint, clay and timber.

title: Demographics of Tiruchirappalli
text: Tiruchirappalli is a city in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu.

title: Demographics of Tiruchirappalli
text: It is the fourth most populous city and is the densest regional urban area in the state.

title: Demographics of Tiruchirappalli
text: According to the 2001 census, Tiruchirappalli had a population of 752,066 with in the city limits and an extended urban agglomeration population of 866,354.

title: Demographics of Tiruchirappalli
text: According to the 2011 provisional population totals, the city has a population of 846,915 while the regional urban area has 1,021,717 residents.

title: Demographics of Tiruchirappalli
text: The city's sex ratio of 1025 is among the best for any city in India which has a population of one million or more.

title: 2001 Bangladesh census
text: In 2001, the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics, conducted a national census in Bangladesh, ten years after the 1991 census.

title: 2001 Bangladesh census
text: They recorded data from all of the districts and upazilas and main cities in Bangladesh including statistical data on population size, households, sex and age distribution, marital status, economically active population, literacy and educational attainment, religion, number of children etc.

title: 2001 Bangladesh census
text: According to the adjusted 2001 census figures, Bangladesh's population stood at 129.3 million (an initial count put it at 124.4 million; an adjustment for the standard rate of undercounting then boosted the figure).

title: 2001 Bangladesh census
text: According to the census, Hindus were 9.2 per cent of the population.

title: Urbanisation in India
text: Urbanization in India began to accelerate after independence, due to the country's adoption of a mixed economy, which gave rise to the development of the private sector.

title: Urbanisation in India
text: Urbanisation is taking place at a faster rate in India.

title: Urbanisation in India
text: Population residing in urban areas in India, according to 1901 census, was 11.4%.

title: Urbanisation in India
text: This count increased to 28.53% according to 2001 census, and crossing 30% as per 2011 census, standing at 31.16%.

title: Urbanisation in India
text: According to a survey by UN State of the World Population report in 2007, by 2030, 40.76% of country's population is expected to reside in urban areas.

title: Urbanisation in India
text: As per World Bank, India, along with China, Indonesia, Nigeria, and the United States, will lead the world's urban population surge by 2050.

title: Hockley
text: Hockley is a large village and civil parish in Essex, England located between Chelmsford and Southend-on-Sea.

title: Hockley
text: More specifically it lies between Rayleigh and Rochford.

title: Hockley
text: It came to prominence during the coming of the railway in the 1890s and at the 2001 census had a population of 13,616 people, reducing to 9,616 at the 2011 Census, many of whom commute to London.

title: Hockley
text: The parish of Hockley itself has a population of 8,909 (2001 census), while the urban area runs into the neighbouring parish of Hawkwell.

title: Hockley
text: Hockley railway station serves the village.

title: Borough of Berwick-upon-Tweed
text: Berwick-upon-Tweed was a local government district and borough in Northumberland in the north-east of England, on the border with Scotland.

title: Borough of Berwick-upon-Tweed
text: The district had a resident population of 25,949 according to the 2001 census, which also notes that it is the most ethnically homogeneous in the country, with 99.6% of the population recording themselves in the 2001 census as "White".

title: Borough of Berwick-upon-Tweed
text: It was also the smallest district in England with borough status, and the third-least densely populated local government district (after Eden and Tynedale).

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: Parkridge is a residential community in western Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, located on land annexed by the city between 1975 and 1979.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: Development of the subdivision (initially called "Fairhaven II" after the neighbouring community to the east, began in the early 1980s.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: The extreme west end of the neighbourhood remained undeveloped until the subsequent creation of the adjacent Blairmore Suburban Centre led to the final phase of Parkridge being built out in the early 2010s.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: Whereas the majority of residents are employed in the sales and service sector, the next highest employer is business, finance and administration.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: The two main age groups are those in their 40s and teenagers as of 2005.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: Until recently Parkridge was the farthest western neighbourhood of Saskatoon south of 22nd Street.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: However, new construction will soon see Neighbourhood 2 of the Blairmore SDA bear that claim to fame.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: In comparison, the neighbourhood of Parkridge with a 2001 census population of 4,505 is larger than the Saskatchewan city of Melville which had a population of 4,149 in 2006, and 4,453 in 2001 and Parkridge is a little smaller than the provincial city of Humboldt which was 4,998 in 2006, and 5,161 in 2001.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: In Saskatchewan rural towns must maintain a population above 5,000 to apply for city status.

title: Parkridge, Saskatoon
text: According to MLS data, the average sale price of a home as of 2013 was $327,072.

title: Sauce Viejo, Argentina
text: It is located about 22 km from the province's capital city, Santa Fe, and has a population of 6,825 inhabitants (2001 census ) which represents a growth of 87.96% compared to the 3,631 inhabitants (2001 census ) of the previous census.

text: Kirton is a village in Nottinghamshire, England.

title: Kirton, Nottinghamshire
text: It is located 3 mi east of Ollerton.

title: Kirton, Nottinghamshire
text: According to the United Kingdom Census 2001 it had a population of 273, reducing to 261 at the 2011 census.

title: Cypress-pine
text: Cypress-pine is the common name used for three closely related genera of conifers in the cypress family Cupressaceae:

title: Fokienia
text: Fokienia is a genus of conifer tree belonging to the cypress family.

title: Fokienia
text: In its characteristics, "Fokienia" is intermediate between the genera of "Chamaecyparis" and "Calocedrus".

title: Fokienia
text: Genetically "Fokienia" is much closer to "Chamaecyparis", and not all researchers recognize "Fokienia" as a separate genus.

title: Fokienia
text: The genus comprises only one living species, Fokienia hodginsii or Fujian cypress (; Vietnamese: "Pơmu" ), and one fossil species ("Fokienia ravenscragensis").

title: Cupressaceae
text: Cupressaceae is a conifer family, the cypress family, with worldwide distribution.

title: Cupressaceae
text: The family includes 27–30 genera (17 monotypic), which include the junipers and redwoods, with about 130–140 species in total.

title: Cupressaceae
text: They are monoecious, subdioecious or (rarely) dioecious trees and shrubs 1 – tall.

title: Cupressaceae
text: The bark of mature trees is commonly orange- to red- brown and of stringy texture, often flaking or peeling in vertical strips, but smooth, scaly or hard and square-cracked in some species.

title: Cupressus
text: The genus Cupressus is one of several genera within the family Cupressaceae that have the common name cypress; for the others, see cypress.

title: Cupressus
text: It is considered a polyphyletic group.

title: Cupressus
text: Based on genetic and morphological analysis, the "Cupressus" genus is found in the Cupressoideae subfamily.

title: Cupressus
text: The common name comes from Old French "cipres" and that from Latin "cyparissus", which is the latinisation of the Greek κυπάρισσος ("kypárissos").

title: Pilgerodendron
text: Pilgerodendron is a genus of conifer belonging to the cypress family Cupressaceae.

title: Pilgerodendron
text: It has only one species, Pilgerodendron uviferum, and is endemic to the Valdivian temperate rain forests and Magellanic subpolar forests of southern Chile and southwestern Argentina.

title: Pilgerodendron
text: It grows from 40 to 55°S in Tierra del Fuego, where it is the southernmost conifer in the world.

title: Pilgerodendron
text: It is a member of subfamily Callitroideae, a group of distinct southern hemisphere genera associated with the Antarctic flora.

title: Frenchman Formation
text: The Frenchman Formation is stratigraphic unit of Late Cretaceous (late Maastrichtian) age in the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin.

title: Frenchman Formation
text: It is present in southern Saskatchewan and the Cypress Hills of southeastern Alberta.

title: Frenchman Formation
text: The formation was defined by G.M. Furnival in 1942 from observations of outcrops along the Frenchman River, between Ravenscrag and Highway 37.

title: Frenchman Formation
text: It contains the youngest of dinosaur genera, much like the Hell Creek Formation in the United States.

title: Libocedrus
text: Libocedrus is a genus of five species of coniferous trees in the cypress family Cupressaceae, native to New Zealand and New Caledonia.

title: Libocedrus
text: The genus is closely related to the South American genera "Pilgerodendron" and "Austrocedrus", and the New Guinean genus "Papuacedrus", both of which are included within "Libocedrus" by some botanists.

title: Libocedrus
text: These genera are rather similar to the Northern Hemisphere genera "Calocedrus" and "Thuja": in earlier days, what is now "Calocedrus" was sometimes included in "Libocedrus".

title: Libocedrus
text: They are much less closely related, as recently confirmed (Gadek et al. 2000).

title: Libocedrus
text: The generic name means "teardrop cedar", apparently referring to drops of resin.

title: Ajugeae
text: Ajugeae is a tribe of the Teucrioideae subfamily of the family Lamiaceae and might contain the genera "Acrymia" , "Ajuga" , "Cymaria" , "Garrettia" , "Holocheila" .

title: Cedrol
text: Cedrol is a sesquiterpene alcohol found in the essential oil of conifers (cedar oil), especially in the genera "Cupressus" (cypress) and "Juniperus" (juniper).

title: Cedrol
text: It has also been identified in "Origanum onites", a plant related to oregano.

title: Cedrol
text: Its main uses are in the chemistry of aroma compounds.

title: Cedrol
text: It makes up about 19% of cedarwood oil Texas and 15.8% of cedarwood oil Virginia.

title: 2003 WNBA season
text: The 2003 WNBA Season was the Women's National Basketball Association's seventh season.

title: 2003 WNBA season
text: It was first season in which teams either folded or relocated, as well as the first to have teams that were not co-owned with NBA teams.

title: 2003 WNBA season
text: The Orlando Miracle relocated to Connecticut and became the Connecticut Sun, the Utah Starzz relocated to San Antonio, Texas and became the San Antonio Silver Stars.

title: 2003 WNBA season
text: Meanwhile, both the Miami Sol and the Portland Fire folded, while the Charlotte Sting became the second WNBA team without a brother NBA team.

title: 2003 WNBA season
text: The schedule increased from 32 games per team to 34, where it stands to this day.

title: 2003 WNBA season
text: The season ended with the Detroit Shock winning their first WNBA Championship.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: The Charlotte Hornets are a professional basketball club based in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: They are members of the National Basketball Association (NBA), playing in the Southeast Division of the Eastern Conference.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: The original Charlotte Hornets franchise played in Charlotte from 1988–2002 before relocating to New Orleans, Louisiana and becoming the New Orleans Hornets.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: A new franchise, the "Charlotte Bobcats", began play in the 2004–05 season.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: The team played for ten seasons as the Bobcats before adopting the Hornets name for the 2014–15 season.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: The Hornets name was left available after the New Orleans Hornets became the New Orleans Pelicans.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: As part of a deal between the Bobcats, Hornets and NBA, the renamed Hornets reclaimed the original Hornets' history and records from 1988 to 2002, while all of the Hornets' records from 2002 to 2013 remained with the Pelicans.

title: List of Charlotte Hornets seasons
text: As a result, the Hornets are now reckoned as having suspended operations after the 2001–02 season before returning as the Bobcats in 2004; This has allowed all of Charlotte's NBA history to be recognized under one single franchise.

title: Charlotte Hornets all-time roster
text: The Charlotte Hornets are an American professional basketball team based in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Charlotte Hornets all-time roster
text: They play in the Southeast Division of the Eastern Conference in the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: Charlotte Hornets all-time roster
text: The Hornets were first established in 1988 as an expansion team, but relocated to New Orleans following the 2001–02 season.

title: Charlotte Hornets all-time roster
text: In 2004, a new expansion team, the Charlotte Bobcats, was established.

title: Charlotte Hornets all-time roster
text: After 10 seasons as the Bobcats, the team changed its name to the Charlotte Hornets for the 2014–15 season, a year after the New Orleans franchise relinquished the Hornets name and renamed itself the Pelicans.

title: Charlotte Hornets all-time roster
text: In addition to re-inheriting the Hornets name from New Orleans, the Charlotte franchise reclaimed the history and records of the original 1988–2002 Hornets, effectively becoming a continuation of the original franchise.

title: Muggsy Bogues
text: Tyrone Curtis "Muggsy" Bogues (born January 9, 1965) is an American retired basketball player.

title: Muggsy Bogues
text: The shortest player ever to play in the National Basketball Association, the 5 ft Bogues played point guard for four teams during his 14-season career in the NBA.

title: Muggsy Bogues
text: He is best known for his ten seasons with the Charlotte Hornets, and also played for the Washington Bullets, Golden State Warriors, and Toronto Raptors.

title: Muggsy Bogues
text: After his NBA career, he served as head coach of the now-defunct WNBA team Charlotte Sting.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: The original Charlotte Hornets of the National Basketball Association (NBA) were established in 1988 as an expansion team, based in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: The team's roster was filled with unprotected players at the 1988 NBA Expansion Draft, and five days later the Hornets made their first picks out of college players at the 1988 NBA draft.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: The Hornets remained in Charlotte for 14 seasons before relocating to New Orleans in 2002.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: Two years after the Hornets' departure, the Charlotte Bobcats were established in 2004.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: The Bobcats first participated in the 2004 NBA draft, two days after their expansion draft was held.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: The franchise's name was changed back to the Hornets at the conclusion of the 2013–14 season, one year after the team in Louisiana renamed itself the New Orleans Pelicans.

title: Charlotte Hornets draft history
text: The history and records of the original Charlotte Hornets were conveyed to the newly named Charlotte Hornets.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: The 1991–92 NBA season was the Charlotte Hornets' fourth season in the National Basketball Association.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: With the top overall pick in the 1991 NBA draft, the Hornets selected UNLV star Larry Johnson.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: Under new head coach Allan Bristow, the Hornets would get off to a slow start losing 8 of their first 9 games.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: At midseason, Rex Chapman was traded to the Washington Bullets as the Hornets would get stronger winning 9 of 13 games in February, on their way to finishing sixth in the Central Division with a record of 31 wins and 51 losses, a five-game improvement over the previous season.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: Johnson averaged 19.2 points and 11.0 rebounds per game, as he went on to win the 1992 NBA Rookie of the Year Award.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: Second-year star Kendall Gill led the team in scoring with 20.5 points per game.

title: 1991–92 Charlotte Hornets season
text: The Hornets led the NBA in attendance for the third time in four seasons.

title: Charlotte Hornets
text: The Charlotte Hornets are an American professional basketball team based in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Charlotte Hornets
text: The Hornets compete in the National Basketball Association (NBA), as a member of the league's Eastern Conference Southeast Division.

title: Charlotte Hornets
text: The team is largely owned by former NBA player and North Carolina native Michael Jordan, who acquired controlling interest in the team in 2010.

title: Charlotte Hornets
text: The Hornets play their home games at the Spectrum Center in Uptown Charlotte.

title: Ayana Walker
text: Ayana D’Nay Walker (born September 10, 1979) is an American former women's basketball player.

title: Ayana Walker
text: She played for the Louisiana Tech Lady Techsters basketball team from 1998 to 2002.

title: Ayana Walker
text: Walker was a member of gold-medal winning USA Basketball Women’s National Team in 2001 and set a USA single-game record with 19 rebounds in gold-medal game.

title: Ayana Walker
text: She was also a member of gold-medal winning USA Basketball World University Games Team in 2001.

title: Ayana Walker
text: Walker was drafted as the 20th overall pick by the Detroit Shock in the 2002 WNBA Draft.

title: Ayana Walker
text: As a member of the Shock, she won the 2003 WNBA Championship.

title: Ayana Walker
text: On July 3, 2005, Walker signed with the Charlotte Sting.

title: Ayana Walker
text: After the Sting franchise folded, Walker was drafted by Los Angeles Sparks as the 12th pick in the dispersal draft on January 8, 2007.

title: Ayana Walker
text: She returned to Detroit for her final season in 2007.

title: List of Texas Tech Lady Raiders in the WNBA Draft
text: The Texas Tech Lady Raiders basketball team, representing Texas Tech University, has had 9 players drafted into the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA) since the league began holding drafts in 1997.

title: List of Texas Tech Lady Raiders in the WNBA Draft
text: Sheryl Swoopes was Texas Tech's first player drafted in the WNBA, selected in the 1997 Initial Player Allocation.

title: List of Texas Tech Lady Raiders in the WNBA Draft
text: The Charlotte Sting had drafted three Lady Raiders, more than any other WNBA franchise: Michi Atkins, in the WNBA Elite Draft, and Angie Braziel and Jia Perkins during the college draft.

title: 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season
text: The 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season was the franchise's 25th season in the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season
text: This was the team's first year as the Charlotte Hornets since 2002.

title: 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season
text: The team had been known as the Charlotte Bobcats since its revival in 2004.

title: 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season
text: However, when the team formally changed its name to the Hornets on May 20, 2014; they also reclaimed the history and records of the original Charlotte Hornets franchise from the 1988–89 NBA season through the 2001–02 NBA season.

title: 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season
text: The New Orleans Pelicans retained the remaining history that exists under the New Orleans(/Oklahoma City) Hornets name from the 2002–03 NBA season through the 2012–13 NBA season.

title: 2014–15 Charlotte Hornets season
text: The team was led by head coach Steve Clifford and assistant coaches Patrick Ewing, Bob Beyer, Stephen Silas, Bob Weiss, and Mark Price.

title: Alien (soundtrack)
text: The iconic, avant-garde score to the film "Alien" was composed by Jerry Goldsmith and is considered by some to be one of his best, most visceral scores.

title: Alien (soundtrack)
text: Rather than focusing on themes, Goldsmith creates a bleak and dissonant soundscape that fits the film's dark and intense atmosphere, with only a few "romantic" cues.

title: Christus Apollo
text: Christus Apollo: Cantata Celebrating the Eighth Day of Creation and the Promise of the Ninth is a cantata in four movements for narrator, mezzo-soprano, choir, and orchestra, based on a text by the science fiction author Ray Bradbury and composed by the American composer Jerry Goldsmith.

title: Christus Apollo
text: The piece was commissioned by the California Chamber Symphony in 1969, and premiered later that year in Royce Hall at UCLA with the narration performed by Charlton Heston (who had starred in the 1968 film, "Planet of the Apes", for which Goldsmith had composed the musical score).

title: Mulan (soundtrack)
text: Mulan: An Original Walt Disney Records Soundtrack is the soundtrack for the 1998 Disney animated feature film, "Mulan".

title: Mulan (soundtrack)
text: Released by Walt Disney Records on June 2, 1998, the album featured songs by Matthew Wilder and David Zippel, conducted by Paul Bogaev, and score composed and conducted by Jerry Goldsmith.

title: Mulan (soundtrack)
text: Vocalists included Lea Salonga, Donny Osmond, 98 Degrees, Jaz Coleman, Stevie Wonder and Christina Aguilera.

title: Legend (film score)
text: Legend: The Music of Jerry Goldsmith is a musical film score by American composer Jerry Goldsmith, released in 1986 for the worldwide release of the film of the same name, (excluding the US).

title: Legend (film score)
text: The album was released on compact disc in 1992 through Silva Screen records and featured alternate cover art and additional songs.

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: The score to the 1986 James Cameron film "Aliens" was composed by James Horner.

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: The score itself includes musical references to Gayane's Adagio from Aram Khachaturian's "Gayane" ballet suite, which had been used in Stanley Kubrick's "" (1968).

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: The score also uses musical motifs, sound treatments and excerpts from Jerry Goldsmith's original soundtrack to "Alien" (1979).

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: Additional cues taken from Jerry Goldsmith's "Alien" score were used in the climax of the film when Horner was unable to finish some cues to Cameron's satisfaction.

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: The film's editors also reportedly altered the score's chronological flow, sometimes looping, truncating or removing the music and placing it in fragmented form in the film out of context.

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: Despite production issues, it was nominated for an Academy Award in 1986.

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: It was performed by the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: Aliens (soundtrack)
text: The soundtrack album was released the following year, in 1987.

title: Innerspace
text: Innerspace is a 1987 American science fiction comedy film directed by Joe Dante and produced by Michael Finnell.

title: Innerspace
text: Steven Spielberg served as executive producer.

title: Innerspace
text: The film was inspired by the 1966 science fiction film "Fantastic Voyage".

title: Innerspace
text: It stars Dennis Quaid, Martin Short and Meg Ryan, with Robert Picardo and Kevin McCarthy, with music composed by Jerry Goldsmith.

title: Innerspace
text: It earned well over $25 million in its domestic gross revenue and won an Oscar, the only film directed by Dante to do so.

title: L.A. Confidential (soundtrack)
text: L.A. Confidential is either the original soundtrack, on the Restless Records label featuring mainly songs and source music, or the original film score, on Varèse Sarabande Records, of the 1997 Academy Award- and Golden Globe Award-winning film "L.A. Confidential" starring Kevin Spacey, Russell Crowe, Guy Pearce, James Cromwell, Danny DeVito, and Kim Basinger (who won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for this film).

title: L.A. Confidential (soundtrack)
text: The original score was composed by Jerry Goldsmith.

title: Star Trek: Nemesis (soundtrack)
text: Star Trek: Nemesis – Music from the Original Motion Picture Soundtrack is a soundtrack album for the 2002 film, "", composed by Jerry Goldsmith.

title: Star Trek: Nemesis (soundtrack)
text: Released on December 10, 2002 through Varèse Sarabande, the soundtrack features fourteen tracks of score at a running time just over forty-eight minutes, though bootleg versions containing the entire score have since been released.

title: Star Trek: Nemesis (soundtrack)
text: A deluxe edition soundtrack limited to 5000 copies was released on January 6, 2014 by Varèse Sarabande.

title: Total Recall (1990 film)
text: Total Recall is a 1990 American science-fiction action film directed by Paul Verhoeven, starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Rachel Ticotin, Sharon Stone, Ronny Cox, and Michael Ironside.

title: Total Recall (1990 film)
text: The film is loosely based on the Philip K. Dick short story "We Can Remember It for You Wholesale".

title: Total Recall (1990 film)
text: It tells the story of a construction worker who is having troubling dreams about Mars and a mysterious woman there.

title: Total Recall (1990 film)
text: It was written by Ronald Shusett, Dan O'Bannon, Jon Povill, and Gary Goldman, and won a Special Achievement Academy Award for its visual effects.

title: Total Recall (1990 film)
text: The original score composed by Jerry Goldsmith won the BMI Film Music Award.

title: Lionheart (1987 film)
text: Lionheart, also known as Lionheart: The Children's Crusade, is a 1987 adventure film directed by Franklin J. Schaffner and produced by Talia Shire and Stanley O'Toole.

title: Lionheart (1987 film)
text: Shire's brother, Francis Ford Coppola, initially planned to direct the film but instead opted to be executive producer along with Shire's husband, Jack Schwartzman.

title: Lionheart (1987 film)
text: The screenplay was written by Menno Meyjes and Richard Outten from a story by Meyjes.

title: Lionheart (1987 film)
text: The composer Jerry Goldsmith wrote the score.

title: Lionheart (1987 film)
text: The film was released in August 1987.

title: Lionheart (1987 film)
text: It was distributed by Orion Pictures.

title: Jane Marcus
text: Jane Marcus (1938–2015) was a pioneering feminist literary scholar, specializing in women writers of the Modernist era, but especially in the social and political context of their writings.

title: Jane Marcus
text: Focusing on Virginia Woolf, Rebecca West, and Nancy Cunard, among many others, she devised groundbreaking analyses of Woolf's writings, upending a generation of criticism that ignored feminist, pacifist, and socialist themes in much of Woolf's work and critique of imperialism and bourgeois society.

title: Jane Marcus
text: Marcus's understanding of Woolf's place within the larger context of English literature has become prevailing wisdom today in the fields affected by her theorization and research, despite the controversial nature of her positions when they were originally formulated and how much opposition she garnered from earlier scholars and critics.

title: The Flash Girls
text: The Flash Girls are a now defunct folk music duo based out of Minneapolis, Minnesota.

title: The Flash Girls
text: The duo consisted of Emma Bull, a noted science fiction author, and Lorraine Garland, also known as "The Fabulous Lorraine".

title: The Flash Girls
text: Garland is also notable as Neil Gaiman's personal assistant; the group formed at a Guy Fawkes Day party at Gaiman's home.

title: The Flash Girls
text: The connections that both Bull and Garland had with the science fiction and fantasy communities allowed them to have an unusually notable group of people writing songs for and with them, including Jane Yolen, Alan Moore, and Neil Gaiman.

title: The Flash Girls
text: These songs are mixed in with their own original works, traditional songs such as Star of the County Down and Lily of the West, as well as poems put to music, including works by Dorothy Parker and A.A. Milne.

title: The Duchess and the Jeweller
text: "The Duchess and the Jeweller" (1938) is a short story by Virginia Woolf.

title: The Duchess and the Jeweller
text: Woolf, being an advocate of addressing the "stream of consciousness," shows the thoughts and actions of a greedy jeweller; Woolf makes a thematic point that corrupt people do corrupt actions for purely selfish motives (and often without regret).

title: The Duchess and the Jeweller
text: It was first published in British "Harper's Bazaar" Magazine in April 1938 and subsequently published posthumously in 1944 in the collection "A Haunted House and Other Short Stories.

title: Me! I'm Afraid of Virginia Woolf
text: Me!

title: Me! I'm Afraid of Virginia Woolf
text: I'm Afraid of Virginia Woolf is a 1978 television play by Alan Bennett, produced by London Weekend Television and directed by Stephen Frears.

title: Me! I'm Afraid of Virginia Woolf
text: The title of the play is a parody of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

title: Me! I'm Afraid of Virginia Woolf
text: ", which in turn plays on the title of the Disney song "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf?

title: Me! I'm Afraid of Virginia Woolf
Orlando: A Biography
text: Orlando: A Biography is a novel by Virginia Woolf, first published on 11 October 1928.

title: Orlando: A Biography
text: A high-spirited romp inspired by the tumultuous family history of Woolf's lover and close friend, the aristocratic poet and novelist Vita Sackville-West, it is arguably one of Woolf's most popular novels: a history of English literature in satiric form.

title: Orlando: A Biography
text: The book describes the adventures of a poet who changes sex from man to woman and lives for centuries, meeting the key figures of English literary history.

title: Orlando: A Biography
text: Considered a feminist classic, the book has been written about extensively by scholars of women's writing and gender and transgender studies.

title: Moments of Being
text: Moments of Being is a collection of posthumously-published autobiographical essays by Virginia Woolf.

title: Moments of Being
text: The collection was first found in the papers of her husband, used by Quentin Bell in his biography of Virginia Woolf, published in 1972.

title: Moments of Being
text: In 1976, the essays were edited for publication by Jeanne Schulkind.

title: Moments of Being
text: The second edition was published in 1985.

title: Moments of Being
text: The original texts are now housed at Sussex University and in the British Library in London.

title: Freshwater (opera)
text: Freshwater is a two-act chamber opera composed by Andy Vores, based on the 1929 comic play by Virginia Woolf.

title: Freshwater (opera)
text: Vores received assistance in creating the opera from Quentin Bell, Woolf's nephew and executor, who provided a rarely seen earlier version of the text that served as the inspiration for several passages of the libretto.

title: Pamela L. Caughie
text: Pamela L. Caughie is a professor and graduate program director in the English Department at Loyola University of Chicago.

title: Pamela L. Caughie
text: As of 2010, she is the president of the Modernist Studies Association.

title: Pamela L. Caughie
text: Caughie received her PhD from the University of Virginia in 1987.

title: Pamela L. Caughie
text: She is also a highly acclaimed Virginia Woolf scholar, and in 2010 was granted a National Endowment for the Humanities grant of $175,000 to continue her work on an electronic edition of Woolf's "To the Lighthouse".

title: The Mark on the Wall
text: "The Mark on the Wall" is the first published story by Virginia Woolf.

title: The Mark on the Wall
text: It was published in 1917 as part of the first collection of short stories written by Virginia Woolf and her husband, Leonard Woolf, called "Two Stories".

title: The Mark on the Wall
text: It was later published in New York in 1921 as part of another collection entitled "Monday or Tuesday".

title: Jane de Gay
text: Rev Dr "Jane de Gay" is a British academic and lecturer who has earned a reputation as an expert on the life and works of Virginia Woolf.

title: Jane de Gay
text: Dr de Gay's works on Woolf include a series of articles and a 2006 book, "Virginia Woolf's Novels and the Literary Past", published by Edinburgh University Press.

title: Jane de Gay
text: Her work has been recognised by the Virginia Woolf Society of Great Britain.

title: Jane de Gay
text: She has co-edited four books on gender and theatre, including "Languages of Theatre Shaped by Women" (with Lizbeth Goodman).

title: Billy Boy
text: "Billy Boy" is a traditional folk song and nursery rhyme found in the United States.

title: Billy Boy
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 326.

title: Billy Boy
text: It is a variant of the traditional English folk song "My Boy Billy", collected by Ralph Vaughan Williams and published by him in 1912 as number 232 in "Novello's School Songs".

title: Billy Boy
text: The song is very popular with the Orange Order.

title: Aiken Drum
text: "Aiken Drum" is a popular Scottish folk song and nursery rhyme, which probably has its origins in a Jacobite song about the Battle of Sheriffmuir (1715).

title: Aiken Drum
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 2571.

title: Tweedledum and Tweedledee
text: Tweedledum and Tweedledee are fictional characters in an English nursery rhyme and in Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There".

title: Tweedledum and Tweedledee
text: Their names may have originally come from an epigram written by poet John Byrom .

title: Tweedledum and Tweedledee
text: The nursery rhyme has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 19800.

title: Tweedledum and Tweedledee
text: The names have since become synonymous in western popular culture slang for any two people who look and act in identical ways, generally in a derogatory context.
