title: Girls and Boys Come Out To Play
text: 'Girls and Boys Come Out to Play' or 'Boys and Girls Come Out to Play' is a nursery rhyme that has existed since at least 1708.

title: Girls and Boys Come Out To Play
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 5452.

title: Row, Row, Row Your Boat
text: "Row, Row, Row Your Boat" is an English language nursery rhyme and a popular children's song.

title: Row, Row, Row Your Boat
text: It can also be an "action" nursery rhyme, whose singers sit opposite one another and "row" forwards and backwards with joined hands.

title: Row, Row, Row Your Boat
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 19236.

title: Did You Ever See a Lassie?
text: "Did You Ever See a Lassie?"

title: Did You Ever See a Lassie?
text: is a folk song, nursery rhyme, and singing game.

title: Did You Ever See a Lassie?
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 5040.

title: Lavender's Blue
text: "Lavender's Blue" (sometimes called "Lavender Blue") is an English folk song and nursery rhyme dating to the 17th century.

title: Lavender's Blue
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 3483.

title: Lavender's Blue
text: It has been recorded in various forms since the 20th century and some pop versions have been hits in the US and UK charts.

title: A Wise Old Owl
text: "A Wise Old Owl" is an English language nursery rhyme.

title: A Wise Old Owl
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 7734 and in The Oxford Dictionary of Nursery Rhymes, 2nd Ed.

title: A Wise Old Owl
text: of 1997, as number 394.

title: A Wise Old Owl
text: The rhyme is an improvement of a traditional nursery rhyme "There was an owl lived in an oak, wisky, wasky, weedle."

title: Pretty Little Dutch Girl
text: "Pretty Little Dutch Girl" is a children's nursery rhyme, clapping game and jump-rope rhyme.

title: Pretty Little Dutch Girl
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 12986.

title: Three Little Kittens
text: "Three Little Kittens" is an English language nursery rhyme, probably with roots in the British folk tradition.

title: Three Little Kittens
text: The rhyme as published today however is a sophisticated piece usually attributed to American poet Eliza Lee Cabot Follen (1787–1860).

title: Three Little Kittens
text: With the passage of time, the poem has been absorbed into the "Mother Goose" collection.

title: Three Little Kittens
text: The rhyme tells of three kittens who first lose, then find and soil, their mittens.

title: Three Little Kittens
text: When all is finally set to rights, the kittens receive their mother's approval and some pie.

title: Three Little Kittens
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 16150.

title: Corporate synergy
text: Corporate synergy refers to a financial benefit that a corporation expects to realize when it merges with or acquires another corporation.

title: Corporate synergy
text: Corporate synergy occurs when corporations interact congruently.

title: PRX-07034
text: PRX-07034 is a selective 5-HT receptor antagonist.

title: PRX-07034
text: It has cognition and memory-enhancing properties and potently decreases food intake and body weight in rodents.

title: PRX-07034
text: PRX-07034 was under development by Epix Pharmaceuticals for the treatment of obesity and cognitive impairment associated with Alzheimer's disease and schizophrenia but upon the company collapsing due to lack of funds the compound was auctioned to another corporation.

title: Exxon
text: Exxon was the brand name of oil and natural resources company Exxon Corporation, prior to 1972 known as Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

title: Exxon
text: In 1999, Exxon Corporation merged with Mobil to form ExxonMobil.

title: Exxon
text: The "Exxon" brand is still used by ExxonMobil's downstream operations as a brand for certain of its gas stations, motor fuel and related products (the highest concentration of which are located in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Texas and in the Mid-Atlantic and Southeastern states).

title: Exxon
text: Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was one of the Seven Sisters that dominated the global petroleum industry from the mid-1940s to the 1970s.

title: Oregon and Transcontinental Company
text: The Oregon and Transcontinental Company was a 19th-century holding company in the United States, organized by Henry Villard in 1881 to control the Northern Pacific Railroad and Oregon Railway and Navigation Company.

title: Oregon and Transcontinental Company
text: It was incorporated in Oregon.

title: Oregon and Transcontinental Company
text: New Jersey passed legislation in 1889 to facilitate the control of other companies by another corporation with a goal of encouraging trusts to convert into holding companies and relocate to that state.

title: Oregon and Transcontinental Company
text: Oregon and Transcontinental in 1890 re-incorporated as a holding company in New Jersey and became the North American Company so that it could take advantage of these expanded corporate powers and invest in a wider range of businesses.

title: Mobil Producing Nigeria
text: Mobil Producing Nigeria (MPN) "is one of three" Nigerian subsidiaries of the petroleum company ExxonMobil.

title: Mobil Producing Nigeria
text: It began operations in 1955.

title: Mobil Producing Nigeria
text: All of its operations are offshore, where it owns 90 platforms on 3200 km2 of territory.

title: Mobil Producing Nigeria
text: MPN is the second largest producer of crude oil in Nigeria after Shell.

title: Mobil Producing Nigeria
text: Erha field/vessel is the recent offshore deployment of ExxonMobil FPSO in Nigeria partnering with Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation.

title: Dummy corporation
text: A dummy corporation or dummy company is an entity created to serve as a front or cover for one or more companies.

title: Dummy corporation
text: It can have the appearance of being real (logo, website, and sometimes employing actual staff), but lacks the capacity to function independently.

title: Dummy corporation
text: The dummy corporation's sole purpose is to protect "an individual or another corporation from liability in either contract or import".

title: Religious Technology Center
text: The Religious Technology Center (RTC) is an American non-profit corporation that was founded in 1982 by the Church of Scientology to control and oversee the use of all of the trademarks, symbols and texts of Scientology and Dianetics.

title: Religious Technology Center
text: Although RTC controls their use, those works are owned by another corporation, the Church of Spiritual Technology which is doing business as L. Ron Hubbard Library, registered in Los Angeles County, California.

title: Scott Parkin
text: Scott Parkin (born 1969, Garland, Texas is an anti-war, environmental and global justice organizer, former community college history instructor, and a founding member of the Houston Global Awareness Collective.

title: Scott Parkin
text: He has been a vocal critic of the American invasion of Iraq, and of corporations such as Exxonmobil and Halliburton.

title: Scott Parkin
text: Since 2006, he has worked as an campaigner for the Rainforest Action Network, organizing campaigns against Bank of America, Citibank, TXU and the Keystone XL Pipeline.

title: Scott Parkin
text: He also organizes with Rising Tide North America.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: Boris Abramovich Berezovsky (Russian: Бори́с Абра́мович Березо́вский , 23 January 1946 – 23 March 2013) was a Russian business oligarch, government official, engineer and mathematician.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: He was a member of the Russian Academy of Sciences.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: Berezovsky was politically opposed to the President of Russia Vladimir Putin, since Putin's election in 2000 and remained a vocal critic of Putin for the rest of his life.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: In late 2000, after the Russian Deputy Prosecutor General demanded that Berezovsky appear for questioning, he did not return from abroad and moved to the UK, which granted him political asylum in 2003.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: In Russia he was later convicted "in absentia" of fraud and embezzlement.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: The first charges were brought during Primakov's government in 1999.

title: Boris Berezovsky (businessman)
text: Despite an Interpol Red Notice for Berezovsky's arrest, Russia repeatedly failed to obtain the extradition of Berezovsky from Britain, which became a major point of diplomatic tension between the two countries.

title: Yvonne Ridley
text: Yvonne Ridley (born 23 April 1958) is a British journalist who was a chair of the National Council of the now defunct Respect Party.

title: Yvonne Ridley
text: She was captured by the Taliban in 2001, and two years later converted to Islam after giving her captors an understanding that she would study Islam if they agreed to release her.

title: Yvonne Ridley
text: She is a vocal supporter of Palestine, a cause she took up as a schoolgirl and is also a critic of the political ideology of Zionism and vocal critic of Western media portrayals and foreign policy in the War on Terror, and has undertaken speaking tours throughout the Muslim world as well as America, Europe and Australia.

title: Yvonne Ridley
text: She has been called "something close to a celebrity in the Islamic world" by the journalist Rachel Cooke, and in 2008 was voted the "most recognisable woman in the Islamic world" by Islam Online.

title: List of Charmed characters
text: "Charmed" is an American television series that was originally broadcast by The WB for eight seasons from October 7, 1998, until May 21, 2006.

title: List of Charmed characters
text: The series narrative follows a trio of sisters, known as The Charmed Ones, the most powerful good witches of all time, who use their combine Power of Three to protect innocent lives from evil beings such as demons and warlocks.

title: List of Charmed characters
text: Each sister possesses unique magical powers that grow and evolve, while they attempt to maintain normal lives in modern-day San Francisco.

title: List of Charmed characters
text: The main characters of the first three seasons were Prue (Shannen Doherty), Piper (Holly Marie Combs) and Phoebe Halliwell (Alyssa Milano).

title: List of Charmed characters
text: After Doherty departed from the series in 2001, resulting in her character's death, she was replaced by Rose McGowan as the long-lost younger half-sister Paige Matthews from the fourth season onwards.

title: List of Charmed characters
text: The following list only contains characters that appeared in five or more episodes.

title: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay
text: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay (Tagalog: "So Long Have I Waited For You") is a Filipino soap opera, produced by ABS-CBN and Star Cinema.

title: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay
text: It started July 8, 2002 and ended November 14, 2003.

title: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay
text: The critically acclaimed and top-rating teleserye won the CMMA Best Drama Series and the PMPC Star Awards Best Primetime Drama Series.

title: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay
text: It is the first local soap opera that became a finalist to the Best Drama Series category of the International Emmy Awards.

title: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay
text: It was also part of the top five drama series of the Asian TV Awards.

title: Charmed (season 4)
text: The fourth season of "Charmed", an American supernatural drama television series, began airing on October 4, 2001 on The WB.

title: Charmed (season 4)
text: Airing on Thursdays at 9:00 pm, the season consisted of 22 episodes and concluded its airing on May 16, 2002.

title: Charmed (season 4)
text: This season also saw the introduction of Rose McGowan as Paige Matthews—half-sister to Prue, Piper and Phoebe—and a slight alteration of the opening credits, due to the third season departure of Shannen Doherty as Prue.

title: Charmed (season 4)
text: Paramount Home Entertainment released the complete fourth season in a six-disc boxed set on February 28, 2006.

title: Safe Harbor (TV series)
text: Safe Harbor is an American television drama series that aired on The WB Television Network from September 20, 1999 to November 28, 1999.

title: Safe Harbor (TV series)
text: The series was created and executive produced by Brenda Hampton, who at the time was best known for work on the fellow WB series "7th Heaven", the series was paired with "7th Heaven" on the network's Monday night lineup.

title: Safe Harbor (TV series)
text: Despite "7th Heaven" being the No. 1 show on The WB during the 1999-2000 season, "Safe Harbor" was unable to hold a solid audience after "7th Heaven" and was canceled after ten episodes and one season with the show moving to Sunday nights where the last two episodes aired.

title: Charmed
text: Charmed is an American television series created by Constance M. Burge and produced by Aaron Spelling and his production company Spelling Television, with Brad Kern serving as showrunner.

title: Charmed
text: The series was originally broadcast by The WB for eight seasons from October 7, 1998, until May 21, 2006.

title: Charmed
text: The series narrative follows a trio of sisters, known as The Charmed Ones, the most powerful good witches of all time, who use their combined "Power of Three" to protect innocent lives from evil beings such as demons and warlocks.

title: Charmed
text: Each sister possesses unique magical powers that grow and evolve, while they attempt to maintain normal lives in modern-day San Francisco.

title: Charmed
text: Keeping their supernatural identities separate and secret from their ordinary lives often becomes a challenge for them, with the exposure of magic having far-reaching consequences on their various relationships and resulting in a number of police and FBI investigations throughout the series.

title: Charmed
text: The series initially focuses on the three Halliwell sisters, Prue (Shannen Doherty), Piper (Holly Marie Combs) and Phoebe (Alyssa Milano).

title: Charmed
text: However, following Prue's death in the third-season finale, their long-lost half sister Paige Matthews (Rose McGowan) assumes her place within the "Power of Three" from season four onwards.

title: Sarah Drew
text: Sarah Drew (born October 1, 1980) is an American actress.

title: Sarah Drew
text: She is known for playing Hannah Rogers in The WB family drama series "Everwood" (2004–2006) and Dr. April Kepner in the ABC medical drama series "Grey's Anatomy" (2009–present).

title: Power of Three (Charmed)
text: The Power of Three, on The WB series "Charmed", refers to any bond formed by three magical beings good or evil.

title: Power of Three (Charmed)
text: It is most commonly used to describe the bond between the Warren/Halliwell line, more specifically the Charmed Ones, which is said to be the most powerful magical force in history.

title: Power of Three (Charmed)
text: The "Power of Three" originally included the Halliwell sisters Prue (Shannen Doherty), Piper (Holly Marie Combs) and Phoebe (Alyssa Milano).

title: Power of Three (Charmed)
text: However, following Prue's death in the third season finale, their long-lost younger half sister Paige Matthews (Rose McGowan) takes her place within the "Power of Three" from season four onwards.

title: Kerr Smith
text: Kerr Van Cleve Smith (born March 9, 1972) is an American actor known for playing Jack McPhee on The WB drama series "Dawson's Creek", Kyle Brody in The WB supernatural drama "Charmed" and more recently Axel Palmer in "My Bloody Valentine 3D".

title: Kerr Smith
text: He is also known for portraying Carter Horton in "Final Destination" (2000).

title: Rose McGowan
text: Rose Arianna McGowan (born September 5, 1973) is an Italian-born American actress, film producer, director and singer.

title: Rose McGowan
text: She is best known to television audiences for having played Paige Matthews in The WB supernatural drama series "Charmed" from 2001 to 2006.

title: Sophia Bush
text: Sophia Anna Bush (born July 8, 1982) is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist.

title: Sophia Bush
text: She starred in The WB/CW drama series "One Tree Hill", where she played Brooke Davis from 2003 to 2012.

title: Sophia Bush
text: She is known for her film roles in "John Tucker Must Die" (2006), "The Hitcher" (2007), and "The Narrows" (2008).

title: Sophia Bush
text: From 2014 to 2017, she starred in the NBC police procedural drama series "Chicago P.D." as Det. Erin Lindsay.

title: Lawrence Austin
text: Lawrence "Baby Casius" Austin ( (1956--) 22 1956 (age (2017)-(1956)-((11)<(01)or(11)==(01)and(30)<(22)) ) ) born in Warrnambool is an Australian professional super feather/light/light welter/welter/light middle/middleweight boxer of the 1970s and '80s who won the West Australia State welterweight title, West Australia State light middleweight title, Victoria State light middleweight title, Australian lightweight title, Australian light welterweight title, Australian welterweight title, South Seas Light Middleweight Title, and Commonwealth light welterweight title (twice), and was a challenger for the Australian light middleweight title against Russell Sands, and Commonwealth light welterweight title against Jeff Malcolm, his professional fighting weight varied from 128 lb , i.e. super featherweight to 159 lb , i.e. middleweight.

title: Lawrence Austin
text: He was inducted into the Australian National Boxing Hall of Fame in 2008.

title: Julian Holland (boxer)
text: Julian "Fighting Farrier" Holland ( (1972--) 13 1972 (age 45 ) ) born in Bendigo is an Australian professional welter/light middleweight boxer of the 1990s and 2000s who won the Queensland (Australia) State welterweight title, Pan Pacific welterweight title, Australian welterweight title, Oceanic Boxing Association welterweight title, Australasian welterweight title, Pan Pacific light middleweight title, World Boxing Organization (WBO) Asia Pacific welterweight title, and Commonwealth light welterweight title, his professional fighting weight varied from 143 lb , i.e. welterweight to 154 lb , i.e. light middleweight.

title: Chris Algieri
text: Christopher Mark "Chris" Algieri (born March 2, 1984) is an American professional boxer and former kickboxer.

title: Chris Algieri
text: In boxing he held the WBO junior welterweight title in 2014 and challenged for the WBO welterweight title same year; in kickboxing he was an undefeated ISKA World welterweight and WKA World super welterweight champion.

title: Andrew Murray (Guyanese boxer)
text: Andrew "The Eagle" Murray (1 July 1971 — 26 January 2002 (aged 30)) born in Georgetown was a Guyanese professional welter/light middle/middleweight boxer of the 1990s and 2000s who won the World Boxing Council (WBC) FECARBOX welterweight title, World Boxing Association (WBA) Fedelatin welterweight title, and Commonwealth welterweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Association (WBA) World welterweight title against Ike Quartey, World Boxing Union (WBU) welterweight title against Michele Piccirillo, and World Boxing Organization (WBO) North American Boxing Organization (NABO) light middleweight title against Fathi Missaoui, his professional fighting weight varied from 145 lb , i.e. welterweight to 156 lb , i.e. middleweight.

title: Andrew Murray (Guyanese boxer)
text: Andrew Murray was trained by Emanuel Steward, and was the Vice-President of the Guyana Amateur Boxing Board and was training several young boxers, and he had coached Hugo Lewis to the Guyanese super featherweight title on 26 December 2001.

title: Andrew Murray (Guyanese boxer)
text: Andrew Murray died in a traffic collision on the Soesdyke-Linden Highway early in the morning of Sunday 27 January 2002, he had been in Linden promoting a fight card and was on his way back to Georgetown.

title: Bernard Paul (boxer)
text: Bernard "Punching Postman" Paul (born October 22, 1965) is a Mauritian/British professional light welter/welter/light middleweight boxer of the 1990s and 2000s who won the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) Southern (England) Area light welterweight title, and Commonwealth light welterweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Organization (WBO) Inter-Continental light welterweight title against Jon Thaxton, British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) British light welterweight title against Mark Winters, and World Boxing Organization (WBO) Inter-Continental light welterweight title against Ricky Hatton, his professional fighting weight varied from 138 lb , i.e. light welterweight to 149+1/4 lb , i.e. light middleweight.

title: Jeff Malcolm
text: Jeff "Flash" Malcolm (born 9 May 1956 in Cowra, New South Wales), is an Australian professional boxer who fought from 1971 until 2002.

title: Jeff Malcolm
text: He won the Australian light welterweight title, New South Wales (Australia) State lightweight title, Australasian light welterweight title, South Pacific light welterweight title, Queensland (Australia) State welterweight title, International Boxing Council (IBC) welterweight title, South Pacific welterweight title, World Boxing Federation (WBF) Intercontinental welterweight title, WBF welterweight title, Pan Asian Boxing Association (PABA) welterweight title, World Boxing Association (WBA) Fedelatin welterweight title, PABA light middleweight title, and Commonwealth light welterweight title.

title: Jeff Malcolm
text: He was also a challenger for the South Seas light welterweight title against Pat Leglise, Australian welterweight title against Wilf Gentzen, and World Boxing Organization (WBO) welterweight title against Manning Galloway.

title: Jeff Malcolm
text: His professional fighting weight varied from 135 lb , i.e. lightweight to 165+1/4 lb , i.e. super middleweight.

title: Jeff Malcolm
text: He was inducted into the Australian National Boxing Hall of Fame in 2007.

title: Ralph Charles
text: Ralph Charles (born 5 February 1943) is an English amateur welterweight and professional light welter/welter/light middle/middleweight boxer of the 1960s and '70s who as an amateur won the Amateur Boxing Association of England (ABAE) 1959 Junior Class-A title against Kenneth "Ken"/"Kenny" J. Cooper (Warley ABC), boxing out of West Ham Boys & ABC, won the Amateur Boxing Association of England (ABAE) 1960 Junior Class-B title against J. Harwood (National Association of Boys Clubs), boxing out of West Ham Boys & ABC, and was runner-up for the 1963 Amateur Boxing Association of England welterweight title, against Johnny Pritchett (Bingham & District ABC), boxing out of West Ham ABC, and as a professional won the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) Southern Area welterweight title, BBBofC British welterweight title, European Boxing Union (EBU) welterweight title, and Commonwealth welterweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Council (WBC) welterweight title, and World Boxing Association (WBA) World welterweight title against José Nápoles, his professional fighting weight varied from 140 lb , i.e. light welterweight to 157 lb , i.e. middleweight.

title: Bunny Grant
text: George Leslie "Bunny" Grant (born 29 September 1940) is a Jamaican professional feather/super feather/light/light welter/welterweight/light middleweight boxer of the 1950s, '60s and '70s who won the Jamaican lightweight title, Jamaican welterweight title, Central American light welterweight Title, Latin American junior welterweight title, and British Commonwealth lightweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Council (WBC) light welterweight title and World Boxing Association (WBA) World light welterweight title against Eddie Perkins, Commonwealth welterweight title against Clyde Gray, his professional fighting weight varied from 125+1/2 lb , i.e. featherweight to 152+1/2 lb , i.e. light middleweight.

title: Bunny Grant
text: Bunny Grant was managed by Jacques Deschamps, and Pancho Rankine (circa 1962), and trained by Harry Wiley (circa 1962).

title: Zab Judah
text: Zabdiel Judah (born October 27, 1977) is an American professional boxer.

title: Zab Judah
text: He is a four-time former world champion in two weight classes, having held the IBF and WBO junior welterweight titles between 2000 and 2004; the IBF junior welterweight title again in 2011; and the undisputed welterweight title in 2005, which included a reign as the lineal champion from 2005 to 2006.

title: Fatai Onikeke
text: Fatai "Kid Dynamite" Onikeke ( (1983--) 02 1983 (age (2017)-(1983)-((11)<(04)or(11)==(04)and(30)<(02)) ) ) is a Nigerian/Australian professional light welter/welterweight boxer of the 2000s and 2010s who won the Nigerian welterweight title, African Boxing Union (ABU) welterweight title, World Boxing Foundation (WBFo) Intercontinental light welterweight title, International Boxing Federation (IBF) Pan Pacific light welterweight title, and Commonwealth welterweight title, and was a challenger for the World Boxing Organization (WBO) Africa light welterweight title, WBFo light welterweight title, and World Boxing Organization (WBO) Oriental light welterweight title against Lance Gostelow , his professional fighting weight varied from 138+1/2 lb , i.e. light welterweight to 146+1/2 lb , i.e. welterweight.

title: U Know What's Up
text: "U Know What's Up" is a 1999 hit song by singer-songwriter-producer Donell Jones' second studio album, "Where I Wanna Be".

title: U Know What's Up
text: The song features Lisa Lopes of TLC.

title: U Know What's Up
text: It reached number one on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks chart on November 13, 1999, and stayed at number one for eight consecutive weeks.

title: U Know What's Up
text: It peaked at number seven on the Billboard Hot 100, remaining there for two consecutive weeks.

title: U Know What's Up
text: Outside the United States, the song peaked within the top ten of the charts in the United Kingdom.

title: U Know What's Up
text: The song was produced by Edward "Eddie F" Ferrell and Darren Lighty for Untouchables Entertainment.

title: U Know What's Up
text: It is Jones's biggest hit to date.

title: U Know What's Up
text: The song was co-written by Anthony Hamilton.

title: U Know What's Up
text: The songs serves as the opening track on LaFace Records.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: The Broadway cast recording of the musical My Fair Lady was released as an album on April 2, 1956.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: The songs were composed by Frederick Loewe with lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner and conducted by Franz Allers, while the cast included stars Julie Andrews and Rex Harrison.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: The album became a massive seller, topping the charts on the US "Billboard" 200 for fifteen weeks at different times in 1956 (eight consecutive weeks), 1957, 1958 and 1959.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: In the UK, upon its release in 1958, the album reached No.1 for 19 consecutive weeks and became the biggest-selling album of the year.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: The album was released on Columbia Records, whose President, Goddard Lieberson provided the $375,000 needed to stage the show in return for the rights to the Cast recording.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: The album was later re-issued on Compact disc in 1988 and has been re-released a number of times since.

title: My Fair Lady (Broadway cast recording)
text: It is currently available with bonus tracks.

title: Stay (Sugarland song)
text: "Stay" is a song recorded by American country music duo Sugarland.

title: Stay (Sugarland song)
text: It was released in September 2007 as the fourth and final single from their album "Enjoy the Ride" (see 2006 in country music).

title: Stay (Sugarland song)
text: Overall, the song is the group's eighth single to enter the "Billboard" Hot Country Songs charts, where it reached a peak position of #2 for four weeks, stuck behind Taylor Swift's "Our Song", and has become their signature song.

title: Stay (Sugarland song)
text: The music video for "Stay" was ranked #10 on CMT's 100 Greatest Videos.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: "Feel Good Inc" is a song by British virtual band Gorillaz, featuring De La Soul.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: The song was released as the lead single from the band's second studio album "Demon Days" on 9 May 2005.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: The single peaked at No. 2 in the United Kingdom and No. 14 in the United States.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: It also topped the Hot Modern Rock Tracks chart in the U.S. for eight consecutive weeks, a first for the band.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: This is the only song in Damon Albarn's career to reach the top 40 on the "Billboard" Hot 100.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: It peaked in the top 10 in 17 countries, reaching No. 1 in Spain.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: The song was listed in Pitchfork Media and Rolling Stone's Best Songs of the 2000s.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: The song won Best Pop Collaboration at the 2006 Grammy Awards.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: This song has surpassed "Clint Eastwood" to be Gorillaz's most successful single worldwide.

title: Feel Good Inc.
text: Popdose ranked it 26th on their list of 100 best songs of the decade.

title: Can't Touch It
text: "Can't Touch It" is a song by Australian singer and songwriter Ricki-Lee Coulter.

title: Can't Touch It
text: It was written by Coulter with Brian Kierulf and Joshua M. Schwartz of KNS Productions, who also produced the song.

title: Can't Touch It
text: "Can't Touch It" was released as the lead single from Coulter's second studio album "Brand New Day" on 4 August 2007.

title: Can't Touch It
text: Upon its release, "Can't Touch It" peaked at number two on the ARIA Singles Chart and number one on the ARIA Dance Singles Chart, where it remained for eight consecutive weeks.

title: Can't Touch It
text: It was certified platinum by the Australian Recording Industry Association for shipments of 70,000 copies.

title: Stay (Shakespears Sister song)
text: "Stay" is a song by UK based pop act Shakespears Sister, released by London Records in January 1992 as the second single from their album "Hormonally Yours".

title: Stay (Shakespears Sister song)
text: Upon release, the single became a global smash hit becoming the duo's first and only No. 1 single in numerous territories, including the UK, where it topped the UK Singles Chart for eight consecutive weeks; the longest UK No. 1 reign for any all-female band, and was the fourth biggest selling single of 1992.

title: Stay (Shakespears Sister song)
text: The single also held the No. 1 position in band member Siobhan Fahey's birthplace, Ireland, for six weeks, and it was a transatlantic hit reaching No. 4 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in the US.

title: No One (Alicia Keys song)
text: "No One" is a song by American singer and songwriter Alicia Keys from her third studio album, "As I Am" (2007).

title: No One (Alicia Keys song)
text: It was written and produced by Keys, Kerry Brothers Jr., and George M. Harry, and released as the album's lead single on September 11, 2007.

title: No One (Alicia Keys song)
text: The song topped the "Billboard" Hot 100 for five consecutive weeks and the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart for 10 consecutive weeks, while charting inside the top 10 in most major markets.

title: I Don't Wanna Know
text: "I Don't Wanna Know" is a song by American R&B artist Mario Winans, featuring a rap by P. Diddy, re-recorded background vocals by Enya and sampling the synthesizer riff from Enya's song "Boadicea".

title: I Don't Wanna Know
text: It reached number 1 in the United Kingdom and in Netherlands, and number 2 in the United States, stuck for eight consecutive weeks behind the Usher singles "Yeah" and "Burn", respectively.

title: I Don't Wanna Know
text: It remains Winans' only major success to date.

title: I Don't Wanna Know
text: As a result of its eight weeks at number 2, "I Don't Wanna Know" stands in joint fifth place for the most weeks at number 2 by a song which did not go to number 1, behind Foreigner's "Waiting for a Girl Like You", Missy Elliott's "Work It", Donna Lewis's "I Love You Always Forever" and Shania Twain's "You're Still the One".

title: Cadillac (album)
text: Cadillac is a 1989 album recorded by French singer Johnny Hallyday.

title: Cadillac (album)
text: It was released in June 1989 and achieved success in France, where it debuted at #1 for eight consecutive weeks on the SNEP albums chart on July 2, 1989, and totalled 61 weeks in the top 50.

title: Cadillac (album)
text: It provided five singles in France, including a top three hit: "Mirador" (#3), "Si j'étais moi" (#25), "Les Vautours..." (#30), "Himalaya" (#30) and "Cadillac" (#39).

title: Cadillac (album)
text: The lyrics were written by Étienne Roda-Gil, who had worked in the 1980s with Vanessa Paradis, and the music was composed and arranged by Jacques Cardona, David Hallyday, Georges Augier, Jean-Pierre Bucolo and Jean-Claude Petit.

title: Cadillac (album)
text: This album was inspired by Antoine Laumet de La Mothe, sieur de Cadillac, a French who founded Detroit in 1701 and who gave his name to the brand of luxury vehicles.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor and philanthropist, who helped make country music a worldwide phenomenon.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: He has released 12 studio albums and 44 singles since 1992, and is best known for his number one single "Achy Breaky Heart", which became the first single ever to achieve triple Platinum status in Australia and was the best-selling single of 1992 in the same country.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: Thanks to the video of the song, the linedance entered the mainstream, becoming a worldwide craze.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: Cyrus, a multi-platinum selling recording artist, has scored a total of eight top-ten singles on the Billboard Country Songs chart.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: His most successful album to date is the debut of "Some Gave All", which has been certified 9× multi-platinum in the United States and is the longest time spent by a debut artist at number one on the "Billboard" 200 (17 consecutive weeks) and most consecutive chart-topping weeks in the SoundScan era.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: It is the only album (from any genre) in the SoundScan era to log 17 consecutive weeks at number one and is also the second-highest selling debut album by a male country artist after Garth Brooks'.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: It ranked 43 weeks in the top 10, a total topped by only one country album in history, "Ropin' the Wind" by Garth Brooks.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: "Some Gave All" was also the first debut album to enter at the number 1 in the Billboard Country Albums.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: The album has also sold more than 20 million copies worldwide and is the best-selling debut album of all time for a solo male artist. "

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: Some Gave All" was also the best-selling album of 1992 in the US with 4,832,000 copies.

title: Billy Ray Cyrus discography
text: In his career, he has released 35 charted singles, of which 16 have charted in the top 40.

title: Traitor's Gate (Spooks)
text: "Traitor's Gate" is the fourth episode in the first series of the British television series "Spooks".

title: Traitor's Gate (Spooks)
text: It first aired on BBC One in the United Kingdom on 4 June 2002, on a Tuesday; the other first series episodes aired on Mondays.

title: Traitor's Gate (Spooks)
text: The episode was written by Howard Brenton, and directed by Rob Bailey.

title: Traitor's Gate (Spooks)
text: The episode focuses on MI5 and 6's efforts in taking down a terrorist cell before they can succeed in attacking 43rd President of the United States George W. Bush.

title: Traitor's Gate (Spooks)
text: The episode guest stars Anthony Head and Hugh Laurie, who play their respective characters Peter Salter and Jools Siviter.

title: Traitor's Gate (Spooks)
text: After its first broadcast, "Traitor's Gate" was seen by 6 million viewers, the lowest ratings in the first series.

title: The Farm (The Office)
text: "The Farm" is the seventeenth episode of the ninth season of the American comedy television series "The Office" and the 192nd overall.

title: The Farm (The Office)
text: It originally aired on NBC on March 14, 2013.

title: The Farm (The Office)
text: The episode guest stars Matt Jones as Dwight's cousin Zeke, Majandra Delfino as Dwight's sister Fannie, Blake Garrett Rosenthal as his nephew, and Thomas Middleditch as his brother.

title: The Hard Easy (Adventure Time)
text: "The Hard Easy" is the twenty-third episode of the fourth season of the American animated television series "Adventure Time".

title: The Hard Easy (Adventure Time)
text: The episode was written and storyboarded by Tom Herpich and Skyler Page, from a story by Patrick McHale, Kent Osborne, and Pendleton Ward.

title: The Hard Easy (Adventure Time)
text: It originally aired on Cartoon Network on October 1, 2012.

title: The Hard Easy (Adventure Time)
text: The episode guest stars Brian Doyle-Murray as Prince Huge and Jonathan Katz as the Mudscamp elder.

title: The Hard Easy (film)
text: The Hard Easy is a 2006 American action crime drama film directed by Ari Ryan, and written by Jon Lindstrom and Tom Schanley.

title: The Hard Easy (film)
text: The film stars Henry Thomas, Vera Farmiga, David Boreanaz, Bruce Dern, Peter Weller, Gary Busey, and Nick Lachey.

title: The Hard Easy (film)
text: The film was released straight-to-DVD in the United States on May 22, 2007.

title: Roy's Wedding
text: "Roy's Wedding" is the second episode of the ninth season of the American comedy television series "The Office" and the show's 178th episode overall.

title: Roy's Wedding
text: The episode originally aired on NBC on September 27, 2012.

title: Roy's Wedding
text: The episode guest stars David Denman as Roy Anderson, Michael Patrick McGill as his brother Kenny, Robert R. Shafer as Bob Vance, and Ameenah Kaplan as Val.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: "Brother from Another Series" is the sixteenth episode of "The Simpsons"<nowiki>'</nowiki> eighth season.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on February 23, 1997.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: Sideshow Bob is released from prison into the care of his brother Cecil and claims to be a changed man.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: However, Bart does not believe him and tries to find out what Bob is up to.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: It was the first episode directed by Pete Michels and was written by Ken Keeler.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: The episode guest stars Kelsey Grammer in his sixth appearance as Sideshow Bob and David Hyde Pierce as Cecil.

title: Brother from Another Series
text: The title is not only a pun on the movie "The Brother from Another Planet" (used for a previous episode as well), but also a reference to the fact that guest stars Kelsey Grammer (Frasier Crane) and David Hyde Pierce (Niles Crane) also played bickering brothers on the NBC sitcom "Frasier".

title: Moving On (The Office)
text: "Moving On" is the sixteenth episode of the ninth season of the American comedy television series "The Office" and the 192nd episode overall.

title: Moving On (The Office)
text: The episode was written by Graham Wagner.

title: Moving On (The Office)
text: It was directed by Jon Favreau.

title: Moving On (The Office)
text: It originally aired on NBC on February 14, 2013.

title: Moving On (The Office)
text: The episode guest stars Bob Odenkirk, Mary Gillis, Collette Wolfe, and Andy Buckley.

title: Moving On (The Office)
text: The episode also features the return of former series regular Zach Woods as Gabe Lewis.

title: Web Weirdos
text: "Web Weirdos" is the third episode of the fourth season of the American animated television series "Adventure Time".

title: Web Weirdos
text: The episode was written and storyboarded by Ako Castuera and Jesse Moynihan, from a story by Patrick McHale, Kent Osborne, and Pendleton Ward.

title: Web Weirdos
text: It originally aired on Cartoon Network on April 16, 2012.

title: Web Weirdos
text: The episode guest stars both Bobcat Goldthwait and Susie Essman.

title: Web Weirdos
text: The series follows the adventures of Finn (voiced by Jeremy Shada), a human boy, and his best friend and adoptive brother Jake (voiced by John DiMaggio), a dog with magical powers to change shape and grow and shrink at will.

title: Web Weirdos
text: In this episode, Finn must help a grumpy spider couple, whose names are Barb and Ed, reconcile before he and Jake are eaten.

title: Andy's Ancestry
text: "Andy's Ancestry" is the third episode of the ninth season of the American comedy television series "The Office".

title: Andy's Ancestry
text: The episode originally aired on NBC on October 4, 2012.

title: Andy's Ancestry
text: The episode was written by Jonathan Green and Gabe Miller, and was directed by David Rogers.

title: Andy's Ancestry
text: The episode guest stars Randall Park as Jim and Pam's actor friend, Steve.

title: Evicted!
text: "Evicted!"

title: Evicted!
text: is the twelfth episode of the first season of the American animated television series "Adventure Time".

title: Evicted!
text: The episode was written and storyboarded by Bert Youn and Sean Jimenez, from a story by Adam Muto.

title: Evicted!
text: It originally aired on Cartoon Network on March 18, 2010 as a preview for the series; it later officially aired on May 17, 2010.

title: Evicted!
text: The episode guest stars Erik Estrada as King Worm.

title: Evicted!
text: The episode marks the first appearance of Marceline the Vampire Queen (voiced by Olivia Olson), who would go on to play a larger role in the series as a friend and companion to Finn and Jake.

title: 2006–07 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: The 2006–07 Wigan Athletic F.C. season was the club's 29th season in the Football League and their second season in the Premier League.

title: Springfield Park (Wigan)
text: Springfield Park was a multi-purpose stadium in Wigan, Greater Manchester.

title: Springfield Park (Wigan)
text: It was the home ground of Wigan Athletic F.C. until the club moved to the new JJB Stadium (now DW Stadium) after the 1998–99 season.

title: Springfield Park (Wigan)
text: At its largest, the stadium held 40,000.

title: Springfield Park (Wigan)
text: In its 102-year existence the ground only saw 32 years as a Football League venue, 11 years for Wigan Borough F.C. and 21 years for Wigan Athletic FC, before it was demolished to make way for a housing estate in 1999.

title: Trinidad and Tobago League Cup
text: The Trinidad and Tobago League Cup, or commonly known as the First Citizens Cup for sponsorship reasons, is the league cup style football competition open for Trinidad and Tobago teams competing in the country's TT Pro League.

title: Trinidad and Tobago League Cup
text: Similar to the FA Trophy, it is played on a knockout (single elimination) basis in September and October towards the beginning of each Pro League season.

title: Trinidad and Tobago League Cup
text: Unlike the FA Trophy, where 36 teams enter each season from the top three tiers of the Trinidad and Tobago football league system and the Secondary Schools Football League, only teams from the TT Pro League compete in the league cup.

title: Trinidad and Tobago League Cup
text: The knockout tournament was inaugurated in 2000 and is currently sponsored by First Citizens Bank.

title: Trinidad and Tobago League Cup
text: Although the league cup is one of the three major domestic trophies attainable by Trinidad and Tobago league teams, it is perceived as a lower priority than the league championship and the FA Trophy.

title: Trinidad and Tobago League Cup
text: The current theme is "Where Winners Reign", with TT$110,000 to the winner, TT$20,000 to the runners-up, semifinal winners receive TT$7,000, quaterfinal winners receive TT$5,000 and Play-off round winners receive TT$3,000.

title: 2002–03 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: During the 2002–03 English football season, Wigan Athletic F.C. competed in the Football League Second Division.

title: 2004–05 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: During the 2004–05 English football season, Wigan Athletic F.C. competed in the Football League Championship.

title: 2007–08 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: The 2007–08 Wigan Athletic F.C. season was the club's 30th season in the Football League and their third season in the Premier League.

title: Nick Powell
text: Nicholas Edward "Nick" Powell (born 23 March 1994) is an English professional footballer who plays for Wigan Athletic as a midfielder.

title: Nick Powell
text: He began his career at Crewe Alexandra, initially as a forward, making his debut at the age of 16.

title: Nick Powell
text: After impressing for Crewe Alexandra during the 2011–12 season, including scoring in their 2–0 victory in the League Two play-off Final, he moved to Manchester United in July 2012.

title: Nick Powell
text: Unable to break into the Manchester United first team, however, he went on loan to Wigan Athletic, Leicester City and Hull City before being released in June 2016.

title: Nick Powell
text: He joined Wigan Athletic in July 2016.

title: Nick Powell
text: He has represented England at under-16, under-17, under-18, under-19 and under-21 levels.

title: 1978–79 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: The 1978–79 season was the 41st season in the history of Wigan Athletic F.C. and their first as a professional club in the Football League.

title: 1978–79 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: After finishing 2nd in the Northern Premier League during the previous season, the club was nominated to apply for Football League status, and were elected into the league to replace Southport.

title: 1978–79 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: After a poor start, the club exceeded expectations in the league, and towards the end of the season, a second consecutive promotion seemed possible.

title: 1978–79 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: The club eventually fell short, finishing the season in 6th place with a total of 55 points.

title: 1979–80 Wigan Athletic F.C. season
text: The 1979–80 season was the 42nd season in the history of Wigan Athletic F.C. and their second as a professional club in the Football League.

title: List of Wigan Borough F.C. players
text: Wigan Borough F.C. was an English football club based in the town of Wigan.

title: List of Wigan Borough F.C. players
text: The club was founded in 1920 and joined the Lancashire Combination.

title: List of Wigan Borough F.C. players
text: In 1921, Borough turned professional when their application was accepted to play in the inaugural season of the newly formed Football League Third Division North.

title: List of Wigan Borough F.C. players
text: The team played in the Football League for ten seasons, with their most successful season coming in 1928–29, finishing fourth in the league and reaching the third round of the FA Cup.

title: List of Wigan Borough F.C. players
text: Wigan Borough folded during the 1931–32 season due to financial problems, and League football did not return to the town until Wigan Athletic F.C. were elected into the Football League in 1978.

title: Roy Harper (comics)
text: Roy Harper is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics.

title: Roy Harper (comics)
text: Roy is one of DC's most longstanding characters, originating in 1940s comics as Speedy, the teen sidekick of the superhero Green Arrow.

title: Roy Harper (comics)
text: Like his mentor Green Arrow, Roy is a world-class archer and athlete who uses his exceptional marksmanship to fight crime.

title: Roy Harper (comics)
text: Along with other prominent DC Comics superhero sidekicks, he goes on to become a core member of the superhero group the Teen Titans.

title: Roy Harper (comics)
text: As an adult, Roy casts off his Speedy identity to establish himself as the superhero Arsenal, and for a time adopts the name Red Arrow to symbolise his having become an equal of Green Arrow.

title: Roy Harper (comics)
text: As well as continuing to serve as one of the Titans at various times, Roy has had leading roles in the superhero groups the Seven Soldiers of Victory, the Outsiders, the Justice League, and the Outlaws.

title: Tara Strong filmography
text: Tara Strong (born Tara Lyn Charendoff; February 12, 1973) is a Canadian–American actress who has done voice work for numerous animations and video games and performed in various live-action productions.

title: Tara Strong filmography
text: Many of her major voice roles include animated series such as "Rugrats", "The Powerpuff Girls", "The Fairly OddParents", "Drawn Together", "Teen Titans" and the spin-off series "Teen Titans Go!

title: Tara Strong filmography
text: ", and "", as well as video games such as "Mortal Kombat X", "Final Fantasy X-2", and the "" series.

title: Tara Strong filmography
text: Her portrayals have garnered nominations in the Annie Awards and Daytime Emmys, and an award from the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences.

title: Teen Titans Go! (TV series)
text: Teen Titans Go!

title: Teen Titans Go! (TV series)
text: is an American animated television series based on the DC Comics fictional superhero team, the "Teen Titans".

title: Teen Titans Go! (TV series)
text: The series was announced following the popularity of DC Nation's New Teen Titans shorts.

title: List of Teen Titans episodes
text: "Teen Titans" is an American animated television series based on the DC comics series of the same name by Bob Haney and Bruno Premiani.

title: List of Teen Titans episodes
text: Developed by David Slack for Cartoon Network, the series was produced by DC Entertainment and Warner Bros.

title: List of Teen Titans episodes
text: Animation with Sander Schwartz serving as executive producer and Glen Murakami, Bruce Timm, and Linda M. Steiner signing on as producers.

title: List of Teen Titans episodes
text: The series follows the adventures of a team of crime-fighting teenaged superheroes, consisting of the leader Robin (voiced by Scott Menville), foreign alien princess Starfire (voiced by Hynden Walch), the technological genius Cyborg (voiced by Khary Payton), the dark sorceress Raven (voiced by Tara Strong), and the green shapeshifter Beast Boy (voiced by Greg Cipes).

title: Teen Titans (season 1)
text: The first season of the animated television series Teen Titans, based on the DC comics series created by Bob Haney and Bruno Premiani, originally aired on Cartoon Network in the United States.

title: Teen Titans (season 1)
text: Developed by television writer David Slack, the series was produced by DC Entertainment and Warner Bros.

title: Teen Titans (season 1)
text: Animation.

title: Teen Titans (season 1)
text: It stars Scott Menville, Hynden Walch, Khary Payton, Tara Strong, and Greg Cipes as the voices of the main characters.

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: "Teen Titans Go!

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: " is an American animated television series based on the DC Comics fictional superhero team, the "Teen Titans".

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: The series was announced following the popularity of DC Nation's New Teen Titans shorts, both of which are based on the 2003 "Teen Titans" TV series.

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: "Teen Titans Go!"

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: is a more comedic take on the DC Comics franchise, dealing with situations that happen every day.

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: Sporting a new animation style, "Teen Titans Go!"

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: serves as a comedic spin-off with no continuity to the previous series, and only certain elements are retained.

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: Many DC characters make cameo appearances and are referenced in the background.

title: List of Teen Titans Go! episodes
text: The original principal voice cast returns to reprise their respective roles.

title: Teen Titans
text: The Teen Titans, also known as the New Teen Titans and the Titans, are a fictional superhero team appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics, often in an eponymous monthly series.

title: Teen Titans
text: As the group's name suggests, its members are teenage superheroes, many of whom have acted as sidekicks to DC's premiere superheroes in the Justice League.

title: Teen Titans
text: First appearing in 1964 in "The Brave and the Bold" #54, the team was founded by Kid Flash (Wally West), Robin (Dick Grayson), and Aqualad (Garth), with the team adopting the name Teen Titans in issue 60 following the addition of Wonder Girl (Donna Troy) to its ranks.

title: Teen Titans: Trouble in Tokyo
text: Teen Titans: Trouble in Tokyo is a 2006 television animated superhero film adaptation of the DC Comics superhero team Teen Titans.

title: Teen Titans: Trouble in Tokyo
text: It is set in the milieu of the animated series "Teen Titans" that ran from 2003–2006.

title: Teen Titans: Trouble in Tokyo
text: The film premiered on Cartoon Network on September 15, 2006 and on Kids' WB on September 16, 2006. "

title: Teen Titans: Trouble in Tokyo
text: Teen Titans" head writer David Slack returned for this movie.

title: Teen Titans (season 4)
text: The fourth season of the animated television series "Teen Titans", based on the DC comics series of the same time by Bob Haney and Bruno Premiani, originally aired on Cartoon Network in the United States.

title: Teen Titans (season 4)
text: Developed by television writer David Slack, the series was produced by DC Entertainment and Warner Bros.

title: Teen Titans (season 4)
text: Animation.

title: Teen Titans (season 4)
text: It stars Scott Menville, Hynden Walch, Khary Payton, Tara Strong, and Greg Cipes as the main characters.

title: Tara Strong
text: Tara Strong (born Tara Lyn Charendoff; February 12, 1973) is a Canadian–American actress who has done voice work for numerous animations and video games and performed in various live-action productions.

title: Tara Strong
text: Many of her major voice roles include animated series such as "Rugrats", "The Powerpuff Girls", "The Fairly OddParents", "Drawn Together", "Teen Titans" and the spin-off series "Teen Titans Go!

title: Tara Strong
text: ", and "", as well as video games such as "Mortal Kombat X", "Final Fantasy X-2", and the "" series.

title: Tara Strong
text: Her portrayals have garnered nominations in the Annie Awards and Daytime Emmys, and an award from the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences.

title: 122nd (Muskoka) Battalion, CEF
text: The 122nd Battalion, CEF was a unit in the Canadian Expeditionary Force during the First World War.

title: 122nd (Muskoka) Battalion, CEF
text: Based in Huntsville, Ontario, the unit began recruiting in late 1915 in the Muskoka district.

title: 122nd (Muskoka) Battalion, CEF
text: After sailing to England in June 1917, the battalion was absorbed into the Canadian Forestry Depot on June 9, 1917.

title: 122nd (Muskoka) Battalion, CEF
text: The 122nd Battalion, CEF had one Officer Commanding: Lieut-Col.

title: 122nd (Muskoka) Battalion, CEF
text: D. M. Grant.

title: 122nd SS-Standarte
text: The 122nd SS-Standarte was a regimental command of the Allgemeine-SS that was formed in the city of Strasbourg during World War II.

title: 122nd SS-Standarte
text: The Standarte was activated on November 12, 1940, and reached battalion strength by the end of the year.

title: 122nd SS-Standarte
text: The command was a successor to the previously disbanded 121st SS-Standarte, also situated in Strasbourg.

title: 122nd Division
text: In military terms, 122nd Division or 122nd Infantry Division may refer to:

title: 122nd Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
text: The 122nd Infantry Division (German: "122.

title: 122nd Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
text: Infanterie-Division") was a German division in World War II.

title: 122nd Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
text: It was formed on 5 October 1940

title: 122nd Fighter Aviation Squadron
text: The 122nd Fighter Aviation Squadron ("Serbo-Croatian: 122.

title: 122nd Fighter Aviation Squadron
text: lovačka avijacijska eskadrila / 122.

title: 122nd Fighter Aviation Squadron
text: ловачка авијацијска ескадрила") was an aviation squadron of Yugoslav Air Force established in April 1961 as part of 94th Fighter Aviation Regiment at Skopski Petrovac military airport.

title: 122d Fighter Squadron
text: The 122nd Fighter Squadron (122nd FS) is a unit of the Louisiana Air National Guard 159th Fighter Wing located at Naval Air Station Joint Reserve Base New Orleans, Louisiana.

title: 122d Fighter Squadron
text: The 122nd is equipped with the F-15C/D Eagle.

title: 122nd Hydroplane Liaison Squadron
text: The 122nd Hydroplane Liaison Squadron ("Serbo-Croatian: 122.

title: 122nd Hydroplane Liaison Squadron

title: 122nd Hydroplane Liaison Squadron

title: 122nd Infantry Regiment (United States)
text: The 122nd Infantry Regiment is an infantry regiment of the United States Army.

title: 122nd Infantry Regiment (United States)
text: It is a component of the Georgia Army National Guard and traces its roots back to the year 1857.

title: 122nd Infantry Regiment (United States)
text: It exists today as the 122nd Regiment–Regional Training Institute.

title: 122nd Ohio Infantry
text: The 122nd Ohio Volunteer Infantry (or 122nd OVI) was an infantry regiment in the Union Army during the American Civil War.

title: 122nd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
text: The 122nd Division (第122師団 , Dai-hyakunijūni Shidan ) was an infantry division of the Imperial Japanese Army.

title: 122nd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
text: Its call sign was the Maizuru Division (舞鶴兵団 , Maizuru Heidan ) .

title: 122nd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
text: It was formed 16 January in Mudanjiang as a triangular division.

title: 122nd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
text: It was a part of a batch of eight simultaneously created divisions comprising the 121st, 122nd, 123rd, 124th, 125th, 126th, 127th and 128th Divisions.

title: 122nd Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
text: The nucleus for the formation was the 4th Independent Border Group and the remnants of the 11th Division.

title: Koningsdag
text: Koningsdag (] ) or King's Day is a national holiday in the Kingdom of the Netherlands.

title: Koningsdag
text: Celebrated on 27 April (26 April if the 27th is a Sunday), the date marks the birth of King Willem-Alexander.

title: Garifuna Settlement Day
text: Garifuna Settlement Day is a public holiday in Belize, celebrated each year on November 19.

title: Garifuna Settlement Day
text: The holiday was created by Belizean civil rights activist, Thomas Vincent Ramos, in 1941.

title: Garifuna Settlement Day
text: It was recognized as a public holiday in the southern districts of Belize in 1943, and declared a national holiday in 1977.

title: Garifuna Settlement Day
text: The holiday celebrates the settlement of the Garifuna people in Belize after being exiled from the Grenadines by the British army.

title: Garifuna Settlement Day
text: The major festivities for the holiday occur in the town of Dangriga, including parades, street music, and traditional dancing.

title: White Sunday
text: White Sunday is a national holiday in Samoa falling on the second Sunday of October, with the Monday following a public holiday.

title: White Sunday
text: It is a day for parents and communities to acknowledge and celebrate childhood by hosting special programs during church services which include scriptural recitations.

title: White Sunday
text: Biblical story reenactments, and creative dance performances.

title: White Sunday
text: Children receive gifts (often new clothing and/or school supplies) on White Sunday and are allowed privileges normally reserved for elders, such as being the first to be served food at family meal time.

title: Christmas in the Basque Country
text: Christmas in the Basque Country starts with the of Santo Tomas on 21 December, a celebration in which most people go out onto the streets to dance and eat talo with txistorra (a type of Basque chorizo).

title: Christmas in the Basque Country
text: They wear a traditional outfit called the casera dress.

title: Christmas in the Basque Country
text: For girls it consists of a long skirt and a long-sleeved old-fashioned shirt with headscarves and aprons.

title: Christmas in the Basque Country
text: The boys wear a long black shirt, trousers and txapela (traditional black beret).

title: Christmas in the Basque Country
text: The casera outfits are normally dark blue, but can come in many colors.

title: Christmas in the Basque Country
text: They wear caseras because that is what the people of the mountain wear and the holiday used to celebrate the peasants who sold their goods in town and came on Santo Tomas to pay rent to landlords in the city.

title: The Eighth (United States)
text: The Eighth was a federal holiday in the United States from 1828 until 1861.

title: The Eighth (United States)
text: It honored the Battle of New Orleans, which took place on January 8, 1815, with Tennessee's Andrew Jackson leading a successful battle against regular British soldiers and freed slaves.

title: The Eighth (United States)
text: The holiday was celebrated widely across the US South after this final battle in the War of 1812.

title: The Eighth (United States)
text: "The Eighth" became an official national holiday in 1828, following Jackson's election as President.

title: The Eighth (United States)
text: The Eighth continued as an official national holiday from 1828 until the advent of the American Civil War.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: Jounen Kwéyòl (Creole Day) is celebrated in Saint Lucia on the last Sunday of October across the entire island, and has been held annually since 1984.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: On the Sunday of this week, the various towns chosen to host this festival put out the result of their grand preparations; local dishes and foods such as roast breadfruit, Green Fig and Salt Fish (The National Dish of Saint Lucia), plantain, king fish, Manicou (opossum), Souse (a soup made with pork and often cucumber), fried bake and floats, Accra (a fried dough which contains salt fish), Paime (otherwise known as Conkies) and a famous dish known as Bouillon (fish, chicken or meat stewed with dasheen, yams, plantains, banana and dumplings) Also local drinks such as Cocoa Tea, Golden Apple Juice, Guava Juice and more.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: Apart from the food part, the event is collaborated with kweyol music some of which have been past down to and from many generations.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: The most widely used instrument besides vocals are the Tambos (drums) and are beaten throughout as people speak in the creole language and have a merry time.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: Most people commemorate this day by wearing the island's National Wear such as the Wob Dwiete.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: Persons who do not want to wear the extreme layers of skirts and dresses make clothing out of special plaid material called Madras which is one of the cloths used in the national wear.

title: Jounen Kwéyòl
text: Among the places which celebrate it every year are Mon Repos and Dennery.

title: Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day
text: Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day (French: "Fête de la Saint-Jean-Baptiste" ), officially known in Quebec as the National Holiday, (French: "la fête nationale" ) is a holiday celebrated annually on June 24, the feast day of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist.

title: Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day
text: In Quebec, it is a public holiday with festivities occurring on June 23 and 24 which are publicly financed and organized by a "Comité organisateur de la fête nationale" (National Holiday Organizing Committee).

title: Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day
text: June 24 is also celebrated as a festival of French Canadian culture in other Canadian provinces and the United States.

title: Oranjegekte
text: Oranjegekte (Orange craze) or Oranjekoorts (Orange fever) is a phenomenon in the Netherlands that occurs during major sporting events, especially international football championships, and during Koningsdag, an annual holiday celebrating the king's birthday.

title: Oranjegekte
text: It manifests itself in the wearing of orange clothing such as T-shirts, caps and scarfs; lavish attention for sports and sports fans in the media; and the decoration of cars, rooms, houses, shops, and even entire streets in orange, the traditional color of the Dutch royal family, the House of Orange-Nassau.

title: Children's Day (Japan)
text: Children's Day (こどもの日 , Kodomo no Hi ) is a Japanese national holiday which takes place annually on May 5, the fifth day of the fifth month, and is the final celebration in Golden Week.

title: Children's Day (Japan)
text: It is a day set aside to respect children's personalities and to celebrate their happiness.

title: Children's Day (Japan)
text: It was designated a national holiday by the Japanese government in 1948.

title: Children's Day (Japan)
text: It has been a day of celebration in Japan since ancient times.

title: Queen's Day (disambiguation)
text: Queen's Day or "Koninginnedag" is the former name of a national holiday in the Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba from 1890 to 2013.

title: Queen's Day (disambiguation)
text: It has since been renamed King's Day or "Koningsdag" to honor the birthday of King Willem-Alexander.

title: James Gunn
text: James Gunn (born August 5) is an American screenwriter, director, producer, novelist, actor, and musician.

title: James Gunn
text: He started his career as a screenwriter in the mid-1990s, writing the scripts for "Tromeo and Juliet" (1996), "Scooby-Doo" (2002) and its sequel "" (2004), and the 2004 version of "Dawn of the Dead".

title: James Gunn
text: He then started working also as a director, starting with "Slither" (2006).

title: James Gunn
text: He subsequently wrote and directed the web series "James Gunn's PG Porn", and the superhero films "Super" (2010), "Guardians of the Galaxy" (2014) and "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.

title: Tromeo and Juliet
text: Tromeo and Juliet is a 1996 American independent transgressive romantic comedy film and a loose adaptation of William Shakespeare's "Romeo & Juliet" from Troma Entertainment.

title: Tromeo and Juliet
text: The film was directed by Lloyd Kaufman from a screenplay by Kaufman and James Gunn, who also served as associate director.

title: Romeo × Juliet
text: Romeo × Juliet (ロミオ×ジュリエット , Romio to Jurietto ) is an anime television series, loosely based on William Shakespeare's classical play, "Romeo and Juliet", along with numerous references and characters from other Shakespearean plays.

title: Romeo × Juliet
text: Though the anime borrows mostly from Shakespeare's story, the manga adaptation differs extensively from the original.

title: Romeo × Juliet
text: "Romeo × Juliet" was broadcast in Japan on Chubu-Nippon, broadcasting from April 4, 2007 to September 26, 2007.

title: Romeo × Juliet
text: In 2009, "Romeo × Juliet" was dubbed into English and released by Funimation Entertainment.

title: Romeo and Juliet on screen
text: William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet may be one of the most-screened plays of all time.

title: Romeo and Juliet on screen
text: The most notable theatrical releases were George Cukor's multi-Oscar-nominated 1936 production "Romeo and Juliet", Franco Zeffirelli's 1968 film "Romeo and Juliet", and Baz Luhrmann's 1996 MTV-inspired "Romeo + Juliet".

title: Romeo and Juliet on screen
text: The latter two were both, at the time, the highest-grossing Shakespeare films.

title: Romeo and Juliet on screen
text: Cukor featured the mature actors Norma Shearer and Leslie Howard as the teenage lovers while Zeffirelli populated his film with beautiful young people, and Baz Luhrmann produced a heavily cut fast-paced version aimed at teenage audiences.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: "Romeo × Juliet" (ロミオ×ジュリエット , Romio to Jurietto ) is a 24-episode anime television adaptation of "Romeo and Juliet", a 16th-century tragedy originally written by William Shakespeare.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The English playwright himself makes a cameo appearance in the series as a minor character.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The series was produced jointly by Gonzo and SKY Perfect Well Think, with Fumitoshi Oizaki as the main director.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: It was first broadcast in Japan on Chubu-Nippon Broadcasting between April 4, 2007 and September 26, 2007.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: It was later broadcast by other Japanese television networks such as TBS, KBS Kyōto and SUN-TV.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: It was broadcast in Hungary by Animax and in Italy by Rai 4.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The chief screenwriter for the series was Reiko Yoshida.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The music was composed by Hitoshi Sakimoto and performed by Eminence Symphony Orchestra with Tomohiro Yoshida as sound director.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The series used three pieces of theme music.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The opening theme was "Inori (You Raise Me Up)" (祈り 〜You Raise Me Up〜 ) by Lena Park.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: "Cyclone" (サイクロン) ) by 12012 was the ending theme for the first 14 episodes.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: "Good Bye, Yesterday" by Mizrock was the ending theme for episodes 15 to 23.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: "Inori: You Raise Me Up" by Lena Park was used as a special ending for episode 24.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The anime is licensed in North America by Funimation.

title: List of Romeo × Juliet episodes
text: The complete series was released in two sections, with the first half of the series, the "Romeo Collection" being released June 23, 2009 and the second half of the series, the "Juliet Collection" being released August 11, 2009.

title: A rose by any other name would smell as sweet
text: "A rose by any other name would smell as sweet" is a popular reference to William Shakespeare's play "Romeo and Juliet", in which Juliet seems to argue that it does not matter that Romeo is from her rival's house of Montague, that is, that he is named "Montague."

title: A rose by any other name would smell as sweet
text: The reference is often used to imply that the names of things do not affect what they really are.

title: A rose by any other name would smell as sweet
text: This formulation is, however, a paraphrase of Shakespeare's actual language, seen underlined below.

title: A rose by any other name would smell as sweet
text: This scene is called the balcony scene by many people.

title: A rose by any other name would smell as sweet
text: Juliet not only makes the statement above but compares Romeo to a rose saying that if he wasn't named Romeo he would still be handsome and be Juliet's Love.

title: A rose by any other name would smell as sweet
text: Also as said before this states that if he wasn't Romeo, then he wouldn't be a Montague and she would be able to get married with no problem at all.

title: James Gunn's PG Porn
text: James Gunn's PG Porn is a web series created by brothers James Gunn, Brian Gunn, and Sean Gunn.

title: James Gunn's PG Porn
text: It consists of a series of pornography spoofs, with a humorous event occurring just before the supposed commencement of pornographic sexual acts.

title: James Gunn's PG Porn
text: Each episode pairs a mainstream actor with a pornographic actress or model.

title: James Gunn's PG Porn
text: The tagline is, "For people who love everything about Porn...except the sex."

title: Romeo
text: Romeo Montague (Italian: "Romeo Montecchi" ) is the protagonist of William Shakespeare's tragedy "Romeo and Juliet".

title: Romeo
text: The son of Montague and his wife, he secretly loves and marries Juliet, a member of the rival House of Capulet.

title: Romeo
text: Forced into exile after slaying Juliet's cousin, Tybalt, in a duel, Romeo commits suicide upon hearing falsely of Juliet's death.

title: Romeo + Juliet
text: William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet (shortened to Romeo + Juliet) is a 1996 American romantic drama film directed, co-produced, and co-written by Baz Luhrmann, co-produced by Gabriella Martinelli, and co-written by Craig Pearce, being an adaptation and modernization of William Shakespeare's tragedy "Romeo and Juliet".

title: Romeo + Juliet
text: The film stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Claire Danes in the leading roles of Romeo and Juliet, who instantly fall in love when Romeo crashes a party and meets her, despite their being members of the Montague and Capulet family; Brian Dennehy, John Leguizamo, Pete Postlethwaite, Paul Sorvino, and Diane Venora star in supporting roles.

title: The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet (film)
text: The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet is a 1982 film adaptation of William Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet", directed by William Woodman and starring Alex Hyde-White as Romeo and Blanche Baker as Juliet.

title: National Intelligence Medal for Valor
text: The National Intelligence Medal for Valor, formerly the Intelligence Community Medal for Valor, is a decoration of the United States Intelligence Community awarded by the National Intelligence Awards Program led by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

title: Ground Intelligence Officer
text: Ground Intelligence Officer (MOS 0203) is a primary military occupation code (or MOS) of an U.S. Marine Corps intelligence officer.

title: Ground Intelligence Officer
text: Ground intelligence officers serve as staff officers and commanders in the operating forces and are responsible for analyzing intelligence and planning, deployment and tactical employment of ground surveillance and reconnaissance units.

title: Ground Intelligence Officer
text: The Ground Intelligence Officer can be a Recon Marine after their training is done.

title: Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency
text: The Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency is an intelligence officer who, upon nomination by the President and confirmation by the Senate, serves as the nation's highest-ranking military intelligence officer.

title: Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency
text: As the chief of the Defense Intelligence Agency, the Director is the primary intelligence adviser to the Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and also answers to the Director of National Intelligence through the civilian Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence.

title: Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency
text: The Director is also the Commander of the Joint Functional Component Command for Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance, a subordinate command of United States Strategic Command.

title: Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency
text: Additionally, he chairs the Military Intelligence Board, which coordinates activities of the entire defense intelligence community.

title: National Intelligence Cross
text: The National Intelligence Cross is a decoration of the United States Intelligence Community (IC) awarded under the National Intelligence Awards (NIA) Program by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI).

title: National Intelligence Cross
text: It is the highest award presented by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

title: National Intelligence Cross
text: It is equivalent of the Central Intelligence Agency's Distinguished Intelligence Cross.

title: National Intelligence Medal of Achievement
text: The National Intelligence Medal of Achievement is an award that was presented to members of the United States Intelligence Community, both civilian and military, to recognize significant acts of service to the community as a whole.

title: National Intelligence Medal of Achievement
text: The National Intelligence Medal of Achievement was replaced with the equivalent National Intelligence Exceptional Achievement Medal, during the restructuring of the National Intelligence Community Awards (NICA) Program, with the revision of Intelligence Community Directive 655 (National Intelligence Awards Program) in 2012.

title: National Intelligence Superior Service Medal
text: The National Intelligence Superior Service Medal is an award of the National Intelligence Awards Program that recognizes an individual's superior service or a lasting contribution over a long period of time to the United States Intelligence Community and the United States as a whole.

title: National Intelligence Superior Service Medal
text: The medal ranks below the National Intelligence Distinguished Service Medal, but above the National Intelligence Exceptional Achievement Medal.

title: National Intelligence Board
text: The National Intelligence Board (formerly the National Foreign Intelligence Board) is a body of senior U.S. intelligence community leaders led by the Director of National Intelligence (DNI).

title: National Intelligence Board
text: The Board is tasked with reviewing and approving National Intelligence Estimates (NIEs).

title: Robert Suettinger
text: Robert Suettinger was United States President Bill Clinton's national intelligence officer for East Asia at the National Intelligence Council (NIC) from 1997-1998.

title: Robert Suettinger
text: While there, Suettinger oversaw the preparation of national intelligence estimates for the director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Robert Suettinger
text: His areas of specialty included the People's Republic of China and the North Korean nuclear weapons program.

title: Robert Suettinger
text: After working in the Clinton administration, Suettinger has been a senior analyst for the Brookings Institution where he wrote the book "Beyond Tiananmen – The Politics of U.S.-China Relations, 1989-2000".

title: Robert Suettinger
text: He also is a senior advisor at The Stimson Center.

title: National Intelligence Reform Medal
text: The National Intelligence Reform Medal is an award of the United States Intelligence Community's National Intelligence Awards Program that recognizes extraordinary service in implementing the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act.

title: National Intelligence Reform Medal
text: The medal ranks below the National Intelligence Superior Service Medal, but above the National Intelligence Exceptional Achievement Medal.

title: National Intelligence Reform Medal
text: Established 23 May 2007 with the creation of the National Intelligence Awards Program, it was retired in November 2010.

title: National Intelligence Estimate
text: National Intelligence Estimates (NIEs) are United States federal government documents that are the authoritative assessment of the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) on intelligence related to a particular national security issue.

title: National Intelligence Estimate
