text: NIEs are produced by the National Intelligence Council and express the coordinated judgments of the United States Intelligence Community, the group of 16 U.S. intelligence agencies.

title: National Intelligence Estimate
text: NIEs are classified documents prepared for policymakers.

title: Moche Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2015
text: The Moche Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2015 was an event of the Association of Surfing Professionals for 2015 ASP World Tour.

title: MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal
text: MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal formerly known as "Moche Rip Curl Pro Portugal" or "Rip Curl Pro Portugal" is a professional surfing competition of the ASP World Tour held every year in October at the Supertubos beach in Peniche, Portugal.

title: MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal
text: The event was first founded in 2009 as "Rip Curl Search Portugal".

title: MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal
text: The defending champion is the 2016 WSL champion, John John Florence who won the event in 2016.

title: Coco Ho
text: Coco Malia Camille Hapaikekoa Ho (born April 28, 1991) is a professional Hawaiian surfer born in Honolulu, Hawaii.

title: Coco Ho
text: She began surfing at 7 years old, following in the footsteps of her family.

title: Coco Ho
text: Today, Coco has won over 25 surfing awards and has been voted a top three fan favorite in Surfer magazine’s Surfer Poll.

title: MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2016
text: The MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2016 was an event of the World Surf League for 2016 World Surf League Men's Championship Tour.

title: Damien Hardman
text: Damien Hardman (born January 23, 1966) known as The Iceman is a former Australian surfer from Sydney.

title: Damien Hardman
text: He won the Rip Curl Pro twice in 1988 and 1993, and was runner-up three times in 1989, 1991 and 1997, and in 1987/88 and 1991 he won the ASP World Tour.

title: Damien Hardman
text: In 1999, he was inducted into the Australian Surfing Hall of Fame in 1999.

title: MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2017
text: The MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2017 is an event of the World Surf League for the 2017 World Surf League Men's Championship Tour.

title: Supertubos
text: The Supertubos (Portuguese for "Supertubes") is a beach located in Peniche, Portugal, which due to its great conditions of surfing and its curvy waves and tubes helds every year the MEO Rip Curl Pro Portugal, one of the World Surf League Men's Championship Tour events.

title: Moche Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2014
text: The Moche Rip Curl Pro Portugal 2014 is an event of the Association of Surfing Professionals for 2014 ASP World Tour.

title: Barton Lynch
text: Barton Lynch (born August 9, 1963) is an Australian surfer known for his competitive prowess and style.

title: Barton Lynch
text: In 1988, he was crowned ASP World Tour Champion.

title: Barton Lynch
text: He also won the 1991 Rip Curl Pro.

title: Barton Lynch
text: In 1998, he was inducted into the Australian Surfing Hall of Fame, and in 2000, he was inducted into the Australian Sporting Hall of Fame.

title: Andy Irons
text: Philip Andrew Irons (July 24, 1978November 2, 2010) was an American professional surfer.

title: Andy Irons
text: Irons learned to surf on the dangerous and shallow reefs of the North Shore in Kauai, Hawaii.

title: Andy Irons
text: Over the course of his professional career, he won three world titles (2002, 2003, 2004), three Quiksilver Pro France titles (2003, 2004, 2005), two Rip Curl Pro Search titles (2006 and 2007) and 20 elite tour victories including the Vans Triple Crown of Surfing four times from 2002-2006.

title: Andy Irons
text: On September 3, 2010 he won the Billabong Pro Teahupoo in Tahiti.

title: Andy Irons
text: He and his family hosted the Annual Irons Brothers Pinetrees Classic, a contest for youngsters.

title: Andy Irons
text: The Governor of Hawaii declared February 13 forever "Andy Irons Day".

title: Andy Irons
text: He is the only surfer to have won a title at every venue on the ASP calendar.

title: Marion Christopher Barry
text: Marion Christopher Barry was born in June 1980 to Marion Barry and Barry's third wife, Effi Slaughter Barry.

title: Marion Christopher Barry
text: He was their only child.

title: Marion Christopher Barry
text: His father had wanted to name him Marion Barry III, but Effi was strongly opposed, and they decided to give him the middle name Christopher instead.

title: Marion Christopher Barry
text: For most of his adult life, Barry went by his middle name, Christopher.

title: Chris Funk
text: Christopher Funk is an American musician and multi-instrumentalist best known as a member of the Portland, Oregon, indie rock band The Decemberists.

title: Chris Funk
text: He plays guitar, pedal steel, piano, violin, dobro, hurdy-gurdy, mandolin, saxophone, the theremin and many other instruments.

title: Chris Funk
text: According to Colin Meloy, as stated at the Pilgrimage Festival in Franklin, TN on September 27, 2015, Funk was originally given the middle name "Ryman" but a clerical error on his birth certificate resulted in his middle name being recorded as "Lyman."

title: Jeff Strabone
text: Jeff Strabone is a Brooklyn-based American scholar, political activist and civic leader.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: In 2016, his website "directelection.org" listed the names and addresses of members of the U.S. Electoral College, and he urged people to write to electors to ask them not to vote for president-elect Donald Trump, an effort which brought him national attention.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: As a civic leader in Brooklyn, he has been active in promoting theatre preservation, building codes and housing issues, hospital preservation, and traffic flow.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: He has been a leader of Brooklyn's Cobble Hill Association, a neighborhood preservation group.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: He is the co-founder and chairman of the New Brooklyn Theatre.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: In 2008, he changed his middle name to "Hussein" as a show of solidarity with then presidential candidate Barack Obama, who was running for the office of president, and who had been criticized for his Muslim-sounding middle name.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: He is an associate professor of English and teaches British and African literature, and he was granted tenure at Connecticut College in 2016.

title: Jeff Strabone
text: He commented about the post-election effort:

title: Bobbi Bacha
text: Bobbi Bacha is a Texas Private Investigator portrayed in 2004 TV Sony Pictures Movie "Suburban Madness" played by actress Sela Ward.

title: Bobbi Bacha
text: Bobbi Bacha also was involved and worked on the case of New York millionaire Robert Durst who was charged with murder in Galveston, Texas for killing his neighbor Morris Black but was found not guilty by a Galveston County Jury.

title: Suburban Madness
text: Suburban Madness is an American crime drama television film, based on a true story, starring Sela Ward as PI Bobbi Bacha of Blue Moon Investigations.

title: Suburban Madness
text: It aired on CBS on October 3, 2004.

title: Latvian name
text: Latvian names, like in most European cultures, consist of two main elements: the given name ("vārds") followed by family name ("uzvārds").

title: Latvian name
text: During the Soviet occupation (1940 - 1991) the practice of giving a middle name was discouraged, but since the restoration of Independence Latvian legislation again allows giving of up to two given names and it has become more common to give a middle name to children.

title: Middle name
text: In several cultures, people's names usually include one or more names in addition to the portion that is usually considered adequate to identify them.

title: Middle name
text: In a number of cultures where a given name is expected to precede the surname, such a name is likely to be placed after the given name and before the surname, and thus called a middle name.

title: Middle name
text: In English-speaking American culture, that term is often applied (arguably mistakenly) to names, occupying that position, even if the bearer would insist that that name is being mistakenly called a "middle name", and is actually (to mention several types of atypical cases):

title: Barend
text: Barend or (somewhat dated spelling) Barent is a Dutch male given name and occasional middle name.

title: Barend
text: As of 2014, there are over than 4,000 men in the Netherlands with this as their first name, and nearly 3,000 with it as their middle name.

title: Barend
text: It was likely derived from Bernard.

title: Barend
text: Notable people with the name include:

title: Singh
text: Singh is a title, middle name or surname, which originated in India.

title: Singh
text: Derived from the Sanskrit word for lion, it was adopted as a title by certain warrior castes in India.

title: Singh
text: It was mandated by Guru Gobind Singh for all Sikhs.

title: Singh
text: It was later adopted by several castes and communities.

title: Singh
text: As a surname or a middle name, it is now found throughout the Indian subcontinent and among the Indian diaspora, cutting across communities and religious groups, becoming more of a title than a surname.

title: Milhouse Van Houten
text: Milhouse Mussolini van Houten is a fictional character featured in the animated television series "The Simpsons", voiced by Pamela Hayden, and created by Matt Groening who named the character after President Richard Nixon's middle name.

title: Milhouse Van Houten
text: Later in the series, it is revealed that Milhouse's middle name is "Mussolini."

title: Embassy of China, London
text: The Embassy of China in London is the diplomatic mission of China in the United Kingdom.

title: Embassy of China, London
text: The Embassy in London is China's only embassy in the UK, alongside two Consulates-General in Edinburgh and Manchester.

title: Embassy of China, London
text: Established in 1877 as the Chinese Legation, the London mission was China's first permanent overseas diplomatic mission.

title: Embassy of China, London
text: It has served as the diplomatic mission of the Qing Empire, Republic of China and (since 1950) the People's Republic of China.

title: Embassy of China, London
text: It was the location of the Qing Empire's detention of Sun Yat-sen, an important episode in the Chinese revolution of 1911.

title: Embassy of China, London
text: It remains today the focal point for events relating to China held in the United Kingdom, including celebrations in 2012 to commemorate 40 years of diplomatic relations between the UK and the People's Republic of China.

title: Diplomatic mission
text: A diplomatic mission or foreign mission is a group of people from one state or an organisation present in another state to represent the sending state/organisation officially in the receiving state.

title: Diplomatic mission
text: In practice, a diplomatic mission usually denotes the resident mission, namely the embassy, which is the office of a country's diplomatic representatives in the capital city of another country, whereas consulates are diplomatic missions which are not performed in the capital of the receiving state.

title: Diplomatic mission
text: As well as being a diplomatic mission to the country in which it is situated, it may also be a non-resident permanent mission to one or more other countries.

title: Diplomatic mission
text: There are thus resident and non-resident embassies.

title: Head of mission
text: In diplomatic usage, head of mission (HOM) or chief of mission (COM) from the French "chef de mission diplomatique" (CMD) is the head of a diplomatic representation, such as an ambassador, high commissioner, nuncio, chargé d'affaires, permanent representative, and to a consul-general or consul.

title: Head of mission
text: Depending on the context, it may also refer to the heads of certain international organizations' representative offices.

title: Head of mission
text: Certain other titles or usages that would qualify as a head of mission or equivalent also exist.

title: Head of mission
text: While they are primarily referred to by the other titles mentioned above, it is common for the diplomatic corps of several countries to use deputy head of mission or deputy chief of mission (DCM) as the primary title for the second in command of a diplomatic mission.

title: Diplomatic bag
text: A diplomatic bag, also known as a diplomatic pouch, is a container with certain legal protections used for carrying official correspondence or other items between a diplomatic mission and its home government or other diplomatic, consular, or otherwise official entities.

title: Diplomatic bag
text: The physical concept of a "diplomatic bag" is flexible and therefore can take many forms (e.g., a cardboard box, briefcase, duffel bag, large suitcase, crate or even a shipping container).

title: Diplomatic bag
text: Additionally, a diplomatic bag usually has some form of lock and/or tamper-evident seal attached to it in order to deter or detect interference by unauthorized third parties.

title: Diplomatic bag
text: The most important point is that as long as it is externally marked to show its status, the "bag" has diplomatic immunity from search or seizure, as codified in article 27 of the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations.

title: Diplomatic bag
text: It may only contain articles intended for official use.

title: Diplomatic bag
text: It is often escorted by a diplomatic courier, who is similarly immune from arrest and detention.

title: High Commission of Australia, London
text: The High Commission of Australia in London is the diplomatic mission of Australia in the United Kingdom.

title: High Commission of Australia, London
text: It is located in Australia House, a Grade II listed building.

title: High Commission of Australia, London
text: It is both Australia's first diplomatic mission and the longest continuously occupied diplomatic mission in the United Kingdom.

title: Alvaro Mexia
text: Alvaro Mexia was a 17th-century Spanish explorer and cartographer of the east coast of Florida.

title: Alvaro Mexia
text: Mexia was stationed in St Augustine and was given a diplomatic mission to the native populations living south of St. Augustine and in the Cape Canaveral area.

title: Alvaro Mexia
text: This mission resulted in a "Period of Friendship" between the Spanish and the Ais native population.

title: Embassy of Algeria, Islamabad
text: The Embassy of Algeria in Islamabad is the diplomatic mission of Algeria to Pakistan.

title: Embassy of Algeria, Islamabad
text: It is located at House No. 107, St. No. 9, in Sector E-7, Islamabad.

title: Embassy of Algeria, Islamabad
text: Pakistan was one of the first countries to recognise the Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic in 1958.

title: Embassy of Algeria, Islamabad
text: This was followed shortly later by Algeria opening its diplomatic mission in Karachi, then the capital of Pakistan.

title: Embassy of the United States, Nairobi
text: The Embassy of the United States of America to Kenya (also known as Embassy Nairobi by the State Department), located in Nairobi, is home to the diplomatic mission of the United States to the Republic of Kenya.

title: Embassy of the United States, Nairobi
text: The embassy opened in central Nairobi in 1964, when the United States established diplomatic relations with Kenya.

title: Embassy of the United States, Nairobi
text: In 1998, the original embassy was the target of a terrorist attack, after which a new embassy building was constructed in Gigiri, a suburb of Nairobi, in 2003.

title: Embassy of the United States, Nairobi
text: The US diplomatic mission to Somalia is also based at the Nairobi embassy.

title: United States Mission to the European Union
text: The United States Mission to the European Union (USEU) is the diplomatic mission of the United States to the European Union; it is based in Brussels, Belgium.

title: United States Mission to the European Union
text: The US has maintained diplomatic relations with the EU and its predecessors since 1953.

title: United States Mission to the European Union
text: The first predecessor of the current mission was the US diplomatic mission to the European Coal and Steel Community in Luxembourg, which opened in 1956.

title: United States Mission to the European Union
text: In 1961, the US Mission to the European Communities was established in Brussels, which later became the United States Mission to the European Union, upon the latter's establishment in 1993.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: Although Azerbaijan initiated diplomatic relations with Western and other countries since the Safavids dynasty in XVI century, the first diplomatic body - the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was established in 1918 when Azerbaijan was formed as a republic for the first time and Mehmet Hasan Hacınkski became the first minister.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: The parliament sent the diplomatic delegation to the Ottoman State after signing the first international document - the Pact of Peace and Friendship - with this state and on this agreement, the Ottoman State became the first country recognizing independence of the ADR.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: The next step, the "Friendship and Peace" treaty with Iran was signed on 20 March 1919.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: And the diplomatic mission of Azerbaijan had started to work as a consulate in Tehran and other cities.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: However, this successful revival continued until the Russian army entered Baku on April 28, 1920.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: The diplomatic delegation of the Republic attended the Paris Peace Conference, 1919.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: As a result of the national democratic movement that started in Azerbaijan in 1988-1990, the country restored its independence on 5 February, 1991.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: Afterwards, Azerbaijan started to create bilateral relations with other countries.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: In this regard, the diplomatic missions have been established in foreign countries.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: Today Azerbaijan has embassies and consulates in more than 70 countries.

title: List of diplomatic missions of Azerbaijan
text: Recent diplomatic missions started to operate in Brasil, Australia and Vietnam.

title: Network Analysis and Ethnographic Problems
text: Network Analysis and Ethnographic Problems: Process Models of a Turkish Nomad Clan is an anthropological and complexity science book by social anthropologists Douglas R. White, University of California, Irvine, and Ulla Johansen of the University of Cologne.

title: Network Analysis and Ethnographic Problems
text: It is considered an important publication in anthropology and the political science of Central Asia.

title: Participant observation
text: Participant observation is one type of data collection method typically used in qualitative research.

title: Participant observation
text: It is a widely used methodology in many disciplines, particularly cultural anthropology and (European) ethnology, less so in sociology, communication studies, human geography and social psychology.

title: Participant observation
text: Its aim is to gain a close and intimate familiarity with a given group of individuals (such as a religious, occupational, sub cultural group, or a particular community) and their practices through an intensive involvement with people in their cultural environment, usually over an extended period of time.

title: Participant observation
text: The method originated in the field research of social anthropologists, especially Bronisław Malinowski and his students in Britain, the students of Franz Boas in the United States, and in the later urban research of the Chicago School of sociology.

title: Social Anthropology (journal)
text: Social Anthropology/Anthropologie Sociale is a quarterly academic journal published since 2007 by Wiley-Blackwell on behalf of the European Association of Social Anthropologists.

title: Social Anthropology (journal)
text: It was established in 1992 and originally published by Cambridge University Press.

title: Social Anthropology (journal)
text: The current editors-in-chief are Sarah Green and Patrick Laviolette.

title: Social Anthropology (journal)
text: Articles are published in English or French.

title: Muted group theory
text: Muted group theory (MGT) is developed by social anthropologists Edwin Ardener and Shirley Ardener in 1975.

title: Muted group theory
text: The theory describes the relationship between a dominant group and its subordinate group(s): As the dominant group contributes mostly to the formulation of the language system, including the norms and vocabulary, members from the subordinate group have to learn and use the dominant-made language to express themselves.

title: Muted group theory
text: However, this translation process may result in loss and distortion of information as the people from subordinate groups cannot articulate their ideas clearly.

title: Muted group theory
text: The dominant may also ignore the voice of the lower-power.

title: Muted group theory
text: All these may eventually lead to the mutedness of the subordinate group.

title: Muted group theory
text: Although this theory is initially developed to study the different situations faced by women and men, it can also be applied to any marginalized group that is muted by the inadequacies of their languages.

title: Symbolic culture
text: Symbolic culture is the ability to learn and transmit behavioural traditions from one generation to the next by the invention of things that exist entirely in the symbolic realm.

title: Symbolic culture
text: Symbolic culture is the cultural realm constructed and inhabited uniquely by Homo sapiens and is differentiated from ordinary culture, which many other animals possess.

title: Symbolic culture
text: Symbolic culture is studied by archaeologists, social anthropologists and sociologists.

title: Association of Social Anthropologists
text: The Association of Social Anthropologists of the UK and Commonwealth, is a learned society in the United Kingdom dedicated to promoting the academic discipline of psychosocial studies.

title: Association of Social Anthropologists
text: It is a member of the Academy of Social Sciences.

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: Aleksandar Bošković is a social anthropologist from former Yugoslavia, who published twelve books and several hundred articles and book reviews on history and theory of anthropology, from a transactionalist and comparative perspective.

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: He is Professor in the Department of Ethnology and Anthropology (University of Belgrade Faculty of Philosophy), and Professor of Anthropology at the University of Donja Gorica in Montenegro.

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: Since 2 February 2017, Bošković also heads the Department of Anthropological Research (within the Center for Sociological and Anthropological Studies) at the Institute of Social Sciences in Belgrade, where he is Director of Research, and former (19 May 2009- 1 February 2017) Head of the Center for Political Studies and Public Opinion Research.

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: Aleksandar Bošković previously taught at the Universities of St Andrews (1994), Belgrade (then Yugoslavia, 1998), Brasília (Brazil, 1999-2001), University of the Witwatersrand (Johannesburg, South Africa, 2001-2003), and Rhodes University (Grahamstown, South Africa, 2003-2006).

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: Between 2000 and 2014, Aleksandar Bošković was teaching in the Post-graduate Program in Anthropology of the Faculty of Social Sciences (FDV), University of Ljubljana (Slovenia).

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: Just before the 2016 conference of the European Association of Social Anthropologists, held at the University of Milano-Bicocca, he was selected as the EASA Book Series Editor.

title: Aleksandar Bošković
text: Together with Han Vermeulen, he is co-convenor of the recently established History of Anthropology Network of the EASA.

title: Coral Gardens and Their Magic
text: Coral Gardens and Their Magic, properly Coral Gardens and Their Magic: A Study of the Methods of Tilling the Soil and of Agricultural Rites in the Trobriand Islands, is the final book in anthropologist Bronisław Malinowski's ethnographic trilogy on the lives of the Trobriand Islanders.

title: Coral Gardens and Their Magic
text: It concentrates on the cultivation practices the Trobriand Islanders used to grow yams, taro, bananas and palms.

title: Coral Gardens and Their Magic
text: It describes the gardens in which the Trobrianders grew food as more than merely utilitarian spaces, even as works of art.

title: Coral Gardens and Their Magic
text: In 1988 Alfred Gell called the book "still the best account of any primitive technological-cum-magical system, and unlikely ever to be superseded in this respect".

title: Coral Gardens and Their Magic
text: The book has been described as Malinowski's "magnum opus".

title: Alfred Gell
text: Alfred Antony Francis Gell, {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} ( ; June 12, 1945 – January 28, 1997) was a British social anthropologist whose most influential work concerned art, language, symbolism and ritual.

title: Alfred Gell
text: He was trained by Edmund Leach (MPhil, Cambridge University) and Raymond Firth (PhD, London School of Economics) and did his fieldwork in Melanesia and tribal India.

title: Alfred Gell
text: Gell taught at the London School of Economics, among other places.

title: Alfred Gell
text: He was also a Fellow of the British Academy.

title: Alfred Gell
text: He died of cancer in 1997, at the age of 51.

title: Thomas Hylland Eriksen
text: Thomas Hylland Eriksen (born February 6, 1962) is a Norwegian anthropologist.

title: Thomas Hylland Eriksen
text: He is currently a professor of social anthropology at the University of Oslo, as well as the 2015-2016 president of the European Association of Social Anthropologists.

title: Thomas Hylland Eriksen
text: He is a member of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters.

title: 2013 Birthday Honours
text: The 2013 Birthday Honours were appointments by some of the 16 Commonwealth realms of Queen Elizabeth II to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 2013 Birthday Honours
text: The Birthday Honours are awarded as part of the Queen's Official Birthday celebrations during the month of June.

title: 2013 Birthday Honours
text: The Queen's Birthday Honours were announced on 15 June 2013 in the United Kingdom, on 10 June 2013 in Australia on 3 June 2013 in New Zealand, on 15 June 2013 in Grenada, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Saint Lucia and Belize.

title: 2014 Birthday Honours
text: The 2014 Birthday Honours were appointments by some of the 16 Commonwealth realms of Queen Elizabeth II to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 2014 Birthday Honours
text: The Birthday Honours are awarded as part of the Queen's Official Birthday celebrations during the month of June.

title: 2014 Birthday Honours
text: The Queen's Birthday Honours were announced on 14 June 2014 in the United Kingdom, on 9 June 2014 in Australia, on 2 June 2014 in New Zealand, on 14 June 2014 in Grenada, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Saint Lucia and Belize.

title: Birthday Honours
text: King's/Queen's Birthday Honours is, in some Commonwealth realms, the marking of the reigning monarch's official birthday by granting various individuals appointment into national or dynastic orders or the award of decorations and medals.

title: Birthday Honours
text: The honours are presented by the monarch or a viceregal representative.

title: Birthday Honours
text: New Year Honours and Birthday Honours are bestowed each year.

title: Birthday Honours
text: All royal honours are published in the relevant gazette, and the daily newspapers of each realm.

title: 1925 Birthday Honours
text: The 1925 Birthday Honours were appointments by King George V to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of the British Empire.

title: 1925 Birthday Honours
text: The appointments were made to celebrate the official birthday of The King, and were published in "The London Gazette" on 3 June 1925.

title: Henry Greer (politician)
text: Captain Sir Joseph Henry Greer {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (1 February 1855 – 25 August 1933) was an Irish soldier, politician, and racing horse owner and breeder.

title: Henry Greer (politician)
text: He was born in County Tyrone, was educated at Wellington and joined the 7th Highlanders after military college.

title: Henry Greer (politician)
text: He was appointed as Director of the Irish National Stud in 1915.

title: Henry Greer (politician)
text: He also became the Aga Khan III's first stud manager.

title: Henry Greer (politician)
text: He received a knighthood in the 1925 Birthday Honours.

title: 2016 Birthday Honours
text: The 2016 Queen's Birthday Honours are appointments by some of the 16 Commonwealth realms of Queen Elizabeth II to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 2016 Birthday Honours
text: The Birthday Honours are awarded as part of the Queen's Official Birthday celebrations during the month of June.

title: 2016 Birthday Honours
text: The Queen's Birthday Honours were announced on 6 June 2016 in New Zealand and 10 June in the United Kingdom.

title: 2017 Birthday Honours
text: The 2017 Queen's Birthday Honours are appointments by some of the 16 Commonwealth realms of Queen Elizabeth II to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 2017 Birthday Honours
text: The Birthday Honours are awarded as part of the Queen's Official Birthday celebrations during the month of June.

title: 2017 Birthday Honours
text: The Queen's Birthday Honours for the United Kingdom were announced on 16 June; the honours for New Zealand were announced on 5 June and for Australia on 12 June.

title: 2015 Birthday Honours
text: The 2015 Queen's Birthday Honours are appointments by some of the 16 Commonwealth realms of Queen Elizabeth II to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 2015 Birthday Honours
text: The Birthday Honours are awarded as part of the Queen's Official Birthday celebrations during the month of June.

title: 2015 Birthday Honours
text: The Queen's Birthday Honours were announced on 1 June 2015 in New Zealand, on 8 June in Australia, and on 12 June in the United Kingdom, in Grenada, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Saint Lucia and Belize.

title: 1951 Birthday Honours
text: The King's Birthday Honours 1951 were appointments in many of the Commonwealth realms of King George VI to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 1951 Birthday Honours
text: The appointments were made to celebrate the official birthday of the King, and were published on 1 June 1951 for the British Empire, Australia, New Zealand, Ceylon, and Pakistan.

title: 1951 Birthday Honours
text: These were the last Birthday Honours awarded by George VI, who died eight months later.

title: 1965 Birthday Honours
text: The Queen's Birthday Honours 1965 were appointments in many of the Commonwealth realms of Queen Elizabeth II to various orders and honours to reward and highlight good works by citizens of those countries.

title: 1965 Birthday Honours
text: The appointments were made to celebrate the official birthday of The Queen.

title: 1965 Birthday Honours
text: The announcement date varies from year to year.

title: 1965 Birthday Honours
text: The 1965 Queen's Birthday Honours were announced on 12 June for the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand, Sierra Leone, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Malawi, and the Gambia.

title: Miner Memorial Library
text: Miner Memorial Library is the public library of Lempster, New Hampshire, located at 3 Second New Hampshire Turnpike.

title: Miner Memorial Library
text: The library occupies a single-story wood frame structure built in 1845 as a church for a Universalist congregation.

title: Miner Memorial Library
text: Despite significant alteration for its use as a library, the building remains a fine example of vernacular church architecture in Sullivan County.

title: Miner Memorial Library
text: The building was formally dedicated in 1927 to the memory of Lempster native Alonzo Ames Miner, a leading Universalist minister and president of Tufts College.

title: Miner Memorial Library
text: After years of declining attendance, the remaining congregants gave the building to the town in 1965.

title: Miner Memorial Library
text: The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2006.

title: Dover, New Hampshire
text: Dover is a city in Strafford County, New Hampshire, United States.

title: Dover, New Hampshire
text: The population was 29,987 at the 2010 census, the largest in the New Hampshire Seacoast region.

title: Dover, New Hampshire
text: The population was estimated at 31,153 in 2016.

title: Dover, New Hampshire
text: It is the county seat of Strafford County, and home to Wentworth-Douglass Hospital, the Woodman Institute Museum, and the Children's Museum of New Hampshire.

title: Carroll County, New Hampshire
text: Carroll County is a county located in the state of New Hampshire, in the United States.

title: Carroll County, New Hampshire
text: As of the 2010 census, the population was 47,818, making it the third-least populous county in New Hampshire.

title: Carroll County, New Hampshire
text: Its county seat is Ossipee.

title: Carroll County, New Hampshire
text: The county was created in 1840 and organized at Ossipee from towns removed from Strafford County.

title: Carroll County, New Hampshire
text: It was named in honor of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, who had died in 1832, the last surviving signer of the United States Declaration of Independence.

title: Hampden County, Massachusetts
text: Hampden County is a non-governmental county located in the Pioneer Valley of the state of Massachusetts, in the United States.

title: Hampden County, Massachusetts
text: As of the 2010 census, Hampden County's population was 463,490.

title: Hampden County, Massachusetts
text: Its traditional county seat is Springfield, the Connecticut River Valley's largest city, and economic and cultural capital.

title: Hampden County, Massachusetts
text: Hampden County was split from Hampshire County in 1812, because Northampton, Massachusetts, was made Hampshire County's "shire town" in 1794; however, Springfield—theretofore Hampshire County's traditional shire town, dating back to its founding in 1636—grew at a pace far quicker than Northampton and was granted shire town-status over its own, southerly jurisdiction.

title: Hampden County, Massachusetts
text: It was named for John Hampden.

title: Hampden County, Massachusetts
text: To the north of Hampden County is modern-day Hampshire County; to the west is Berkshire County; to the east is Worcester County; to the south are Litchfield County, Hartford County, and Tolland County in Connecticut.

title: Woodsville, New Hampshire
text: Woodsville is a census-designated place (CDP) in the town of Haverhill in Grafton County, New Hampshire, U.S., along the Connecticut River at the mouth of the Ammonoosuc River.

title: Woodsville, New Hampshire
text: The population was 1,126 at the 2010 census.

title: Woodsville, New Hampshire
text: Although North Haverhill is now the county seat of Grafton County, the village of Woodsville has traditionally been considered the county seat, as the county courthouse was originally located there.

title: Woodsville, New Hampshire
text: The county buildings are now located halfway between Woodsville and the village of North Haverhill to the south.

title: Lempster, New Hampshire
text: Lempster is a town in Sullivan County, New Hampshire, United States.

title: Lempster, New Hampshire
text: The population was 1,154 at the 2010 census.

title: Lempster, New Hampshire
text: Settlements include the town center (Lempster village) and the village of East Lempster.

title: Essex County, Vermont
text: Essex County is a county in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Vermont.

title: Essex County, Vermont
text: As of the 2010 census, the population was 6,306, making it the least-populous county in both Vermont and New England.

title: Essex County, Vermont
text: Its shire town (county seat) is the municipality of Guildhall.

title: Essex County, Vermont
text: The county was created in 1792 and organized in 1800.

title: Essex County, Vermont
text: Bordered by the Connecticut River next to New Hampshire, Essex County is part of the Berlin, New Hampshire micropolitan area.

title: Essex County, Vermont
text: It is south of the Canadian province of Quebec.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: The Gardnerville Branch Jail is a historic jail located at 1440 Courthouse St. in Gardnerville, Nevada.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: The jail was built in 1910 and served as Douglas County's only jail from 1910 to 1915.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: Prior to 1910, the only county jail was in Genoa, the county seat; however, since Gardnerville was several miles from Genoa, it resorted to housing prisoners in the local judge's granary.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: As the granary was considered unfit for holding prisoners, the community petitioned the county to construct a new jail.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: However, local leaders in Minden, who wanted to move the county seat to their town, protested the move, as they suspected that Gardnerville was attempting to claim the county seat itself.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: Nonetheless, the county approved the construction of the new jail.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: The jail housed its first prisoners before construction even finished, as the Genoa jail burned down; one prisoner was briefly chained to a post until the new jail could accommodate him.

title: Gardnerville Branch Jail
text: Once completed, the jail served the county until 1915, when Minden became the county seat and opened its own county jail.

title: Steven D. Smith
text: Steven "Steve" Smith (born June 23, 1964) is a New Hampshire politician and a member of the New Hampshire House of Representatives representing Sullivan County District 11, which includes the towns of Acworth, Charlestown, Goshen, Langdon, Lempster, and Washington.

title: Steven D. Smith
text: He is a software tester by profession, and also runs a slot car business and racing facility.

title: East Lempster, New Hampshire
text: East Lempster is an unincorporated community in the town of Lempster in Sullivan County, New Hampshire, United States.

title: Heaven Knows (Robert Plant song)
text: "Heaven Knows" is a rock song performed by English rock singer Robert Plant.

title: Heaven Knows (Robert Plant song)
text: It was the first single to be released from his 1988 album "Now and Zen".

title: Heaven Knows (Robert Plant song)
text: It reached number 33 on the UK singles chart and number 1 on the "Billboard" Album Rock Tracks chart.

title: Heaven Knows (Robert Plant song)
text: It was Plant's third number-one rock song, following 1983's "Other Arms" and 1985's "Little by Little."

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: 10 H.M. (Short for 10 Hronia Mazi, Greek: "10 Χρόνια Μαζί"; English: "10 Years Together") is an album released by Greek singer Despina Vandi starting on December 6, 2007.

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: It is her 12th album from the beginning of her career, and her 10th album with Phoebus.

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: It is also her first studio album of new material since her 2004 release of "Stin Avli Tou Paradisou".

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: The album is dedicated to the 10-year collaboration with Phoebus and features a track of the same name.

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: The album is a triple CD, with the first CD containing pop/rock songs, the second CD containing Modern Laika songs and third CD containing new remixes of older songs.

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: The album is completely written and produced by Phoebus and released by Heaven Music.

title: 10 Hronia Mazi
text: The main sponsor is WIND Hellas.

title: Mark Britten
text: Mark Britten is an American comedian from Arlington, Texas, whose chosen stage name is "The Chinaman".

title: Mark Britten
text: Born of a Chinese-American mother and a Caucasian father, his act employs material from his "dysfunctional background" and skews ethnic stereotypes of all kinds.

title: Mark Britten
text: He has been a performing stand-up comic for ten years, and is known for his voice impersonations, parodies of rock singers and other vocalists and biting anecdotes about the foibles of ethnic and cultural stereotypes. "

title: Mark Britten
text: The Austin Chronicle" describes him as "a rock star trapped in a comic’s body."

title: Mark Britten
text: He is a member of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

title: Stranger in Town (album)
text: Stranger in Town is the tenth studio album by American rock singer Bob Seger and his second with the Silver Bullet Band, released by Capitol Records in May 1978 (see 1978 in music).

title: Stranger in Town (album)
text: Like its predecessor, the Silver Bullet Band backed Seger on about half of the songs and the Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section backed Seger on the other half.

title: Gary Cherone
text: Gary Francis Caine Cherone ( ; born July 26, 1961) is an American rock singer and songwriter.

title: Gary Cherone
text: He is best known for his work as the lead vocalist of the Boston rock group Extreme, as well as his short stint as the lead vocalist for Van Halen on their 11th album "Van Halen III" and subsequent tour.

title: Gary Cherone
text: In recent years he has released solo recordings.

title: Gary Cherone
text: In 2007, he reunited with Extreme.

title: Ride Out (album)
text: Ride Out is the seventeenth studio album by American rock singer–songwriter Bob Seger.

title: Ride Out (album)
text: The album was released on October 14, 2014.

title: Ride Out (album)
text: Although Seger had previously stated that this may be his final album, a followup album entitled "I Knew You When" will be released on November 17, 2017.

title: Bob Seger
text: Robert Clark Seger ( , born May 6, 1945) is an American singer-songwriter, guitarist and pianist.

title: Bob Seger
text: As a locally successful Detroit-area artist, he performed and recorded as Bob Seger and the Last Heard and Bob Seger System throughout the 1960s.

title: Bob Seger
text: By the early 1970s, he had dropped the 'System' from his recordings and continued to strive for broader success with various other bands.

title: Bob Seger
text: In 1973, he put together the Silver Bullet Band, with a group of Detroit-area musicians, with whom he became most successful on the national level with the album "Live Bullet" (1976), recorded live with the Silver Bullet Band in 1975 at Cobo Hall in Detroit, Michigan.

title: Bob Seger
text: In 1976, he achieved a national breakout with the studio album "Night Moves".

title: Bob Seger
text: On his studio albums, he also worked extensively with the Alabama-based Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section, which appeared on several of Seger's best-selling singles and albums.

title: Anggun discography
text: The discography of Anggun consists of ten studio albums, two soundtrack albums, three greatest hits albums, seven single compilations, thirty-eight singles and twenty music videos.

title: Anggun discography
text: Anggun began performing at the age of seven and recorded a children's album two years later.

title: Anggun discography
text: Her debut studio album, "Dunia Aku Punya", was released in 1986 under Billboard Indonesia, but did not achieve commercial success.

title: Anggun discography
text: Anggun's popularity was later established after the success of the single "Mimpi", which was listed as one of the 150 Greatest Indonesian Songs of All Time.

title: Anggun discography
text: With the release of subsequent singles and three more studio albums— "Anak Putih Abu Abu", "Nocturno" and "Anggun C. Sasmi... Lah!!!

title: Anggun discography
text: "—Anggun became one of the most successful Indonesian rock singers in the early 1990s.

title: Anggun discography
text: In 1993, she became the youngest Indonesian singer to found her own record company, Bali Cipta Records.

title: Anggun discography
text: By the age of nineteen, Anggun had sold over four million albums in Indonesia.

title: Freudiana
text: Freudiana was to be the 11th album by The Alan Parsons Project, but during its development, Eric Woolfson had creative differences with Alan Parsons, and decided to turn the album into a rock opera.

title: Freudiana
text: It was released as simply "Freudiana," and is known as the "unofficial" Alan Parsons Project album, and considered by APP fans to really be their 11th album.

title: Freudiana
text: Alan Parsons later continued as a solo artist with his 1993 album "Try Anything Once", which was musically in a direction more or less continued from that of 1987's "Gaudi".

title: Against the Wind (album)
text: Against the Wind is the eleventh album by American rock singer Bob Seger and his fourth with the Silver Bullet Band.

title: Against the Wind (album)
text: It was released in February 1980.

title: Against the Wind (album)
text: It is Seger's only number-one album to date, spending six weeks at the top of the "Billboard" Top LPs chart, knocking Pink Floyd's "The Wall" from the top spot.

title: Chief of the Defence Staff (Canada)
text: The Chief of the Defence Staff (CDS; French: "chef d'état-major de la Défense" ) is the second most senior member of the Canadian Armed Forces (after the commander-in-chief) and heads the Armed Forces Council, having primary responsibility for command, control, and administration of the forces, as well as military strategy, plans, and requirements.

title: Chief of the Defence Staff (Canada)
text: The position is held by a senior member of one of the three main branches of the Canadian Armed Forces.

title: Chief of the Defence Staff (Canada)
text: The current CDS, since 17 July 2015, is Jonathan Vance.

title: One Rank, One Pension
text: One Rank One Pension (OROP), or "same pension, for same rank, for same length of service, irrespective of the date of retirement", is a longstanding demand of the Indian armed forces and veterans.

title: One Rank, One Pension
text: The demand for pay-pension equity, which underlies the OROP concept, was provoked by the exparte decision by the Indira Gandhi-led Indian National Congress (INC) government, in 1973, two years after the historic victory in the 1971 Bangladesh war, and shortly after Field Marshal SHFJ Manekshaw retired, to decrease armed forces pensions by 20–40 percent, and increase civilian pensions by 20 percent, without consultation with armed forces headquarters.

title: One Rank, One Pension
text: <ref name="V Mahalingam, 21/9"> </ref>

title: Armed Forces Covenant
text: The Military Covenant or Armed Forces Covenant is a term introduced in 2000 into British public life to refer to the mutual obligations between the nation and its Armed Forces.

title: Armed Forces Covenant
text: According to "The Guardian", "it is an informal understanding, rather than a legally enforceable deal, but it is nevertheless treated with great seriousness within the services".

title: Armed Forces Covenant
text: It was coined in , and has now entered political discourse as a way of measuring whether the government and society at large have kept to their obligations to support members of the armed forces.

title: Fernando Tapias Stahelin
text: Fernando Tapias Stahelin (born July 14, 1943 - † September 27, 2015) was a General (retired) of Colombian Armed Forces.

title: Fernando Tapias Stahelin
text: He served as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff of Colombian Armed Forces for a period of four years (1998–2002) during the presidential term of president Andres Pastrana.

title: Fernando Tapias Stahelin
text: After that, he served as ambassador of Colombia in Dominican Republic from 2002 to 2004 and subsequently served as Deputy Minister of Defense for its social and business group for two years from 2009 to 2010 during the presidential term of president Alvaro Uribe.

title: Fernando Tapias Stahelin
text: He was in the Colombian Armed Forces for 41 years, achieving all the military ranks all the way up to his appointment as General Commander for the Colombian Armed Forces.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: In June 1941, Roosevelt issued Executive Order 8802, which created the Fair Employment Practice Committee (FEPC).

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: It was the most important federal move in support of the rights of African-Americans between Reconstruction and the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: The President's order stated that the federal government would not hire any person based on their race, color, creed, or national origin.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: The FEPC enforced the order to ban discriminatory hiring within the federal government and in corporations that received federal contracts.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: Millions of blacks and women achieved better jobs and better pay as a result.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: The war brought the race issue to the forefront.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: The Army and Navy had been segregated since the Civil War.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: But by 1940, the African-American vote had largely shifted from Republican to Democrat, and African-American leaders like Walter Francis White of the NAACP and T. Arnold Hill of the Urban League had become recognized as part of the Roosevelt coalition.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: In June 1941, at the urging of A. Philip Randolph, the leading African-American trade unionist, Roosevelt signed an executive order establishing the Fair Employment Practice Committee and prohibiting discrimination by any government agency, including the armed forces.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: In practice the services, particularly the Navy and the Marines, found ways to evade this order — the Marine Corps remained all-white until 1942.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: In September 1942, at Eleanor's instigation, Roosevelt met with a delegation of African-American leaders, who demanded full integration into the forces, including the right to serve in combat roles and in the Navy, the Marine Corps and the United States Army Air Forces.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: Roosevelt agreed, but then did nothing to implement his promise.

title: Franklin D. Roosevelt's record on civil rights
text: It was left to his successor, Harry S. Truman, to fully desegregate the armed forces.

title: Armed Forces Day (Poland)
text: Armed Forces Day, known also as the Feast of the Polish Armed Forces (Polish: "Święto Wojska Polskiego" ), is a national holiday celebrated annually on 15 August in Poland, commemorating the anniversary of the 1920 victory over Soviet Russia at the Battle of Warsaw during the Polish–Soviet War.

title: Armed Forces Day (Poland)
text: Armed Forces Day is held in conjunction with the Day of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary, itself a separate public holiday.

title: Armed Forces Day (Poland)
text: The event is marked by military parades, equipment reviews, showcases and remembrances by all branches of the Polish Armed Forces across the country.

title: Armed Forces Day (Poland)
text: One of the most prominent events of the day is in the capital Warsaw, which hosts a large military parade through the city's center.

title: Armed Forces Day (Poland)
text: Originally celebrated during the Second Republic, the holiday was barred by authorities during the communist era beginning in 1947, only to be revived again in 1992.

title: 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade
text: The 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade was held on May 9, 2010 in Kiev, honoring the 65th anniversary of the Soviet Union's victory in the Great Patriotic War.

title: 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade
text: Inspecting the parade was the Chief of General Staff of the Armed Forces General of the Army Ivan Svyda.

title: 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade
text: The commander of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Colonel General Gennady Vorobyov, Commanded the Parade.

title: 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade
text: The President of Ukraine Viktor Yanukovych delivered a jubilee address.

title: 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade
text: 2,500 members of the Ukrainian Armed Forces troops from Russia and Belarus took part in the parade.

title: 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade
text: 17 military orchestras took part in the parade under the command of the Chief of the Military Music Department of the General Staff of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Major General Volodymyr Derkach.

title: Conscription in the United States
text: Conscription in the United States, commonly known as the draft, has been employed by the federal government of the United States in four conflicts: the American Civil War, World War I, World War II, and the Cold War (including both the Korean and Vietnam Wars).

title: Conscription in the United States
text: The third incarnation of the draft came into being in 1940 through the Selective Training and Service Act.

title: Conscription in the United States
text: It was the country's first peacetime draft.

title: Conscription in the United States
text: From 1940 until 1973, during both peacetime and periods of conflict, men were drafted to fill vacancies in the United States Armed Forces that could not be filled through voluntary means.

title: Conscription in the United States
text: The draft was ended when the United States Armed Forces moved to an all-volunteer military force.

title: Conscription in the United States
text: However, the Selective Service System remains in place as a contingency plan; all male civilians between the ages of 18 and 25 are required to register so that a draft can be readily resumed if needed.

title: Rostker v. Goldberg
text: Rostker v. Goldberg, 453 U.S. 57 (1981) , was a decision of the United States Supreme Court holding that the practice of requiring only men to register for the draft was constitutional.

title: Rostker v. Goldberg
text: After extensive hearings, floor debate and committee sessions on the matter, the United States Congress enacted the law, as it had previously been, to apply to men only.

title: Rostker v. Goldberg
text: Several attorneys, including Robert L. Goldberg, subsequently challenged the gender distinction as unconstitutional.

title: Rostker v. Goldberg
text: (The named defendant is Bernard D. Rostker, Director of the Selective Service System.)

title: Rostker v. Goldberg
text: In a 6-3 decision, the Supreme Court held that this gender distinction was not a violation of the equal protection component of the due process clause, and that the Act would stand as passed.

title: September 16 military parade
text: The 16 September military parade in honour of the anniversary of Mexican Independence is an annual tradition dating back to the late 19th century and the beginning of the professionalisation of the Mexican Armed Forces in the 20th century.

title: September 16 military parade
text: Held yearly in the Zócalo in Mexico City, this parade, the largest of the various parades held simultaneously nationwide on September 16, Mexican Independence Day, is presided by the President of Mexico in the fulfillment of his duty as the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces.

title: September 16 military parade
text: It is also attended by members of the Cabinet of Mexico, the Congress of the Union, civil service employees, the Secretaries of National Defense and Navy, members of the Mexican Armed Forces and Federal Police, uniformed service veterans, the state diplomatic corps, delegations representing the religious sector, indigenous peoples, sports and the private sector, and the general public.

title: September 16 military parade
text: Seen on TV and the Internet and heard on radio, this is one of the biggest events of the year.

title: September 16 military parade
text: Taking part in this are members of the Mexican Armed Forces and the Federal Police.

title: PepsiCo
text: PepsiCo, Inc. is an American multinational food, snack, and beverage corporation headquartered in Purchase, New York.

title: PepsiCo
text: PepsiCo has interests in the manufacturing, marketing, and distribution of grain-based snack foods, beverages, and other products.

title: PepsiCo
text: PepsiCo was formed in 1965 with the merger of the Pepsi-Cola Company and Frito-Lay, Inc.

title: PepsiCo
text: PepsiCo has since expanded from its namesake product Pepsi to a broader range of food and beverage brands, the largest of which included an acquisition of Tropicana Products in 1998 and the Quaker Oats Company in 2001, which added the Gatorade brand to its portfolio.

title: Rewrapped
text: Rewrapped is a reality cooking television show hosted by Joey Fatone that premiered on April 21, 2014, on Food Network.

title: Rewrapped
text: Similar to short-form cooking reality shows, it features three chefs challenged to first recreate a classic snack food, then innovate a totally new dish using said snack food as the main ingredient.

title: Rewrapped
text: The show is a loose spinoff of the show "Unwrapped", whose host Marc Summers acts as "Head Judge" for each episode, alongside a representative of the company that produces the food of the day, and a third impartial judge involved in the food industry in some way (chef, critic, blogger, etc.).

title: Twisties
text: Twisties are a type of cheese curl, corn-based snack food product, available mainly in Australia, and other Oceanian countries such as Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia, Vanuatu and Fiji, the Southeast Asian countries Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore and Brunei, and the island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean.

title: Twisties
text: It was launched in 1950 by the General Foods Corporation.

title: Twisties
text: The brand name is owned by The Smith's Snackfood Company.

title: Twisties
text: While originally an Australian-owned company, Smith's was acquired in August 1998 by Frito-Lay, the second largest producer of snack foods in Australia, which in turn is owned by American multi-national PepsiCo.

title: Twisties
text: In Malaysia, Twisties is a product of Mondelēz International, after having been a part of Danone and later, Kraft Foods previously.

title: Twisties
text: In Thailand, the Twisties trademark is owned by Lay's, which like The Smith's Snackfood Company, is owned by PepsiCo.

title: Twisties
text: In New Zealand, Malta and Italy, Twisties are marketed under different names.

title: Snack Foods Limited
text: Snack Foods Limited is an Australian snack food company and was officially formed on 25 November 1999, and was owned by Arnott's Biscuits Holdings Pty Ltd.

title: Snack Foods Limited
text: , a subsidiary of the American Campbell Soup Company.

title: Snack Foods Limited
text: Snack Foods Limited owns one of Australia's largest salted snack food companies, Snack Brands Australia.

title: Snack Foods Limited
text: In April 2008, Campbell Arnott's sold Arnott’s Snackfoods to The Real McCoy Snackfood Co and the company is now known as Snack Brands Australia.

title: Mondelez International
text: Mondelez International, Inc., styled Mondelēz ( ), is an American multinational confectionery, food, and beverage company based in Illinois which employs about 107,000 people around the world.

title: Mondelez International
text: It consists of the global snack and food brands of the former Kraft Foods Inc after the October 2012 spin-off of its North American grocery operations.

title: Mondelez International
text: The Mondelez name, adopted in 2012, was suggested by Kraft Foods employees and is derived from the words "mundus" (Latin for “world”) and "delez" (a proxy for the word "delicious").

title: Robert's American Gourmet Food
text: Robert's American Gourmet Food was and is a snack food company located in the United States.

title: Robert's American Gourmet Food
text: Founded by businessman Robert Ehrlich in 1986, the company was best known for its snack food, Pirate's Booty, which is found in over 90% of United States supermarkets. Robert's American Gourmet targeted health-conscious shoppers with a range of snack foods.

title: Canyon Creek Food Company
text: Canyon Creek Food Company () is a food processing company based in Edmonton, Alberta that provides fresh soups and other prepared food products geared towards health conscious consumers.

title: Canyon Creek Food Company
text: The company provides its fresh food product line to grocery retailers and a broad range of food service establishments such as restaurants and institutions throughout Canada.

title: Handi-Snacks
text: Handi-Snacks are a snack food product line sold by Mondelez International.

title: Handi-Snacks
text: The common two-compartment Handi-Snack has a small spread compartment and a larger compartment for crackers; a red plastic spreader is included with crackers.

title: Snackbox Food Holdings
text: Snackbox Food Holdings Co, Ltd (Korean: 스낵박스푸드홀딩스 ) is a Korean lunch snack food company.

title: Snackbox Food Holdings
text: Its headquarters is in Mokdong-Ri Gyoha-Eup Paju Gyeonggi-do, Korea, and was established in 2004.

title: Snackbox Food Holdings
text: It offers a number of snack food services to home party foods.

title: Snackbox Food Holdings
text: The company offers a range of products including fruit lunch packs, salad, yogurt and sandwiches.

title: Snackbox Food Holdings
text: Snack Box has about 25 employees as of January, 2006.

title: Deep-fried peanuts
text: Deep Fried Peanuts are a snack food created by deep frying peanuts in an oil.

title: Deep-fried peanuts
text: The resulting product is a snack food that can be eaten in its entirety, both shell and nut.

title: Deep-fried peanuts
text: The deep-frying process does not change the flavor or texture of the nutmeats, but changes the texture and flavor of the shells -- especially if seasonings are used -- to make them more palatable.

title: Once Upon a Secret
text: Once Upon a Secret: My Affair with President John F. Kennedy and Its Aftermath is a book by the former White House intern Mimi Alford in February 2012.

title: Once Upon a Secret
text: It contains the autobiographical account of the woman who had an affair with U.S. President John F. Kennedy towards the end of his life (from June 1962 to July 1963).

title: Once Upon a Secret
text: Despite its consuming influence over her life at the time, Alford managed to keep her involvement in the affair secret for nearly 50 years, until basic details were published in the 2003 Kennedy biography "" by Robert Dallek.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Sheila Cavanagh is an associate professor of sociology and former chair of the Sexuality Studies Program at York University.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Cavanagh is currently chair of the Canadian Sexuality Studies Association and co-editor (along with Malena Gustavson) of the "Somatechnics" journal.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Her research is in the area of gender and sexuality with a concentration on queer, cultural, and psychoanalytic theories.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Cavanagh is editing a special issue on transgender and psychoanalysis in "Transgender Studies Quarterly" and completing her third book monograph titled "Transgender and the Other Sexual Difference: Bracha L. Ettinger and Jacques Lacan".

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: She co-edited a collection with Angela Failler and Rachel A. J. Hurst titled "Skin, Culture and Psychoanalysis" (2013) published by Palgrave Macmillan.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Her first sole-authored book titled "Sexing the Teacher: School Sex Scandals and Queer Pedagogies" (2007) was given honorable mention by the Canadian Women’s Studies Association.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Her second sole-authored book titled "Queering Bathrooms: Gender, Sexuality, and the Hygienic Imagination" (2010) is a GLBT Indie Book Award finalist and recipient of the CWSA/ACEF Outstanding Scholarship Prize Honourable Mention (2012).

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Her performed ethnography titled Queer Bathroom Monologues (QBM) premiered at the Toronto Fringe Festival (2011) and was given the Audience Pick Award.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: The play was professionally staged at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre, Toronto, in June 2014 for WorldPride and has toured at conferences, colleges and universities in Canada and the United States.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: She has published in a wide range of international journals and given keynotes addresses at conferences in Sweden, Turkey and Canada.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: Cavanagh teaches an undergraduate course titled Sociology of Gender and a range of graduate courses in sexuality studies, feminist theory and queer theory.

title: Sheila Cavanagh
text: She is also interviewed in Rohan Spong's documentaries "T is for Teacher" (2009) and "Queer Science" (2008).

title: Mark D. Fabiani
text: Mark D. Fabiani (born 1957) is an American political strategist, crisis management expert, former Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles and chief of staff to Mayor Tom Bradley, and former White House lawyer and spokesman.

title: Mark D. Fabiani
text: He is recognized for his work as special counsel to President Bill Clinton and legal spokesperson for the Clinton White House from 1994 through 1996, as well as for his work as head of communications for the Gore presidential campaign in 2000.

title: Mark D. Fabiani
text: He also served in senior positions at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and at the Department of Justice.

title: Monica Lewinsky
text: Monica Samille Lewinsky (born July 23, 1973) is an American activist, television personality, fashion designer, and former White House intern.

title: The White House Doctor
text: The White House Doctor: My Patients Were Presidents – A Memoir is a book authored by Connie Mariano, the first military woman in the history of the United States to be appointed as Physician to the President, the first female director of the medical unit of the White House, and the first Filipino-American to become a rear admiral in the US Navy.

title: The White House Doctor
text: With a foreword from Bill Clinton, the autobiographical book takes a look at the personal lives of three American Presidents (George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush) and three American First Ladies (Barbara Bush, Hillary Clinton, and Laura Bush) she had taken care of while working as a White House physician.

title: The White House Doctor
text: It was described as a "fascinating look into what goes on behind closed doors at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue".

title: Gregory B. Craig
text: Gregory Bestor "Greg" Craig (born March 4, 1945) is an American lawyer and former White House Counsel under President Barack Obama from 2009 to 2010.

title: Gregory B. Craig
text: A former attorney at the Washington, D.C. law firm of Williams & Connolly, Craig has represented numerous high-profile clients.

title: Gregory B. Craig
text: Prior to becoming White House Counsel, Craig served as assistant to the President and special counsel in the White House of President Bill Clinton, where he directed the team defending Clinton against impeachment.

title: Gregory B. Craig
text: Craig also served as a senior advisor to Senator Edward Kennedy and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.

title: Their Lives
text: Their Lives: The Women Targeted by the Clinton Machine is a book by Candice E. Jackson.

title: Their Lives
text: Published by conservative publisher World Ahead Publishing on May 31, 2005, it recounts the stories of seven women who crossed paths with Bill Clinton: Monica Lewinsky, Paula Jones, Gennifer Flowers, Kathleen Willey, Elizabeth Gracen, Juanita Broaddrick, and Sally Perdue.

title: Eric Schultz
text: Eric Schultz is a senior advisor to former President Barack Obama and is the founder of Schultz Group.

title: Eric Schultz
text: Schultz is a former White House Principal Deputy Press Secretary and special assistant to President Obama.

title: Eric Schultz
text: Recognized by "Politico" as the strategist “White House officials turn to in a crisis to handle communications,” Schultz was originally hired at the White House in 2011 to respond to Congressional oversight investigations.

title: Eric Schultz
text: After White House Deputy Press Secretary Josh Earnest replaced Jay Carney to become White House Press Secretary, Schultz was appointed White House Deputy Press Secretary.

title: Eric Schultz
text: In this role, Schultz often diffuses "tensions with humor.

title: Eric Schultz
text: But he can be relentless in pushing his message in both public and private conversations.”

title: Eric Schultz
text: Former White House Communications Director Jen Psaki compared Schultz to fictional crisis manager Olivia Pope, "he's the person you want next to you in a foxhole when there's a crisis."

title: Eric Schultz
text: At the end of President Obama's second term, former White House Senior Advisor Valerie Jarrett said of Schultz, “We’ve all grown to rely on his wise counsel" and that the President "trusts his sound judgement."

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: The Lewinsky scandal was an American political sex scandal that involved 49-year-old President Bill Clinton and 22-year-old White House intern Monica Lewinsky.

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: The sexual relationship took place between 1995 and 1996 and came to light in 1998.

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: Clinton ended a televised speech with the statement that he did not have sexual relations with Lewinsky.

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: Further investigation led to charges of perjury and to the impeachment of President Clinton in 1998 by the U.S. House of Representatives.

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: He was subsequently acquitted on all impeachment charges of perjury and obstruction of justice in a 21-day Senate trial.

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: Clinton was held in civil contempt of court by Judge Susan Webber Wright for giving misleading testimony in the Paula Jones case regarding Lewinsky and was also fined $90,000 by Wright.

title: Lewinsky scandal
text: His license to practice law was suspended in Arkansas for five years; shortly thereafter, he was disbarred from presenting cases in front of the United States Supreme Court.

title: William H. Ginsburg
text: William H. Ginsburg (March 25, 1943 – April 1, 2013) was an American lawyer, best known for representing former White House intern Monica Lewinsky in her controversy regarding sexual activities with President Bill Clinton in 1998.

title: Donald Trump in music
text: Donald Trump in music refers to songs, albums and bands that refer to Donald Trump and his various brands, including Trump Tower, his TV show, his hotel chain, and his casinos.

title: Donald Trump in music
text: Though recent songs refer to Trump's campaign and subsequent election as president of the United States, more than 200 songs refer to Trump prior to his successful presidential campaign between 1989 and 2013.

title: Donald Trump in music
text: With his victory in the 2016 presidential election, Trump's prominence in hip-hop music has been liked to that of Ronald Reagan's in hardcore punk during the 1980s.

title: Protests against Donald Trump
text: Protests against Donald Trump, or anti-Trump protests, have occurred both in the United States and elsewhere since Donald Trump's entry into the 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Protests against Donald Trump
text: Protests have expressed opposition to Trump's campaign rhetoric, his electoral win, his inauguration and various presidential actions.

title: Protests against Donald Trump
text: Some protests have taken the form of walk-outs, business closures, petitions and, especially since Trump's inauguration, rallies, demonstrations or marches.

title: Protests against Donald Trump
text: While most protests have been peaceful, some protesters have destroyed property, and attacked Trump supporters.

title: Tony Fabrizio
text: Anthony Fabrizio (born 1960) is an American Republican pollster and strategist.

title: Tony Fabrizio
text: He is the principal in Fabrizio, Lee & Associates, and was the pollster for Donald Trump's fall 2016 Presidential campaign, former Senator Bob Dole's 1996 Presidential campaign, U.S. Senator Rand Paul's U.S. Senate and 2016 Presidential campaign, and former Governor Rick Perry's 2012 Presidential campaign, among others.

title: Tony Fabrizio
text: He also served as a pollster for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in the 2014 midterm elections.

title: David Urban
text: David Urban (born c. 1964) is an American lobbyist, political operative, and political commentator who worked on the 2016 Donald Trump presidential campaign, helping to orchestrate the 2016 Republican National Convention and serving as a senior advisor in the successful effort to win Pennsylvania.

title: David Urban
text: In November 2016, it was reported that Urban was being considered as the next chair of the Republican National Committee, as well as the White House Deputy Chief of Staff, and in May 2017, it was reported that Trump was considering Urban to replace Reince Priebus as White House Chief of Staff.

title: Paul Manafort
text: Paul John Manafort Jr. (born April 1, 1949) is an American lawyer, lobbyist and political consultant.

title: Paul Manafort
text: He joined Donald Trump's presidential campaign team in March 2016 and served as campaign manager from June to August 2016.

title: Paul Manafort
text: He was previously an adviser to the U.S. presidential campaigns of Republicans Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush, and Bob Dole.

title: Paul Manafort
text: In 1980 Manafort co-founded the Washington, D.C.-based lobbying firm Black, Manafort & Stone, along with principals Charles R. Black Jr., and Roger J. Stone.

title: Paul Manafort
text: In 1984 it was renamed Black, Manafort, Stone and Kelly (BMSK) & associates, after Peter G. Kelly was recruited.

title: Immigration policy of Donald Trump
text: Illegal immigration was a signature issue of U.S. President Donald Trump's presidential campaign, and his proposed reforms and remarks about this issue generated much publicity.

title: Immigration policy of Donald Trump
text: A hallmark promise of his campaign was to build a substantial wall on the United States-Mexico border.

title: Immigration policy of Donald Trump
text: Trump has also expressed support for a variety of "limits on legal immigration and guest-worker visas", including a "pause" on granting green cards, which Trump says will "allow record immigration levels to subside to more moderate historical averages".

title: Immigration policy of Donald Trump
text: Trump's proposals regarding H-1B visas frequently changed throughout his presidential campaign, but as of late July 2016, he appeared to oppose the H-1B visa program.

title: Immigration policy of Donald Trump
text: Trump has questioned official estimates of the number of illegal immigrants in the United States (between 11 and 12 million), insisting the number is much higher (between 30 and 34 million).

title: Hope Hicks
text: Hope Charlotte Hicks (born October 21, 1988) is an American communications and public relations consultant who is the current White House Communications Director for President Donald Trump.

title: Hope Hicks
text: From January to September 2017, she served as White House Director of Strategic Communications, a role created for her.

title: Hope Hicks
text: She previously served as the press secretary and early communications director for Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, as well as the national press secretary for his presidential transition team, and before that was an employee of The Trump Organization.

title: Hope Hicks
text: She is Trump's longest-serving political aide.

title: Brad Parscale
text: Brad Parscale (born January 3, 1976) is an American digital media and political strategist.

title: Brad Parscale
text: He served as the digital media director for Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Brad Parscale
text: Parscale began working for the Trump Organization in 2011, developing and designing websites, and creating and managing digital media strategies.

title: Brad Parscale
text: In early 2015, Trump hired Parscale and his firm, Giles-Parscale, to create a website for his exploratory campaign.

title: Brad Parscale
text: When Trump declared himself a Republican candidate in 2015, one of the first people he called was Parscale, asking him to update his exploratory campaign site into a "full-fledged presidential campaign website."

title: Brad Parscale
text: Throughout the Republican primary, Parscale was responsible for the Donald J. Trump for President website, as well as for digital media strategy and online fundraising campaigns.

title: Brad Parscale
text: In June 2016, Parscale was officially named digital media director for the Donald J. Trump for President campaign, overseeing all aspects of digital media and online fundraising, as well as traditional media strategy, like radio and television placements.

title: Brad Parscale
text: In January 2017, Parscale, along with another senior Trump aide, Nick Ayers, formally launched America First Policies, a non-profit organization that promotes President Trump's agenda and White House initiatives.

title: Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000
text: Donald Trump's presidential campaign of 2000 for the nomination of the Reform Party began when real estate magnate Donald Trump of New York announced the creation of a presidential exploratory committee on the October 7, 1999 edition of "Larry King Live".

title: Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000
text: Though Trump had never held elected office, he was well known for his frequent comments on public affairs and business exploits as head of The Trump Organization.

title: Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000
text: He had previously considered a presidential run in 1988 as a Republican, but chose not to run.

title: Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000
text: For 2000, Minnesota Governor Jesse Ventura persuaded Trump to seek the presidential nomination of the Reform Party, which was fracturing despite achieving ballot access and qualifying for matching funds as a result of the 1996 presidential campaign of businessman Ross Perot.

title: Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000
text: Trump's entrance into the Reform Party race coincided with that of paleoconservative commentator Pat Buchanan, whom Trump attacked throughout the campaign as a "Hitler-lover."
