text: Wafangdian (), formerly Fuxian or Fu County (), is one of the two "northern county-level cities", the other being Zhuanghe, under the administration of Dalian, located in the south of Liaoning province, China.

title: Wafangdian
text: The city is famous for its ball bearing industry.

title: Wafangdian
text: Wafangdian Bearing Factory is the largest bearing manufacturer in Asia and was initially built by the Japanese during World War II.

title: Wafangdian
text: Its area is 3576.40 km2 and its permanent population as of 2010 is 942,197, compared to 1,024,876 registered with hukou permits.

title: Wafangdian
text: The city borders the prefecture-level city of Yingkou to the northeast.

title: Fuding Railway Station
text: Fuding Railway Station () is a railway station located in Fuding City, Ningde, Fujian Province, China, on the Wenzhou-Fuzhou Railway operated by the Nanchang Railway Bureau, China Railway Corporation.

title: Yingkou East Railway Station
text: Yingkou East Railway Station (IATA: YDD) is a railway station of Beijing–Harbin High-Speed Railway, in particular of both the Panjin–Yingkou and Harbin–Dalian sub-sections.

title: Yingkou East Railway Station
text: It is located in Dashiqiao, in the Yingkou prefecture level city, in the Liaoning province of China.

title: Yingkou Lanqi Airport
text: Yingkou Lanqi Airport (IATA: YKH, ICAO: ZYYK) is an airport serving the city of Yingkou in Liaoning province of Northeast China.

title: Yingkou Lanqi Airport
text: It is located in Lanqi Village in Xishi District of Yingkou, about 17 km from the city center by road.

title: Yingkou Lanqi Airport
text: The airport opened on 3 February 2016, when the inaugural China Eastern Airlines flight landed from Shanghai Pudong International Airport.

title: Yingkou Lanqi Airport
text: The total investment for the project was estimated at CNY 8.94 billion.

title: Taimushan Railway Station
text: Mount Taimu Railway Station () is a railway station located in Fuding City, Ningde, Fujian Province, China, on the Wenzhou-Fuzhou Railway operated by the Nanchang Railway Bureau, China Railway Corporation.

title: Tongcheng Subdistrict, Fuding
text: Tongcheng () is a subdistrict of the city of Fuding, Fujian, People's Republic of China.

title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Yingkou
text: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Yingkou/Yingkow (Latin: "Imcheuven(sis)" , ) is a diocese located in the city of Yingkou in the Ecclesiastical province of Shenyang 瀋陽 in China.

title: Muscogee language
text: The Muscogee language (Mvskoke in Muscogee), also known as Creek, Seminole, Maskókî or Muskogee, is a Muskogean language spoken by Muscogee (Creek) and Seminole people, primarily in the U.S. states of Oklahoma and Florida.

title: Black Indians in the United States
text: Black Indians are people of mixed African-American and Native American heritage, who have strong ties to Native American culture.

title: Black Indians in the United States
text: Many Indigenous peoples of the Eastern Woodlands, such as the Narragansett, Pequot, Lumbee and Cherokee, have a significant degree of African ancestry.

title: Seminole
text: The Seminole are a Native American people originally from Florida.

title: Seminole
text: Today, they principally live in Oklahoma with a minority in Florida, and comprise three federally recognized tribes: the Seminole Tribe of Oklahoma, the Seminole Tribe of Florida, and Miccosukee Tribe of Indians of Florida, as well as independent groups.

title: Seminole
text: The Seminole nation emerged in a process of ethnogenesis from various Native American groups who settled in Florida in the 18th century, most significantly northern Muscogee (Creeks) from what is now Georgia and Alabama.

title: Seminole
text: The word "Seminole" is derived from the Creek word "simanó-li", which may be itself be derived from the Spanish word "cimarrón", menaning "runaway" or "wild one".

title: Draining and development of the Everglades
text: The history of draining and development of the Everglades dates back to the 19th century.

title: Draining and development of the Everglades
text: During the Second Seminole War beginning in 1836, the United States military's mission was to seek out Seminole people in the Everglades and capture or kill them.

title: Draining and development of the Everglades
text: Those missions gave the military the opportunity to map land that seemed to frustrate and confound them at every turn.

title: Draining and development of the Everglades
text: A national push for expansion and progress toward the latter part of the 19th century stimulated interest in draining the Everglades for agricultural use.

title: Draining and development of the Everglades
text: According to historians, "From the middle of the nineteenth century to the middle of the twentieth century, the United States went through a period in which wetland removal was not questioned.

title: Draining and development of the Everglades
text: Indeed, it was considered the proper thing to do."

title: Seminole music
text: Seminole music is the music of the Seminole people, an indigenous people of the Americas who formed in Florida in the 18th century.

title: Seminole music
text: Today most live in Oklahoma, but a minority continue in Florida.

title: Seminole music
text: They have three federally recognized tribes, and some people belong to bands outside those groups.

title: Seminole music
text: Their traditional music includes extensive use of rattles, hand drums, water drums, and flutes.

title: Seminole County, Oklahoma
text: Seminole County is a county located in the U.S. state of Oklahoma.

title: Seminole County, Oklahoma
text: As of the 2010 census, the population was 25,482.

title: Seminole County, Oklahoma
text: Its county seat is Wewoka.

title: Seminole County, Oklahoma
text: Before Oklahoma's admission as a state, the county was the entire small portion of Indian Territory allocated to the Seminole people, who were removed from Florida in the 1820s.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: The Battle of Jupiter Inlet occurred on January 15, 1838, between the Seminole Indians - Seminole Negro and the United States Navy.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: This was the first of a series of battles led by the US Navy in the area, also referred to as the First Battle of Loxahatchee.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: The battle started when Lt. Levin Powell led an expedition of 200 soldiers, sailors and marines, down the east coast of Florida.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: The Navy spotted a trail alongside the Jupiter Inlet, and seventy-five men were landed to find the Seminole camp nearby.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: The camp was led by Sam Jones, Ar-pi-uck-i, the spiritual medicine and war chief of the Miccosukee and Seminole people during the war.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: The officers that advanced on the camp were outnumbered and ambushed.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: After a long fight, the US retreated with five men killed in action and about twenty others wounded.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: Ltn.

title: Battle of Jupiter Inlet
text: Powell was one of those killed in battle.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: The Seminole Nation of Oklahoma is a federally recognized Native American tribe based in the U.S. state of Oklahoma.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: It is the largest of the three federally recognized Seminole governments, which include the Seminole Tribe of Florida and the Miccosukee Tribe of Indians of Florida.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: Its members are descendants of the 3,000 Seminoles who were forcibly removed from Florida to Indian Territory, along with 800 Black Seminoles, after the Second Seminole War.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: The Seminole Nation of Oklahoma is headquartered in Wewoka within Seminole County, Oklahoma.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: Of 18,800 enrolled tribal members, 13,533 live within the state of Oklahoma.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: The tribe began to revive its government in 1936 under the Indian Reorganization Act.

title: Seminole Nation of Oklahoma
text: While its reservation was originally larger, today the tribal jurisdictional area covers Seminole County, Oklahoma, within which it has a variety of properties.

title: Dhoolpet
text: Dhoolpet is one of the old suburbs in Hyderabad, India.

title: Dhoolpet
text: It is part of the old city of Hyderabad.

title: Dhoolpet
text: This place is inhabited by people who migrated from Uttar Pradesh during the Nizam rule.

title: Dhoolpet
text: The Nizam helped these people settle in this area.

title: Dhoolpet
text: The area is notorious for bootlegging and has witnessed attacks on policemen or excise department officials during raids.

title: Black Seminoles
text: The Black Seminoles are black Indians associated with the Seminole people in Florida and Oklahoma.

title: Black Seminoles
text: They are the descendants of free blacks and of escaped slaves (called maroons) who allied with Seminole groups in Spanish Florida.

title: Black Seminoles
text: Historically, the Black Seminoles lived mostly in distinct bands near the Native American Seminole.

title: Black Seminoles
text: Some were held as slaves of particular Seminole leaders; but they had more freedom than did slaves held by whites in the South and by other Native American tribes, including the right to bear arms.

title: Charles Charamba
text: Charles Charamba (born 27 April 1971) is a Zimbabwean gospel musician and a pastor in the Apostolic Faith Mission Church of Zimbabwe.

title: Charles Charamba
text: Charamba's albums have been the top selling gospel music in Zimbabwe since the early 2000s.

title: Charles Charamba
text: He has toured both Great Britain and the United States, and throughout southern Africa.

title: Charles Charamba
text: One of Charamba's most famous songs is “Machira Chete”.

title: Charles Charamba
text: His wife, Olivia (née Maseko), is also a gospel singer, and appears with him on stage and on his albums; they are often called the "First Family of Gospel".

title: Andraé Crouch
text: Andraé Edward Crouch (July 1, 1942 – January 8, 2015) was an American gospel singer, songwriter, arranger, record producer and pastor.

title: Andraé Crouch
text: Referred to as "the father of modern gospel music" by contemporary Christian and gospel music professionals, Crouch was known for his compositions "The Blood Will Never Lose Its Power", "My Tribute (To God Be the Glory)" and "Soon and Very Soon".

title: Andraé Crouch
text: In secular music, he was known for his collaborative work during the 1980s and 1990s with Stevie Wonder, Elton John and Quincy Jones as well as conducting choirs that sang on the Michael Jackson hit "Man in the Mirror" and Madonna's "Like a Prayer".

title: Andraé Crouch
text: Crouch was noted for his talent of incorporating contemporary secular music styles into the gospel music he grew up with.

title: Andraé Crouch
text: His efforts in this area helped pave the way for early American contemporary Christian music during the 1960s and 1970s.

title: Just as I Am (Yolanda Adams album)
text: Just as I Am is the debut album by gospel singer Yolanda Adams, released on September 22, 1987 on the Sound of Gospel label and produced by Thomas Whitfield, who also worked with singer Vanessa Bell Armstrong on early 1980s gospel releases.

title: Just as I Am (Yolanda Adams album)
text: Though original pressings of the vinyl and cassette release are difficult to find, the album has since been re-released on CD along with another catalog album from Sound of Gospel by Wanda Nero Butler entitled "New Born Soul".

title: Kierra Sheard
text: Kierra Valencia "Kiki" Sheard (born June 20, 1987 in Detroit, Michigan) is an American gospel singer, fashion designer, and radio host.

title: Kierra Sheard
text: She is the daughter of gospel singer Karen Clark Sheard (member of gospel singing group The Clark Sisters) and the granddaughter of gospel choral director Mattie Moss Clark.

title: Kierra Sheard
text: Sheard portrayed Litha in the 2010 Christian-drama film "Preacher's Kid".

title: Kierra Sheard
text: After appearing on her mother's albums, Sheard broke onto the music scene with the release of her debut album "I Owe You" in 2004.

title: Kierra Sheard
text: Her hit single "You Don't Know" was written about her mother's bout with an almost fatal blood clot.

title: Latice Crawford
text: Latice Crawford (born July 22, 1982 as Latice Tenae Crawford) is an American urban contemporary gospel singer and composer.

title: Latice Crawford
text: She is best known for using her three-octave, contralto vocal range of to finish third on the second season of the competitive gospel singing television show "Sunday Best" on Black Entertainment Television.

title: Latice Crawford
text: Her self-titled debut album reached two "Billboard" charts, the Top Gospel Albums and the Top Heatseekers.

title: Latice Crawford
text: Her second album, "Diary of a Church Girl", also appeared on the Top Gospel Albums chart.

title: Yolanda Adams
text: Yolanda Yvette Adams (born August 27, 1961) is an American gospel singer, record producer, actress, and former radio host of her own nationally syndicated morning gospel show.

title: Yolanda Adams
text: s of 2009 , she had sold 4.5 million albums since 1991 in the United States, and nearly 8 million albums worldwide according to SoundScan.

title: Yolanda Adams
text: Adams is known as the "Queen of Contemporary Gospel Music" and the "First Lady of Modern Gospel".

title: David Huntsinger
text: David Huntsinger is a pianist, composer, songwriter, and arranger who moved from his native California to Nashville, TN, in 1976 and played for the Rambos.

title: David Huntsinger
text: He co-wrote the song, "Holy Spirit, Thou Art Welcome", with Dottie Rambo, as well as the children’s musical, "Down By The Creek Bank".

title: David Huntsinger
text: In 1979 he left the Rambos to pursue a career as a studio pianist.

title: David Huntsinger
text: He wrote and arranged music for the 1989 Grammy-winning album "A Child’s Gift of Lullabyes", and arranged for and co-produced Andy Griffith’s 1996 Grammy-winning album, "I Love To Tell The Story: 25 Timeless Hymns".

title: David Huntsinger
text: He has worked with many artists, such as Sandi Patti, Steve Green, Kathy Troccoli, Michael Crawford, Glen Campbell, Carman, Larnelle Harris, Johnny Cash and Dolly Parton.

title: David Huntsinger
text: He toured with Vince Gill for a Christmas tour in 1999, and in 2001 for the Amy Grant/Vince Gill Christmas tour.

title: David Huntsinger
text: He has also written a number of children’s musicals, as well as produced many albums of his own original works and arrangements.

title: David Huntsinger
text: He played the piano for "An Unfinished Life", and contributed to two songs heard in "The Great Debaters".

title: David Huntsinger
text: He arranged for and played piano in the 1997 Christmas album "Piano Winterlude" (Unison).

title: David Huntsinger
text: He has done several projects for Discovery House Music.

title: David Huntsinger
text: In 2010 he composed a number of pieces for a special 25th Anniversary concert for the international television network 3ABN called "Pillars of Our Faith".

title: J-Shin
text: Jonathan "J-Shin" Shinoster is a contemporary R&B/gospel singer born in Liberty City, Florida, who was signed to Slip-n-Slide Records/Atlantic Records and is best known for his hit single "One Night Stand" with LaTocha Scott of Xscape.

title: Karen Clark Sheard
text: Karen Clark-Sheard (born Karen Valencia Clark; November 15, 1960) also known as "The Maestris Of Gospel" is an American gospel four-time Grammy Award-winning singer, musician, and songwriter.

title: Karen Clark Sheard
text: The youngest daughter of pioneering gospel choral director Mattie Moss Clark, Sheard began her career as a member of the legendary Grammy Award-winning female gospel group The Clark Sisters.

title: Karen Clark Sheard
text: She is the mother of contemporary gospel singer and actress Kierra "Kiki" Sheard.

title: Muyiwa Olarewaju
text: Muyiwa Olarewaju (born 26 November is a British Gospel singer and songwriter who mixes traditional gospel music with elements of world music (from Africa, the Caribbean and Asia), soul, R&B and pop.

title: Muyiwa Olarewaju
text: He is also an experienced performer, broadcaster and presenter.

title: Muyiwa Olarewaju
text: In 2009 he became the first-ever international act to perform on America's popular entertainment channel, BET, for the prestigious annual Celebration of Gospel show.

title: Muyiwa Olarewaju
text: He has presented the Turning Point programme to an estimated global audience of 70 million.

title: Muyiwa Olarewaju
text: With his group Riversongz, he sold out Indigo2 at the O2 in London, the first gospel act to do so, and he has played at the largest gospel music event in the world, The Experience, attracting a 500,000 strong audience.

title: Anthony Woodson
text: Anthony Woodson (born January 7, 1988) is a professional Canadian football running back for the Calgary Stampeders of the Canadian Football League.

title: Anthony Woodson
text: He was drafted 29th overall by the Winnipeg Blue Bombers in the 2010 CFL Draft and played for parts of two seasons with the club.

title: Anthony Woodson
text: On September 9, 2013, Woodson was traded to the Toronto Argonauts, along with a fifth round draft pick in 2014, in exchange for offensive lineman Marc Parenteau and a third round draft pick in 2014.

title: Anthony Woodson
text: He signed with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats as a free agent on February 11, 2015 and spent two years with the team before signing with his hometown Stampeders on February 17, 2017.

title: Ron Snidow
text: Ronald Wayne Snidow (December 30, 1941 – May 17, 2009) was an American football defensive tackle in the National Football League for the Washington Redskins and the Cleveland Browns.

title: Ron Snidow
text: He attended San Rafael High School in California.

title: Ron Snidow
text: He played college football at the University of Oregon.

title: Ron Snidow
text: The Washington Redskins drafted Snidow in the third round of the 1963 NFL draft.

title: Ron Snidow
text: After five seasons with the Redskins, he was traded to the Cleveland Browns in exchange for a second round draft choice, just prior to the opening of the 1968 season.

title: Ron Snidow
text: Snidow was first-team All-Pro with the Browns in 1969.

title: Ron Snidow
text: He appeared in 126 career regular season games.

title: Ron Snidow
text: After suffering a broken leg while playing with the Browns, he retired at the end of the 1972 season, having played 10 years in the NFL.

title: Ron Snidow
text: After retiring from the NFL, Snidow worked as a commercial real estate broker in Southern California, until he retired.

title: Ron Snidow
text: In 2008, Snidow was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig's disease, which he died from a year later on May 17, 2009, while on a vacation cruise off the coast of Italy on the island of Elba.

title: 1987–88 Quebec Nordiques season
text: Quebec made a huge trade during the 1987 NHL Entry Draft, as the Nordiques traded away Dale Hunter and Clint Malarchuk to the Washington Capitals for Gaetan Duchesne, Alan Haworth, and the Capitals first round draft pick in the 1987 NHL Entry Draft, in which the Nordiques selected Joe Sakic.

title: 1987–88 Quebec Nordiques season
text: Haworth had an injury plagued season in 1986–87, appearing in only 50 games, however, he scored 25 goals and 41 points.

title: 1987–88 Quebec Nordiques season
text: In 1985–86, Haworth had a career high 34 goals and 73 points for the Capitals.

title: 1987–88 Quebec Nordiques season
text: Duchesne had a career high 52 points with Washington in 1986–87, as he scored 17 goals and had 35 assists.

title: 1987–88 Quebec Nordiques season
text: Joe Sakic was the Nordiques second selection in the 1987 NHL Entry Draft, as he scored 60 goals and 133 points in 72 games with the Swift Current Broncos of the Western Hockey League (WHL), as Quebec selected Bryan Fogarty with their first pick.

title: 1987–88 Quebec Nordiques season
text: Fogarty had 70 points in 56 games with the Kingston Canadians of the Ontario Hockey League (OHL).

title: Fred Hageman
text: Fred John Hageman (born June 30, 1937 in Bunkie, Louisiana) is a former American football linebacker in the National Football League for the Washington Redskins.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He played college football at the University of Arkansas and University of Kansas, and was drafted in the 2nd round in 1959 by the Oakland Raiders but did not report and returned to Kansas to finish his undergraduate degree and play out his senior season where he was a 2 time All Big 8 selection as a center and middle linebacker.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He was a Tri-Captain and played in 4 post season games including the College All-Star game with numerous All Americans.

title: Fred Hageman
text: Was drafted in the 7th round of the 1960 NFL Draft by the New York Giants and was immediately traded to Washington for cash and a high draft pick.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He was the "Tribe's" defensive leader and starting middle linebacker upon reporting to camp.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He was a runner-up for Rookie of the Year as a middle linebacker and played more minutes than any other player in the NFL in 1961.

title: Fred Hageman
text: After his first stellar season, he was moved to starting Center where he played at an elite level.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He was traded to the Chicago Bears in 1965, where he was injured in a pre-season game.

title: Fred Hageman
text: Although urged to return by many, Fred returned to Kansas and earned his master's degree in Education.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He went on to a very successful business career.

title: Fred Hageman
text: The "gentle giant" at a huge 6 foot 5 and 255 pounds of solid muscle with world class speed, Fred was named as Kansas University's "Center of the Century" and was named to its first team "All-Time KU Football Team" along with the likes of Gayle Sayers, John Hadl and other NFL greats.

title: Fred Hageman
text: Known as "Pappy" to many, he led KU's team, to a #2 Ranking and a Big 8 Championship in 1960.

title: Fred Hageman
text: Some believe the teams he led in 1959 and 1960, along with John Hadl, were the best in KU's history.

title: Fred Hageman
text: Fred was enshrined in the Batesville, Arkansas Area Sports Hall of Fame in 1992.

title: Fred Hageman
text: He was the first All-State Athlete at Batesville, H.S.

title: Robin Cole
text: Robin Cole, a former professional American football player, was born September 11, 1955 in Compton, California.

title: Robin Cole
text: He was the seventh of ten children born to Obediah and Georgia Mae Cole.

title: Robin Cole
text: He attended high school at Compton High, graduating in 1973.

title: Robin Cole
text: He furthered his education at the University of New Mexico where he became an All American and the first person to be a first round draft pick out of the University.

title: Robin Cole
text: He was drafted by the Pittsburgh Steelers, the 21st pick in the first round of the draft.

title: Robin Cole
text: At Pittsburgh, he was a part of the Steel Curtain defense, replacing Andy Russell as right outside linebacker.

title: Robin Cole
text: He played linebacker and defensive end for twelve seasons for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Robin Cole
text: He played in two Super Bowls - Super Bowl XIII and Super Bowl XIV.

title: Robin Cole
text: Mr. Cole was in the starting lineup in Super Bowl XIV in 1980 and was elected to the Pro Bowl in 1984.

title: Robin Cole
text: He was runner up for MVP in Super Bowl XIV.

title: Robin Cole
text: He played one season, 1988, with the New York Jets.

title: LaRon Landry
text: LaRon Louis Landry (born October 14, 1984) is a former American football safety.

title: LaRon Landry
text: He played college football for Louisiana State University (LSU), and earned consensus All-American honors.

title: LaRon Landry
text: The Washington Redskins drafted him with the sixth overall pick in the 2007 NFL Draft.

title: LaRon Landry
text: He also played for the New York Jets and Indianapolis Colts.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: Marc Parenteau (born December 4, 1980 in Sherbrooke, Quebec) is a professional Canadian football offensive lineman who last played for the Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: He was drafted 36th overall by the Ottawa Renegades in the 2003 CFL Draft.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: He was signed by the Saskatchewan Roughriders to a contract on February 12, 2007 and played for five seasons before being released on February 10, 2012.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: He was soon after signed by the Toronto Argonauts on February 13, 2012.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: Parenteau would go on to win the 100th Grey Cup with the Argonauts.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: On September 9, 2013, Parenteau was traded to the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, along with a 3rd round draft pick in 2014, in exchange for running back Anthony Woodson and a fifth round draft pick in 2014.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: He retired after 9 years in the CFL in January 2014 after winning 2 Grey Cups (2007 & 2012) and he is the only offensive lineman to ever score a touchdown in a Grey Cup game (2010).

title: Marc Parenteau
text: Before his CFL career, Marc was an All-Star (All Big East) lineman with the Boston College Eagles from 1999-2003.

title: Marc Parenteau
text: He continues to be a real estate sales representative in the Ottawa, ON area.

title: Tom Draper
text: Thomas Edward Draper (nicknamed "Drapes" or in Finland "Toppi") (born November 20, 1966 in Outremont, Quebec) is a retired Canadian professional ice hockey goaltender.

title: Tom Draper
text: He was chosen in the eighth round, 165th overall,and the 8th pick by the Winnipeg Jets in the 1985 NHL Entry Draft.

title: Tom Draper
text: On February 28, 1991 the Jets traded Tom to the St. Louis Blues for future considerations.

title: Tom Draper
text: Which on May 24, 1991 turned out being for Jim Vesey and in the same contract he was traded back to the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Tom Draper
text: Then on June 22, 1991 the Buffalo Sabres acquired him from the Jets for the seventh round draft pick in the 1992 entry draft.

title: Tom Draper
text: On September 30, 1993 the Sabres traded him to the New York Islanders for a seventh round draft pick, Steve Plouffe in the 1994 entry draft.

title: Tom Draper
text: He then became a free agent and the Winnipeg Jets picked him up again on December 14, 1995.

title: Darius Hanks
text: Darius Hanks (born February 23, 1989) is a former American football wide receiver.

title: Darius Hanks
text: He played college football at the University of Alabama.

title: Darius Hanks
text: Despite being projected as a fifth round draft pick, he was signed by the Washington Redskins as an undrafted free agent in 2012.

title: Jeris White
text: Jeris Jerome White (born September 3, 1952) is a former professional American football cornerback in the National Football League (NFL) for nine seasons for the Miami Dolphins, Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and Washington Redskins.

title: Jeris White
text: He played football at Radford High School, Honolulu, Hawaii, and at the University of Hawaii.

title: Jeris White
text: He was drafted by Miami in the second round of the 1974 NFL Draft.

title: Jeris White
text: He is the first person from a Hawaii high and collegiate school to ever play in a Super Bowl.

title: Jeris White
text: White was a holdout when the Redskins opened the 1983 season, so Washington replaced him with its first-round draft pick Darrell Green.

title: 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology in the 1990 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Jackets posted an undefeated 11–0–1 record.

title: 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: For the season the Yellow Jackets offense scored 379 points while the defense allowed 186 points.

title: 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: Highlights from the season included a nationally televised win over #1 Virginia on the road and a defeat of archrival Georgia for the second consecutive year.

title: 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: Georgia Tech capped off the season by defeating Nebraska, 45–21, in the Florida Citrus Bowl.

title: 1990 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: Head coach Bobby Ross and the Yellow Jackets were awarded a share of the national championship, winning the UPI Poll title by one vote over Colorado, who won the AP Poll title.

title: 1964 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1964 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology during the 1964 college football season.

title: 1964 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by 20th-year head coach Bobby Dodd, and played their home games at Grant Field in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: 1964 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: They competed as independents for the first time since 1920, after dropping from the Southeastern Conference in 1963.

title: 1987 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1987 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology during the 1987 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1987 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by first-year head coach Bobby Ross, and played their home games at Grant Field in Atlanta, Georgia, the last season under that name before the stadium was renamed in honor of legendary Georgia Tech head coach Bobby Dodd.

title: 1987 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The team competed as members of the Atlantic Coast Conference, finishing in last and failing to a win a conference game.

title: 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology in the 2012 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by fifth year head coach Paul Johnson and played their home games at Bobby Dodd Stadium.

title: 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: They were members of the Coastal Division of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: They finished the season 7–7, 5–3 in ACC play to share the Coastal Division Championship with Miami and North Carolina.

title: 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: With Miami and North Carolina on post seasons bans, Georgia Tech represented the division in the ACC Championship Game where they were defeated by Florida State.

title: 2012 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: They were invited to the Sun Bowl where they defeated USC.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football
text: The Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represents the Georgia Institute of Technology in the sport of American football.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football
text: The Yellow Jackets team competes in the Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and the Coastal Division of the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC).

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football
text: Georgia Tech has fielded a football team since 1892 and has an all-time record of 700–471–43 (a .594 winning percentage).

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football
text: The Yellow Jackets play in Bobby Dodd Stadium at Historic Grant Field in Atlanta, Georgia, which has a capacity of 55,000.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football
text: The Yellow Jackets have won four Division I-A college football national championships and fifteen conference titles.

title: 1953 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1953 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology during the 1953 college football season.

title: 1953 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by ninth-year head coach Bobby Dodd and played their home games at Grant Field in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: 1953 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: They finished second in the Southeastern Conference to Alabama, who had upset then-No.

title: 1953 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: 5 Georgia Tech in Birmingham, giving the Yellow Jackets their first conference loss since 1950.

title: 1953 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were invited to the 1954 Sugar Bowl, where they defeated West Virginia, 42–19.

title: 1988 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1988 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology during the 1988 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1988 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by second-year head coach Bobby Ross, and played their home games at Bobby Dodd Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia, the first season under that name after it was renamed in honor of the legendary Georgia Tech head coach.

title: 1988 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The team competed as members of the Atlantic Coast Conference, finishing in last and failing to a win a conference game for the second consecutive season.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: The Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball team represents the Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets in NCAA Division I basketball.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: The team plays its home games in McCamish Pavilion on the school's Atlanta campus and is currently coached by Josh Pastner.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: Under the tenure of Bobby Cremins, Georgia Tech established itself as a national force in basketball.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: Cremins led his team to the first ACC tournament victory in school history in 1985 and in 1990 he took Georgia Tech to the school's first Final Four appearance ever.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: Cremins retired from Georgia Tech in 2000 with the school's best winning percentage as a head coach.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: The Yellow Jackets returned to the Final Four in 2004 under Paul Hewitt and lost in the national title game, losing to UConn.

title: Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets men's basketball
text: Overall, the team has won 1,318 games and lost 1,176 games, a .528 win percentage.

title: 1980 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1980 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology during the 1980 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1980 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by first-year head coach Bill Curry, and played their home games at Grant Field in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: 1980 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: Georgia Tech struggled mightily under Curry, finishing with one of the worst records in Georgia Tech history with 1 win, 9 losses, and 1 tie.

title: 1980 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: A major highlight was achieved, however, when the Yellow Jackets produced a 3–3 tie against the number one team in the country, the undefeated Notre Dame Fighting Irish.

title: 1959 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The 1959 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team represented the Georgia Institute of Technology during the 1959 college football season.

title: 1959 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: The Yellow Jackets were led by 15th-year head coach Bobby Dodd and played their home games at Grant Field in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: 1959 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: After winning their first four games of the season, three of which were victories over top ten opponents, Georgia Tech sat at #4 in the AP Poll.

title: 1959 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: Georgia Tech's season was derailed by several close losses, however, and they finished the regular season unranked with a 6–4 record.

title: 1959 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team
text: They were invited to the Gator Bowl, where they lost to Southwest Conference co-champion Arkansas.

title: Simon Coveney
text: Simon Anthony Coveney (born 16 June 1972) is an Irish Fine Gael politician who has served as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and Deputy Leader of Fine Gael since June 2017.

title: Simon Coveney
text: He has been a Teachta Dála (TD) since 1998, currently for the Cork South-Central constituency.

title: Simon Coveney
text: He previously served as Minister for Housing, Planning, Community and Local Government from 2016 to 2017, Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine from 2011 to 2016 and Minister for Defence from 2014 to 2016.

title: Simon Coveney
text: He served as Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the South constituency from 2004 to 2007.

title: Paddy O'Toole
text: Paddy J. O'Toole (born 15 January 1938) is a former Irish Fine Gael politician.

title: Paddy O'Toole
text: He was nominated by the Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave to the 13th Seanad Éireann in 1973.

title: Paddy O'Toole
text: He was first elected to Dáil Éireann on his second attempt at the 1977 general election as a Fine Gael Teachta Dála for Mayo East.

title: Paddy O'Toole
text: O'Toole was just one of a handful of new Fine Gael TDs in what has gone down in history as the biggest landslide election victory for Jack Lynch's Fianna Fáil party.

title: Fine Gael leadership election, 2017
text: The 2017 Fine Gael leadership election was triggered in May 2017, when Enda Kenny resigned as party leader.

title: Fine Gael leadership election, 2017
text: Voting began by members of Fine Gael and Young Fine Gael on 29 May 2017.

title: Fine Gael leadership election, 2017
text: On 2 June Leo Varadkar was announced as the victor, beating rival Simon Coveney 60% to 40%.

title: Fine Gael leadership election, 2017
text: With Fine Gael being the governing party at the time, this election effectively appointed a new Taoiseach for Ireland.

title: Enda Kenny
text: Enda Patrick Kenny (born 24 April 1951) is an Irish Fine Gael politician who served as Taoiseach from 2011 to 2017, Leader of Fine Gael from 2002 to 2017, Minister for Defence from May 2014 to July 2014 and 2016 to 2017, Leader of the Opposition from 2002 to 2011, Minister for Tourism and Trade from 1994 to 1997 and Minister of State for Youth Affairs from 1986 to 1987.

title: Enda Kenny
text: He has been a Teachta Dála (TD) since 1975, currently for the Mayo constituency.

title: Leo Varadkar
text: Leo Eric Varadkar ( ; Irish: "Leo de Varad" ;born 18 January 1979) is an Irish Fine Gael politician who has served as Taoiseach, Minister for Defence and Leader of Fine Gael since June 2017.

title: Leo Varadkar
text: He has been a Teachta Dála (TD) since 2007, currently for the Dublin West constituency.

title: Leo Varadkar
text: He previously served as Minister for Social Protection from 2016 to 2017, Minister for Health from 2014 to 2016 and Minister for Transport, Tourism and Sport from 2011 to 2014.

title: Charles Flanagan
text: Charles Matthew Flanagan (born 1 November 1956) is an Irish Fine Gael politician who has served as Minister for Justice and Equality since June 2017.

title: Charles Flanagan
text: He has been a Teachta Dála (TD) since 1987, currently for the Laois constituency.

title: Charles Flanagan
text: He previously served as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade from 2014 to 2017, Minister for Children and Youth Affairs from May 2014 to July 2014 and Chair of the Fine Gael Parliamentary Party from 2011 to 2014.

title: Liam Cosgrave
text: William Michael "Liam" Cosgrave (born 13 April 1920) is a former Irish Fine Gael politician who served as Taoiseach from 1973 to 1977 and the Leader of the Fine Gael Party from 1965 to 1977.

title: Liam Cosgrave
text: He served as Leader of the Opposition from 1965 to 1973, Minister for External Affairs from 1954 to 1957, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and Government Chief Whip from 1948 to 1951.

title: Liam Cosgrave
text: He was a Teachta Dála (TD) from 1943 to 1981.

title: John Bruton
text: John Gerard Bruton (born 18 May 1947) is a former Irish Fine Gael politician who served as Taoiseach from 1994 to 1997, European Union Ambassador to the United States from 2004 to 2009, Leader of Fine Gael from 1990 to 2001, Leader of the Opposition from 1990 to 1994 and 1997 to 2001, Minister for the Public Service from January 1987 to March 1987, Minister for Finance from 1981 to 1982 and 1986 to 1987, Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism from 1983 to 1986, Minister for Industry and Energy from 1982 to 1983, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry and Commerce from 1973 to 1977.

title: John Bruton
text: He served as a Teachta Dála (TD) from 1969 to 2004.

title: Frances Fitzgerald (politician)
text: Frances Mary Fitzgerald (born 1 August 1950) is an Irish Fine Gael politician who has served as Tánaiste since May 2016 and Minister for Enterprise and Innovation since June 2017.

title: Frances Fitzgerald (politician)
text: She has been a Teachta Dála (TD) since 2011 and previously between 1992 and 2002, currently for the Dublin Mid-West constituency.

title: Frances Fitzgerald (politician)
text: She previously served as Minister for Justice and Equality from 2014 to 2016, Minister for Children and Youth Affairs from 2011 to 2014, Leader of the Opposition in the Seanad and Leader of Fine Gael in the Seanad from 2007 to 2011.

title: Frances Fitzgerald (politician)
text: She was a Senator for the Labour Panel from 2007 to 2011.

title: James Reilly (Irish politician)
text: James Reilly (born 16 August 1955) is an Irish Fine Gael politician and medical doctor.

title: James Reilly (Irish politician)
text: Between the February 2016 general election and the 6 May 2016 formation of a new government, he was the Acting Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, having held that ministry since July 2014 in the previous government, and was also deputy leader of Fine Gael from 2010 to 2017.

title: James Reilly (Irish politician)
text: He was the Minister for Health from March 2011 to July 2014.

title: James Reilly (Irish politician)
text: Reilly was a Teachta Dála (TD) for the Dublin North constituency since the 2007 general election until he lost his seat in the 2016 general election.

title: James Reilly (Irish politician)
text: Reilly was nominated by Taoiseach Enda Kenny to Seanad Éireann in May 2016.

title: James Reilly (Irish politician)
text: James Reilly was re-appointed as deputy leader of Fine Gael on 4 July 2016.

title: Johnny Angel
text: Johnny Angel is a 1945 film noir directed by Edwin L. Marin and written by Frank Gruber and Steve Fisher from the novel "Mr. Angel Comes Aboard" by Charles Gordon Booth.

title: Johnny Angel
text: The movie stars George Raft, Claire Trevor and Signe Hasso, and features Hoagy Carmichael.

title: William D. Russell (director)
text: William D. Russell (April 30, 1908 - April, 1968) was an American film and television director.

title: William D. Russell (director)
text: Born in Indianapolis, Indiana on April 30, 1908, he began his Hollywood career with the 1945 film "Hollywood Victory Caravan".

title: William D. Russell (director)
text: His career in film ended with his last film, 1951's "Best of the Badmen".

title: William D. Russell (director)
text: In the early fifties he began directing for television with Screen Gems, and his many credits include episodes of "Father Knows Best" (he was with the show from 1954 to 1956), "Dennis the Menace", "Perry Mason", "Hazel", "Bewitched", "the Farmer's Daughter" and "Family Affair".

title: William D. Russell (director)
text: Russell was nominated for three Emmys, first for "You Are There" in 1953, second for "the Farmer's Daughter" in 1964, and later for "Family Affair" in 1967.

title: William D. Russell (director)
text: His directorial career ended shortly before his death in April 1968.

title: Johnny Lee Clary
text: Johnny Lee Clary (June 18, 1959 – October 21, 2014) was an American man who served as a Ku Klux Klan leader before he became a Pentecostal Christian, traveling around the world preaching the gospel and teaching against racism and hate groups such as the Ku Klux Klan, Neo Nazis, and the Aryan Nations.

title: Johnny Lee Clary
text: Clary was also known as professional wrestler Johnny Angel who had success in the 1980s in the National Wrestling Federation (NWF).

title: Claudia Drake
text: Claudia Drake (January 30, 1918 – October 19, 1997) was an American actress and singer.

title: Claudia Drake
text: She appeared in a number of B Movies in a mixture of leading and supporting roles.

title: Claudia Drake
text: She starred in the 1945 film noir "Detour".

title: Shelley Fabares
text: Michele Ann Marie Fabares ( ; born January 19, 1944) is an American actress and singer, known professionally as Shelley Fabares.

title: Shelley Fabares
text: She is best-known for her roles as Donna Reed's daughter Mary Stone on "The Donna Reed Show" (1958–1963), and as Hayden Fox's love interest (and eventual wife) Christine Armstrong on the sitcom "Coach" (1989–1997).

title: Shelley Fabares
text: She was Elvis Presley's co-star in three films.

title: Shelley Fabares
text: In 1962, her recording of "Johnny Angel" reached number one on the "Billboard" Hot 100 chart.

title: Johnny Angel (song)
text: "Johnny Angel" is a song written and composed by Lyn Duddy and Lee Pockriss.

title: Johnny Angel (song)
text: The song was originally recorded by both Laurie Loman and Georgia Lee, however these two versions were not successful.

title: Johnny Angel (song)
text: It first became a popular hit single in 1962 when covered by Shelley Fabares who took it to number one on the "Billboard" Hot 100 Chart.

title: Johnny Angel (song)
text: British singer Patti Lynn had a moderate hit with her cover of "Johnny Angel" the same year on the UK Singles Chart.

title: Johnny Angel (song)
text: The American pop music duo The Carpenters also covered "Johnny Angel" in 1973 as part of a medley of oldies on side two of their album "Now & Then".

title: Johnny Angel Wendell
text: Johnny Angel Wendell is an American writer, musician, and radio talk show host.

title: Johnny Angel Wendell
text: He is married and lives in Los Angeles with his two sons.

title: Johnny Angel Wendell
text: Once a resident of Massachusetts, he is now a Los Angeles Weekly columnist, Wendell is the host of KTLK-AM 1150's "Southern California Live with Johnny Wendell".

title: Johnny Angel Wendell
text: Wendell is also a regular on KFI-AM640.

title: A Kiss for Corliss
text: A Kiss for Corliss is a 1949 American comedy film directed by Richard Wallace and written by Howard Dimsdale.

title: A Kiss for Corliss
text: It stars Shirley Temple in her final starring role as well as her final film appearance.

title: A Kiss for Corliss
text: It is a sequel to the 1945 film "Kiss and Tell".

title: A Kiss for Corliss
text: "A Kiss for Corliss" was retitled "Almost a Bride" before release and this title appears in the title sequence.

title: A Kiss for Corliss
text: The film was released on November 25, 1949, by United Artists.

title: Cool from the Wire
text: Cool from the Wire is the major-label debut album from American hard rock band Dirty Looks.

title: Cool from the Wire
text: It was released in 1988 on Atlantic Records.

title: Cool from the Wire
text: It includes the song "Oh Ruby", that received airplay on rock stations.

title: Cool from the Wire
text: "It’s Not the Way You Rock" was used in the film Johnny Be Good, and appeared on its soundtrack.

title: Cool from the Wire
text: The album peaked #134 in "Billboard" 200.

title: Gösta Prüzelius
text: Karl Gösta Prüzelius (11 August 1922 – 15 May 2000) was a Swedish actor.

title: Gösta Prüzelius
text: His first film part was in the 1945 film Flickorna i Småland.

title: Gösta Prüzelius
text: He played in films as diverse as "Summer with Monika", "Space Invasion of Lapland", "Fanny and Alexander", and Ingmar Bergman's film version of "The Magic Flute" (1975).

title: Gösta Prüzelius
text: He also provided the Swedish voice for Bagheera in Disney's "The Jungle Book" (1967), and played the policeman Klöverhage in a number of the Åsa-Nisse films.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Lenelle Moïse (born 1980) is a poet, actress and playwright born in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Currently based in the United States, she performs at colleges throughout the country, presenting work about race, gender, class, immigration and sexuality.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Her spoken word CD "Madivinez" won the 2007 Patchwork Majority Radio Album Award for Best Solo Album.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Moïse was a member of the permanent ensemble cast in the Culture Project's premiere production of "Rebel Voices", a play by Rob Urbinati based on Howard Zinn and Anthony Arnove's book "Voices of a People's History of the United States."

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: In 2008, she developed a two-person vocal musical about art, infamy and race called "EXPATRIATE", also at the Culture Project, in which she co-starred with Karla Cheatham-Mosley.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: When she was a junior at Ithaca College, Lenelle co-wrote "Sexual Dependency", a feature film by Bolivian filmmaker Rodrigo Bellot who was a schoolmate at the time.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: The film went on to win the International Film Critics' Award at the Locarno International Film Festival in Switzerland.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Moïse also wrote and starred in Mara Alper's short experimental video "To Erzulie" which premiered at the Berlin Sommerfest der Literaturen in July 2002.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: She has completed her own experimental shorts "Blue Passersby Eyes" and "Atlantic Soul."

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Her homemade music video "Pied Piper" was an official selection of the International Museum of Women 2007 Online Film Festival.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Her essays and poems are published in a number of anthologies, most recently "Word Warriors: 35 Women Leaders of the Spoken Word Revolution" (Seal Press).

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: Her debut book "Haiti Glass" (City Lights Publishers, April 2014), part of the Sister Spit series, is a collection of verse and prose.

title: Lenelle Moïse
text: She experiments with collage as a form of meditative practice and nonlinear storytelling.

title: Jeffrey Stanley
text: Jeffrey Stanley (born September 3, 1967) is a playwright born in Roanoke, Virginia.

title: Jeffrey Stanley
text: He began writing in elementary school, and graduated from New York University Tisch School of the Arts Undergraduate Film Program and Graduate Dramatic Writing Program.

title: Jeffrey Stanley
text: He was also a guest at Yaddo, a Copeland Fellow at Amherst College, and a 2014-15 Amtrak Residency for Writers recipient.

title: Jeffrey Stanley
text: He was a 2011-12 PDC playwright-in-residence at Philadelphia's Plays and Players Theatre.

title: Aramazd Stepanian
text: Aramazd Stepanian (Armenian: Արամազդ Ստեփանեան , born October 11, 1951) is an Armenian actor, producer, director and playwright born in Abadan, Iran.

title: Aramazd Stepanian
text: He is the owner of the Luna Playhouse where he also serves as the artistic director and producer.

title: Aramazd Stepanian
text: He was also a former candidate for Los Angeles, California City Council.

title: DeObia Oparei
text: DeObia Oparei (born 1971), also credited as Dhobi Oparei and Deobia Operei, is an English actor and playwright born in London, known for his role as the Gunner in "" and as Thundarian in "Your Highness".

title: DeObia Oparei
text: His parents are of Nigerian ancestry.

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: Michael Wynne is an English playwright born in Birkenhead on 3 August 1972.

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: While reading for a Politics degree in London, he entered a competition for new young writers run by the Royal Court Theatre.

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: He won this with his first play "The Knocky" - an award-winning comedy, set on a Birkenhead council estate.

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: It was produced at the Royal Court in 1995 and subsequently performed at Liverpool's Everyman Theatre in 1997.

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: In 2010, Wynne won the Olivier Award for Best New Comedy for "The Priory".

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: In 2011, Wynne wrote the BBC Christmas show, "Lapland".

title: Michael Wynne (playwright)
text: A series was later announced, entitled "Being Eileen", again written by Wynne, which began to air on 4 February 2013.

title: Juan García Larrondo
text: Juan García Larrondo (born 1965) is a Spanish playwright born in El Puerto de Santa María, Cádiz Province.

title: Finn Iunker
text: Finn Iunker (born 27 March 1969) is a Norwegian playwright born in Arendal.

title: Finn Iunker
text: He lives in Oslo.

title: Sumie Tanaka
text: Sumie Tanaka ("田中澄江"; April 11, 1908—March 1, 2000) was a Japanese screenwriter and playwright born in Tokyo.

title: Sumie Tanaka
text: She was most well known for her long collaboration with film director Mikio Naruse and for writing screenplays for Japan's first major female director Kinuyo Tanaka.

title: Sumie Tanaka
text: Member of the Bungakuza theatre company, she was married to playwright and dramatist Chikao Tanaka.

title: Sumie Tanaka
text: The screenplays she wrote for Repast ("めし", Meshi; 1951), Home Sweet Home ("我が家は楽し ", Wa ga ya wa tanoshi; 1951), and Record of Youth ("少年期 ", Shonenki; 1951) won her the Blue Ribbon Award for Best Screenplay in 1951.

title: Bertha Runkle
text: Bertha Runkle (1879–1958) was an American novelist and playwright born in Berkeley Heights, New Jersey.

title: Bertha Runkle
text: From a literary family, she wrote five novels.

title: Bertha Runkle
text: Her first and best known, "The Helmet of Navarre", was made into a Broadway play.

title: James Roland MacLaren
text: James Roland MacLaren (1839–1912) was a British actor and playwright born on 10 June 1839 in Bonhill, Scotland to Archibald MacLaren and Anne McIntyre.

title: James Roland MacLaren
text: The family later moved to Liverpool, where James Roland MacLaren first took to the stage, appearing second to Barry Sullivan, the well known Victorian actor.

title: James Roland MacLaren
text: He subsequently went to Sunderland with Alfred Davis where he took over the New Royal Lyceum Theatre (now demolished).

title: James Roland MacLaren
text: It was here with MacLaren that the actor Sir Henry Irving made his first stage appearances before moving to London where he later became famous as the inspiration for Bram Stoker's Count Dracula.

title: James Roland MacLaren
text: For some thirty years MacLaren was renowned in the north east of England as an actor in stock companies, a noted recitalist and a playwright.

title: James Roland MacLaren
text: He usually played heavy villain roles and was popular amongst the audience as the 'traitor'.

title: George D. Buffett
text: George Duval Buffett (November 19, 1928 – October 13, 2012) was an American politician who was a Republican member of the New Mexico House of Representatives from 1979 to 2002.

title: George D. Buffett
text: Buffett attended University of New Mexico and was a businessman.

title: George D. Buffett
text: He died in 2012.

title: George D. Buffett
text: He was an arch-conservative state representative, owner of Buffett's Candy and cousin of Warren Buffett.

title: TaeguTec
text: TaeguTec Ltd. (Korean: 대구텍), formerly known as Korea Tungsten Company, is a multinational corporation headquartered in Daegu, Korea.

title: TaeguTec
text: It is the largest cutting tools manufacturer in the Far East, also Korea's largest manufacturer of tungsten cutting tools and hard metal tools with the only integrated tungsten production plant in the world.

title: TaeguTec
text: TaeguTec group has 26 overseas subsidiaries and over 130 distributors and 30 agents in 50 countries across Europe, Asia, Australia, and the American countries.

title: TaeguTec
text: Considered as the world's oldest manufacturer of tungsten and related products, the group has earned reputation for its excellent global marketing and large production capacity worldwide.

title: TaeguTec
text: In addition to the initial 80 per cent stake purchased in 2006, Warren Buffett paid additional 2 billion dollars for the remaining stake in IMC, of which TaeguTec was a part.

title: TaeguTec
text: Through this acquisition, TaeguTec became Berkshire Hathaway's first and only wholly owned subsidiary in Korea.

title: TaeguTec
text: On October 25, 2007, Buffett flew to Daegu to tour TaeguTec and to meet with the management.

title: TaeguTec
text: On March 21, 2011, Warren Buffett re-visited the firm to attend TaeguTec Plant 2 inauguration ceremony and later met with Korean President Lee Myung-bak.

title: Owner earnings
text: Owner earnings is a valuation method detailed by Warren Buffett in 1986.

title: Owner earnings
text: He stated that the value of a company is simply the total of the net cash flows (owner earnings) expected to occur over the life of the business, minus any reinvestment of earnings.

title: Susan Buffett
text: Susan Thompson Buffett (June 15, 1932 – July 29, 2004), the first wife of investor Warren Buffett, was active in civil rights, abortion rights and population control causes.

title: Susan Buffett
text: She was a director of Berkshire Hathaway, owning 2.2 percent (worth US$3 billion in 2004) of the company at the time of her death.

title: Susan Buffett
text: She was the 153rd richest person in the world.

title: Susan Buffett
text: She was president of the Buffett Foundation, which has contributed millions of dollars to educational groups, medical research, population-control groups and other charities.

title: Susan Alice Buffett
text: Susan Alice Buffett (born July 30, 1953) is the daughter of Warren Buffett.

title: Susan Alice Buffett
text: She is also an American philanthropist, her charitable work has focused largely on the Sherwood Foundation, formerly known as the Susan A. Buffett Foundation, an organization in Omaha that provides grants in public education, human services and social justice in the interest of promoting the welfare of children from lower-income families.

title: Susan Alice Buffett
text: She is also on the boards of the Buffett Foundation and Girls, Inc. According to a 2010 interview with her brother Howard Graham Buffett, Buffett's philanthropic focus has consistently remained on children, education and family issues, but she has also committed to other causes, including Debt, AIDS, Trade, Africa, a non-governmental organization dedicated to various improvements in Africa.

title: The Warren Buffett Way
text: The Warren Buffett Way, a book by author Robert Hagstrom, outlines the principles of value investing practiced by successful investor Warren Buffett.

title: Buffett Foundation
text: The Buffett Foundation is a charitable organization formed by Omaha, Nebraska investor and industrialist Warren Buffett as a vehicle to manage his charitable giving.

title: Buffett Foundation
text: It was renamed Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation in honor of his wife Susan Buffett when she died in 2004.

title: Peter Buffett
text: Peter Andrew Buffett (born May 4, 1958) is an American musician, composer, author and philanthropist.

title: Peter Buffett
text: With an acclaimed career that spans more than 30 years, Peter is an Emmy Award winner, New York Times best-selling author and co-chair of the NoVo Foundation.

title: Peter Buffett
text: He is the youngest son of billionaire investor Warren Buffett.

title: Howard Graham Buffett
text: Howard Graham Buffett (born December 16, 1954) is an American businessman, former politician, philanthropist, photographer, farmer, and conservationist.

title: Howard Graham Buffett
text: He is the middle child of billionaire investor Warren Buffett.

title: Howard Graham Buffett
text: He is named after Howard Buffett, his grandfather, and Benjamin Graham, Warren Buffett's favorite professor.

title: Howard Warren Buffett
text: Howard Warren Buffett (born October 14, 1983) is an American public relations professor, political advisor, and philanthropist.

title: Howard Warren Buffett
text: He serves as faculty member at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs and was previously the executive director of the Howard G. Buffett Foundation, a private philanthropic foundation that funds initiatives aimed at improving the standard of living and quality of life for the world’s most impoverished and marginalized populations.

title: Howard Warren Buffett
text: He previously led agriculture-based economic stabilization and redevelopment programs in Iraq and Afghanistan while at the United States Department of Defense, and as a policy advisor in the Executive Office of the President of the United States under President Barack Obama.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy Final
text: The 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy (officially known as Wills International Cup, also known as Mini World Cup) was a One Day International (ODI) cricket tournament held in Bangladesh.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy Final
text: It was the first tournament apart from the World Cups to involve all Test playing nations.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy Final
text: The winners of the Knock-out stage—India, South Africa, Sri Lanka and Indies—reached the semi-finals.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy Final
text: South Africa made their way to the final by defeating Sri Lanka in the first semi-final by 92 runs; the match was reduced to 39 overs per innings due to rain.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy Final
text: In the second semi-final, West Indies defeated India by six wickets, and qualified for the final.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: These were the nine squads (all Test nations) picked to take part in the 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy, the first installment of the Champions Trophy cricket tournament.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: The tournament was held in Bangladesh from 24 October to 2 November 1998.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: Teams could name a preliminary squad of 30, but only 14-man squads were permitted for the actual tournament, one month before the start of the tournament.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: In the knockout tournament, New Zealand and Zimbabwe were the only teams to play a pre-quarter final match.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: New Zealand won the match and qualified for the quarter-final where they faced Sri Lanka.

title: 1998 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: South Africa won the inaugural edition of the ICC KnockOut Trophy by defeating West Indies in the final by four wickets.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: These were the eleven squads (all Test nations and two ODI nations) picked to take part in the 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy, the second installment of the Champions Trophy cricket tournament.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: The tournament was held in Kenya from 3 to 15 October 2000.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: In the preliminary quarter finals, two ODI full-status teams Kenya and Zimbabwe played with India and Sri Lanka respectively, and India and Sri Lanka won their matches convincingly.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: In third preliminary quarter final, England beat Bangladesh to secure his position in Knockout Tournament.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy squads
text: New Zealand won the second edition of the ICC KnockOut Trophy by defeating India in the final by four wickets, which was their first ICC event to be won.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: Guy Philip Randall-Johnson (born 8 December 1959) is a former English cricketer and umpire from Crediton, Devon.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: Randall-Johnson initially played Minor counties cricket for Devon between 1987 and 1991.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: In 1993, Randall-Johnson first stood as an umpire in a Minor Counties Championship match between Dorset and Wales Minor Counties.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: Two years later he stood in his first MCCA Knockout Trophy match, played between Cornwall and Devon.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: He stood in his first List A match in the 1999 NatWest Trophy played between the Somerset Cricket Board and Bedfordshire.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: Between 1999 and 2003 he stood in 7 List A matches, the last of which he stood was between Dorset and Buckinghamshire in the 1st round of the 2004 Cheltenham & Gloucester Trophy which was held in 2003.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: Randall-Johnson stood as an umpire in Minor counties cricket until 2008, by which time he had stood in 54 Minor Counties Championship matches and 25 MCCA Knockout Trophy matches.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: He made headlines in 2006 for walking out of a Minor Counties Championship match after being on the receiving end of abuse from Berkshire players after he gave Berkshire captain Julian Wood out LBW.

title: Guy Randall-Johnson
text: After not getting an apology from the players, he walked out of the game, with others having to deputise for him.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy
text: The 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy was a One Day International cricket tournament held in Kenya (which helped to booster cricket in Kenya).

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy
text: New Zealand were crowned champions and cashed the winner's cheque of US$250 000.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy
text: It was their first win in a major ICC tournament.

title: 2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy
text: Zaheer Khan, Yuvraj Singh and Marlon Samuels made their ODI debuts during the competition.

title: Sam Davies (cricketer)
text: Davies made his 2nd XI debut for Glamorgan vs MCC young cricketers and has to date made over 25 appearances for the county.

title: Sam Davies (cricketer)
text: He later made his Test Match debut for Wales Minor Counties against Lincolnshire in the 2009 MCCA Knockout Trophy.

title: Sam Davies (cricketer)
text: His Minor Counties Championship debut came in the same season against Shropshire.

title: Sam Davies (cricketer)
text: To date he has made fourteen Minor Counties Championship and ten MCCA Knockout Trophy appearances.

title: Sam Davies (cricketer)
text: While studying for a degree in Sports Coaching at the University of Wales Institute, Cardiff, Davies made his debut in first-class cricket for Cardiff MCCU against Somerset in 2012 at Taunton Vale Sports Club Ground, making scores of 42 and 14.

title: Lindum Sports Club Ground
text: Lindum Sports Club Ground is a cricket ground in Lincoln, Lincolnshire.

title: Lindum Sports Club Ground
text: The first recorded match on the ground was in 1861, when Lincolnshire played an All-England Eleven.

title: Lindum Sports Club Ground
text: Lincolnshire played their first Minor Counties Championship match at the ground in 1907 against Staffordshire.

title: Lindum Sports Club Ground
text: Lincolnshire used the ground during a number of periods during the 21st century, playing their final Minor Counties Championship match at the ground in 2000 against Cumberland.

title: Lindum Sports Club Ground
text: The first MCCA Knockout Trophy watch played the ground saw Lincolnshire play Bedfordshire in 1996.

title: Lindum Sports Club Ground
text: From 1996 to 2007, the ground held 4 MCCA Knockout Trophy matches, with the final match played on the ground to date against Lincolnshire and Staffordshire.

title: Sridharan Sharath
text: Sridharan Sharath (born 31 October 1972, in Madras, Tamil Nadu) is a former Indian cricketer who played first class cricket for the Tamil Nadu cricket team.

title: Sridharan Sharath
text: A left-handed batsman, in 134 first class matches he made 8390 runs at 51.47 with 27 hundreds, making him one of the most prolific batsman in Indian domestic cricket history.

title: Sridharan Sharath
text: Although he never got to represent his country at Test or ODI cricket, he did get to play for India A on numerous occasions.

title: Sridharan Sharath
text: He is the only Tamil Nadu player to have played 100 Ranji Trophy games.

title: Digswell Park
text: Digswell Park is a cricket ground in Welwyn Garden City, Hertfordshire.

title: Digswell Park
text: The first recorded match on the ground was in 1866 between The Node and Southgate.

title: Digswell Park
text: In 2000, the ground hosted its only Minor Counties Championship match to date, which was between Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire.

title: Digswell Park
text: In 2003, the ground hosted 2 MCCA Knockout Trophy matches.

title: Digswell Park
text: Hertfordshire resumed their usage of Digswell Park and have to date played 4 further MCCA Knockout Trophy matches on the ground.

title: Peter Kingston-Davey
text: Peter William Kingston-Davey (22 October 1940) is a former English cricket umpire from Tiverton, Devon.

title: Peter Kingston-Davey
text: In 1995, Kingston-Davey first stood as an umpire in a Minor Counties Championship match between Dorset and Wales Minor Counties.

title: Peter Kingston-Davey
text: Two years later he stood in his first MCCA Knockout Trophy match, played between Dorset and Wales Minor Counties.

title: Peter Kingston-Davey
text: He stood in his first List A match in the 1999 NatWest Trophy played between Devon and Berkshire.

title: Peter Kingston-Davey
text: Between 1999 and 2003 he stood in 5 List A matches, the last of which he stood in was between Devon and Suffolk in the 1st round of the 2004 Cheltenham & Gloucester Trophy which was held in 2003.

title: Peter Kingston-Davey
text: Peter-Kingston stood as an umpire in Minor counties cricket until 2006, by which time he had stood in 39 Minor Counties Championship matches and 15 MCCA Knockout Trophy matches.

title: 514th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 514th Flight Test Squadron (514 FLTS) is a United States Air Force squadron.

title: 514th Flight Test Squadron
text: It is assigned to the Ogden Air Logistics Center (OO-ALC), Air Force Materiel Command, stationed at Hill Air Force Base, Utah.

title: 10th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 10th Flight Test Squadron is part of the 413th Flight Test Group of Air Force Materiel Command based at Tinker Air Force Base, Oklahoma.

title: 10th Flight Test Squadron
text: It performs acceptance testing on refurbished Rockwell B-1 Lancer, Boeing B-52 Stratofortress, Boeing E-3 Sentry, and Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker aircraft before they are returned to their units.

title: 413th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 413th Flight Test Squadron is part of the 96th Test Wing and is based at Duke Field, Eglin Air Force Base, Florida.

title: 413th Flight Test Squadron
text: It performs flight testing on C-130 Hercules, CV-22 Osprey, MH-53 Pave Low, UH-1 Iroquois, and HH-60 Pave Hawk aircraft.

title: 370th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 370th Flight Test Squadron is a United States Air Force unit assigned to the 413th Flight Test Group, stationed at Edwards Air Force Base, California.

title: 445th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 445th Flight Test Squadron (445 FTS) is a United States Air Force squadron.

title: 445th Flight Test Squadron
text: It was last assigned to the 412th Operations Group, Air Force Materiel Command, stationed at Edwards Air Force Base, California.

title: 339th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 339th Flight Test Squadron is a United States Air Force unit based at Robins Air Force Base, Georgia.

title: 339th Flight Test Squadron
text: It is part of the Warner Robins Air Logistics Center, with a mission to certify aircraft as worthy to return to service.

title: 339th Flight Test Squadron
text: The squadron is responsible for conducting flight tests on the Lockheed C-130 Hercules, the Lockheed C-5 Galaxy and McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle after program depot maintenance is completed.

title: 419th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 419th Flight Test Squadron is a United States Air Force squadron.

title: 419th Flight Test Squadron
text: It is assigned to the 412th Operations Group, Air Force Materiel Command, stationed at Edwards Air Force Base, California.

title: 417th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 417th Flight Test Squadron is an inactive United States Air Force squadron.

title: 417th Flight Test Squadron
text: It was last assigned to the 412th Operations Group at Edwards Air Force Base, California, where it was inactivated on 14 February 2012.

title: 417th Flight Test Squadron
text: The squadron was first activated in 1989 as the 6517th Test Squadron and conducted flight testing of the McDonnell Douglas C-17 Globemaster III until it was inactivated in 1995 as the 417th Test Squadron.

title: 417th Flight Test Squadron
text: It was reactivated in 2006 and performed ground and flight testing on the Boeing YAL-1A until 2012.

title: 415th Flight Test Flight
text: The 415th Flight Test Flight is a United States Air Force reserve squadron.

title: 415th Flight Test Flight
text: It is assigned to the 413th Flight Test Group of Air Force Reserve Command, stationed at Randolph Field, Joint Base San Antonio, Texas.

title: 486th Flight Test Squadron
text: The 486th Flight Test Squadron is a secretive unit, with a somewhat misleading designation, assigned to Eglin Air Force Base, Florida, and which is associated with United States Department of State Foreign Emergency Support Team activities.

title: 486th Flight Test Squadron
text: The squadron motto is ""Non semper ea sunt quae videntur"" which translates as "Not always what they seem".

title: 486th Flight Test Squadron
text: It was apparently assigned to the 227th Special Operations Flight, later redesignated the 150th Special Operations Squadron, McGuire Air Force Base, New Jersey, but is currently assigned to the 46th Test Wing at Eglin, and operates a pair of Boeing C-32B or Boeing 757-23A aircraft, on stand-by alert for special operations and intelligence missions world-wide.

title: 486th Flight Test Squadron
text: Official documents make it clear that operations fall under the aegis of Air Force Special Operations Command.

title: Keyed Up
text: Keyed Up is the fifteenth studio album by country music star Ronnie Milsap, released in 1983.

title: Keyed Up
text: It featured the No. 5 country chart hit "Stranger in My House", plus the No. 1 country hits "Don't You Know How Much I Love You" and "Show Her."

title: Country Music Star No. 1
text: Country Music Star No. 1 contains recordings of a prestardom Glen Campbell, which were made around 1960–1961.

title: Country Music Star No. 1
text: This album, just like the other Starday album Country Soul, was released after Campbell rose to international fame with hits including "Gentle on My Mind", "By the Time I Get to Phoenix" and "Wichita Lineman".

title: Country Music Star No. 1
text: Campbell sued against these releases but eventually settled with Starday.

title: Stranger in the House (song)
text: "Stranger in the House" is a song composed by Elvis Costello.

title: Stranger in the House (song)
text: Costello recorded the song as a duet with country music star George Jones in the summer of 1978 for Jones' 1979 album "My Very Special Guests".

title: Stranger in the House (song)
text: Costello also recorded a solo version recorded at a John Peel session on October 1978 which surfaced as a free 7" single with the first copies of his second album "This Year's Model" in the United Kingdom.

title: Stranger in the House (song)
text: According to Holly Jones-Warren's liner notes to the 2005 Legacy Records reissue of "My Very Special Guests", Costello wrote the song specifically with Jones in mind, with the new wave star stating, "George Jones was my guiding light whenever I wrote in the country idiom."

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: Gruhn Guitars is a musical instrument shop and place of interest located in Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: Vintage instruments comprise a large portion of its inventory, but it also features new instruments from factories and independent luthiers.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: It is a mecca for rock stars and well-heeled collectors.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: The business opened on January 2, 1970.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: It won a lot of new business and national attention after Visa featured it in 1992 in a TV commercial.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: George Gruhn is the world’s leading expert on vintage American guitars and related instruments, according to Walter Carter, historian and archivist for the Gibson Guitar Company.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: The shop was originally called GTR, which stood for George Gruhn, Tut Taylor and Randy Wood; a story has circulated that country music star Hank Williams, Jr. encouraged Gruhn to go into business.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: The store is located right by the stage door of the Ryman Auditorium, the home of the Grand Ole Opry.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: On December 31, 2006, Garrison Keillor, for his New Year's Show at Ryman Auditorium for PBS' "Great Performances" visited Gruhn Guitars with Vince Gill before the start of the show.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: Garrison Keiller's New Year's Eve Special Gill told a story about buying some of his guitars at Gruhn's.

title: Gruhn Guitars
text: "Gruhn's customer's have included the likes of Duane Allman, Mark Knopfler, Conan O'Brien, Robert Plant and Eric Clapton.

title: Randy Travis
text: Randy Bruce Traywick (born May 4, 1959), better known by his stage name, Randy Travis, is an American country music singer, songwriter, guitarist, and actor.

title: Randy Travis
text: Since 1985, he has recorded 20 studio albums and charted more than 50 singles on the "Billboard" Hot Country Songs charts, and 16 of these were number-one hits.

title: Randy Travis
text: Considered a pivotal figure in the history of country music, Travis broke through in the mid-1980s with the release of his album "Storms of Life", which sold more than four million copies.

title: Randy Travis
text: The album established him as a major force in the Neotraditional country movement.

title: Randy Travis
text: Travis followed up his successful debut with a string of platinum and multi-platinum albums.

title: Randy Travis
text: He is known for his distinctive baritone vocals, delivered in a traditional style that has made him a country music star since the 1980s.

title: Christy Sutherland
text: Christy Sutherland (born April 9, 1976) is a Nashville country music and praise/worship singer-songwriter.

title: Christy Sutherland
text: Signed to Epic Records in 2004, she charted the single "Freedom" on the Hot Country Songs charts.

title: Christy Sutherland
text: She is married to Kenneth Matthew Dudney, son of Country music star, Barbara Mandrell.

title: Christy Sutherland
