text: The two were wed on July 14, 2006 during a private ceremony at Mandrell's private home.

title: Christy Sutherland
text: Dudney currently works as tour and business manager for Sutherland.

title: This Is Me (Randy Travis album)
text: This Is Me is the ninth studio album by country music star Randy Travis, and was released on April 26, 1994 by Warner Bros..

title: This Is Me (Randy Travis album)
text: Producer Kyle Lehning, Travis, and A&R Martha Sharp considered more than 1,000 songs before settling on the final ten.

title: This Is Me (Randy Travis album)
text: The tracks "Before You Kill Us All", "Whisper My Name", "This Is Me", and "The Box" were all released as singles, peaking at #2, #1, #5, and #8, respectively, on the "Billboard" country music charts.

title: This Is Me (Randy Travis album)
text: "Small Y'all" was later recorded by George Jones on his 1998 album "It Don't Get Any Better Than This".

title: Based on a True Story...
text: Based on a True Story... is the eighth studio album by American country music artist Blake Shelton.

title: Based on a True Story...
text: It was released on March 26, 2013 via Warner Bros.

title: Based on a True Story...
text: Records and debuted at #3 with a career best for Shelton at nearly 200,000 sold.

title: Based on a True Story...
text: The album became the ninth best-selling album of 2013 in the US, earning Shelton a Platinum certification by the RIAA on September 30, 2013.

title: Based on a True Story...
text: In 2016, "Based on a True Story..." was certified double-platinum by the RIAA.

title: Old 8×10
text: Old 8×10 is the third studio album by country music star Randy Travis.

title: Old 8×10
text: It was released on July 12, 1988 by Warner Bros.

title: Old 8×10
text: Records Nashville.

title: Old 8×10
text: The album produced the singles "Honky Tonk Moon", "Deeper Than the Holler", "Is It Still Over", and "Promises".

title: Old 8×10
text: All of these except "Promises" reached Number One on the Hot Country Songs charts in the late 1980s.

title: Old 8×10
text: The German edition of the album (the first Randy Travis release in that country) contained the bonus track "Forever and Ever, Amen".

title: Old 8×10
text: In January 1990, Old 8×10 earned Travis three American Music Awards for 'Favorite Country Male Artist', 'Favorite Country Album', and 'Favorite Country Single' (Deeper Than the Holler).

title: My Eyes (Blake Shelton song)
text: "My Eyes" is a song recorded by American country music artist Blake Shelton featuring Gwen Sebastian.

title: My Eyes (Blake Shelton song)
text: It was released in April 2014 as the fifth single from his seventh studio album, "Based on a True Story...".

title: My Eyes (Blake Shelton song)
text: The song was written by Andrew Dorff, Tommy Lee James and Josh Osborne.

title: Andlang
text: In Norse mythology, Andlang (also Andlàngr or Öndlangr) is described as the second heavenly realm which stretches between the first, containing the halls of the gods, and the third, named Vídbláin.

title: Andlang
text: In all there are nine heavens according to Snorri.

title: Andlang
text: Andlang will serve as a shelter and dwelling place for the souls of the dead during and after the destruction of Ragnarök.

title: Takama-ga-hara
text: Takama-ga-hara (高天原 , the Plain of High Heaven ) is a place in Japanese mythology.

title: Takama-ga-hara
text: In Shinto, Takama-ga-hara (or Takama no Hara) is the dwelling place of the kami.

title: Takama-ga-hara
text: It is believed to be connected to the Earth by the bridge "Ama-no uki-hashi" (the "Floating Bridge of Heaven").

title: Oldest synagogues in the United Kingdom
text: The designation oldest synagogue in the United Kingdom requires careful definition.

title: Oldest synagogues in the United Kingdom
text: A number of synagogues that predate the expulsion of the Jews from England have been discovered by archaeologists or by historians in buildings that have been in use for other purposes for many centuries.

title: Oldest synagogues in the United Kingdom
text: A second set of synagogues post-dates the legal return of Jews to England in the seventeenth century.

title: Oldest synagogues in the United Kingdom
text: Some synagogues have been destroyed or demolished and rebuilt on the same site, so that, while the site or congregation may be very old, the building may be modern.

title: Oldest synagogues in the United Kingdom
text: Still other old synagogue buildings exist, but were sold by the congregation and are now used for other purposes, some as churches or mosques, others for everything from residences to school recital halls.

title: Oldest synagogues in the United Kingdom
text: And some very old synagogues have been in continuous use as synagogues for many centuries.

title: Château de Druyes
text: Château de Druyes is a medieval castle located in Druyes-les-Belles-Fontaines in Yonne, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté.

title: Château de Druyes
text: It was built in the 12th century by the Counts of Nevers, and remained in their possession until the 18th century.

title: Château de Druyes
text: It was as much a noble residence as it was a fortified castle.

title: Château de Druyes
text: It was a frequented dwelling place of Peter II of Courtenay, the Emperor of Constantinople in the 13th century, and his daughter Matilda, Countess of Nevers, Auxerre and Tonnerre.

title: Vídbláin
text: In Norse mythology, Víðbláinn is the third heaven in the cosmology of Snorri's "Gylfaginning", located above Andlang and Asgard.

title: Vídbláin
text: It will serve as a shelter and dwelling place for the souls of the dead during and after the destruction of Ragnarök.

title: Inquiline
text: In zoology, an inquiline (from Latin "inquilinus", "lodger" or "tenant") is an animal that lives commensally in the nest, burrow, or dwelling place of an animal of another species.

title: Inquiline
text: For example, some organisms such as insects may live in the homes of gophers and feed on debris, fungi, roots, etc.

title: Inquiline
text: The most widely distributed types of inquiline are those found in association with the nests of social insects, especially ants and termites – a single colony may support dozens of different inquiline species.

title: Inquiline
text: The distinctions between parasites, social parasites, and inquilines are subtle, and many species may fulfill the criteria for more than one of these, as inquilines do exhibit many of the same characteristics as parasites.

title: Inquiline
text: However, parasites are specifically "not" inquilines, because by definition they have a deleterious effect on the host species, while inquilines do not.

title: Heaven in Judaism
text: Shamayim (שָׁמַיִם), the Hebrew word for "heaven" (literally "heavens", plural), denotes one component of the three-part cosmos, the other elements being "erets" (the earth) and "sheol" (the underworld).

title: Heaven in Judaism
text: "Shamayim" is the dwelling place of God and other heavenly beings, "erets" is the home of the living, and "sheol" is the realm of the dead, including, in post-Hebrew Bible literature (including the Christian New Testament), the abode of the righteous dead.

title: List of oldest synagogues
text: The designation oldest synagogue in the world requires careful definition.

title: List of oldest synagogues
text: Many very old synagogues have been discovered in archaeological digs.

title: List of oldest synagogues
text: Some synagogues have been destroyed and rebuilt several times on the same site, so, while the site or congregation may be ancient, the building may be modern.

title: List of oldest synagogues
text: Still other very old synagogue buildings exist, but have been used for many centuries as churches, mosques, or for other purposes.

title: List of oldest synagogues
text: And some very old synagogues have been in continuous use as synagogues for many centuries.

title: Flaming Feather
text: Flaming Feather is a 1952 Technicolor Western film directed by Ray Enright and starring Sterling Hayden.

title: Flaming Feather
text: The film was shot on location around Oak Creek Canyon near Sedona, AZ, and at the Montezuma Castle National Monument near Sedona.

title: Flaming Feather
text: The local Yavapai Indians, who were employed as extras on the production, refused to enter the cliff-dwellings because they represented the "dwelling place of the dead."

title: Flaming Feather
text: Consequently, production was delayed while a band of Navajos was brought in from a reservation 137 miles away to replace them.

title: Tabernacle
text: The Tabernacle (Hebrew: מִשְׁכַּן‎ ‎ , "mishkan", "residence" or "dwelling place"), according to the Hebrew Bible, was the portable earthly dwelling place of God amongst the children of Israel from the time of the Exodus from Egypt through the conquering of the land of Canaan.

title: Tabernacle
text: Built of woven layers of curtains along with 48 boards clad with polished gold standing like vertical blinds held in place by 5 bars per side with the middle bar shooting through from end to end and furnished with items made from the gold, silver, brass, furs, jewels, and other valuable materials taken out of Egypt at God's orders, and according to specifications revealed by Yahweh (God) to Moses at Mount Sinai, it was transported by the Israelites on their journey through the wilderness and their conquest of the Promised Land.

title: Tabernacle
text: Solomon's Temple in Jerusalem superseded it as the dwelling-place of God some 300 years later.

title: Christopher Mitchell (actor)
text: Christopher Mitchell (21 May 1947 – 22 February 2001) was a British actor most notable for his role in the BBC sitcom "It Ain't Half Hot Mum" as Gunner Nigel 'Parky' Parkin.

title: Christopher Mitchell (actor)
text: His film credits include "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" (1967), "This, That and the Other" (1969), "The Sex Thief" (1973) and "What's Up Superdoc!

title: Roy Holder
text: Roy Holder (born 15 June 1946) is an English television actor who has appeared in various programmes including "Ace of Wands", "Z-Cars", "Spearhead", the "Doctor Who" serial "The Caves of Androzani" and "Sorry!

title: Roy Holder
text: " His first notable appearance on the screen was in the 1961 film "Whistle Down the Wind", and he then appeared in "The Taming of the Shrew" (1967), "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" (1967), "Romeo and Juliet" (1968), "The Virgin Soldiers" (1969), "Loot" (1970), "Psychomania" (1973), "The Land That Time Forgot" (1975), "Trial by Combat" (1976) and "Jesus of Nazareth" (1977).

title: Roy Holder
text: More recently, Roy played the part of Mr Hill in "Pride & Prejudice" (2005), and Gaffer Tom in "Robin Hood" (2010).

title: The Wheels on the Bus
text: "The Wheels on the Bus" is an American folk song dating no later than 1939 written by Verna Hills.

title: The Wheels on the Bus
text: It is a popular children's song in the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, and Canada, and is often sung by children on bus trips to keep themselves amused.

title: The Wheels on the Bus
text: It has a very repetitive rhythm, making the song easy for a large number of people to sing, in a manner similar to the song "99 Bottles of Beer".

title: The Wheels on the Bus
text: It is based on fellow traditional British song "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush".

title: The Wheels on the Bus
text: The song is also sometimes sung to the tune of "Buffalo Gals", as in the version done by Raffi.

title: Clive Donner
text: Clive Stanley Donner (21 January 1926 – 6 September 2010) was a British film director who was a defining part of the British New Wave, directing films such as "The Caretaker", "Nothing But the Best", "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" and "What's New Pussycat?

title: Clive Donner
text: He also directed television movies and commercials through the mid-1990s.

title: Michael Finnegan (song)
text: "Michael Finnegan" (variant spellings include "Michael Finnagen" and "Michael Vinnegan") is an example of an unboundedly long song, which can continue with numerous variations until the singer decides (or is forced) to stop.

title: Michael Finnegan (song)
text: Like most other perpetual songs, this song tends to be sung by schoolchildren.

title: Michael Finnegan (song)
text: It is a popular song often sung around a campfire or during scouting events.

title: Michael Finnegan (song)
text: The origin of the words and music is unknown, but the tune bears similarity to Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush.

title: Michael Finnegan (song)
text: The earliest documented reference is "The Hackney Scout Song Book" (Stacy & Son Ltd, 1921).

title: Michael Finnegan (song)
text: It also appears in "The Oxford song book, vol.2, collected and arranged by Thomas Wood" (Oxford University Press, 1927).

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (film)
text: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush is a 1967 British film made based on the novel of the same name by Hunter Davies.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (film)
text: It was listed to compete at the 1968 Cannes Film Festival, but the festival was cancelled due to the events of May 1968 in France.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (disambiguation)
text: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (disambiguation)

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (Traffic song)
text: "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" is a single by Traffic.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (Traffic song)
text: It is the title song to the film "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush", and features all four members of Traffic singing a joint lead, though the bridge and parts of the chorus have Steve Winwood singing unaccompanied.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (Traffic song)
text: The single uses an edited version of the song, with the intro removed.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (Traffic song)
text: When released in late 1967, the single cracked the UK Top 10.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (Traffic song)
text: Footage of the band acting out the song was commissioned by The Beatles for possible inclusion in the film "Magical Mystery Tour" but was not used in the final edit.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (Traffic song)
text: It is now included in the special features of the 2012 DVD/Blu-ray edition of the film.

title: Traffic (band)
text: Traffic were an English rock band, formed in Birmingham.

title: Traffic (band)
text: The group was formed in April 1967 by Steve Winwood, Jim Capaldi, Chris Wood and Dave Mason.

title: Traffic (band)
text: They began as a psychedelic rock group and diversified their sound through the use of instruments such as keyboards like the Mellotron and harpsichord, sitar, and various reed instruments, and by incorporating jazz and improvisational techniques in their music.

title: Traffic (band)
text: Their first three singles were "Paper Sun", "Hole in My Shoe", and "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush".

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush
text: "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" (also titled "Mulberry Bush" or "This is the Way") is an English language nursery rhyme and singing game.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush
text: It has a Roud Folk Song Index number of 7882.

title: Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush
text: The same tune is also used for "Lazy Mary, Will You Get Up" and a variant is used for The Wheels on the Bus.

title: Thrill of a Lifetime (film)
text: Thrill of a Lifetime is a 1937 American comedy film directed by George Archainbaud and written by Seena Owen, Grant Garett and Paul Girard Smith.

title: Thrill of a Lifetime (film)
text: The film stars James V. Kern, Charles Adler, George Kelly, Billy Mann -- at the time a musical-comedy act called the Yacht Club Boys -- along with Judy Canova, Ben Blue and Eleanore Whitney.

title: Campus Confessions
text: Campus Confessions is a 1938 American film directed by George Archainbaud, featuring Betty Grable in her first starring role, and American basketball player Hank Luisetti in his only film appearance.

title: Flying with Music
text: Flying with Music is a 1942 American musical film directed by George Archainbaud and written by Louis S. Kaye and M. Coates Webster.

title: Flying with Music
text: The film stars Marjorie Woodworth, George Givot, William Marshall, Edward Gargan, Jerry Bergen and Norma Varden.

title: Flying with Music
text: The film was released on May 22, 1942, by United Artists.

title: Criminal Lawyer
text: Criminal Lawyer is a 1937 American drama film directed by Christy Cabanne from a screenplay by G. V. Atwater and Thomas Lennon, based on a story by Louis Stevens.

title: Criminal Lawyer
text: The film stars Lee Tracy, Margot Grahame and Eduardo Cianelli.

title: Criminal Lawyer
text: RKO produced the film and premiered it on January 26, 1937 in New York City, with a national release a few days later on January 29.

title: Criminal Lawyer
text: It was the second time Stevens' story had been used for a film, the first being 1932's State's Attorney, starring John Barrymore and Helen Twelvetrees, directed by George Archainbaud, and also produced and released by RKO.

title: The Millerson Case
text: The Millerson Case is a 1947 drama directed by George Archainbaud, starring Warner Baxter, Nancy Saunders and Clem Bevans.

title: The Millerson Case
text: In the 8th film of Columbia's "Crime Doctor" series, Dr. Robert Ordway (Warner Baxter) is vacationing in the Blue Ridge Mountains district of West Virginia when a Typhoid fever epidemic breaks out.

title: The Millerson Case
text: Three deaths occur with the first two being typhoid-caused but the death of the third person is from poisoning.

title: Handcuffs or Kisses
text: Handcuffs or Kisses is a 1921 American silent drama film directed by George Archainbaud and starring Elaine Hammerstein, Julia Swayne Gordon, and Dorothy Chappell.

title: Handcuffs or Kisses
text: It was future Hollywood star Ronald Colman's first film in America.

title: Handcuffs or Kisses
text: This is presumed to be a lost film.

title: Hoppy Serves a Writ
text: Hoppy Serves a Writ is a 1943 Western film directed by George Archainbaud and starring William Boyd as Hopalong Cassidy.

title: Hoppy Serves a Writ
text: The supporting cast features Andy Clyde, Victor Jory and George Reeves.

title: Hoppy Serves a Writ
text: The film remains noteworthy today as one of the earliest performances (his 3rd) of unshaven newcomer Robert Mitchum, who made an impression upon the studio by generating a surprising fan mail response exactly as Clark Gable had after playing an extremely similar unshaven role in "The Painted Desert", a Western starring William Boyd produced a dozen years earlier.

title: Arthur Roberts (editor)
text: Arthur Roberts July 17, 1890 – February 5, 1961), also known as Arthur E. Roberts, was an American film editor who edited over 100 films during his almost 30 year career.

title: Arthur Roberts (editor)
text: He began ending towards the end of the silent era of the film industry, his first film being 1927's "The College Hero", directed by Walter Lang.

title: Arthur Roberts (editor)
text: His last film was Republic's "Lay That Rifle Down" in 1955, after which he spent a brief period as the editor for the television series, "Lassie", before retiring in 1956.

title: Arthur Roberts (editor)
text: During his career he would work with many famous directors, including Frank Capra (on several films, including "The Donovan Affair"), Lowell Sherman (on "The Royal Bed"), William Seiter (on several films, including "Way Back Home"), Edward Cline (on "Cracked Nuts"), George Cukor ("A Bill of Divorcement"), Dorothy Arzner (the first female member of the DGA, on "Christopher Strong"), Anthony Mann ("Strangers in the Night"), George Archainbaud ("Girls of the Big House"), Fritz Lang ("House by the River"),

title: Alias French Gertie
text: Alias French Gertie is an American Pre-Code crime film directed by George Archainbaud, with a screenplay by Wallace Smith, based upon the unproduced play, "The Chatterbox" by Bayard Veiller.

title: Alias French Gertie
text: It starred Bebe Daniels and Ben Lyon, who were making their first on-screen appearance together.

title: Alias French Gertie
text: A copy of this film survives in the Library of Congress.

title: The Big Brain
text: The Big Brain is a 1933 American Pre-Code drama film directed by George Archainbaud and written by Sy Bartlett and Warren Duff.

title: The Big Brain
text: The film stars George E. Stone, Phillips Holmes, Fay Wray, Minna Gombell and Lilian Bond.

title: The Big Brain
text: The film was released on August 5, 1933, by RKO Pictures.

title: Conductivity near the percolation threshold
text: In a mixture between a dielectric and a metallic component, the conductivity formula_1 and the dielectric constant formula_2 of this mixture show a critical behavior if the fraction of the metallic component reaches the percolation threshold.

title: Conductivity near the percolation threshold
text: The behavior of the conductivity near this percolation threshold will show a smooth change over from the conductivity of the dielectric component to the conductivity of the metallic component and can be described using two critical exponents s and t, whereas the dielectric constant will diverge if the threshold is approached from either side.

title: Conductivity near the percolation threshold
text: To include the frequency dependent behavior, a resistor-capacitor model (R-C model) is used.

title: 1-Pentanol
text: 1-Pentanol, (or n-pentanol, pentan-1-ol), is an alcohol with five carbon atoms and the molecular formula CHOH.

title: 1-Pentanol
text: 1-Pentanol is a colorless liquid with an unpleasant aroma.

title: 1-Pentanol
text: It is the straight-chain form of amyl alcohol, one of 8 isomers with that formula.

title: Aldonic acid
text: An aldonic acid is any of a family of sugar acids obtained by oxidation of the aldehyde functional group of an aldose to form a carboxylic acid functional group.

title: Aldonic acid
text: Thus, their general chemical formula is HOOC-(CHOH)-CHOH.

title: Aldonic acid
text: Oxidation of the terminal hydroxyl group instead of the terminal aldehyde yields a uronic acid, while oxidation of both terminal ends yields an aldaric acid.

title: Isopropyl alcohol
text: Isopropyl alcohol (IUPAC name propan-2-ol), also called dimethyl carbinol or, incorrectly, isopropanol, is a compound with the chemical formula CHO or CHOH or CHCHOHCH (sometimes represented as "i"-PrOH).

title: Isopropyl alcohol
text: It is a colorless, flammable chemical compound with a strong odor.

title: Isopropyl alcohol
text: As a propyl group linked to a hydroxyl group, it is the simplest example of a secondary alcohol, where the alcohol carbon atom is attached to two other carbon atoms, sometimes shown as (CH)CHOH.

title: Isopropyl alcohol
text: It is a structural isomer of 1-propanol.

title: Isopropyl alcohol
text: It has a wide variety of industrial and household uses, and is a common ingredient in chemicals such as antiseptics, disinfectants and detergents.

title: 1-Hexanol
text: 1-Hexanol is an organic alcohol with a six-carbon chain and a condensed structural formula of CH(CH)OH.

title: 1-Hexanol
text: This colorless liquid is slightly soluble in water, but miscible with diethyl ether and ethanol.

title: 1-Hexanol
text: Two additional straight chain isomers of 1-hexanol, 2-hexanol and 3-hexanol, exist, both of which differing by the location of the hydroxyl group.

title: 1-Hexanol
text: Many isomeric alcohols have the formula CHOH.

title: 1-Hexanol
text: It is used in the perfume industry.

title: Tetrakis(hydroxymethyl)phosphonium chloride
text: Tetrakis(hydroxymethyl)phosphonium chloride (THPC) is an organophosphorus compound with the chemical formula Cl.

title: Tetrakis(hydroxymethyl)phosphonium chloride
text: The cation P(CHOH) is four-coordinate, as is typical for phosphonium salts. THPC has applications as a precursor to fire-retardant materials.

title: Seidel's algorithm
text: Seidel's algorithm is an algorithm designed by Raimund Seidel in 1992 for the all-pairs-shortest-path problem for undirected, unweighted, connected graphs.

title: Seidel's algorithm
text: It solves the problem in formula_1 expected time for a graph with formula_2 vertices, where formula_3 is the exponent in the complexity formula_4 of formula_5 matrix multiplication.

title: Seidel's algorithm
text: If only the distances between each pair of vertices are sought, the same time bound can be achieved in the worst case.

title: Seidel's algorithm
text: Note that even though the algorithm is designed for connected graphs, it can be applied individually to each connected component of a graph with the same running time overall.

title: Seidel's algorithm
text: Note also that there is an exception to the expected running time given above for computing the paths: if formula_6 the expected running time becomes formula_7.

title: Index of alcohol-related articles
text: Alcohol is any organic compound in which a hydroxyl functional group (-OH) is bound to a carbon atom, usually connected to other carbon or hydrogen atoms.

title: Index of alcohol-related articles
text: An important class are the simple acyclic alcohols, the general formula for which is CHOH.

title: Index of alcohol-related articles
text: Of those, ethanol (CHOH) is the type of alcohol found in alcoholic beverages, and in common speech the word alcohol refers specifically to ethanol.

title: Index of alcohol-related articles
text: Articles related to alcohol include:

title: Xylitol
text: Xylitol is a sugar alcohol used as a sweetener.

title: Xylitol
text: The name derives from Greek: ξύλον , "xyl", "wood" + suffix -"itol", used to denote sugar alcohols.

title: Xylitol
text: Xylitol is categorized as a polyalcohol or sugar alcohol (alditol).

title: Xylitol
text: It has the formula CHOH(CHOH)CHOH and is an achiral isomer of pentane-1,2,3,4,5-pentol.

title: Xylitol
text: Multiple studies using electron microscopy have indicated that xylitol is effective in inducing remineralization of deeper layers of demineralized enamel.

title: Xylitol
text: Fair evidence was found that xylitol (as chewing gum, lozenges, nasal spray, etc.) reduced the incidence of acute middle ear infection in healthy children.

title: Gluconic acid
text: Gluconic acid is an organic compound with molecular formula CHO and condensed structural formula HOCH(CHOH)COOH.

title: Gluconic acid
text: It is one of the 16 stereoisomers of 2,3,4,5,6-pentahydroxyhexanoic acid.

title: Northern California PGA Championship
text: The Northern California PGA Championship is a golf tournament that is the championship of the Northern California section of the PGA of America.

title: Northern California PGA Championship
text: Mark Fry, long-time pro at Sequoyah Country Club in Oakland, California, holds the record for most victories with 10.

title: Northern California PGA Championship
text: Tony Lema, British Open winner in 1964 and 12-time PGA Tour winner, won three consecutive Northern California PGA championships from 1962–64.

title: Northern California PGA Championship
text: Other PGA Tour winners who were also victorious in the Northern California PGA Championship include Bob Lunn (six-time PGA tour winner), Dick Lotz (three-time PGA tour winner), Bruce Summerhays (three-time PGA tour winner, Bob Wynn, and John McMullin.

title: 1977 PGA Championship
text: The 1977 PGA Championship was the 59th PGA Championship, played August 11–14 at Pebble Beach Golf Links in Pebble Beach, California.

title: 1977 PGA Championship
text: Lanny Wadkins, 27, won his only major championship in a sudden-death playoff over Gene Littler.

title: 1977 PGA Championship
text: It was the first playoff at the PGA Championship in ten years and was the first-ever sudden-death playoff in a stroke-play major championship.

title: 1977 PGA Championship
text: The last was 36 years earlier at the 1941 PGA Championship, when the 36-hole final match went to two extra holes.

title: Middle Atlantic PGA Championship
text: The Middle Atlantic PGA Championship is a golf tournament that is the championship of the Middle Atlantic section of the PGA of America.

title: Middle Atlantic PGA Championship
text: The tournament has been played annually since 1932 in Virginia, Maryland, or Washington, DC.

title: Middle Atlantic PGA Championship
text: Fred Funk, eight-time winner on the PGA Tour, holds the record with six Middle Atlantic PGA victories.

title: Middle Atlantic PGA Championship
text: Other PGA Tour winners who have also won the Middle Atlantic PGA Championship include Chandler Harper (seven time PGA tour winner and 1950 PGA Championship winner), Bobby Cruickshank (17-time PGA tour winner), Lew Worsham (four-time PGA tour winner), and George Fazio (two-time PGA tour winner and golf course designer).

title: Connecticut PGA Championship
text: The Connecticut PGA Championship is a golf tournament that is a championship of the Connecticut section of the PGA of America.

title: Connecticut PGA Championship
text: The tournament has been played annually since 1929 mostly in Connecticut, although it's been held four times in Massachusetts.

title: Connecticut PGA Championship
text: Dennis Coscina, who has competed on the Senior tour and is long-time teaching pro, holds the record for most wins with eight.

title: Connecticut PGA Championship
text: PGA Tour winners who have also won the Connecticut PGA Championship include Gene Kunes and Joe Turnesa.

title: Connecticut PGA Championship
text: The winner of the Connecticut PGA Championship earns entry into the Travelers Championship.

title: 2000 PGA Championship
text: The 2000 PGA Championship was the 82nd PGA Championship, held August 17–20 at the Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Kentucky.

title: 2000 PGA Championship
text: It was the second time for the event at Valhalla, which hosted four years earlier in 1996.

title: 2000 PGA Championship
text: Tiger Woods won his second straight PGA Championship and fifth major in a three-hole playoff over Bob May.

title: 2000 PGA Championship
text: Woods and May finished at 18 under par to set the PGA Championship record to par, later equaled by Woods in 2006.

title: 2000 PGA Championship
text: It was the first time since 1937 that a PGA Championship title was successfully defended, and the first ever as a stroke play event.

title: 2000 PGA Championship
text: Woods and May were five shots ahead of third-place finisher Thomas Bjørn.

title: 1940 PGA Championship
text: The 1940 PGA Championship was the 23rd PGA Championship, held August 26 to September 2 at Hershey Country Club in Hershey, Pennsylvania, east of Harrisburg.

title: 1940 PGA Championship
text: Then a match play championship, Byron Nelson won his first PGA Championship, defeating Sam Snead 1 up in the 36-hole final.

title: 1940 PGA Championship
text: It was the third of Nelson's five major titles; he won the PGA Championship again in 1945.

title: 1940 PGA Championship
text: From 1939 to 1945, Nelson made five of the six finals, missing only in 1942 (not held in 1943).

title: Argentine PGA Championship
text: The Argentine PGA Championship is a golf tournament played in Argentina since 1920.

title: Argentine PGA Championship
text: It was generally supported by the leading Argentine golfers and its list of champions includes Eduardo Romero (8 times), José Jurado (7 times), Vicente Fernández (5 times), José Cóceres (twice) and Ángel Cabrera.

title: Argentine PGA Championship
text: However, the record holder is former British Open champion Roberto De Vicenzo, who recorded 16 victories between 1944 and 1985.

title: 2006 PGA Championship
text: The 2006 PGA Championship was the 88th PGA Championship, played August 17–20 at Medinah Country Club in Medinah, Illinois, a suburb northwest of Chicago.

title: 2006 PGA Championship
text: Tiger Woods won his third PGA Championship, five shots ahead of runner-up Shaun Micheel, the 2003 champion.

title: 2006 PGA Championship
text: Woods' victory was his 12th major championship.

title: 2006 PGA Championship
text: The No. 3 Course was the longest to date in major championship history.

title: 2006 PGA Championship
text: Medinah previously hosted the tournament in 1999, when Woods captured his first PGA Championship.

title: 2006 PGA Championship
text: The purse was $6.8 million with a winner's share of $1.224 million.

title: 1939 PGA Championship
text: The 1939 PGA Championship was the 22nd PGA Championship, held July 9–15 at Pomonok Country Club in Queens, New York.

title: 1939 PGA Championship
text: Then a match play championship, Henry Picard won his only PGA Championship, defeating Byron Nelson with a birdie at the 37th hole.

title: 1939 PGA Championship
text: It was the second of his two major titles; he won the Masters in 1938.

title: 1939 PGA Championship
text: Nelson won the U.S. Open three months earlier and the next PGA Championship in 1940.

title: 1939 PGA Championship
text: Beginning in 1939, he made five finals in six PGA Championships, and won his second title in 1945.

title: 2018 PGA Championship
text: The 2018 PGA Championship is the forthcoming 100th PGA Championship that will take place from August 9–12 at Bellerive Country Club in Town and Country, Missouri.

title: 2018 PGA Championship
text: This will be the second PGA Championship at Bellerive.

title: 2018 PGA Championship
text: This will also be the last PGA Championship to be held in the month of August; just before the 2017 tournament, the PGA announced that the Championship would be held in May beginning in 2019.

title: Levolution (album)
text: Levolution is the second studio album by Australian rock band Juke Kartel, and the first American released album.

title: Levolution (album)
text: Levolution was released to the Australian public through Carved Records on 20 August 2010, and later released to the United States on 28 September 2010.

title: Levolution (album)
text: Produced by Brian Virtue (Jane's Addiction, Velvet Revolver, Thirty Seconds to Mars, Chevelle) and Rick Parashar (Pearl Jam, Alice in Chains, 3 Doors Down, Nickelback), the album features a half-dozen freshly penned tracks and six from the band's 2009 Australian CD, Nowhere Left to Hide, remixed by Dan Korneff (My Chemical Romance, Cavo).

title: Levolution (album)
text: With its overarching theme of personal growth and "the journey we’re all on", says vocalist/lyricist Toby Rand, Levolution finds musical parity in its strong hooks, multi-textured instrumentals and passionate vocals.

title: A Boy in a Man's World
text: A Boy in a Man's World is the second studio album by Mucky Pup.

title: A Boy in a Man's World
text: The album was recorded at Nevessa Productions and released in 1989 through Torrid Records and Roadrunner Records.

title: A Boy in a Man's World
text: The album features a re-recorded version of "U-Stink-But-I-♥-U," which the band had previously won a Bloom County songwriting contest with.

title: A Boy in a Man's World
text: The band would also shoot their first music video for this song.

title: A Boy in a Man's World
text: The album also features "Batman", a song based on an urban legend that also contains a snippet of the title theme to the 1966 "Batman" TV.

title: Deceit (Doctor Who novel)
text: Deceit is an original novel written by Peter Darvill-Evans and based on the long-running British science fiction television series "Doctor Who".

title: Deceit (Doctor Who novel)
text: It features the Seventh Doctor, Ace and Bernice.

title: Deceit (Doctor Who novel)
text: Also included is "Doctor Who Magazine" comic character Abslom Daak, in his first appearance outside "DWM".

title: Deceit (Doctor Who novel)
text: A prelude to the novel, also penned by Darvill-Evans, appeared in "Doctor Who Magazine" #198.

title: In My Country There Is Problem
text: "In My Country There Is Problem", also known as "Throw the Jew Down the Well" after the song's key line, is a song written by British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen for his comic character Borat Sagdiyev.

title: In My Country There Is Problem
text: It features in the 'Country Music' segment of "Borat's Guide to the USA (Part 2)", that focuses heavily on the (positive) reaction of the patrons of an Arizona country and western bar to the antisemitic sentiments of the song.

title: In My Country There Is Problem
text: It appeared in "".

title: Nagaram (2010 film)
text: Nagaram Marupakkam (English: The other side of the town ) is a 2010 Indian Tamil action film co-produced written and directed by Sundar C., who himself plays the lead role.

title: Nagaram (2010 film)
text: Co-produced by his wife Kushboo, the film also stars Anuya Bhagvath and Vadivelu in pivotal roles and features music by Thaman.

title: Nagaram (2010 film)
text: Sundar's first directorial after five years, "Nagaram" released on 19 November 2010, it is based on the 1993 American movie Carlito's Way .

title: Nagaram (2010 film)
text: The film is very well known for comedy sequences and portrayal of the comic character "Style Pandi" by Vadivelu.

title: Impossible Dream
text: Impossible Dream is Patty Griffin’s fifth commercially released album, and fourth studio album.

title: Impossible Dream
text: It was released on April 20, 2004.

title: Impossible Dream
text: The album features an unlisted song – Griffin’s mother and father singing “The Impossible Dream” – at the end of “Top of the World.”

title: A Week of Garfield
text: A Week of Garfield (ガーフィールドの一週間 , Gāfirudo no Isshukan ) is a 1989 Family Computer title based on the comic character Garfield.

title: A Week of Garfield
text: It was only released in Japan due to issues with using the Garfield license in North America and Europe.

title: A Week of Garfield
text: It is the third video game to be based on Jim Davis' "Garfield" Comics.

title: Children Running Through
text: Children Running Through is Patty Griffin's sixth commercially released album, and fifth studio album.

title: Children Running Through
text: It was released on 6 February 2007.

title: Children Running Through
text: The album features vocals from Emmylou Harris on "Trapeze".

title: Children Running Through
text: "Heavenly Day" was the album's first single.

title: Music of Hair
text: Music of Hair is Andrew Bird's first released album.

title: Music of Hair
text: The album came out in 1996.

title: Music of Hair
text: The tracks featured were written in Bird's early twenties, and the album was released when he was 23.

title: Music of Hair
text: The album features contributions from musicians Colin Bunn, Dave Dieckmann, Kat Eggleston, Al Ehrich, Kevin O'Donnell; and, James "Jimbo" Mathus, Katharine Whalen and Chris Phillips from Squirrel Nut Zippers.

title: Kiss (Carly Rae Jepsen album)
text: Kiss is the second studio album by Canadian recording artist Carly Rae Jepsen.

title: Kiss (Carly Rae Jepsen album)
text: It was released on September 14, 2012, by 604, Schoolboy and Interscope Records.

title: Kiss (Carly Rae Jepsen album)
text: After her debut, "Tug of War" (2008), which managed to receive success in Canada but was never released worldwide, "Kiss" became Jepsen's first internationally released album.

title: Kiss (Carly Rae Jepsen album)
text: Songs on the album are in the nu-disco, dance-pop, and teen pop genres, drawing inspiration from The Cars, Madonna, and Swedish performer, Robyn.

title: Kiss (Carly Rae Jepsen album)
text: Featuring production from a wide collection of producers including Dallas Austin, Josh Ramsay, and Redfoo, the album features a track with guest vocals from Justin Bieber.

title: Vice President of Panama
text: The Vice President of Panama is the second-highest political position in the Government of Panama.

title: Vice President of Panama
text: Since 2009, the position of Vice President has been held by only one person.

title: Vice President of Panama
text: Previously, there were positions of First Vice President and Second Vice President, also known as First Designate to Presidency ("Primer Designado a la Presidencia") and Second Designate ("Segundo Designado a la Presidencia").

title: Vice President of Panama
text: According to the current constitution, Vice Presidents are elected in the same ticket as the President.

title: Vice President of Panama
text: However, the position of Second Vice President has been abolished since 2009.

title: Abteilungsleiter (NSDAP)
text: Abteilungsleiter ("section leader"), German for department head, was also a mid-level administrative political position of the Nazi Party, often held by staff political officers attached to various "Gaue" throughout Germany.

title: Abteilungsleiter (NSDAP)
text: The position of Abteilungsleiter was not an actual Nazi Party political rank, but a title held by a Party member in addition to their formal rank.

title: Abteilungsleiter (NSDAP)
text: The position was first created in 1933, after the Nazis had secured power in Germany.

title: Public Law 113-167
text: Pub.L.

title: Public Law 113-167
text: 113–167 (formerly the bill ), a United States public law, that is entitled "to amend the Interstate Land Sales Full Disclosure Act to clarify how the Act applies to condominiums," is a bill that was introduced into the United States House of Representatives during the 113th United States Congress.

title: Public Law 113-167
text: The Interstate Land Sales Full Disclosure Act of 1968 was passed in 1968 with the intention of helping protect consumers from land-related scams, but regulating the sale of land across state lines.

title: Public Law 113-167
text: The act requires sellers to prepare center information about the piece of property they are trying to sell and disclose it in a "Property Report."

title: Public Law 113-167
text: The law was originally administered by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, but is currently run by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: Public Law 113-167
text: H.R. 2600 would make changes to this law related to condominiums.

title: Hannah Gale
text: Hannah "Annie" Elizabeth Rolinson Gale (December 29, 1876 – August 7, 1970) was a British-born Canadian politician who was the first woman to hold an elected political position in Canada.

title: Attorney misconduct
text: Attorney misconduct is unethical or illegal conduct by an attorney.

title: Attorney misconduct
text: Attorney Misconduct may include: conflict of interest, over billing, refusing to represent a client for political or professional motives, false or misleading statements, hiding evidence, abandoning a client, failing to disclose all relevant facts, arguing a position while neglecting to disclose prior law which might counter the argument, and" in some instances" having sex with a client.

title: DISCLOSE Act
text: The Democracy Is Strengthened by Casting Light On Spending in Elections Act, commonly known as the DISCLOSE Act and also known as H.R. 5175 (S.3628-Senate), was a bill introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives by Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland) on April 29, 2010 and in the U.S. Senate by Charles Schumer (D-New York) on July 21, 2010.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: Although attempts to regulate campaign finance by legislation date back to 1867, the modern era of "campaign finance reform" in the United States begins with the passage of the Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA) of 1971 and, more importantly, 1974 amendments to that Act.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: The 1971 FECA required candidates to disclose sources of campaign contributions and campaign expenditures.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: The 1974 Amendments essentially rewrote the Act from top to bottom.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: The 1974 Amendments placed statutory limits on contributions by individuals for the first time, and created the Federal Election Commission (FEC) as an independent enforcement agency.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: It provided for broad new disclosure requirements, and limited the amounts that candidates could spend on their campaigns, or that citizens could spend separate from candidate campaigns to promote their political views.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: Specifically, it attempted to restrict the influence of wealthy individuals by limiting individual donations to $1,000 and donations by political action committees (PACs) to $5,000.

title: Campaign finance reform in the United States
text: However, the Act's provisions limiting expenditures were struck down as unconstitutional in the 1976 Supreme Court decision Buckley v. Valeo.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: World Tamil Movement (abbreviated WTM) is a non-profit organization created in 1986 run by Canadians of ethnic Tamil heritage.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: Its president was Sitha Sithampalam until June, 2008.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: The organisation has functioned as a community group that offers services such as translation, vocational training and a library for the Tamil population in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: It further organised cultural and sports leagues, and classes to help women and children integrate into the larger Canadian society.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: It was further involved in relief efforts for the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: It has also openly declared itself to share the politics of Sri Lankan Tamil nationalism, stating "It's no secret that the World Tamil Movement supports the right of the Tamil people to self-determination in the Northern and Eastern part of Sri Lanka.

title: World Tamil Movement
text: This is a political position – perhaps one that not everyone will agree with, but one that we are constitutionally entitled to hold."

title: State Secretary (Norway)
text: In Norway, a State Secretary (Norwegian: "statssekretær" ) is a partisan political position within the executive branch of government.

title: State Secretary (Norway)
text: Contrary to the position Secretary of State in many other countries, the Norwegian State Secretary does not head his or her Ministry, rather, they are second in rank to a Minister.

title: State Secretary (Norway)
text: Resembling a "de facto" vice minister, the State Secretary, however, cannot attend a Council of State, and does not act as a temporary Minister in case of illness or other leave of absence.

title: Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act
text: Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act, Bill-C74 was first introduced in the Canadian House of Commons on November 15, 2005.

title: Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act
text: Introduced as a part of a package of “lawful access” proposals, Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act (MITA) if passed, would have required telephone and internet service providers to design, create and maintain interception capabilities into existing networks and into new technologies as they are introduced into Canada.

title: Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act
text: Second, it would have allowed law enforcement to compel telephone and internet service providers to disclose subscriber information without a warrant.

title: Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act
text: The bill failed to pass into law when Parliament was dissolved on November 28, 2005.

title: Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act
text: Lawful access legislation was, however, was re-introduced under the name Bill C-13 (short titled Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act) by Stephen Harper's Conservative government on November 20, 2013 and it passed through all legislative stages to receive royal assent on December 9, 2014.

title: Mark Arm
text: Mark Arm (born Mark Thomas McLaughlin, February 21, 1962) is the vocalist for the grunge band Mudhoney.

title: Mark Arm
text: His former group, Green River, is one of the first grunge bands, along with Malfunkshun, Soundgarden, Skin Yard, the U-Men, and others.

title: Mark Arm
text: He is also the manager of the Sub Pop warehouse and previously worked at Fantagraphics Books.

title: Fist Sized Chunks
text: Fist Sized Chunks is the third studio album by the grunge band Skin Yard.

title: Fist Sized Chunks
text: It was released in 1990 on Cruz Records.

title: Matt Cameron
text: Matthew David Cameron (born November 28, 1962) is an American musician who serves as the drummer for the American rock bands Pearl Jam and Soundgarden.

title: Matt Cameron
text: After getting his start with the Seattle, Washington-based bands Bam Bam and Skin Yard, he first gained fame as the drummer for Soundgarden, which he joined in 1986 and remained in until the band's break-up in 1997.

title: Matt Cameron
text: In 1998, Cameron was invited to play on Pearl Jam's U.S. Yield Tour.

title: Matt Cameron
text: He soon became a permanent member and has remained in the band ever since.

title: Matt Cameron
text: In 2010, Soundgarden reunited for a tour and released a new album, "King Animal," on November 13, 2012.

title: Inside the Eye
text: Inside the Eye is the last album released by Skin Yard in 1993.

title: Skin Yard (album)
text: Skin Yard was the first album released by the band Skin Yard in January, 1987.

title: Skin Yard (album)
text: 1400 vinyl copies were released on translucent skin-tone vinyl.

title: Cat Butt
text: Cat Butt was a Seattle, Washington rock group formed in 1987.

title: Cat Butt
text: The band did a short west coast tour, and then went on to record their first full-length album, "Journey to the Center Of."

title: Cat Butt
text: It was produced by Jack Endino of Skin Yard.

title: Cat Butt
text: To promote the album the band did a large U.S. tour, before disbanding in late 1990.

title: Cat Butt
text: Although not achieving the success of other Sub Pop bands, they maintained a loyal cult following in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Gruntruck
text: Gruntruck is an American rock band formed in 1989 in Seattle, Washington by vocalist Ben McMillan and drummer Norman Scott, both previously from early Grunge pioneers Skin Yard.

title: Gruntruck
text: While in Skin Yard, Norman also briefly joined Soundgarden, and collaborated with Chris Cornell on a lesser-known band, the low frequency power trio Bass Truck.

title: Gruntruck
text: Lead guitarist Tommy Niemeyer from metal thrashers The Accüsed and bassist Tim Paul, previously of PDX hardcore punks Final Warning, rounded out the initial, classic line-up.

title: Gruntruck
text: Their sound is described as Grunge, and the band focuses more on the metal side of the genre.

title: Chris Hanzsek
text: Chris Hanzsek is an American musical engineer and record producer currently living in Snohomish, Washington.

title: Chris Hanzsek
text: He was co-founder, with then partner Tina Casale, of C/Z Records and their recording studio, Reciprocal Recording, in 1984.

title: Chris Hanzsek
text: Many of the bands he produced in the mid-1980s are regarded as the foundation of Seattle’s “grunge” scene, such as, The Melvins, Soundgarden, The U-Men, Malfunkshun, Skin Yard, and Green River who can all be heard on C/Z’s landmark compilation album, “Deep Six”.

title: Daniel House
text: Daniel House (born August 8, 1961) is a business owner/entrepreneur and musician best known for his contribution to the Seattle “grunge” music movement of the 1980s and ‘90s.

title: Daniel House
text: He was a co-founder and bass-player for Skin Yard, a band that was active from 1985 to 1992, and was President and owner of C/Z Records, a Seattle-based independent record label that released music by many bands including 7 Year Bitch, Built to Spill, Coffin Break, Engine Kid, The Gits, Hammerbox, Love Battery, The Melvins, The Presidents of the United States of America, Silkworm, and Skin Yard.

title: Daniel House
text: In 2003 he moved from Seattle to Los Angeles where he oversaw the development and creation of the now-defunct www.DownloadPunk.com as well as the music-centric online dating website, RocknRollDating.com.

title: Jack Endino
text: Jack Endino (born 1964) is an American producer and musician based in Seattle, United States.

title: Jack Endino
text: Long associated with Seattle label Sub Pop and the grunge movement, Endino worked on seminal albums from bands such as Mudhoney, Soundgarden, and Nirvana.

title: Jack Endino
text: Endino was also the guitarist for the Seattle band Skin Yard which was active between 1985 and 1992.

title: Jack Endino
text: Endino currently manages a studio in Seattle called Soundhouse Recording.

title: Hall & Oates
text: Daryl Hall and John Oates, often referred to as Hall & Oates, are an American musical duo from Philadelphia.

title: Hall & Oates
text: Daryl Hall is generally the lead vocalist of the pairing.

title: Hall & Oates
text: John Oates primarily plays electric guitar and provides backing vocals.

title: Hall & Oates
text: The two write most of the songs they perform, either separately or in collaboration.

title: Hall & Oates
text: They achieved their greatest fame from the late 1970s to the mid-1980s with a fusion of rock and roll and rhythm and blues.

title: Janna Allen
text: Janna Allen (May 12, 1957 – August 25, 1993) was an American songwriter.

title: Janna Allen
text: She is best known as a co-writer of some of the biggest hits recorded by Daryl Hall & John Oates, in collaboration variously with Daryl Hall, John Oates and her sister Sara Allen, who was Hall's longtime girlfriend and the person for whom the duo's hit song "Sara Smile" was written.

title: Big Bam Boom
text: Big Bam Boom is the twelfth studio album by Daryl Hall & John Oates, released by RCA Records late in 1984.

title: Big Bam Boom
text: It marked the end of one of the most successful album runs by a duo of the 1980s.

title: Big Bam Boom
text: RCA issued a remastered version in July 2004 with four bonus tracks.

title: Big Bam Boom
text: The song "Out of Touch" (the first single) was a #1 pop hit, and charted in several other areas (#24 Hot Black Singles, #8 on the Adult Contemporary charts and #1 on the dance charts, #48 in the UK).

title: Big Bam Boom
text: Another song taken from the album, the Daryl Hall and Janna Allen-penned "Method of Modern Love" reached a high point of #5, and "Some Things Are Better Left Unsaid," reached #18.

title: Jonathan Wolfson
text: Jonathan Wolfson (born December 1, 1970) is an American television executive, manager, and publicist.

title: Jonathan Wolfson
text: He is known for his managerial work with the musical group Daryl Hall & John Oates and the Canadian-rock group Loverboy.

title: Jonathan Wolfson
text: He was previously well known for his publicity work with Suge Knight through his company Wolfson Public Relations.

title: Jonathan Wolfson
text: Jonathan has executive produced Daryl Hall’s TV shows "Daryl’s Restoration Over-Hall" and "Live From Daryl’s House".

title: Ferry Cross the Mersey
text: "Ferry Cross the Mersey" (sometimes written Ferry 'Cross the Mersey) is a song written by Gerry Marsden.

title: Ferry Cross the Mersey
text: It was first recorded by his band Gerry and the Pacemakers and released in late 1964 in the UK and in 1965 in the United States.

title: Ferry Cross the Mersey
text: It was a hit on both sides of the Atlantic, reaching number six in the United States and number eight in the UK.

title: Ferry Cross the Mersey
text: The song is from the film of the same name and was released on its soundtrack album.

title: Ferry Cross the Mersey
text: In the mid-1990s a musical theatre production also titled "Ferry Cross the Mersey" related Gerry Marsden's Merseybeat days; it premiered in Liverpool and played in the UK, Australia, and Canada.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: Live from Daryl's House (simply known as Daryl's House, and often abbreviated as LFDH) is an online series that was first created in fall 2007.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: The show features singer-songwriter Daryl Hall performing with his band and various guest artists at his home in Millerton, New York.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: The show provides a performance space that is an alternative to live concerts and studio sessions for popular artists.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: This allows the artists to "...have fun and  creatively spontaneous".

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: The majority of shows include a segment in which Hall and the guest artist prepare food from different cuisines for everyone to eat.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: The food comes from various local restaurants and the chefs of those establishments walk Hall and guest through the preparation of the food.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: "Live From Daryl's House" expanded to broadcast TV but remained unchanged.

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: Hall was quoted by Billboard.com as saying "it's an Internet show that is being shown on television, so I'm not adapting the show at all in any way to be a 'TV' show."

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: The show debuted in 95 markets on September 24, 2011, with back-to-back half-hour episodes featuring Train (Episode 33) and Fitz & the Tantrums (Episode 35).

title: Live from Daryl's House
text: Starting with the 66th episode of "Live From Daryl's House", the shows are filmed at Hall's club, Daryl's House, in Pawling, New York.

title: One on One (song)
text: "One on One" is a song performed by American musical duo Hall & Oates.

title: One on One (song)
text: Written by member Daryl Hall, the song was released as the second single from their eleventh studio album "HO" on January 29, 1983.

title: One on One (song)
text: Backed by minimalistic, synthesizer-based production, the song's lyrics incorporate various sports metaphors to describe seduction.

title: One on One (song)
text: Daryl Hall performs lead vocals, while John Oates provides backing harmony vocals.

title: Don't Let the Sun Catch You Crying
text: "Don't Let the Sun Catch You Crying" is a song written and originally performed by British beat group Gerry and the Pacemakers.

title: Don't Let the Sun Catch You Crying
text: The songwriting is credited to Gerry Marsden and the other band members, Freddie Marsden, Les Chadwick and Les Maguire.

title: Don't Let the Sun Catch You Crying
text: It was first recorded by Louise Cordet, and then recorded by the group themselves in early 1964.

title: Did It in a Minute
text: "Did It in a Minute" is a song performed by American musical duo Hall & Oates.

title: Did It in a Minute
text: Written by member Daryl Hall with Sara and Janna Allen.

title: Did It in a Minute
text: The song was released as the third of four singles from their tenth studio album "Private Eyes" in March 1982.

title: Did It in a Minute
text: Daryl Hall performs lead vocals, while John Oates provides backing harmony vocals.

title: Say It Isn't So (Hall & Oates song)
text: "Say It Isn't So" is a song by American duo Daryl Hall & John Oates written by Daryl Hall.

title: Say It Isn't So (Hall & Oates song)
text: It was released by RCA Records in October 1983 as the first of two new singles from their compilation album "Rock 'n Soul Part 1", released that same year (see 1983 in music).

title: Say It Isn't So (Hall & Oates song)
text: The song was remixed as a "special extended dance mix" by John "Jellybean" Benitez, which topped "Billboard" magazine's Hot Dance Club Play chart.

title: Say It Isn't So (Hall & Oates song)
text: The song peaked at number 2 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 for four weeks, coincidentally behind "Say Say Say" by Paul McCartney and Michael Jackson.

title: U.S. Route 19 Truck (Pittsburgh)
text: U.S. Route 19 Truck (US 19 Truck) is a truck route of U.S. Route 19 (US 19) located in Western Pennsylvania in the Pittsburgh Metro Area that has a length of 19 mi .

title: U.S. Route 19 Truck (Pittsburgh)
text: It is a loop off US 19; the southern terminus located in Mt. Lebanon and the northern terminus in McCandless Township, connecting to US 19 at both ends.

title: U.S. Route 19 Truck (Pittsburgh)
text: The route is notable for a large, unorthodox interchange with the Penn–Lincoln Parkway (I-376/US 22/US 30) just west of the Fort Pitt Tunnel, where the route joins the Parkway and forms several wrong-way concurrencies, including one with its own opposing directions.

title: U.S. Route 19 Truck (Pittsburgh)
text: North of Pittsburgh, U.S. Route 19 Truck is called McKnight Road and south of Pittsburgh it carries West Liberty Avenue and Washington Road.

title: Pureland Industrial Complex
text: Pureland Industrial Complex is a 3000 acre industrial park located in Logan Township in Gloucester County, New Jersey, United States.

title: Pureland Industrial Complex
text: It borders the Delaware River and Raccoon Creek, and is located 12 mi south of the ports of Camden and Philadelphia.

title: Pureland Industrial Complex
text: Interstate 295, U.S. Route 322 and U.S. Route 130 run through it and connect it to major truck routes.

title: Pureland Industrial Complex
text: SMS Rail Lines connect to Penns Grove Secondary and the national rail network.

title: Pureland Industrial Complex
text: It was opened in 1975 and is the largest industrial park in the state of New Jersey, and one of the largest in the world.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: The Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel, also known as the Nehalem Divide Railroad Tunnel, is an abandoned railroad tunnel near Scappoose, Oregon, United States, that is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: The tunnel was driven by the Portland and Southwestern Railroad, whose chief business was logging.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: Unusually for a logging railroad, the Portland and Southwestern built tunnels.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: In order to reach the far side of the Nehalem divide in the Northern Oregon Coast Range, the railroad undertook a 1712 ft tunnel.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: Some work was started in 1910, but most work began in 1918 and was completed in 1919.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: Since the tunnel was not through solid rock, the tunnel was lined with timber.

title: Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel
text: The tunnel was used until 1945, when it was replaced by a truck road over the divide.

title: Al Haj FAW motors
text: Al Haj FAW motors is sole distributor and assembler of FAW vehicles in Pakistan.

title: Al Haj FAW motors
text: The company is a subsidiary of Al Haj group and has an assembly plant located in Karachi.

title: Al Haj FAW motors
text: The assembly plant was inaugurated in 2013.

title: Al Haj FAW motors
text: The company assembles passenger vehicles, light commercial vehicles and commercial trucks.

title: Al Haj FAW motors
text: Over the time Al Haj FAW has secured the trust of major transport and logistics corporations in Pakistan as one of the major truck providers.

title: Truck stop
text: A truck stop, also known as a transport cafe in the United Kingdom and as a travel center by major chains in the United States, is a commercial facility which provides refuelling, rest (parking), and often ready-made food and other services to motorists and truck drivers.

title: Truck stop
text: Truck stops are usually located on or near a busy road.

title: Strawberry Park, Cheshire
text: Strawberry Park and Strawberry Fields are suburbs in the town of Ellesmere Port, Cheshire West and Chester.

title: Strawberry Park, Cheshire
text: They are located to the south of Hope Farm and to the west of Backford Cross.

title: Param, Rampur
text: Param (Hindi: परम ) is a village in Rampur district in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh.

title: Param, Rampur
text: It is 3 km from Ram Ganga and 8 km from the Grand Truck Road.

title: A5117 road
text: The A5117 is a road in Cheshire, England.

title: A5117 road
text: It runs between Shotwick ( ) and Helsby ( ) and connects the A550 at Woodbank to the M56.

title: A5117 road
text: As such it forms a northerly bypass to Chester and a shorter route between the North West and North Wales than the A55.

title: A5117 road
text: The road is dualled west of the M56.

title: A5117 road
text: There is roundabout with the A540 and at Dunkirk at the western terminus of the M56.

title: A5117 road
text: East of the junction the road is single carriageway and crosses the A41 by way of a roundabout at Backford Cross.

title: A5117 road
text: The A5117 intersects the M53 at Junction 10.

title: A5117 road
text: This junction is just east of Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet.

title: A5117 road
text: The road then continues almost parallel to the M56, which it intersects at Junction 14, at which there is a Motorway service area.

title: A5117 road
text: The road then continues south east to terminate where it joins the A56 at Helsby.

title: U.S. Route 287
text: U.S. Route 287 is a north–south United States highway.

title: U.S. Route 287
text: It is 2,882 km long.

title: U.S. Route 287
text: It serves as the major truck route between Fort Worth, Texas and Amarillo, Texas, and between Fort Collins, Colorado and Laramie, Wyoming.

title: U.S. Route 287
text: The highway is broken into two segments by Yellowstone National Park, where an unnumbered park road serves as a connector.

title: Backford Cross
text: Backford Cross is a village on the Wirral Peninsula, Cheshire, England.

title: Backford Cross
text: It is a suburb of the town of Ellesmere Port and part of Cheshire West and Chester.

title: Backford Cross
text: Backford Cross is located around the A41/A5117 junction, south of Great Sutton and about 1.5 mi north of the village of Backford, near Chester.

title: Backford Cross
text: Backford Cross is largely made up of residential homes built from 1990 onwards and serves as a commuter village to Ellesmere Port and Chester, although inhabitants show no allegiance to either locality.

title: Backford Cross
text: The area is split between postcode districts, with parts of the village in Great Sutton, Ellesmere Port CH66 and other areas in Backford, Chester CH1.

title: Snow Queen (2002 film)
text: Snow Queen is a 2002 made-for-television film made by Hallmark Entertainment, directed by David Wu, and based on the story "The Snow Queen" by Hans Christian Andersen.

title: Snow Queen (2002 film)
text: The film stars Bridget Fonda as the title character and Chelsea Hobbs as her rival and the story's heroine, Gerda.

title: Snow Queen (2002 film)
text: The film originally aired on Hallmark Channel as a two-part miniseries, but has since been released as a full-length film on DVD in the United States.

title: Snow Queen (2002 film)
text: The DVD came out on November 9, 2009, in the United Kingdom, and on September 2, 2011, in Australia.

title: Snow Queen (2002 film)
text: This was Bridget Fonda's last acting role to date.

title: La Femme Musketeer
text: La Femme Musketeer is a made for television movie produced by Hallmark Entertainment and Larry Levinson Productions, filmed on Draguć in Croatia.

title: La Femme Musketeer
text: It originally premiered on June 20, 2004 on Hallmark Channel.

title: The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns
text: The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns is a 1999 Hallmark Entertainment made-for-TV fantasy movie.

title: The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns
text: It stars Randy Quaid, Colm Meaney, Kieran Culkin, Roger Daltrey, Caroline Carver and Whoopi Goldberg.

title: The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns
text: The film contains two main stories that eventually intertwine: the first being the story of an American businessman who visits Ireland and encounters magical leprechauns and the second, a story of a pair of star-crossed lovers who happen to be a fairy and a leprechaun, belonging to opposing sides of a magical war.

title: The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns
text: It contains many references to Romeo and Juliet such as two lovers taking poison and feuding clans.

title: Silver Bells (film)
text: Silver Bells is a 2005 made-for-television drama film starring Anne Heche and Tate Donovan.

title: Silver Bells (film)
text: It was produced by Hallmark Entertainment as a Hallmark Hall of Fame movie and was based on the novel of the same name by Luanne Rice.

title: The Boys Next Door (1996 film)
text: The Boys Next Door is a 1996 television movie based on a play by Tom Griffin which was published in 1983 under the title "Damaged Hearts, Broken Flowers" and again in 1988 under the title "The Boys Next Door".

title: The Boys Next Door (1996 film)
text: The movie was produced by Hallmark Entertainment as a Hallmark Hall of Fame Movie.

title: Donald J. Hall Jr.
text: Donald J. Hall Jr., is the President and Chief Executive Officer of Hallmark Cards, and a director of Crown Media Holdings, a member of the board of directors of Hallmark Entertainment Holdings and of the Business Men's Assurance Company of America.

title: Donald J. Hall Jr.
text: He is the son of Donald J. Hall Sr., the chairman of the board and controlling shareholder of Hallmark Cards.

title: Caroline Carver (actress)
text: Caroline Carver (born 1976) is an English actress, screenwriter, and producer best known for roles such as Princess Jessica in the TV film "The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns" (1999), Ingrid in "The Aryan Couple" (2004), and Sandy in "My First Wedding" (2006).

title: Snow White: The Fairest of Them All
text: Snow White: The Fairest of Them All is a 2001 fantasy adventure television film co-written and directed by Caroline Thompson and produced by Hallmark Entertainment.

title: Snow White: The Fairest of Them All
text: The film was first released theatrically in Europe, and subsequently aired in the United States on ABC as part of their series on "The Wonderful World of Disney" on March 17, 2002.

title: Family Plan
text: Family Plan is a made-for-television movie filmed in Los Angeles by Mat IV Productions in association with Alpine Media and Larry Levinson Productions and presented by Hallmark Entertainment.

title: Family Plan
text: It premiered on February 12, 2005 on Hallmark Channel, as part of their Valentine's Day celebration.

title: Family Plan
text: This is the feature film debut of Chloë Grace Moretz

title: You Me and Captain Longbridge
text: You Me and Captain Longbridge (2008) is a 15 minutes short film directed by Kenny Doughty and written & produced by Caroline Carver.

title: You Me and Captain Longbridge
text: The film stars Callum Williams as the 11-year-old Luke, Chris Larkin as Captain Longbridge and Joseph Fiennes as the voice of Luke as an adult.

title: You Me and Captain Longbridge
text: The short film played in 12 International Film Festivals and won 3 awards.

title: The Moth Diaries (film)
text: The Moth Diaries is a 2011 Irish-Canadian horror film directed by Mary Harron and based on a 2002 novel "The Moth Diaries" by Rachel Klein.

title: The Moth Diaries (film)
text: The film stars Lily Cole, Sarah Gadon, Sarah Bolger, Judy Parfitt, and Scott Speedman.

title: John Ridge
text: John Ridge, born Skah-tle-loh-skee (Yellow Bird) (c. 1802 – June 22, 1839), was from a prominent family of the Cherokee Nation, then located in present-day Georgia.

title: John Ridge
text: He went to Cornwall, Connecticut to study at the Foreign Mission School.

title: John Ridge
text: He met Sarah Bird Northup, of a Yankee New England family, and they married in 1824.

title: John Ridge
text: Soon after their return to New Echota in 1825, Ridge was chosen for the Cherokee National Council and became a leader in the tribe.

title: Magic in Harry Potter
text: In the "Harry Potter" series created by J. K. Rowling, magic is depicted as a supernatural force that can be used to override the usual laws of nature.

title: Magic in Harry Potter
text: Many fictional magical creatures exist in the series, while ordinary creatures sometimes exhibit new magical properties in the novel's world.

title: Magic in Harry Potter
text: Objects, too, can be enhanced or imbued with magical property.

title: Magic in Harry Potter
text: The small percentage of humans who are able to perform magic are referred to as witches and wizards, in contrast to the non-magical muggles.

title: Identity Films
text: Identity Films is a production company formed by Anthony Mastromauro in 2006.

title: Identity Films
text: The company has most recently produced the upcoming independent coming-of-age drama "As Cool As I Am", directed by Max Mayer, starring James Marsden, Claire Danes and Sarah Bolger, as well as "Moonlight Serenade" directed by Giancarlo Tallarico and starring Amy Adams, Alec Newman, and Harriet Sansom Harris, as well as Artie Lange's "Beer League" directed by Frank Sebastiano, co-starring Lange and Ralph Macchio.

title: Dark Knight (TV series)
text: Dark Knight or (Fantasy Quest), is a 2000 TV series, a medieval adventure, and a radical new look at the Ivanhoe legend, a Channel 5 series, an Ivanhoe for the 21st Century, battling not only tyranny and oppression but a Pandora's Box of strange, terrifying and magical creatures.

title: Dark Knight (TV series)
text: An epic journey into the Dark Ages; a time of fear, magic and mystery, of action and exciting adventure where the only light in a dangerous land is the glint of fire on the sword blade of the "Chosen One" - the Dark Knight.

title: Dark Knight (TV series)
text: This joint New Zealand/England production attempted to capitalize on the same sword and sorcery market successfully mined by "".

title: Barbie and the Secret Door
text: Barbie and the Secret Door is a 2014 American/Canadian direct-to-video computer animated musical fantasy film, and the 28th entry in the Barbie film series.

title: Barbie and the Secret Door
text: This film is directed by Karen Lloyd, produced by Mattel Entertainment and Rainmaker Entertainment and released by Universal Studios Home Entertainment, and features the voice of Kelly Sheridan as Princess Alexa.

title: Barbie and the Secret Door
text: The story focuses on Alexa, a shy princess who discovers a secret door in her kingdom and enters a whimsical land filled with magical creatures.

title: The Spiderwick Chronicles (film)
text: The Spiderwick Chronicles is a 2008 American fantasy adventure film based on the bestselling book series of the same name by Holly Black and Tony DiTerlizzi.

title: The Spiderwick Chronicles (film)
text: It was directed by Mark Waters and stars Freddie Highmore, Sarah Bolger, Mary-Louise Parker, Martin Short, Nick Nolte, and Seth Rogen.

title: The Spiderwick Chronicles (film)
text: Set in the Spiderwick Estate in New England, it follows the adventures of Jared Grace and his family as they discover a field guide to faeries, battle goblins, mole trolls and other magical creatures.

title: Sinbad of the Seven Seas
text: Sinbad of the Seven Seas is a 1989 Italian fantasy film produced and directed by Enzo G. Castellari from a story by Luigi Cozzi, revolving around the adventures of Sinbad the Sailor.

title: Sinbad of the Seven Seas
text: Sinbad must recover five magical stones to free the city of Basra from the evil spell cast by a wizard, which his journey takes him to mysterious islands and he must battle magical creatures in order to save the world.

title: Stormbreaker (film)
text: Stormbreaker (titled Alex Rider: Operation Stormbreaker in the United States) is a 2006 action spy film directed by Geoffrey Sax.

title: Stormbreaker (film)
text: The screenplay by Anthony Horowitz is based on his novel of the same name, the first novel in the "Alex Rider" series.

title: Stormbreaker (film)
text: The film stars Alex Pettyfer as Alex Rider, and also stars Mickey Rourke, Bill Nighy, Sophie Okenedo, Alicia Silverstone, Sarah Bolger, Stephen Fry and Ewan McGregor.

title: Stormbreaker (film)
text: "Stormbreaker" was an international co-production between companies and financiers from the United Kingdom, the United States, and Germany.

title: As Cool as I Am (film)
text: As Cool as I Am is an American comedy-drama film based on the novel of the same name by Pete Fromm.

title: As Cool as I Am (film)
text: Claire Danes, Sarah Bolger and James Marsden star as the Diamond family.

title: As Cool as I Am (film)
text: The film is directed by Max Mayer, who also directed "Adam".

title: As Cool as I Am (film)
text: Filming on the adaptation began in New Mexico in May 2011.

title: As Cool as I Am (film)
text: The film was released in the United States on June 21, 2013 by IFC Films.

title: Leeds Equity Partners
text: Leeds Equity Partners is a private equity firm focused on investments in the Knowledge Industries.

title: Leeds Equity Partners
text: The firm is investing its fifth private equity fund, Leeds Equity Partners V, L.P., the largest fund focused exclusively on investing in this sector.

title: Leeds Equity Partners
text: The firm's investors include a broad range of leading institutions, public and private pension plans, endowments, foundations, financial institutions, family offices and high-net-worth individuals.

title: Polycom
text: Polycom is an American multinational corporation that develops video, voice and content collaboration and communication technology.

title: Polycom
text: The firm employs approximately 3,800 employees and had annual revenues of approximately $1.4 billion in 2013.

title: Polycom
text: It is the largest pure-play collaboration company in its industry.

title: Polycom
text: The company also licenses: H.264 video codecs, Siren codecs, session initiation protocol, native 1080p high-definition cameras and displays, native 720p and 1080p high-definition encoding/decoding, low-latency architecture and low bandwidth utilization, wideband advanced audio coding with low delay (AAC-LD), multichannel spatial audio with echo cancellation and interference filters to eliminate feedback from mobile devices, and inter-operation with legacy video conferencing.

title: Polycom
text: In July 2016, it was announced that the company was being taken private by private equity firm Siris Capital Group.

title: Court Square Capital Partners
text: Court Square Capital Partners is a private equity firm focused on leveraged buyout transactions.

title: Court Square Capital Partners
text: Court Square was originally a captive private equity firm within Citigroup known as Citigroup Venture Capital Equity Partners.

title: Court Square Capital Partners
text: Court Square's investment professionals have invested over $4.5 billion in more than 150 transactions, which have returned $14 billion to date.

title: Mekong Capital
text: Mekong Capital is a Vietnam-focused private equity firm.

title: Mekong Capital
text: Operating in Vietnam since 2001, Mekong Capital is one of the first private equity firms to engage Vietnam, and has completed 30 private equity investments in Vietnam through 4 funds with approximately 25 full-time employees.

title: Mekong Capital
text: Mekong Capital has offices in Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi.

title: Mekong Capital
text: Focusing on manufacturing companies until 2005, Mekong Capital shifted its focus towards consumer-driven businesses in 2006.

title: Mekong Capital
