text: Mekong Capital is known as a private equity firm that has invested significant resources in the development of its corporate culture, and in the corporate cultures of its portfolio companies, and is the subject of several case studies.

title: Maxeda
text: Maxeda (formerly Vendex KBB) is a Dutch retail group that operates do it yourself stores in Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: Maxeda
text: Maxeda is the result of the merger of Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer (KBB) and Vendex.

title: Maxeda
text: Formerly it owned large Dutch department stores.

title: Maxeda
text: Since 2004 Maxeda is owned by a consortium of investors led by American private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: Avenue Capital Group
text: Avenue Capital Group is a global investment firm focusing on distressed securities and private equity with regional teams focusing on opportunities in the United States, Europe and Asia.

title: Avenue Capital Group
text: The firm operates as both a private equity firm and as a hedge fund.

title: Avenue Capital Group
text: Avenue’s core strategy is focused on distressed debt and equity securities although the firm also manages investment funds that focus on long-short opportunities, real estate, and collateralized debt obligations.

title: Avenue Capital Group
text: The firm manages assets valued at approximately $12 billion.

title: Avenue Capital Group
text: The firm was founded by former professionals of Amroc Investments, an affiliate of the Robert M. Bass Group.

title: HGGC
text: HGGC is a middle-market private equity firm based in Palo Alto, California, with over $4.25 billion of cumulative capital commitments.

title: HGGC
text: Since inception in 2007, HGGC has completed platform investments, add-on acquisitions, recapitalizations and liquidity events with aggregate transaction value of over $12 billion, representing more than 60 individual investments with more than 46,000 portfolio company employees.

title: HGGC
text: The firm was named 2014 M&A Mid-Market Private Equity Firm of the Year by Mergers & Acquisitions magazine.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts
text: KKR & Co.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts
text: L.P. (formerly known as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.) is an American multinational private equity firm, specializing in leveraged buyouts, headquartered in New York City.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts
text: The firm sponsors and manages private equity investment funds.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts
text: The firm has completed over $400 billion of private equity transactions since its inception.

title: Lincolnshire Management
text: Lincolnshire Management is a private equity firm focused on investments and acquisitions in middle-market companies across a range of industries.

title: Lincolnshire Management
text: In 2010, Private Equity News ranked Lincolnshire as a top ten performing private equity firm.

title: Lincolnshire Management
text: Additionally, In 2011, CNN Money /Fortune Magazine ranked Lincolnshire Management as the 5th ranked private equity firm.

title: Manischewitz
text: Manischewitz is a leading brand of kosher products based in the United States, best known for their matzo and kosher wine.

title: Manischewitz
text: Founded in 1888, it became a public corporation in 1923 and remained under family control until 1990, when it was bought out by a private equity firm.

title: Manischewitz
text: On April 7, 2014, Sankaty Advisors, an arm of private equity firm Bain Capital, bought the company from a group including investment firm Harbinger.

title: Manischewitz
text: It is the world's largest matzo manufacturer and one of America's largest kosher brands.

title: Princess Olga of Hanover
text: Princess Olga of Hanover and Cumberland (German: "Olga Adelaide Louise Marie Alexandrina Agnes Prinzessin von Hannover und Cumberland" ; 11 July 1884 – 21 September 1958) was the youngest daughter of Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover (1845–1923) and Princess Thyra of Denmark (1853–1933), the youngest daughter of Christian IX of Denmark (1818–1906) and Louise of Hesse-Kassel (1817–1898).

title: Princess Olga of Hanover
text: Olga was a great-great-granddaughter of George III of the United Kingdom (1738–1820) and Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz (1744–1818).

title: Chainsaw (Scream Queens)
text: "Chainsaw" is the third episode of the horror black comedy series "Scream Queens".

title: Chainsaw (Scream Queens)
text: It premiered on September 29, 2015 on Fox.

title: Chainsaw (Scream Queens)
text: The episode was both directed and written by Ian Brennan.

title: Chainsaw (Scream Queens)
text: In this episode, the Red Devil continues the terror on campus using a chainsaw.

title: Chainsaw (Scream Queens)
text: Chanel (Emma Roberts) finds a new project in Hester (Lea Michele), and Dean Munsch (Jamie Lee Curtis) appoints a new Wallace University mascot while trying to separate Gigi (Nasim Pedrad) and Wes (Oliver Hudson)'s budding relationship as Chad (Glen Powell) and Earl Grey (Lucien Laviscount) lead their fraternity on a witch hunt for the Red Devil.

title: Sian Powers
text: Sian Powers is a fictional character from the British ITV soap opera, "Coronation Street", portrayed by Sacha Parkinson.

title: Sian Powers
text: Sian was introduced as a love interest for Sophie Webster (Brooke Vincent).

title: Sian Powers
text: Sian joined the cast of "Coronation Street" alongside Ben Richardson (Lucien Laviscount) in January 2009 as Sophie's schoolmates.

title: Sian Powers
text: They soon form a new group of teenagers along with Ryan Connor (Ben Thompson).

title: Sian Powers
text: Sian and girlfriend Sophie are "Coronation Street's" first lesbian couple.

title: Sian Powers
text: It was announced on 29 May 2011 that Parkinson had quit her role, and she made her last on screen appearance on 30 December 2011.

title: One Night in Istanbul
text: One Night in Istanbul, also known as One Night in Istanbul: The Movie, is a British comedy-drama film, directed by James Marquand and produced/written by Nicky Allt.

title: One Night in Istanbul
text: The film stars Steven Waddington, Paul Barber, Lucien Laviscount, Samantha Womack, and Ingvar Eggert Sigurðsson.

title: One Night in Istanbul
text: It is based on the play of the same name by Nicky Allt.

title: Gelston Castle
text: Gelston Castle, located between Castle Douglas and Kirkcudbright, in Dumfries and Galloway, Great Britain, was built for Sir William Douglas of Castle Douglas, who had acquired the lands of Gelston in 1799.

title: Gelston Castle
text: However, Sir William Douglas died without issue in 1809 and his property was divided between various nieces and nephews, with Gelston going to the youngest daughter of his brother James, Mathilda Douglas.

title: Gelston Castle
text: In 1813 Mathilda married William Maitland, and their family continued to preside over the estate for most of the 19th Century.

title: Gelston Castle
text: Gelston then became the property of the Galliers-Pratts who retained the castle for pheasant shooting, and from whom it was requisitioned during World War II.

title: Gelston Castle
text: During this time it served as a home for handicapped boys evacuated from Glasgow, before the roof was removed once this use had ceased.

title: Lady Alexandra Curzon
text: Lady Alexandra Naldera Curzon, CBE (20 March/April 1904 – 7 August 1995), was the third daughter of George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston and Viceroy of India, and Lord Curzon's first wife, the American mercantile heiress, Mary Victoria Curzon, Baroness Curzon of Kedleston (née Leiter).

title: Lady Alexandra Curzon
text: She was named after her godmother, Queen Alexandra and her place of conception, Naldehra, India.

title: Lady Alexandra Curzon
text: She and her two older sisters were memorialized by Anne de Courcy in "The Viceroy's Daughters: The Lives of the Curzon Sisters".

title: Love Beats Rhymes
text: Love Beats Rhymes (working title "Coco") is an upcoming American musical drama film directed by RZA.

title: Love Beats Rhymes
text: The film stars Azealia Banks as a twenty five-year-old female rapper from Brooklyn, New York who wants to pursue a music career.

title: Love Beats Rhymes
text: The film also stars Lorraine Toussaint, Jill Scott, Lucien Laviscount, MC Jin, Hana Mae Lee, and Common.

title: Love Beats Rhymes
text: The film is awaiting release by CodeBlack Films and Lionsgate.

title: Bottom of the World (film)
text: Bottom of the World is a 2017 drama film.

title: Bottom of the World (film)
text: It was directed by Richard Sears, written by Brian Gottlieb and stars Jena Malone, Douglas Smith and Ted Levine.

title: Cressida Bonas
text: Cressida Curzon Bonas (born 18 February 1989) is an English actress, dancer and model.

title: Cressida Bonas
text: She is the youngest daughter of Lady Mary-Gaye Curzon and entrepreneur Jeffrey Bonas, and a granddaughter of Edward Curzon, 6th Earl Howe.

title: The Bye Bye Man
text: The Bye Bye Man is a 2017 American supernatural horror film directed by Stacy Title and written by Jonathan Penner, based on the chapter "The Bridge to Body Island" in Robert Damon Schneck's book "The President's Vampire".

title: The Bye Bye Man
text: The film stars Douglas Smith, Lucien Laviscount, Cressida Bonas, Doug Jones, Carrie-Anne Moss, Faye Dunaway and Jenna Kanell.

title: Casino, New South Wales
text: Casino is a town in the Northern Rivers area of New South Wales, Australia, with a population of 9,629 people at the 2011 census .

title: Casino, New South Wales
text: It lies on the banks of the Richmond River and is situated at the junction of the Bruxner Highway and the Summerland Way.

title: Tabulam
text: Tabulam is a rural village in the far north-east of New South Wales, Australia, 800 kilometres from the state capital, Sydney.

title: Tabulam
text: Tabulam is located on the Bruxner Highway (Highway 44) between Tenterfield and Casino and on the Clarence River.

title: Tabulam
text: According to the 2006 Census, there were 573 people living in Tabulam.

title: Tabulam
text: Tabulam is locally administered by Kyogle Council.

title: Bruxner Highway
text: The Bruxner Highway is a 420 km state highway located in New South Wales, Australia.

title: Bruxner Highway
text: The highway forms an east-west link from the Northern Rivers coast, across the Northern Tablelands in northern New South Wales, close to the border with Queensland.

title: Wollongbar, New South Wales
text: Wollongbar is a town (2011 population: 2,396) in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, Australia.

title: Wollongbar, New South Wales
text: The town is located on the Bruxner Highway between the towns of Lismore and Alstonville.

title: Alstonville, New South Wales
text: Alstonville (2011 population: 5,648) is a town in northern New South Wales, Australia, part of the region known as the Northern Rivers.

title: Alstonville, New South Wales
text: Alstonville is on the Bruxner Highway between the town of Ballina (13 km to the east) and city of Lismore (19 km to the west).

title: Alstonville, New South Wales
text: The village of Wollongbar is 4 km to the west of Alstonville.

title: Alstonville, New South Wales
text: Alstonville is the service centre of the area known as the Alstonville Plateau.

title: Richmond Valley Council
text: Richmond Valley Council (RVC) is a local government area on the Northern Rivers region of north-eastern New South Wales, Australia.

title: Richmond Valley Council
text: RVC services an area of 3051 km2 and draws its name from the Richmond River, which flows through most of the council area.

title: Richmond Valley Council
text: The area under management is located adjacent to the Bruxner Highway, Pacific Highway, and the North Coast railway line.

title: Mummulgum
text: Mummulgum is a small rural village in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, Australia, 740 kilometres from the state capital, Sydney.

title: Mummulgum
text: Mummulgum is located on Shannon Brook between Tenterfield and Casino on the Bruxner Highway (Highway 44).

title: Mummulgum
text: It is 58 km south-west of Kyogle with the village and surrounding area being locally administered by Kyogle Council.

title: Mummulgum
text: The nearest large town is Casino which is 27 kilometres east of Mummulgum.

title: Tenterfield, New South Wales
text: Tenterfield is a town in New South Wales, Australia.

title: Tenterfield, New South Wales
text: It is located in the New England region at the intersection of the New England and Bruxner Highway's.

title: Tenterfield, New South Wales
text: Tenterfield is a three-hour drive from Brisbane, Queensland, three hours from Byron Bay, New South Wales, two hours from Armidale, New South Wales and eight hours from Sydney.

title: Tenterfield, New South Wales
text: The town is situated on the north-western part of the Northern Tableland plateau, nestled in a valley, astride the Great Dividing Range and beneath the imposing Mount MacKenzie (1,287m elevation).

title: Tenterfield, New South Wales
text: At the 2015 census , Tenterfield had a population of 6,986.

title: Bonshaw, New South Wales
text: Bonshaw is a village in New South Wales, Australia 783 km north of Sydney.

title: Bonshaw, New South Wales
text: In 2006 the village had a population of 171 people in the district.

title: Bonshaw, New South Wales
text: It is located near the northern border of the State close to Texas, Queensland, from which it is separated by the Dumaresq River which forms the border between the states.

title: Bonshaw, New South Wales
text: Bonshaw is located in Inverell Shire and Arrawatta County.

title: Bonshaw, New South Wales
text: It is on the Bruxner Highway between Tenterfield and Goondiwindi.

title: Bonshaw, New South Wales
text: It is a village designed to serve the needs of the agricultural holdings in the area.

title: Goonellabah, New South Wales
text: Goonellabah is the eastern suburb of Lismore, New South Wales, Australia, and is on the Bruxner Highway.

title: Goonellabah, New South Wales
text: At the 2006 census, Goonellabah had a population of 12,527 people.

title: Owsley Stanley
text: Owsley Stanley (born Augustus Owsley Stanley III, January 19, 1935 – March 12, 2011) was an American audio engineer and clandestine chemist.

title: Owsley Stanley
text: He was a key figure in the San Francisco Bay Area hippie movement during the 1960s and played a pivotal role in the counterculture of the 1960s.

title: Owsley Stanley
text: Under the professional name Bear, he was the soundman for the rock band the Grateful Dead, whom he met when Ken Kesey invited them to an Acid Test party.

title: Owsley Stanley
text: As their sound engineer, Stanley frequently recorded live tapes behind his mixing board, designed their trademark skull logo, and developed their Wall of Sound sound system, one of the largest mobile public address systems ever constructed.

title: San Francisco Bay Area Water Trail
text: The San Francisco Bay Area Water Trail is a growing network of launch and landing sites that allow people in non-motorized small boats and beachable sail craft such as kayaks, canoes, dragon boats, stand up paddle and windsurf boards, to safely enjoy San Francisco Bay through single and multiple-day trips.

title: San Francisco Bay Area Water Trail
text: The Water Trail is enhancing Bay Area communities’ connections to the Bay and creating new linkages to existing shoreline open spaces and other regional trails as well as increasing education about personal safety, navigational safety, and appropriate boating behavior near sensitive wildlife species and shoreline habitat.

title: San Francisco Bay Area Water Trail
text: The Water Trail is implemented under the leadership of the California Coastal Conservancy in close collaboration with the Association of Bay Area Governments, the San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission, and the California Department of Boating and Waterways.

title: Ragazzi Boys Chorus
text: The Ragazzi Boys Chorus is a boys' and young men's chorus in the San Francisco Bay Area San Francisco Bay Area and is known for winning a Grammy Award for Best Classical Album in 2000 for its participation in Perséphone with the San Francisco Symphony.

title: Ragazzi Boys Chorus
text: The chorus was formed in 1987 with 6 boys, and it now includes more than 170 singers from 86 schools in 26 Bay Area communities including San Mateo, Santa Clara and Santa Cruz counties.

title: Ragazzi Boys Chorus
text: The choir has placed highly in numerous international competitions.

title: Ragazzi Boys Chorus
text: It also auditions the most singers to either national or state American Choral Directors Association honor choirs each year.

title: Gary Arlington
text: Gary Edson Arlington (October 7, 1938 – January 16, 2014) was an American retailer, artist, editor, and publisher, who became a key figure in the underground comix movement of the 1960s and 1970s.

title: Gary Arlington
text: As owner of America's first comic book store, the San Francisco Comic Book Company, located in San Francisco's Mission District, Arlington's establishment became a focal point for the Bay Area's underground artists.

title: Gary Arlington
text: He published comics under the name San Francisco Comic Book Company as well as Eric Fromm (not connected to the German critical theorist).

title: Gary Arlington
text: Cartoonist Robert Crumb has noted, "Gary made a cultural contribution in San Francisco in the late '60s, through the '70s, '80s & '90s that was more significant than he realizes."

title: Oakland, California
text: Oakland is the largest city and the county seat of Alameda County, California, United States.

title: Oakland, California
text: A major West Coast port city, Oakland is the largest city in the East Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area, the third largest city overall in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth largest city in California, and the 45th largest city in the United States, with a population of 419,267 as of 2015 .

title: Oakland, California
text: It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port in the San Francisco Bay, the entirety of Northern California, and the fifth busiest in the United States of America.

title: Oakland, California
text: The city was incorporated in 1852.

title: San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority
text: The San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority (SFBRA) is a government agency dedicated to preserving and restoring San Francisco Bay and its shoreline.

title: San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority
text: SFBRA was created by the California legislature in 2008.

title: San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority
text: It is headquartered in Oakland.

title: San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority
text: In 2016, the SFBRA placed a funding measure on the June ballots in all 9 San Francisco Bay Area counties.

title: San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority
text: The measure, known as the San Francisco Bay Clean Water, Pollution Prevention and Habitat Restoration Program or Measure AA, passed by the required 2/3 majority in the combined county vote.

title: San Francisco Bay Restoration Authority
text: The measure provides for $500 million in funding for the authority, to be used to restore wetlands and mitigate expected sea level rise.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: The Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG) is a regional planning agency incorporating various local governments in the San Francisco Bay Area in California.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: It encompasses nine counties surrounding the San Francisco Bay.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: Those counties are Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, Napa, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Solano, and Sonoma.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: It has the ability to establish housing and transportation goals for cities to minimize urban sprawl by that requiring housing be zoned for near new workplace construction.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: It deals with land use, housing, environmental quality, and economic development.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: Non-profit organizations as well as governmental organizations can be members.

title: Association of Bay Area Governments
text: All nine counties and 101 cities within the Bay Area are voluntary members of ABAG.

title: Codornices Creek
text: Codornices Creek (sometimes spelled and/or pronounced "Cordonices"), 2.0 mi long, is one of the principal creeks which runs out of the Berkeley Hills in the East Bay area of the San Francisco Bay Area in California.

title: Codornices Creek
text: In its upper stretch, it passes entirely within the city limits of Berkeley, and marks the city limit with the adjacent city of Albany in its lower section.

title: Codornices Creek
text: Before European settlement, Codornices probably had no direct, permanent connection to San Francisco Bay.

title: Codornices Creek
text: Like many other small creeks, it filtered through what early maps show as grassland to a large, northward-running salt marsh and slough that also carried waters from Marin Creek and Schoolhouse Creek.

title: Codornices Creek
text: A channel was cut through in the 19th Century, and Codornices flows directly to San Francisco Bay by way of a narrow remnant slough adjacent to Golden Gate Fields racetrack.

title: Jory Prum
text: Jory Prum (January 31, 1975 – April 22, 2016), also known as Jory K. Prum, was an American audio engineer, best known for his work in film and video games.

title: Jory Prum
text: He was the owner of a recording studio located in the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: Key System
text: The Key System (or Key Route) was a privately owned company that provided mass transit in the cities of Oakland, Berkeley, Alameda, Emeryville, Piedmont, San Leandro, Richmond, Albany and El Cerrito in the eastern San Francisco Bay Area from 1903 until 1960, when it was sold to a newly formed public agency, AC Transit.

title: Key System
text: The Key System consisted of local streetcar and bus lines in the East Bay, and commuter rail and bus lines connecting the East Bay to San Francisco by a ferry pier on San Francisco Bay, later via the lower deck of the Bay Bridge.

title: Key System
text: At its height during the 1940s, the Key System had over 66 mi of track.

title: Key System
text: The local streetcars were discontinued in 1948 and the commuter trains to San Francisco were discontinued in 1958.

title: Key System
text: The Key System's territory is today served by BART and AC Transit bus service.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital was founded in 1531 by Bishop Gavin Dunbar, the Elder.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The hospital was endowed by a mortification just before his death.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: Dunbar petitioned the King, James V of Scotland, and the charter, signed on 24 February 1531 records the King’s approval that ‘ ... "found an hospital near the cathedral church, but outside the cemetery"...’ It was also known as St Mary's Hospital.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: In the mortification, Dunbar's charitable purpose is recorded.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: Bedesmen were supported by a charitable foundation that emerged from the original church control until the twenty-first century.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: Bedesmen drew their name from the word "bede" - a prayer.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The residents of Dunbar's Hospital said prayers in a cycle of Divine Office.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The Bede House, Old Aberdeen was used by the Bedesmen from the hospital from 1789 to the end of the nineteenth century.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The only remains of the 1531 building can be seen in a perimeter wall for Seaton Park in Old Aberdeen.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The last Bedesman died in 1988.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The Managers of the Hospital constituted a Charity, Bishop Dunbar Hospital Trust.

title: Bishop Dunbar's Hospital
text: The Charity ceased active operation in 2012.

title: Columba de Dunbar
text: Columba de Dunbar ( 1386 – 1435) was Bishop of Moray from 1422 until his death at Spynie Palace near Elgin sometime before 7 November 1435.

title: Haripur Barabari
text: Haripur Barabari (Bengali: হরিপুর বড়বাড়ি ), is a palace in Horipur Union of Nasirnagar Upazila at Brahmanbaria district, Bangladesh earlier known as East Bengal.

title: Haripur Barabari
text: This palace founded by Jamindar Krishna Prasad Roy Choudhury(1870-1936) in eighteenth century.

title: Patrick IV, Earl of March
text: Patrick IV, Earl of March (1242 – 10 October 1308), sometimes called Patrick de Dunbar "8th" Earl of March, was the most important magnate in the border regions of Scotland.

title: Patrick IV, Earl of March
text: He was one of the Competitors for the Crown of Scotland.

title: George II, Earl of March
text: George de Dunbar, 11th Earl of Dunbar & March Lord of Annandale and the Isle of Man, (c. 1370 – after 1457) was the last of his family to hold these titles.

title: Gospatric, Earl of Northumbria
text: Gospatric or Cospatric (from the Cumbric "Servant of Saint Patrick"), (died after 1073), was Earl of Northumbria, or of Bernicia, and later lord of sizable estates around Dunbar.

title: Gospatric, Earl of Northumbria
text: While his paternal ancestry is uncertain, his descendants held the Earldom of Dunbar, later known as the Earldom of March, in south-east Scotland until 1435.

title: Patrick V, Earl of March
text: Patrick de Dunbar, 9th Earl of March, (c. 1285–1369) was a prominent Scottish magnate during the reigns of Robert the Bruce and David II.

title: Mike Dunbar
text: Mike Dunbar (December 31, 1948 – September 13, 2013) was an American football and baseball coach.

title: Mike Dunbar
text: He served as the head football coach at Central Washington University in 1983 and from 1987 to 1991 and at the University of Northern Iowa from 1997 to 2000, compiling a career college football coaching record of 83–24–1.

title: Mike Dunbar
text: Dunbar was also the head baseball coach at Central Washington for one season, in 1983, tallying mark of 25–20–1.

title: Mike Dunbar
text: He graduated from the University of Washington in 1972 with a B.A. in education and from Pacific Lutheran University in 1979 with an M.A. in education.

title: Mike Dunbar
text: Dunbar died of cancer on September 13, 2013, in his hometown of Dupont, Washington, at the age of 64.

title: George I, Earl of March
text: George de Dunbar, 10th Earl of Dunbar and March (1338–1420), 12th Lord of Annandale and Lord of the Isle of Man, was "one of the most powerful nobles in Scotland of his time, and the rival of the Douglases."

title: Earl of Dunbar
text: The title Earl of Dunbar, also called Earl of Lothian or Earl of March, was the head of a comital lordship in south-eastern Scotland between the early 12th century and the early 15th century.

title: Earl of Dunbar
text: The first man to use the title of Earl in this earldom was Gospatric II, Earl of Lothian, son of Gospatric, Earl of Northumbria.

title: Earl of Dunbar
text: It descended to George de Dunbar, 11th Earl of March, who was forfeited by parliament of his titles & estates in 1435, and retired into obscurity in England.

title: Earl of Dunbar
text: His son Patrick retained a barony at Kilconquhar in Fife.

title: Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame
text: The Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame is a collection of plaques, mounted on a brick wall in the Ashburn Alley section of Citizens Bank Park, the ballpark of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame
text: From 1978 to 2003, the Phillies inducted one figure from their franchise history and one notable person from the Philadelphia Athletics (A's) organization each year—with the exception of 1983, when the Phillies inducted their Centennial Team.

title: Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame
text: Once Veterans Stadium closed in 2003, the wall plaques used to recognize the Phillies' members were moved to Citizens Bank Park; however, the Phillies no longer induct notable Athletics.

title: Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame
text: Each person inducted into the Wall of Fame was honored with a metal plaque showing the person's face; their position with, and years of service to, the team; and a summary of their most important contributions.

title: Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame
text: In March 2004, the Athletics' plaques were relocated to the Philadelphia Athletics Historical Society in Hatboro, Pennsylvania, and a single plaque listing all of the A's inductees was attached to a statue of Connie Mack located across the street from Citizens Bank Park.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: The Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop, also known as McGuire Motor Company and Crandall's Electric Service, is a historic structure located in Fairfield, Iowa, United States.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: The monorail system is located in a former auto repair shop along an alley between East Broadway Avenue and East Briggs Avenue.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: It is the rear, single-story, portion of the building at 117 E. Broadway Ave where the system is located.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: The storefront portion of the building, also historically associated with the automobile industry, is a two-story brick building built on a stone foundation.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: The east side of the central business district in Fairfield had become the center for automobile related businesses by the 1920s.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: Harley Carter bought this building in 1920, and had the monorail system, manufactured by the Louden Machinery Company, installed about 1922.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: The overhead material handling system is permanently attached to the east wall of the shop.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: It allowed the mechanics to more easily move the heavy engines and other parts to and from vehicles.

title: Louden Monorail System in the Auto Repair Shop
text: The structure was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1999.

title: Gum Wall
text: The Market Theater Gum Wall is a brick wall covered in used chewing gum, in an alleyway in downtown Seattle.

title: Gum Wall
text: It is located in Post Alley under Pike Place Market.

title: Gum Wall
text: Similar to Bubblegum Alley in San Luis Obispo, California, the Market Theater Gum Wall is a local landmark.

title: Gum Wall
text: Parts of the wall can be covered several inches thick, 15 feet high for 50 feet.

title: Up Your Alley Fair
text: The Up Your Alley Fair, most commonly referred to by locals as Dore Alley Fair or simply Dore Alley is a leather and fetish event held in San Francisco, California on the last Sunday of July on Folsom Street between 9th and 10th Streets and on Dore Street from Howard Street to half a block southeast of Folsom Street.

title: Up Your Alley Fair
text: The streets are lined with vendors' booths, and a sound stage (for dancing) is located at the 10th Street end of Folsom Street.

title: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley
text: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley, also known as Louviers and Duck Street, is a historic home located near Wilmington, New Castle County, Delaware.

title: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley
text: It was built in 1811, and is a two- to three-story, five bay, stuccoed stone dwelling.

title: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley
text: The three center bays project slightly from the main body of the house.

title: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley
text: In 1935, a kitchen wing was added to the other end of the house plus a gated wall and garage.

title: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley
text: The house was owned by the Du Pont family.

title: Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley
text: Also on the property is "Chicken Alley," an excellent example of the 19th century workers' row house.

title: Bubblegum Alley
text: Bubblegum Alley is a tourist attraction in downtown San Luis Obispo, California, known for its accumulation of used bubble gum on the walls of an alley.

title: Bubblegum Alley
text: It is a 15 ft high and 70 ft long alley lined with chewed gum left by passers-by.

title: Bubblegum Alley
text: It covers a stretch of 20 meters in the 700 block of Higuera Street in downtown San Luis Obispo.

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: Ouch!

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: is a type of sugar-free bubble gum made by the Wm. Wrigley Jr.

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: Company under the Hubba Bubba brand name.

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: By the 1990s, the gum was available in the flavors of grape, watermelon, and strawberry.

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: Each stick of gum was wrapped with paper made to look like a bandage and was packaged in a metallic container similar to that of a bandage box.

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: In October 2009, the gum was redesigned to have a new look and packaging, and is now also available in bubblegum flavor.

title: Ouch! (gum)
text: Each pack comes with one of a possible twenty collectable games inside.

title: Old US 67 Rest Area
text: The Old US 67 Rest Area is a historic roadside rest area in rural Clark County, Arkansas.

title: Old US 67 Rest Area
text: It is located in on the west side of U.S. Route 67 (US 67) and an old paved section formerly designated Highway 51, between the small towns of Curtis and Gum Springs.

title: Old US 67 Rest Area
text: The rest area consists of a semicircular fieldstone retaining wall, which is segmented by six fieldstone pillars.

title: Old US 67 Rest Area
text: A semicircular concrete bench stands facing a fieldstone well.

title: Old US 67 Rest Area
text: The rest area was built five years after US 67 was paved in 1931, by the National Youth Administration, a federal New Deal agency, and the state highway department.

title: Digital Media Factory
text: The Digital Media Factory is a multi-media design, production and post-production facility founded by Marty Collins and wife, Ginny Mitchell along with partners Ned Hearn and Brian Critchlow.

title: Digital Media Factory
text: They are located in Santa Cruz, California in the former Wrigley Gum manufacturing facility located at 2809 Mission Street on the west end of Santa Cruz.

title: Hollywood Star Lanes
text: Hollywood Star Lanes was a 32-lane bowling alley located on Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles, California.

title: Hollywood Star Lanes
text: Open from 1960 to 2002, the alley was featured in the movies "The Big Lebowski" and "The Big Empty", which was filmed on location over three weeks of the eleven-week filming schedule.

title: Hollywood Star Lanes
text: In 2002, the alley was closed after the Los Angeles Unified School District seized the land by eminent domain, with the goal of building an elementary school at the site.

title: Dead or Alive 5 Plus
text: Dead or Alive 5 Plus (stylized as "Dead or Alive 5+" and abbreviated to "DOA5+") is a fighting game in the "Dead or Alive" series, developed by Team Ninja in partnership with Sega AM2 and released by Tecmo Koei for the PlayStation Vita in March 2013.

title: Dead or Alive 5 Plus
text: An expanded handheld port of the 2012 game "Dead or Alive 5", "DOA5+" was met with positive critical reception, gaining better scores than the original.

title: 2008 Fiesta Bowl
text: The 2008 Tostitos Fiesta Bowl was a college football bowl game.

title: 2008 Fiesta Bowl
text: It was part of the 2007–2008 Bowl Championship Series (BCS) of the 2007 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2008 Fiesta Bowl
text: Played annually since 1971, first at Sun Devil Stadium on the campus of Arizona State University in Tempe, Arizona through 2006, the game was played at 8 p.m. EST on January 2, 2008, at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Arizona.

title: 2008 Fiesta Bowl
text: The game featured the fourth ranked (BCS), Big 12 champion Oklahoma Sooners hosting the ninth ranked (BCS), Big East champion West Virginia Mountaineers.

title: 2008 Fiesta Bowl
text: West Virginia defeated Oklahoma by a score of 48–28.

title: 2008 Fiesta Bowl
text: The contest was televised on Fox.

title: 1989 Cotton Bowl Classic
text: The 1989 Mobil Cotton Bowl Classic was a college football bowl game played on January 2, 1989, at the Cotton Bowl in Dallas, Texas.

title: 1989 Cotton Bowl Classic
text: The game was played on January 2, the day after New Year's Day, since New Year's Day fell on a Sunday.

title: 1989 Cotton Bowl Classic
text: The bowl game featured the Arkansas Razorbacks from the Southwest Conference and the UCLA Bruins from the Pacific-10 Conference and was televised in the United States on CBS.

title: 1989 Cotton Bowl Classic
text: Troy Aikman, the UCLA quarterback and LaSalle Harper, an Arkansas linebacker were named the Most Valuable Players of the game.

title: 2013 Sugar Bowl
text: The 2013 Allstate Sugar Bowl was a postseason college football bowl game on Wednesday, January 2, 2013, at the Mercedes-Benz Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana.

title: 2013 Sugar Bowl
text: The game featured the Florida Gators of the SEC and the Louisville Cardinals of the Big East.

title: 2013 Sugar Bowl
text: The game was broadcast live on ESPN at 8:30 PM ET.

title: 2013 Sugar Bowl
text: Louisville was selected to their first Sugar Bowl after a 10-2 regular season that culminated in a share of the Big East title.

title: 2013 Sugar Bowl
text: Florida was picked as the other half of the matchup following an 11–1 campaign.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament was held in March at Municipal Auditorium in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The 19th annual NAIA basketball tournament featured 32 teams playing in a single-elimination format.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: 1956 would be the last year for unseeded teams going into the tournament.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The championship game featured McNeese State University (La.) and Texas Southern University.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: It was the first and only appearance for the McNeese State made in the NAIA tournament.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The Cowboys beat the Tigers 60 to 55.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The third place game featured Pittsburg State University (Ks.)

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: Gorillas who defeated the Wheaton College (Ill.) Thunder 77 to 70.

title: 1956 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: This tournament featured six all-time leading scorers.

title: 2017 NHL Winter Classic
text: The 2017 NHL Winter Classic (officially the 2017 Bridgestone NHL Winter Classic) was a regular-season outdoor National Hockey League (NHL) game that was held on January 2, 2017.

title: 2017 NHL Winter Classic
text: The game featured the St. Louis Blues taking on the Chicago Blackhawks at Busch Stadium in St. Louis, Missouri, home of Major League Baseball's Cardinals.

title: 2017 NHL Winter Classic
text: The game was announced on March 9, 2016, after news of the matchup had been leaked on February 7 before the details had been finalized, and was one of four outdoor regular-season games during the 2016–17 NHL season.

title: 1989 Fiesta Bowl
text: The 1989 Sunkist Fiesta Bowl, played on January 2, 1989, was the 18th edition of the Fiesta Bowl.

title: 1989 Fiesta Bowl
text: The game featured the Notre Dame Fighting Irish, and the West Virginia Mountaineers.

title: 1989 Fiesta Bowl
text: With both teams coming into the game undefeated, the Fiesta Bowl was the stage for the "National Championship" for the second time in three years.

title: 1989 Fiesta Bowl
text: As in 1987, the Fiesta Bowl featured two independent schools squaring off for the national title.

title: 1989 Fiesta Bowl
text: However, it was not a #1 vs. #2 matchup as the second-ranked Miami Hurricanes, like Notre Dame and West Virginia independent, chose to play in the Orange Bowl.

title: 1943 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The 1943 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament was held in March at Municipal Auditorium in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: 1943 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The 7th annual NAIA basketball tournament featured 32 teams playing in a single-elimination format.

title: 1943 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The championship game featured Southeast Missouri State University defeating Northwest Missouri State University 34 to 32.

title: 1943 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: This was the first tournament to feature a championship game between two teams from the same state, Missouri, playing in Missouri.

title: 1943 NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
text: The 3rd place game featured the first overtime in the NAIA Final Four history when North Texas State University defeated Murray State College 59 to 55 in one overtime.

title: List of NBL Canada All-Stars
text: The National Basketball League of Canada (NBL) All-Star Game is an annual exhibition basketball played between the Central and Atlantic Division All-Stars.

title: List of NBL Canada All-Stars
text: Ten players—five starters and five reserves—from each division are chosen from the league's rosters.

title: List of NBL Canada All-Stars
text: The following is a list of NBL Canada All-Stars, players who have been selected by the coaches to compete in the prestigious event at the All-Star Weekend.

title: List of NBL Canada All-Stars
text: No player has played in three or more All-Star Games, especially due to the exclusion of the 2015 game, but ten have competed at this stage on multiple occasions.

title: List of NBL Canada All-Stars
text: Joey Haywood and Eddie Smith were the captains of the 2012 game, in which the All-Stars were divided into teams regardless of which division their team played in.

title: Parkway Field
text: Parkway Field is the name of a minor league baseball and college baseball park that stood in Louisville, Kentucky.

title: Parkway Field
text: It was home to the Louisville Colonels of the American Association from 1923 into the mid-1950s, the Louisville Buckeyes of the Negro American League in 1949, and then of the University of Louisville team for several decades until they abandoned it in 1998 and moved to Cardinal Stadium.

title: Parkway Field
text: Prior to its demolition, Parkway Field had become a home run haven for U of L Head Coach Gene Baker's "Over the Wall Gang."

title: Parkway Field
text: The Cards led NCAA Division I in long balls in 1991 and 1992 while finishing runnerup in 1995.

title: Parkway Field
text: The 1991 squad featured six Cardinals who tallied at least 15 roundtrippers each, Richie Hawks, Rob Newman, Greg Gooding, Dan Kopriva, Charlie Allen, and Darren Oppel.

title: Parkway Field
text: The 1992 club also topped the nation in team batting average and team slugging percentage.

title: LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton
text: LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton is a 2001 American documentary film directed by Deborah Dickson, Susan Frömke and Albert Maysles.

title: LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton
text: It was nominated for Best Documentary Feature at the 74th Academy Awards.

title: Keith Richards
text: Keith Richards (born 18 December 1943) is an English guitarist, singer, songwriter, and author, best known as a founder member of the rock band the Rolling Stones. "

title: Keith Richards
text: Rolling Stone" magazine credited Richards for "rock's greatest single body of riffs" on guitar and ranked him 4th on its list of 100 best guitarists.

title: Keith Richards
text: Fourteen songs that Richards wrote with the Rolling Stones' lead vocalist Mick Jagger are listed among "Rolling Stone" magazine's "500 Greatest Songs of All Time".

title: Keith Richards
text: The Stones are generally known for their guitar interplay of rhythm and lead ("weaving") between Richards and Brian Jones, Mick Taylor and Ronnie Wood over the years.

title: Keith Richards
text: In spite of this, Richards plays the only guitar tracks on some of their most famous songs including "Paint It Black", "Ruby Tuesday", "Sympathy for the Devil" and "Gimme Shelter".

title: Merry Clayton
text: Merry Clayton (born December 25, 1948) is an American soul and gospel singer and an actress.

title: Merry Clayton
text: She provided a number of backing vocal tracks for major performing artists in the 1960s, most notably in her duet with Mick Jagger on the Rolling Stones song "Gimme Shelter."

title: Merry Clayton
text: Clayton is featured in "20 Feet from Stardom", the Oscar-winning documentary about background singers and their contributions to the music industry.

title: Merry Clayton
text: In 2013, she released "The Best of Merry Clayton", a compilation of her favorite songs.

title: Gimme Shelter (1970 film)
text: Gimme Shelter is a 1970 documentary film directed by Albert and David Maysles and Charlotte Zwerin chronicling the last weeks of The Rolling Stones' 1969 US tour which culminated in the disastrous Altamont Free Concert.

title: Gimme Shelter (1970 film)
text: The film is named after "Gimme Shelter", the lead track from the group's 1969 album "Let It Bleed".

title: Gimme Shelter (1970 film)
text: The film was screened at the 1971 Cannes Film Festival, but was not entered into the main competition.

title: Baird Bryant
text: Wenzell Baird Bryant (Columbus, Indiana, December 12, 1927 – Hemet, California, November 13, 2008) was an American filmmaker.

title: Baird Bryant
text: He is best known as the cameraman on the Albert Maysles film "Gimme Shelter" who filmed the fatal stabbing of Rolling Stones concertgoer Meredith Hunter by Hells Angel Alan Passaro at the Altamont Free Concert in December 1969.

title: Gimme Shelter (album)
text: Gimme Shelter is a compilation by The Rolling Stones, released on Decca Records in 1971.

title: Gimme Shelter (album)
text: It reached #19 on the U.K chart.

title: Gimme Shelter
text: "Gimme Shelter" is the opening track to the 1969 album Let It Bleed by the Rolling Stones.

title: Gimme Shelter
text: Although the first word was spelled "Gimmie" on that album, subsequent recordings by the band and other musicians have made "Gimme" the customary spelling.

title: Gimme Shelter
text: Greil Marcus, writing in "Rolling Stone" magazine at the time of its release, praised the song, stating that the band has "never done anything better."

title: Altamont Diary
text: Alamont Diary is the debut album by Melbourne electronica band Black Cab.

title: Altamont Diary
text: Released in 2004, it is a concept album based on the ill-fated 1969 free concert at Altamont Speedway in California headlined by the Rolling Stones.

title: Altamont Diary
text: The album, whose genre is described a psych-country, features audio samples of former Stones tour manager Sam Cutler, taken from the 1970 documentary film "Gimme Shelter".

title: Gimme Shelter (disambiguation)
text: "Gimme Shelter" is a song by The Rolling Stones.

title: Stanton Y. Hill
text: Stanton Hill is an American broadcast producer and voice actor.

title: Stanton Y. Hill
text: He has produced television commercials for clients such as Pepsi, Activision, Nissan, Budweiser, McDonald's, Energizer, Jimmy Dean, and Visa.

title: Stanton Y. Hill
text: In 2007 he produced the award winning short film "Stars" starring Kevin Durand and directed by Jason Eli Lewis.

title: Stanton Y. Hill
text: In 2011 Hill produced the launch commercial for Call of Duty: Black Ops featuring Kobe Bryant and the Rolling Stones "Gimme Shelter".

title: Catan: Cities & Knights
text: Catan: Cities & Knights (German: "Städte und Ritter" ), formerly "The Cities and Knights of Catan" is an expansion to the board game "The Settlers of Catan" for three to four players (five to six player play is also possible with the "Settlers" and "Cities & Knights" five to six player extensions; two-player play is possible with the "" expansion).

title: Catan: Cities & Knights
text: It contains features taken from "The Settlers of Catan", with emphasis on city development and the use of knights, which are used as a method of attacking other players as well as helping opponents defend Catan against a common foe.

title: Catan: Cities & Knights
text: "Cities & Knights" can also be combined with the "" expansion or with scenarios (again, five to six player play only possible with the applicable five to six player extension(s)).

title: Catan (2008 video game)
text: Catan is a PlayStation 3 video game developed by Game Republic.

title: Catan (2008 video game)
text: "Catan" is an original adaptation of Klaus Teuber's board game "The Settlers of Catan"; it is not a port of the 2007 XBLA adaptation by Big Huge Games.

title: Catan (2008 video game)
text: The download was released in Japan on December 18, 2008 for 1200 yen.

title: Catan (2008 video game)
text: The game has since expanded to other territories.

title: Struggle for Rome (board game)
text: Catan Histories: Struggle for Rome is a 2006 German-style board game based on the game mechanics of "Settlers of Catan", depicting the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

title: Struggle for Rome (board game)
text: The game is created by Klaus Teuber, the creator of "Settlers", and is published under license from Catan GmbH by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English.

title: Struggle for Rome (board game)
text: It is the second game in the "Catan Histories" series of board games.

title: Struggle for Rome (board game)
text: Often games produced in different languages by different publishers have slight rule differences between the versions.

title: Struggle for Rome (board game)
text: Catan Histories: Struggle for Rome is no exception.

title: Catan
text: The Settlers of Catan, sometimes shortened to Catan or Settlers, is a multiplayer board game designed by Klaus Teuber and first published in 1995 in Germany by Franckh-Kosmos Verlag (Kosmos) as Die Siedler von Catan.

title: Catan
text: Players assume the roles of settlers, each attempting to build and develop holdings while trading and acquiring resources.

title: Catan
text: Players are awarded points as their settlements grow; the first to reach a set number of points, typically 10, is the winner.

title: Catan
text: The game and its many expansions are also published by Mayfair Games, Filosofia, Capcom, 999 Games, Κάισσα, and Devir.

title: Catan Card Game
text: The Catan Card Game, originally named The Settlers of Catan: The Card Game, is a card game adaptation of "The Settlers of Catan".

title: Catan Card Game
text: It is a member of the "Catan" series of games, and is published by Kosmos in German, and Mayfair Games in English.

title: Catan Card Game
text: The "Catan Card Game" is a two-player game, although the rules can be accommodated as to allow players to share a set or for each player to have their own.

title: Catan Card Game
text: Seven expansions of the "Catan Card Game" have been released.

title: Catan Dice Game
text: Catan Dice Game is a German-style board game, developed by Klaus Teuber and published in 2007 by Catan GmbH and its licensors, Kosmos in Germany and Mayfair Games in English-speaking countries.

title: Catan Dice Game
text: It is a dice game re-imagining of Teuber's most notable title, "Settlers of Catan".

title: Catan Dice Game
text: "Catan Dice Game" can be played by any number of players, but is ideally suited for up to four.

title: Catan Dice Game
text: A variation, known as "Catan Dice Game Plus", is freely available from the "Catan" website, whose gameplay is closer to its "Settlers" origins.

title: Elasund
text: Elasund: The First City (German: "Elasund - Die erste Stadt" ; ] ) is a German-style board game designed by Klaus Teuber.

title: Elasund
text: It is the second game in the "Catan Adventures" series (the first being ""), a series of spinoff games based on the theme from Teuber's hit game "The Settlers of Catan" as well as its German-language novelization by Rebecca Gablé.

title: Elasund
text: As a game in the "Catan" series, it is published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English.

title: Elasund
text: Despite the thematic connection between "Elasund" and "Settlers", the two games have completely different mechanics.

title: Catan: Seafarers
text: Catan: Seafarers, or Seafarers of Catan in older editions, (German: "Die Seefahrer von Catan" ) is an expansion of the board game "The Settlers of Catan" for three to four players (five-to-six-player play is also possible with both of the respective five-to-six-player extensions).

title: Catan: Seafarers
text: The main feature of this expansion is the addition of ships, gold rivers, and the pirate to the game, allowing play between multiple islands.

title: Catan: Seafarers
text: The expansion also provides numerous scenarios, some of which have custom rules.

title: Catan: Seafarers
text: The "Seafarers" rules and scenarios are also, for the most part, compatible with "" and "".

title: The Kids of Catan
text: The Kids of Catan is a German board game designed for children using the theme from "The Settlers of Catan".

title: The Kids of Catan
text: Like other Catan titles, the game is created by Klaus Teuber and published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English.

title: The Rivals for Catan
text: The Rivals for Catan (German: "Die Fürsten von Catan" ) is an updated revision of the "Catan Card Game", a card game adaptation of "The Settlers of Catan".

title: The Rivals for Catan
text: The game was released in 2010.

title: The Rivals for Catan
text: It is a member of the "Catan" series of games, and is published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English.

title: The Rivals for Catan
text: Like its predecessor, "The Rivals for Catan" is a two-player game.

title: The Rivals for Catan
text: As with the "Catan Adventures" series of games, the theme is based on the Rebecca Gablé novel "The Settlers of Catan", a novel based on the original board game.

title: Tomb Raider III
text: Tomb Raider III: Adventures of Lara Croft, or simply Tomb Raider III, is an action-adventure video game developed by Core Design and published by Eidos Interactive.

title: Tomb Raider III
text: It was originally released for the PlayStation and Microsoft Windows platforms in 1998.

title: Tomb Raider III
text: "Tomb Raider III" is the third title in the "Tomb Raider" video game series and a sequel to "Tomb Raider II".

title: Tomb Raider III
text: The story of the game follows archaeologist-adventurer Lara Croft as she embarks upon a quest to recover four pieces of a meteorite that are scattered across the world.

title: Tomb Raider III
text: To progress through the game, the player must explore five locations (India, South Pacific, London, Nevada, and Antarctica) and complete a series of levels that involve solving puzzles, jumping over obstacles, and defeating enemies.

title: Lara Croft Go
text: Lara Croft Go is a 2015 turn-based puzzle video game in the "Tomb Raider" series.

title: Lara Croft Go
text: The player moves Lara Croft as a puzzle piece through a board game while avoiding obstacles and manipulating the environment.

title: Lara Croft Go
text: The developers distilled major series motifs, such as boulder chases and reaction-based gameplay, to suit "Lara Croft Go"'s time-independent gameplay.

title: Lara Croft Go
text: Square Enix Montreal developed the game as a spiritual successor to its 2014 "Hitman Go", based on another Square Enix franchise.

title: Lara Croft Go
text: The company released "Lara Croft Go" in August 2015 for Android, iOS, Windows, and Windows Phone devices.

title: Lara Croft Go
text: A version for PlayStation 4 and PlayStation Vita was unveiled in November 2016.

title: Lara Croft
text: Lara Croft is a fictional character and the main protagonist of the Square Enix (previously Eidos Interactive) video game franchise "Tomb Raider".

title: Lara Croft
text: She is presented as a highly intelligent, athletic, and beautiful English archaeologist-adventurer who ventures into ancient, hazardous tombs and ruins around the world.

title: Lara Croft
text: Created by a team at UK developer Core Design that included Toby Gard, the character first appeared in the 1996 video game "Tomb Raider".

title: Lara Croft
text: She has also appeared in video game sequels, printed adaptations, a series of animated short films, feature films (portrayed by Angelina Jolie, later by Alicia Vikander), and merchandise related to the series.

title: Lara Croft
text: Official promotion of the character includes a brand of apparel and accessories, action figures, and model portrayals.

title: Lara Croft
text: Croft has also been licensed for third-party promotion, including television and print advertisements, music-related appearances, and as a spokesmodel.

title: Lara Croft
text: As of June 2016, Lara Croft has been featured on over 1,100 magazine covers surpassing any supermodel.

title: Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris
text: Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris is an action-adventure game developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 4 and Xbox One.

title: Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris
text: It is the sequel to the 2010 video game "Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light", and the second instalment in "Lara Croft" spin-off series of the "Tomb Raider" franchise.

title: Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris
text: The video game was announced at E3 2014 on 9 June.

title: Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris
text: "Temple of Osiris" stars "Tomb Raider" mainstay protagonist Lara Croft, voiced by English actress Keeley Hawes.

title: Alice David
text: Alice David (born 22 March 1987) is a French actress, known for the television series "Bref" (2011) and the film "Babysitting" (2014).

title: Alice David
text: She is the voice of the French dub of Lara Croft in the video game "Tomb Raider".

title: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
text: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light is an action-adventure game developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Android and, iOS through digital distribution.

title: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
text: It is part of the "Tomb Raider" series, but unlike previous games, the game does not carry the "Tomb Raider" brand and has a heavy emphasis on cooperative gameplay.

title: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
text: In multiplayer, players take the role as either Lara Croft or a 2,000-year-old Mayan warrior named Totec.

title: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
text: They must work together in order to stop the evil spirit Xolotl and retrieve the Mirror of Smoke.

title: Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light
text: A single-player campaign mode is available that does not include the non-playable character AI following or helping Lara.

title: Toby Gard
text: Toby Gard (born 1972 in Chelmsford, Essex) is an English computer game character designer and consultant, notably being part of the team that created fictional female British archaeologist Lara Croft.

title: Toby Gard
text: Lara Croft was awarded a "Guinness World Record" recognizing her as the "most successful human video game heroine."

title: Lara Croft: Tomb Raider
text: Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (also known as simply Tomb Raider) is a 2001 action-adventure film based on the popular "Tomb Raider" video game series featuring the character Lara Croft portrayed by Angelina Jolie.

title: Lara Croft: Tomb Raider
text: An international co-production between the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, and Germany, it was directed by Simon West and revolves around Lara Croft trying to obtain ancient artifacts from the enemy, the Illuminati.

title: Tomb Raider
text: Tomb Raider, also known as Lara Croft: Tomb Raider between 2001 and 2007, is a media franchise that originated with an action-adventure video game series created by British gaming company Core Design.

title: Tomb Raider
text: Formerly owned by Eidos Interactive, then by Square Enix after their acquisition of Eidos in 2009, the franchise focuses on a fictional English archaeologist Lara Croft, who travels around the world searching for lost artifacts and infiltrating dangerous tombs and ruins.

title: Tomb Raider
text: The gameplay generally focuses around action-adventure exploration of environments, solving puzzles, navigating hostile environments filled with traps, and fighting numerous enemies.

title: Tomb Raider
text: Additional media has grown up around the theme in the form of film adaptations, comics and novels.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: Tomb Raider is a media franchise consisting of action-adventure games, comic books, novels, theme park rides, and movies, centring on the adventures of the female fictional British archaeologist Lara Croft.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: Since the release of the original "Tomb Raider" in 1996, the series developed into a lucrative franchise of related media, and Lara went on to become a major icon of the video game industry.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: The "Guinness Book of World Records" has recognised Lara Croft as the "Most Successful Human Videogame Heroine" in 2006.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: Six games in the series were developed by Core Design, and the latest four by Crystal Dynamics.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: All the games were first published by Eidos Interactive, now Eidos officially became part of Square Enix on 22 April 2009, meaning Square Enix owns the rights to the "Tomb Raider" trademark and characters of the franchise.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: To date two movies, "" and "", have been produced starring American actress Angelina Jolie as Lara Croft.

title: List of Tomb Raider media
text: A reboot was announced in 2016.

title: You and Me (Uniting Nations song)
text: "You and Me" is the second single of the UK act Uniting Nations immediately following the big success of "Out of Touch", Uniting Nations' remake of a Hall and Oats hit.

title: You and Me (Uniting Nations song)
text: The single also appears in the Uniting Nations album "One World".

title: You and Me (Uniting Nations song)
text: The song fronted the newcoming member of the band Craig Powell.

title: You and Me (Uniting Nations song)
text: The track also included vocals from studio session artist Jinian Wilde.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: American rock band Linkin Park has recorded material for seven studio albums, the most recent being One More Light in 2017.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: A single from the album titled "Heavy" was released worldwide.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: The band was formed in Los Angeles, California, in 1996 by three high school friends; Mike Shinoda, Rob Bourdon, and Brad Delson.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: The group later expanded to a six piece when they added Joe Hahn, Dave "Phoenix" Farrell, and Mark Wakefield to the line-up.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: Mark Wakefield was later changed by lead vocalist Chester Bennington.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: After facing numerous rejections from several major record labels, Linkin Park turned to Jeff Blue for additional help.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: After failing to catch Warner Bros.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: Records on three previous reviews, Jeff Blue, now the vice president of Warner Bros.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: Records, helped the band sign a deal with the company in 1999.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: The band released its breakthrough album, "Hybrid Theory", the following year.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: The album produced four singles, "One Step Closer", "Crawling", "Papercut" and "In the End".

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: The album included a total of twelve songs in addition with two special edition tracks available in Japan.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: Later in 2002 the band released a Remix album "Reanimation", which would include works from "Hybrid Theory" and non-album tracks.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: "Reanimation" debuted on July 30, 2002, featuring the likes of Black Thought, Jonathan Davis, Aaron Lewis, and many others.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: "Reanimation" claimed the second spot on the "Billboard" 200, and sold nearly 270,000 copies during its debut week.

title: List of songs recorded by Linkin Park
text: The remix album included twenty remixed songs, mainly hip-hop influenced.

title: Better Off Alone
text: "Better Off Alone" is a song by Alice Deejay, the trance music project of Dutch producer Jürgen Rijkers (DJ Jurgen) in collaboration with Sebastiaan Moljin and Eelke Kahlberg (Pronti & Kalmani).

title: Better Off Alone
text: In 1998, the song was released as an instrumental by DJ Jurgen on Violent Records.

title: Better Off Alone
text: Later releases of the track included vocals by Judith Pronk, who would later become a seminal part of the Alice Deejay project.

title: Rabid Neurosis
text: Rabid Neurosis (RNS) was an MP3 warez release organization which was founded in 1996, following in the footsteps of Compress 'Da Audio (CDA), the first MP3 piracy group.

title: Rabid Neurosis
text: In 1999, the group claimed to have released over 6,000 titles a year.

title: Rabid Neurosis
text: RNS occasionally used the tagline "Rabid Neurosis - Spread The Epidemic."

title: Rabid Neurosis
text: RNS were best known for releasing highly anticipated albums by hip hop, pop, rock and dance artists weeks and sometimes months before their official release date.

title: Rabid Neurosis
text: RNS is known to have greatly contributed to the mp3 scene.

title: Rabid Neurosis
text: After their group was mentioned in an MTV News article about the early leak of the Eminem album "Encore", RNS stopped including their initials in filenames and ID3 tags.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: Barbara Higbie (born 1958) is a Grammy nominated, Bammy award winning pianist, composer, violinist, singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: She has played on over 65 CDs including 3 tunes on the recent Carlos Santana CD.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: A longtime Windham Hill recording artist, she has also recorded for Olivia/Second Wave records and Slowbaby Records.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: She resides in the San Francisco Bay Area with her family.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: She is a folk, jazz, pop, and fusion singer-songwriter, noted for her highly melodic, jazz/folk piano performances.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: She has toured nationally and internationally since the early 1980s.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: An early recording artist on the Windham Hill record label, she formed and played with the group Montreux along with Darol Anger, Mike Marshall, Todd Phillips, and Michael Manring.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: She recorded a critically acclaimed album titled "Unexpected" with singer Teresa Trull in 1983, which was included in The Boston Globe's Guide to Best Albums of 1983.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: Higbie and Trull teamed up again in 1997 to record an album titled "Playtime".

title: Barbara Higbie
text: Since 1990, Barbara Higbie has released a number of solo albums on the Windham Hill and Slowbaby labels.

title: Barbara Higbie
text: She is known as a versatile and soulful musician.

title: Encore (Eminem song)
text: "Encore" (stylized as "ƎNCORE" and sometimes known as "Curtains Down") is a song by rappers Eminem, 50 Cent and Dr. Dre, released in 2004 as a vinyl single in the U.S.

title: Encore (Eminem song)
text: It was the title track from the Eminem album of the same name, which was also released that year.

title: Encore (Eminem song)
text: It is the third single and final track from the album.

title: Not Afraid
text: "Not Afraid" is a song by American rapper Eminem from his seventh studio album "Recovery" (2010).

title: Not Afraid
text: It was released as the album's lead single on April 29, 2010, by Interscope Records.

title: Not Afraid
text: "Not Afraid" was first revealed as a single by Eminem via Twitter, after which the song debuted on radio.

title: Not Afraid
text: To promote the single's release, a freestyle rap, "Despicable", was released on the Internet and received attention for its tone and lyrical content.

title: Not Afraid
text: "Not Afraid" was written and produced by Eminem, Boi-1da, Jordan Evans and Matthew Burnett; keyboardist Luis Resto was also attributed with songwriting credit.

title: Not Afraid
text: According to Eminem's manager Paul Rosenberg and music critics, "Not Afraid" carries a positive message and depicts Eminem's change in direction from drugs and violence.

title: Not Afraid
text: The hip hop song features a choir that assists Eminem in a heavily layered chorus and vocals are sung over a guitar, synthesizer and piano; no Auto-Tune was used on the sung vocals, but many reverberation tools were.

title: In Death Reborn

title: Bonsallo Avenue
text: Bonsallo Avenue is a street in South Los Angeles that consists of two segments about four miles apart.

title: Bonsallo Avenue
text: The southern segment, near Slauson Avenue, is between Los Angeles' Mt Carmel and Hoover-Gage parks.

title: Harsh Times
text: Harsh Times is a 2005 American crime film set in South Los Angeles.

title: Harsh Times
text: The film stars Christian Bale and Freddy Rodriguez, and was written and directed by David Ayer, who wrote the script for the Academy Award-winning 2001 film "Training Day".

title: Harsh Times
text: The film was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Bauer Martinez Entertainment.

title: Harsh Times
text: Ayer says that the film's characters are largely based on the people he knew when he lived in South Central.

title: Street Kings 2: Motor City
text: The film was released on direct-to-DVD in the United States on April 19, 2011.

title: West Athens, California
text: West Athens is a census-designated place (CDP) in Los Angeles County, California, United States.

title: West Athens, California
text: The population was 8,729 at the 2010 census, down from 9,101 at the 2000 census.

title: West Athens, California
text: It is an Unincorporated community within the 2nd Supervisorial District of Los Angeles County.

title: West Athens, California
text: West Athens is served by the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, operating out of the South Los Angeles Station.

title: West Athens, California
text: The approximate boundaries for West Athens are: 87th Street to the North, Vermont Avenue to the East, El Segundo Boulevard to the South, and approximately Western Avenue to Van Ness Avenue to the West.

title: West Athens, California
text: West Athens is predominantly residential, with commercial uses along its main corridors.

title: West Athens, California
text: Los Angeles Southwest Community College lies within West Athens.

title: End of Watch
text: End of Watch is a 2012 American crime drama film written and directed by David Ayer.

title: End of Watch
text: It stars Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Peña as Brian Taylor and Miguel Zavala, two Los Angeles Police Department officers who work in South Los Angeles.

title: End of Watch
text: The film focuses on their day-to-day police work, their dealings with a certain group of gang members, their friendship with each other, and their personal relationships.

title: David Ayer
text: David Ayer (born January 18, 1968) is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter.

text: It is a South Side (Sureno) gang loyal to Hispanic prison gangs.

title: Central Avenue (Los Angeles)
text: Central Avenue is a major north-south thoroughfare in the central portion of the Los Angeles, California metropolitan area.

title: Central Avenue (Los Angeles)
text: Located just to the west of the Alameda Corridor, it runs from the eastern end of the Los Angeles Civic Center south, ending at Del Amo Boulevard in Carson.

title: Central Avenue (Los Angeles)
text: From north to south, Central Avenue passes through Downtown Los Angeles, South Los Angeles (including Watts, Florence-Graham, and Willowbrook), Compton, and Carson (where it runs through California State University, Dominguez Hills).

title: South of 8
