title: 1974 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 1974 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the Southwest Conference during the 1974 NCAA Division I football season.

title: 1974 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: In their fifth and final season under head coach Jim Carlen, the Red Raiders compiled a 6–4–2 record (3–4 against conference opponents), finished in sixth place in the conference, and outscored opponents by a combined total of 193 to 158.

title: 1974 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The team's statistical leaders included Tommy Duniven with 552 passing yards, Larry Isaac with 671 rushing yards, and Lawrence Williams with 477 receiving yards.

title: 1974 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The team played its home games at Clifford B. & Audrey Jones Stadium.

title: Texas Tech Red Raiders football
text: The Texas Tech Red Raiders football program is a college football team that represents Texas Tech University (variously "Texas Tech" or "TTU").

title: Texas Tech Red Raiders football
text: The team competes, as a member of the Big 12 Conference, which is a Division I Football Bowl Subdivision (formerly Division I-A) of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA).

title: Texas Tech Red Raiders football
text: The program began in 1925 and has an overall winning record, including a total of 11 conference titles and one division title.

title: Texas Tech Red Raiders football
text: On December 12, 2012, former Red Raiders quarterback Kliff Kingsbury became the team's 15th head coach, following the resignation of Tommy Tuberville.

title: Texas Tech Red Raiders football
text: Home games are played at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas.

title: 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the Southwest Conference (SWC) during the 1986 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: In their first and only season under head coach David McWilliams, the Red Raiders compiled a 7–4 record in the regular season (5–3 against SWC opponents) and finished in a tie for fourth place in the conference.

title: 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The team was invited to play in the 1986 Independence Bowl and lost to Ole Miss, 20 to 17.

title: 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The team was coached in the bowl game by Spike Dykes.

title: 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: Over the course of the full 1986 season, the team outscored opponents by a combined total of 271 to 268.

title: 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The team played its home games at Clifford B. and Audrey Jones Stadium in Lubbock, Texas.

title: 2013 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 2013 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the 2013 NCAA Division I FBS football season as members of the Big 12 Conference.

title: 2013 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: Kliff Kingsbury led the Red Raiders in his first season as the program's fifteenth head coach.

title: 2013 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders played home games on the university's campus in Lubbock, Texas at Jones AT&T Stadium.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: The Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry was an American college football rivalry between the Texas A&M Aggies football team of Texas A&M University and Texas Tech Red Raiders football team of Texas Tech University.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: The series began in 1927.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: The rivalry had continued uninterrupted since 1957 when the two schools became conference rivals.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas A&M leads the series 37–32–1.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas A&M started the series with a 12–3 advantage while the two teams played each other as non-conference opponents from 1927–1955.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas Tech took a 2–1 record during its probationary membership in the Southwest Conference from 1957–59.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas A&M led the series during the Southwest Conference years (1960–95) with an 18–17–1 record.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas Tech led the series during the Big 12 Conference years (1996–2011) with a 10–6 record.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Both teams are tied with six games each for the longest winning streak.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas Tech holds the longest uninterrupted winning streak of the series, six games between 1968 and 1973, while Texas A&M has the longest nonconsecutive winning streak, six games in 1927, 1932 and 1942 through 1945.

title: Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry
text: Texas A&M currently holds a three-game winning streak but with their departure from the Big 12 Conference in 2012, it is uncertain if the rivalry will continue in the future.

title: 2015 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 2015 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the 2015 NCAA Division I FBS football season as members of the Big 12 Conference.

title: 2015 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: Kliff Kingsbury led the Red Raiders in his third season as the program's fifteenth head coach.

title: 2015 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders played their home games on the university's campus in Lubbock, Texas at Jones AT&T Stadium.

title: 2015 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: They finished the season 7-6 and 4-5 in Big 12 play to finish in 7th.

title: 2015 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: They were invited to the Texas Bowl where they lost to LSU.

title: 2016 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 2016 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the 2016 NCAA Division I FBS football season as members of the Big 12 Conference.

title: 2016 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: Kliff Kingsbury led the Red Raiders in his fourth season as the program's fifteenth head coach.

title: 2016 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders played their home games on the university's campus in Lubbock, Texas at Jones AT&T Stadium.

title: 2016 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: They finished the season 5–7, 3–6 in Big 12 play.

title: 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the 2012 NCAA Division I FBS football season as members of the Big 12 Conference.

title: 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: Tommy Tuberville lead the Red Raiders in his third season as the program's fourteenth head coach.

title: 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders played home games on the university's campus in Lubbock, Texas at Jones AT&T Stadium.

title: 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: They finished the season 8–5, 4–5 in Big 12 play to finish in a four way tie for fifth place.

title: 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: They were invited to the Meineke Car Care Bowl of Texas where they defeated Minnesota.

title: 2009 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The 2009 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team represented Texas Tech University in the 2009 NCAA Division I FBS football season.

title: 2009 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The team was coached by Mike Leach during the regular season, and was coached by interim head coach Ruffin McNeill during the 2010 Valero Alamo Bowl.

title: 2009 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas.

title: 2009 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The football team competed in the Division I NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision.

title: 2009 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders finished the season 9–4, 5–3 in Big 12 play and won the Valero Alamo Bowl 41–31 against Michigan State.

title: 2014 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: Kliff Kingsbury lead the Red Raiders in his second season as the program's fifteenth head coach.

title: 2014 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: The Red Raiders played home games on the university's campus in Lubbock, Texas at Jones AT&T Stadium.

title: 2014 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team
text: They finished the season 4–8, 2–7 in Big 12 play to finish in eighth place.

title: Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere
text: Field Marshal Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (14 November 1773 – 21 February 1865), was a British Army officer, diplomat and politician.

title: Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere
text: As a junior officer he took part in the Flanders Campaign, in the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War and in the suppression of Robert Emmet's insurrection in 1803.

title: Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere
text: He commanded a cavalry brigade in Sir Arthur Wellesley's Army before being given overall command of the cavalry in the latter stages of the Peninsular War.

title: Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere
text: He went on to be Commander-in-Chief, Ireland and then Commander-in-Chief, India.

title: Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere
text: In the latter role he stormed Bharatpur—a fort which previously had been deemed impregnable.

title: Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur
text: Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur, formerly Brij University, Bharatpur, is a state university located at Bharatpur, Rajasthan, India.

title: Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur
text: It was established in 2012 by the Government of Rajasthan through "Brij University, Bharatpur Act, 2012".

title: Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur
text: In 2014, in commemoration of Maharaja Surajmal, it was renamed Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur through "Brij University, Bharatpur (Change of Name) Act, 2014".

title: Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur
text: Ashwini Kumar Bansal was appointed Vice Chancellor of the university in February 2017.

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces (CINCLAND), was a senior officer in the British Army.

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: CINCLAND commanded HQ Land Forces, an administrative apparatus that had responsibility for all of the army's fighting units in the United Kingdom (excluding Northern Ireland), Germany and Brunei, together with training garrisons in Nepal, Belize, Canada and Kenya.

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: CINCLAND was also the Standing Joint Commander (UK) (SJC(UK)), with responsibility for the provision of Military Aid to Civil Power within the United Kingdom.

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: The position had existed since 1968, when it was known as General Officer Commanding Army Strategic Command.

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: In 1972 it became Commander-in-Chief United Kingdom Land Forces (CINCUKLF).

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: As from 1 April 2008, HQ Land Command was renamed HQ Land Forces (HQLF).

title: Commander-in-Chief, Land Forces
text: Therefore, the Commander-in-Chief became Commander-in-Chief of HQ Land Forces.

title: Commander-in-Chief, India
text: During the period of the British Raj, the Commander-in-Chief, India (often "Commander-in-Chief "in" or "of" India") was the supreme commander of the British Indian Army.

title: Commander-in-Chief, India
text: The Commander-in-Chief and most of his staff were based at General Headquarters, India, and liaised with the civilian Governor-General of India.

title: Commander-in-Chief, India
text: Following the Partition of India in 1947 and the creation of the independent dominions of India and Pakistan, the post was abolished.

title: Commander-in-Chief, India
text: It was briefly replaced by the position of Supreme Commander of India and Pakistan before the role was abolished in November 1948.

title: Commander-in-Chief, India
text: Subsequently, the role of Commander-in-Chief was merged into the offices of the Governors-General of India and Pakistan, respectively, before becoming part of the office of President of India from 1950, of the President of Pakistan from 1956, and of the President of Bangladesh from 1972.

title: Vishvendra Singh
text: Vishvendra Singh (Born 23 June 1962 at Moti Mahal, Bharatpur) is a member of the Legislative Assembly from Deeg-Kumher Constituency in Bharatpur district of Rajasthan India.

title: Vishvendra Singh
text: He is the son of the last ruler of the princely state of Bharatpur.

title: Vishvendra Singh
text: In the 26th amendment to the Constitution of India promulgated in 1971, the Government of India abolished all official symbols of princely India, including titles, privileges, and remuneration (privy purses).

title: Claude Auchinleck
text: Field Marshal Sir Claude John Eyre Auchinleck {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (21 June 1884 – 23 March 1981) was a British Army commander during the Second World War.

title: Claude Auchinleck
text: He was a career soldier who spent much of his military career in India, where he rose to become Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army by early 1941.

title: Claude Auchinleck
text: In July 1941 he was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the Middle East theatre, but after initial successes the war in North Africa turned against the British, and he was relieved of the post in 1942 during the crucial Alamein campaign.

title: Claude Auchinleck
text: In June 1943 he was once more appointed Commander-in-Chief India, where his support through the organisation of supply, maintenance and training for Slim's Fourteenth Army played an important role in its success.

title: Claude Auchinleck
text: He served as Commander-in-Chief India until Partition in 1947, when he assumed the role of Supreme Commander of all British forces in India and Pakistan until late 1948.

title: Siege of Bharatpur (1805)
text: The Siege of Bharatpur took place between 2 January and 22 February 1805 in the Indian Princely state of Bharatpur (now part of Rajasthan), during the Second Anglo-Maratha War.

title: Siege of Bharatpur (1805)
text: Forces of the British East India Company, led by General Gerard Lake, were four times repulsed in attempts to storm the fortress.

title: Siege of Bharatpur (1805)
text: The victory by Bharatpur backed by the Maratha Empire was an embarrassing defeat for the British.

title: Bharatpur district
text: Bharatpur District is a district of Rajasthan state in western India also known as Jat Kingdom.

title: Bharatpur district
text: The town of Bharatpur is the district headquarters.

title: Bharatpur district
text: Bharatpur District is a part of National Capital Region (NCR).

title: Bharatpur, Rajasthan
text: Bharatpur is a city and newly created municipal corporation in the Indian state of Rajasthan.

title: Bharatpur, Rajasthan
text: Located in the Braj region, Bharatpur was once considered to be impregnable and unbeatable.

title: Bharatpur, Rajasthan
text: The city is situated 180 km south of India's capital, New Delhi, 178 km from Rajasthan's capital Jaipur, 55 km west of Agra and 34 km from Lord Krishna's birthplace Mathura.

title: Bharatpur, Rajasthan
text: It is also the administrative headquarters of Bharatpur District and the headquarters of Bharatpur Division of Rajasthan.

title: Bharatpur, Rajasthan
text: The Royal House of Bharatpur traces its history to the 11th century.

title: Bharatpur, Rajasthan
text: Bharatpur is part of National Capital Region (NCR).

title: Lohagarh Fort
text: Lohagarh Fort (Iron fort) is situated at Bharatpur in Rajasthan, India.

title: Lohagarh Fort
text: It was constructed by Bharatpur Jat rulers.

title: Lohagarh Fort
text: Maharaja Suraj Mal used all his power and wealth to a good cause, and built numerous forts and palaces across his kingdom, one of them being the Lohagarh Fort (Iron fort), which was one of the strongest ever built in Indian history.

title: Lohagarh Fort
text: The inaccessible Lohagarh fort could withstand repeated attacks of British forces led by Lord Lake in 1805 when they laid siege for over six weeks.

title: Lohagarh Fort
text: Of the two gates in the fort, one in the north is known as Ashtdhaatu (eight metalled) gate while the one facing the south is called Chowburja (four-pillared) gate.

title: Santa Claus Is a Black Man
text: "Santa Claus Is a Black Man" is a Christmas song by record producer and songwriter Teddy Vann, performed by his daughter Akim Vann (billed as Akim) and his Teddy Vann Production Company for a 1973 single.

title: Santa Claus Is a Black Man
text: The song, described as "Vann's take on 'I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus'", has been called a cult classic, and continues to receive Christmas airplay.

title: Santa Claus (1898 film)
text: Santa Claus is a 1898 British short silent drama film, directed by George Albert Smith, which features Santa Claus visiting a house on Christmas Eve.

title: Santa Claus (1898 film)
text: The film, according to Michael Brooke of BFI Screenonline, "is believed to be the cinema's earliest known example of parallel action and, when coupled with double-exposure techniques that Smith had already demonstrated in the same year's "The Mesmerist" (1898) and "Photographing a Ghost" (1898), the result is one of the most visually and conceptually sophisticated British films made up to then."

title: The Year Without a Santa Claus (2006 film)
text: The Year Without a Santa Claus is a 90-minute 2006 live-action remake of the Rankin-Bass classic "The Year Without a Santa Claus" which premiered on NBC December 11, 2006.

title: The Year Without a Santa Claus (2006 film)
text: A widescreen DVD was released on December 12, 2006 (UPC 085391115120).

title: Santa Claus in film
text: Motion pictures featuring Santa Claus abound and apparently constitute their own subgenre of the Christmas film genre.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: Early films of Santa revolve around similar simple plots of Santa's Christmas Eve visit to children.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: In 1897, in a short film called "Santa Claus Filling Stockings", Santa Claus is simply filling stockings from his pack of toys.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: Another film called "Santa Claus and the Children" was made in 1898.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: A year later, a film directed by George Albert Smith in titled "Santa Claus" (or "The Visit from Santa Claus" in the United Kingdom) was created.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: In this picture, Santa Claus enters the room from the fireplace and proceeds to trim the tree.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: He then fills the stockings that were previously hung on the mantle by the children.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: After walking backward and surveying his work, he suddenly darts at the fireplace and disappears up the chimney.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: "Santa Claus' Visit" in 1900 featured a scene with two little children kneeling at the feet of their mother and saying their prayers.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: The mother tucks the children snugly in bed and leaves the room.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: Santa Claus suddenly appears on the roof, just outside the children's bedroom window, and proceeds to enter the chimney, taking with him his bag of presents and a little hand sled for one of the children.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: He goes down the chimney and suddenly appears in the children's room through the fireplace.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: He distributes the presents and mysteriously causes the appearance of a Christmas tree laden with gifts.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: The scene closes with the children waking up and running to the fireplace just too late to catch him by the legs.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: A 1909 film by D. W. Griffith titled "A Trap for Santa Claus" shows children setting a trap to capture Santa Claus as he descends the chimney, but instead capture their father who abandoned them and their mother but tries to burglarize the house after he discovers she inherited a fortune.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: A twenty-nine-minute 1925 silent film production titled "Santa Claus", by explorer/documentarian Frank E. Kleinschmidt, filmed partly in northern Alaska, feature Santa in his workshop, visiting his Eskimo neighbors, and tending his reindeer.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: A year later, another movie titled "Santa Claus" was produced with sound on De Forest Phonofilm.

title: Santa Claus in film
text: Over the years, various actors have donned the red suit (aside from those discussed below), including Monty Woolley in "Life Begins at Eight-thirty" (1942), Alberto Rabagliati in "The Christmas That Almost Wasn't" (1966), Dan Aykroyd in "Trading Places" (1983), Jan Rubes in "One Magic Christmas" (1985), David Huddleston in "" (1985), Jonathan Taylor Thomas in "I'll Be Home for Christmas" (1998), and Ed Asner in "Elf" (2003).

title: Santa Claus in film
text: Later films about Santa vary, but can be divided into the following themes.

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: A Miser Brothers' Christmas is a stop motion spin-off special based on some of the characters from the 1974 Rankin-Bass special "The Year Without a Santa Claus".

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: Distributed by Warner Bros.

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: Animation under their Warner Premiere label (the rights holders of the post-1974 Rankin-Bass library) and Toronto-based Cuppa Coffee Studios, the one-hour special premiered on ABC Family on Saturday, December 13, 2008, during the network's annual The 25 Days of Christmas programming.

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: Mickey Rooney and George S. Irving reprised their respective roles as Santa Claus and Heat Miser at ages 88 and 86.

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: Snow Miser, originally portrayed by Dick Shawn who died in 1987, was voiced by Juan Chioran, while Mrs. Claus, voiced by Shirley Booth in the original, was portrayed by Catherine Disher (because Booth had died in 1992).

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: The movie aimed to emulate the Rankin/Bass animation style.

title: A Miser Brothers' Christmas
text: This is the last Christmas special to feature Mickey Rooney as Santa Claus, as he died in 2014, as well as the last time George Irving voiced Heat Miser, as he died in 2016.

title: Santa's Workshop (Colorado)
text: Santa's Workshop is an amusement park that opened on June 16, 1956 in Cascade, Colorado, just west of Colorado Springs at the base of Pikes Peak.

title: Santa's Workshop (Colorado)
text: Modeled after the Santa's Workshop in Lake Placid, New York, the park features a charming North Pole village complete with specialty shops for boys, girls, Christmas ornaments, and candy.

title: Santa's Workshop (Colorado)
text: The village is also home to Santa's Workshop itself, where children can meet with Santa Claus and Mrs. Claus year round.

title: Santa's Workshop (Colorado)
text: Many of the park's staff get into the holiday spirit as well, and children will find Santa's elves hard at work in admissions and the many shops around the premises.

title: The Year Without a Santa Claus
text: The Year Without a Santa Claus is a 1974 Christmas stop motion animated television special produced by Rankin/Bass Productions.

title: The Year Without a Santa Claus
text: The story is based on Phyllis McGinley's 1956 book of the same name, illustrated by Kurt Werth.

title: The Year Without a Santa Claus
text: It was originally broadcast on December 10, 1974 on ABC.

title: Santa Claus: The Movie
text: Santa Claus: The Movie (known on-screen as simply Santa Claus) is a 1985 British-American Christmas film starring Dudley Moore, John Lithgow, and David Huddleston in the title role.

title: Santa Claus: The Movie
text: It is the last major fantasy film produced by the Paris-based father-and-son production team of Alexander and Ilya Salkind.

title: Santa Claus: The Movie
text: The film was directed by Jeannot Szwarc and released in North America on November 27, 1985, by TriStar Pictures.

title: Santa Claus: The Movie
text: The 2005 DVD release was released by Anchor Bay Entertainment, now known as Starz Home Entertainment, under license from the film's current owner, StudioCanal; however, the current, 25th Anniversary home video release (which also now includes Blu-ray) is by Lionsgate Home Entertainment, again under StudioCanal's license.

title: Larry Wilson (screenwriter)
text: Larry Wilson is an American film producer and screenwriter.

title: Larry Wilson (screenwriter)
text: He is best known for his screenwriting work on the films "Beetlejuice" (1988) and "The Addams Family" (1991).

title: Larry Wilson (screenwriter)
text: He also co-wrote the films "The Little Vampire" (2001) and the television film "The Year Without a Santa Claus" (2006).

title: Larry Wilson (screenwriter)
text: He also wrote and directed a number of episodes of the "Tales from the Crypt" television series from 1991 to 1996.

title: Jonathan Meath
text: Jonathan Meath (born September 16, 1955) is an American TV producer based in Boston who is notable for children's television production.

title: Jonathan Meath
text: He was Senior Producer of the TV game show "Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?

title: Jonathan Meath
text: " He produced "Zoom (1999)" and "The Wubbulous World of Dr. Seuss."

title: Jonathan Meath
text: He co-founded a production company called Andanzura.

title: Jonathan Meath
text: In addition, he is notable for having a dual career as a professional Santa Claus.

title: Jonathan Meath
text: He made numerous appearances in various media as Santa, including ABC's "Good Morning America" show, and at New York's Radio City Music Hall with The Rockettes.

title: Jonathan Meath
text: He appeared on the cover of "Boston Magazine" as "Father Christmas".

title: Jonathan Meath
text: He was described by "National Public Radio" and "Time Magazine" as a "top Santa", and appeared as Santa in a Delta Airline's in-flight safety video.

title: Jonathan Meath
text: He is featured as Santa in Coca-Cola’s worldwide 2016 holiday advertising campaign both in print and commercials titled “A Coke for Christmas."

title: The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie
text: The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie is an EP/soundtrack by The Naked Brothers Band for "".

title: The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie
text: It was released as an extra disc on the Naked Brothers Band Movie DVD.

title: The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie
text: The disc was only available with the DVD for a short time only and now is only available to buy on Amazon.

title: The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie
text: It was not an official release and has not yet been released separately, or on The iTunes Store.

title: The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie
text: The first single "Crazy Car" charted on the Billboard Hot 100 in 2007 at No. 83.

title: Nat Wolff
text: Nathaniel Marvin "Nat" Wolff (born December 17, 1994) is an American actor, singer-songwriter, and musician.

title: Nat Wolff
text: Wolff gained recognition for composing the music for "The Naked Brothers Band" (2007–09), a Nickelodeon television series he starred in with his younger brother Alex that was created by their actress mother Polly Draper.

title: Nat Wolff
text: Wolff's jazz pianist father Michael Wolff co-produced the series' soundtrack albums, "The Naked Brothers Band" (2007) and "I Don't Want to Go to School" (2008); the former of which ranked the 23rd spot on the "Billboard" 200 charts.

title: The Naked Brothers Band (album)
text: The Naked Brothers Band is a soundtrack album by The Naked Brothers Band for Season 1 of The Naked Brothers Band television series.

title: The Naked Brothers Band (album)
text: The album was also released as a deluxe fanpack that includes a poster, lyrics & 2 bonus tracks.

title: Alex Wolff
text: Alexander "Alex" Draper Wolff (born November 1, 1997) is an American actor, musician, and composer.

title: Alex Wolff
text: He first gained recognition for starring alongside his older brother Nat in the Nickelodeon musical comedy television series "The Naked Brothers Band" (2007–09), which was created by the boys' mother Polly Draper.

title: Alex Wolff
text: Wolff and his brother released two soundtrack albums for the series, "The Naked Brothers Band" and "I Don't Want to Go to School", which were co-produced by their father Michael Wolff.

title: The Naked Brothers Band (video game)
text: The Naked Brothers Band: The Video Game is a 2008 multiplatform video game developed by Barking Lizards Technologies, with 1st Playable Productions developing the DS title, and published by THQ.

title: The Naked Brothers Band (video game)
text: The game is based on, and includes songs by, The Naked Brothers Band.

title: The Naked Brothers Band (video game)
text: The game was also going to be on PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 and PSP but got cancelled after development.

title: Mystery Girl (film)
text: Mystery Girl is a rock-mockumentary musical comedy.

title: Mystery Girl (film)
text: It's the first and second The Naked Brothers Band episode of Season 3, and TV movie on Nickelodeon.

title: Mystery Girl (film)
text: It has premiered on October 18, 2008.

title: Mystery Girl (film)
text: This episode was the highest rated Naked Brothers Band episode ever with more than 4 million viewers.

title: I Don't Want to Go to School
text: I Don't Want To Go To School is the second soundtrack album by The Naked Brothers Band, it was the soundtrack for the second season of The Naked Brothers Band.

title: I Don't Want to Go to School
text: The album was released as a deluxe fanpack that includes a poster, lyrics and two bonus tracks.

title: The Premiere (film)
text: "The Premiere" is the eighth TV movie on the part documentary and part rock-mockumentary musical comedy series "The Naked Brothers Band," which was created by Polly Draper.

title: The Premiere (film)
text: "The Premiere" aired on Saturday, April 11, 2009.

title: The Premiere (film)
text: The premise of "The Premiere" is that The Naked Brothers Band "Musical Mystery Movie" premieres.

title: The Premiere (film)
text: It also features guest appearances by Victoria Justice from "Zoey 101".

title: Nat and Alex Wolff
text: Nat and Alex Wolff are an American pop music duo from New York, New York, consisting of brothers Nat and Alex Wolff.

title: Nat and Alex Wolff
text: The siblings are known for their work on the Nickelodeon television series "The Naked Brothers Band", which was created and produced by their mother, actress Polly Draper.

title: Nat and Alex Wolff
text: It was adapted from the mockumentary film that Draper wrote and directed.

title: Nat and Alex Wolff
text: The duo's initial teen pop boy band called "The Naked Brothers Band" was depicted as part of its participation in their Nickelodeon series that aired from 2007 to 2009.

title: Nat and Alex Wolff
text: They have released four full-length albums and have been nominated for several awards.

title: Operation Mojo
text: Operation Mojo is part documentary and part rock-mockumentary musical comedy of the TEENick series The Naked Brothers Band.

title: Operation Mojo
text: It's the sixth television movie of "The Naked Brothers Band", and the second of season 3.

title: Operation Mojo
text: The movie aired on Nickelodeon on November 22, 2008

title: Harris G. Mirkin
text: Harris George Mirkin (24 August 1936 – 30 May 2013) was a political science professor who aroused controversy with an essay, "The Pattern of Sexual Politics," published in the "Journal of Homosexuality".

title: Harris G. Mirkin
text: This prompted the Missouri legislature to reduce the university's budget by the amount of Mirkin's salary, as a gesture of non-support for Mirkin's work.

title: Contract with the World
text: Contract With the World is a 1980 novel written by Canadian author Jane Rule.

title: Contract with the World
text: The story takes place in Vancouver, British Columbia, in the mid-1970s, and is divided in six parts, each focusing on the perspective of a different character.

title: Contract with the World
text: Themes of artistic motivation, personal fulfilment, and sexual politics are present throughout.

title: Susie Bright
text: Susannah "Susie" Bright, also known as Susie Sexpert (born March 25, 1958), is an American feminist, author, journalist, critic, editor, publisher, producer, and performer, often on the subject of sexual politics and sexuality.

title: Au Pairs (band)
text: The Au Pairs were a British post-punk band that formed in Birmingham in 1978 and continued until 1983.

title: Au Pairs (band)
text: They produced two studio albums and three singles.

title: Au Pairs (band)
text: Their songs were said to have "contempt for the cliches of contemporary sexual politics" and their music has been compared to the Gang of Four and the Young Marble Giants.

title: Au Pairs (band)
text: The band was led by Lesley Woods, who was once described as "one of the most striking women in British rock".

title: Laura Kipnis
text: Laura Kipnis (born 1956) is an American cultural critic and essayist.

title: Laura Kipnis
text: A feminist intellectual, her work focuses on sexual politics, gender issues, aesthetics, popular culture, and pornography.

title: Laura Kipnis
text: She began her career as a video artist, exploring similar themes in the form of video essays.

title: Laura Kipnis
text: She is professor of media studies at Northwestern University in the Department of Radio-TV-Film, where she teaches filmmaking.

title: C. V. Balakrishnan
text: C. V. Balakrishnan (Malayalam: സി.

title: C. V. Balakrishnan
text: ബാലകൃഷ്ണൻ ; born 24 September 1952) is a Malayalam-language novelist, short story writer, essayist and screenplay writer from the south Indian state of Kerala.

title: C. V. Balakrishnan
text: His novels and short stories encompass the emotional issues related to mass culture, sexual politics, fate of the marginalised and institutionalised religions.

title: C. V. Balakrishnan
text: An author of more than 40 literary works along with a few film scripts and film criticisms, his best known work is the novel "Ayussinte Pusthakam" ("Book of Life").

title: C. V. Balakrishnan
text: He received the Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award in 2000 for the novel "Atmavinu Seriyennu Thonnunna Karyangal" and the Kerala State Film Award for Best Book on Cinema in 2002 for "Cinemayude Idangal".

title: C. V. Balakrishnan
text: In 2014, he won the Padmaprabha Literary Award

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: The British University Hurling Championship is an annual Hurling competition held for universities in Great Britain.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: It is organised by the BUGAA which is a branch of the Higher Education GAA committee which oversees Gaelic Games in Universities.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: Unlike its sister competition, the British University Gaelic Football Championship, this competition is not overseen by the British Universities Sports Association as yet.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: The best players each year are chosen for an all-star team to play the Scottish Universities Shinty Team.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: The trophies for British University Gaelic Games Championships memorialise students who were pioneers of Gaelic Games at British Universities.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: The Michael O'Leary Cup is awarded to the winner of the British University Hurling Championship.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: It was presented to BUGAA by The Friary, Dundee.

title: British University Hurling Championship
text: The Cup is named after a founder member of the hurling club at the University of Glasgow who died in 2001.

title: Carol J. Adams
text: Carol J. Adams (born 1951) is an American writer, feminist, and animal rights advocate.

title: Carol J. Adams
text: She is the author of several books, including "The Sexual Politics of Meat: A Feminist-Vegetarian Critical Theory" (1990) and "The Pornography of Meat" (2004), focusing in particular on what she argues are the links between the oppression of women and that of non-human animals.

title: Shannon Bell
text: Shannon Bell (born 5 July 1955) is a Canadian performance philosopher who lives and writes philosophy-in-action, experimental philosophy.

title: Shannon Bell
text: Bell is also professor and graduate programme director in the York University Political Science Department, Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

title: Shannon Bell
text: She teaches postmodern theory, fast feminism, sexual politics, cyber politics, identity politics and violent philosophy.

title: Kate Millett
text: Katherine Murray Millett (September 14, 1934 – September 6, 2017) was an American feminist writer, educator, artist, and activist.

title: Kate Millett
text: She attended Oxford University and was the first American woman to be awarded a degree with first-class honors after studying at St Hilda's College, Oxford.

title: Kate Millett
text: She has been described as "a seminal influence on second-wave feminism", and is best known for her book "Sexual Politics" (1970), which was based on her doctoral dissertation at Columbia University.

title: Kate Millett
text: Journalist Liza Featherstone attributes previously unimaginable "legal abortion, greater professional equality between the sexes, and a sexual freedom" being made possible partially due to Millett's efforts.

title: 2011 Barcelona Ladies Open – Doubles
text: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci were the defending champions, but Roberta Vinci chose not to continue her performance before the quarterfinals.

title: Flavia Pennetta
text: Flavia Pennetta (] ; born 25 February 1982) is a retired Italian professional tennis player and Grand Slam-champion in both singles and doubles.

title: Flavia Pennetta
text: She became Italy's first top-10 female singles player on 17 August 2009 and the first Italian to be ranked world No. 1 in doubles on 28 February 2011.

title: Flavia Pennetta
text: She became a Grand Slam singles champion, winning the 2015 US Open by defeating her childhood friend Roberta Vinci in the first all-Italian Grand Slam final .

title: 2015 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles
text: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci were the defending champions, but Errani chose not to participate this year.

title: 2015 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles
text: Vinci played alongside Karin Knapp, but lost in the third round to Casey Dellacqua and Yaroslava Shvedova.

title: 2015 Rogers Cup – Women's Doubles
text: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci were the defending champions, but chose not participate together.

title: 2015 Rogers Cup – Women's Doubles
text: Errani played alongside Flavia Pennetta, but lost in the quarterfinals to Bethanie Mattek-Sands and Lucie Šafářová.

title: 2015 Rogers Cup – Women's Doubles
text: Vinci teamed up with Jelena Janković, but lost in the first round to Garbiñe Muguruza and Carla Suárez Navarro.

title: 2015 Rogers Cup – Women's Doubles
1994 Athens International – Doubles
text: Horacio de la Peña and Jorge Lozano were the defending champions, but did not participate this year.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: Jorge Lozano (born 17 May 1963 in San Luis Potosí) is a retired professional tennis player from Mexico.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He reached his highest doubles ranking of World No. 4 in August 1988.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: His highest singles ranking was World No. 51, achieved the following month.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: During his career, he won two mixed doubles titles at the French Open: in 1990 with Arantxa Sánchez, and in 1988 with Lori McNeil.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He reached the round of 16 in singles at the 1988 US Open and also the semifinal in doubles that same year.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: Qualified twice for the Doubles Masters at the Royal Albert Hall in London and reached the semifinals in 1988.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: In his career, he won nine doubles titles, but no singles titles.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He turned professional in 1986, and in his career, he won $U.S.739,424 in prize money.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He was the first player to be beaten by Pete Sampras in the main draw of a Grand Slam tournament, at the French Open in 1989.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: In Davis Cup play, represented Mexico for 15 years, 1981–1995, won 12 doubles matches, and lost 12 as well.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He lost 11 singles matches, and won 8, making his overall win / loss record at the Davis Cup 20–23.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: Lozano won his first title at Forest Hills in 1988, with his partner Todd Witsken, and won his last at Athens in 1993.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He resides in Guadalajara, Mexico where he directs a tennis academy for kids and also coaches the men and women tennis team at the University Tec de Monterrey.

title: Jorge Lozano
text: He is currently the captain of the Mexican Davis Cup Team.

title: Morbo (band)
text: Morbo was a Mexican electronica/synthpop/ambient/alternative rock group formed by Juan Carlos Lozano.

title: Morbo (band)
text: Lozano was one of the four founding members of Moenia, which originally included Juan Carlos Lozano as lead vocalist on 1997's debut album 'Moenia' and its 1998 companion remix album 'Moenia Mixes'.

title: Morbo (band)
text: Despite the acclaimed success of 1997's Moenia and 1998's remix album, in itself a risky and previously-unheard of novelty in the Mexican music industry, and due to disagreements between Lozano, Jorge Soto and Alejandro 'Midi' Ortega as to the creative route Moenia should take, Lozano decided to leave Moenia as vocalist with original founding member Alfonso Pichardo returning as lead singer.

title: Morbo (band)
text: Lozano then formed the perhaps less commercial, still synth-oriented, but more guitar-centered Morbo, whose musical vision first came to fruition in 2001's eponymous "Morbo".

title: 1988 Volvo International – Doubles
text: Jorge Lozano and Todd Witsken won in the final 6–3, 7–6 against Pieter Aldrich and Danie Visser.

title: Marta Domachowska
text: Marta Domachowska (; born 16 January 1986 in Warsaw) is a Polish retired professional tennis player ranked World No. 37 in singles (2006) and World No. 62 in doubles (2006).

title: Marta Domachowska
text: She reached 2008 Australian Open fourth round in singles and won 2006 Canberra International in doubles with Roberta Vinci.

title: Marta Domachowska
text: She also reached three WTA Tour singles finals at 2004 Hansol Korea Open (lost to Maria Sharapova), 2005 Internationaux de Strasbourg (lost to Anabel Medina Garrigues) and 2006 U.S. National Indoor Tennis Championships (lost to Sofia Arvidsson).

title: Marta Domachowska
text: She was 2003 Australian Open finalist in girls' singles, represented Poland at the 2008 Summer Olympics and was member of Poland Fed Cup team.

title: Marta Domachowska
text: Domachowska was the best female Polish tennis player after Magdalena Grzybowska's retirement and before Agnieszka Radwańska's successes.

title: Roberta Vinci
text: Roberta Vinci (] ; born 18 February 1983) is an Italian tennis player.

title: Roberta Vinci
text: Up until 6 April 2015, she held the position of World No. 1 in doubles, while reaching a career-high of World No. 7 in singles in May 2016.

title: Roberta Vinci
text: She is the fourth Italian woman to have reached the top 10 in singles, together with Flavia Pennetta, Francesca Schiavone and Sara Errani.

title: Roberta Vinci
text: At 33 years and 4 days old, she is also the oldest ever player to make her first appearance in the Top 10.

title: Truth Initiative
text: Truth Initiative (formerly the American Legacy Foundation or Legacy) is a nonprofit tobacco control organization "dedicated to achieving a culture where all youth and young adults reject tobacco."

title: Truth Initiative
text: It was established in March 1999 as a result of the Master Settlement Agreement between the attorneys general of 46 states, the District of Columbia and five United States territories, and the tobacco industry.

title: Truth Initiative
text: Truth Initiative is best known for its youth smoking prevention campaign.

title: Truth Initiative
text: Its other primary aims include conducting tobacco control research and policy studies, organizing community and youth engagement programs and developing digital cessation and prevention products, including through revenue-generating models.

title: Truth Initiative
text: The organization changed its name from the American Legacy Foundation to Truth Initiative on September 8, 2015, to better align with its Truth campaign.

title: Truth Initiative
text: As of 2016, the organization had more than $957 million in assets and a staff of 133 based primarily in its Washington, D.C. office.

title: Truth in Science
text: Truth in Science is a United Kingdom-based creationist organization which promotes the Discovery Institute's "Teach the Controversy" campaign, which it uses to try to get pseudoscientific intelligent design creationism taught alongside evolution in school science lessons.

title: Truth in Science
text: The organization claims that there is scientific controversy about the validity of Darwinian evolution, a view rejected by the United Kingdom's Royal Society and over 50 Academies of Science around the world.

title: Truth in Science
text: The group is affiliated with the Discovery Institute, the hub of the intelligent design movement, following its strategy and circulating the Institute's promotional materials.

title: The Last Embrace
text: The Last Embrace is the final release by Spirit Caravan.

title: The Last Embrace
text: It was released on 2xCD and 2xLP in 2003 by Meteor City Records.

title: The Last Embrace
text: It contains 19 songs from their two albums, "Jug Fulla Sun" and "Elusive Truth", the three songs that appeared on their debut 7" (under the name Shine), the two songs from their final 7", "Spirit Caravan", the song from their split 7" with Sixty Watt Shaman and their song from the Rise 13 compilation on Rise Above Records.

title: The Last Embrace
text: It also features the last three songs Spirit Caravan recorded, "The Last Embrace," "Brainwashed" and "Dove-Tongued Aggressor."

title: Curiosity (TV series)
text: Curiosity is an American documentary television series that premiered on August 7, 2011, on the Discovery Channel.

title: Curiosity (TV series)
text: Each episode focuses on one question in science, technology, and society (e.g., why the sank) and, for the first season, features a different celebrity host.

title: Curiosity (TV series)
text: Stephen Hawking hosted the premiere episode titled "Did God Create the Universe?"

title: Curiosity (TV series)
text: , which aired simultaneously on seven Discovery Communications networks: Discovery Channel, TLC, Discovery Fit and Health, Animal Planet, Science, Investigation Discovery, and Destination America.

title: Curiosity (TV series)
text: Season one consists of 16 episodes.

title: Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)
text: Truth (stylized as truth) is a national campaign aimed at curbing youth smoking in the United States.

title: Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)
text: The "truth" campaign is produced and funded by the American Legacy Foundation, a public health nonprofit organization established in 1999 under the Master Settlement Agreement between U.S. tobacco companies, 46 U.S. states, the District of Columbia, and five territories.

title: Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)
text: "truth" produces television and online content to promote anti-tobacco messages.

title: Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)
text: In August 2014, "truth" launched "Finish It", a redesigned campaign encouraging youth to be the generation that ends smoking.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: An unforgiving sun, a parched earth, and a failed economy have left a small Texas town desolate.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: For ten years Promise, Texas has known nothing but one curse after another.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: It's barren, broken, and dying, leaving a town full of despair.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: When a couple finds a boy walking along a dusty road, alone in the middle of nowhere, with nothing but a mat tucked under his arm, they pick him up in hopes of helping him.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: What they don't realize is that he has come to help them and the residents of Promise.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: No one knows who he is or where he came from.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: Some think he's an answer to prayer.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: Others think he's a runaway or a false prophet.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: And the only thing this boy will say about himself is that he's here to help.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: The town's sheriff, Brody, is determined to uncover the truth.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: But Brody has his own problems trying to hold a dying town together.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: Miracle after miracle takes place and the residents of Promise embrace the boy.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: But when the beloved town doctor dies, it is time for the truth to be revealed.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: The boy pleads with Brody in front of the whole town to believe that he's come to help, not to hurt anyone.

title: I Am... Gabriel
text: Finally, with his back against the wall the boy reveals his true identity.

title: Discovery Museum and Planetarium
text: The Discovery Museum and Planetarium is a hands-on science museum in Bridgeport, Connecticut, that serves as both a tourist destination and an educational resource for area schools.

title: Discovery Museum and Planetarium
text: The Discovery Museum provides dynamic, hands-on STEM experiences designed to resonate with the innate curiosity, learning desire, and spirit of exploration of visitors, encouraging young learners to ask questions, solve problems, and engineer solutions today so they are better prepared to embrace the challenges of tomorrow.

title: Discovery Networks Benelux
text: Discovery Networks Benelux is a branch of Discovery Networks International responsible for channels in the Netherlands and Belgium.

title: Discovery Networks Benelux
text: Discovery Networks Benelux operates Discovery, Animal Planet, TLC (Netherlands), Eurosport 1, Eurosport 2 and Investigation Discovery in the region with local advertising, sponsorship, programming and the use of the local language either dubbed or subtitled.

title: Discovery Networks Benelux
text: Discovery Networks Benelux also use existing services from Discovery Networks International: Discovery Science and Discovery World.

title: Every Voice
text: Every Voice is an American nonprofit, nonpartisan liberal political advocacy organization.

title: Every Voice
text: The organization was formed in 2014 upon the merger of the Public Campaign Action Fund, a 501(c)(4) group, and the Friends of Democracy.

title: Every Voice
text: Every Voice, along with its affiliated Super PAC, Every Voice Action, advocates for campaign finance reform in the United States via public financing of political campaigns and limitations on political donations.

title: Every Voice
text: The organization's president, David Donnelly, has said "We fully embrace the irony of working through a Super PAC to fight the influence of Super PACs."

title: Extrema (band)
text: Extrema formed in 1986 in Milan.

title: Extrema (band)
text: The initial lineup included guitarist Tommy Massara, vocalist/guitarist Andrea Boria, bassist Luca Varisco, and drummer Stefano Bullegas.

title: Extrema (band)
text: Regarded as one of Italy's first thrash metal bands, Extrema's first EP, "We F**kin' Care" (1987), sold an impressive 3,000 copies by word of mouth alone.

title: Extrema (band)
text: Italian heavy metal fans didn't yet seem prepared to embrace local talent, however, and the next four years saw Extrema (by then entirely re-vamped, with Massara signing on new members Gianluca Perotti on vocals, Mattia Bigi on bass, and Chris Dalla Pellegrina on drums) relegated to open for visiting acts like Slayer, D.R.I., and Corrosion of Conformity.

title: Extrema (band)
text: Finally realizing that their only hope of impressing local talent scouts lay in conquering from the outside-in, Extrema started aggressively shopping their demos to international heavy metal critics, and even financed a trip to New York City for a one-off gig.

title: Extrema (band)
text: The strategy worked, and their four-track demo from 1991 was soon making waves with some major international publications, eventually leading to a record deal with Contempo Records.

title: Extrema (band)
text: The result was the 1993's "Tension at the Seams" album, which led to stadium support slots with Italian rock star Vasco Rossi, and more importantly a high-profile metal festival appearance in Turin alongside Megadeth, The Cult, Suicidal Tendencies, and Metallica.

title: Extrema (band)
text: The album also featured an unconventional cover of The Police's "Truth Hits Everybody" and spawned a video clip for the track "Child O' Boogaow" which was on heavy rotation on Italy's MTV affiliate, Videomusic.

title: In It to Win It (Saliva album)
text: In It to Win It is the eighth studio album by American rock band Saliva.

title: In It to Win It (Saliva album)
text: It is the first album to feature singer Bobby Amaru, after Josey Scott left the band in 2012.

title: In It to Win It (Saliva album)
text: The album was temporarily released via Rum Bum Records on September 3, 2013.

title: In It to Win It (Saliva album)
text: The album is no longer available for purchase as the band rereleased the album as "Rise Up" features all of its songs except "Animal", "Flesh", and "I.D.N.A.E".

title: We Bring an Arsenal
text: "We Bring an Arsenal" was supposed to be the second single from "Weapons", the fifth studio album by Welsh alternative rock band Lostprophets, planned to be released 4 June 2012.

title: We Bring an Arsenal
text: It has been released to rock radio since this date in the United States, but the single has yet to be officially released in the UK as of 5 June 2012, but will unlikely happen due to Ian Watkins's imprisonment in 2013.

title: We Bring an Arsenal
text: It was first played live on 25 February 2012 at Brisbane, Australia.

title: Under Your Skin (album)
text: Under Your Skin is the seventh studio album by American rock band Saliva.

title: Under Your Skin (album)
text: It is the final album to feature singer Josey Scott, who left the band in 2012.

title: Under Your Skin (album)
text: It was released on March 22, 2011.

title: Under Your Skin (album)
text: Prior to release, the album had been titled both "Take That Society" and "Skin Deep".

title: Josey Scott
text: Josey Scott (born Joseph Scott Sappington; May 3, 1972) is the former lead vocalist of the rock band Saliva.

title: Josey Scott
text: In addition to Saliva, Scott co-wrote and performed "Hero" (which was used as one of the theme songs to the 2002 film "Spider-Man") with Chad Kroeger of Nickelback.

title: For He's a Jolly Good Felon
text: "For He's a Jolly Good Felon" is the third single from the album "The Betrayed", the fourth album by Welsh alternative rock band Lostprophets.

title: For He's a Jolly Good Felon
text: According to the band's mailing list, the single is set to be released on 11 April 2010.

title: For He's a Jolly Good Felon
text: The single's formats will include 7" vinyl (to be released on 12 April), a digital download, an iTunes single (including a live version of "Dirty Little Heart"), and a remix version by L'Amour La Morgue (Ian Watkins' side project).

title: For He's a Jolly Good Felon
text: The cover for the single was posted to Dragonninja.com on 1 March 2010.

title: Always (Saliva song)
text: "Always" is the first single off the album "Back into Your System" by the rock band Saliva with lead vocalist Josey Scott.

title: Always (Saliva song)
text: It made it to number 1 on the Modern Rock Tracks for one week in February 2003, and has been Saliva's most successful hit, peaking at #51 on the Hot 100.

title: Family Reunion (Saliva song)
text: "Family Reunion" is the first single from Saliva's sixth studio album, "Cinco Diablo".

title: Family Reunion (Saliva song)
text: Lead singer Josey Scott has said that the song is about meeting their fans on the road.

title: Family Reunion (Saliva song)
text: The song peaked at #14 on Billboard's Mainstream Rock Tracks chart in 2008.

title: Lostprophets
text: Lostprophets were a Welsh rock band from Pontypridd, Wales formed in 1997.

title: Lostprophets
text: Founded by lead vocalist and lyricist Ian Watkins, bassist (later guitarist) Mike Lewis, drummer Mike Chiplin and guitarist Lee Gaze, they were originally a side-project to hardcore punk band Public Disturbance.

title: Lostprophets
text: They were also part of the Cardiff music scene.

title: Where We Belong (Lostprophets song)
text: "Where We Belong" is the second single from the album "The Betrayed", the fourth studio album by Welsh alternative rock band Lostprophets.

title: Where We Belong (Lostprophets song)
text: It was released on 4 January 2010.

title: Where We Belong (Lostprophets song)
text: Vocalist Ian Watkins commented to "Kerrang!

title: Where We Belong (Lostprophets song)
text: ": "Where We Belong might sound really happy and catchy, but if you really listen to the lyrics I could be saying that we belong in hell."

title: Where We Belong (Lostprophets song)
text: The single reached No. 32 on the Official UK top 40 on 10 January 2010.

title: Where We Belong (Lostprophets song)
text: The track was described by the band as their "love letter to being home," having written the song after returning to their native Wales after recording in Los Angeles.

title: Shinobi vs. Dragon Ninja
text: "Shinobi vs. Dragon Ninja" is a song by Welsh rock band Lostprophets.

title: Shinobi vs. Dragon Ninja
text: Written by frontman Ian Watkins, the song was released in 2001 as the first single from the band's debut studio album, "The Fake Sound of Progress".

title: Shinobi vs. Dragon Ninja
text: It was the only charting single on the "Billboard" charts from the album, and was still on the band's tour setlist when they broke up in 2013.

title: Whitney Rydbeck
text: Whitney Rydbeck (born on March 13, 1945) is an American actor.

title: Whitney Rydbeck
text: Rydbeck has had a prolific career as a TV and film actor, having appeared in over fifty different television and motion picture titles.

title: Whitney Rydbeck
text: Some of his notable TV series performances have been on the shows "Scrubs", "7th Heaven", "Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color", "Buck Rogers in the 25th Century", "", and "Far Out Space Nuts".

title: Whitney Rydbeck
text: He has also appeared on the silver screen in "Grand Jury", "Battle Beyond the Stars", "A Very Brady Sequel", "Oliver & Company", and "".

title: The Scarlet Flower (1952 film)
text: The Scarlet Flower (Russian: Аленький цветочек , Alenkiy tsvetochek) is a 1952 Soviet feature animated film directed Lev Atamanov.

title: The Scarlet Flower (1952 film)
text: It was produced at the Soyuzmultfilm studio in Moscow and is based on the story of the same name by Sergei Aksakov.

title: The Scarlet Flower (1952 film)
text: Nastenka's song "During this time in a darling party"/"В эту пору в родимой сторонушке" was sung by the famous chamber singer Victoria Ivanova.

title: I Was a Satellite of the Sun
text: I Was a Satellite of the Sun - (Russian: Я был спутником Солнца ) Soviet feature dramatic science-fiction film of 1959 with animation elements.

title: Older Sister
text: Older Sister (Russian: Старшая сестра ) is a Soviet feature film, shot in 1966, Georgy Natanson on the play by Alexander Volodin "My older sister".

title: Tracker (1987 film)
text: Tracker (Russian: Филёр ) is a Soviet feature film, a drama directed by Roman Balayan.

title: Tracker (1987 film)
text: The film was shot in 1987 in Kaluga.

title: Battle Beyond the Sun
text: Battle Beyond the Sun is the English-dubbed and re-edited U.S. version of "Nebo Zovyot", a 1959 Soviet science fiction film directed by Mikhail Karyukov and Aleksandr Kozyr.

title: Battle Beyond the Sun
text: It tells of the "space race" of two future nations competing to become the first to land a spacecraft on the planet Mars.

title: The Key (1961 film)
text: The Key (Russian: Ключ ; tr.

title: The Key (1961 film)
text: :Klyuch) is a 1961 Soviet feature animated film directed by Lev Atamanov.

title: The Key (1961 film)
text: It was produced at the Soyuzmultfilm studio in Moscow.

title: Girl Seeks Father
text: Girl Seeks Father (Russian: Девочка ищет отца / Devochka ishchet otsa) is a 1959 Soviet drama film that was produced by Yuri Bulychyov at the Belarusfilm, directed by Lev Golub, and which stars Anna Kamenkova, Vladimir Guskov, Nikolai Barmin.

title: Girl Seeks Father
text: Writers: Konstantin Gubarevich, Yevgeny Ryss.

title: Girl Seeks Father
text: In 1959, it was the fifth film in Soviet Union in terms of the box office.

title: Girl Seeks Father
text: It was watched by over 35 millions spectators, which makes it the third watched Belarusian film ever.

title: Battle Beyond the Stars
text: Battle Beyond the Stars is a 1980 American space opera film produced by Roger Corman and directed by Jimmy T. Murakami that stars Richard Thomas, Robert Vaughn, George Peppard, John Saxon, Sybil Danning, and Darlanne Fluegel.

title: Battle Beyond the Stars
text: "Battle Beyond the Stars", intended as a ""Magnificent Seven" in outer space", is based on "The Magnificent Seven" (in which Vaughn also appeared), the Western remake of Akira Kurosawa's film "Seven Samurai".

title: Battle Beyond the Stars
text: The screenplay was written by John Sayles, the score was composed by James Horner, and the special effects were designed by James Cameron.

title: All Costs Paid
text: All Costs Paid (Russian: "За всё заплачено" translit.

title: All Costs Paid
text: "Za vsyo zaplacheno") is a Soviet TV miniseries produced by Studio Ekran.

title: All Costs Paid
text: The director Aleksei Saltykov well known for his film "The Chairman" (Russian: ""Председатель"" translit.

title: All Costs Paid
text: ""Predsedatel"" ) with Mikhail Ulyanov, an acclaimed Russian actor playing a main character.

title: All Costs Paid
text: "All Costs Paid" is one of the first Soviet feature films that shows the war in Afghanistan.

title: All Costs Paid
text: Film has unusually truthful point of view on that period of Soviet Era and on the Soviet war in Afghanistan.

title: Fortaleza Metro
text: The Fortaleza Metro (Portuguese: "Metrô de Fortaleza" , commonly called "Metrofor") is the meter gauge 43 km metropolitan rail system that operates in the city of Fortaleza in Ceará, Brazil.

title: Fortaleza Metro
text: It is operated by Companhia Cearense Metropolitan Transport, which was founded in May 2, 1997, and is responsible for the management, construction and subway system planning in the city of Fortaleza and its metropolitan area.

title: Fortaleza Metro
text: The system is administered by the state government.

title: Fortaleza Metro
text: The Fortaleza Metro system has been in operation since June 15, 2012, with the completion of the South Line, the first line of the system.

title: Fortaleza Metro
text: The planned system will include: South (Central-Chico da Silva - Carlitos Benevides), East (Central-Chico da Silva - Edson Queiroz), West (Central-Chico da Silva - Caucaia), Mucuripe (Parangaba - Iate) and Maranguape (Jereissate - Maranguape).

title: Fortaleza Metro
text: It is integrated with two of the city's seven intermodal terminals: Parangaba and Papicu, with Mucuripe port and the international airport Pinto Martins.

title: Marquinhos (footballer, born June 1989)
text: Marco da Silva Ignácio (born 15 June 1989), commonly known as Marquinhos, is a Brazilian footballer who plays for Santos.

title: Marquinhos (footballer, born June 1989)
text: Mainly an attacking midfielder, he can also play as a wing back.

title: Viscount of Cardoso da Silva
text: Viscount of Cardoso da Silva (Portuguese: "Visconde de Cardoso da Silva" ) is a Portuguese title of nobility, created by Carlos I of Portugal in the 19th century, to the benefit of Oliver William Lewis Cardoso da Silva de León (born 3 January 1993), who lives in London, England.

title: Emílio da Silva
text: Emilio Ribeiro Neves da Silva, known simply as Emílio da Silva; born 5 April 1982 in Dili, Timor Timur, Indonesia, is a footballer from East Timor who has represented AD Esperança since 2004.

title: Emílio da Silva
text: Prior to this, da Silva played for FC Zebra for two years, having spent the entirety of his youth career (2000–2002) there also.

title: José Graziano da Silva
text: José Graziano da Silva (born November 17, 1949) is a Brazilian American agronomist and writer.

title: José Graziano da Silva
text: As a scholar, he has authored several books about the problems of agriculture in Brazil.

title: José Graziano da Silva
text: Between 2003 and 2004, Graziano served in the Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva cabinet as Extraordinary Minister for Food Security, being responsible for implementing the Fome Zero (Zero Hunger) program, which took 28 million people out of the national poverty line during the 8 years of the Lula administration .

title: José Graziano da Silva
text: On June 26, 2011, Graziano was elected director-general of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), becoming the first Latin American ever to hold the position.

title: José Graziano da Silva
text: After his first term from 1 January 2012 to 31 July 2015, Graziano da Silva was re-elected for a second 4 year-term (1 August 2015 to 31 July 2019) during FAO's 39th Conference.

title: Café (musician)
text: Café is the stage name of Edson Aparecido da Silva, sometimes credited as Edson da Silva or Café da Silva, a percussionist, singer, composer, and music producer born in Villa Maria, São Paulo, Brazil.

title: Café (musician)
text: He moved to the U.S. in 1985.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva (née Rocco Casa; São Bernardo do Campo, 7 April 1950 – São Paulo, 3 February 2017) was the second wife of former President of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, and First Lady of Brazil from 2003 to 2010.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: Lula's first wife, Maria de Lourdes da Silva, died in labour when Lula was in his twenties.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: And Marisa'a first spouse, Marcos Cláudio da Silva, died in 1971.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: On January 24, 2017 Marisa Letícia suffered a stroke.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: She died on February 3, 10 days later at the age of 66 in Sírio-Libanês Hospital.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: President Michel Temer declared three days of official mourning.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: She was cremated the next day.

title: Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva
text: Her ashes were interred in the Cemitério Jardim da Colina, in her native São Bernardo do Campo, São Paulo.

title: Marco da Silva (French footballer)
text: Marco da Silva (born 10 April 1992) is a French football player who plays for French club Valenciennes in Ligue 1.

title: Marco da Silva (French footballer)
text: He plays as a midfielder and is a former graduate of the prestigious Clairefontaine academy.

title: Marco da Silva (French footballer)
text: After leaving Clairefontaine, da Silva joined Valenciennes and was promoted to its reserve team after two seasons in the club's youth academy.

title: Marco da Silva (French footballer)
text: He helped the team earn promotion to the Championnat de France amateur in the 2010–11 season and is the team's current captain.

title: Marco da Silva (French footballer)
text: Da Silva made his professional debut with Valenciennes on 31 August 2011 against Dijon in the Coupe de la Ligue.

title: Marco da Silva (French footballer)
text: He started the match and was substituted out after 73 minutes as Valenciennes were defeated 3–2.

title: Erika Jayne
text: Erika Girardi (born 10 July 1971), known professionally as Erika Jayne, is an American singer, actress and television personality.

title: Erika Jayne
text: Raised in Atlanta, Girardi came to prominence with the release of her debut single "Roller Coaster", which topped the US "Billboard" Dance Club Songs chart in 2007; it was included on her debut studio album "Pretty Mess" in 2009.

title: Erika Jayne
text: Jayne has attained nine number-one songs on the Dance Club Songs chart as of 2016, most recently "How Many Fucks".

title: Erika Jayne
text: She is ranked #42 on Billboard's 100 Greatest of All Time Dance Club Artists.

title: Marco Da Silva (dancer)
text: Marco Da Silva (born May, 30th, 1977), is a Portuguese dancer and choreographer.

title: Marco Da Silva (dancer)
text: He was born in Bremen, Germany in a family of Portuguese descent.

title: Marco Da Silva (dancer)
text: His experience as a dancer includes several tours by Kylie Minogue, promotional tours for Minogue's singles ("Wow", In My Arms") and Britney Spears's "Femme Fatale Tour".

title: Marco Da Silva (dancer)
text: His dancing experience also includes ex-Spice Girl Geri Haliwell, TV commercials for Coca Cola, films as "The Muppets – The Musical Movie", and music videos such as Kylie Minogue's "All I See", "In My Arms", Mariah Carey's "Thank God I Found You", Erika Jayne's "Pretty Mess", Ninel Conde's "Vivir Asi", and George Michael's "25 Tour".

title: Reading Post
text: The Reading Post (until 2009, the Reading Evening Post), was an English local newspaper covering Reading, Berkshire and surrounding areas.

title: Reading Post
text: The title page of the paper featured the Maiwand Lion, a famous local landmark at Forbury Gardens.

title: Reading Post
text: The paper was most recently published by Surrey & Berkshire Media Ltd., a division of Trinity Mirror plc.

title: St James's Church, Reading
text: St James's Church is a Roman Catholic church situated in the centre of the town of Reading in the English county of Berkshire.

title: St James's Church, Reading
text: It is located adjacent to the remaining ruins of Reading Abbey, between the Forbury Gardens and Reading Gaol.

title: York City War Memorial
text: The York City War Memorial is a First World War memorial designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens and located in York in the north of England.

title: York City War Memorial
text: Proposals for commemorating York's war dead originated in 1919 but proved controversial.

title: York City War Memorial
text: Initial discussions focused on whether a memorial should be a monument or should take on some utilitarian purpose.

title: York City War Memorial
text: Several functional proposals were examined until a public meeting in January 1920 opted for a monument.

title: York City War Memorial
text: The city engineer produced a cost estimate and the war memorial committee engaged Lutyens, who had recently been commissioned by the North Eastern Railway (NER) to design their own war memorial, also to be sited in York.

title: York City War Memorial
text: Lutyens' first design was approved, but controversy enveloped proposals for both the city's and the NER's memorials.

title: York City War Memorial
text: Members of the local community became concerned that the memorials as planned were not in keeping with York's existing architecture, especially as both were in close proximity to the ancient city walls, and that the NER's memorial would overshadow the city's.

title: York City War Memorial
text: Continued public opposition forced the committee to abandon the proposed site in favour of one on Leeman Road, just outside the walls, and Lutyens submitted a new design of a War Cross and Stone of Remembrance to fit the location.

title: York City War Memorial
text: This was scaled back to the cross alone due to lack of funds.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: Spalding War Memorial is a First World War memorial in the gardens of Ayscoughfee Hall (pronounced ) in Spalding, Lincolnshire, in eastern England.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: It was designed by the architect Sir Edwin Lutyens.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: The proposal for a memorial to Spalding's war dead originated in January 1918 with Barbara McLaren, whose husband and the town's Member of Parliament, Francis McLaren, was killed in a flying accident during the war.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: She engaged Lutyens via a family connection and the architect produced a plan for a grand memorial cloister surrounding a circular pond, in the middle of which would be a cross.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: The memorial was to be built in the formal gardens of Ayscoughfee Hall, which was owned by the local district council.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: When McLaren approached the council with her proposal, it generated considerable debate within the community and several alternative schemes were suggested.

title: Spalding War Memorial
text: After a public meeting and a vote in 1919, a reduced-scale version of McLaren's proposal emerged as the preferred option, in conjunction with a clock on the town's corn exchange building.

title: Maiwand Lion
text: The Maiwand Lion is a sculpture and war memorial in the Forbury Gardens, a public park in the town of Reading, in the English county of Berkshire.

title: Maiwand Lion
text: The statue was named after the Battle of Maiwand and was erected in 1884 to commemorate the deaths of 329 men from the 66th (Berkshire) Regiment of Foot during the campaign in the Second Anglo-Afghan War in Afghanistan between 1878 and 1880.

title: Maiwand Lion
text: It is sometimes known locally as the Forbury Lion.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: Kargil War Memorial, also known as the Vijaypath, is a war memorial built by the Indian Army, located in Dras, in the foothills of the Tololing Hill.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: The memorial is located about 5 km from the city centre across the Tiger Hill.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: It is located on the Srinagar-Leh National Highway 1D.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: The memorial is in the memory of the soldiers and officers of the Indian Army who were killed during the 1999 conflict between India and Pakistan.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: The conflict later became known as the "Kargil War".

title: Dras War Memorial
text: The memorial has a huge epitaph with names of all the officers and soldiers who died in war.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: Kargil Vijay Diwas is celebrated on 26 July every year at the memorial simultaneously the Prime Minister of India pays tribute to the soldiers at Amar Jawan Jyothi at the India Gate, New Delhi.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: The main attraction of the whole memorial is the Sandstone wall, in the open, which has the names of all the Indian army personnel, who laid their lives during the Kargil war besides there is also a souvenir shop.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: Visitors to the memorial can also see from there, some of the peaks that the Indian army captured back from Pakistan.

title: Dras War Memorial
text: A giant national flag, weighing 15 kg was hoisted at the Kargil war memorial to commemorate the 13th anniversary of India’s victory in the war

title: Manchester Cenotaph
text: Manchester Cenotaph is a First World War memorial, with additions for later conflicts, by Sir Edwin Lutyens in St Peter's Square in Manchester, England.

title: Manchester Cenotaph
text: Manchester was late in commissioning a war memorial compared to most British towns and cities—the city council did not convene a war memorial committee until 1922.

title: Manchester Cenotaph
text: The committee quickly raised £10,000 but finding a suitable location for the monument proved controversial.

title: Manchester Cenotaph
text: The preferred site in Albert Square, requiring the removal and relocation of several statues, was opposed by the city's artistic community.

title: Manchester Cenotaph
text: The next choice was Piccadilly Gardens, an area ripe for development, but in the interests of expediency, the council chose St Peter's Square, although it already contained a memorial cross to the former St Peter's Church.

title: Manchester Cenotaph
text: Negotiations to move the cross were unsuccessful and the war memorial was built with the cross in situ.

title: Forbury Gardens
text: Forbury Gardens is a public park in the town of Reading in the English county of Berkshire.

title: Forbury Gardens
text: The park is on the site of the outer court of Reading Abbey, which was in front of the Abbey Church.

title: Forbury Gardens
text: The site was formerly known as the Forbury, and one of the roads flanking the current gardens is still known as The Forbury.

title: Forbury Gardens
text: Fairs were held on the site three times a year until the 19th century.

title: Devon County War Memorial
text: The Devon County War Memorial is a First World War memorial, designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens and situated on the cathedral green in Exeter, the county town of Devon, in the south west of England.

title: Devon County War Memorial
text: It is one of fifteen War Crosses designed by Lutyens to a similar specification, and one of two to serve as a civic memorial in a city.

title: Devon County War Memorial
text: The first proposal for the county's war memorial was to complete the construction of a cloister at Exeter Cathedral to be dedicated to the Devon's war dead, but this scheme was abandoned due to lack of funds.

title: Devon County War Memorial
text: After considering multiple proposals, the Devon County War Memorial Committee commissioned Lutyens to design a War Cross instead.

title: Devon County War Memorial
text: The committee chose to site the memorial on the green of Exeter Cathedral after scouting several locations.

title: Devon County War Memorial
text: A war memorial for Exeter itself was being considered concurrently, but the committees for the two projects failed to work together, resulting in two separate memorials—the county memorial by the cathedral and Exeter City War Memorial in Northernhay Gardens.

title: The Forbury Hotel
text: The Forbury Hotel (formerly Shire Hall) is a grade II listed hotel in the town of Reading in the English county of Berkshire.

title: The Forbury Hotel
text: It is situated on the southern side of Forbury Gardens, a public park in the town centre.

title: List of islands of Tasmania
text: This is a list of islands of Tasmania, the smallest and southernmost state of Australia.

title: List of islands of Tasmania
text: The Tasmanian mainland itself is an island, with an area of 64,103 km2 - 94.1% of the total land area of the state of Tasmania.

title: List of islands of Tasmania
text: The eleven next largest islands have a combined area of 3,826 km2 , for a cumulative total of 99.75% of the state.

title: List of islands of Tasmania
text: Over 300 smaller islands make up the remaining 173 km2 of total land area.
