title: Ashanti Region
text: The Ashanti Region is located in south Ghana and is third largest of 10 administrative regions, occupying a total land surface of 24389 km2 or 10.2 per cent of the total land area of Ghana.

title: Ashanti Region
text: In terms of population, however, it is the most populated region with a population of 4,780,380 according to the 2010 census, accounting for 19.4% of Ghana’s total population.

title: Ashanti Region
text: The Ashanti Region is known for its major gold bar and cocoa production.

title: Ashanti Region
text: The largest city and regional capital is Kumasi.

title: Geography of the Philippines
text: The Philippines is an archipelago that consists of 7,641 islands with a total land area of 301780 km2 .

title: Geography of the Philippines
text: The 11 largest islands contain 95% of the total land area.

title: Geography of the Philippines
text: The largest of these islands is Luzon at about 105000 km2 .

title: Geography of the Philippines
text: The next largest island is Mindanao at about 95000 km2 .

title: Geography of the Philippines
text: The archipelago is around 800 km from the Asian mainland and is located between Taiwan and Borneo.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: The Kingdom of the Isles comprised the Hebrides, the islands of the Firth of Clyde and the Isle of Man from the 9th to the 13th centuries AD.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: The islands were known to the Norse as the "Suðreyjar", or "Southern Isles" as distinct from the "Norðreyjar" or Northern Isles of Orkney and Shetland.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: The historical record is incomplete and the kingdom was probably not a continuous entity throughout the entire period.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: The islands concerned are sometimes referred to as the "Kingdom of Mann and the Isles", although only some of the later rulers claimed that title.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: At times the rulers were independent of external control, although for much of the period they had overlords in Norway, Ireland, England, Scotland or Orkney.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: At times there also appear to have been competing claims for all or parts of the territory.

title: List of rulers of the Kingdom of the Isles
text: The islands involved have a total land area of over 8300 km2 and extend for more than 500 km from north to south.

title: Aonghus Mór
text: Aonghus Mór mac Domhnaill (died c.1293) was a leading figure in the thirteenth-century kingdoms of the Isles and Scotland.

title: Aonghus Mór
text: He was a son of Domhnall mac Raghnaill, the eponym of Clann Domhnaill, a branch of Clann Somhairle.

title: Aonghus Mór
text: Aonghus Mór appears to have succeeded his father in the mid part of the thirteenth century.

title: Aonghus Mór
text: At the time, the rulers of the Isles were fiercely independent of the Scottish Crown, and owed nominal allegiance to the distant Norwegian Crown.

title: Aonghus Mór
text: Aonghus Mór's first certain appearance in the historical record seems to evince his involvement in aiding native Irish kindreds against the consolidation of Anglo-Irish authority in the north-west Ireland.

title: Aonghus Mór
text: Such cooperation could have been undertaken in the context of overseas kindreds like Clann Domhnaill constructing Irish alliances to gain assistance against Scottish encroachment.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: The Kingdom of the Isles comprised the Hebrides, the islands of the Firth of Clyde and the Isle of Man from the 9th to the 13th centuries AD.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: The islands were known to the Norse as the "Suðreyjar", or "Southern Isles" as distinct from the "Norðreyjar" or Northern Isles of Orkney and Shetland.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: The historical record is incomplete, and the kingdom was not a continuous entity throughout the entire period.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: The islands concerned are sometimes referred to as the Kingdom of Mann and the Isles, although only some of the later rulers claimed that title.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: At times the rulers were independent of external control, although for much of the period they had overlords in Norway, Ireland, England, Scotland or Orkney.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: At times there also appear to have been competing claims for all or parts of the territory.

title: Kingdom of the Isles
text: The islands involved have a total land area of over 8300 km2 and extend for more than 500 km from north to south.

title: Lord of Islay
text: Lord of Islay was a thirteenth- and fourteenth-century title borne by the chiefs of Clann Domhnaill before they assumed the title "Lord of the Isles" in the late fourteenth century.

title: Lord of Islay
text: The first person regarded to have styled themself "Lord of Islay" is Aonghus Mór, son of the eponymous ancestor of the clan, Domhnall mac Raghnaill.

title: Lord of Islay
text: The designation "of Islay" was frequently used by these lords and later members of the clan.

title: Jaluit Atoll
text: Jaluit Atoll (Marshallese: Jālwōj , , or Jālooj , ) is a large coral atoll of 91 islands in the Pacific Ocean and forms a legislative district of the Ralik Chain of the Marshall Islands.

title: Jaluit Atoll
text: Its total land area is 11.34 km2 , and it encloses a lagoon with an area of 690 km2 .

title: Jaluit Atoll
text: Most of the land area is on the largest islet (motu) of Jaluit (10.4 km2).

title: Jaluit Atoll
text: Jaluit is approximately 220 km southwest of Majuro.

title: Jaluit Atoll
text: Jaluit Atoll is a designated conservation area and Ramsar Wetland.

title: National parks of Taiwan
text: National parks of Taiwan are protected spaces for their nature, wildlife, and history in its current jurisdiction.

title: National parks of Taiwan
text: Currently there are nine national parks in Taiwan, all are under the administration of the Ministry of the Interior.

title: National parks of Taiwan
text: These national parks covers 7489.49 km2 .

title: National parks of Taiwan
text: The 3103.76 km2 total land area constitutes around 8.6% of the entire land area of the country.

title: Protected areas of Himachal Pradesh
text: Forests in Himachal Pradesh currently cover an area of nearly 37,691 sqkm , which is about 38.3% of the total land area of the state.

title: Protected areas of Himachal Pradesh
text: The forests were once considered to be the main source of income of the state and most of the original forests were clear felled.

title: Protected areas of Himachal Pradesh
text: The emphasis has shifted, however, from exploitation to conservation.

title: Protected areas of Himachal Pradesh
text: The state government aims to increase forest cover to 50% of the total land area.

title: Protected areas of Himachal Pradesh
text: There have been various projects, including the establishment of protected areas such as National Parks, designed to preserve and expand the forests.

title: Azra
text: Azra was a rock band that was popular across Yugoslavia in the 1980s.

title: Azra
text: Azra was formed in 1977 by its frontman Branimir "Johnny" Štulić.

title: Azra
text: The other two members of the original line-up were Mišo Hrnjak (bass) and Boris Leiner (drums).

title: Azra
text: The band is named after a verse from "Der Asra" by Heinrich Heine.

title: Azra
text: They are considered to be one of the most influential bands from the former Yugoslav new wave rock era and the Yugoslav rock scene in general.

title: Cargo Records (Canada)
text: Cargo Records was a Canadian independent record label and distributor, active in the 1980s and 1990s.

title: Cargo Records (Canada)
text: Based in Montreal, the company both released albums directly as a label, and distributed albums on behalf of many other small independent labels, making it one of the largest and most influential Canadian record companies of the alternative rock era.

title: Adam and the Ants
text: Adam and the Ants were an English rock band active during the late 1970s and early 1980s.

title: Adam and the Ants
text: The group, which lasted from 1977 to 1982, existed in two incarnations, both fronted by Adam Ant.

title: Adam and the Ants
text: The first, founded in May 1977 and known simply as The Ants until November that year, achieved considerable cult popularity during the transition from the punk rock era to the post-punk and new wave era and were noted for their high camp and overtly sexualised stage performances and songs.

title: Adam and the Ants
text: The final line-up of this first incarnation – Dave Barbarossa, Matthew Ashman and Leigh Gorman – left the band in January 1980 at the suggestion of then-de facto manager Malcolm McLaren, to form the instrumentalist personnel of the controversial Bow Wow Wow.

title: The Beach Boys
text: The Beach Boys are an American rock band formed in Hawthorne, California, in 1961.

title: The Beach Boys
text: The group's original lineup consisted of brothers Brian, Dennis, and Carl Wilson; their cousin Mike Love; and their friend Al Jardine.

title: The Beach Boys
text: Distinguished by their vocal harmonies and early surf songs, they are one of the most influential acts of the rock era.

title: The Beach Boys
text: The group, led by their principal songwriter and producer Brian, pioneered novel approaches to popular music form and production, combining their affinities for jazz-based vocal groups, 1950s rock and roll, and black R&B to create their unique sound.

title: The Beach Boys
text: He later arranged his compositions for studio orchestras and explored a variety of other styles, often incorporating classical or jazz elements and unconventional recording techniques in innovative ways.

title: The Beatles
text: The Beatles were an English rock band formed in Liverpool in 1960.

title: The Beatles
text: With members John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, they became widely regarded as the foremost and most influential act of the rock era.

title: The Beatles
text: Rooted in skiffle, beat and 1950s rock and roll, the Beatles later experimented with several musical styles, ranging from pop ballads and Indian music to psychedelia and hard rock, often incorporating classical elements and unconventional recording techniques in innovative ways.

title: The Beatles
text: In 1963 their enormous popularity first emerged as "Beatlemania", and as the group's music grew in sophistication in subsequent years, led by primary songwriters Lennon and McCartney, they came to be perceived as an embodiment of the ideals shared by the counterculture of the 1960s.

title: Marsha Albert
text: Marsha Albert (born 1948) is credited with being the person who jump-started the early 1960s phenomena known as Beatlemania in the United States when as a 15-year-old girl, on 17 December 1963, she introduced for the first time on American radio a song written and recorded by The Beatles titled I Want to Hold Your Hand (the Beatles' best-selling single worldwide), and that Beatles historian and author Bruce Spizer noted, in 2004, by his stating "Marsha Albert's actions forced a major record company to push up the release date of a debut single from an unknown band during the holiday season, a time when record companies traditionally released no new product."

title: Cultural impact of the Beatles
text: The Beatles were an English rock band, formed in Liverpool in 1960.

title: Cultural impact of the Beatles
text: With members John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, they became widely regarded as the foremost and most influential act of the rock era.

title: Cultural impact of the Beatles
text: In the early 1960s, their enormous popularity first emerged as "Beatlemania", but as the group's music grew in sophistication, led by primary songwriters Lennon and McCartney, they came to be perceived as an embodiment of the ideals shared by the counterculture of the 1960s.

title: Cultural depictions of Elvis Presley
text: Elvis Presley has inspired artistic and cultural works since he entered the national consciousness.

title: Cultural depictions of Elvis Presley
text: From that point, interest in his personal and public life has never stopped.

title: Cultural depictions of Elvis Presley
text: Some scholars have even studied many aspects of his profound cultural influence. "

title: Cultural depictions of Elvis Presley
text: Billboard" historian Joel Whitburn declared Presley the "#1 act of the Rock era".

title: Bruce Spizer
text: David "Bruce" Spizer (born July 2, 1955) is a tax attorney in New Orleans, Louisiana, who is also recognized as an expert on The Beatles.

title: Bruce Spizer
text: He has published eight books, and is frequently quoted as an authority on the history of the band and its recordings.

title: Christian Death
text: Christian Death is an American deathrock band formed in Los Angeles, California, in 1979 by Rozz Williams.

title: Christian Death
text: They became a highly influential act, heralding the American gothic rock and deathrock movements.

title: High Lonesome (Randy Travis album)
text: High Lonesome is the seventh studio album by American country music artist Randy Travis, released on August 27, 1991.

title: High Lonesome (Randy Travis album)
text: Four singles were released from the album: "Forever Together" (#1 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Songs charts), "Better Class of Losers" (#2), "Point of Light" (#3), and "I'd Surrender All" reached number 20.

title: High Lonesome (Randy Travis album)
text: All of these singles except "Point of Light" were co-written by Travis and country singer Alan Jackson.

title: High Lonesome (Randy Travis album)
text: Conversely, Travis co-wrote Jackson's 1992 Number One hit "She's Got the Rhythm (And I Got the Blues)" from his 1992 album "A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)".

title: Steers & Stripes
text: Steers & Stripes is the seventh studio album, released in 2001, by country duo Brooks & Dunn on Arista Nashville.

title: Steers & Stripes
text: The album produced five singles on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now Hot Country Songs) charts, of which the first three were all Number Ones.

title: Steers & Stripes
text: "Ain't Nothing 'bout You", the first single, became the duo's biggest hit, not only spending six weeks at the top of the country charts, but also reaching #25 on the Billboard Hot 100.

title: Steers & Stripes
text: The song was also declared by "Billboard" as the Number One country song for the entire year of 2001.

title: Steers & Stripes
text: Following it were "Only in America" and "The Long Goodbye" (the latter of which was later a pop hit for Ronan Keating, co-written with Paul Brady).

title: Steers & Stripes
text: The last two singles were the #5 "My Heart Is Lost to You" and the #12 "Every River".

title: Nothin' 'bout Love Makes Sense
text: "Nothin' 'bout Love Makes Sense" is a song written by Gary Burr, Joel Feeney and Kylie Sackley, and performed by American country music artist LeAnn Rimes.

title: Nothin' 'bout Love Makes Sense
text: It was released in August 2004 as the first single from Rimes' album "This Woman".

title: Nothin' 'bout Love Makes Sense
text: The song peaked at number five on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.

title: Nothin' 'bout Love Makes Sense
text: A music video was also released in 2004 for the song.

title: Holler Back
text: Holler Back is the fifth studio album by American country music group The Lost Trailers.

title: Holler Back
text: It was released on August 26, 2008 as their second album for BNA Records.

title: Holler Back
text: The album's title track was released in March 2008, becoming their first Top 10 hit that year with a peak at number 9.

title: Holler Back
text: Following it was "How 'bout You Don't", a Top 20 hit.

title: Holler Back
text: "All This Love" was originally chosen as the third single for release in June 2009 but after "Country Folks Livin' Loud" charted as an album cut, it was released as the album's next single.

title: (Who Says) You Can't Have It All
text: "(Who Says) You Can't Have It All" is a song co-written and recorded by American country music artist Alan Jackson.

title: (Who Says) You Can't Have It All
text: It was released in January 1994 as the fifth and final single from his album "A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)".

title: (Who Says) You Can't Have It All
text: The song peaked at number 4 on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot Country Singles chart and number 11 on the Canadian "RPM" Country Tracks chart.

title: (Who Says) You Can't Have It All
text: Jackson wrote the song with Jim McBride.

title: A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)
text: A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love) is the third studio album by American country music artist Alan Jackson.

title: A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)
text: It was released on October 6, 1992, and produced the singles "Chattahoochee", "She's Got the Rhythm (And I Got the Blues)", "Tonight I Climbed the Wall", "(Who Says) You Can't Have It All" and "Mercury Blues".

title: A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)
text: "Chattahoochee" and "She's Got the Rhythm" were both Number One hits on the Hot Country Songs charts, while the other three songs all reached Top Five.

title: Chattahoochee (song)
text: "Chattahoochee" is a song co-written and recorded by American country music artist Alan Jackson.

title: Chattahoochee (song)
text: It was released in May 1993 as the third single from his album "A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)".

title: Chattahoochee (song)
text: The album is named for a line in the song itself.

title: Chattahoochee (song)
text: Jackson wrote the song with Jim McBride.

title: Tonight I Climbed the Wall
text: "Tonight I Climbed the Wall" is a song written and performed by American country music artist Alan Jackson.

title: Tonight I Climbed the Wall
text: It was released in January 1993 as the second single from his album "A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)".

title: Tonight I Climbed the Wall
text: It peaked at number 4 on both the United States "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart and the Canadian "RPM" Country Tracks chart.

title: She's Got the Rhythm (And I Got the Blues)
text: "She's Got the Rhythm (And I Got the Blues)" is a song co-written by American country music artists Alan Jackson and Randy Travis, and performed by Jackson.

title: She's Got the Rhythm (And I Got the Blues)
text: It was released in October 1992 as the first single from his album "A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)".

title: She's Got the Rhythm (And I Got the Blues)
text: The song received an award in 1993 from Music City News for being one of the most performed country songs of the year.

title: Alan Jackson albums discography
text: Alan Jackson is an American country music artist.

title: Alan Jackson albums discography
text: The first artist signed to Arista Nashville Records, he was with them from 1989 to 2011.

title: Alan Jackson albums discography
text: He has released sixteen studio albums, two Christmas albums, ten compilations, and a tribute album for the label.

title: Alan Jackson albums discography
text: His first two greatest hits albums (1995's "The Greatest Hits Collection" and 2003's "Greatest Hits Volume II") as well as his 1992 studio album "A Lot About Livin' (And a Little 'bout Love)" are all his highest-certified albums, each certified 6× Platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America, with sales in the US of over 6,000,000.

title: Alan Jackson albums discography
text: He has sold over 40 million albums in the US since 1991 when Nielsen SoundScan began tracking sales for Billboard.

title: Black 13
text: Black 13 is a 1953 British crime drama film directed by Ken Hughes and starring Peter Reynolds, Rona Anderson, Patrick Barr and John Le Mesurier.

title: Black 13
text: The film is a remake of the 1948 Italian film "Gioventù perduta" (a.k.a. "Lost Youth") by Pietro Germi.

title: Black 13
text: It was made by Vandyke Productions.

title: Lipstick (1960 film)
text: Il rossetto (internationally released as Lipstick) is a 1960 Italian crime-drama film directed by Damiano Damiani.

title: Lipstick (1960 film)
text: It is the feature film debut of Damiani, after two documentaries and several screenplays.

title: Lipstick (1960 film)
text: The film's plot was loosely inspired by actual events.

title: Lipstick (1960 film)
text: Pietro Germi reprised, with very slight modifications, the character he played in "Un maledetto imbroglio".

title: Cineriz
text: Cineriz was an Italian media company, involved primarily in the production and distribution of films, founded in the early 50s by the businessman Angelo Rizzoli.

title: Cineriz
text: The company catalogue counts also many movies directed by Federico Fellini, Gillo Pontecorvo, Luchino Visconti, Michelangelo Antonioni, Pier Paolo Pasolini, Pietro Germi, Roberto Rossellini and Vittorio De Sica.

title: Serafino (film)
text: Serafino (also known as "Serafino ou L'amour aux champs" in France) is a 1968 Italian film directed by Pietro Germi.

title: Commedia all'italiana
text: Commedia all'italiana (i.e. "Comedy in the Italian way"; ] ) or Italian-style comedy is an Italian film genre.

title: Commedia all'italiana
text: It is widely considered to have started with Mario Monicelli's "I soliti ignoti" ("Big Deal on Madonna Street") in 1958 and derives its name from the title of Pietro Germi's "Divorzio all'italiana" ("Divorce Italian Style", 1961).

title: The Testimony (1946 film)
text: The Testimony (Italian:Il testimone) is 1946 Italian crime film directed by Pietro Germi and starring Roldano Lupi, Marina Berti and Ernesto Almirante.

title: The Testimony (1946 film)
text: The film was made at the Cines Studios in Rome.

title: The Testimony (1946 film)
text: It is one of several films regarded as an antecedent of the later giallo thrillers.

title: Pietro Germi
text: Pietro Germi (] ; 14 September 1914 – 5 December 1974) was an Italian actor, screenwriter, and director.

title: Pietro Germi
text: Germi was born in Genoa, Liguria, to a lower-middle-class family.

title: Pietro Germi
text: He was a messenger and briefly attended nautical school before deciding on a career in acting.

title: Ottavio Alessi
text: Born in Cammarata, Province of Agrigento, Alessi entered the film industry in 1940 as an assistant director.

title: Ottavio Alessi
text: In 1945 he started an intense career as a screenwriter, alternating between genre films and art films and collaborating with Pietro Germi, Franco Rossi, Folco Quilici and Luciano Salce, among others.

title: Ottavio Alessi
text: He also directed two films in the 1960s.

title: Divorce Italian Style
text: Divorce Italian Style (Italian: "Divorzio all'italiana" ) is a 1961 Italian comedy film directed by Pietro Germi.

title: Divorce Italian Style
text: The screenplay was written by Ennio De Concini, Pietro Germi, Alfredo Giannetti, and Agenore Incrocci; based on the novel "Un delitto d'onore" ("Honour Killing") by Giovanni Arpino.

title: Divorce Italian Style
text: It stars Marcello Mastroianni, Daniela Rocca, Stefania Sandrelli, Lando Buzzanca, and Leopoldo Trieste.

title: Divorce Italian Style
text: The movie won the Academy Award for Best Writing, Story and Screenplay - Written Directly for the Screen; Mastroianni was nominated for Best Actor in a Leading Role (Marcello Mastroianni) and Germi for Best Director.

title: Path of Hope
text: Path of Hope (Italian: "Il Cammino della speranza" ) is a 1950 Italian language drama film directed by Pietro Germi that belongs to the Italian neorealism film movement.

title: Path of Hope
text: It is based on Nino Di Maria's novel "Cuori negli abissi".

title: Path of Hope
text: Federico Fellini co-wrote the script.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: The Washington Senators baseball team was one of the American League's eight charter franchises.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: The club was founded in Washington, D.C. in as the Washington Senators.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: In , the team changed its official name to the Washington Nationals.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: The name "Nationals" appeared on the uniforms for only two seasons, and was then replaced with the "W" logo for the next 52 years.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: However, the names "Senators", "Nationals" and shorter "Nats" were used interchangeably by fans and media for the next sixty years; in , the latter two names were revived for the current National League franchise that had previously played in Montreal.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: For a time, from 1911 to 1933, the Senators were one of the more successful franchises in Major League Baseball.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: The team's rosters included Baseball Hall of Fame members Goose Goslin, Sam Rice, Joe Cronin, Bucky Harris, Heinie Manush and one of the greatest players and pitchers of all time, Walter Johnson.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: But the Senators are remembered more for their many years of mediocrity and futility, including six last-place finishes in the 1940s and 1950s.

title: History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)
text: Joe Judge, Cecil Travis, Buddy Myer, Roy Sievers and Eddie Yost were other notable Senators players whose careers were spent in obscurity due to the team's lack of success.

title: Baltimore Orioles
text: The Baltimore Orioles are an American professional baseball team based in Baltimore, Maryland.

title: Baltimore Orioles
text: The Orioles compete in Major League Baseball (MLB) as a member of the American League (AL) East division.

title: Baltimore Orioles
text: As one of the AL's original eight charter franchises when the league was established in 1901, this particular franchise spent its first year as a major league club in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, as the Milwaukee Brewers before moving to St. Louis, Missouri to become the St. Louis Browns.

title: Baltimore Orioles
text: After 52 often-beleaguered years in St. Louis, the franchise was purchased in November 1953 by a syndicate of Baltimore business and civic interests led by attorney/civic activist Clarence Miles and Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro, Jr. The team's current majority owner is lawyer Peter Angelos.

title: Boston Red Sox
text: The Boston Red Sox are an American professional baseball team based in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Boston Red Sox
text: The Red Sox compete in Major League Baseball (MLB) as a member club of the American League (AL) East division.

title: Boston Red Sox
text: The Red Sox have won eight World Series championships and have played in twelve.

title: Boston Red Sox
text: Founded in 1901 as one of the American League's eight charter franchises, the Red Sox' home ballpark has been Fenway Park since 1912 .

title: Boston Red Sox
text: The "Red Sox" name was chosen by the team owner, John I. Taylor, around 1908 , following the lead of previous teams that had been known as the "Boston Red Stockings", including the forerunner of the Atlanta Braves.

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: The Atlanta Braves are a professional baseball team based in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: The Braves are members of the National League (NL) East division in Major League Baseball (MLB).

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: Since the franchise started as the Boston Red Stockings (no relationship to the current Boston Red Sox team) in 1871, the team has changed its name several times and relocated twice.

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: The Braves were a charter member of the NL in 1876 as the Boston Red Caps, and are one of the NL's two remaining charter franchises (the other being the Chicago Cubs).

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: In baseball, the head coach of a team is called the manager, or more formally, the field manager.

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: The duties of the team manager include team strategy and leadership on and off the field.

title: List of Atlanta Braves managers
text: The Braves franchise has employed 45 managers.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: The Detroit Tigers are a professional baseball team based in Detroit, Michigan.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: The Tigers are members of the American League Central Division in Major League Baseball.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: In baseball, the head coach of a team is called the manager, or more formally, the field manager.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: The duties of the team manager include team strategy and leadership on and off the field.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: The team initially began in the now defunct Western League in 1894, and later became one of the American League's eight charter franchises in 1901.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: Since the inception of the team in 1894, it has employed 46 different managers.

title: List of Detroit Tigers managers
text: The Tigers current manager is Brad Ausmus, who was hired for the 2014 season.

title: Wayne Garland
text: Marcus Wayne Garland (born October 26, 1950) is a retired American right-handed pitcher who spent nine seasons from 1973 to 1981 in Major League Baseball (MLB) with the Baltimore Orioles (1973–1976) and Cleveland Indians (1977–1981).

title: Wayne Garland
text: He was one of 24 ballplayers who profited from the advent of MLB free agency following the 1976 season.

title: Wayne Garland
text: A torn rotator cuff rendered his playing career into a cautionary tale of the risks of signing pitchers to free-agent contracts of seven years or longer.

title: Wayne Garland
text: The article outlined how Garland was constantly criticized by Cleveland's incompetent management for not living up to his contract (even though his decline in performance was entirely due to a serious arm injury that could not be fixed effectively by mid-1970's sports medicine) and had fans savagely booing him and even vandalizing his car during games.

title: History of the Cleveland Indians
text: The Cleveland Indians are a professional baseball team based in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: History of the Cleveland Indians
text: They are in the Central Division of Major League Baseball's American League.

title: History of the Cleveland Indians
text: Since 1994, they have played in Progressive Field.

title: History of the Cleveland Indians
text: The Cleveland team originated in 1900 as the Lake Shores, when the American League (AL) was officially a minor league.

title: History of the Cleveland Indians
text: One of the AL's eight charter franchises, the major league incarnation of the club was founded in Cleveland in 1901.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: The Guelph Royals are a baseball team based in the downtown area of Guelph, Ontario, and are a member of the Southern Ontario-based Intercounty Baseball League.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: The Royals are an iconic symbol of Guelph pride.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: The club was founded in 1861 as the Guelph Maple Leafs, and after winning the "Canadian Silver Ball Championship" three times between 1869 and 1872, went on to become world semi-professional champions in 1874, and hold brief membership in the International Association for Professional Base Ball Players during the 1877 season, rivalling National League teams.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: In 1919, they joined the Intercounty Baseball League, and underwent a series of name changes (the Guelph-Waterloo Royals in 1954; the Guelph Plymouths in 1957; the Guelph Merchants in 1958; the Guelph Royals in 1962; the Guelph CJOYs in 1964) before being officially renamed the "Royals".

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: From 1861 to 1925, the team divided its home games between various ballparks in the city, before the construction of a stadium in Exhibition Park led them to permanently play there.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: In 1986, they moved into a new stadium, David E. Hastings Stadium, also in Exhibition Park.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: In spite of only winning one Intercounty championship between 1932 and 1993, the team has done well in recent years, winning four since.

title: Guelph Royals (baseball)
text: They currently hold nine Intercounty championships, behind the Kitchener Panthers, with 12, and the Brantford Red Sox, with 10, and are one of only two remaining charter franchises in the league, along with the Kitchener Panthers.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: The Minnesota Twins are an American professional baseball team based in Minneapolis, Minnesota, and play in the Central Division of Major League Baseball's American League.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: The team is named after the Twin Cities area of Minneapolis and St. Paul, Minnesota.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: One of the American League's eight charter franchises, the club was founded in Kansas City, Kansas in 1894 as the Kansas City Blues before moving to Washington, D.C. and renamed Senators.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: In 1905 the team changed its official name to the Washington Nationals.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: The name "Nationals" would appear on the uniforms for only 2 seasons, and would then be replaced with the "W" logo for the next 52 years.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: The media often shortened the nickname to "Nats".

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: Many fans and newspapers (especially out-of-town papers) persisted in using the "Senators" nickname.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: Over time, "Nationals" faded as a nickname, and "Senators" became dominant.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: Baseball guides would list the club's nickname as "Nationals or Senators", acknowledging the dual-nickname situation.

title: History of the Minnesota Twins
text: In 1961, the Senators relocated to Minnesota and were renamed the Twins.

title: Detroit Tigers
text: The Detroit Tigers are an American professional baseball team based in Detroit, Michigan.

title: Detroit Tigers
text: The Tigers compete in Major League Baseball (MLB) as a member club of the American League (AL) Central division.

title: Detroit Tigers
text: One of the AL's eight charter franchises, the club was founded in Detroit in 1901 .

title: Detroit Tigers
text: They are the oldest continuous one-name, one-city franchise in the AL The Tigers have won four World Series championships (, , , and ), 11 AL pennants (1907, 1908, 1909, 1934, 1935, 1940, 1945, 1968, 1984, 2006, 2012), and four AL Central division championships (2011, 2012, 2013, and 2014).

title: Detroit Tigers
text: The Tigers also won division titles in 1972, 1984 and 1987 while members of the AL East.

title: Detroit Tigers
text: The team currently plays its home games at Comerica Park in Downtown Detroit.

title: Antoine Quinquet
text: Antoine Quinquet was a French pharmacist who was born in Soissons on 9 March 1745.

title: Antoine Quinquet
text: In 1760 he was apprenticed to an apothecary in Soissons and in 1777 he moved to Paris where he worked for Antoine Baumé.

title: Antoine Quinquet
text: He travelled to Geneva, where he met Aimé Argand.

title: Antoine Quinquet
text: In 1779, he returned to Paris and opened his own pharmacy there.

title: Trouble light
text: A trouble light, also known as a rough service light, drop light, or inspection lamp, is a special lamp used to illuminate obscure places and able to handle moderate abuse.

title: Trouble light
text: The light bulb is housed in a protective cage and a handle that are molded to form a single unit.

title: Trouble light
text: It has a long power line for distant reaching; the handle may also have electrical outlet on it, allowing the light to also double as an extension cord.

title: Lewis lamp
text: The Lewis lamp is a type of light fixture used in lighthouses.

title: Lewis lamp
text: It was invented by Winslow Lewis who patented the design in 1810.

title: Lewis lamp
text: The primary marketing point of the Lewis lamp was that it used less than half the oil of the prior oil lamps which they replaced.

title: Lewis lamp
text: The lamp used a similar design to an Argand lamp, adding a parabolic reflector behind the lamp and a magnifying lens made from 4 in green bottle glass in front of the lamp.

title: Lewis lamp
text: A similar variant using a parabolic reflector was created by the inventor of the Argand lamp, Aimé Argand.

title: Lewis lamp
text: While the Argand variant became widely used by European lighthouses, the Lewis lamp design was selected by the United States for use in American lighthouses.

title: Kudlik
text: The qulliq (seal-oil, blubber or soapstone lamp, Inuktitut: ᖁᓪᓕᖅ , ‘"kudlik"’ ] ; Inupiaq: "naniq" ), is the traditional oil lamp used by Arctic peoples, including the Inuit, the Chukchi and the Yupik peoples.

title: Hefner lamp
text: The Hefner lamp, or in German Hefnerkerze, is a flame lamp used in photometry that burns amyl acetate.

title: Argand lamp
text: The Argand lamp, a kind of oil lamp, was invented and patented in 1780 by Aimé Argand.

title: Argand lamp
text: Its output is 6 to 10 candela, brighter than that of earlier lamps.

title: Argand lamp
text: Its more complete combustion of the candle wick and oil than in other lamps required much less frequent trimming of the wick.

title: Glow switch starter
text: A glow switch starter is a type of preheat starter used with fluorescent lamp.

title: Glow switch starter
text: It is commonly filled with neon gas or argon gas and contains a bimetallic strip and a stationary electrode.

title: Glow switch starter
text: The operating principle is simple, when current is applied, the gas inside ionizes and heats a bimetallic strip which in turn bends toward the stationary electrode thus shorting the starter between the electrodes of the fluorescent lamp After a second the starter's bimetallic strip will cool and open the circuit between the electrodes and the process repeats until the lamp has lit.

title: Glow switch starter
text: One disadvantage of glow switch starters is that when the lamp is at the end of its life it will continuously blink on and off until the glow switch starter wears out or an electrode on the fluorescent lamp burns out.

title: Carbon button lamp
text: The carbon button lamp is a single-electrode incandescent lamp invented by Nikola Tesla.

title: Carbon button lamp
text: A carbon button lamp contains a small carbon sphere positioned in the center of an evacuated glass bulb.

title: Carbon button lamp
text: This type of lamp must be driven by high-frequency alternating current, and depends on an electric arc or perhaps a vacuum arc to produce high current around the carbon electrode.

title: Carbon button lamp
text: The carbon electrode is then heated to incandescence by collisions by ions which constitute the electric current.

title: Carbon button lamp
text: Tesla found that these lamps could be used as powerful sources of ionizing radiation.

title: Kerosene lamp
text: A kerosene lamp (usually called a paraffin lamp in some countries) is a type of lighting device that uses kerosene (paraffin) as a fuel.

title: Kerosene lamp
text: Kerosene lamps have a wick or mantle as light source, protected by a glass chimney or globe; lamps may be used on a table, or hand-held lanterns may be used for portable lighting.

title: Kerosene lamp
text: Like oil lamps, they are useful for lighting without electricity, such as in regions without rural electrification, in electrified areas during power outages, at campsites, and on boats.

title: Kerosene lamp
text: There are three types of kerosene lamp: flat wick, central draught (tubular round wick), and mantle lamp.

title: Kerosene lamp
text: Kerosene lanterns meant for portable use have a flat wick and are made in dead flame, hot blast, and cold blast variants.

title: Hollow-cathode lamp
text: A hollow-cathode lamp (HCL) is type of cold cathode lamp used in physics and chemistry as a spectral line source (e.g. for atomic absorption spectrometers) and as a frequency tuner for light sources such as lasers.

title: Hollow-cathode lamp
text: An HCL takes advantage of the hollow cathode effect, which causes conduction at a lower voltage and with more current than a cold cathode lamp that does not have a hollow cathode.

title: Sunset Las Palmas Studios
text: Sunset Las Palmas Studios, located at 1040 N. Las Palmas Avenue in Hollywood, California, is an independent production lot providing stages and related services to television, movie and commercial production companies.

title: Sunset Las Palmas Studios
text: Founded in 1919, the lot is one of the oldest production facilities in Hollywood and has played host to many notable productions, including such television shows as "The Burns and Allen Show", "I Love Lucy", "The Addams Family", "Jeopardy!", "The Rockford Files", "MADtv", and "The Suite Life on Deck", as well as such movie productions as "When Harry Met Sally..." and "The Player".

title: Sunset Las Palmas Studios
text: It was previously known as Hollywood Center Studios.

title: Meg Ryan
text: Meg Ryan (born Margaret Mary Emily Anne Hyra; November 19, 1961) is an American actress, director, and producer.

title: Meg Ryan
text: Ryan began her acting career in 1981 in minor roles, before joining the cast of the CBS soap opera "As the World Turns" in 1982.

title: Meg Ryan
text: Subsequently, she began to appear in supporting roles in films during the mid-1980s, achieving recognition in independent movies such as "Promised Land" (1988) before her performance in the Rob Reiner-directed romantic comedy "When Harry Met Sally..." (1989) brought her widespread attention and her first Golden Globe nomination.

title: When Harry Met Sally...
text: When Harry Met Sally... is a 1989 American romantic comedy film written by Nora Ephron and directed by Rob Reiner.

title: When Harry Met Sally...
text: It stars Billy Crystal as Harry and Meg Ryan as Sally.

title: When Harry Met Sally...
text: The story follows the title characters from the time they meet just before sharing a cross-country drive, through twelve years or so of chance encounters in New York City.

title: When Harry Met Sally...
text: The film raises the question "Can men and women ever just be friends?"

title: When Harry Met Sally...
text: and advances many ideas about relationships that became household concepts, such as "high-maintenance" and the "transitional person".

title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd
text: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd is a 2003 American comedy film.

title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd
text: It is the second film in the "Dumb and Dumber" film series and a prequel to the 1994 film "Dumb and Dumber".

title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd
text: The film was directed by Troy Miller and based on the characters created by the Farrelly brothers from the original film.

title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd
text: The film was poorly received by critics; however, it was a modest domestic box office success considering its budget, taking in just under $40 million.

title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd
text: The subtitle is inspired by the film "When Harry Met Sally...".

title: When Harry Met Sally... (soundtrack)
text: When Harry Met Sally... is the soundtrack to the movie "When Harry Met Sally..." starring Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan.

title: When Harry Met Sally... (soundtrack)
text: The songs are performed by pianist Harry Connick Jr., who won the Grammy Award for Best Jazz Male Vocal Performance.

title: Gretchen Palmer
text: Gretchen Palmer (born December 16, 1961) is an American television and film actress.

title: Gretchen Palmer
text: She has had recurring roles in television series such as "The Joe Schmo Show" and "The Parkers", and has appeared in films including "Fast Forward", "Crossroads", "The Malibu Bikini Shop", "Red Heat", "When Harry Met Sally...", "Chopper Chicks in Zombietown", "Moonbase", "Trois" (2000) and "I Got the Hook Up" (1998).

title: Gretchen Palmer
text: She also appeared on The Young and the Restless as Serena.

title: Nora Ephron
text: Nora Ephron ( ; May 19, 1941 – June 26, 2012) was an American writer and filmmaker.

title: Nora Ephron
text: She is best known for her romantic comedy films and was nominated three times for the Academy Award for Best Writing: for "Silkwood" (1983), "When Harry Met Sally..." (1989), and "Sleepless in Seattle" (1993).

title: Nora Ephron
text: She won a BAFTA Award for Best Original Screenplay for "When Harry Met Sally...".

title: Nora Ephron
text: She sometimes wrote with her sister Delia Ephron.

title: Nora Ephron
text: Her last film was "Julie & Julia."

title: Nora Ephron
text: She also co-authored the Drama Desk Award–winning theatrical production "Love, Loss, and What I Wore".

title: Nora Ephron
text: In 2013, Ephron received a posthumous Tony Award nomination for Best Play for "Lucky Guy".

title: Bruno Kirby
text: Bruno Kirby (born Giovanni Quidaciolu, Jr.; April 28, 1949 – August 14, 2006) was an American actor, singer, voice artist, chef, and comedian.

title: Bruno Kirby
text: He was known for his roles in "City Slickers", "When Harry Met Sally...", "Good Morning, Vietnam", "The Godfather Part II", and "Donnie Brasco".

title: Bruno Kirby
text: He voiced Reginald Stout in "Stuart Little".

title: Connie Sawyer
text: Connie Sawyer (born November 27, 1912) is an American actress.

title: Connie Sawyer
text: She is best known for her work in "Dumb and Dumber", "Pineapple Express" and "When Harry Met Sally...".

title: Golden Gate University School of Law
text: Golden Gate University School of Law (informally referred to as GGU School of Law, GGU Law and Golden Gate Law) is one of the professional graduate schools of Golden Gate University.

title: Golden Gate University School of Law
text: Located in downtown San Francisco, California, GGU is a California non-profit corporation and is fully accredited by the American Bar Association (ABA).

title: Golden Gate University School of Law
text: In 2011, the "National Jurist" ranked the law school's public interest program among the top 20 in the United States.

title: Golden Gate University School of Law
text: In 2013, the same publication ranked Golden Gate University School of Law among the 20 US law schools with the highest average law school debt among its 2011 graduates.

title: Golden Gate University School of Law
text: Golden Gate Law was named by National Jurist magazine among the top 20 U.S. law schools for practical, hands-on training in 2014.

title: Otaara
text: Otaara, abbreviated Otr.

title: Otaara
text: in the horticultural trade, is an intergeneric hybrid of orchids, with "Brassavola", "Broughtonia", "Cattleya", "Laelia" and "Sophronitis" as parent genera.

title: William Henry Nicholls
text: William Henry Nicholls (23 July 1885 – 10 March 1951) was an Australian amateur botanist, authority on, and collector of Australian orchids.

title: William Henry Nicholls
text: An accomplished photographer and watercolourist, he contributed almost 100 articles on orchids to "The Victorian Naturalist", many of which described new species with line drawings.

title: William Henry Nicholls
text: He was working on producing a 24-volume illustrated monograph of all the orchids of Australia when he died.

title: William Henry Nicholls
text: Only four volumes were published shortly after his death but the entire work was published in a single book, "Orchids of Australia" in 1969.

title: William Henry Nicholls
text: Some of the many orchids described and named by Nicholls and retaining the name he gave them include "Caladenia caudata", "Caladenia echidnachila", "Caladenia ensata", "Caladenia ferruginea", "Caladenia magniclavata", "Caladenia ornata", "Caladenia praecox", "Caladenia radiata", "Pterostylis fischii", "Pterostylis hamiltonii", "Pterostylis hildii" and "Pterostylis tenuissima".

title: Paracaleana
text: Paracaleana commonly known as duck orchids, is a genus of flowering plants in the orchid family, Orchidaceae that is found in Australia and New Zealand.

title: Paracaleana
text: The Australian species are found in all states but have not been recorded in the Northern Territory.

title: Paracaleana
text: Orchids in this genus are similar to "Caleana major", but there are differences in the flowers and in the insects that pollinate them.

title: Paracaleana
text: "Paraceleana" orchids, as well as hammer orchids ("Drakaea") are pollinated by male thynnid wasps.

title: Paracaleana
text: Duck orchids have a single leaf and one or a few, dull-coloured, inconspicuous flowers.

title: Caladenia
text: Caladenia, commonly known as spider orchids, is a genus of 350 species of plants in the orchid family, Orchidaceae.

title: Caladenia
text: Spider orchids are terrestrial herbs with a single hairy leaf and a hairy stem.

title: Caladenia
text: The labellum is fringed or toothed in most species and there are small projections called calli on the labellum.

title: Caladenia
text: The flowers have adaptations to attract particular species of insects for pollination.

title: Caladenia
text: The genus is divided into three groups on the basis of flower shape, broadly, spider orchids, zebra orchids and cowslip orchids, although other common names are often used.

title: Caladenia
text: Although they occur in other countries, most are Australian and 136 species occur in Western Australia, making it the most species-rich orchid genus in that state.

title: Broughtonia sanguinea
text: Broughtonia sanguinea, also known as Blood Red Broughtonia is a plant in the genus "Broughtonia", a member of the Orchidaceae family.

title: Broughtonia sanguinea
text: The genus is abbreviated Bro in trade journals.

title: Broughtonia
text: Broughtonia is a genus of orchids (family Orchidaceae) native to the Bahamas and the Greater Antilles.

title: Broughtonia
text: The genus is abbreviated Bro in trade journals.

title: Calochilus
text: Calochilus, commonly known as beard orchids, is a genus of about 30 species of plants in the orchid family, Orchidaceae.

title: Calochilus
text: Beard orchids are terrestrial, herbs with a single leaf at the base of the plant, or no leaves.

title: Calochilus
text: Their most striking feature is a densely hairy labellum, giving rise to their common name.

title: Calochilus
text: Beard orchids, unlike some other Australian orchids, do not reproduce using daughter tubers, but self-pollinate when cross-pollination has not occurred.

title: Calochilus
text: Most species occur in Australia but some are found in New Zealand, New Guinea and New Caledonia.

title: Cypripedioideae
text: Lady's slipper orchids (also known as lady slipper orchids or slipper orchids) are orchids in the subfamily Cypripedioideae, which comprises the genera "Cypripedium, Mexipedium, Paphiopedilum, Phragmipedium" and "Selenipedium".

title: Cypripedioideae
text: They are characterised by the slipper-shaped pouches (modified labellums) of the flowers – the pouch traps insects so they are forced to climb up past the staminode, behind which they collect or deposit pollinia, thus fertilizing the flower.

title: Hawkinsara
text: Hawkinsara, abbreviated Hknsa.

title: Hawkinsara
text: in the horticultural trade, is an intergeneric hybrid of orchids, with parent genera "Broughtonia", "Cattleya", "Laelia" and "Sophronitis".

title: Cattleytonia
text: Cattleytonia (from "Cattleya" and "Broughtonia", its parental genera) is an intergeneric hybrid of orchids.

title: Cattleytonia
text: It is abbreviated Ctna in horticultural trade.

title: Tertiary Student Rugby League World Cup
text: The Tertiary Student Rugby League World Cup, also known as the University Rugby League World Cup, first took place in 1986 in New Zealand, when the then five test nations each entered a side in what was the first non-first grade World Cup hosted by the Rugby League International Federation.

title: 1991 Rugby World Cup
text: The 1991 Rugby World Cup was the second edition of the Rugby World Cup, and was jointly hosted by England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland and France; at that time, the five European countries that participated in the Five Nations Championship making it the first Rugby World Cup to be staged in the northern hemisphere, with England as the host of the championship game.

title: 1991 Rugby World Cup
text: Following on from the success of the inaugural 1987 Rugby World Cup, the 1991 World Cup received increased attention and was seen as a major global sporting event for the first time.

title: 1991 Rugby World Cup
text: Also for the first time qualifying competitions were introduced as the number of entrants had increased from 16 nations four years before to a total of 33 countries, the eight quarter-finalists from 1987 qualified automatically with the remaining 25 countries having to qualify for the remaining eight spots.

title: 1991 Rugby World Cup
text: This however resulted in only one new side qualifying for the tournament, Western Samoa replacing Tonga.

title: 1991 Rugby World Cup
text: The same 16-team pool/knock-out format was used with just minor changes to the points system.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: The 2002 FIFA World Cup was the 17th staging of the FIFA World Cup which took place from 31 May to 30 June 2002 in South Korea and Japan.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: It was the first World Cup to be held in Asia, the first to be held on a continent other than Europe or the Americas, the last World Cup during which the golden goal rule was in force and the only World Cup to be jointly hosted by more than one nation.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: Brazil won the tournament for a record fifth time, winning the final against Germany 2–0.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: The victory meant Brazil qualified for the 2005 FIFA Confederations Cup for the fifth time, representing the World.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: In the third place play-off match against South Korea, Turkey won 3–2 taking third place in only their second ever FIFA World Cup finals.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: China PR, Ecuador, Senegal and Slovenia made their first appearances at the finals with Turkey making its first appearance since 1954.

title: 2002 FIFA World Cup
text: Republic of Ireland, Russia and Sweden returned after missing the 1998 tournament.

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: The 1968–1969 season was the 66th season of competitive football in Belgium.

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: Standard Club Liégeois won their 4th Division I title.

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: No Belgian club managed to pass the second round of the European competitions, though for the first time 6 Belgian clubs qualified (1 more club qualified for the Inter-Cities Fairs Cup).

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: K Lierse SK won the Belgian Cup final against RR White (2-0).

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: The Belgium national football team continued their 1970 FIFA World Cup qualification campaign with 3 home wins against all other Group 6 teams (Finland, Yugoslavia and Spain) and a draw in Spain.

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: Belgium qualified for the 1970 FIFA World Cup finals in Mexico with one match to go.

title: 1968–69 in Belgian football
text: For the first time since the 1954 FIFA World Cup, Belgium would qualify for a major tournament.

title: Orvar Bergmark
text: Orvar Bergmark (16 November 1930 – 10 May 2004) was a Swedish football defender and manager.

title: Orvar Bergmark
text: He was the second Swedish national manager ever, and managed to qualify the Swedish national football team for the FIFA World Cup in Mexico 1970, after having beaten France (among others) in the qualifications.

title: Orvar Bergmark
text: The 1970 World Cup was the first one in 12 years, and it was also the first time in 20 years that Sweden had "qualified" for a World Cup.

title: Orvar Bergmark
text: (Sweden hosted the 1958 FIFA World Cup, and hence did not need to qualify.)

title: Orvar Bergmark
text: Sweden did not qualify for the World Cups in 1954, 1962 and 1966).

title: Ukraine national football team
text: The Ukraine's National Football Team (Ukrainian: Збірна України з футболу ) is the national football team of Ukraine and is controlled by the Football Federation of Ukraine.

title: Ukraine national football team
text: After Ukrainian Independence and the country's breakaway from the Soviet Union, they played their first match against Hungary on 29 April 1992.

title: Ukraine national football team
text: The team's biggest success on the world stage was reaching the quarter-finals in the 2006 FIFA World Cup, which also marked the team's debut in the finals of a major championship.

title: Ukraine national football team
text: As the host nation, Ukraine automatically qualified for UEFA Euro 2012.

title: Ukraine national football team
text: Four years later, Ukraine qualified for Euro 2016 via the play-off route, the first time qualifying for a UEFA European Championship via the qualifying process, as it finished in third place in its qualifying group.

title: Ukraine national football team
text: This marked the first time in Ukraine's five play-off appearances that it managed to win such a tie, previously unsuccessful in the play-off ties for the Euro 2000, 2002 World Cup, 2010 World Cup and 2014 World Cup.

title: Algeria at the FIFA World Cup
text: Algeria have appeared in the finals of the FIFA World Cup on four occasions in 1982, 1986, 2010 and 2014.

title: Algeria at the FIFA World Cup
text: They have once qualified for the knockout rounds, reaching the round of 16 in 2014 before losing to Germany.

title: Algeria at the FIFA World Cup
text: 32 years before, Algeria nearly qualified to the second round of the 1982 World Cup after beating both West Germany and Chile; however, an arrangement match between West Germany and Austria wound up eliminating the Algerians.

title: Algeria at the FIFA World Cup
text: In 2014, Algeria qualifyed for the first time into the round of 16.

title: Switzerland women's national football team
text: The Switzerland women's national football team represents Switzerland in international women's football.

title: Switzerland women's national football team
text: The team played its first match in 1972.

title: Switzerland women's national football team
text: Their most recent competition is qualification for the 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup, and they had qualified as the best team in their group.

title: Switzerland women's national football team
text: It would be the first time that Switzerland participated in a women's World Cup, and the first time both the men's team and women's team qualified for a World Cup simultaneously.

title: Switzerland women's national football team
text: Switzerland qualified for the European Championship for the first time in 2017.

title: Switzerland women's national football team
text: They have never qualified for the Olympic games.

title: 2014 Cricket World Cup Qualifier
text: The 2014 ICC World Cup Qualifier was a cricket tournament to decide the final qualification for the 2015 World Cup.

title: 2014 Cricket World Cup Qualifier
text: The top two teams qualified for the World Cup joining Ireland and for the first time Afghanistan who have already qualified through the 2011–13 ICC World Cricket League Championship and maintained their ODI status.

title: 2014 Cricket World Cup Qualifier
text: The World Cup Qualifier was the final event of the 2009–14 World Cricket League.

title: 2014 Cricket World Cup Qualifier
text: It was staged in New Zealand, from 13 January to 1 February 2014 after Scotland relinquished the right to host it.

title: 2015 Cricket World Cup opening ceremony
text: The opening ceremonies of the 2015 Cricket World Cup took place in New Zealand and Australia on the eve of the beginning of the World Cup hosted by them after 23 years.

title: 2015 Cricket World Cup opening ceremony
text: Two ceremonies took place at the same time, one in North Hagley Park, Christchurch in New Zealand while the other in Melbourne, Australia.

title: 2015 Cricket World Cup opening ceremony
text: Thousands of fans turned up to watch the opening ceremony in both locations.

title: 2015 Cricket World Cup opening ceremony
text: It was the first major sporting event hosted by Christchurch after the deadly 2011 Christchurch earthquake.

title: Northern Virginia Campaign
text: The Northern Virginia Campaign, also known as the Second Bull Run Campaign or Second Manassas Campaign, was a series of battles fought in Virginia during August and September 1862 in the Eastern Theater of the American Civil War.

title: Northern Virginia Campaign
text: Confederate General Robert E. Lee followed up his successes of the Seven Days Battles in the Peninsula Campaign by moving north toward Washington, D.C., and defeating Maj. Gen. John Pope and his Army of Virginia.

title: Battle of Cross Keys
text: The Battle of Cross Keys was fought on June 8, 1862, in Rockingham County, Virginia, as part of Confederate Army Maj. Gen. Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson's campaign through the Shenandoah Valley during the American Civil War.

title: Battle of Cross Keys
text: Together, the battles of Cross Keys and Port Republic the following day were the decisive victories in Jackson's Valley Campaign, forcing the Union armies to retreat and leaving Jackson free to reinforce Gen. Robert E. Lee for the Seven Days Battles outside Richmond, Virginia.

title: Battle of Malvern Hill
text: The Battle of Malvern Hill, also known as the Battle of Poindexter's Farm, was fought on July 1, 1862 between the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia, led by Gen. Robert E. Lee, and the Union Army of the Potomac under Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan.

title: Battle of Malvern Hill
text: It was the final battle of the Seven Days Battles during the American Civil War, taking place on a 130 ft elevation of land known as Malvern Hill, near the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia and just one mile (1.6 km) from the James River.

title: Battle of Malvern Hill
text: Including inactive reserves, more than fifty thousand soldiers from each side took part, using more than two hundred pieces of artillery and three warships.

title: Battle of Port Republic
text: The Battle of Port Republic was fought on June 9, 1862, in Rockingham County, Virginia, as part of Confederate Army Maj. Gen. Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson's campaign through the Shenandoah Valley during the American Civil War.

title: Battle of Port Republic
text: Port Republic was a fierce contest between two equally determined foes and was the most costly battle fought by Jackson's Army of the Valley during its campaign.

title: Battle of Port Republic
text: Together, the battles of Cross Keys (fought the previous day) and Port Republic were the decisive victories in Jackson's Valley Campaign, forcing the Union armies to retreat and leaving Jackson free to reinforce Gen. Robert E. Lee for the Seven Days Battles outside Richmond, Virginia.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: Savage's Station was the wartime name of a supply depot, ammunition dump, field hospital, and command headquarters of the Army of the Potomac during the Peninsula Campaign of the American Civil War.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: Savage's Station was located in Henrico County, Virginia on what was the Richmond and York River Railroad, however the historical department of the Norfolk Southern Railroad, the railroad track's current owner, has no record that an actual train station or station house ever existed on the property.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: A farmhouse is known to have been located in a copse of trees on a small knoll next to the railroad track and is visible in several period drawings and photographs made during the war.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The house served as the nucleus of a large field hospital during and after the battle of Seven Pines and the Seven Days Battles.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The house also functioned as General George B. McClellan's headquarters during the battle of Savage's Station on June 29, 1862.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: Although the house survived the battle in 1862, it was burned by Federal cavalry under General Philip H. Sheridan in 1864.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The house appears to have never been rebuilt, and no trace of it remains today.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: However, a smokehouse from the 19th century still existed on the property as late as the 1930s when it was photographed during a survey of local historical structures as a project of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: The smokehouse fell into ruin and collapsed sometime prior to the 1980s.

title: Savage's Station, Virginia
text: A small brick-walled cemetery from the 18th century still sits near the former location of the house not far from the railroad track.

title: William Dorsey Pender
text: William Dorsey Pender (February 6, 1834 – July 18, 1863) was a General in the Confederacy in the American Civil War serving as a Brigade and Divisional commander.

title: William Dorsey Pender
text: Promoted to brigadier on the battlefield at Seven Pines by Confederate President Jefferson Davis in person, he fought in the Seven Days Battles and at Second Manassas, Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville, being wounded in each of these engagements.

title: William Dorsey Pender
text: Lee rated him as one of the most promising of his commanders, promoting him to major general at twenty-nine.

title: William Dorsey Pender
text: Pender was mortally wounded on the second day of Gettysburg.

title: Seven Days Union order of battle
text: The following Union Army units and commanders fought in the Seven Days Battles (from June 25 to July 1, 1862) of the American Civil War.

title: Seven Days Union order of battle
text: Order of battle compiled from the army organization-return of casualties during the battle and the reports.

title: Seven Days Union order of battle
text: The Confederate order of battle is listed separately.

title: Seven Days Battles
text: The Seven Days Battles were a series of six major battles over the seven days from June 25 to July 1, 1862, near Richmond, Virginia, during the American Civil War.

title: Seven Days Battles
text: Confederate General Robert E. Lee drove the invading Union Army of the Potomac, commanded by Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan, away from Richmond and into a retreat down the Virginia Peninsula.

title: Seven Days Battles
text: The series of battles is sometimes known erroneously as the Seven Days Campaign, but it was actually the culmination of the Peninsula Campaign, not a separate campaign in its own right.

title: Seven Days Confederate order of battle
text: The following Confederate States Army units and commanders fought in the Seven Days Battles (from June 25 to July 1, 1862) of the American Civil War.

title: Seven Days Confederate order of battle
text: Order of battle compiled from the army organization during the battle, the casualty returns and the reports.

title: Seven Days Confederate order of battle
text: The Union order of battle is listed separately.

title: Battle of Gaines's Mill
text: The Battle of Gaines's Mill, sometimes known as the First Battle of Cold Harbor or the Battle of Chickahominy River, took place on June 27, 1862, in Hanover County, Virginia, as the third of the Seven Days Battles (Peninsula Campaign) of the American Civil War.

title: Battle of Gaines's Mill
text: Following the inconclusive Battle of Beaver Dam Creek (Mechanicsville) the previous day, Confederate General Robert E. Lee renewed his attacks against the right flank of the Union Army, relatively isolated on the northern side of the Chickahominy River.

title: Battle of Gaines's Mill
text: There, Brig. Gen. Fitz John Porter's V Corps had established a strong defensive line behind Boatswain's Swamp.

title: Battle of Gaines's Mill
text: Lee's force was destined to launch the largest Confederate attack of the war, about 57,000 men in six divisions.

title: Battle of Gaines's Mill
text: Porter's reinforced V Corps held fast for the afternoon as the Confederates attacked in a disjointed manner, first with the division of Maj. Gen. A.P. Hill, then Maj. Gen. Richard S. Ewell, suffering heavy casualties.

title: Battle of Gaines's Mill
text: The arrival of Maj. Gen. Stonewall Jackson's command was delayed, preventing the full concentration of Confederate force before Porter received some reinforcements from the VI Corps.

title: The Lighthouse (Poole)
text: The Lighthouse is an arts centre in Poole, Dorset, England.

title: The Lighthouse (Poole)
text: According to the Arts council of England it is the largest arts centre in the United Kingdom outside London.

title: Canford Cliffs
text: Canford Cliffs is an affluent suburb of Poole in Dorset, England.

title: Canford Cliffs
text: The neighbourhood lies on the English Channel coast midway between Poole and Bournemouth.

title: Canford Cliffs
text: To the southwest is Sandbanks which has some of the highest property values in the world, and together Canford Cliffs and Sandbanks form a parish, which has the fourth highest property prices in the world and second highest in the United Kingdom after London.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: Viscount Trenchard, of Wolfeton in the County of Dorset, is a title in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: It was created in 1936 for Marshal of the Royal Air Force, Hugh Trenchard, 1st Baron Trenchard.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: He had already been created a Baronet, of Wolfeton in the County of Dorset, in the Baronetage of the United Kingdom in 1919 and Baron Trenchard, of Wolfeton in the County of Dorset, in 1930, also in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: His second son, the second Viscount, held junior ministerial positions from 1979 to 1983 in the Conservative administration of Margaret Thatcher.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: s of 2016 the titles are held by the latter's son, the third Viscount, who succeeded in 1987.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: In 2004 he replaced the recently deceased Lord Vivian as one of the ninety elected(by hereditary peers)hereditary peers that are allowed to remain in the House of Lords after the passing of the House of Lords Act 1999.

title: Viscount Trenchard
text: Lord Trenchard sits on the Conservative benches.

title: Fire Radio
text: Fire Radio is a United Kingdom radio station broadcasting to Bournemouth, Poole, and Christchurch, Dorset, based in Southampton, Hampshire.

title: Dorset County Council election, 2013
text: An election to Dorset County Council took place on 2 May 2013 as part of the United Kingdom local elections.

title: Dorset County Council election, 2013
text: 45 councillors were elected from 42 electoral divisions, which returned either one or two county councillors each by first-past-the-post voting for a four-year term of office.

title: Dorset County Council election, 2013
text: The electoral divisions were the same as those used at the previous election in 2009.

title: Dorset County Council election, 2013
text: No elections were held in Bournemouth or Poole, which are unitary authorities outside the area covered by the County Council.

title: Dorset County Council election, 2013
text: The election saw the Conservative Party maintain overall control of the council.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: Viscount Wimborne, of Canford Magna in the County of Dorset, is a title in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: It was created in 1918 for Ivor Guest, 2nd Baron Wimborne.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: The Guest family descends from the engineer and businessman John Josiah Guest.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: On 14 August 1838 he was created a baronet, of Dowlais in the County of Glamorgan, in the Baronetage of the United Kingdom.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: He was succeeded by his eldest son, the second Baronet.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: In 1880 he was created Baron Wimborne, of Canford Magna in the County of Dorset, in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: On his death the titles passed to his eldest son, the second Baron.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: In 1910, four years before he succeeded his father, he had been raised to the Peerage of the United Kingdom in his own right as Baron Ashby St Ledgers, of Ashby St Ledgers in the County of Northampton.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: On his retirement as Lord-Lieutenant of Ireland in 1918 he was further honoured when he was made Viscount Wimborne, of Canford Magna in the County of Dorset, in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: His son, the second Viscount, represented Breconshire in the House of Commons.

title: Viscount Wimborne
text: s of 2014 the titles are held by the latter's grandson, the fourth Viscount, who succeeded his father in 1993.

title: Lush (company)
text: Lush Ltd. is a cosmetics retailer headquartered in Poole, Dorset, United Kingdom.

title: Lush (company)
text: The company was founded by Mark Constantine, a trichologist and Liz Weir, a beauty therapist.

title: Lush (company)
text: They met in a hair and beauty salon in Poole, England.

title: Lush (company)
text: A few years later, they decided to branch out and start their own business selling natural hair and beauty products.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: Baron de Mauley, of Canford in the County of Dorset, is a title in the Peerage of the United Kingdom.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: It was created in 1838 for the Whig politician the Hon. William Ponsonby, who had earlier represented Poole, Knaresborough and Dorset in the House of Commons.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: He was the third son of the 3rd Earl of Bessborough, an Anglo-Irish peer, and the husband of Lady Barbara Ashley-Cooper, one of the co-heirs to the ancient barony by writ of Mauley (or Maulay), which superseded the feudal barony the "caput" of which was at Mulgrave Castle, Yorkshire, which barony by writ had become extinct in 1415.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: His son, later the second Baron, sat as Member of Parliament for Poole and Dungarvon.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: s of 2009 the title is held by the latter's great-great-grandson, the seventh Baron, who succeeded his uncle in 2002.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: He is one of the ninety elected hereditary peers that remain in the House of Lords after the passing of the House of Lords Act 1999, and sits as a Conservative.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: He was elected in 2005 and thereby became the first hereditary peer having succeeded to his title after the House of Lords Act of 1999, to have obtained an elective hereditary peers seat in the House of Lords.

title: Baron de Mauley
text: As a descendant of the third Earl of Bessborough, Lord de Mauley is also in remainder to the earldom of Bessborough and its subsidiary titles.

title: List of cider producers in Dorset
text: This is a list of cider brands from Dorset in the United Kingdom.

title: List of cider producers in Dorset
text: Although neighbouring county of Somerset is better known for its apple orchards, Dorset has an equally long orchard and cider tradition.

title: List of cider producers in Dorset
text: Many Dorset cider producers are using traditional Dorset varieties of apple The Dorset Cider museum is based in Owermoigne, near Dorchester

title: Poole Methodist Church
text: Poole Methodist Church (also known as Poole High Street Methodist Church or The Spire) is a nineteenth-century Methodist church on Poole High Street in Dorset, England.

title: Poole Methodist Church
text: An extension to the church was nominated for the 2016 Carbuncle Cup for "the ugliest building in the United Kingdom completed in the last 12 months".

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: Športno Nogometni Klub Radgona (English: Sports Football Club Radgona ), commonly referred to as ŠNK Radgona or simply Radgona, is a Slovenian football club, which plays in the town of Gornja Radgona.

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: The club was established in 1946 as NK Radgona.

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: They currently play in the East division of the Slovenian Third League, the third tier of the Slovenian football pyramid.

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: Since the 2007–08 season the club plays under the name ŠNK Radgona ("Slovene: "Športno Nogometni Klub Radgona" ").

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: Previously, the club was named NK Radgona and NK Arcont Radgona (due to sponsorship reasons).

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: Since the 2014–15 season the club plays its home matches at the Gornja Radgona Stadium, located in the Gornja Radgona Sports Park, with a seating capacity for 301 spectators.

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: In summer 2016, the club's staff established a reserve team and registered it to the 2.

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: MNL (fifth tier) for the 2016–17 season but it was dissolved in summer 2017.

title: ŠNK Radgona
text: Radgona is currently managed by Boris Lazić who took charge of the team on 8 December 2016.

title: Old Trafford, Greater Manchester
text: Old Trafford is an area of Stretford, in the Metropolitan Borough of Trafford, Greater Manchester, England, 2 mi southwest of Manchester city centre.

title: Old Trafford, Greater Manchester
text: The crossroads sites of two old toll gates roughly delineate the borders of the area: Brooks's Bar to the east and Trafford Bar to the west.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: The Trojans Rugby Football Club is an under-nineteen-year-old rugby club originally based out of Lassiter High School.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: It is one of the original high school rugby clubs which are part of the Georgia High School Rugby Association (GHSRA).

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: The club was founded in 2005, and has made its mark on rugby in Georgia.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: Matches and practices are held at Noonday Creek Park in Marietta.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: Coach Randall Joseph has been the head coach since the club's founding, with Anthony "Bubba" Gautney as assistant coach.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: The club has taken park in many tournaments and state final matches in Georgia and the Southeast United States.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: A major goal of the Trojans Rugby Football Club is to teach and play the sport of rugby in the United States.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: This is a great struggle throughout Georgia because of opposition from the high school's football coaches and athletic directors.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: The club plays the most common version of rugby, called rugby union but often just referred to as rugby.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
