text: Although the club plays by rugby union rules, they also play by the rules of the International Rugby Board (IRB) for those under 19 years of age.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: In the summer of 2011, the Trojan Rugby Football Club took part in another version of rugby called rugby sevens.

title: Trojans Rugby Football Club
text: This variation of rugby is faster paced, with the same size fields but fewer people, and shorter half lengths.

title: Trafford Bar tram stop
text: Trafford Bar is a tram stop on Greater Manchester's light rail system, Metrolink, at the junction of Talbot Road and Seymour Grove in Old Trafford.

title: Trafford Bar tram stop
text: It opened on 15 June 1992 as part of Phase 1 of Metrolink's expansion, before which it was a railway station.

title: Aquinas Old Collegians Football Club
text: Aquinas Old Collegians Football Club, nicknamed the Bloods, is an amateur Australian rules football club in Ringwood, Victoria, playing in the Victorian Amateur Football Association (VAFA).

title: Aquinas Old Collegians Football Club
text: Previously called Aquinas Old Boys Football Club when it was founded in 1981, the club plays at Aquinas College.

title: Aquinas Old Collegians Football Club
text: The club song is "We're a team of Champions", to the tune of "Join in the Chorus" .

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Maxine's Tap Room is a historic bar in Fayetteville, Arkansas, located on 107 N. Block Ave. It is one of the oldest bars in Northwest Arkansas.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Marjorie Maxine Miller opened the bar in 1950 when she was 24 years old with money she borrowed from her parents.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: She managed to pay her parents back within the year.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: In 1960 she tore down the old wooden building in which the bar had been located and had the current building—a long, narrow brick structure—built in its place.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: The new building had only one window, exactly 8.5 in by 40 in , in the front, which was the minimum size allowed by the building codes at the time.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: This was more than likely a business decision aimed at limiting break-ins.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Other examples of Miller's shrewd business style include keeping a club behind the bar, having only a pay phone available, and trying to hire football players as employees so the team would follow as patrons, a business style that led to the bar's longevity and success.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Adding to the Tap Room's charm were a 50 ft -long bar that stretched nearly the entire length of the building and dominated the room, an old coin-operated cigarette machine, a juke box that still played 45s, and a deer head adorned with Mardi Gras beads, sunglasses and a tie.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Miller was a constant figure behind the cash register for 50 years until her health started to decline around 2000.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: She died at age 82 in May 2006.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: A month later the Tap Room caught fire.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Due to lack of insurance the bar was closed for over a year, reopening in August 2007.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Most of the furniture inside the bar was replaced, including the bar.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: The exposed rafters darkened by the fire were simply painted black, and a skylight was installed where the roof had burned through.

title: Maxine's Tap Room
text: Considerable efforts were made to retain many things that had been in the bar for a very long time, such as the older lights and signs.

title: List of Manchester United F.C. players
text: Manchester United Football Club is an English professional football club based in Old Trafford, Greater Manchester.

title: List of Manchester United F.C. players
text: The club was formed in Newton Heath in 1878 as Newton Heath LYR F.C., and played their first competitive match in October 1886, when they entered the First Round of the 1886–87 FA Cup.

title: List of Manchester United F.C. players
text: The club was renamed Manchester United F.C. in 1902, and moved to Old Trafford in 1910.

title: List of Manchester United F.C. players
text: Since playing their first competitive match, exactly 900 players have made a competitive first-team appearance for the club, of whom 205 players have made at least 100 appearances (including substitute appearances).

title: Ragbi Klub Mornar Bar
text: Ragbi Klub Mornar Bar (Montenegrin:Рагби клуб Морнар Бар, English: Rugby Club Mornar Bar) is a Montenegrin rugby club based in Bar, Montenegro.

title: Ragbi Klub Mornar Bar
text: It was founded in 2013.

title: Ragbi Klub Mornar Bar
text: The club plays in the Montenegrin national division.

title: Ragbi Klub Mornar Bar
text: During its first match in Bar, Mornar played against Nikšić on April 19, 2014.

title: Gorse Hill
text: Gorse Hill is an area in Stretford, within the Trafford borough of Greater Manchester, England.

title: Gorse Hill
text: The population of the ward taken at the 2011 census was 11,894.

title: Gorse Hill
text: It is a residential area with two minor industrial estates on either side of the main A56 Chester Road, which divides the two halves of the ward.

title: Gorse Hill
text: Gorse Hill Park is a park which has recently had its historic main gates renovated and sits in between the two halves of the ward also, bridging Chester Road and Talbot Road.

title: Gorse Hill
text: Gorse Hill is also the northernmost ward of Trafford council and is home to Trafford Town Hall, housing the council offices.

title: Gorse Hill
text: Gorse Hill shares a border with Old Trafford ward, home to both Manchester United F.C. and Lancashire County Cricket Club.

title: Manchester United F.C.
text: Manchester United Football Club is a professional football club based in Old Trafford, Greater Manchester, England, that competes in the Premier League, the top flight of English football.

title: Manchester United F.C.
text: Nicknamed "the Red Devils", the club was founded as Newton Heath LYR Football Club in 1878, changed its name to Manchester United in 1902 and moved to its current stadium, Old Trafford, in 1910.

title: Mary Poppins (film)
text: Mary Poppins is a 1964 American musical-fantasy film directed by Robert Stevenson and produced by Walt Disney, with songs written and composed by the Sherman Brothers.

title: Mary Poppins (film)
text: The screenplay is by Bill Walsh and Don DaGradi, loosely based on P. L. Travers' book series "Mary Poppins".

title: Mary Poppins (film)
text: The film, which combines live-action and animation, stars Julie Andrews in the role of Mary Poppins who visits a dysfunctional family in London and employs her unique brand of lifestyle to improve the family's dynamic.

title: Mary Poppins (film)
text: Dick Van Dyke, David Tomlinson, and Glynis Johns are featured in supporting roles.

title: Mary Poppins (film)
text: The film was shot entirely at the Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, California using painted London background scenes.

title: Mary Poppins (song)
text: "Mary Poppins" is a song from the 2015 stage musical "Love Birds" with music and lyrics by Robert J. Sherman.

title: Mary Poppins (song)
text: It is sung by "The Original Quack Pack", a penguin barbershop quartet who resemble the penguins from the 1964 Walt Disney motion picture, "Mary Poppins".

title: Mary Poppins (song)
text: In dialogue leading up to the song, the penguins explain that while they did know the same nanny, (Mary Poppins) they are not the same penguins as in the movie.

title: Mary Poppins (song)
text: The song expresses their longing for the magical nanny of literary fame.

title: My Kind of Town
text: "My Kind of Town" or "My Kind of Town (Chicago Is)" is a popular song composed by Jimmy Van Heusen, with lyrics by Sammy Cahn.

title: My Kind of Town
text: It was originally part of the musical score for "Robin and the 7 Hoods", a 1964 musical film starring several members of the Rat Pack.

title: My Kind of Town
text: It was nominated for the 1964 Academy Award for Best Original Song but lost to "Chim Chim Cher-ee" from "Mary Poppins".

title: My Kind of Town
text: Although the song predated the Grammy Award Best Original Song for a Motion Picture category, the entire score was nominated for the 1964 Grammy Award in the category Best Original Score Written for A Motion Picture, but it lost to the eponymously titled "Mary Poppins" score.

title: Chim Chim Cher-ee
text: "Chim Chim Cher-ee" is a song from "Mary Poppins", the 1964 musical motion picture.

title: Chim Chim Cher-ee
text: It was originally sung by Dick Van Dyke and Julie Andrews, and also is featured in the Cameron Mackintosh/Disney "Mary Poppins" musical.

title: Chim Chim Cher-ee
text: The song can be heard in the "Mary Poppins" scene of The Great Movie Ride at Disney's Hollywood Studios and during the "Mary Poppins" segment of "" at Disneyland.

title: Mary Poppins Returns
text: Mary Poppins Returns (also known as Mary Poppins 2) is an upcoming American musical fantasy film directed by Rob Marshall and written by David Magee.

title: Mary Poppins Returns
text: It is the sequel to the 1964 film "Mary Poppins".

title: Mary Poppins Returns
text: The film stars Emily Blunt, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Ben Whishaw, Emily Mortimer, Pixie Davies, Joel Dawson, Nathanael Saleh, Julie Walters, Colin Firth, Dick Van Dyke and Meryl Streep.

title: Mary Poppins Returns
text: Set 25 years after the 1964 film, it will feature Mary Poppins, the former nanny of Jane and Michael Banks, re-visiting them after a family tragedy.

title: Mary Poppins Returns
text: The film is scheduled for release on December 25, 2018, giving it one of the longest gaps between film sequels in history.

title: Mary Poppins Opens the Door
text: Mary Poppins Opens the Door is a British children's fantasy novel by the Australian-British writer P.L. Travers, the third book and last novel in the "Mary Poppins" series that features the magical English nanny Mary Poppins.

title: Mary Poppins Opens the Door
text: It was published in 1943 by Harcourt, Brace & World, Inc and illustrated by Mary Shepard and Agnes Sims.

title: I Love to Laugh
text: "I Love to Laugh", also called "We Love to Laugh", is a song from Walt Disney's film "Mary Poppins".

title: I Love to Laugh
text: It was composed by Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman.

title: I Love to Laugh
text: The song is sung in the film by "Uncle Albert" (Ed Wynn), and "Bert" (Dick Van Dyke) as they levitate uncontrollably toward the ceiling, eventually joined by Mary Poppins (Julie Andrews) herself.

title: I Love to Laugh
text: The premise of the scene, that laughter and happiness cause Uncle Albert (and like-minded visitors) to float into the air, can be seen as a metaphor for the way laughter can "lighten" a mood.

title: I Love to Laugh
text: (Compare Peter Pan's flight power, which is also powered by happy thoughts.)

title: I Love to Laugh
text: Conversely, thinking of something sad literally brings Albert and his visitors "down to earth" again.

title: I Love to Laugh
text: The song states a case strongly in favor of laughter, even if Mary Poppins appears to disapprove of Uncle Albert's behavior, especially since it not only complicates the task of getting Albert down, but the infectious mood sends Bert and the Banks children into the air as well.

title: A Man Has Dreams
text: "A Man Has Dreams" is a song from Walt Disney's film "Mary Poppins", written by Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman.

title: A Man Has Dreams
text: The song melody is a slowed down version of "The Life I Lead" which serves as Banks's leitmotif as he was fired.

title: A Man Has Dreams
text: In both the motion picture and the stage musical, the song is performed as a conversational duet between Bert, the chimney sweep (Dick Van Dyke) and George Banks (David Tomlinson).

title: A Man Has Dreams
text: It is operatic in nature, sung dialogue, and was highly unusual for a musical film of that era.

title: A Man Has Dreams
text: The song incorporates a reprise of "A Spoonful of Sugar" which is Mary Poppins's leitmotif.

title: Step in Time
text: "Step In Time" is a song and dance number from Walt Disney's 1964 film "Mary Poppins", and it is composed by Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman.

title: Step in Time
text: The choreography for this song was provided by Marc Breaux and Dee Dee Wood.

title: Step in Time
text: It is sung by Bert, the chimney sweep (Dick Van Dyke) and the other chimney sweeps on the rooftops of London.

title: Step in Time
text: In the first part of the song, the lines he says in the verses are "Kick your knees up", "'Round the chimney", "Flap like a birdie", "Up on the railing", "Over the rooftops" and "Link your elbows" followed by an interlude.

title: Step in Time
text: The interlude continues with Bert, Mary Poppins, Michael, Jane and all the chimney sweepers dancing around the rooftops and as Admiral Boom looks at them with the telescope, he thinks that they're Hottentots, so he orders Mr. Binnacle to make them scram with colorful fireworks.

title: Step in Time
text: In the second part, as all the chimney sweepers get in the house of George Banks, Mrs. Brill walks into the living room looking at them and screams, "They're at it again!"

title: Step in Time
text: and she runs away trying to strike one of the chimney sweepers with a frying pan.

title: Step in Time
text: As Jane, Michael, Mary Poppins and Bert get in the same place, Ellen runs around the dining room with an "OW!"

title: Step in Time
text: and the chimney sweepers flip her.

title: Step in Time
text: The other phrases in the rest of the musical number are "Votes for women," "It's the master," and "What's all this?"

title: Mary Poppins, Goodbye
text: Mary Poppins, Goodbye (Russian: Мэри Поппинс, до свидания!

title: Mary Poppins, Goodbye
text: ; translit.

title: Mary Poppins, Goodbye
text: "Meri Poppins, do svidaniya") is a Soviet 1983 two-part musical miniseries (part 1 "Lady Perfection", part 2 "Week ends on Wednesday"), directed by Leonid Kvinikhidze.

title: Mary Poppins, Goodbye
text: It is loosely based on Mary Poppins stories by P. L. Travers.

title: Mary Poppins, Goodbye
text: The TV series were ordered by the Gosteleradio of USSR and produced by Mosfilm.

title: Mary Poppins, Goodbye
text: The official television premiere was on January 8, 1984.

title: Kathy Sullivan (Australian politician)
text: Kathryn Jean Martin "Kathy" Sullivan AM (born 8 March 1942), Australian politician, was a Liberal member of the Australian Senate from 1974 to 1984, representing Queensland, and a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Moncrieff, Queensland, from 1984 to 2001.

title: Kathy Sullivan (Australian politician)
text: She previously held the record for the longest service in the Australian Parliament for a woman, oustripping the record previously held by Dorothy Tangney.

title: Kathy Sullivan (Australian politician)
text: This record has since been surpassed by Bronwyn Bishop.

title: Kathy Sullivan (Australian politician)
text: She was the first woman member of the parliament to have served in both houses.

title: Richard Torbay
text: George Richard Torbay (born 26 March 1961), an Australian politician, was an independent member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly representing Northern Tablelands from 1999 to 2013.

title: Richard Torbay
text: Torbay was the 30th Speaker of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, serving from 2007 until 2011, and was the first independent member to be Speaker of the House since 1913.

title: Richard Torbay
text: Prior to his election to State parliament, he served as Mayor of Armidale City Council from 1995 to 1998.

title: Peter Blacker
text: Peter Douglas Blacker (born 20 October 1941) is a former Australian politician who represented the seat of Flinders in the South Australian House of Assembly for the Nationals SA from 1973 to 1993.

title: Peter Blacker
text: During that time he was the only Nationals member in the South Australian parliament.

title: Peter Blacker
text: He is now the Chair of the Minister’s Regional Communities Consultative Council.

title: Mehmet Tillem
text: Mehmet Tillem (born 10 September 1974) is a former Australian politician.

title: Mehmet Tillem
text: He was an Australian Labor Party member of the Australian Senate from 21 August 2013 to 30 June 2014.

title: Mehmet Tillem
text: He filled a casual vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator David Feeney, but was defeated at the 2013 federal election, and left parliament at the conclusion of his term.

title: Mehmet Tillem
text: He is the first Turkish-born member of the Australian parliament.

title: Bob Debus
text: Robert John Debus {'1': ", '2': ", '3': ", '4': "} (born 16 September 1943), a former Australian politician, has been a member of the Australian House of Representatives and the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, representing the Australian Labor Party.

title: Bob Debus
text: Debus has been a minister in both the Australian and New South Wales governments.

title: Bob Debus
text: He served in the NSW Parliament from 1981 to 1988 and again from 1995 to 2007; and in the Australian Parliament from 2007 to 2010.

title: Roslyn Dundas
text: Roslyn Dundas (born 28 July 1978) is a former Australian politician.

title: Roslyn Dundas
text: She was an Australian Democrats member of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly from 2001 to 2004, when she was defeated in a bid for re-election.

title: Roslyn Dundas
text: Until Kelly Vincent's election to the South Australian Legislative Council in 2010, Dundas was the youngest woman ever elected to an Australian parliament.

title: Philip Ruddock
text: Philip Maxwell Ruddock (born 12 March 1943) is an Australian politician who is currently mayor of Hornsby Shire.

title: Philip Ruddock
text: He previously was a Liberal member of the House of Representatives from 1973 to 2016.

title: Philip Ruddock
text: First elected in a 1973 by-election, by the time of his retirement he was the last parliamentary survivor of the Whitlam and Fraser Governments.

title: Philip Ruddock
text: He was both the Father of the House and the Father of the Parliament from 1998 to his retirement.

title: Philip Ruddock
text: He is the second longest-serving parliamentarian in the history of the Australian Parliament (only Billy Hughes served longer).

title: Philip Ruddock
text: Ruddock served continuously in federal cabinet during the Howard Government, as Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs from 1996 to 2003, and then Attorney-General from 2003 to 2007.

title: Michael Atkinson
text: Michael John Atkinson (born 17 June 1958), an Australian politician in the South Australian Branch of the Australian Labor Party, is the 34th Speaker of the South Australian House of Assembly for the Jay Weatherill government, serving since 5 February 2013.

title: Michael Atkinson
text: First elected to the House at the 1989 election, Atkinson is Father of the House.

title: Bronwyn Bishop
text: Bronwyn Kathleen Bishop (née Setright; born 19 October 1942) is a former Australian politician who was the 29th Speaker of the House of Representatives, holding the office between 12 November 2013 and 2 August 2015.

title: Carol Martin
text: Carol Anne Martin (born 13 October 1957) is a former Australian politician who served as a Labor Party member of the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia between 2001 and 2013, representing the seat of Kimberley.

title: Carol Martin
text: She was the first Aboriginal woman to be elected to any Australian parliament.

title: South Korea 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The Korea 2022 FIFA World Cup bid was the second official bid from the Korea Football Association or the KFA.

title: South Korea 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: If this bid was successful, Korea would have been hosting their second World Cup Finals and it would have been their first solo hosting since they shared the 2002 FIFA World Cup with other co-host Japan.

title: South Korea 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Despite recent tensions, Han Sung-joo, chairman of the bid committee hoped to involve North Korea if South Korea received the bid.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: The bidding process for the 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cups was the process by which the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA) selected locations for the 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cups.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: The process began officially in March 2009; eleven bids from thirteen countries were received, including one which was withdrawn and one that was rejected before FIFA's executive committee voted in November 2010.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: Two of the remaining nine bids applied only to the 2022 World Cup, while the rest were initially applications for both.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: Over the course of the bidding, all non-European bids for the 2018 event were withdrawn, resulting in the exclusion of all European bids from consideration for the 2022 edition.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: By the time of the decision, bids for the 2018 World Cup included England, Russia, a joint bid from Belgium and Netherlands, and a joint bid from Portugal and Spain.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: Bids for the 2022 World Cup came from Australia, Japan, Qatar, South Korea, and the United States.

title: 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids
text: Indonesia's bid was disqualified due to lack of governmental support, and Mexico withdrew its bid for financial reasons.

title: Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup bid was a bid by Qatar to host the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

title: Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The bid has come under FBI investigation for bribery and corruption, leading to the resignation of FIFA President Sepp Blatter.

title: Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: With a population of 2 million people, Qatar will be the first Arab state to host the World Cup.

title: Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Russia announced its intent to bid for the FIFA World Cup in early 2009, and submitted its request to FIFA in time.

title: Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Russia's President Vladimir Putin has taken a keen interest in the bid and has gone so far as ordering Vitaly Mutko, the Minister of Sports, to "prepare a bid for Russia to hold the 2018 World Cup".

title: Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid
text: According to a report earlier submitted by Vitaly Mutko, who also served that time as President of the Russian Football Union (RFU), the country is ready to spend some $10 billion on the tournament.

title: Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The bid committee also includes RFU CEO Alexey Sorokin and Alexander Djordjadze as the Director of Bid Planning and Operations.

title: Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid
text: In October 2010, Russia formally pulled out of the race to host the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

title: Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid
text: On December 2, 2010 Russia was chosen as the host country for the 2018 FIFA World Cup.

title: Indonesia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The Indonesia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid was the first official bid from the Football Association of Indonesia (PSSI) to host the FIFA World Cup.

title: Indonesia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: FIFA rejected the bid for lack of government support on 19 March 2010.

title: Indonesia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Indonesia was one of four Asian countries bidding to bring the tournament to Asia for a second time, the 2002 tournament having been played in Japan and South Korea.

title: Indonesia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Indonesia, under the name of the Dutch East Indies, had been the first Asian nation to compete in the World Cup, when they participated in the 1938 event, and they lost to Hungary in the first round.

title: Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup bid is Morocco's bid to host the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

title: Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup bid
text: It is competing with the North America 2026 FIFA World Cup bid, a joint bid between Canada, Mexico and the United States for hosting rights.

title: Morocco 2026 FIFA World Cup bid
text: On 11 August 2017, the Royal Moroccan Football Federation announced that it would submit a bid for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

title: Japan 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The Japan 2022 FIFA World Cup bid is the second official bid from the Japan Football Association or the JFA.

title: Japan 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Had this bid been successful, Japan would have been hosting their second World Cup Finals and it would have been their first solo hosting since they shared the 2002 FIFA World Cup with other co-host South Korea, becoming the sixth nation to host the tournament twice, after Italy, France, Mexico, Brazil and (West) Germany.

title: Japan 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: On May 4, 2010, the Japanese Football Association Bid team decided to concentrate solely on winning the right to host the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The United States Soccer Federation submitted a bid with the hope of hosting the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: U.S. Soccer first said in February 2007 that it would put forth a bid for the 2018 World Cup.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: On January 28, 2009, U.S. Soccer announced that it would submit bids for both the 2018 and 2022 Cups.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: In October 2010 it withdrew from the 2018 bid process to focus on winning the 2022 edition.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: On December 2, 2010, it was announced that Qatar would be the host of the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Bill Clinton remarked "The FIFA people were in a mood to give it to people who didn’t have it.

title: United States 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: I think they wanted to make soccer a world sport."

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Australia submitted an unsuccessful bid for the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: On 2 December 2010 FIFA announced that the event would be held in Qatar.

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: Australia also lodged a bid for the 2018 World Cup, but withdrew the bid on 10 June 2010.

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The 2018 and 2022 World Cups will be the 21st and 22nd editions of the FIFA World Cup.

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The bidding procedure to host both the 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup began in January 2009, and national associations had until 2 February 2009 to register their interest.

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: The bid was presented by Frank Lowy, Ben Buckley, Quentin Bryce and Elle Macpherson.

title: Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid
text: However, due to controversies of Qatar hosting, Australia's bid is possible if FIFA decides to strip Qatar's 2022 hosting rights.

title: Bonita Mersiades
text: Bonita Mersiades is an Australian corporate affairs practitioner, sports administrator and writer.

title: Bonita Mersiades
text: Until 24 January 2010, Mersiades was Head of Corporate and Public Affairs with the Football Federation Australia and was also a member of the Senior Management Team for the Australian 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bid.

title: Lutheran High School (La Verne, California)
text: Lutheran High School La Verne (also known as Faith Lutheran), is a private, college preparatory Lutheran High School in La Verne, California.

title: Lutheran High School (La Verne, California)
text: In the century-long tradition of the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod, Lutheran High School La Verne serves students from the San Gabriel, Pomona, and Inland Valleys.

title: Lutheran High School (La Verne, California)
text: Built on a foundation of faith in Christ, the school provides rigorous, college preparatory curriculum to a co-educational student population in grades nine through twelve.

title: Lutheran High School (La Verne, California)
text: It is part of the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod.

title: Lutheran High School (La Verne, California)
text: The school colors are red, white and blue and the mascot is the Trojans.

title: Faith Lutheran College, Redlands
text: Faith Lutheran College, Redlands (often abbreviated as "FLCR"), Queensland, Australia, is an independent co-educational Lutheran primary and secondary school located on two campuses in Victoria Point (Junior School) and Thornlands (Middle and Senior School).

title: Faith Lutheran College, Redlands
text: The school currently educates students from years Prep to Year 12

title: Faith Lutheran High School
text: Faith Lutheran High School, commonly referred to as Faith or FLHS, is a private high school located in Crystal Lake, Illinois.

title: Faith Lutheran High School
text: It is affiliated with the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod and serves students of McHenry County, Illinois.

title: Mundelein High School
text: Mundelein High School (MHS) is a public four-year high school located in Mundelein, Illinois, a northern suburb of Chicago, Illinois, in the United States.

title: Mundelein High School
text: The school serves the Village of Mundelein and parts of surrounding villages, include Vernon Hills, Grayslake, Hawthorn Woods, Round Lake, Wauconda and Libertyville.

title: Mundelein High School
text: It's feeder schools include Carl Sandburg Middle School, Fremont Middle School, West Oak Middle School portions of Hawthorn Middle School North and Hawthorn Middle School South and the Mundelein portion that serves Frassati Catholic Academy.

title: Mentor High School
text: Mentor High School is a public high school located in Mentor, Ohio.

title: Mentor High School
text: It is the only high school in the Mentor Exempted Village School District (informally, "Mentor Schools").

title: Mentor High School
text: At one time, it was the largest high school in Ohio based on single building enrollment.

title: Mentor High School
text: For the 2008–2009 school year, it shifted from a three-year school (grades 10–12) to a four-year high school (grades 9–12), serving 3,200 students.

title: Mentor High School
text: Mentor High School educates students from Mentor, Mentor-on-the-Lake, and parts of Kirtland Hills and Concord Township in Lake County, Ohio.

title: Mentor High School
text: All three middle schools from the Mentor Exempted Village School district, including Memorial Middle School, Shore Middle School, and Ridge Middle School, feed into Mentor High School.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: Port Charlotte High School (PCHS) is a four-year, comprehensive, public high school located in Port Charlotte, Florida, US.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: The school opened in 1981, graduated its first class in 1984, its mascot is the pirate, and the school motto is "Yes, I am a Pirate."

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: It is operated by Charlotte County Public Schools.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: At one time, Port Charlotte High School was the largest high school in Charlotte County, with 2,082 students enrolled in grades Grades 9 through 12.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: Enrollment was traditionally based on students' geographic locations, but is now by choice under the more recently created open enrollment program.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: The school has grown much, and it survived Hurricane Charley.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: The school's main feeders are Murdock Middle School, Port Charlotte Middle School, and Punta Gorda Middle School.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: The school's top athletic rivals are Charlotte High School and Lemon Bay High School.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: The property value of the school is $15,797,719 US.

title: Port Charlotte High School
text: PCHS has educated two NFL players and one MLB player who also performed in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

title: Paso Robles High School
text: Paso Robles High School (PRHS) is the only comprehensive high school located in the city of Paso Robles, California.

title: Paso Robles High School
text: The school receives its students from George H. Flamson Middle School and Daniel E. Lewis Middle School, both located in Paso Robles, as well as from the Lillian Larsen School, a public K-8 school in San Miguel, California and Pleasant Valley Elementary School, a public K-8 school located in an outlying area of northeastern San Luis Obispo County.

title: Paso Robles High School
text: Additionally, the school receives students from private K-8 schools such as Trinity Lutheran School and St. Rose Catholic School, both located in Paso Robles.

title: Faith Lutheran Middle School & High School
text: Faith Lutheran Middle School & High School is a private Christian school located in Summerlin, Clark County, Nevada serving the Las Vegas Valley.

title: Faith Lutheran Middle School & High School
text: Faith has students who come from 60 different zip codes.

title: Faith Lutheran Middle School & High School
text: The school, which began in 1979, serves grades 6–12 and is affiliated with the Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod.

title: Faith Lutheran Middle School & High School
text: Faith Lutheran is the largest Lutheran school in the United States and the largest non-public school in the state of Nevada.

title: Faith Lutheran Middle School & High School
text: Faith Lutheran is governed by a Board of Directors representing the thirteen Lutheran churches in its association.

title: Vernon Fox
text: Vernon Lee Fox, III (born October 9, 1979) is a retired American football safety.

title: Vernon Fox
text: He was signed by the San Diego Chargers as an undrafted free agent after the 2002 NFL Draft.

title: Vernon Fox
text: He played college football at Fresno State.

title: Vernon Fox
text: Fox is currently a professional motivational speaker.

title: Vernon Fox
text: In February 2013, he was hired to be head football coach and admissions counselor at Faith Lutheran Middle School and High School in Las Vegas, NV.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: Sullivan East High School is a 9th through 12th grade high school located in Bluff City, Tennessee.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: The School opened its doors to students in 1968.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: Prior to the completion of Sullivan East High School students in the area attended Bluff City High School, Mary Hughes High School, and Holston Valley High School.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: Sullivan East High School has around 750 students annually.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: Sullivan East graduates roughly 250 Seniors annually.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: The three middle schools that feed into Sullivan East are Mary Hughes School, Bluff City Middle School, and Holston Valley Middle School.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: Sullivan East is part of the Sullivan County school system.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: The school's mascot is the Patriot.

title: Sullivan East High School
text: The current principal is Andy Hare, Current assistant principals include Janet Bailey, and Rick James.

title: Young Hollywood Awards
text: The Young Hollywood Awards was an award presented annually which honors the year's biggest achievements in pop music, movies, sports, television, fashion and more, as voted on by teenagers aged 13–19 and young adults.

title: Young Hollywood Awards
text: The award ceremonies also honor rising and promising young aged performers in Hollywood.

title: Young Hollywood Awards
text: The award ceremony usually features a high number of celebrities and musical performers such as Taylor Swift, Justin Bieber, and Nick Jonas.

title: Young Hollywood Awards
text: New artists such as Black Cards and Brazzabelle have also performed.

title: Jeremy Schoenberg
text: Jeremy Schoenberg (born May 8, 1972), born in Los Angeles County, California, United States.

title: Jeremy Schoenberg
text: Jeremy started out as a child star on both film and television.

title: Jeremy Schoenberg
text: He played on "Days of Our Lives" from 1980 to 1982 as Johnny, Marlena's foster child.

title: Jeremy Schoenberg
text: Jeremy was nominated for this role in the category of Best Young Actor - Daytime TV Series in the 2nd Annual Young Artist Awards.

title: Jeremy Schoenberg
text: He also voiced Linus van Pelt on "Is This Goodbye, Charlie Brown?

title: Penske Media Corporation
text: Penske Media Corporation (PMC) is an American digital media, publishing, and information services company founded in 2003.

title: Penske Media Corporation
text: PMC publishes more than 22 digital brands, including a joint venture in India with ZEE TV for its India.com brand.

title: Penske Media Corporation
text: The company also produces more than 50 annual events and conferences as well as housing a research and emerging data business.

title: Penske Media Corporation
text: PMC brands include PMC Studios, WWD, WWD.com, Footwear News, M, Deadline.com, Variety magazine, Variety.com, CricketCountry.com, HollywoodLife, Beauty Inc, GoldDerby.com, India.com, Movieline, TVLine, BGR, AwardsLine, @Hollywood, LA411, NY411, Young Hollywood Awards, The Style Awards, and Breakthrough of the Year Awards.

title: Penske Media Corporation
text: The company is headquartered in Los Angeles, California and New York, NY with 11 offices around the world.

text: The 15th Annual Young Hollywood Awards were held on Thursday, August 1, 2013 in Los Angeles, California, previously recorded the day before.

title: 2013 Young Hollywood Awards
text: Aisha Tyler was the host while there were no nominees this year, the recipients were "honored" with the awards.

title: 2013 Young Hollywood Awards
text: This was the first year that the awards were televised.

title: Puerto Roc Records
text: Puerto Roc Records is an independent record label that was established in 2006 by founder and sole owner Jonathan "DJ Primo" Padilla.

title: Puerto Roc Records
text: The independent label is based out of Miami, Florida and has its main focus on hip hop/rap music.

title: Puerto Roc Records
text: Puerto Roc Records' main artist is E Grizzly.

title: Puerto Roc Records
text: E Grizzly released his first E.P. in May 2006 titled "Hip Hop is Dead!"

title: Puerto Roc Records
text: and won the 2006 Independent Rap Artist of the Year at the 16th annual L.A. Music Awards in November 2006.

title: Puerto Roc Records

title: Puerto Roc Records

title: 12th Youth in Film Awards
text: The 12th Youth in Film Awards ceremony (now known as the Young Artist Awards), presented by the Youth in Film Association, honored outstanding youth performers under the age of 21 in the fields of film, television and music for the 1989-1990 season.

title: 12th Youth in Film Awards
text: The exact date of the 12th annual ceremony is unknown, however, using the dates of the 11th and 13th annual awards, the 12th annual ceremony is believed to have taken place in late 1990 or early 1991 in Hollywood, California.

title: Young Adult Library Services Association
text: The Young Adult Library Services Association (YALSA), established in 1957, is a division of the American Library Association.

title: Young Adult Library Services Association
text: YALSA is a national association of librarians, library workers and advocates whose mission is to expand the capacity of libraries to better serve teens.

title: Young Adult Library Services Association
text: YALSA administers several awards and sponsors an annual Young Adult Literature Symposium, Teen Read Week, the third week of each October, and Teen Tech Week, the second week of each March.

title: Young Adult Library Services Association
text: YALSA currently has over 5,200 members.

title: Young Adult Library Services Association
text: YALSA aims to expand and strengthen library services for teens through advocacy, research, professional development and events.

title: Maureen Dragone
text: Maureen Dragone (January 20, 1920 – February 8, 2013) was an American journalist and author.

title: Maureen Dragone
text: She was one of the longest-standing members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association which presents the annual Golden Globe Awards.

title: Maureen Dragone
text: In 1978 she founded the Young Artist Association, which presents the annual Young Artist Awards.

title: 2014 Young Hollywood Awards
text: The 16th Annual Young Hollywood Awards were held on Monday, July 28, 2014 in Los Angeles, California, previously recorded the day before.

title: 2014 Young Hollywood Awards
text: Kelly Osbourne hosted the show, with Justin Bieber being honored for his charity work and contributions to the Make-A-Wish Foundation, and Vanessa Hudgens was honored with the Trendsetter Award.

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: The Nickelodeon Kids Choice Awards 2003 was held on April 12, 2003.

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: It was the 16th annual Kids' Choice Awards ("KCA").

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: It was hosted by Rosie O'Donnell.

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: The award show was held in the Barker Hangar at the Santa Monica Airport in Santa Monica, California.

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: This was the last time O'Donnell would host the awards.

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: By that time she has hosted the awards seven times in a row.

title: 2003 Kids' Choice Awards
text: The announcers were Daran Norris and Susanne Blakeslee from "The Fairly OddParents" who used their Cosmo and Wanda voices, respectively, for the event.

title: Winnebago Deal
text: Winnebago Deal are a rock music band from Oxford, United Kingdom.

title: Winnebago Deal
text: They started life in the late 1990s at Bartholomew School in Eynsham, with Ben Perrier (vocals, guitar) and Ben Thomas (then on guitar) writing songs then recruiting a drummer and bass player through an ad.

title: Winnebago Deal
text: They played their first gig in early 1999 and fired the bass player a few months later, with Ben Thomas switching from guitar to bass.

title: Winnebago Deal
text: By the summer of 2000, Perrier and Thomas' dissatisfaction with their drummer led to his departure, with Thomas switching from bass to drums so the band could continue as a two-piece.

title: Winnebago Deal
text: Winnebago Deal now consists of two Bens, Ben Perrier (vocals, guitar) and Ben Thomas (drums).

title: Zachary Throne
text: Zachary Throne (born April 3, 1967 in Hollywood, California) is an American actor and musician who has appeared in a wide number of television, film and stage productions and on numerous rock, pop and soundtrack albums.

title: Zachary Throne
text: Throne is a self-taught, musician who sings, plays guitar, bass, drums, and piano – and is self-taught on all instruments.

title: Zachary Throne
text: He is the son of Malachi Throne and Judith Merians and is the brother of Joshua Throne.

title: Zachary Throne
text: He earned a Gold record in 1992 for his work on the soundtrack album to the television series "The Heights", on which he performed guitars, bass, piano and vocals as well as co-starred in the series.

title: Zachary Throne
text: The album yielded a hit single, "How Do You Talk To An Angel" (on which Zachary performed on) that was #1 on "Billboard" for two weeks in November 1992.

title: Zachary Throne
text: As an actor, Zachary is best known for playing the recurring role of "Howard", the radio station manager/drug dealer on "Beverly Hills 90210" and for playing "Danny" on the FOX series, "Party Of Five".

title: Zachary Throne
text: As a singer, Zachary has sung on many TV and radio jingles.

title: Zachary Throne
text: He provided the singing voice for the character, "Mark Winkle" on the television series, "California Dreams" as well as the singing voice for the character, "Greg Brady" in the films, "The Brady Bunch Movie" and "A Very Brady Sequel".

title: Zachary Throne
text: Currently, he resides in Las Vegas, Nevada where he performs in many shows.

title: Zachary Throne
text: From 2012-2014, he was the lead singer/lead guitar player/bass player for the Sin City Sinners, a group that also featured former Faster Pussycat guitarist and co-founder Brent Muscat as well as Slash bass player, Todd Kerns.

title: Zachary Throne
text: With the group, he recorded two albums, "DIVEBAR Days Revisited" and "A Sinners Christmas 2", both released in 2013.

title: Double Dagger
text: Double Dagger was a post-punk trio from Baltimore, Maryland composed of only drums, vocals, and a very loud bass guitar which fills the space a guitar would normally take.

title: Double Dagger
text: Vocalist Nolen Strals and bassist Bruce Willen also comprised the graphic design team Post Typography, which has done work for some very high-profile clients, including the New York Times.

title: Double Dagger
text: Hence, Double Dagger made a habit of referring to their style of post-hardcore as "graphicdesigncore" early in their career.

title: Double Dagger
text: In October 2011, Double Dagger broke up after a small final tour.

title: Double Dagger
text: Their final EP 333 was released in April 2013 alongside a documentary of their final tour, entitled "If We Shout Loud Enough".

title: Didi Beck
text: Didi Beck is a German electric bass and double bass player.

title: Didi Beck
text: He plays in the rockabilly band, the Boppin'B.

title: Didi Beck
text: An accomplished upright bass slap bass player, he teaches slap bass and has written an instruction book on slapping, and a made a video entitled "How to Learn the Rockabilly Slap Bass Starring Didi Beck".

title: Didi Beck
text: His rapid, virtuosic slapping technique can be heard online.

title: Dave Meros
text: Dave Meros (born 8 February 1956 in Salinas, California), is an American bass guitar player, best known as the bass player for progressive rock band Spock's Beard.

title: Dave Meros
text: Meros is also currently the bass player for Iron Butterfly and has also played with such artists as Gary Myrick, Bobby Kimball of Toto, Simon Phillips, Steve Lukather, Michael Landau, Glenn Hughes, Mark Lindsay of Paul Revere and the Raiders and Big Big Train, and played for Eric Burdon and The Animals for nearly 16 years.

title: Dave Meros
text: He was also tour manager for many of those years and has worked as a tour manager for further artists as well.

title: Dave Meros
text: As a bassist, Meros' musical influences are varied, including Paul McCartney, John Entwistle, Chris Squire, James Jamerson, Marcus Miller, Francis "Rocco" Prestia of Tower of Power, Chuck Rainey and David Hungate.

title: Tracy Ferrie
text: Tracy Ferrie is an American musician, who is the current bass player for the classic rock band Boston and was the former bass player of Christian metal band Stryper.

title: Tracy Ferrie
text: Beginning in 1996, Tracy played bass for Michael Sweet's solo band and was also a member of the bands Electrik, Sally Steele, Seraiah, Whitecross, Guardian, Rebecca St. James, Plumb, Sonicflood and Strange Celebrity.

title: Tracy Ferrie
text: He is from Elkhart, Indiana and a national roller skating champion.

title: Walkdown
text: In country music, walkdown is a bassline which connects two root position chords whose roots are a third apart, often featuring an inverted chord to go between the root notes of the first two chords.

title: Walkdown
text: See: slash chord.

title: Walkdown
text: A walkup would be the converse.

title: Walkdown
text: For example the chords G Major and E minor (a minor third apart) may be joined by an intervening chord to create stepwise motion in the bass: G-D/F♯ -Em (I-V6/4-vi).

title: Walkdown
text: The second chord, D Major, is performed with its third note, the F#, in the bass.

title: Walkdown
text: Walkdowns may be performed by the upright bass player, the electric bass player, the guitarist, or a piano player.

title: Five Guys in a Really Hot Garage
text: Five Guys In A Really Hot Garage is the final studio album by Mucky Pup.

title: Five Guys in a Really Hot Garage
text: It was released in Germany under their own imprint, Mucky Records, through SPV Music in 1995.

title: Five Guys in a Really Hot Garage
text: The lineup saw the additions of Jack "Hinge" Pitzer, formerly of New Jersey thrash metal band, The Beast, on guitar and Joe Mama on bass.

title: Five Guys in a Really Hot Garage
text: Bass player Bill Bergmann appeared on two of the songs and was pictured on the album cover.

title: Five Guys in a Really Hot Garage
text: Bergmann would remain the bass player for what would be the last several months of the band's existence.

title: Five Guys in a Really Hot Garage
text: A single and video was released for the track "Short Attention Span".

title: Rodney Slatford
text: Rodney Slatford (born 18 July 1944) is an English contemporary double bass player and teacher (especially of young children).

title: Rodney Slatford
text: He was the principal bass player of the Midland Sinfonia, Academy of St. Martin in the Fields, and English Chamber Orchestra, a founder of the Nash Ensemble, and has been a principal player in other early music ensembles.

title: Rodney Slatford
text: He is also a publisher of sheet music for double bass.

title: Rodney Slatford
text: He had studied with Adrian Beers and wrote his obituary in "The Independent".

title: Even Steven Levee
text: Even Steven Levee born Steven Louis Levee, is an American musician, bass player, recording engineer, record producer and former nightclub concert promoter.

title: Even Steven Levee
text: He is best known for his work with such bands as Lifeforce, ZRS, Brad Factor:10, The Slashtones, The Freak Parade, and his production work with Hedi, Barbara Lee George, MC Magic D and Gun Hill.

title: Even Steven Levee
text: As a bass player he is known for his diversity, playing with rock, funk, jazz, blues and hip hop artists, and for his use of various fretted and fretless four, five and six string bass guitars.

title: Even Steven Levee
text: He is also well known within the music industry for hosting premier "all star" jam sessions at various nightclubs in the New York area during the 1990s.

title: Even Steven Levee
text: Even has appeared on HBO and "Late Night with Conan O'Brien" during the current century and continues to work in Music and the Information Technology field.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: The Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc. (CPACS) is 501(c)(3), private, nonprofit human services organization in metropolitan Atlanta, headquartered in northern DeKalb County, Georgia, United States of America.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: The organization was founded in 1980 and provides broad services for American citizens and non-citizens of all race, ethnicity, and national origin.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: The organization's primary services include community health, social services, housing, senior services, translation and interpretation, transportation services, education and enrichment programs for children, youth, and families, community education, legal and immigration assistance, counseling, advocacy, and research.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: CPACS's core objective is to help immigrants and refugees achieve the American Dream.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: The center operates the CPACS Cosmo Health Center, a Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC) that serves populations with limited access to health care.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: Since 2005, the organization has held the Tea Walk, a two-mile empowerment walk along the Buford Highway Corridor to celebrate community diversity and promote civic engagement.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: CPACS is a member of the Association of Asian Pacific Community Health Organizations (AAPCHO), which is part of the National Council of Asian Pacific Americans.

title: Center for Pan Asian Community Services, Inc.
text: CPACS is one of the first and largest Asian American and Pacific Islander human services agencies in the Southeastern United States.

title: University of Florida Health Science Center
text: The University of Florida Health Science Center (HSC), also known as the J. Hillis Miller Health Science Center, is the medical division of the University of Florida.

title: University of Florida Health Science Center
text: Its primary campuses are located on the university's main campus in Gainesville, Florida and at UF Health at Jacksonville in Jacksonville, Florida.

title: University of Florida Health Science Center
text: The Health Science Center comprises six colleges: Dentistry, Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy, Public Health and Health Professions, and Veterinary Medicine.

title: University of Florida Health Science Center
text: The Gainesville campus is the only academic health center in the United States with six health-related colleges located on a single, contiguous campus.

title: University of Florida Health Science Center
text: The facility was named after the fourth president of the University of Florida, J. Hillis Miller, Sr., who served from 1947 to 1953.

title: University of Florida Health Science Center
text: Miller spearheaded the effort to fund and build the university's College of Medicine and its teaching hospital, which were incorporated into the Health Science Center.

title: United States Public Health Service
text: The Public Health Service Act of 1944 structured the United States Public Health Service (PHS), founded in 1798, as the primary division of the U.S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare (HEW; which was established in 1953), which later became the United States Department of Health and Human Services in 1979–1980 (when the Education agencies were separated into their own U.S. Department of Education).

title: United States Public Health Service
text: The Office of the Surgeon General was created in 1871.

title: United States Public Health Service
text: The PHS comprises all Agency Divisions of Health and Human Services and the Commissioned Corps.

title: United States Public Health Service
text: The Assistant Secretary for Health (ASH) oversees the PHS and the United States Public Health Service Commissioned Corps.

title: Supporting Healthy Marriage Project
text: The Supporting Healthy Marriage Project (SHM) is part of the Healthy Marriage Initiative funded by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Administration for Children and Families, that was launched in 2003 as "the first large-scale, multisite, multiyear, rigorous test of marriage education programs for low-income married couples".

title: Supporting Healthy Marriage Project
text: The project is motivated by research that "indicates that married adults and children raised by both parents in stable, low-conflict households do better on a host of outcomes".

title: Supporting Healthy Marriage Project
text: The evaluation is led by MDRC, in collaboration with Abt Associates and other partners.

title: Supporting Healthy Marriage Project
text: USASpending.gov reports payments of more than $30 million from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to MDRC for work on the Supporting Healthy Marriage Project from 2009 to 2012.

title: New Bolton Center
text: New Bolton Center is the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine’s 700 acre campus in Kennett Square, Pennsylvania.

title: New Bolton Center
text: It is home to one of the busiest large animal teaching veterinary clinics in the nation.

title: New Bolton Center
text: Since 1958, it has been located at the former South Brook Farm.

title: New Bolton Center
text: Founded in 1964 with contributions from equestrienne Esther du Pont Thouron and others, each year the George D. Widener Hospital for Large Animals (named for horseman George D. Widener, Jr.) sees more than 4,000 patient visits, and its Field Service sees more than 31,000 patient visits.

title: New Bolton Center
text: In addition to its role as one of the nation’s finest equine surgical facilities, New Bolton Center encompasses hospital facilities for the care of large animals and livestock as well as diagnostic laboratories serving the agriculture industry and the monitoring of emerging infectious disease.

title: New Bolton Center
text: Prior to the opening of "New" Bolton Center in 1952, the old Bolton Mansion in Levittown was the site of the farm for the School of Veterinary Medicine.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: Brenda McCowan is a research behaviorist interested in evolutionary, biological, and ecological aspects of animal behavior and communication.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: Her work focuses on improving the health and welfare of domesticated production animals, captive species (zoo, laboratory), and wildlife using applied animal behavior and bioacoustics.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: She received her BS in Animal Physiology from Cornell University in 1985, and her PhD in Biological Anthropology from Harvard University in 1994.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: Dr. McCowan is the Program Head of Primate Behavioral Management at California National Primate Research Center, a position she has held since 2004.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: Dr. McCowan has been on the faculty at the University of California – Davis since 1999, and is currently an Associate Adjunct Professor in the Department of Population Health and Reproduction at the UC Davis School of Veterinary Medicine.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: She also heads the McCowan Lab of Behavioral Management at UC Davis School of Veterinary Medicine.

title: Brenda McCowan
text: Dr. McCowan is also affiliated with the Alaska Whale Foundation, SETI Institute, Hubbs-Sea World Institute, and Santa Fe Institute.

title: Ontario Veterinary College
text: The Ontario Veterinary College (OVC) is the oldest veterinary school in Canada.

title: Ontario Veterinary College
text: It is located on the campus of the University of Guelph in Guelph, Ontario.

title: Ontario Veterinary College
text: The OVC is one of five veterinary schools that offer the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine, DVM program in Canada.

title: Ontario Veterinary College
text: The OVC was ranked 1st in Canada and 4th in the world for veterinary medicine by the QS World University Rankings 2015.

title: Oyewale Tomori
text: Tomori was born in Ilesa, Osun State, Nigeria on 3 February 1946.

title: Oyewale Tomori
text: He received a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine(DVM) from Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria as well as a Doctorate degree, Ph.D in virology from the University of Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria where he was appointed professor of virology in 1981, the same year he received the United State of America Department of Health and Human Services Public Health Service Certificate for contributions to Lassa Fever Research.

title: Oyewale Tomori
text: Three years (1984) after his appointment as a professor of virology, he was appointed the head of the Department of Virology.

title: Oyewale Tomori
text: At the University of Ibadan Tomori's research interest focuses on viral infections including Ebola Hemorrhagic Fever, Yellow Fever, Lassa Fever.

title: Oyewale Tomori
text: He served as the Regional Virologist for the World Health Organization Africa Region ( 1994-2004) before he was appointed as the pioneer vice chancellor of Redeemer's University, Ogun State, Nigeria, a tenure that ended in 2011.

title: Evidence-Based Veterinary Medical Association
text: The Evidence-Based Veterinary Medical Association (EBVMA) is an international, non-profit (501(c)3) professional organization founded with the mission of better organizing the emerging veterinary research, training, and practice of evidence-based veterinary medicine (EBVM) — the formal strategy to integrate the best critically designed and statistically evaluated research available combined with clinical expertise as well as the unique needs or wishes of each client in clinical practice.

title: Evidence-Based Veterinary Medical Association
text: EBVM draws from and parallels the evidence-based medicine movement in human medicine.

title: Western University of Health Sciences
text: Western University of Health Sciences (WesternU) is a private, non-profit, graduate school for the health professions, with a main campus located on 22 acre in downtown Pomona, California, and an additional medical school campus on 50 acres in Lebanon, Oregon.

title: Western University of Health Sciences
text: WesternU offers degrees in osteopathic medicine, dental medicine, optometry, podiatric medicine, nursing, physician assistant studies, physical therapy, pharmacy, biomedical sciences, and veterinary medicine.

title: Western University of Health Sciences
text: With an enrollment of 3,839 students (2016–17), WesternU is one of the largest graduate schools for the health professions in California, offering 21 academic programs in nine colleges.

title: Western University of Health Sciences
text: The university also operates two patient care centers, and has a pet wellness center on its Pomona campus.

title: Western University of Health Sciences
text: The WesternU Pomona campus is also home to the Center for Oral Health (a non-profit organization focusing on promoting oral health), the Southern California Museum of Medical History, and the Harris Family Center for Disability and Health Policy.

title: Oryctodromeus
text: Oryctodromeus (meaning "digging runner") was a genus of small ornithopod dinosaur.

title: Oryctodromeus
text: Fossils are known from the middle Cretaceous Blackleaf Formation of southwestern Montana and the Wayan Formation of southeastern Idaho, USA, both of the Cenomanian stage, roughly 95 million years ago.

title: Oryctodromeus
text: A member of the small, presumably fast-running herbivorous family Thescelosauridae, "Oryctodromeus" is the first dinosaur published that shows evidence of burrowing behavior.

title: Dakotadon
text: Dakotadon is a genus of iguanodont dinosaur from the Barremian-age Lower Cretaceous Lakota Formation of South Dakota, USA, known from a partial skull.

title: Dakotadon
text: It was first described in 1989 as "Iguanodon lakotaensis", by David B. Weishampel and Philip R. Bjork.

title: Dakotadon
text: Its assignment has been controversial.

title: Dakotadon
text: Some researchers suggest that ""I." lakotaensis" was more basal than "I. bernissartensis", and related to "Theiophytalia", but David Norman has suggested that it was a synonym of "I. bernissartensis".

title: Dakotadon
text: Gregory S. Paul, working on a revision of iguanodont species, gave "I." "lakotaensis" its own genus ("Dakotadon") in 2008.

title: Cinizasaurus
text: "Cinizasaurus" is an informal name for fossilized remains from the Late Triassic of New Mexico that were initially interpreted as belonging to a theropod dinosaur.

title: Cinizasaurus
text: The remains, NMMNH P-18400, consist of a tibia, vertebrae, and fragments, and came from the ?

title: Cinizasaurus
text: late Carnian-age Upper Triassic Bluewater Creek Member of the Chinle Formation, near Fort Wingate.

title: Cinizasaurus
text: Andrew Heckert, in his unpublished thesis, proposed the name "Cinizasaurus hunti" for the specimen, but the name was never adopted, and was first referred to in the scientific literature in a 2007 redescription of Late Triassic North American material thought to belong to dinosaurs (Nesbitt, Irmis, and Parker, 2007).

title: Cinizasaurus
text: In the redescription, the authors could only assign the material to Archosauriformes.

title: Supersaurus
text: Supersaurus (meaning "super lizard") is a genus of diplodocid sauropod dinosaur first discovered by Vivian Jones of Delta, Colorado, in late Jurassic period rocks of the middle Morrison Formation of Colorado in 1972, and later in Portugal under the name "S. lourinhanensis".

title: Supersaurus
text: The fossil remains came from the Brushy Basin Member of the formation, dating to about 153 million years ago.

title: Fruitadens
text: Fruitadens is a genus of heterodontosaurid dinosaur.

title: Fruitadens
text: The name means "Fruita tooth", in reference to Fruita, Colorado (USA), where its fossils were first found.

title: Fruitadens
text: It is known from partial skulls and skeletons from at least four individuals of differing biological ages, found in Tithonian (Late Jurassic) rocks of the Morrison Formation in Colorado.

title: Fruitadens
text: "Fruitadens" is the smallest known ornithischian dinosaur, with young adults estimated at 65 to in length and 0.5 to in weight.

title: Fruitadens
text: It is interpreted as an omnivore and represents one of the latest-surviving heterodontosaurids.

title: The Compound (book)
text: The Compound is a 2008 young adult novel by S. A. Bodeen.

title: The Compound (book)
text: The book was first released on April 29, 2008 through Feiwel & Friends and centers upon a young boy named Eli who has been living in a compound for six years.

title: The Compound (book)
text: Bodeen came up with the idea of including cannibalism in the novel after watching a television show where "a dinosaur fed a favorite offspring the bodies of its less fortunate brothers and sisters."

title: Cryptoraptor
text: "Cryptoraptor" (meaning "secret thief") is an informal name for fossilized remains from the Late Triassic of New Mexico that were initially interpreted as belonging to a dinosaur.

title: Cryptoraptor
text: The remains, NMMNH P-17375, consist of a fragmentary skeleton including vertebrae, a pubis, and parts of the thigh bones.

title: Cryptoraptor
text: This specimen came from the Norian-age Upper Triassic Bull Canyon Formation in Quay County.

title: Cryptoraptor
text: Adrian Hunt, in his unpublished dissertation, proposed the name "Cryptoraptor lockleyi" for the specimen, but the name was never adopted, and was first referred to in the scientific literature in a 2007 redescription of Late Triassic North American material thought to belong to dinosaurs (Nesbitt, Irmis, and Parker, 2007).

title: Cryptoraptor
text: In the redescription, the authors could only assign the material to Archosauria.

title: Comanchesaurus
text: "Comanchesaurus" is an informal name for fossilized remains from the Late Triassic of New Mexico that were initially interpreted as belonging to a theropod dinosaur.

title: Comanchesaurus
text: The remains, NMMNH P-4569, consist of a partial skeleton including vertebral centra and hindlimb bones, and came from the Norian-age Upper Triassic Bull Canyon Formation of Guadalupe County.

title: Comanchesaurus
text: Adrian Hunt, in his unpublished dissertation, proposed the name "Comanchesaurus kuesi" for the specimen, but the name was never adopted, and was first referred to in the scientific literature in a 2007 redescription of Late Triassic North American material thought to belong to dinosaurs (Nesbitt, Irmis, and Parker, 2007).

title: Comanchesaurus
text: In the redescription, the authors found the material to belong to a "possible indeterminate saurischian".

title: Sphaerotholus
text: Sphaerotholus is a genus of pachycephalosaurid dinosaur from the Upper Cretaceous of the western United States and Canada.

title: Sphaerotholus
text: To date, three species have been described: the type species, "S. goodwini", from the Den-na-zin Member of the Kirtland Formation (Late Campanian) of San Juan County, New Mexico, USA; "S. buchholtzae", from the Hell Creek Formation (Late Maastrichtian) of western Carter County, Montana, USA; and "S. edmontonense", from the Horseshoe Canyon Formation of Alberta, Canada.

title: Sphaerotholus
text: The etymology of "Sphaerotholus" is a combination of the Greek "sphaira", meaning "ball", and "tholos", meaning "dome", and is a reference to the characteristically dome-shaped pachycephalosaurian skull.

title: Sphaerotholus
text: The survival of "Sphaerotholus" from the Campanian of New Mexico to the end of the Maastrichtian of Montana demonstrates that this taxon had both a relatively long duration (approximately 7-8 million years) and a widespread distribution.

title: Sphaerotholus
text: Williamson and Carr, who first described the genus in 2002, diagnose it as follows: "Differs from all other pachycephalosaurids where known in the possession of a parietosquamosal bar that decreases in depth laterally as seen in caudal view and is bordered by a single row of nodes and one lateroventral corner node."

title: Sphaerotholus
text: "Sphaerotholus" is considered a highly derived pachycephalosaur.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: Mark Thomas Ciardi (born August 19, 1961; pronounced CHAR-dee) is an American film producer and former Major League Baseball pitcher.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: He is currently the Founder & CEO of Apex Entertainment.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: Mark has a rich breadth of experience as a Film Executive, and Producer.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: Apex Entertainment is an independent content production firm that also serves as a financier for media properties.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: Prior to Apex, Mark was the co-founder of Mayhem Pictures that had an overall first look deal with Walt Disney Studios for twelve years.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: At Mayhem, Ciardi produced films including "The Rookie", "Miracle", Invincible, The Game Plan, Secretariat, and Million Dollar Arm and Kevin Costner's McFarland USA.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: Awaiting release is the worldwide best-selling novel, Fallen.

title: Mark Ciardi
text: He also produced the Emmy Award winning, ESPN 30 for 30 documentary titled "Big Shot".

title: Bishop Sullivan Catholic High School
text: Bishop Sullivan Catholic High School (from 1949 to 1993, Norfolk Catholic High School; from 1993-2004, Catholic High School; commonly referred to as "Catholic" or "CHS") is a Roman Catholic secondary school in Virginia Beach, Virginia, founded as Norfolk Catholic High School in 1949 and moved to Virginia Beach in 1993.

title: Bishop Sullivan Catholic High School
text: In 2003, the school was renamed in honor of Walter Francis Sullivan, Bishop Emeritus of the Diocese of Richmond and a significant benefactor during the school's move to Virginia Beach.

title: Bishop Sullivan Catholic High School
text: The Barry Robinson Theater and Fine Arts Center opened that same year.

title: Bishop Sullivan Catholic High School
text: The current principal is Dennis W. Price, who replaced Monsignor William Pitt, following his retirement in 2005.

title: Spalding Catholic High School
text: Spalding Catholic High School was a private, Roman Catholic high school in Granville, Iowa.

title: Spalding Catholic High School
text: It is located in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Sioux City.

title: Spalding Catholic High School
text: The high school closed at the end of the 2013 school year and unified into Gehlen Catholic High School in LeMars, Iowa.

title: Spalding Catholic High School
text: Spalding Catholic School is now a PreK through 6th grade system.

title: Bishop Manogue High School
text: Bishop Manogue Catholic High School is a Catholic high school in Reno, Nevada.

title: Bishop Manogue High School
text: It is the only Catholic high school in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Reno and one of only two Catholic high schools in the state of Nevada.

title: Fremont School District 79
text: Fremont School District 79 is a school district located in Mundelein, Illinois, and it is composed of Fremont Elementary School, Fremont Intermediate School, and Fremont Middle School.

title: Fremont School District 79
text: Fremont Middle School, the one in which the students of the most seniority attend, 16% feed into Adlai E. Stevenson High School in Lincolnshire, Illinois.

title: Fremont School District 79
text: Seventy-nine percent of the students feed into Mundelein High School in Mundelein, Illinois, and the other 5% of the students either will go to Grayslake Central High School in Grayslake, Illinois or Carmel Catholic High School in Mundelein, Illinois .

title: Fremont School District 79
text: The current superintendent is Dr. Bill Robertson, with the principals of Fremont Elementary School, Fremont Intermediate School, and Fremont Middle School being Stefan Ladenburger (both elementary and intermediate) and Pamela Motsenbocker.

title: Carmel High School (Mundelein, Illinois)
text: Carmel Catholic High School is a co-educational, college preparatory, Catholic high school run jointly by the priests and brothers of the Order of Carmelites and the Sisters of Charity of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

title: Carmel High School (Mundelein, Illinois)
text: Located in Mundelein, Illinois, Carmel serves all of Lake County, as well as some of the surrounding counties, and southern Wisconsin.

title: Carmel High School (Mundelein, Illinois)
text: An institution of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago, Carmel Catholic is one of three Carmelite-run high schools in the Chicago area, the others being Joliet Catholic High School and Mount Carmel High School.

title: St. Petersburg Catholic High School
text: St. Petersburg Catholic High School is a private, co-educational Roman Catholic high school in St. Petersburg, Florida.

title: St. Petersburg Catholic High School
text: It is located in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint Petersburg.

title: St. Petersburg Catholic High School
text: The campus was originally opened in February 1957 as Bishop Barry High School for boys.

title: St. Petersburg Catholic High School
text: In 1973, Bishop Barry High School and the nearby Notre Dame Academy for girls merged to become St. Petersburg Catholic High School.

title: St. Petersburg Catholic High School
text: (A decade earlier, St. Paul's High School for girls was merged into Notre Dame Academy.)

title: Monroe Catholic High School
text: Monroe Catholic High School is a private, Roman Catholic high school in Fairbanks, Alaska.

title: Monroe Catholic High School
text: It is the only Catholic high school in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Fairbanks.

title: Monroe Catholic High School
text: It is the northernmost Roman Catholic high school in the Americas.

title: Kapaun Mt. Carmel Catholic High School
text: Kapaun Mt. Carmel Catholic High School, sometimes called Kapaun, is a private, four year, co-educational, secondary school operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Wichita.

title: Kapaun Mt. Carmel Catholic High School
text: It is located in the east side of Wichita, Kansas.

title: Kapaun Mt. Carmel Catholic High School
text: The school colors are blue and white.

title: Kapaun Mt. Carmel Catholic High School
text: The average annual enrollment is approximately 850 students.

title: Bishop Carroll Catholic High School
text: Bishop Carroll Catholic High School is a private high school located in Wichita, Kansas, United States.

title: Bishop Carroll Catholic High School
text: Along with Kapaun Mt. Carmel Catholic High School, it is one of two Catholic high schools in the city, part of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Wichita.

title: John S. Burke Catholic High School
text: John S. Burke Catholic High School, referred to locally as Burke Catholic, is a private, Roman Catholic high school in Goshen, New York and is located within the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: John S. Burke Catholic High School
text: Burke Catholic is the only Catholic high school located in Orange County.

title: John S. Burke Catholic High School
text: The school's colors are blue and white, with their sports teams, the Burke Catholic Eagles, carrying on those colors.

title: John S. Burke Catholic High School
text: Occasionally, silver is added to the school's colors.

title: John S. Burke Catholic High School
text: The school motto is "Non Vox Sed Votum", Latin for "Not Words But Deeds".

title: United States presidential election, 2012
text: The United States presidential election of 2012 was the 57th quadrennial American presidential election.

title: United States presidential election, 2012
text: It was held on Tuesday, November 6, 2012.

title: United States presidential election, 2012
text: The Democratic nominee, incumbent President Barack Obama, and his running mate, Vice President Joe Biden, were elected to a second term, defeating the Republican nominee, former Governor of Massachusetts Mitt Romney and his running mate, Representative and future House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin.

title: Michigan Democratic primary, 2016
text: The 2016 Michigan Democratic primary took place on March 8 in the U.S. state of Michigan as one of the Democratic Party's primaries ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

title: United States presidential election, 1964
text: The United States presidential election of 1964 was the 45th quadrennial presidential election.

title: United States presidential election, 1964
text: It was held on Tuesday, November 3, 1964.

title: United States presidential election, 1964
text: Democratic candidate and incumbent President Lyndon B. Johnson had come to office less than a year earlier following the assassination of his predecessor John F. Kennedy.

title: United States presidential election, 1964
text: Johnson, who had successfully associated himself with Kennedy’s popularity, won 61.1% of the popular vote, the highest win by a candidate since James Monroe’s re-election in 1820.

title: United States presidential election, 1964
text: It was the most lopsided US presidential election in terms of popular votes, and the tenth-most lopsided presidential election in the history of the United States in terms of electoral votes.

title: United States presidential election, 1964
text: No candidate for president since has equalled or surpassed Johnson’s percentage of the popular vote, and since 1820, only Abraham Lincoln in 1864, Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1936, Richard Nixon in 1972 and Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984 have won by a greater electoral vote margin.

title: United States presidential election, 2020
text: The United States presidential election of 2020, scheduled for Tuesday, November 3, 2020, will be the 59th quadrennial U.S. presidential election.

title: United States presidential election, 2020
text: Voters will select presidential electors who in turn will either elect a new president and vice president through the electoral college or re-elect the incumbents.

title: United States presidential election, 2020
text: The series of presidential primary elections and caucuses are likely to be held during the first six months of 2020.

title: United States presidential election, 2020
text: This nominating process is also an indirect election, where voters cast ballots selecting a slate of delegates to a political party's nominating convention, who then in turn elect their party's presidential nominee.

title: United States presidential election, 1960
text: The United States presidential election of 1960 was the 44th quadrennial presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 8, 1960.

title: United States presidential election, 1960
text: The Republican Party nominated incumbent Vice President Richard Nixon, while the Democratic Party nominated John F. Kennedy, U.S. Senator from Massachusetts.

title: United States presidential election, 1960
