text: The incumbent President, Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower, was not eligible for re-election after being elected the maximum two times allowed by the Twenty-second Amendment; he was the first President denied the choice to run for a third term by that amendment.

title: United States presidential election, 1960
text: This was the first presidential election in which residents in Alaska and Hawaii were able to participate, as both had become states in 1959.

title: United States presidential election, 1968
text: The United States presidential election of 1968 was the 46th quadrennial presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 5, 1968.

title: United States presidential election, 1968
text: The Republican nominee, former Vice President Richard Nixon, won the election over the Democratic nominee, incumbent Vice President Hubert Humphrey.

title: United States presidential election, 1968
text: Analysts have argued the election of 1968 was a major realigning election as it permanently disrupted the New Deal Coalition that had dominated presidential politics for 36 years.

title: United States presidential election, 1892
text: The United States presidential election of 1892 was the 27th quadrennial presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 8, 1892.

title: United States presidential election, 1892
text: It witnessed a re-match of the closely contested presidential election in 1888.

title: United States presidential election, 1892
text: Former Democratic President Grover Cleveland and incumbent Republican President Benjamin Harrison both ran for election to a second term.

title: United States presidential election, 1892
text: In 1888, Cleveland won the popular vote over Harrison, but lost in the electoral college.

title: United States presidential election, 1892
text: In a re-match, Cleveland won both the popular and electoral vote, thus becoming the first and to date only person in American history to be elected to a second, non-consecutive presidential term.

title: United States presidential election, 1892
text: The new Populist Party, formed by groups from The Grange, the Farmers' Alliances, and the Knights of Labor, also fielded a ticket; they polled best in the West, winning in five states and taking a total of 22 electoral votes.

title: United States presidential election, 1976
text: The United States presidential election of 1976 was the 48th quadrennial presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 2, 1976.

title: United States presidential election, 1976
text: The winner was the Dark horse candidate Jimmy Carter, a former Governor from Georgia with his running mate, Walter Mondale, a U.S. Senator from Minnesota, the Democratic candidates, over the incumbent President Gerald Ford from Michigan and his running mate, Bob Dole, a U.S. Senator from Kansas, the Republican candidates.

title: United States presidential election, 2016
text: The United States presidential election of 2016 was the 58th quadrennial American presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 8, 2016.

title: United States presidential election, 2016
text: In a surprise victory, the Republican ticket of businessman Donald Trump and Indiana Governor Mike Pence defeated the Democratic ticket of former First Lady, U.S. Senator of New York and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and U.S. Senator from Virginia Tim Kaine.

title: United States presidential election, 2016
text: Trump took office as the 45th President, and Pence as the 48th Vice President, on January 20, 2017.

title: United States presidential election, 2016
text: Concurrent with the presidential election, Senate, House, and many gubernatorial and state and local elections were also held on November 8.

title: 2044 election
text: The United States presidential election of 2044, scheduled for Tuesday, November 8, 2044, will be the 65th quadrennial U.S. presidential election.

title: 2044 election
text: Voters will select presidential electors who in turn will either elect a new president and vice president through the electoral college or re-elect the incumbents.

title: 2044 election
text: The series of presidential primary elections and caucuses are likely to be held during the first six months of 2044.

title: 2044 election
text: This nominating process is also an indirect election, where voters cast ballots selecting a slate of delegates to a political party's nominating convention, who then in turn elect their party's presidential nominee.

title: Sussex chicken
text: The Sussex chicken is a dual purpose breed of chicken that originated in England around the time of the Roman conquest of Britain in AD 43 that is a popular garden chicken in many countries.

title: Sussex chicken
text: They come in eight colours (with a couple more being developed) and have a bantam version at 1/4 size; the bantams may be any of the eight colours.

title: Durotriges
text: The Durotriges were one of the Celtic tribes living in Britain prior to the Roman invasion.

title: Durotriges
text: The tribe lived in modern Dorset, south Wiltshire, south Somerset and Devon east of the River Axe and the discovery of an Iron Age hoard in 2009 at Shalfleet, Isle of Wight gives evidence that they lived in the western half of the island.

title: Durotriges
text: After the Roman conquest, their main "civitates", or settlement-centred administrative units, were Durnovaria (modern Dorchester, "the probable original capital") and Lindinis (modern Ilchester, "whose former, unknown status was thereby enhanced").

title: Durotriges
text: Their territory was bordered to the west by the Dumnonii; and to the east by the Belgae.

title: AD 43
text: AD 43 (XLIII) was a common year starting on Tuesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.

title: AD 43
text: At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Caesar and Vitellius (or, less frequently, year 796 "Ab urbe condita").

title: AD 43
text: The denomination AD 43 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

title: Roman conquest of Britain
text: The Roman conquest of Britain was a gradual process, beginning effectively in AD 43 under Emperor Claudius, whose general Aulus Plautius served as first governor of Roman Britain (Latin: "Britannia" ).

title: Roman conquest of Britain
text: Great Britain had already frequently been the target of invasions, planned and actual, by forces of the Roman Republic and Roman Empire.

title: Roman conquest of Britain
text: In common with other regions on the edge of the empire, Britain had enjoyed diplomatic and trading links with the Romans in the century since Julius Caesar's expeditions in 55 and 54 BC, and Roman economic and cultural influence was a significant part of the British late pre-Roman Iron Age, especially in the south.

title: Romano-British culture
text: Romano-British culture is the culture that arose in Britain under the Roman Empire following the Roman conquest in AD 43 and the creation of the province of Britannia.

title: Romano-British culture
text: It arose as a fusion of the imported Roman culture with that of the indigenous Britons, a people of Celtic language and custom.

title: Romano-British culture
text: It survived the 5th century Roman departure from Britain.

title: Romano-British culture
text: Scholars such as Christopher Snyder believe that during the 5th and 6th centuries – approximately from AD 410 when the Roman legions withdrew, to AD 597 when St Augustine of Canterbury arrived – southern Britain preserved an active sub-Roman culture that survived the attacks from the Anglo-Saxons and even used a vernacular Latin when writing.

title: History of Wales
text: The history of Wales begins with the arrival of human beings in the region thousands of years ago.

title: History of Wales
text: Neanderthals lived in what is now Wales, or "Cymru" in Welsh, at least 230,000 years ago, while "Homo sapiens" arrived by about 31,000 BC.

title: History of Wales
text: However, continuous habitation by modern humans dates from the period after the end of the last ice age around 9000 BC, and Wales has many remains from the Mesolithic, Neolithic, and Bronze Age.

title: History of Wales
text: During the Iron Age the region, like all of Britain south of the Firth of Forth, was dominated by the Celtic Britons and the Brittonic language.

title: History of Wales
text: The Romans, who began their conquest of Britain in AD 43, first campaigned in what is now northeast Wales in 48 against the Deceangli, and gained total control of the region with their defeat of the Ordovices in 79.

title: History of Wales
text: The Romans departed from Britain in the 5th century, opening the door for the Anglo-Saxon invasion.

title: History of Wales
text: Thereafter Brittonic language and culture began to splinter, and several distinct groups formed.

title: History of Wales
text: The Welsh people were the largest of these groups, and are generally discussed independently of the other surviving Brittonic-speaking peoples after the 11th century.

title: History of England
text: England became inhabited more than 800,000 years ago, as the discovery of flint tools and footprints at Happisburgh in Norfolk has revealed.

title: History of England
text: The earliest evidence for early modern humans in North West Europe, a jawbone discovered in Devon at Kents Cavern in 1927, was re-dated in 2011 to between 41,000 and 44,000 years old.

title: History of England
text: Continuous human habitation in England dates to around 13,000 years ago (see Creswellian), at the end of the last glacial period.

title: History of England
text: The region has numerous remains from the Mesolithic, Neolithic, and Bronze Age, such as Stonehenge and Avebury.

title: History of England
text: In the Iron Age, England, like all of Britain south of the Firth of Forth, was inhabited by the Celtic people known as the Britons, including some Belgic tribes (e.g. the Atrebates, the Catuvellauni, the Trinovantes, etc.) in the south east.

title: History of England
text: In AD 43 the Roman conquest of Britain began; the Romans maintained control of their province of Britannia until the early 5th century.

title: List of Roman hoards in Great Britain
text: The list of Roman hoards in Britain comprises significant archaeological hoards of coins, jewellery, precious and scrap metal objects and other valuable items discovered in Great Britain (England, Scotland and Wales) that are associated with period of Romano-British culture when Southern Britain was under the control of the Roman Empire, from AD 43 until about 410, as well as the subsequent Sub-Roman period up to the establishment of Anglo-Saxon kingdoms.

title: List of Roman hoards in Great Britain
text: It includes both hoards that were buried with the intention of retrieval at a later date (personal hoards, founder's hoards, merchant's hoards, and hoards of loot), and also hoards of votive offerings which were not intended to be recovered at a later date, but excludes grave goods and single items found in isolation.

title: Corieltauvi
text: The Corieltauvi (formerly thought to be called the Coritani, and sometimes referred to as the Corieltavi) were a tribe of people living in Britain prior to the Roman conquest, and thereafter a "civitas" of Roman Britain.

title: Corieltauvi
text: Their territory was in what is now the English East Midlands.

title: Corieltauvi
text: They were bordered by the Brigantes to the north, the Cornovii to the west, the Dobunni and Catuvellauni to the south, and the Iceni to the east.

title: Corieltauvi
text: Their capital was called "Ratae Corieltauvorum", known today as Leicester.

title: Catuvellauni
text: The Catuvellauni were a Celtic tribe or state of southeastern Britain before the Roman conquest, attested by inscriptions into the 4th century.

title: The Crooked Hinge
text: The Crooked Hinge is a mystery novel (1938) by detective novelist John Dickson Carr.

title: The Crooked Hinge
text: It combines a seemingly impossible throat-slashing with elements of witchcraft, an automaton modelled on Maelzel's Chess Player, and the story of the Tichborne Claimant.

title: The Crooked Hinge
text: It was dedicated to fellow author Dorothy Sayers "in friendship and esteem."

title: Penny Mickelbury
text: Penny Mickelbury (born 1948) is an African-American playwright and mystery novelist who worked as a print and television journalist for ten years before concentrating on fiction writing.

title: Penny Mickelbury
text: After leaving journalism, she taught fiction and script writing in Los Angeles and saw two of her plays (‘’Waiting for Gabriel’’ and ‘’Hush Now’’) produced there.

title: Penny Mickelbury
text: She began writing detective novels with "Keeping Secrets", published by Naiad Press in 1994, the first of a series featuring 'Gianna Maglione’, a lesbian chief of a hate-crimes unit based in Washington D.C. and her lover 'Mimi Patterson', a journalist.

title: Penny Mickelbury
text: Her second series features ‘Carol Ann Gibson’, a Washington D.C attorney who is widowed in the first book and subsequently runs an investigation agency with 'Jake Graham', the detective who investigated her husband’s death.

title: Penny Mickelbury
text: Her third features 'Phil Rodriguez', a Puerto Rican private investigator on the Lower Easter Side of New York City.

title: Lake District Mysteries
text: The Lake District Mysteries are a series of detective novels by British crime writer Martin Edwards.

title: Lake District Mysteries
text: The books feature Hannah Scarlett and the historian Daniel Kind, and are the first series of crime novels by a British detective novelist to be set in the Lake District, a region in North-West England.

title: He Who Whispers
text: He Who Whispers is a mystery novel (1946) by detective novelist John Dickson Carr.

title: He Who Whispers
text: Like Many of the works by this author feature so-called impossible crimes (for the most part, falling into the category of the locked room mystery).

title: He Who Whispers
text: In this case, the novel falls into a smaller category of Carr's work in that it is suggested that the crime is the work of a supernatural being (here, a vampire).

title: He Who Whispers
text: The detective is Dr. Gideon Fell, who ultimately uncovers a rational explanation for the novel's events.

title: He Who Whispers
text: Carr considered this one of his best impossible crime novels.

title: June Thomson
text: June Thomson (also known as June Valerie Thomson), (born 1930, in Rettendon, Essex, United Kingdom) is a detective novelist.

title: Andy Straka
text: Andy Straka is a Shamus Award-winning American crime novelist.

title: Andy Straka
text: Born and raised in upstate New York and a graduate of Williams College, he worked in publishing and medical sales for nearly fifteen years before turning to writing in the late 1990s.

title: Andy Straka
text: His debut private-eye novel, "A Witness Above", garnered Shamus, Anthony, and Agatha Award nominations for "Best First Novel" in 2002.

title: Andy Straka
text: "A Killing Sky" received an Anthony Award nomination in 2003, and Straka's third book, "Cold Quarry", won a 2004 Shamus Award.

title: Andy Straka
text: His series of six Frank Pavlicek novels features a former New York City police detective who also spends much of his time flying various hawks to help inspire him to solve criminal cases.

title: Andy Straka
text: The fourth novel in the Pavlicek series, "Kitty Hitter", was called a "great read" by Library Journal.

title: Andy Straka
text: "Kitty Hitter" was re-released with a new title, "The Night Falconer", as an e-book and paperback.

title: Andy Straka
text: A fifth book featuring Pavlicek is the novella "Flightfall".

title: Andy Straka
text: Another full-length novel, "The K Street Hunting Society", was released as book 6 in the Pavlicek series in 2014.

title: Rubislaw quarry
text: Rubislaw Quarry was opened in 1740 and is located at the Hill of Rubislaw in the west end of the Scottish city of Aberdeen.

title: Rubislaw quarry
text: In 1778/9, Aberdeen City Council sold it to a businessman for £13, as it was not thought to be a source of good building material.

title: Rubislaw quarry
text: However, over the next 200 years, an estimated six million tonnes of granite were excavated from the quarry, giving Aberdeen the name of 'The Granite City'.

title: Rubislaw quarry
text: Rubislaw Quarry is one of the biggest man-made holes in Europe.

title: Rupaye Dus Karod
text: Rupaye Dus Karod is a 1991 Indian Bollywood suspense thriller film directed by Sikander Bharti and produced by Waman K. Dehsmukh and written by Shabdh Kumar.

title: Rupaye Dus Karod
text: The film was made in the style of formula-based potboilers and was a hit.

title: Rupaye Dus Karod
text: It stars Rajesh Khanna in the lead role and supporting cast includes Chunky Pandey, Amrita Singh, Sonu Walia, Avinash Wadhavan, Deepika Chikhalia, Sadashiv Amrapurkar, Kiran Kumar in pivotal roles.

title: Rupaye Dus Karod
text: Rupaye Dus Karod (ten crores of rupees) is the story of a detective novelist (writing in Hindi) - Ravi Varma (Rajesh Khanna) whose father had to flee from India in his childhood itself because of a conspiracy masterminded by his wicked business partners and later Ravi finds himself in mystery murder and another plot to have tried to earn 10 crore by fraudulent means .

title: Sue Grafton
text: Sue Taylor Grafton (born April 24, 1940) is a contemporary American author of detective novels.

title: Sue Grafton
text: She is best known as the author of the 'alphabet series' (""A" Is for Alibi", etc.) featuring private investigator Kinsey Millhone in the fictional city of Santa Teresa, California.

title: Sue Grafton
text: The daughter of detective novelist C. W. Grafton, she has said the strongest influence on her crime novels is author Ross Macdonald.

title: Sue Grafton
text: Prior to success with this series, she wrote screenplays for television movies.

title: C. Hugh Holman
text: C. Hugh Holman (February 24, 1914 - October 14, 1981) was an American literary scholar, academic administrator and detective novelist.

title: C. Hugh Holman
text: He was a Professor of English at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill and its Provost from 1966 to 1968.

title: C. Hugh Holman
text: He was the vice president of the National Humanities Center.

title: C. Hugh Holman
text: He was the author of many books about Southern literature, and the founding co-editor of the "Southern Literary Journal".

title: C. Hugh Holman
text: He was the recipient of several awards.

title: Steven Bradford
text: Steven Bradford (born January 12, 1960) is an American politician currently serving in the California State Senate.

title: Steven Bradford
text: He is a Democrat representing the 35th district, encompassing parts of Los Angeles County.

title: Steven Bradford
text: Prior to his election to the state senate, he was an assemblymember for the 62nd district of the California State Assembly.

title: Steven Bradford
text: Bradford was elected to represent the 51st district in a special election held on September 1, 2009, after Curren Price resigned his seat to take a seat in the California State Senate.

title: Steven Bradford
text: He was re-elected in 2010 and, with 72% of the vote, was elected once more to represent the brand new 62nd District, comprising the communities of Del Aire, Del Rey, El Segundo, Gardena, Hawthorne, Inglewood, Lawndale, Lennox, Marina del Rey, West Athens, Westchester, Westmont and Venice Beach.

title: John Alario
text: John A. Alario, Jr. (born September 15, 1943), is the current President of the Louisiana State Senate.

title: John Alario
text: He has served in the Louisiana State Legislature since 1972.

title: John Alario
text: He was a member of the Louisiana House of Representatives from 1972 to 2008.

title: John Alario
text: Alario was Speaker of the House twice.

title: John Alario
text: In 2007, he was elected to the Louisiana State Senate.

title: John Alario
text: He is currently serving his third term as a senator and his second term as the President of the State Senate.

title: John Alario
text: He is the second person in Louisiana and fourth in United States history to have been elected as both Speaker of his state House of Representatives and President of his state Senate.

title: New York's 2nd State Senate district
text: New York's 2nd State Senate district is one of 62 districts of the New York State Senate.

title: New York's 2nd State Senate district
text: It is currently represented by John J. Flanagan (R).

title: New York's 2nd State Senate district
text: Senator Flanagan is New York State Senate's majority leader and temporary president.

title: Nesting (voting districts)
text: "Nesting" is the delimitation of voting districts for one elected body in order to define the voting districts for another body.

title: Nesting (voting districts)
text: For example, in California, the State Assembly (the lower house) is composed of 80 members, each one representing 1/80th of California's population, and the State Senate (the upper house) is composed of 40 members, each one representing 1/40th of California's population.

title: Nesting (voting districts)
text: In this case, the process of nesting could either be first defining the 80 Assembly districts, and then defining the Senate districts as a merge of two Assembly districts, or first defining the 40 Senate districts, and then creating the Assembly districts by splitting each Senate district into two.

title: Nesting (voting districts)
text: If the Assembly districts and the Senate districts are created independently of each other, then the process of nesting is not used.

title: California State Senate
text: The California State Senate is the upper house of the California State Legislature.

title: California State Senate
text: Due to the state's large population and relatively small legislature, the State Senate has the largest population per representative ratio of any state legislative house.

title: California State Senate
text: In the United States House of Representatives, California is apportioned 53 representatives, each representing approximately 704,566 people, while in the State Senate, each of the 40 Senators represents approximately 931,349 people, with the result that California state senators each actually represent more voters than California's representatives to the United States Congress do.

title: California State Senate
text: Each member roughly represents a population equivalent to the state of Delaware.

title: California State Senate
text: As a result of Proposition 140 in 1990 and Proposition 28 in 2012, members elected to the legislature prior to 2012 are restricted by term limits to two four-year terms (eight years), while those elected in or after 2012 are allowed to serve 12 years in the legislature in any combination of four-year state senate or two-year state assembly terms.

title: New York's 4th State Senate district
text: New York's 4th State Senate district is one of 62 districts of the New York State Senate.

title: New York's 4th State Senate district
text: It is currently represented by Philip M. Boyle (R).

title: New York's 1st State Senate district
text: New York's 1st State Senate district is one of 62 districts of the New York State Senate.

title: New York's 1st State Senate district
text: It is currently represented by Senator Kenneth LaValle (R).

title: Hawaii Senate
text: The Hawaiʻi State Senate is the upper chamber of the Hawaii State Legislature.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: The senate consists of twenty-five members elected from an equal number of constituent districts across the islands.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: The senate is led by the President of the Senate, elected from the membership of the body, currently Ron Kouchi.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: The forerunner of the Hawaii State Senate during the government of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻ i was the House of Nobles originated in 1840.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: In 1894 the Constitution of the Republic of Hawaii renamed the upper house the present senate.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: Senators are elected to four-year terms and are not subject to term limits.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: Like most state legislatures in the United States, the Hawaii State Senate is a part-time body and senators often have active careers outside government.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: The lower chamber of the legislature is the Hawaiʻi House of Representatives.

title: Hawaii Senate
text: The membership of the Senate also elects additional officers to include the Senate Vice President, Senate Chief Clerk, Assistant Chief Clerk, Senate Sergeant at Arms and Assistant Sergeant at Arms.

title: Andrea Stewart-Cousins
text: Andrea Stewart-Cousins (Democrat, Independence and Working Families) is a New York State Senator and the first woman in New York State history to lead a conference in Albany.

title: Andrea Stewart-Cousins
text: The Yonkers resident represents the 35th State Senate district in New York which in its present configuration includes Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry, Elmsford, Greenburgh, Hastings-on-Hudson, Irvington, Tarrytown, Scarsdale and parts of Yonkers, White Plains, and New Rochelle.

title: Andrea Stewart-Cousins
text: Prior to being elected to the New York State Senate, she was a Westchester County Legislator.

title: Andrea Stewart-Cousins
text: She was elected to the New York State Senate in 2006.

title: Andrea Stewart-Cousins
text: In 2012, her colleagues chose her to be the first female legislative leader; she currently serves as Democratic Conference Leader.

title: New York's 3rd State Senate district
text: New York's 3rd State Senate district is one of 62 districts of the New York State Senate.

title: New York's 3rd State Senate district
text: It is currently represented by Thomas Croci (R).

title: Covington, Tennessee
text: Covington is a city in central Tipton County, Tennessee, United States.

title: Covington, Tennessee
text: Covington is the largest city and county seat of Tipton County.

title: Covington, Tennessee
text: The city is located in West Tennessee, 12 mi east of the Mississippi River.

title: Covington, Tennessee
text: The city's population was 9,038 at the time of the 2010 U.S. Census.

title: Covington, Tennessee
text: Located 42 mi northeast of Memphis, Covington is part of the Memphis, Tennessee Metropolitan Area.

title: Memphis Hustle
text: The Memphis Hustle are an American professional basketball team of the NBA G League announced to begin play for the 2017–18 season as an affiliate of the Memphis Grizzlies of the National Basketball Association (NBA).

title: Memphis Hustle
text: Based in the Memphis suburb of Southaven, Mississippi, the team will play their home games at the Landers Center.

title: Marion, Arkansas
text: Marion is a city in and the county seat of Crittenden County, Arkansas, United States.

title: Marion, Arkansas
text: The population was 12,345 at the 2010 census, a 38.7% increase since 2000.

title: Marion, Arkansas
text: The city is part of the Memphis metropolitan area.

title: Marion, Arkansas
text: It is the second largest city in Crittenden County, behind West Memphis.

title: Millington, Tennessee
text: Millington is a city in Shelby County, Tennessee, United States.

title: Millington, Tennessee
text: As of the 2010 census, it had a population of 10,176.

title: Millington, Tennessee
text: Millington is the home of the Memphis International Raceway.

title: Millington, Tennessee
text: It was granted the title "Flag City Tennessee" by the Tennessee State Legislature.

title: Millington, Tennessee
text: The Naval Support Activity Mid-South is located at the former Memphis Naval Air Station, which was changed functions from a training base to an administrative one in 1993.

title: Millington, Tennessee
text: There is also a general aviation airport that features the third longest runway in Tennessee.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: Ellenbrook is a northeastern suburb of Perth, Western Australia, about 21 km from Perth's Central business district (CBD), located within the City of Swan.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: Ellenbrook, and its neighbouring suburbs of The Vines and Aveley, are unusual for Perth in being a significant distance from neighbouring suburbs.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: Given this relative isolation and the distance from the CBD, Ellenbrook has been designed and developed as a self-sustainable community.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: At June 2015 the estimated urban population for Ellenbrook and surrounds was 41,681.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: At the time of the 2011 census there were 16,284 people living in the gazetted suburb.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: It is envisioned that Ellenbrook will eventually become a satellite city, with a population of 80,000, however a more modest population prediction of 30,000 has been set for c. 2012.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: In June 2010 Rita Saffioti MLA stated that the population of Ellenbrook and neighbouring areas now stood at "over 25,000".

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: Current City of Swan estimates forecast the population to increase to 37,150 by 2016 and 44,185 by 2021.

title: Ellenbrook, Western Australia
text: Population in the City of Swan's nearby Urban Growth Corridor (roughly east of Whiteman Park) is forecast to reach 14,668 in the same period.

title: West Memphis, Arkansas
text: West Memphis is the largest city in Crittenden County, Arkansas, United States.

title: West Memphis, Arkansas
text: The population was 26,245 at the 2010 census, ranking it as the state's 18th largest city, behind Bella Vista.

title: West Memphis, Arkansas
text: It is part of the Memphis metropolitan area, and is located directly across the Mississippi River from Memphis.

title: Memphis metropolitan area
text: The Memphis-Forrest City Combined Statistical Area, TN-MS-AR (CSA) is the commercial and cultural hub of The Mid-South or Ark-Miss-Tenn.

title: Memphis metropolitan area
text: The census defined combined statistical area covers ten counties in three states – Tennessee, Mississippi, and Arkansas.

title: Memphis metropolitan area
text: As of census 2010 the MSA had a population of 1,324,108 .

title: Memphis metropolitan area
text: The Forrest City Micropolitan area was added to the Memphis area in 2012 to form the Memphis-Forrest City Combined Statistical area and had a population of 1,369,548 according to census estimates.

title: Memphis metropolitan area
text: The greater Mid-South area as a whole has a population of 2.4 million according to 2013 census estimates.

title: Memphis metropolitan area
text: This area is covered by Memphis local news channels and includes the Missouri Bootheel, Northeast Arkansas, West Tennessee, and North Mississippi.

title: Lakeland, Tennessee
text: Lakeland is a city in Shelby County, Tennessee, and a suburb of Memphis.

title: Lakeland, Tennessee
text: The population was 12,430 at the 2010 census.

title: Olive Branch, Mississippi
text: Olive Branch is a city in DeSoto County, Mississippi, United States.

title: Olive Branch, Mississippi
text: The population was 33,484 at the 2010 census, up from 21,054 in 2000.

title: Olive Branch, Mississippi
text: Olive Branch is a suburb of Memphis, Tennessee, and is part of the Memphis Metropolitan Statistical Area, a region that consists of three counties in southwest Tennessee, five counties in northwest Mississippi, and two counties in eastern Arkansas.

title: Olive Branch, Mississippi
text: From 1990 to 2010 Olive Branch was the fastest growing city in the United States, with a growth rate of 838%.

title: Olive Branch, Mississippi
text: Along with other rapidly growing suburbs in DeSoto County, Olive Branch attributes most of its growth and development to the exodus of large numbers of middle-class families from central Memphis.

title: Southaven, Mississippi
text: Southaven is a city in DeSoto County, Mississippi, United States.

title: Southaven, Mississippi
text: It is a suburb of Memphis, Tennessee, and a principal city in the Memphis metropolitan area.

title: Southaven, Mississippi
text: The 2010 census reported a population of 48,982, making Southaven the third largest city in Mississippi.

title: Southaven, Mississippi
text: Southaven is traversed from north to south by the I-55/I-69 freeway.

title: Southaven, Mississippi
text: The city's name derives from the fact that Southaven is located south of Whitehaven, a neighborhood in Memphis.

title: Pasek and Paul
text: Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, known together as Pasek and Paul, are an American songwriting duo and composing team for musical theater, films, and television.

title: Pasek and Paul
text: Their works include "", "Dogfight", "Edges", "Dear Evan Hansen", and "James and the Giant Peach".

title: Pasek and Paul
text: Their original songs have been featured on NBC's "Smash", and in the film "La La Land", for which they won both the Golden Globe and Academy Award for Best Original Song for the song "City of Stars".

title: City of Stars
text: "City of Stars" is a song performed by Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone from the film "La La Land" (2016).

title: City of Stars
text: The music of the song was composed by Justin Hurwitz while the lyrics were provided by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul.

title: City of Stars
text: The song won numerous awards, including the award for Best Original Song at both the 74th Golden Globe Awards and 89th Academy Awards.

title: A Christmas Story: The Musical
text: A Christmas Story: The Musical is a musical version of the film "A Christmas Story".

title: A Christmas Story: The Musical
text: The musical has music and lyrics written by Pasek & Paul and the book by Joseph Robinette.

title: A Christmas Story: The Musical
text: The musical takes place in the 1940s in Indiana and focuses on a child named Ralphie, who wants a Red Ryder BB Gun for Christmas.

title: Another Day of Sun
text: "Another Day of Sun" is the opening number from the 2016 musical film "La La Land".

title: Another Day of Sun
text: The ensemble number portrays an ensemble of drivers in a Los Angeles traffic jam on a highway ramp singing and dancing about their aspirations to succeed in Hollywood.

title: Another Day of Sun
text: The song was filmed on location on a 130-foot-high express ramp of the Judge Harry Pregerson Interchange in three shots, edited with hidden cuts to give the illusion of a single six-minute take.

title: Another Day of Sun
text: The song was composed by Justin Hurwitz with lyrics by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, and choreography by Mandy Moore.

title: List of accolades received by La La Land
text: "La La Land" is a 2016 American romantic musical comedy-drama film written and directed by Damien Chazelle.

title: List of accolades received by La La Land
text: Starring Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, the film focuses on two young people struggling to make ends meet in Los Angeles, while pursuing their dreams as artists.

title: List of accolades received by La La Land
text: Justin Hurwitz composed the film's musical score, while Linus Sandgren was the cinematographer.

title: List of accolades received by La La Land
text: David and Sandy Reynolds-Wasco were responsible for the production design and Mary Zophres designed the costumes.

title: Audition (The Fools Who Dream)
text: "Audition (The Fools Who Dream)" is a song from the film "La La Land" (2016).

title: Audition (The Fools Who Dream)
text: The music of the song was composed by Justin Hurwitz while the lyrics were provided by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul.

title: Audition (The Fools Who Dream)
text: In the film, the song is performed by Emma Stone.

title: Audition (The Fools Who Dream)
text: It received a nomination for Best Original Song at the 89th Academy Awards.

title: David and Sandy Reynolds-Wasco
text: David Wasco and Sandy Reynolds-Wasco are an American husband and wife duo who are production designers and art directors.

title: David and Sandy Reynolds-Wasco
text: They are best known for their frequent collaborations with director Quentin Tarantino film's as a production designer such as "Reservoir Dogs" (1992), "Pulp Fiction" (1994), "" (2003), "" (2004), "Inglourious Basterds" (2009), and "La La Land" (2016) for which they received numerous awards and nominations, including the Art Directors Guild Award for Excellence in Production Design for a Contemporary Film, Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Art Direction, and won the Academy Award for Best Production Design at the 89th Academy Awards.

title: La La Land (soundtrack)
text: La La Land: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack is the soundtrack album to the 2016 film "La La Land".

title: La La Land (soundtrack)
text: The soundtrack album was released through Interscope Records on December 9, 2016.

title: La La Land (soundtrack)
text: The album has peaked at number 2 on the US "Billboard 200" and number 1 on the UK Albums Chart.

title: La La Land (Demi Lovato song)
text: "La La Land" is a song recorded by American singer Demi Lovato.

title: La La Land (Demi Lovato song)
text: It was written by Lovato, Joe Jonas, Nick Jonas and Kevin Jonas and produced by the Jonas Brothers alongside John Fields, for Lovato's debut studio album, "Don't Forget" (2008).

title: La La Land (Demi Lovato song)
text: It was released as the album's second single on April 10, 2009, through Hollywood Records.

title: La La Land (Demi Lovato song)
text: "La La Land" is one of six songs on the album co-written by the Jonas Brothers, who also contributed backing vocals and guitars to the track.

title: La La Land (Demi Lovato song)
text: Lovato said that she wrote the song about being yourself in Hollywood and not letting other people change who you are.

title: La La Land (Demi Lovato song)
text: Musically, the song is a guitar-driven pop rock song and the lyrics speak of Lovato feeling "out of place" in Hollywood.

title: Mary Zophres
text: Mary Zophres is an American costume designer who has worked in the film industry since 1994.

title: Mary Zophres
text: She has been nominated for the Academy Award for Best Costume Design twice for "True Grit" (2010) and for "La La Land" (2016).

title: Mary Zophres
text: She has also been nominated for the BAFTA Award for Best Costume Design three times for "Catch Me If You Can" (2002), "True Grit", and "La La Land".

title: Bucketty
text: Bucketty is a locality in the City of Cessnock local government area (LGA), in New South Wales, Australia.

title: Bucketty
text: It is in the south of the LGA, immediately adjacent to the border with the City of Hawkesbury and Central Coast Council, in the Lower Hunter Region, about 105 km north of Sydney, and 55 km from Cessnock, New South Wales, the council seat.

title: Bucketty
text: Bucketty is presumably the Aboriginal word for "mountain spring".

title: Hunter Institute of TAFE
text: Hunter TAFE, formerly known as the Hunter Institute of Technology, is part of the TAFE NSW network.

title: Hunter Institute of TAFE
text: The Institute has 15 campuses and is Australia's largest regional provider of vocational education and training spanning the Hunter and Central Coast regions of New South Wales.

title: Hunter Institute of TAFE
text: It enrols approximately 60,000 students annually.

title: Hunter Institute of TAFE
text: Newcastle, 160 km north of Sydney, is the major city of the Hunter Region where five of the fifteen campuses are located.

title: Hunter Institute of TAFE
text: It is the second largest city in New South Wales, Australia.

title: Hunter Institute of TAFE
text: The Hunter region is Australia's largest regional economy, due to the rapid mining and agricultural expansion.

title: Gillieston Heights
text: Gillieston Heights is a suburb of the City of Maitland local government area in the Hunter Region of New South Wales, Australia, approximately 5.1 km from the Maitland CBD.

title: Gillieston Heights
text: Prior to 1967, the village was named East Greta however this was changed to honour former Maitland mayor and member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly John Gillies following a poll of residents.

title: Gillieston Heights
text: At the 2011 census, Gillieston Heights had a population of 1,372.

title: Niagara Park, New South Wales
text: Niagara Park is a suburb of the Central Coast region of New South Wales, Australia 6 km north of Gosford's central business district.

title: Niagara Park, New South Wales
text: It is part of the Central Coast Council local government area.

title: Niagara Park, New South Wales
text: It consists of residential housing as well as acreage blocks and small farms with many houses backing onto natural bushland and reserves.

title: Niagara Park, New South Wales
text: It is close to the M1 and is 20 minutes from Shelly Beach.

title: Niagara Park, New South Wales
text: A peaceful community with rural aspects and a large technology driven primary school, Niagara Park is ideal for families with young children.

title: Shelly Beach (Manly)
text: Shelly Beach (also known as Shelley Beach ) is a beach located in Manly, a suburb of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia.

title: Shelly Beach (Manly)
text: It is adjacent to North Head and Fairy Bower.

title: Shelly Beach (Manly)
text: Shelly Beach is a western facing beach on the eastern coast of Australia.

title: Mount View, New South Wales
text: Mount View, New South Wales is a rural locality located in the Hunter Region wine region in New South Wales Australia.

title: Mount View, New South Wales
text: It is located Between Cessnock and Wollombi and is a part of the City of Cessnock local government area.

title: Mount View, New South Wales
text: It has ideal climate, soil, and temperature for viticultural pursuits, which have been practiced here since the mid-19th century.

title: Mount View, New South Wales
text: The road from Cessnock to Mount View provides access to the Great North Walk, and to lookouts with excellent views of the Hunter Region.

title: Grahamstown Dam
text: Grahamstown Dam is a major off-stream earthfill Embankment dam with a controlled labyrinth spillway and baffle chute that stores water from the Williams River.

title: Grahamstown Dam
text: The dam is located north of Newcastle and within the Port Stephens Council local government area in the Lower Hunter Region of New South Wales, Australia.

title: Grahamstown Dam
text: The dam's main purpose is water supply; it provides about 40 per cent of the potable water for the Hunter region; and is the Hunter's largest drinking water supply dam.

title: Yanco Agricultural High School
text: Yanco Agricultural High School is a co-educational agricultural secondary school located in Yanco in the local government area of Leeton in south western New South Wales.

title: Yanco Agricultural High School
text: The school is one of four agricultural high schools in New South Wales which include Farrer Memorial Agricultural High School in Tamworth in northern New South Wales, James Ruse Agricultural High School in western Sydney and Hurlstone Agricultural High School in south-western Sydney.

title: Yanco Agricultural High School
text: The school was officially opened in March 1922 and is the only residential boarding school in New South Wales to have no day students.

title: Yanco Agricultural High School
text: The school serves the south of New South Wales and Victoria with the other schools serving the other regions of the state.

title: Yanco Agricultural High School
text: Yanco Agricultural High School is located approximately 10 kilometres from the Leeton CBD along Euroley Road.

title: Unincorporated Far West Region
text: The Unincorporated Far West Region is an unincorporated area in the Far West region of New South Wales, Australia.

title: Unincorporated Far West Region
text: The area is one of only two areas in New South Wales that are not part of any local government area (the other is Lord Howe Island).

title: Unincorporated Far West Region
text: The region includes several small towns including Tibooburra, Milparinka and Silverton.

title: Unincorporated Far West Region
text: Silverton and Tibooburra have village councils.

title: Unincorporated Far West Region
text: The region surrounds Broken Hill, but does not include it, which is in the separate City of Broken Hill local government area.

title: Shelly Beach, New South Wales
text: Shelly Beach is a coastal suburb of the Central Coast region of New South Wales, Australia, located east of Tuggerah Lake and bordering the Pacific Ocean south of The Entrance.

title: Shelly Beach, New South Wales
text: It is part of the Central Coast Council local government area.

title: Shelly Beach, New South Wales
text: It is 66 km south of Newcastle & 93 km north of Sydney.

title: Shelly Beach, New South Wales
text: Shelly Beach is considered one of the most popular surfing beaches on the Central Coast.

title: Bamboo Mañalac
text: Francisco Gaudencio Lope Belardo Mañalac (born March 21, 1976), popularly known as Bamboo Mañalac or simply by the mononym Bamboo, is a Filipino American musician and singer-songwriter.

title: Bamboo Mañalac
text: He began his career as vocalist and original frontman of Rivermaya and later fronted his own band, Bamboo.

title: Bamboo Mañalac
text: Bamboo band disbanded in 2011 and Mañalac then pursued a solo career and released his first solo album, "No Water, No Moon".

title: The Voice of the Philippines
text: The Voice of the Philippines is a Filipino reality television singing competition on ABS-CBN.

title: The Voice of the Philippines
text: It is based on the reality singing competition "The Voice of Holland", which was originally created by Dutch television producer John de Mol as part of "The Voice" franchise.

title: The Voice of the Philippines
text: Toni Gonzaga has been hosting the show since the first season; on the other hand, Luis Manzano, who had crossovered from "The Voice Kids", had hosted the show since the second season.

title: The Voice of the Philippines
text: Both are accompanied by Robi Domingo and Alex Gonzaga who serves as the show's "V-Reporters" or the social media and backstage correspondents.

title: The Voice of the Philippines
text: Sarah Geronimo, Bamboo Mañalac, Lea Salonga, and apl.de.ap serve as the four coaches and the judging panel of the show.

title: No Water, No Moon
text: No Water, No Moon is the debut album by Bamboo Mañalac following his departure from his former band, Bamboo.

title: No Water, No Moon
text: Its lead single was "Questions".

title: Rivermaya
text: Rivermaya is a Filipino rock band.

title: Rivermaya
text: Formed in 1994, it is one of several bands who spearheaded the 1990s Philippine alternative rock explosion.

title: Rivermaya
text: Rivermaya is currently composed of original members Mark Escueta and Nathan Azarcon, together with Mike Elgar and Ryan Peralta.

title: Rivermaya
text: Former original members include Rico Blanco, who had been the original songwriter of the band and vocalist Bamboo Mañalac, who later formed the band Bamboo and later went on his solo career.

title: Rivermaya
text: Rivermaya is listed as the twentieth biggest-selling artists/act in the Philippines as of present.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: The Voice Kids is a Philippine reality singing television competition on ABS-CBN.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: It is based on the Dutch reality singing competition of the same name.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: The show aired on May 24, 2014.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: The original coaches of the show is composed of Lea Salonga, Bamboo Mañalac, and Sarah Geronimo.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: Geronimo did not return for the third season and was replaced by Sharon Cuneta.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: It is hosted by Luis Manzano, together with Alex Gonzaga for the first season and Robi Domingo and Yeng Constantino for the second season.

title: The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)
text: On the third season, Kim Chiu joins Manzano and Domingo on the hosting duties, replacing Constantino.

title: Bamboo (band)
text: Bamboo was a Filipino rock band formed in 2002 and had been active from 2004 until it disbanded in 2011.

title: Bamboo (band)
text: It consisted of Bamboo Mañalac, Ira Cruz, Nathan Azarcon and Vic Mercado.

title: Kakoy Legaspi
text: Victor "Kakoy" Legaspi (sometimes spelled Kakoi Legaspi) is a critically acclaimed Filipino musician, best known for his stint as being part of the second evolution line-up of the band Rivermaya as a guitarist from 2001 until 2004.

title: Kakoy Legaspi
text: He also played for Barbie's Cradle, and Peryodiko as well and has played as a session guitarist for Bamboo Mañalac.

title: The Voice Teens (Philippines season 1)
text: The first season of "The Voice Teens" is a Philippine reality singing competition on ABS-CBN which began airing on April 16, 2017.

title: The Voice Teens (Philippines season 1)
text: Lea Salonga, Bamboo Mañalac and Sharon Cuneta, who had appeared in the last season of "The Voice Kids" returned to the show as coaches; they will also be accompanied by Sarah Geronimo, who had returned to the franchise after a season hiatus.

title: The Voice Teens (Philippines season 1)
text: The show is hosted by Toni Gonzaga and Luis Manzano — the two previously teamed up in hosting the second season of "The Voice of the Philippines".

title: The Voice Teens (Philippine TV series)
text: The Voice Teens is a Philippine reality television singing competition for teenagers that airs on ABS-CBN.

title: The Voice Teens (Philippine TV series)
text: It is based on the Dutch reality singing competition "The Voice Kids".

title: The Voice Teens (Philippine TV series)
text: The coaches and judges of the Philippine show are Lea Salonga, Bamboo Mañalac, Sharon Cuneta and Sarah Geronimo.

title: As the Music Plays
text: As The Music Plays is the debut album released by Pinoy rock band Bamboo following the return of Bamboo Mañalac in the Philippine music scene after 5 years of hiatus in the United States.

title: As the Music Plays
text: Bamboo immediately gained fame for the track "Noypi" which captivated the hearts of the youth and sparked patriotism in the Philippines.

title: As the Music Plays
text: This album contains 10 tracks, with 3 in Tagalog, namely: "Noypi", "Hudas", and "Masaya".

title: Amistad Dam Port of Entry
text: The Amistad Dam Port of Entry is a port of entry into the United States from Mexico.

title: Amistad Dam Port of Entry
text: It was built when Amistad Dam was completed in 1969.

title: Amistad Dam Port of Entry
text: The Dam was a bi-national effort to establish flood control on the Rio Grande and provide sources of water.

title: Amistad Dam Port of Entry
text: Although US Department of Transportation statistics combine traffic counts with Del Rio Texas Port of Entry, approximately 65,000 vehicles crossed the dam into the US in 2005.

title: Karaboro languages
text: The Karaboro languages are spoken in Burkina Faso by approximately 65,000 people (SIL 1995/1991).

title: Karaboro languages
text: They belong to the Senufo subfamily, but are separated from other Senufo languages by a small band of unrelated languages.

title: Karaboro languages
text: Within Senufo they are thought to be most closely related to the Senari languages.

title: Remington Model 51
text: The Remington Model 51 is a small pocket pistol designed by John Pedersen and manufactured by Remington Arms in the early 20th century for the American civilian market.

title: Remington Model 51
text: Remington manufactured approximately 65,000 Model 51 pistols in .32 ACP and .380 ACP calibers from 1918 to 1927, though small numbers were assembled into the mid-1930s.

title: Darayim District
text: Darayim is a district in Badakhshan Province, Afghanistan.

title: Darayim District
text: It was created in 2005 from part of Fayzabad District and is home to approximately 65,000 residents.

title: Albertina
text: The Albertina is a museum in the Innere Stadt (First District) of Vienna, Austria.

title: Albertina
text: It houses one of the largest and most important print rooms in the world with approximately 65,000 drawings and approximately 1 million old master prints, as well as more modern graphic works, photographs and architectural drawings.

title: Albertina
text: Apart from the graphics collection the museum has recently acquired on permanent loan two significant collections of Impressionist and early 20th-century art, some of which will be on permanent display.

title: Albertina
text: The museum also houses temporary exhibitions.

title: Marovoay
text: Marovoay ] is a city and commune (commune urbaine, Malagasy: "kaominina" ) in north-western Madagascar.

title: Marovoay
text: It belongs to the district of Marovoay, which is a part of Boeny Region.

title: Marovoay
text: The population of the commune was estimated to be approximately 65,000 in 2001 commune census.

title: Hanna Varis
text: Hanna Leena Kristiina Varis (b. 1959 in Kuusankoski) is a Finnish graphic artist and painter.

title: Hanna Varis
text: She earned a Master of Arts degree from the Aalto University School of Arts, Design and Architecture in 1990.

title: Hanna Varis
text: She participated in the NUROPE, Nomadic University for Art, Philosophy and Enterprise in Europe, in 2006-2010.

title: Hanna Varis
text: She has held over 70 solo exhibitions and participated at over 140 group exhibitions.

title: Hanna Varis
text: Her works are part of major art collections in Finland and abroad, such as the Kiasma, Amos Anderson Art Museum, and Helsinki Art Museum in Helsinki, Wäinö Aaltonen Museum of Art in Turku, and Albertina Museum in Vienna.

title: Gwangjang Market
text: Gwangjang Market, previously Dongdaemun Market, is a traditional street market in Jongno-gu, Seoul, South Korea.

title: Gwangjang Market
text: The market is one of the oldest and largest traditional markets in South Korea, with more than 5000 shops and 20,000 employees in an area of 42000 m2 .

title: Gwangjang Market
text: Approximately 65,000 people visit the market each day.

title: United Negro College Fund
text: The United Negro College Fund, also known as UNCF or the United Fund, is an American philanthropic organization that funds scholarships for black students and general scholarship funds for 37 private historically black colleges and universities.

title: United Negro College Fund
text: UNCF was incorporated on April 25, 1944 by Frederick D. Patterson (then president of what is now Tuskegee University), Mary McLeod Bethune, and others.

title: United Negro College Fund
text: UNCF is headquartered at 1805 7th Street, NW in Washington, D.C.

title: United Negro College Fund
text: In 2005, UNCF supported approximately 65,000 students at over 900 colleges and universities with approximately $113 million in grants and scholarships.

title: United Negro College Fund
text: About 60% of these students are the first in their families to attend college, and 62% have annual family incomes of less than $25,000.

title: United Negro College Fund
text: UNCF also administers over 450 named scholarships.

title: Pakistan Air Force
text: The Pakistan Air Force (PAF) (Urdu: ‎ —"Pāk Fizāʾiyah" , , reporting name: PAF) is the aerial warfare branch of the Pakistan Armed Forces, tasked primarily with the aerial defence of Pakistan, with a secondary role of providing air support to the Pakistan Army and the Pakistan Navy.

title: Pakistan Air Force
text: The PAF also has a tertiary role of providing strategic air transport and logistics capability to Pakistan.

title: Pakistan Air Force
text: The PAF employs approximately 65,000 full-time personnel (including approximately 3,000 pilots) and currently operates 883 aircraft.

title: Leda (river)
text: The Leda is a river in north-western Germany in the state of Lower Saxony.

title: Leda (river)
text: It is a right tributary of the Ems and originates at the confluence of the Sagter Ems and the Soeste (Dreyschloot) near the town of Barßel.

title: Leda (river)
text: The Leda flows into the Ems near the town of Leer.

title: Leda (river)
text: On the southern bank of the Leda, in the "Overledingen Land" (Overledingen="country over the Leda"), opposite Leer, lies the small settlement of Kloster Muhde ("Muhde" from the Old Frisian "mutha" meaning "(river) mouth").

title: Leda (river)
text: The total length of the river is 29 km , of which the lower 1.9 km are navigable for sea-going vessels.

title: Proto-Norse language
text: Proto-Norse (also called Proto-Scandinavian, Primitive Norse, Proto-Nordic, Ancient Nordic, Ancient Scandinavian, Old Nordic, Old Scandinavian, Proto-North Germanic, North Proto-Germanic or Common Scandinavian) was an Indo-European language spoken in Scandinavia that is thought to have evolved as a northern dialect of Proto-Germanic in the first centuries CE.

title: Proto-Norse language
text: It is the earliest stage of a characteristically North Germanic language, and the language attested in the oldest Scandinavian Elder Futhark inscriptions, spoken around from the 2nd to 8th centuries (corresponding to the late Roman Iron Age and the Germanic Iron Age).

title: Proto-Norse language
text: It evolved into the dialects of Old Norse at the beginning of the Viking Age in about 800, which later themselves evolved into modern North Germanic languages.

title: Suorva
text: Suorva or Suorvadammen (the Suorva Dam) is a small settlement situated at the southern parts of Akkajaure, in Stora Sjöfallet National Park, Sweden.

title: Suorva
text: The settlement can be reached by car (and bus, from Gällivare).

title: Suorva
text: It consists of a few houses and a dam operated by Vattenfall, which regulates the flow to the hydroelectric plant in Vietas located about 5 kilometers downstream.

title: Suorva
text: The road over the dam is normally open for hikers (not cars) and makes for a possible route into the northern parts of Sarek National Park which does not require using a boat.

title: Frankish language
text: Frankish (reconstructed Frankish: "*Frenkisk"), Old Franconian or Old Frankish was the West Germanic language spoken by the Franks between the 4th and 8th century.

title: Frankish language
text: The language itself is poorly attested, but it gave rise to numerous loanwords in Old French.

title: Frankish language
text: Old Dutch is the term for the Old Franconian dialects spoken in the Low Countries, ie.

title: Frankish language
text: in present-day Belgium, in the present Netherlands and Western parts of today's Germany until about the 12th century when it evolved into Middle Dutch.

title: Old Saxon
text: Old Saxon, also known as Old Low German, was a Germanic language and the earliest recorded form of Low German (spoken nowadays in Northern Germany, the northeastern Netherlands, southern Denmark, the Americas and parts of Eastern Europe).

title: Old Saxon
text: It is a West Germanic language, closely related to the Anglo-Frisian languages.

title: Old Saxon
text: It has been documented from the 8th century until the 12th century, when it gradually evolved into Middle Low German.

title: Old Saxon
text: It was spoken throughout modern northwestern Germany, primarily in the coastal regions and in the eastern Netherlands by Saxons, a Germanic tribe who inhabited the region of Saxony.

title: Old Saxon
text: It partially shares Anglo-Frisian's (Old Frisian, Old English) Ingvaeonic nasal spirant law which sets it apart from Low Franconian and Irminonic languages, such as Dutch, Luxembourgish and German.

title: Afrikaans
text: Afrikaans ( ) is a West Germanic language spoken in South Africa, Namibia and, to a lesser extent, Botswana and Zimbabwe.

title: Afrikaans
text: It evolved from the Dutch vernacular of South Holland (Hollandic dialect) spoken by the mainly Dutch settlers of what is now South Africa, where it gradually began to develop distinguishing characteristics in the course of the 18th century.

title: Afrikaans
text: Hence, it is a daughter language of Dutch, and was previously referred to as "Cape Dutch" (a term also used to refer collectively to the early Cape settlers) or "kitchen Dutch" (a derogatory term used to refer to Afrikaans in its earlier days).

title: Afrikaans
text: However, it is also variously described as a creole or as a partially creolised language.

title: Afrikaans
text: The term is ultimately derived from Dutch "Afrikaans-Hollands " meaning "African Dutch".

title: Afrikaans
text: It is the first language of most of the Afrikaners and Coloureds of Southern Africa.

title: Leer
text: Leer is a town in the district of Leer, the northwestern part of Lower Saxony, Germany.

title: Leer
text: It is situated on the river Leda, a tributary of the river Ems, near the border with the Netherlands.

title: Dutch language
text: Dutch ( ) is a West Germanic language that is spoken by around 24 million people as a first language—including the population of the Netherlands and about sixty percent that of Belgium—and by another 5 million as a second language.

title: Dutch language
text: It is the third most widely spoken Germanic language, after English and German.

title: English language
text: English is a West Germanic language that was first spoken in early medieval England and is now a global "lingua franca".

title: English language
text: Named after the Angles, one of the Germanic tribes that migrated to England, it ultimately derives its name from the Anglia (Angeln) peninsula in the Baltic Sea.

title: English language
text: It is closely related to the Frisian languages, but its vocabulary has been significantly influenced by other Germanic languages, particularly Norse (a North Germanic language), as well as by Latin and Romance languages, particularly French.

title: German language
text: German ("Deutsch" ] ) is a West Germanic language that is mainly spoken in Central Europe.

title: German language
text: It is the most widely spoken and (co-) official language in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, South Tyrol (Italy), the German-speaking Community of Belgium, and Liechtenstein.

title: German language
text: It is also one of the three official languages of Luxembourg.

title: German language
text: The languages which are most similar to German are the other members of the West Germanic language branch: Afrikaans, Dutch, English, the Frisian languages, Low German/Low Saxon, Luxembourgish, and Yiddish.

title: German language
text: German is the second most widely spoken Germanic language, after English.

title: Chawalit Kamutchati
text: Chawalit Kamutchati (born 6 March 1937) is a Thai former sports shooter.

title: Chawalit Kamutchati
text: He competed in the 50 metre rifle, three positions event at the 1972 Summer Olympics.

title: William Bonfield
text: William Bonfield CBE, FREng, FRS (born 6 March 1937) is a British material scientist, and Emeritus Professor of Medical Materials in the University of Cambridge.

title: Paul Méfano
text: Paul Méfano (born 6 March 1937 in Basra, Iraq), is a French composer and conductor.

title: Norman Coburn
text: Norman Coburn (born 6 March 1937 in Sydney) is a retired Australian actor of stage, television and film, notable for his roles primarily in TV soap operas, most especially in Home and Away for his long-standing Guinness World Record-listed role as Donald Fisher between 1988–2003, with sporadic returns in 2005 and 2007.

title: Valentina Tereshkova
text: Valentina Vladimirovna Tereshkova (Russian: Валенти́на Влади́мировна Терешко́ва ; ] ; born 6 March 1937) is a retired Russian cosmonaut, engineer, and politician.

title: Valentina Tereshkova
text: She is the first woman to have flown in space, having been selected from more than 400 applicants and five finalists to pilot Vostok 6 on 16 June 1963.

title: Valentina Tereshkova
text: She completed 48 orbits of the Earth in her three days in space.

title: Australian referendum, 1937
text: The 1937 Australian Referendum was held on 6 March 1937.

title: Australian referendum, 1937
text: It contained two referendum questions.

title: Arild Nyquist
text: Arild Nyquist (6 March 1937 – 21 December 2004) was a Norwegian novelist, poet, writer of children's books and musician.

title: Arild Nyquist
text: He was born in Oslo, the son of Gerd Nyquist.

title: Arild Nyquist
text: His father-in-law was Olav Mosebekk.

title: Arild Nyquist
text: He made his literary debut in 1963 with the novel "Ringer i et sommervann".

title: Vatroslav Rožić
text: Vatroslav Rožić (13 March 1857 – 6 March 1937) was a Croatian linguist and ethnographer.

title: Robin Bailie
text: Robin John Bailie (born 6 March 1937) is a Northern Irish solicitor and former politician.

title: Bob Clifford (footballer)
text: Bob Clifford (born 6 March 1937) is a former Australian rules footballer who played with Richmond in the Victorian Football League (VFL).

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: Lung Fu Shan Country Park (, established December18, 1998) is a country park located in the Central and Western District of Hong Kong.

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: It covers the densely vegetated slopes of "Lung Fu Shan", including the disused Pinewood Battery as well as the Pinewood Garden picnic area, providing a scenic backdrop to the residential and commercial districts of Hong Kong Island.

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: In proximity to residential areas in the Mid-levels and the Western District, Lung Fu Shan area is intensively used by the public, especially by morning walkers and picnickers.

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: It is situated at the north of Pok Fu Lam Country Park.

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: Towards the east of Lung Fu Shan Country Park is Hatton Road, to the south is Harlech Road whereas to the north and west is a covered conduit constructed by the Water Supplies Department.

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: This country park covers an area of about 47 hectares, making it the smallest country park in Hong Kong (not including special areas).

title: Lung Fu Shan Country Park
text: It is also the newest country park, according to the establishment date.

title: Hatton Castle, Angus
text: Hatton Castle stands on the lower part of Hatton Hill, the most easterly of the Sidlaw Hills, to the south of Newtyle in Angus, Scotland.

title: Hatton Castle, Angus
text: The castle overlooks the wooded Den of Newtyle, and its views extend across Strathmore and include Ben Lawers and Schiehallion as well as the Angus and Glenshee hills.

title: Hatton Castle, Angus
text: The 16th-century castle was originally built in a typical Scottish "Z plan" tower house design, as a fortified country house or "château".

title: Hatton Castle, Angus
text: There was an earlier castle called Balcraig Castle which stood less than half a mile from the present building, also on Hatton Hill.

title: Hatton Castle, Aberdeenshire
text: Hatton Castle is almost 3 miles south-east of Turriff, Aberdeenshire in the north-east of Scotland.

title: Hatton Castle, Aberdeenshire
text: Formerly known as Balquholly Castle, sometimes spelt as "Balquollie", it was renamed in 1814.

title: Hatton Castle, Aberdeenshire
text: The 17994 sqft mansion was designated a category A listed building in 1972; the gardens are included in the Inventory of Gardens and Designed Landscapes in Scotland.

title: Angus cattle
text: Angus cattle are naturally polled and solid black or red even though the udder may be white.

title: Angus cattle
text: The native colour is black, but more recently red colours have emerged.

title: Angus cattle
text: The UK registers both in the same herd book, but in the US they are regarded as two separate breeds – Red Angus and Black Angus.

title: Angus cattle
text: Black Angus is the most common breed of beef cattle in the US, with 324,266 animals registered in 2005.

title: Angus cattle
text: In 2014, the British Cattle Movement Service named Angus the UK's most popular native beef breed, and the second most popular beef breed overall.

title: Hatton Hill
text: Hatton Hill is a mountain landform in Angus, Scotland and is the most easterly peak of the Sidlaw Hills.

title: Hatton Hill
text: Hatton Castle stands on the flanks of Hatton Hill above the village of Newtyle.

title: Hutton Castle
text: Hutton Castle is located in the Scottish Borders, overlooking the Whiteadder Water.

title: Hutton Castle
text: It stands 2.5 km southeast of Chirnside and 11 km west of Berwick-on-Tweed.

title: Hutton Castle
text: It has also been known as Hatton Hall and Hutton Hall.

title: Hatton, Warwickshire
text: Hatton (grid reference  ) is a village and civil parish about 4 mi north of Warwick, in the Warwick District of Warwickshire in England.

title: Hatton, Warwickshire
text: It had a population of 1,078 at the 2001 Census, increasing to 2,319 at the 2011 Census.

title: Hatton, Warwickshire
text: Notable features include a remarkable series of 21 locks on the Grand Union Canal, a shopping village (Hatton Country World) and a former psychiatric hospital (Central Hospital, Hatton) that has been turned into a large housing estate while still preserving the original Victorian buildings.

title: Hatton, Warwickshire
text: The public house, Hatton Arms, was historically noted for its regular large assemblies of motorcycles.

title: Hatton, Warwickshire
text: Other public houses in the area include the Falcon Inn, although less well known as it is situated further away from the village centre.

title: Auchterhouse Castle
text: Auchterhouse Castle is a c. 13th century castle located northwest of Dundee, Angus, Scotland.

title: Auchterhouse Castle
text: The original castle was enclosed with walls, towers, and contained a keep.

title: Auchterhouse Castle
text: The castle may have been in ownership of the Ramsay family, who were hereditary Sheriffs of Angus.

title: Auchterhouse Castle
text: Sir William Wallace is alleged to have stayed at the castle and one its towers was named in his honour.

title: Auchterhouse Castle
text: King Edward I of England spent the night of the 20 July 1303 at the castle.

title: Auchterhouse Castle
text: The castle came into the possession of James Erskine, 7th Earl of Buchan who may have built the 17th century tower house.

title: Hatton baronets
text: The Hatton Baronetcy, of Long Stanton in the County of Cambridge, was a title in the Baronetage of England.

title: Hatton baronets
text: It was created on 5 July 1641 for Thomas Hatton, Member of Parliament for Corfe Castle, Malmesbury and Stamford.

title: Hatton baronets
text: The title became extinct on the death of the tenth Baronet in 1812.

title: Broughty Castle
text: Broughty Castle is a historic castle on the banks of the river Tay in Broughty Ferry, Dundee, Scotland.

title: Broughty Castle
text: It was completed around 1495, although the site was earlier fortified in 1454 when George Douglas, 4th Earl of Angus received permission to build on the site.

title: Broughty Castle
text: His son Archibald Douglas, 5th Earl of Angus was coerced into ceding the castle to the crown.

title: Broughty Castle
text: The main tower house forming the centre of the castle with four floors was built by Andrew, 2nd Lord Gray who was granted the castle in 1490.

title: Nerdist Industries
text: Nerdist Industries, LLC is part of the digital division of Legendary Entertainment.

title: Nerdist Industries
text: Nerdist Industries was founded as a sole podcast (The Nerdist Podcast) created by Chris Hardwick but later spread to include a network of podcasts, a premium content YouTube channel, a news division (Nerdist News), and a television version of the original podcast produced by and aired on BBC America.

title: Course of the Force
text: Course of the Force, founded in 2012, is a partnership between Lucasfilm, Nerdist Industries, Machinima and Octagon (Sports Agency).

title: Course of the Force
text: The partnership's primary event is an Olympic-style lightsaber relay along the California coast.

title: Chloe Dykstra
text: Chloe Frances Dykstra (born September 15, 1988) is an American actress, cosplayer, and model.

title: Chloe Dykstra
text: She produces and co-hosts a web series "Just Cos" for the Nerdist Industries' YouTube channel and is a cast member of the SyFy show" Heroes of Cosplay".

title: Chloe Dykstra
text: She is also a freelance game journalist for a number of websites.

title: Chloe Dykstra
text: She was featured in a "Daily Dot" article for her parody photo essay of Me In My Place pin-up blog photos.

title: Chloe Dykstra
text: Dykstra was born in Los Angeles, California, and is the daughter of John Dykstra.

title: Nerdist News
text: Nerdist News is a Nerdist-branded pop culture newsletter launched in February 2012.

title: Nerdist News
text: It was founded and operated by Nerdist Industries' CEO, Peter Levin, and its CCO, Chris Hardwick.

title: Nerdist News
text: It is hosted by Jessica Chobot.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Siddharth N. "Bobby" Mehta was former CEO and vice chairman of HSBC North America.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta served as an Advisor of TransUnion since December 31, 2012.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta serves as consultant of TransUnion.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served the chief executive officer and president of TransUnion from August 2007 to December 31, 2012, and Transunion Financing Corp. until December 31, 2012.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: From May 2007 to July 2007, he served as a consultant to the board of directors at TransUnion.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as the chief executive officer and president of TransUnion until December 31, 2012.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as the chief executive officer of TransUnion LLC.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of HSBC Finance Corporation from April 2005 to February 2007.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as chief executive officer and president of TransUnion LLC from 2007 to 2012.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: From 1998 to 2007, he held a variety of positions with HSBC Finance Corporation and HSBC North America Holdings, Inc.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta served as chief executive officer of HSBC North America until February 2007.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta served as consultant of TransUnion since May 2007 until July 2007.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta served as group managing director of HSBC Holdings PLC of HSBC Finance Corp. since April 30, 2005, and its unit chief executive officer since March 2005.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as the chief executive of HS BC North America Holdings Inc., of HSBC Finance Corp., from March 2005 to February 15, 2007.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as an executive chairman of HSBC Financial Corporation Limited since April 2005 and served as its chief executive officer from April 2005 to February 15, 2007.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as the chief executive officer of HSBC Bank USA, N.A. until February 2007.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as the chief executive officer of HSBC North America Holdings Inc. since March 2005.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as chairman and chief executive officer of HSBC Financial Corp., Ltd.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He oversaw HSBC's global credit card services, its North American consumer lending and mortgage services businesses and its first mortgage operation.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He was also responsible for corporate marketing, strategic planning and corporate development for HSBC North America Holdings Inc. and had responsibility for the strategic management of credit cards throughout the HSBC Group.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta served as group executive of Credit Card Services, Auto Finance and Canada of Household International Inc., since July 2002.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He worked at MasterCard’s U.S. region board since March 2000.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta joined Household International Inc., in 1998.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as senior vice president of The Boston Consulting Group in Los Angeles and co-leader of Boston Consulting Group Financial Services Practice in the United States.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta served as a director of Global Board of MasterCard Incorporated since March 17, 2005.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as unit chairman of HSBC Holdings PLC and served as its board member since March 2005.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as vice chairman and director of HSBC Financial Corporation Limited., (Formerly Household International Inc.).

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He has been a director of Avant Credit Corporation since December 18, 2014.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He has been an independent director of The Allstate Corporation since February 19, 2014.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He serves as a member of the advisory board at Core2 Group, Inc.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He has been non-executive independent director at Piramal Enterprises Ltd since April 1, 2013.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He serves on the boards of Datacard, Chicago Public Education Fund, University of Chicago Laboratory Schools, The Economic Club of Chicago, The Field Museum and Myelin Repair Foundation.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He serves as a director of TransUnion Corp. and TransUnion LLC.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as a director of MasterCard International Inc. (also known as MasterCard Worldwide) (formerly, MasterCard Inc.), since March 17, 2005.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He served as a director of HSBC Financial Corp.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Ltd.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He has been a director of TransUnion since April 2012.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta serves on the board of international advisors for the Monterey, California, Institute of International Studies and is a member of the Financial Services Roundtable.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He also serves on the board of advisors for the Myelin Repair Foundation.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: Mehta holds a Bachelor of Arts in economics from the London School of Economics and Masters of Business Administration from the University of Chicago.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He stepped down as head of the North American unit after the lender raised its forecast for bad loans in the U.S.

title: Bobby Mehta
text: He is of Indian descent.

title: The Nerdist Podcast
text: The Nerdist Podcast is a weekly interview show "about what it really means to be a nerd" hosted by Chris Hardwick, usually accompanied by Jonah Ray and Matt Mira.

title: The Nerdist Podcast
text: The audio podcasts are typically an hour in length and include conversations with notable comedians or entertainers, sometimes at their own home.

title: The Nerdist Podcast
text: The show launched February 8, 2010.

title: The Nerdist Podcast
text: It serves as the flagship podcast for Nerdist Industries, which was founded in 2012 after the success of "The Nerdist Podcast".

title: The Nerdist Podcast
text: The show's theme song is "Jetpack Blues, Sunset Hues" by the chiptune band Anamanaguchi.

title: The Drop-In (podcast)
text: The Drop-In is an At Will Radio podcast hosted by Will Malnati.

title: The Drop-In (podcast)
