text: In the episode, assistant district attorney Miguel Prado (Jimmy Smits) asks Dexter Morgan (Michael C. Hall) for his assistance in killing a murderous gambler.

title: The Damage a Man Can Do
text: Meanwhile, Dexter's sister Ofr.

title: The Damage a Man Can Do
text: Debra Morgan (Jennifer Carpenter) finds her boyfriend and informant Anton Briggs (David Ramsey) to be missing after she tells him that he is no longer legally obligated to work for her.

title: Vince Masuka
text: Vincent "Vince" Masuka (Masuoka in the books) is a fictional character in the Showtime television series "Dexter" and the novels by Jeff Lindsay upon which the series is based.

title: Vince Masuka
text: On television he is portrayed by Korean-American C. S. Lee.

title: Vince Masuka
text: Masuka is the Miami Metro Police lead forensic science investigator; he works alongside Dexter Morgan in the lab and at crime scenes.

title: Vince Masuka
text: He often cracks tasteless and inappropriate jokes, when convenient invokes his Japanese heritage and harbors unrequited desire for Dexter's foster sister Debra.

title: Vince Masuka
text: Although goofy and obsessed with sex, he is clever and very good at his job, causing Dexter to worry from time to time that Masuka will uncover his secret.

title: Sage Kirkpatrick
text: Sage Kirkpatrick is an actress probably best known for playing Dexter Morgan's mother, Laura Moser, in the Showtime TV drama series, "Dexter".

title: Darkly Dreaming Dexter
text: Darkly Dreaming Dexter is a 2004 novel by Jeff Lindsay, the first in his series about serial killer Dexter Morgan.

title: Darkly Dreaming Dexter
text: It formed the basis of the Showtime television series "Dexter" and won the 2005 Dilys Award and the 2007 Book to TV award.

title: It's Alive! (Dexter)
text: "It's Alive!"

title: It's Alive! (Dexter)
text: is the second season premiere and thirteenth overall episode of the American television drama series "Dexter", which first aired on September 30, 2007 on Showtime in the United States.

title: It's Alive! (Dexter)
text: The episode was written by Daniel Cerone and was directed by Tony Goldwyn.

title: It's Alive! (Dexter)
text: In the episode, which takes place five weeks after the first-season finale, Sgt. James Doakes (Erik King) is following Dexter Morgan (Michael C. Hall) at all times, but when he gets his first opportunity Dexter finds himself unable to kill.

title: It's Alive! (Dexter)
text: Meanwhile, his sister Debra (Jennifer Carpenter) returns to work after her ex-fiancé Brian tried to kill her, and his girlfriend Rita Bennett (Julie Benz) refuses to believe that Dexter sent her ex-husband Paul (Mark Pellegrino) to prison in spite of the evidence in front of her.

title: Hello, Dexter Morgan
text: "Hello, Dexter Morgan" is the 11th and penultimate episode of the fourth season of Showtime TV series, Dexter, which aired on December 6, 2009.

title: Hello, Dexter Morgan
text: The police team attempt to get Christine Hill to talk while Dexter frames another man in order to get Arthur Mitchell, the Trinity Killer, all to himself.

title: Lance Krall
text: Lance Krall (born December 9, 1970 in Monterey, California) is an American comedian and actor, television writer, director, and producer of Vietnamese descent.

title: Lance Krall
text: He became well known after his portrayal as "Kip" in the role in faux-reality show "The Joe Schmo Show".

title: Lance Krall
text: He went on to create and star in "The Lance Krall Show" and "Free Radio."

title: Matt Kennedy Gould
text: Matt Kennedy Gould (born October 4, 1975) is an American former television personality.

title: Matt Kennedy Gould
text: He rose to prominence in 2003, when he was the protagonist of "The Joe Schmo Show", a fake reality show in which, unbeknownst to him, all the participants but Gould were actors portraying broad reality show participant archetypes.

title: List of The Joe Schmo Show episodes
text: "The Joe Schmo Show" is an American reality television hoax show created by Paul Wernick and Rhett Reese.

title: List of The Joe Schmo Show episodes
text: The series premiered in the United States on Spike on September 2, 2003.

title: List of The Joe Schmo Show episodes
text: The show's third season premiered on January 8, 2013.

title: Stone Stanley Entertainment
text: Stone Stanley Entertainment is an American film and television production company, founded in 1990 by David G. Stanley and Scott A. Stone as Stone Stanley Productions.

title: Stone Stanley Entertainment
text: Since then, Stone Stanley has produced several television programs, most notably "Shop 'til You Drop", "Loveline", "Legends of the Hidden Temple", "The Man Show", "The Mole", "Popstars", and "The Joe Schmo Show", plus six of the most successful Jane Fonda exercise videos, and the first Dimension Films theatrical motion picture release, "".

title: Rhett Reese
text: Rhett Reese is an American film producer, television producer and screenwriter.

title: Rhett Reese
text: As a screenwriter, his credits include "Clifford's Really Big Movie", "Cruel Intentions 3".

title: Rhett Reese
text: He has collaborated with Paul Wernick, writing the films "Zombieland", "", and "Deadpool".

title: Rhett Reese
text: Together they also created the reality series "The Joe Schmo Show".

title: Gretchen Palmer
text: Gretchen Palmer (born December 16, 1961) is an American television and film actress.

title: Gretchen Palmer
text: She has had recurring roles in television series such as "The Joe Schmo Show" and "The Parkers", and has appeared in films including "Fast Forward", "Crossroads", "The Malibu Bikini Shop", "Red Heat", "When Harry Met Sally...", "Chopper Chicks in Zombietown", "Moonbase", "Trois" (2000) and "I Got the Hook Up" (1998).

title: Gretchen Palmer
text: She also appeared on The Young and the Restless as Serena.

title: Robert Belushi
text: Robert James Belushi (born October 23, 1980) is an American actor.

title: Robert Belushi
text: In films, he is best known for his work on "Sorority Row", "One Small Hitch", and "Valentine's Day".

title: Robert Belushi
text: On television, he is best known as Allen ("The Buddy") on the of Spike TV's "The Joe Schmo Show" and Linus the Bartender on the ninth and final season of CBS's "How I Met Your Mother".

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: Free Radio is a television show, created by Lance Krall and Rory Rosegarten.

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: The show originated on VH1, but has also played on Comedy Central, and Super Channel (Canada).

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: It stars Lance Krall, prominent for his role on "The Joe Schmo Show", and Anna Vocino, who also starred with Krall on "The Lance Krall Show".

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: The show focuses on a dysfunctional radio station, KBOM.

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: Krall plays a moronic intern turned moronic DJ when KBOM's regular shock jock, Rip Rebel, defects to satellite radio.

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: Lance eventually gets his own show entitled "Moron in the Morning".

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: Real celebrities guest star as themselves with Lance, who often either does not realize who they are or mixes them up with other celebrities on the air.

title: Free Radio (TV series)
text: Most of the dialogue is improvised.

title: The Joe Schmo Show
text: The Joe Schmo Show is a reality television hoax show created by Paul Wernick and Rhett Reese.

title: The Joe Schmo Show
text: The series is broadcast in the U.S. on the cable network Spike.

title: The Joe Schmo Show
text: The show's premise is that a target person or persons are led to believe that they are contestants on a reality television show; in reality, all of the other participants in the purported show – including the host – are actors, and their actions and the outcome of the purported show are all scripted in an attempt to elicit comedic reactions from the targets.

title: The Joe Schmo Show
text: The show's first season, The Joe Schmo Show, aired in 2003, and its second season, Joe Schmo 2, aired in 2004.

title: The Joe Schmo Show
text: The first season's hoax was conducted as a typical reality competition show while the second hoax was a "Bachelor"-like dating series.

title: Ralph Garman
text: Ralph Garman (born November 17, 1964) is an American actor, comedian, and radio host best known as the host of "The Joe Schmo Show", for his voice work on the Fox animated series "Family Guy", and as the entertainment reporter and impressionist for the "Kevin and Bean" morning show on Los Angeles radio station KROQ-FM.

title: Take 21
text: Take 21, previously Toronto Student Film Festival or TSFF, is an annual event for youth to showcase their talent in a variety of short film genres.

title: Take 21
text: Take 21 has attracted film makers from several different countries.

title: Take 21
text: Prizes have focused on work experiences in the industry, scholarships to film making programmes, money, and film equipment.

title: Three are Three
text: Three are Three (Spanish: Tres eran tres) is a 1955 Spanish comedy film directed by Eduardo García Maroto.

title: Three are Three
text: In three separate segments it parodies different film genres.

title: The Importance of Being Icelandic
text: The Importance of Being Icelandic is a 1998 documentary film by the filmmaker Jon Gustafsson (born in Iceland and living in Canada) that traces the steps of three Icelandic Canadians on a different quest of discovering their Icelandic heritage by going to Iceland.

title: The Importance of Being Icelandic
text: In addition to their time in Iceland, he returns with them to Canada and captures their reactions of the Islendingadagurinn celebrated each year at Gimli.

title: The Importance of Being Icelandic
text: The contrasts in perspective between his viewpoint on Canadian culture and that of three Icelandic-Canadians on a quest for their ancestral heritage is at the centre of the documentary.

title: Jackie Lou Blanco
text: Jacqueline Lourdes Blanco-Davao (born February 11, 1964) is a Filipina actress and aerobic instructor of Filipino descent.

title: Jackie Lou Blanco
text: During the 1980s and the 1990s, she appeared in different film genres including "Hihintayin Kita sa Langit", (1991), "Si Aida, Si Lorna, o Si Fe", (1989) "Misis mo, Misis ko", (1988) and "Palabra de honor" (1983).

title: Poetical Refugee
text: Poetical Refugee (French: La Faute à Voltaire ) is a 2000 French drama film directed by Abdellatif Kechiche, starring Sami Bouajila, Élodie Bouchez and Bruno Lochet.

title: Poetical Refugee
text: It was Kechiche‘s debut feature film and was awarded the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival for best first film, winning seven awards, overall, at different film festivals.

title: Music composition and composers in Pristina
text: Music composition and composers in Pristina refers to music composition and composers who have left their mark in Pristina.

title: Music composition and composers in Pristina
text: The importance of Kosovan Folklore on the different genres, their development and their popularity.

title: Music composition and composers in Pristina
text: As referring to genres as a categorization would not cover all compositions and composers in a fair way, a highlight of every composers work and different genres is provided because of the different genres a composers work has included throughout the years.

title: Film laboratory
text: A film laboratory is a commercial service enterprise and technical facility for the film industry where specialists develop, print, and conform film material for classical film production and distribution which is based on film material, such as negative and positive, black and white and color, on different film formats: 65-70mm, 35mm, 16mm, 9.5mm, 8mm.

title: Film laboratory
text: The film laboratory managers can charge by the footage or by time used while in lab.

title: Buddy film
text: The buddy film is a film genre in which two (or on occasion, more than two) people—often both men— are put together.

title: Buddy film
text: The two often contrast in personality, which creates a different dynamic onscreen than a pairing of two people of the opposite gender.

title: Buddy film
text: The contrast is sometimes accentuated by an ethnic difference between the two.

title: Buddy film
text: The buddy film is commonplace in American cinema; unlike some other film genres, it endured through the 20th century with different pairings and different themes.

title: The Five Obstructions
text: The Five Obstructions is a 2003 Danish documentary film directed by Lars von Trier and Jørgen Leth.

title: The Five Obstructions
text: The film is conceived as a documentary, but incorporates lengthy sections of experimental films produced by the filmmakers.

title: The Five Obstructions
text: The premise is that von Trier has created a challenge for his friend and mentor, Jørgen Leth, another renowned filmmaker.

title: The Five Obstructions
text: von Trier's favorite film is Leth's "The Perfect Human" (1967), and von Trier gives Leth the task of remaking "The Perfect Human" five times, each time with a different "obstruction" (or obstacle) imposed by von Trier.

title: Parody film
text: A parody film is a subgenre of comedy film that parodies other film genres or films as pastiches, works created by imitation of the style of many different films reassembled together.

title: Party switching in the United States
text: In the United States politics, party switching is any change in party affiliation of a partisan public figure, usually one who is currently holding elected office.

title: Party switching in the United States
text: Use of the term "party switch" can also connote a transfer of held power in an elected governmental body from one party to another.

title: Hungarian Communist Party
text: The Party of Communists in Hungary (Hungarian: "Kommunisták Magyarországi Pártja" ), renamed Hungarian Communist Party ("Magyar Kommunista Párt" ) in October 1944, was founded on November 24, 1918, and was in power in Hungary briefly from March to August 1919 under Béla Kun and the Hungarian Soviet Republic.

title: Hungarian Communist Party
text: The communist government was overthrown by the Romanian Army and driven underground.

title: Hungarian Communist Party
text: The party regained power following World War II and held power from 1945 under the leadership of Mátyás Rákosi.

title: Hungarian Communist Party
text: In 1948 the party merged with the Social Democrats to become the Hungarian Working People's Party.

title: Hungarian Communist Party
text: The Communist Party of Hungary was a member of the Communist International.

title: Australian federal election, 1972
text: Federal elections for the House of Representatives were held in Australia on 2 December 1972, and were won by the Australian Labor Party led by Gough Whitlam.

title: Australian federal election, 1972
text: Labor won 67 of the 125 seats contested and defeated the Liberal Party led by Prime Minister William McMahon and Coalition partner the Country Party led by Doug Anthony.

title: Australian federal election, 1972
text: The elections ended 23 years of successive Coalition governments which held power since 1949.

title: Swedish general election, 1982
text: General elections were held in Sweden on 19 September 1982.

title: Swedish general election, 1982
text: They saw the return of the Swedish Social Democratic Party to power after six years in opposition, the longest period in opposition by the Social Democrats since the 1910s.

title: Swedish general election, 1982
text: The center-right coalition of Thorbjörn Fälldin had earlier suffered a loss upon the breakup of the government in 1981, the year before the election, when the rightist Moderate Party chose to withdraw from the government, protesting against the centrist tax policies of the Fälldin government.

title: Swedish general election, 1982
text: After regaining power, socialist leader Olof Palme succeeded in being elected Prime Minister again, having earlier held power between 1969 and 1976.

title: Swedish general election, 1982
text: He would retain this position successfully until his assassination in 1986.

title: Tefik Mborja
text: Tefik Selim Mborja (1888-1954) was an Albanian politician and lawyer.

title: Tefik Mborja
text: He served as the general secretary of the Albanian Fascist Party during the Second World War.

title: United Bermuda Party
text: The United Bermuda Party (UBP) was a political party in Bermuda.

title: United Bermuda Party
text: It represented itself as centrist party in favour of a moderate social and fiscal agenda.

title: United Bermuda Party
text: Having held power in Bermuda's House of Assembly continuously from 1968 to 1998, the 47-year-old party officially ceased operations on 30 June 2011 after the majority of its members joined the One Bermuda Alliance.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: The fourth legislative assembly election of Madras State (later renamed as Tamil Nadu) was held in February 1967.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: The Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) led coalition under the leadership of C.N. Annadurai won the election defeating the Indian National Congress (Congress).

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: Anti-Hindi agitations, the rising prices of essential commodities and a shortage of rice were the dominant issues.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: K. Kamaraj's resignation as the Chief Minister in 1963, to concentrate on party affairs, along with persistent rumours of corruption had weakened the incumbent Congress Government.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: This was the second time after Communist Party of India winning Kerala assembly elections in 1957, for a non-Congress party to gain majority in a state in India, and the last time that Congress held power in Tamil Nadu.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: It was the first time a party or pre-election alliance was formed a nob-Congress government with absolute majority.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: It marked the beginning of Dravidian dominance in the politics of Tamil Nadu.

title: Madras Legislative Assembly election, 1967
text: Annadurai, who became the first non-Congress chief minister of post-independence Tamil Nadu, died in office in 1969 and V.R. Nedunchezhiyan took over as acting chief minister.

title: Confederation of Mexican Workers
text: The Confederation of Mexican Workers (Spanish: "Confederación de Trabajadores de México (CTM)" ) is the largest confederation of labor unions in Mexico.

title: Confederation of Mexican Workers
text: For many years, it was one of the essential pillars of the Partido Revolucionario Institucional (the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI), which ruled Mexico for more than seventy years.

title: Confederation of Mexican Workers
text: However, the CTM began to lose influence within the PRI structure in the late 1980s, as technocrats increasingly held power within the party.

title: Confederation of Mexican Workers
text: Eventually, the union found itself forced to deal with a new party in power after the PRI lost the 2000 general election, an event that drastically reduced the CTM's influence in Mexican politics.

title: Bal'arab bin Himyar
text: Bal'arab bin Himyar (died 1749) was one of the rival Imams during the civil wars in Oman in the final years of the Yaruba dynasty.

title: Bal'arab bin Himyar
text: He was elected Imam in 1728, holding power in the interior of Oman while his cousin, Saif bin Sultan II, held power on the coast.

title: Bal'arab bin Himyar
text: In 1737 he renounced his claim after being defeated by Saif's Persian allies.

title: Bal'arab bin Himyar
text: He was again elected Imam in 1743 during another Persian invasion, and again held power in the interior while Ahmad bin Said al-Busaidi was recognized as ruler by the coastal people.

title: Bal'arab bin Himyar
text: He died in battle against Ahmad bin Said in 1749.

title: Bal'arab bin Himyar
text: Ahmad became the undisputed ruler of the country.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: Albania ( , ; Albanian: "Shqipëri/Shqipëria" ; Gheg Albanian: "Shqipni/Shqipnia, Shqypni/Shqypnia" ), officially the People's Socialist Republic of Albania (), was a socialist state that ruled Albania from 1946 to its fall in 1992.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: From 1946 to 1976 it was known as the People's Republic of Albania, and from 1944 to 1946 as the Democratic Government of Albania.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: Throughout this period the country had a reputation for its Stalinist style of state administration dominated by Enver Hoxha and the Party of Labour of Albania and for policies stressing national unity and self-reliance.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: Travel and visa restrictions made Albania one of the most difficult countries to visit or to travel from.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: In 1967, it declared itself the world's first atheist state.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: It was the only Warsaw Pact member to formally withdraw from the alliance before 1990, an action occasioned by the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: The first multi-party elections in Socialist Albania took place on 31 March 1991 – the communists gained a majority in an interim government and the first parliamentary elections were held on 22 March 1992.

title: People's Socialist Republic of Albania
text: The People's Socialist Republic was officially dissolved on 28 November 1998 upon the adoption of the new Constitution of Albania.

title: Magnolia Bowl
text: The LSU–Ole Miss football rivalry, renamed the Magnolia Bowl in 2008, is an American college football rivalry game played annually by the LSU Tigers football team of Louisiana State University (LSU) and the Ole Miss Rebels football team of the University of Mississippi (Ole Miss).

title: Magnolia Bowl
text: The teams compete for the Magnolia Bowl Trophy.

title: Magnolia Bowl
text: The Tigers and the Rebels first met in 1894, and have been regular opponents in Southeastern Conference (SEC), meeting annually since 1945.

title: Magnolia Bowl
text: The rivalry was at its height during the 1950s and 1960s, when both teams were highly ranked and during which time both teams claimed a national championship.

title: Magnolia Bowl
text: The rivalry died down from the 1970s to the 1990s, owing to Ole Miss not returning to conference or national prominence since the 1970s and because LSU has seen new rivalries emerge when the SEC split into two divisions in 1992, most notably Alabama, Arkansas, Auburn, and Florida.

title: Magnolia Bowl
text: Even though the rivalry has not attracted the same national attention in recent years, it still stirs up passion in both Oxford and Baton Rouge.

title: Oregon Ducks football
text: The Oregon Ducks football program is a college football team for the University of Oregon, located in the U.S. state of Oregon.

title: Oregon Ducks football
text: The team competes at the NCAA Division I level in the FBS and is a member of the Pac-12 Conference (Pac-12).

title: Oregon Ducks football
text: Known as the Ducks, the team was commonly called the Webfoots until the mid-1960s.

title: Oregon Ducks football
text: The first football team was fielded in 1894.

title: Oregon Ducks football
text: Oregon plays its home games at the 54,000 seat Autzen Stadium in Eugene; its main rivals are the Oregon State Beavers and the Washington Huskies.

title: Oregon Ducks football
text: The Ducks and Beavers historically end each regular season with the Civil War rivalry game in late November.

title: Wayne Walker
text: Wayne Harrison Walker (September 30, 1936 – May 19, 2017) was an American professional football player and sports broadcaster.

title: Wayne Walker
text: He played fifteen seasons with the Detroit Lions of the National Football League, as a linebacker and placekicker.

title: Wayne Walker
text: Walker played in 200 regular season games, the second most for a defensive player at the time.

title: Wayne Walker
text: He played in three Pro Bowls and was thrice selected as a first-team All-NFL player.

title: Wayne Walker
text: After the 1972 season, he retired as a player and was a sports broadcaster for CBS and the sports director for KPIX-TV in San Francisco from 1974 to 1994.

title: Wayne Walker
text: Walker was a weekend sportscaster during the off-season during his later years as a Detroit Lion.

title: 1983 Oregon State vs. Oregon football game
text: The 1983 Oregon State vs. Oregon football game was a college football game played on November 19, 1983, at Autzen Stadium in Eugene, Oregon, the 87th playing of the annual Civil War rivalry game.

title: 1983 Oregon State vs. Oregon football game
text: The game ended in a scoreless tie.

title: 1983 Oregon State vs. Oregon football game
text: Since overtime was added to NCAA Division I games in 1996, this game is likely to be the last ever with that distinction.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: The Battle of the Blue is an annual college football rivalry game between the University of Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens and Villanova University Wildcats.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: The first game was played between the two teams in 1895, was played annually from 1964 to 1980 when Villanova dropped football, and then resumed with the re-emergence of Villanova football having been played annually since 1988.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: Beginning in 2007, the annual Delaware–Villanova game became known as Battle of the Blue.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: As part of this concept, the winning team gets to keep the Battle of the Blue Trophy at its institution for the year and is responsible for bringing the trophy to the following installment of the rivalry game.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: The trophy consists of a football with a Villanova logo and the Wildcat shade of blue on one side and the Blue Hen logo and the Delaware shade of blue on the other side.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: The ball sits in a wooden platform and the scores of each game are engraved on the base of the trophy.

title: Battle of the Blue
text: Villanova had possession of the trophy for the first four years, until Delaware won in 2011.

title: Civil War (college football game)
text: The Civil War is the colloquial name for an American college football rivalry game played annually in Oregon, between the Ducks of the University of Oregon in Eugene and the Beavers of Oregon State University in Corvallis.

title: Civil War (college football game)
text: First played in 1894, it is the fifth most played college football rivalry game in NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision.

title: Civil War (college football game)
text: Both universities are members of the North Division of the Pac-12 Conference.

title: The Rivalry (Lehigh–Lafayette)
text: The Rivalry is an American college football rivalry game played by the Lafayette Leopards football team of Lafayette College and the Lehigh Mountain Hawks football team of Lehigh University.

title: The Rivalry (Lehigh–Lafayette)
text: It is the most-played football rivalry in the nation and the longest uninterrupted annual rivalry series.

title: The Rivalry (Lehigh–Lafayette)
text: As of 2016, "The Rivalry" has been played 152 times since 1884 with only a single interruption in 1896.

title: The Rivalry (Lehigh–Lafayette)
text: The college's football teams met twice annually (except 1891, when they played three games, and 1896, when they did not play at all) until 1901.

title: The Rivalry (Lehigh–Lafayette)
text: The two institutions are located seventeen miles apart in the Lehigh Valley in eastern Pennsylvania.

title: The Rivalry (Lehigh–Lafayette)
text: Though primarily alluding to football, "The Rivalry" pertains to a meeting between the two schools in all sports and other endeavors.

title: Army–Navy Game
text: The Army–Navy Game is an American college rivalry game in college football between the Army Black Knights of the United States Military Academy (USMA) at West Point, New York, and the Navy Midshipmen of the United States Naval Academy (USNA) at Annapolis, Maryland.

title: Army–Navy Game
text: The Black Knights (formerly the "Army Cadets" and "Army Black Knights") and Midshipmen each represent their service's oldest officer commissioning sources.

title: Army–Navy Game
text: As such, the game has come to embody the spirit of the interservice rivalry of the United States Armed Forces.

title: Army–Navy Game
text: The game marks the end of the college football regular season and the third and final game of the season's Commander-in-Chief's Trophy series, which also includes the Air Force Falcons of the United States Air Force Academy (USAFA) near Colorado Springs, Colorado.

title: Battle for the Bell
text: The Battle for the Bell is an American college football rivalry game played by the Marshall Thundering Herd football team of Marshall University and the Ohio Bobcats football team of Ohio University.

title: Battle for the Bell
text: It is a regional rivalry, with the universities' campuses located about 80 miles (130 km) from each other, with a bell awarded as the trophy for the winner of the game.

title: Battle for the Bell
text: With Marshall's move from the Mid-American Conference to Conference USA in 2005, this rivalry game was on hiatus for several years.

title: Battle for the Bell
text: The series unexpectedly resumed in 2009 when the Herd and Bobcats faced off in the 2009 Little Caesars Pizza Bowl, which Marshall won 21–17.

title: Battle for the Bell
text: A six-year contract between the schools began in 2010.

title: Battle for the Bell
text: Ohio leads the all-time series over Marshall 33–20–6.

title: Textile Bowl
text: The Textile Bowl is an American college football rivalry game played annually by the Clemson Tigers football team of Clemson University and the NC State Wolfpack football team of North Carolina State University.

title: Textile Bowl
text: The rivalry game has been known as the Textile Bowl since 1981.

title: Textile Bowl
text: The two universities are founding members of the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC), and both have competed in the ACC's Atlantic Division since the conference initiated divisional play.

title: Textile Bowl
text: The rivalry's name is derived from the fact that Clemson and North Carolina State have two of the largest university-level textile schools in the world, and from the textile industry's historic importance in the economic development of their respective states of South Carolina and North Carolina.

title: Good Morning, Miami
text: Good Morning, Miami is a sitcom which ran from 2002 to 2004 on NBC.

title: Good Morning, Miami
text: Created by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, the show focused on the personal and professional life of Jake, the executive producer of the lowest-rated morning show in the country, based in Miami.

title: Boston Common (TV series)
text: Boston Common was an American television sitcom created by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, and aired on NBC from 1996 to 1997.

title: Boston Common (TV series)
text: The series was one of the 10 highest rated shows in its first season as it ranked 8th in the yearly ratings with a 15.6 household rating, but with a move to Sundays in its second season, the show dropped from 8th to 52nd place.

title: David Kohan
text: David Sanford Kohan (born April 16, 1964) is an American television producer and writer.

title: David Kohan
text: After writing for "The Wonder Years" and "The Dennis Miller Show", Kohan co-created and produced "Will & Grace", "Boston Common", "Good Morning, Miami", "Twins" and "Four Kings" with Max Mutchnick.

title: David Kohan
text: Kohan has won an Emmy and a People's Choice Award.

title: David Kohan
text: He has been nominated for a Golden Globe Award.

title: David Kohan
text: He and his business partner Max Mutchnick worked on a half-hour comedy series for CBS called "Partners".

title: Will & Grace
text: Will & Grace is an American sitcom created by Max Mutchnick and David Kohan.

title: Will & Grace
text: Set in New York City, the show focuses on the relationship between best friends Will Truman (Eric McCormack), a gay lawyer, and Grace Adler (Debra Messing), a straight interior designer.

title: Will & Grace
text: The show was broadcast on NBC from September 21, 1998 to May 18, 2006, for a total of eight seasons, and re-started its run on NBC on September 28, 2017.

title: Will & Grace
text: During its original run, "Will & Grace" was one of the most successful television series with gay principal characters.

title: Partners (2012 TV series)
text: Partners is an American comedy series that aired on CBS from September 24 to November 12, 2012, on Monday nights at 8:30 p.m., following the sitcom "How I Met Your Mother".

title: Partners (2012 TV series)
text: The series was created by "Will & Grace" creators Max Mutchnick and David Kohan, who also served as the show's executive producers and it stars Michael Urie, David Krumholtz, Sophia Bush, and Brandon Routh.

title: James Carroll (actor)
text: James Carroll (December 20, 1955 – April 27, 2016) was an American-born Canadian actor and radio personality, best known for playing Max Sutton on "Wind at My Back", which aired on CBC Television from 1996 to 2001.

title: James Carroll (actor)
text: Most recently, Carroll found a second career as a community radio host and personality based in Huntsville, Ontario.

title: James Carroll (actor)
text: Carroll initially joined Hunters Bay Radio (CKAR-FM) in 2010 as the host of a local afternoon radio show.

title: James Carroll (actor)
text: However, he soon became involved in the growth of the community station, hosting a Top 20 countdown, a Motown show on Mondays, and a local talent show.

title: James Carroll (actor)
text: Carroll helped Hunters Bay Radio expand from its origins as a small, online station broadcast from a household basement into a full FM radio station with a staff of 60 employees by 2016.

title: Pilot (Will & Grace)
text: "Pilot" (also known as "Love and Marriage") is the first episode of "Will & Grace"<nowiki>'</nowiki>s first season.

title: Pilot (Will & Grace)
text: It was written by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, and directed by James Burrows.

title: Pilot (Will & Grace)
text: It originally aired on the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in the United States on September 21, 1998.

title: Pilot (Will & Grace)
text: In the episode, Grace Adler receives an unexpected marriage proposal from her boyfriend.

title: Pilot (Will & Grace)
text: Her gay best friend Will Truman tries to support her, but finally tells her that she is making a big mistake, even though he risks losing their friendship.

title: Pilot (Will & Grace)
text: The situation gets complicated when Grace's socialite assistant, Karen Walker, and Will's flamboyantly gay friend, Jack McFarland, interfere.

title: Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More
text: "Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More" is a double-length episode of the American television series "Will & Grace"' s fifth season.

title: Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More
text: It was written by Jeff Greenstein and Bill Wrubel and directed by series producer James Burrows.

title: Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More
text: The episode originally aired on the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in the United States on November 21, 2002.

title: Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More
text: Guest stars in "Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More" include Harry Connick Jr., Katie Couric, Judith Ivey, and Debbie Reynolds.

title: Four Kings
text: Four Kings is an American sitcom introduced as a part of NBC's winter 2006 programming but cancelled before the end of the season.

title: Four Kings
text: It aired at 8:30pm on Thursdays.

title: Four Kings
text: It starred Seth Green, Josh Cooke, Shane McRae, and Todd Grinnell.

title: Four Kings
text: The show was created by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, both of whom created "Will & Grace".

title: The Stones (TV series)
text: The Stones is a sitcom television series that starred Robert Klein, Judith Light, Lindsay Sloane and Jay Baruchel as the Stone family that are divorced but still live under the same roof.

title: The Stones (TV series)
text: The show premiered on CBS on March 17, 2004 and was canceled after 3 episodes due to low ratings.

title: The Stones (TV series)
text: It was supposed to begin in 2003 but was delayed.

title: The Stones (TV series)
text: It was produced by David Kohan, Max Mutchnick and Jenji Kohan.

title: Jean Portante
text: Jean Portante was born in Differdange, Luxembourg, and now lives in Paris.

title: Jean Portante
text: He has written novels, stories, plays, journalism and poetry, and has been widely translated, including in English Point/Erasing, translated by Anne Marie Glasheen (Daedalus, 2003) and In Reality, translated by Zoë Skoulding (Seren Press, 2013).

title: Jean Portante
text: He is a translator of poetry into French from Spanish, Italian, English and German.

title: Jean Portante
text: His novels include Mrs Haroy ou la mémoire de la baleine (Editions Phi, 1997) among others, which has been translated into many languages, and he is also the author of the biography Allen Ginsberg: L'autre Amérique (Le Castor Astral, 1999).

title: Jean Portante
text: Portante’s collection of poems L’Etrange langue (Editions Le Taillis Pré, 2002) won the Mallarmé award in France in 2003, and the same year he was given the Grand Prix d’Automne de la Société des Gens de Lettres for his entire life’s work in poetry.

title: Jean Portante
text: In 2005, Le Castor Astral published a selected poems, La Cendre des mots, covering his work from 1989 to 2005.

title: Jean Portante
text: Since 2006 he has been a member of the Académie Mallarmé.

title: Jean Portante
text: In 2008 he co-founded the French poetry magazine "Inuits dans la jungle" with the poet Jacques Darras, while in Luxembourg he heads the literary magazine Transkrit.

title: Jean Portante
text: In 2011 he was awarded Luxembourg’s Batty Weber National Prize, which is given every three years for a life’s work.

title: Jean Portante
text: His latest books are En réalité (Editions Phi 2008); La réinvention de l'oubli (Editions le Castor Astral, 2010), Conceptions (Editions Phi, 2012) and Après le tremblement (Editions Le Castor Astral, 2013)

title: Don Bousquet
text: Don Bousquet (born 1948) is a Rhode Island-based cartoonist.

title: Don Bousquet
text: He was born in Pawtucket, Rhode Island.

title: Don Bousquet
text: His cartoon "Bousquet" regularly appears in "The Providence Journal", "Rhode Island Monthly", and the "South County Independent" and his work has also appeared in numerous other publications, such as "Yankee Magazine".

title: Don Bousquet
text: Most of Bosquet's best sellers were published by Covered Bridge Press.

title: Don Bousquet
text: On March 29, 2014, Bosquet retired from one of his most visible platforms, his Sunday placement in "The Providence Journal", and would be "winding down" his drawing.

title: Latresne
text: Latresne is a commune in the Gironde department in Nouvelle-Aquitaine in southwestern France.

title: Latresne
text: The 20th-century French jurist and Islamologist Georges-Henri Bousquet (1900–1978) died in Latresne.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: Vaughan Hart is a leading architectural historian, and Professor of Architecture in the Department of Architecture and Civil Engineering at the University of Bath.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: Hart studied architecture at Bath and Cambridge Universities (Trinity Hall), where he was taught by Michael Brawne, Patrick Hodgkinson, Peter Smithson and Dalibor Vesely.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: He worked first as an architectural assistant to Colin St John Wilson on the British Library project in London, before studying for a doctorate in Cambridge on Inigo Jones under Joseph Rykwert.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: Hart's concerns lie in particular with the symbolic function of architecture, and with the meaning of architectural forms.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: Hart has published widely in the field of architectural history, specialising in the Italian architectural treatises and in British architectural history of the Renaissance and Baroque periods.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: He is the co-translator (with Peter Hicks) of the treatises of Sebastiano Serlio, and he has also translated the two guidebooks to Rome published by Andrea Palladio and the guidebook to Venice by Francesco Sansovino (2017).

title: Vaughan Hart
text: These works have in turn been translated into Chinese and Japanese.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: Hart's translation of these classic works formed part of a wider project initiated by Rykwert and Robert Tavernor through their translation of the treatise by Leon Battista Alberti.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: In addition, Hart's monographs include influential studies of the work of Inigo Jones, Sir John Vanbrugh and Nicholas Hawksmoor, all published by Yale University Press for the Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art.

title: Vaughan Hart
text: The latter monograph was awarded the Best Book on British Art Prize of the American College Art Association in 2005.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: Professor Ghulam Nabi Firaq (15 July 1927 - 17 December 2016) was a Kashmiri poet, writer and an educationist.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: From the last fifty years he had been writing poetry and prose.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: In doing so he used, besides traditional ones, several poetic forms including blank verse, free verse, sonnets, quatrains, metric poems and lyrics.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: He also translated dozens of English poems of outstanding English poets into Kashmiri.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: As a result of all this, he enriched the expression of the language and made it more suitable for communicating his sensibility which in nature is modern.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: Besides, he had been writing essays and articles in Kashmiri language, which was his mother tongue, and which he had made the vehicle of expression from early fifties.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: As a literary critic and historian he had been trying to evaluate the Kashmiri poetry of the last five hundred years and rehabilitate it by bringing to prominence among other things its intrinsic merit and power of expression.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: He also holds the Sahitya Akademi Award for his works in Kashmiri literature.

title: Ghulam Nabi Firaq
text: He is regarded as one of the very few people of Kashmir who has been trying to preserve the rich Kashmiri culture, heritage and language.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: John Bradley Hirst, (9 July 1942 – 3 February 2016) was an Australian historian and commentator.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: He has been described as an "historian, public intellectual, and active citizen".

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: Born in Adelaide, Hirst attended Unley High School and undertook his undergraduate and postgraduate study at the University of Adelaide.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: Abandoning an early desire to become a Methodist Minister, in 1968 he was appointed a lecturer at Melbourne's new La Trobe University, where he remained until the end of his career.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: His wife and fellow-student Christine accompanied him to Melbourne.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: They had two children, Catherine and David.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: Hirst was subsequently head of department and Reader in History at La Trobe.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: He retired in 2006, and was an Emeritus Scholar at La Trobe until his death.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: Hirst had a distinguished career "in teaching, supervision and research.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: He developed new subjects and methodologies to teach them.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: In addition to those concerning Australian history there was his pioneering subject designed to inform students about Australia's European cultural heritage."

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: This work was published as "The Shortest History of Europe" and has been translated into nine languages (Swedish, Greek, Chinese, Spanish, German, Portuguese, Russian, Turkish and Korean).

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: Hirst was seconded to the University of Melbourne to edit "Historical Studies", Australia's leading historical journal, from 1977 to 1980.

title: John Hirst (historian)
text: In retirement, he travelled regularly to Sydney to instruct, without remuneration, groups of post-graduate students in thesis writing.

title: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park
text: The Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park is a part of the state park system of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, managed by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR).

title: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park
text: This 1000 acre park "recalls the role of canals in transporting raw materials and manufactured goods between emerging industrial centers."

title: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park
text: The Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park at Uxbridge, Massachusetts, is the midpoint of the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor of the National Park System.

title: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park
text: The Blackstone River and Valley is where the industrial revolution was born in America.

title: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park
text: The southern entrance to this state park is the site of the historic Stanley Woolen Mill, currently being redeveloped for commercial and tourism.

title: Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park
text: The Native American Nipmuc name for the village here was "Wacentug", translated as "bend in the river".

title: Georges-Henri Bousquet
text: Georges-Henri Bousquet (21 June 1900, Meudon – 23 January 1978, Latresne) was a 20th-century French jurist, economist and Islamologist.

title: Georges-Henri Bousquet
text: He was Professor of law at the Faculty of Law of the University of Algiers where he was a specialist in the sociology of North Africa (Berbers, Islam).

title: Georges-Henri Bousquet
text: He is also known for his translation work of the great Muslim authors, Al-Ghazali, a theologian who died in 1111 and Tunisian historian Ibn Khaldun (1332-1406).

title: Georges-Henri Bousquet
text: He was known as a polyglot, spoke several European languages (Dutch, his second mother tongue, English, German, Italian, but also Spanish, Danish, Norwegian ...) and Eastern ones (Arab, Malay ...).

title: Sally Gibson
text: Sally Gibson is an author, archivist and heritage consultant who resides in Toronto and has written three books about the city and its heritage.

title: Sally Gibson
text: She has a Master of Urban Studies from Yale University, and a Master of Library Science and a Ph.D. in Urban Geography from the University of Toronto.

title: Sally Gibson
text: Gibson grew up in New Jersey, went to Vassar College, and moved to Toronto in 1969.

title: Sally Gibson
text: Her first book, "More than an Island: A History of the Toronto Island" was described by urban thinker Jane Jacobs as "city history at its very best".

title: Sally Gibson
text: Her second book, "Inside Toronto: Urban Interiors 1880s to 1920s", was a finalist for the City of Toronto Book Award and won a Heritage Toronto Book Award of Excellence in 2007.

title: Sally Gibson
text: Her third book, "Toronto’s Distillery District: History by the Lake", evolved from her work as the Distillery District's site historian and won a Heritage Toronto Book Award of Merit in 2009.

title: Armando Mook
text: Armando Mook, also Armando Moock Bousquet (1894 in Santiago to 1942 in Buenos Aires) was a Chilean writer and playwright.

title: Armando Mook
text: He wrote the play "Arm in Arm Down the Street", which was adapted into films in 1956 and 1966.

title: Armando Mook
text: Other works include "Los demonios" (1917) and "La Serpiente" (1919).

title: Armando Mook
text: "La Serpiente" (also "La Serpierde"; "The Serpent") is considered his best work.

title: Armando Mook
text: He was a contemporary of Germán Luco Cruchaga.

title: Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools
text: Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools is a computer science textbook by Alfred V. Aho, Monica S. Lam, Ravi Sethi, and Jeffrey D. Ullman about compiler construction.

title: Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools
text: First published in 1986, it is widely regarded as the classic definitive compiler technology text.

title: David H. Bailey
text: David Harold Bailey (born 1948) is a mathematician and computer scientist.

title: David H. Bailey
text: He received his B.S. in mathematics from Brigham Young University in 1972 and his Ph.D. in mathematics from Stanford University in 1976.

title: David H. Bailey
text: He worked for 14 years as a computer scientist at NASA Ames Research Center, but since 1998 has been at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

title: David H. Bailey
text: He is now officially retired, but continues as an active researcher.

title: David H. Bailey
text: He is also a Research Associate at the University of California, Davis, Department of Computer Science.

title: Nuria Oliver
text: Nuria Oliver is a computer scientist.

title: Nuria Oliver
text: She is Director of Data Science Research at Vodafone and Chief Data Scientist at DataPop Alliance.

title: Nuria Oliver
text: Previously, she was Scientific Director at Telefónica and a researcher at Microsoft Research.

title: Nuria Oliver
text: She holds a PhD from the Media Lab at MIT, and is an IEEE Fellow.

title: Nuria Oliver
text: She is one of the most cited female computer scientist in Spain, with her research having been cited by more than 11800 publications.

title: Nuria Oliver
text: She is well known for her work in computational models of human behavior, human computer-interaction, mobile computing and big data for social good.

title: Franz Josef Och
text: Franz Josef Och (November 2, 1971) is a German computer scientist.

title: Franz Josef Och
text: He is currently working at Grail (an Illumina company) as Head of Data Science.

title: Franz Josef Och
text: Prior to this he was Chief Data Scientist at Human Longevity Inc., and earlier worked for Google as a Distinguished Research Scientist and head of machine translation based at Google's Mountain View, California, headquarters south of San Francisco.

title: Sethi–Ullman algorithm
text: In computer science, the Sethi–Ullman algorithm is an algorithm named after Ravi Sethi and Jeffrey D. Ullman, its inventors, for translating abstract syntax trees into machine code that uses as few registers as possible.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: The University of Berat is a private institution, independent and secular Higher Education, which operates the state fee.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: Licensed by the Council of Ministers, no. 697 dated 18.06.2009, he opened the doors in the academic year 2009- 2010, offering programs in two faculties: Faculty of Social Sciences Programs in Science Teaching Legal, Political Science and Psychology General Administration and the Faculty of Economics with Learning programs in Banking and Finance-Business Administration.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: During the first academic year, about 1,000 students attended studies.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: A year later, this new institution offering undergraduate degrees in study programs: Preschool Teacher Education, Primary Education Teacher, English Language, Nursing, Engineering Computer and Information Technology, thus finalizing the 2010-2011 academic year with the opening of two new faculties: Faculty of Medical Sciences and the Faculty of Architecture and Inxhinierive.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: Academic Year 2010-2011 finds the University Berat with about 2600 students in the first cycle of study.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: Since the first year of its inception, the institution pointed at the center of academic life, the promotion of intellectual product and melting learning and research.

title: Albanian University in Berat
text: Through presentations, research and exchange, the University directs and encourages the identification and development of projects that will once again consolidate its primary purpose, scientific development, and research toward better quality.

title: Ravi Sethi
text: Ravi Sethi (born 1947) is an Indian computer scientist retired from Bell Labs and president of Avaya Labs Research.

title: Ravi Sethi
text: He also serves as a member of the National Science Foundation's Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) Advisory Committee.

title: Ravi Sethi
text: He is best known as one of three authors of the classic computer science textbook "", also known as the "Dragon Book".

title: Bell Labs
text: Nokia Bell Labs (formerly named AT&T Bell Laboratories, Bell Telephone Laboratories and Bell Labs) is an American research and scientific development company, owned by Finnish company Nokia.

title: Bell Labs
text: Its headquarters are located in Murray Hill, New Jersey, in addition to other laboratories around the rest of the United States and in other countries.

title: Annie Easley
text: Annie J. Easley (April 23, 1933 – June 25, 2011) was an African-American computer scientist, mathematician, and rocket scientist.

title: Annie Easley
text: She worked for the Lewis Research Center (now Glenn Research Center) of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and its predecessor, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA).

title: Annie Easley
text: She was a leading member of the team which developed software for the Centaur rocket stage and one of the first African-Americans to work as a computer scientist at NASA.

title: Pharma Medica
text: Pharma Medica Research Inc. is an American research and development company that works with pharmaceutical companies and performs clinical trials in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industry.

title: Pharma Medica
text: The company is based in Toronto, Canada with headquarters in Mississauga, Ontario.

title: Pharma Medica
text: Pharma Medica has locations in Scarborough, Ontario and St. Charles, Missouri.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: Chronic Mycoplasma pneumonia and Chlamydia pneumonia infections are associated with the onset and exacerbation of asthma.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: These microbial infections result in chronic lower airway inflammation, impaired mucociliary clearance, an increase in mucous production and eventually asthma.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: Furthermore, children who experience severe viral respiratory infections early in life have a high possibility of having asthma later in their childhood.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: These viral respiratory infections are mostly caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and human rhinovirus (HRV).

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: Although RSV infections increase the risk of asthma in early childhood, the association between asthma and RSV decreases with increasing age.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: HRV on the other hand is an important cause of bronchiolitis and is strongly associated with asthma development.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: In children and adults with established asthma, viral upper respiratory tract infections (URIs), especially HRVs infections, can produce acute exacerbations of asthma.

title: Asthma-related microbes
text: Thus, "Chlamydia pneumoniae", "Mycoplasma pneumoniae" and human rhinoviruses are microbes that play a major role in non-atopic asthma.

title: Severe acute respiratory syndrome
text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a viral respiratory disease of zoonotic origin caused by the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV).

title: Severe acute respiratory syndrome
text: Between November 2002 and July 2003, an outbreak of SARS in southern China caused an eventual 8,098 cases, resulting in 774 deaths reported in 37 countries, with the majority of cases in Hong Kong (9.6% fatality rate) according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

title: Severe acute respiratory syndrome
text: No cases of SARS have been reported worldwide since 2004.

title: Yi Guan
text: Yi Guan is a Chinese virologist who, in 2014, was ranked as 11th in the world by Thomson Reuters (now known as Clarivate Analytics) among global researchers in the field of microbiology.

title: Yi Guan
text: His research on the viral respiratory disease SARS allowed the Chinese government to successfully avert the 2004 outbreak of this disease.

title: Yi Guan
text: He is the current Director (China affairs) of the State Key Laboratory for Emerging Infectious Diseases University of Hong Kong.

title: Yi Guan
text: In early 2017, Guan warned that the H7N9 influenza virus "poses the greatest threat to humanity than any other in the past 100 years."

title: Irish Thoracic Society
text: The Irish Thoracic Society (ITS) is the official society for professionals involved in the care of people with chronic or acute respiratory disease in Ireland.

title: Irish Thoracic Society
text: Membership of the Society is drawn from respiratory physicians, internal medicine physicians, pediatricians, thoracic surgeons, general practitioners, junior doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, pharmacists, dietitians, pulmonary function and respiratory therapists, scientists and other healthcare providers who specialize or have an interest in respiratory disease and care throughout Ireland - North and South.

title: Chronic Respiratory Disease
text: Chronic Respiratory Disease is a quarterly peer-reviewed medical journal that covers research in the field of respiratory disease, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, respiratory failure, and obstructive sleep apnea.

title: Chronic Respiratory Disease
text: The editors-in-chief are Mike Morgan (Glenfield Hospital), Carolyn Rochester (Yale University), and Sally Singh (Glenfield Hospital).

title: Chronic Respiratory Disease
text: It was established in 2004 and is published by SAGE Publications.

title: Feline viral rhinotracheitis
text: Feline viral rhinotracheitis (FVR) is an upper respiratory or pulmonary infection of cats caused by "feline herpesvirus 1", of the family "Herpesviridae".

title: Feline viral rhinotracheitis
text: It is also commonly referred to as feline influenza, feline coryza, and feline pneumonia but, as these terms describe other very distinct collections of respiratory symptoms, they are misnomers for the condition.

title: Feline viral rhinotracheitis
text: Viral respiratory diseases in cats can be serious, especially in catteries and kennels. Causing one-half of the respiratory diseases in cats, FVR is the most important of these diseases and is found worldwide.

title: Feline viral rhinotracheitis
text: The other important cause of feline respiratory disease is "feline calicivirus".

title: Aspirin-induced asthma
text: Aspirin-induced asthma, also termed Samter's triad, Samter's syndrome, aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), and recently by an appointed task force of the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology/World Allergy Organization (EAACI/WAO) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs-exacerbated respiratory disease (N-ERD).

title: Aspirin-induced asthma
text: is a medical condition initially defined as consisting of three key features: asthma, respiratory symptoms exacerbated by aspirin, and nasal/ethmoidal polyposis; however, the syndrome's symptoms are exacerbated by a large variety of other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugss (NSAIDs) besides aspirin.

title: Aspirin-induced asthma
text: The symptoms of respiratory reactions in this syndrome are hypersensitivity reactions to NSAIDs rather than the typically described true allergic reactions that trigger other common allergen-induced asthma, rhinitis, or hives.

title: Aspirin-induced asthma
text: The NSAID-induced reactions do not appear to involve the common mediators of true allergic reactions, immunoglobulin E or T cells.

title: Aspirin-induced asthma
text: Rather, AERD is a type of NSAID-induced hypersensitivity syndrome.

title: Aspirin-induced asthma
text: EAACI/WHO classifies the syndrome as one of 5 types of NSAID hypersensitivity or NSAID hypersensitivity reactions.

title: Journal of Thoracic Disease
text: The Journal of Thoracic Disease is a peer-reviewed open access medical journal covering pulmonology.

title: Journal of Thoracic Disease
text: It was established in December 2009 and is published monthly by AME Publishing Company.

title: Journal of Thoracic Disease
text: It is the official journal of the State Key Laboratory of Respiratory Disease, the Guangzhou Institute of Respiratory Disease, the First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University, and the Society for Thoracic Disease.

title: Journal of Thoracic Disease
text: The editor-in-chief is Zhong Nanshan (Guangzhou Institute of Respiratory Diseases).

title: Journal of Thoracic Disease
text: According to the "Journal Citation Reports", the journal has a 2016 impact factor of 2.365.

title: Pulmonary rehabilitation
text: Pulmonary rehabilitation, also known as respiratory rehabilitation, is an important part of the management and health maintenance of people with chronic respiratory disease who remain symptomatic or continue to have decreased function despite standard medical treatment.

title: Pulmonary rehabilitation
text: It is a broad therapeutic concept.

title: Pulmonary rehabilitation
text: It is defined by the American Thoracic Society and the European Respiratory Society as an evidence-based, multidisciplinary, and comprehensive intervention for patients with chronic respiratory diseases who are symptomatic and often have decreased daily life activities.

title: Pulmonary rehabilitation
text: In general, pulmonary rehabilitation refers to a series of services that are administered to patients of respiratory disease and their families, typically to attempt to improve the quality of life for the patient.

title: Pulmonary rehabilitation
text: Pulmonary rehabilitation may be carried out in a variety of settings, depending on the patient's needs, and may or may not include pharmacologic intervention.

title: SARS (disambiguation)
text: SARS is severe acute respiratory syndrome, a viral respiratory disease of zoonotic origin caused by the SARS coronavirus.

title: Judith Ortiz Cofer
text: Judith Ortiz Cofer (February 24, 1952 – December 30, 2016) was a Puerto Rican American author.

title: Judith Ortiz Cofer
text: Her critically acclaimed and award-winning work spans a range of literary genres including poetry, short stories, autobiography, essays, and young-adult fiction.

title: Judith Ortiz Cofer
text: Ortiz Cofer was the Emeritus Regents' and Franklin Professor of English and Creative Writing at the University of Georgia, where she taught undergraduate and graduate creative writing workshops for 26 years.

title: Judith Ortiz Cofer
text: In 2010, Ortiz Cofer was inducted into the Georgia Writers Hall of Fame, and in 2013, she won the University's 2014 Southeastern Conference Faculty Achievement Award.

title: Winfred Blevins
text: Win Blevins (born October 21, 1938) is a New York Times Bestselling American author of historical fiction, narrative non-fiction, historical fantasy, and non-fiction books, as well as short stories, novellas, articles, reviews, and screenplays.

title: Winfred Blevins
text: He has written many books about the western mountain trappers, and is known for his "mastery of western lore."

title: Winfred Blevins
text: His notable works include Stone Song, So Wild a Dream, and Dictionary of the American West.

title: Winfred Blevins
text: According to WorldCat, the Dictionary of the American West is held in 728 libraries.

title: Winfred Blevins
text: Blevins has won numerous awards, including being named winner of the Owen Wister Award for Lifetime Achievement in writing literature of the West, being selected for the Western Writers Hall of Fame, being twice named 'Writer of the Year' by Wordcraft Circle of Native Writers, and winning two Spur Awards for Novel of the West.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: The Nebula Award for Best Novel is given each year by the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America (SFWA) for science fiction or fantasy novels.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: A work of fiction is defined by the organization as a novel if it is 40,000 words or longer; awards are also given out for pieces of shorter lengths in the categories of short story, novelette, and novella.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: To be eligible for Nebula Award consideration a novel must be published in English in the United States.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: Works published in English elsewhere in the world are also eligible provided they are released on either a website or in an electronic edition.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: The Nebula Award for Best Novel has been awarded annually since 1966.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: Novels which were expanded forms of previously published short stories are eligible, as are novellas published by themselves if the author requests them to be considered as a novel.

title: Nebula Award for Best Novel
text: The award has been described as one of "the most important of the American science fiction awards" and "the science-fiction and fantasy equivalent" of the Emmy Awards.

title: Jay Cronley

title: Dim Gray Bar Press

text: Barry Magid is also a psychoanalyst and a Dharma heir to Charlotte Joko Beck in the Ordinary Mind Zen School.

title: Duty to settle
text: A liability insurance company's duty to settle is defined as an implied obligation to by the insurer to a policyholder and to a claimant to attempt "in good faith to effectuate prompt, fair, and equitable settlements of claims in which liability has become reasonably clear."

title: Duty to settle
text: To the surprise of many, a typical liability insurance policy makes no express contractual promise to settle.

title: Duty to settle
text: In California, "an insurer, who wrongfully refuses to accept a reasonable settlement within the policy limits is liable for the entire judgment against the insured even if it exceeds the policy limits."

title: Duty to settle
text: A rationale for this duty is that "hen an offer is made to settle a claim in excess of policy limits for an amount within policy limits, a genuine and immediate conflict of interest arises between carrier and assured."

title: Duty to settle
text: "An insurer who denies coverage does so at its own risk.

title: Duty to settle
text: Such factors as a belief that the policy does not provide coverage, should not affect a decision as to whether the settlement offer in question is a reasonable one."

title: Duty to settle
text: "It is the duty of the insurer to keep the insured informed of settlement offers." "

title: Duty to settle
text: n insurer potentially can be liable for unreasonably coercing an insured to contribute to a settlement fund."

title: Fraley v. Facebook, Inc.

text: The case resulted in the parties reaching a settlement.

title: Fraley v. Facebook, Inc.

title: Nilmoni Tagore

title: Damian Wayne
text: Damian Wayne or Damian al Ghul (Arabic: داميان الغول) is a fictional superhero and at times antihero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics, commonly in association with Batman.

title: Damian Wayne
