title: Kent County Cricket Club in 2011
text: Pakistan fast bowler Wahab Riaz joined Kent as their overseas player in June, and another fast bowler, South African Charl Langeveldt, signed as Kent's second overseas player for the Friends Life t20 competition only.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: Grant Duff Douglas Ainslie (1865–27 March 1948) was a Scottish poet, translator, critic and diplomat.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: He was born in Paris, France, and educated at Eton College and at Balliol and Exeter Colleges, Oxford.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: A contributor to the Yellow Book, he met and befriended Oscar Wilde at age twenty-one while an undergraduate at Oxford.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: He was also associated with other such notable figures as Aubrey Beardsley, Walter Pater and Marcel Proust.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: The first translator of the Italian philosopher Benedetto Croce into English, he also lectured on Hegel.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: He was identified as the "Dear Ainslie" recipient of twelve letters written by Arthur Conan Doyle in 1895 - 1896, which were auctioned by Christie's in 2004.

title: Douglas Ainslie
text: (http://www.bestofsherlock.com/ref/200405christies_lots.htm) See "The Identification of Ainslie" by Al Dawson in "The Magic Door", v. 14, no. 2 (Summer 2012), pp. 1,6,7 - a publication of The Friends of the Arthur Conan Doyle Collection, Toronto Public Libraries.

title: Adrian Conan Doyle
text: Adrian Malcolm Conan Doyle (19 November 19103 June 1970) was the youngest son of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and his second wife Jean, Lady Doyle or Lady Conan Doyle.

title: Adrian Conan Doyle
text: He had two siblings, sister Jean and brother Denis, as well as two half-siblings, sister Mary and brother Kingsley.

title: The Red-Headed League
text: "The Red-Headed League" is one of the 56 Sherlock Holmes short stories written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

title: The Red-Headed League
text: It first appeared in "The Strand Magazine" in August 1891, with illustrations by Sidney Paget.

title: The Red-Headed League
text: Conan Doyle ranked "The Red-Headed League" second in his list of his twelve favourite Holmes stories.

title: The Red-Headed League
text: It is also the second of the twelve stories in "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes", which was published in 1892.

title: The Return of Sherlock Holmes (1929 film)
text: The Return of Sherlock Holmes is a 1929 American Pre-Code mystery film directed by Basil Dean and written by Arthur Conan Doyle, Basil Dean and Garrett Fort.

title: The Return of Sherlock Holmes (1929 film)
text: The film shares its title with the third volume of the Sherlock Holmes stories, "The Return of Sherlock Holmes" by Arthur Conan Doyle.

title: The Return of Sherlock Holmes (1929 film)
text: The film stars Clive Brook, H. Reeves-Smith, Betty Lawford, Charles Hay and Phillips Holmes.

title: The Return of Sherlock Holmes (1929 film)
text: The film was released October 29, 1929, by Paramount Pictures.

title: The Return of Sherlock Holmes (1929 film)
text: A copy is held at the Library of Congress.

title: Sherlock Holmes (2010 film)
text: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes, also known simply as Sherlock Holmes, is a British-American 2010 steampunk mystery film directed by Rachel Lee Goldenberg and produced by independent American film studio The Asylum.

title: Sherlock Holmes (2010 film)
text: It features the Sherlock Holmes characters created by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, though it follows an original plot.

title: Sherlock Holmes (2010 film)
text: The film details an unrecorded case in which eccentric detective Holmes and his companion Dr. Watson investigate a series of unusual monster attacks and a plot to destroy London.

title: Sherlock Holmes (2010 film)
text: Gareth David-Lloyd plays Dr. John Watson and Ben Syder, making his film debut, plays Sherlock Holmes.

title: Dead Man's Land
text: Dead Man's Land is a book by Robert Ryan, based in World War I.

title: Dead Man's Land
text: It involves Sherlock Holmes' sidekick, Dr. Watson (created by Arthur Conan Doyle).

title: Dead Man's Land
text: It is fully authorized by Conan Doyle Estate Ltd. "Dead Man' Land" has been written under license from the Sir Arthur Conan Doyle literary Estate

title: The Adventure of the Empty House
text: "The Adventure of the Empty House", one of the 56 Sherlock Holmes short stories written by British author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, is one of 13 stories in the cycle collected as "The Return of Sherlock Holmes".

title: The Adventure of the Empty House
text: Public pressure forced Conan Doyle to bring the sleuth back to life, and explain his apparently miraculous survival of a deadly struggle with Professor Moriarty.

title: The Adventure of the Empty House
text: Doyle ranked "The Adventure of the Empty House" sixth in his list of his twelve favorite Holmes stories.

title: The Lost World (TV series)
text: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's The Lost World is a syndicated television series loosely based on the 1912 novel by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, "The Lost World".

title: The Lost World (TV series)
text: The show premiered in the United States in the fall of 1999 (after the TV-movie/pilot aired in February on DirecTV and then on the cable television channel TNT in April), it ran for three seasons before it was cancelled on a cliffhanger in 2002 after funding for a fourth season fell through.

title: The Lost World (TV series)
text: To this day, the cliffhanger remains unresolved.

title: The Lost World (TV series)
text: All three seasons were released in DVD box sets in 2004.

title: Sherlock Holmes (1916 film)
text: Sherlock Holmes is a 1916 American silent film starring William Gillette as Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes.

title: Sherlock Holmes (1916 film)
text: The film, which was directed by Arthur Berthelet, was produced by Essanay Studios in Chicago.

title: Sherlock Holmes (1916 film)
text: It was adapted from the 1899 stage play of the same name, which was based on the stories, "A Scandal in Bohemia," "The Final Problem," and "A Study in Scarlet" by Arthur Conan Doyle.

title: Der Hund von Baskerville
text: Der Hund von Baskerville is a 1914 German silent film adaptation of Arthur Conan Doyle's "The Hound of the Baskervilles".

title: Der Hund von Baskerville
text: This was the first film adaptation of the famed Conan Doyle novel.

title: Der Hund von Baskerville
text: According to the website silentera.com, the film was considered lost, but has been rediscovered; the Russian Gosfilmofond film archive possesses a print, while the Filmmuseum München has a 35mm positive print.

title: 1896 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1896 Tennessee Volunteers football team represented the University of Tennessee in the 1896 college football season.

title: 1896 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: It was the first official Tennessee Volunteers football team since 1893.

title: 1896 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1896 Vols went undefeated at 4–0 for the first winning season in school history.

title: 1896 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: This was also the Tennessee's first season in the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association (SIAA), though they did not play a conference opponent.

title: 1929 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1929 Tennessee Volunteers football team (variously "Tennessee", "UT" or the "Vols") represented the University of Tennessee in the 1929 college football season.

title: 1929 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Playing as a member of the Southern Conference (SoCon), the team was led by head coach Robert Neyland, in his fourth year, and played their home games at Shields-Watkins Field in Knoxville, Tennessee.

title: 1929 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1928 Vols won nine, lost zero and tied one game (9–0–1 overall, 6–0–1 in the SoCon).

title: 1929 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: In a virtual repeat of the previous year, a tie with Kentucky spoiled Tennessee's perfect season.

title: 1929 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Playing eight home games, the Volunteers outscored their opponents 330 to 13 and posted eight shutouts.

title: 1938 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1938 Tennessee Volunteers football team represented the University of Tennessee in the 1938 season.

title: 1938 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Head coach Robert Neyland fielded his third team at Tennessee after returning from active duty in the United States Army.

title: 1938 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1938 Tennessee Volunteers won the school's first national championship and are regarded as one of the greatest teams in SEC and NCAA history.

title: 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team (variously "Tennessee", "UT" or the "Vols") represented the University of Tennessee in the 1985 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Playing as a member of the Southeastern Conference (SEC), the team was led by head coach Johnny Majors, in his ninth year, and played their home games at Neyland Stadium in Knoxville, Tennessee.

title: 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: They finished the season with a record of nine wins, one loss and two ties (9–1–2 overall, 5–1 in the SEC), as SEC champions and with a victory over Miami in the 1986 Sugar Bowl.

title: 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The Volunteers offense scored 325 points while the defense allowed 140 points.

title: 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: At season’s end, the Volunteers ranked fourth in both the AP Poll and the Coaches' Poll.

title: 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team (variously "Tennessee", "UT" or the "Vols") represented the University of Tennessee in the 1930 college football season.

title: 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Playing as a member of the Southern Conference (SoCon), the team was led by head coach Robert Neyland, in his fifth year, and played their home games at Shields-Watkins Field in Knoxville, Tennessee.

title: 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1930 Vols won nine and lost one game (9–1 overall, 6–1 in the SoCon).

title: 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The only loss of the season came on October 18 to eventual Rose Bowl champion, Alabama.

title: 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Tennessee and Vanderbilt were the only teams to score against Alabama in 1930.

title: 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1930 Volunteers team outscored their opponents 209 to 31 and posted seven shutouts

title: 1899 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1899 Tennessee Volunteers football team represented the University of Tennessee in the 1899 Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association football season.

title: 1899 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: They were the first UT team to have a head coach.

title: 1899 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: J. A. Pierce helmed the team in 1899 and 1900.

title: 1899 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1899 Tennessee Volunteers won six games and lost two.

title: 1992 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1992 Tennessee Volunteers football team represented the University of Tennessee in the 1992 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1992 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The Volunteers were a member of the Southeastern Conference (SEC), in the Eastern Division and played their home games at Neyland Stadium in Knoxville, Tennessee.

title: 1992 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: They finished the season with a record of nine wins and three (9–3 overall, 5–3 in the SEC) and with a victory over Boston College in the Hall of Fame Bowl.

title: 1992 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The Volunteers offense scored 347 points while the defense allowed 196 points.

title: 1891 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1891 Tennessee Volunteers football team represented the University of Tennessee in the 1891 season.

title: 1891 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: This was the first Tennessee Volunteers football team.

title: 1891 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: They traveled on Thanksgiving Day to Chattanooga, Tennessee to face Sewanee.

title: 1891 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: They had no head coach and were mainly an intramural team.

title: Tennessee Volunteers football statistical leaders
text: The Tennessee Volunteers football statistical leaders are individual statistical leaders of the Tennessee Volunteers football program in various categories, including passing, rushing, receiving, total offense, defensive stats, and kicking.

title: Tennessee Volunteers football statistical leaders
text: Within those areas, the lists identify single-game, single-season, and career leaders.

title: Tennessee Volunteers football statistical leaders
text: The Volunteers represent University of Tennessee in the NCAA's Southeastern Conference.

title: 1983 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The 1983 Tennessee Volunteers Tennessee Volunteers football team (variously "Tennessee", "UT" or the "Vols") represented the University of Tennessee in the 1983 NCAA Division I-A football season.

title: 1983 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: Playing as a member of the Southeastern Conference (SEC), the team was led by head coach Johnny Majors, in his seventh year, and played their home games at Neyland Stadium in Knoxville, Tennessee.

title: 1983 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: They finished the season with a record of nine wins and three losses (9–3 overall, 4–2 in the SEC) and a victory over Maryland in the Florida Citrus Bowl.

title: 1983 Tennessee Volunteers football team
text: The Volunteers offense scored 282 points while the defense allowed 165 points.

title: Ashley Rolfe
text: Ashley Rolfe is one of the United States Air Force female fighter pilots who qualified to fly McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle.

title: Ashley Rolfe
text: As a member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, she makes history at the 104th Fighter Wing as the first female fighter pilot in the wing’s 70-year history in Aug. 18, 2016.

title: Ashley Rolfe
text: She served in 67th Fighter Squadron at Kadena.

title: Ashley Rolfe
text: Kadena was Rolfe’s first duty assignment, where she also made history by serving in the 67th Fighter Squadron as the only female F-15 pilot.

title: Ashley Rolfe
text: In 2010 she was the only female fighter pilot participating in Exercise Commando Sling that appeared in Air Force TV News "One of a Kind".

title: Lydia Litvyak
text: Lydia Vladimirovna Litvyak (Лидия Владимировна Литвяк, (August 18, 1921 in Moscow – August 1, 1943 in Krasnyi Luch), also known as Lilya, was a fighter pilot in the Soviet Air Force during World War II.

title: Lydia Litvyak
text: With twelve solo victories and four shared kills over a total of 66 combat missions, over about two years of missions, she was the first female fighter pilot to shoot down an enemy plane, the first of two female fighter pilots who have earned the title of fighter ace, and the holder of the record for the greatest number of kills by a female fighter pilot.

title: Lydia Litvyak
text: She was shot down near Orel during the Battle of Kursk as she attacked a formation of German planes.

title: Manfred Meurer
text: Manfred Meurer (8 September 1919 – 22 January 1944) was a German fighter pilot during World War II.

title: Manfred Meurer
text: A flying ace, he claimed 65 aerial victories making him the fifth most successful night fighter pilot in the history of aerial warfare.

title: Manfred Meurer
text: All of his victories were claimed over the Western Front in Defense of the Reich missions against the Royal Air Force's (RAF) Bomber Command.

title: Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag
text: Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag is an IMAX film centered on the experiences of a USAF F-15 Eagle fighter pilot, then-Captain John Stratton, who wants to be professionally successful as a fighter pilot.

title: Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag
text: It chronicles his experience during USAF Red Flag training at Nellis AFB, a simulated air war designed to train pilots for combat.

title: Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag
text: Directed by Stephen Low and presented by Boeing, the film shows how airmen simulate a war without killing one another, as well as the training of military air base firemen, military ordnance crews, midair refueling operations, cockpit views, and other aspects of aerial combat.

title: Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag
text: The film was released in December 2004.

title: Ayesha Farooq
text: Flight Lieutenant Ayesha Farooq (Urdu:عائشہ فاروق) (born August 24, 1987) is a Pakistani fighter pilot from Bahawalpur who is the first female to become fighter pilot in Pakistan Air Force.

title: Ayesha Farooq
text: In 2013, she became first and only Pakistani and South Asian female fighter pilot after topping the final exams to qualify.

title: Ayesha Farooq
text: She now flies missions in a Chinese-made Chengdu J-7 fighter jet alongside her 24 male colleagues in Squadron 20.

title: Ilmari Juutilainen
text: Eino Ilmari "Illu" Juutilainen (21 February 1914 – 21 February 1999) was a fighter pilot of the Ilmavoimat (Finnish Air Force), and the top scoring non-German fighter pilot of all time.

title: Ilmari Juutilainen
text: This makes him the top flying ace of the Finnish Air Force, leading all Finnish pilots in score against Soviet aircraft in World War II (1939–40 and 1941–44), with 94 confirmed aerial combat victories in 437 sorties.

title: Ilmari Juutilainen
text: He himself claimed 126 victories.

title: Ilmari Juutilainen
text: He achieved 34 of his victories while flying the Brewster Buffalo fighter.

title: Egon Mayer
text: Egon Mayer (19 August 1917 – 2 March 1944) was a German fighter pilot during World War II.

title: Egon Mayer
text: He was credited with 102 enemy aircraft shot down in over 353 combat missions.

title: Egon Mayer
text: His victories were all claimed over the Western Front.

title: Egon Mayer
text: Mayer was the first fighter pilot to score 100 victories entirely on the Western Front.

title: Paul Zorner
text: Paul Anton Guido Zorner, born Paul Zloch (31 March 1920 – 27 January 2014) was a German night fighter pilot, who fought in the "Luftwaffe" during World War II.

title: Paul Zorner
text: Zorner is credited with 59 night aerial victories claimed in 272 missions, including 110 night fighter missions.

title: Paul Zorner
text: Zorner was the ninth most successful fighter pilot in the "Luftwaffe" and in the history of aerial warfare.

title: Tadeusz Sawicz
text: Tadeusz Władysław Sawicz (13 February 1914 – 19 October 2011) was a Polish World War II fighter pilot.

title: Tadeusz Sawicz
text: He served in the Polish Air Force, and after the fall of Poland, he served in the Polish and allied units in France and United Kingdom.

title: Tadeusz Sawicz
text: He was the commander of several air units, including the No. 315 Polish Fighter Squadron, 1st Polish Fighter Wing, 3rd Polish Fighter Wing, 131st (Polish) Fighter Wing and 133rd Fighter Wing.

title: Tadeusz Sawicz
text: He participated in the Battle of Britain and was ranked as the 82nd highest scoring Polish fighter pilot of the war.

title: Wilhelm Crinius
text: Wilhelm Crinius (2 December 1920 – 26 April 1997) was a Luftwaffe fighter ace during World War II.

title: Wilhelm Crinius
text: A flying ace or fighter ace is a military aviator credited with shooting down five or more enemy aircraft during aerial combat.

title: Wilhelm Crinius
text: Crinius is credited with 114 aerial victories claimed in approximately 400 combat missions.

title: Wilhelm Crinius
text: He recorded 100 victories over the Eastern Front.

title: Wilhelm Crinius
text: Of his 14 victories claimed over the Western Front, one was a four-engined bomber.

title: Wilhelm Crinius
text: On 23 September 1942, Crinius became the only German fighter pilot to be awarded the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross ("Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes") and the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves ("Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes mit Eichenlaub") simultaneously.

title: Kavadh II
text: Shērōē (also spelled Shīrūya, شیرویه in New Persian), better known by his dynastic name of Kavadh II (Middle Persian: kwʾt' "Kawād"; New Persian: قباد‎ ‎ "Qobād" or "Qabād"), was king of the Sasanian Empire briefly in 628.

title: Kavadh II
text: He was the son of Khosrau II (590–628).

title: Kavadh II
text: He became king after orchestrating a coup d'état against his father.

title: Suintila
text: Suintila, or "Swinthila", "Svinthila"; (ca. 588 – 633/635) was Visigothic King of Hispania, Septimania and Galicia from 621 to 631.

title: Suintila
text: There was a new peace in the Kingdom of the Visigoths.

title: Suintila
text: As a direct result, by 624 the king was able to retake those lands that had been under the control of the Byzantine Empire.

title: Suintila
text: He was a son of Reccared I and wife Bado, and a brother of the general Geila.

title: Ashur-etil-ilani
text: Ashur-etil-ilani was a king of Assyria (c. 631 BC – c. 627 BC).

title: Ashur-etil-ilani
text: He succeeded his father Ashurbanipal.

title: Hormizd VI
text: Hormizd VI (Persian: هرمز‎ ‎ ) was a Sasanian king of parts of Persia from 630 to 631.

title: Hormizd VI
text: He was one of the many pretenders who rose after the murder of Khosrau II (590–628) in 628.

title: Hormizd VI
text: He maintained himself about two years (630–632) in the district of Nisibis.

title: Hormizd VI
text: He was the grandson of Khosrau II.

title: Duchy of Thuringia
text: The Duchy of Thuringia was an eastern frontier march of the Merovingian kingdom of Austrasia, established about 631 by King Dagobert I after his troops had been defeated by the forces of the Slavic confederation of Samo at the Battle of Wogastisburg.

title: Duchy of Thuringia
text: It was recreated in the Carolingian Empire and its dukes appointed by the king until it was absorbed by the Saxon dukes in 908.

title: Duchy of Thuringia
text: From about 1111/12 the territory was ruled by the Landgraves of Thuringia as Princes of the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Samo
text: Samo founded the first recorded political union of Slavic tribes, known as Samo's Empire ("realm", "kingdom", or "tribal union"), stretching from Silesia to present-day Slovenia, ruling from 623 until his death in 658.

title: Samo
text: According to Fredegarius, the only contemporary source, Samo was a Frankish merchant who unified several Slavic tribes against robber raids and violence by nearby settled Avars, showing such bravery and command skills in battle that he was elected as the "Slavic king" (Latin: "Rex Sclavorum" ).

title: Samo
text: In 631, Samo successfully defended his realm against the Frankish Kingdom in the three-day Battle of Wogastisburg.

title: Chach of Alor
text: Chach (c. 631-711 CE) (Sindhi: چچ‎ ) was a Brahmin who reigned as king of Sindh in the mid-7th century CE.

title: Chach of Alor
text: A former prime minister to the king Rai Sahasi II, Chach ascended to the throne by marrying the king's widow.

title: Chach of Alor
text: The Brahmin dynasty under Chach expanded the kingdom of Sindh, and his successful efforts to subjugate surrounding monarchies and ethnic groups into an empire covering the entire Indus valley and beyond were recorded in the "Chach Nama".

title: Samo's Empire
text: Samo's Empire is the historiographical name for the Slavic tribal union established by King ("rex") Samo, which existed between 631 and 658 A.D..

title: Samo's Empire
text: The centre of the union was most likely in Moravia, while the union included Silesia, Bohemia, Lusatia and Carantania.

title: Khosrow IV
text: Khosrow IV was a Sasanian usurper who ruled briefly in 631.

title: Khosrow IV
text: Little is known about his rule, he appears to have ruled during a time of upheaval and chaos across the Sasanian Empire the 7th century has the century where Iran has plunged into its "dark ages".

title: Khosrow IV
text: He was the son of Mah-Adhur Gushnasp, who was the minister of the Sasanian Empire during the reign of Ardashir III, and Kahar-dukht, the daughter of Yazdandar, who was the son of Khosrau I.

title: Khosrow IV
text: His rule seems to coincide with other pretenders such as Hormizd VI so it is likely that he ruled a district or province rather than the Empire in its entirety.

title: Khosrow IV
text: He was killed after a few days of reign.

title: Farrukhzad Khosrow V
text: Farrukhzad Khosrau V was briefly king of the Sasanian Empire from March 631 to April 631.

title: Farrukhzad Khosrow V
text: He was the son of Khosrau II.

title: The Greatest Gift (TV series)
text: The Greatest Gift was a 1950s US TV soap opera featuring actors Ward Costello, Anne Meara and Jack Klugman as Jim Hanson.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: John Black is a fictional character from "Days of Our Lives", an American soap opera on the NBC network.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: He has been played by actor Drake Hogestyn since 1986, with a break in between from January 2009 to September 2011.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: John was created by script writers Sheri Anderson, Thom Racina and Leah Laiman as The Pawn in 1985 and introduced by executive producers Betty Corday and Al Rabin.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: John becomes one of "Days of Our Lives' " most popular characters when he is revealed to be the presumed dead Roman Brady (Wayne Northrop) with plastic surgery and amnesia.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: However, Northrop's return in 1991 led to Hogestyn's Roman being retconned into the entirely separate character of John Black, which also establishes the supercouple pairing of John and Marlena, due to John's affair with Roman's wife, Marlena Evans (Deidre Hall).

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: During the time in which he believes he is Roman, John picks up the mantle of Roman's feud with the notorious international criminal Stefano DiMera (Joseph Mascolo).

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: John and Stefano's feud is central to the character's history as Stefano is partly responsible for John's memory loss.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: Their lives are further intertwined in 2008 when the two are falsely led to believe they are half brothers—a story that was later disproved.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: Hogestyn's portrayal has made him one of daytime's most popular and recognizable stars.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: Hogestyn was attributed with helping the series out of its ratings slump in the 1980s.

title: John Black (Days of Our Lives)
text: He was often featured in soap opera magazines such as "Soap Opera Digest" and "Soap Opera Weekly".

title: Alamo Heights SA
text: Alamo Heights SA is a dramatic soap opera featuring San Antonio, Texas as the backdrop.

title: Alamo Heights SA
text: It made history several ways.

title: Beverly Marshall
text: Beverly Marshall is a fictional character from the Australian soap opera "Neighbours".

title: Beverly Marshall
text: The character was originally played by Lisa Armytage and she made her first on-screen appearance on 6 July 1987.

title: Beverly Marshall
text: Shaunna O'Grady took over from Armytage and began playing the character from 16 March 1989 until her departure on 5 September 1990.

title: Beverly Marshall
text: Beverly is a doctor and was Jim Robinson's second wife.

title: Beverly Marshall
text: O'Grady reprised her role of Beverly in 2005 to help celebrate "Neighbours"<nowiki>'</nowiki> 20th anniversary, she made a cameo in Annalise Hartman's documentary on Ramsay Street.

title: Roger Howarth
text: Roger Howarth (born September 13, 1968) is an American actor.

title: Roger Howarth
text: He played character Todd Manning on the daytime drama "One Life to Live" ("OLTL"); the character earned Howarth a Daytime Emmy Award in 1994, and is cited as an icon in the soap opera genre.

title: Roger Howarth
text: He left the series in 2003 and joined soap opera "As the World Turns", where he played the character of Paul Ryan until the series final episode in 2010.

title: Roger Howarth
text: Howarth returned to "OLTL" in May 2011, eventually deciding to continue the role on "General Hospital" in March 2012.

title: Roger Howarth
text: He now portrays Franco on "General Hospital," the character formerly created and portrayed by James Franco.

title: Roger Howarth
text: In addition to his soap opera work, Howarth has guest starred in television shows such as "Prey" and "Dawson's Creek".

title: Shaunna O'Grady
text: Shaunna O'Grady (born 1958) is an Australian retired actress who played the second incarnation of Jim Robinson's wife, Dr. Beverly Marshall, on the long-running soap opera "Neighbours".

title: Shaunna O'Grady
text: She is the granddaughter of writer John O'Grady (author of "They're a Weird Mob"), and is married to the television director Chris Adshead.

title: Shaunna O'Grady
text: They have one daughter, Savannah.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: Philip James "Phil" Mitchell is a long-standing fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Steve McFadden.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: Phil was introduced to the soap opera on 20 February 1990, and was followed by his brother, Grant (Ross Kemp), sister Sam (Danniella Westbrook/Kim Medcalf) and mother Peggy (Jo Warne/Barbara Windsor).

title: Phil Mitchell
text: Phil is one of the major introductions made by executive producer Michael Ferguson, who wanted to bring in some macho, male leads.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: Phil and his brother Grant became popularly known as the Mitchell brothers in the British media with Phil initially portrayed as the more level-headed of the two thugs.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: Storylines featuring the Mitchell family dominated the soap opera throughout the 1990s, with Phil becoming a popular and long-running male protagonist into the 2000s and the 2010s.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: McFadden temporarily left the series in late 2003 then returned in March 2005 for a short stint, before making a permanent return in October 2005.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: McFadden took a hiatus from the series at the end of Phil's liver cirrhosis storyline with the character departing on 6 February 2017.

title: Phil Mitchell
text: He returned on 24 July.

title: Katie Landers
text: Katie Landers is a fictional character from the Australian soap opera "Neighbours", played by Sally Jensen.

title: Katie Landers
text: She made her first on screen appearance on 15 February 1988.

title: Katie Landers
text: Katie is the niece of Beverly Marshall and sister to Todd Landers.

title: Katie Landers
text: During her time in the show, she became close friends with Toby Mangel.

title: Katie Landers
text: Katie departed on 6 September 1989.

title: Leslie Schofield
text: Leslie Schofield (born 12 December 1938 in Oldham, Lancashire) is an English actor who is most famous in the UK for his role as Jeff Healy in the popular soap opera, "EastEnders" whom he played from 1997 to 2000.

title: Leslie Schofield
text: His character was famous for unsuccessfully proposing to Pauline Fowler (played by Wendy Richard).

title: Leslie Schofield
text: He also appeared in "EastEnders" briefly in 1988 and 1989 playing a different character named Brian Wicks.

title: Victor Newman
text: Victor Newman is a fictional character from the American CBS soap opera "The Young and the Restless".

title: Victor Newman
text: He has been portrayed by Eric Braeden since 1980.

title: Victor Newman
text: Initially a guest character who was to last for eight to twelve weeks, Victor has evolved into the soap opera's leading male figure.

title: Victor Newman
text: Created by William J. Bell as a "despicable, contemptible, unfaithful wife abuser", the character was planned to be killed off and never heard of again.

title: Victor Newman
text: However, after Bell saw Braeden's performance, he decided to sign the actor onto a contract.

title: Victor Newman
text: Braeden was hesitant to work on a soap opera, but eventually signed a contract, and has remained on the series as a regular cast member for a total of thirty-seven years.

title: Victor Newman
text: The character is widely described as ruthless, and while loving to those he holds dear, is considered a villain.

title: Victor Newman
text: Over the years, he has also been the center of several controversial plots and relationships.

title: Falkland Islands at the 2014 Commonwealth Games
text: The Falkland Islands is represented at the 2014 Commonwealth Games in Glasgow by 25 athletes across three sports, Badminton, Shooting and Lawn Bowls, the largest ever Falkland Islands squad to be sent to the Commonwealth Games.

title: Samoa
text: The Independent State of Samoa (Samoan: "Malo Saʻoloto Tutoʻatasi o Sāmoa" , ] ), commonly known as Samoa (Samoan: "Sāmoa" ) and, until 1997, known as Western Samoa, is a unitary parliamentary democracy with eleven administrative divisions.

title: Samoa
text: The two main islands are Savai'i and Upolu with four smaller islands surrounding the landmasses.

title: Samoa
text: The capital city is Apia.

title: Samoa
text: The Lapita people discovered and settled the Samoan islands around 3,500 years ago.

title: Samoa
text: They developed a unique language and cultural identity.

title: Archery at the Commonwealth Games
text: Archery is one of the optional sports at the quadrennial Commonwealth Games competition.

title: Archery at the Commonwealth Games
text: It has been a Commonwealth Games sport since 1982, but has only featured twice in the competition's history; at the 1982 Commonwealth Games and at the 2010 Commonwealth Games.

title: Archery at the Commonwealth Games
text: It is an optional sport and may or may not be included in the sporting programme of each edition of the Games.

title: Archery at the Commonwealth Games
text: The host country of the games decides whether to include it.

title: Falkland Islands official football team
text: The Falkland Islands official football team is a representative football team of the Falkland Islands, organised by the Falkland Islands Football League.

title: Falkland Islands official football team
text: The Falkland Islands Football League does not belong to the CONMEBOL, as its member countries support Argentina in the sovereignty conflict, and therefore neither can be a member of FIFA.

title: Falkland Islands official football team
text: Thus, the team is not eligible to play in official competitions such as the World Cup and the Copa América.

title: Falkland Islands official football team
text: The team has played in the Island Games in 2001, 2005, 2009, 2011, 2013, 2015 and 2017.

title: Falkland Islands official football team
text: In 2013 the team enjoyed a record win and a 3rd place medal.

title: Falkland Islands at the 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: Falkland Islands competed in the 2010 Commonwealth Games held in Delhi.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: The 2010 Commonwealth Games (Hindi: 2010 राष्ट्रमण्डल खेल), officially known as the XIX Commonwealth Games, were held in Delhi, India, from 3 to 14 October 2010.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: A total of 6,081 athletes from 71 Commonwealth nations and dependencies competed in 21 sports and 272 events, making it the largest Commonwealth Games to date.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: It was also the largest international multi-sport event to be staged in Delhi and India, eclipsing the Asian Games in 1951 and 1982.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: The opening and closing ceremonies were held at the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium, the main stadium of the event.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: It was the first time that the Commonwealth Games were held in India and the second time they were held in Asia after Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 1998.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: It was also the first time a Commonwealth Republic hosted the games, second in a country not presently headed by British monarch since Malaysia in 1998.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games
text: The official mascot of the Games was "Shera" and the official song of the Games, "Jiyo Utho Bado Jeeto", was composed by celebrated Indian musician A.R. Rahman.

title: George Paice (bowls)
text: George Paice born 1941 in Fox Bay Falkland Islands is a New Zealand-based Falkland Islands Lawn Bowler who represented the Falkland Islands at the 2010 Commonwealth Games in Delhi India in the men's pairs alongside playing partner Gerald Reive.

title: George Paice (bowls)
text: The pair achieved two victories at the games, over Guernsey and Samoa.

title: George Paice (bowls)
text: Paice currently plays out of the Papatoetoe Hunters Corner Bowling Club in Auckland New Zealand.

title: Gerald Reive
text: Gerald Reive (born 10 March 1937) is a New Zealand-based Falkland Islands athlete who represented his country at the 2010 Commonwealth Games in New Delhi, India in Lawn Bowls in the men's pairs event, alongside his playing partner George Paice.

title: Gerald Reive
text: They achieved wins against Samoa and Guernsey.

title: Gerald Reive
text: Reive was the flag bearer for the Falkland Islands at the closing ceremony.

title: Gerald Reive
text: He currently plays lawn bowls at the Papatoetoe Hunters Corner Bowling Club in Auckland He attended his second Commonwealth Games in Glasgow 2014 where he entered the men's fours with Michael Reive, Patrick Morrison, and Barry Ford.

title: KTV Ltd.
text: KTV Ltd. is a DVB-T SD and HD encrypted UHF TV and radio service operating in Stanley, capital of the Falkland Islands, and also in part of the Camp.

title: KTV Ltd.
text: The charge for receiving the service of 33 TV and radio channels is £36 per month.

title: KTV Ltd.
text: Founded in 1980 by Sharon and Mario Zuvic Bulic, KTV Ltd. receives channels from the UK, US, Saint Helena Island, and Chile and rebroadcasts them to subscribers in the Falkland Islands.

title: KTV Ltd.
text: KTV Ltd. cooperates with a number of other small radio broadcasting companies in other British overseas territories, notably Saint FM in St Helena, the Falkland Islands Radio Service (FIRS), and Myriam's Country.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games medal table
text: The 2010 Commonwealth Games (officially known as the XIX Commonwealth Games), was a multi-sport event held in Delhi, India from 3 to 14 October 2010.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games medal table
text: It was the first time that India hosted the Commonwealth Games and the second time it was held in Asia after Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 1998.

title: 2010 Commonwealth Games medal table
text: A total of 6,081 athletes from 71 Commonwealth Games Associations (CGAs) participated in this Games, competing in 272 events in 21 sports.

title: Wet Hot American Summer (series)
text: The Wet Hot American Summer series is an American satirical comedy film and two Netflix series' directed by David Wain and written by Wain and Michael Showalter.

title: Wet Hot American Summer (series)
text: The series features an ensemble cast, including Janeane Garofalo, Molly Shannon, Paul Rudd, Christopher Meloni, Michael Showalter (and various other members of MTV's sketch comedy group The State), Elizabeth Banks, Ken Marino, Michael Ian Black, Bradley Cooper, Amy Poehler, Zak Orth, David Hyde Pierce and A. D. Miles.

title: Wet Hot American Summer (series)
text: The film takes place during the last full day at a fictional summer camp in 1981, and spoofs the sex comedies aimed at teen audiences of that era.

title: Wet Hot American Summer (series)
text: The first Netflix series was a prequel to the film focusing on the first day of camp in 1981.

title: Wet Hot American Summer (series)
text: The second Netflix series sees the camp counselors return to Camp Firewood 10 years later, as originally planned in the final scene of the 2001 film.

title: Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)
text: Claire Temple is a character portrayed by Rosario Dawson in the television series of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), based on the comic characters Claire Temple and Night Nurse.

title: Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)
text: A nurse who gives medical aid to vigilantes, she first appeared in the first season of "Daredevil" (2015–).

title: Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)
text: Dawson then signed a deal to return for the second season of the series, as well as potentially appear in any other Marvel Netflix series.

title: Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)
text: She has since reprised the role in "Jessica Jones", "Luke Cage", "Iron Fist", and "The Defenders".

title: Claire Temple (Marvel Cinematic Universe)
text: The character has also appeared in a "Jessica Jones" tie-in comic.

title: Azie Mira Dungey
text: Azie Mira Dungey is an American actress, comedian and writer.

title: Azie Mira Dungey
text: She wrote and played the lead role in the comedic web series "Ask a Slave," and is currently, ". . .writing a book as a follow-up to the series."

title: Azie Mira Dungey
text: Dungey is also currently a writer for the Netflix series "Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt", produced by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock.

title: List of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt episodes
text: "Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt" is an American sitcom created by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock, starring Ellie Kemper in the title role, that has streamed on Netflix since March 6, 2015.

title: List of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt episodes
text: Originally set for a 13-episode first season on NBC for spring 2015, the show was sold to Netflix and given a two-season order.

title: Brenda Bennett
text: Brenda Bennett (born Brenda Elizabeth Claire Siobhan; 24 January 1962) is a British-American singer from Scotland.

title: Brenda Bennett
text: She is best known as a member of the American group Vanity 6 who married the musician Prince's set-designer Roy Bennett, and then became Prince's "wardrobe mistress."

title: Brenda Bennett
text: She started off in a CBS Records band called Ken Lyon and Tombstone which toured with Mott the Hoople and Queen.

title: Brenda Bennett
text: Years later, through Roy Bennett, Prince gave her a "tough-girl, cigarette-smoking" persona and enlisted her in a girlgroup, Vanity 6, that he was attempting to create in 1982.

title: Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt
text: Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt is an American television sitcom created by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock, starring Ellie Kemper in the title role, that has streamed on Netflix since March 6, 2015.

title: Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt
text: Originally set for a 13-episode first season on NBC for spring 2015, the show was sold to Netflix and given a two-season order.

title: Claire Liddell
text: Elizabeth Claire Liddell (b. 24 May ?)

title: Claire Liddell
text: is a Scottish pianist and composer.

title: Claire Liddell
text: She was born in Glasgow and studied at the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama in Glasgow and the Royal College of Music in London with Andrew Lloyd Webber.

title: Sam Means
text: Sam Means is an American comedy writer.

title: Sam Means
text: He won three Emmy awards for his work on "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart", and wrote for both "30 Rock" and "Parks and Recreation" on NBC.

title: Sam Means
text: He is currently a writer and producer on the Netflix series "Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt".

title: Ellie Kemper
text: Elizabeth Claire Kemper (born May 2, 1980) is an American actress and comedian.

title: Ellie Kemper
text: She gained prominence when she starred in the NBC series "The Office" as receptionist Erin Hannon for the final five seasons.

title: Ellie Kemper
text: After her role in "The Office", she was cast in a leading role as Kimmy Schmidt in the Netflix comedy series "Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt", for which she has received critical acclaim.

title: Ellie Kemper
text: Kemper is also known for her supporting roles in the films "Bridesmaids" (2011) and "21 Jump Street" (2012).

title: Jon Bernthal
text: Jonathan Edward "Jon" Bernthal (born September 20, 1976) is an American actor best known for his television role as Shane Walsh on the AMC series "The Walking Dead" and film roles in "The Wolf of Wall Street" (2013), "Fury" (2014), "Sicario" (2015), "The Accountant" (2016), "Baby Driver" (2017), & "Wind River" (2017).

title: Jon Bernthal
text: He portrayed LAPD Detective Joe Teague in "Mob City" and Frank Castle (a.k.a.

title: Jon Bernthal
text: The Punisher) in the Netflix series "Daredevil", and is set to reprise the latter role in the Netflix series "The Punisher".

title: Carole Gray
text: Carole Gray (born 1940 in Bulawayo, Rhodesia (today's Zimbabwe) is a former British dancer and actress who in the 1960s, particularly in West End musicals.

title: Carole Gray
text: She appeared in television series such as "The Avengers", and made her film debut as Cliff Richard's girlfriend Toni in "The Young Ones" (1961).

title: Carole Gray
text: Thereafter, she appeared mainly in horror films, such as "Curse of the Fly", "Devils of Darkness", and "Island of Terror", and was given the nickname the "Scream Queen".

title: Carole Gray
text: She was married to diamond heir Douglas Cullinan.

title: Ben Elton
text: Benjamin Charles Elton (born 3 May 1959) is an English comedian, author, playwright, actor and director.

title: Ben Elton
text: He was a part of London's alternative comedy movement of the 1980s and became a writer on series such as "The Young Ones" and "Blackadder", as well as continuing as a stand-up comedian on stage and television.

title: Ben Elton
text: His style in the 1980s was left-wing political satire.

title: Ben Elton
text: Since then he has published 15 novels and written the musicals "We Will Rock You" (2002) and "Love Never Dies" (2010), the sequel to "The Phantom of the Opera".

title: Ben Elton
text: His novels cover the Dystopian, Satire, and Crime genres.

title: David Mirkin
text: David Mirkin (born September 18, 1955) is an American feature film and television director, writer and producer.

title: David Mirkin
text: Mirkin grew up in Philadelphia and intended to become an electrical engineer, but abandoned this career path in favor of studying film at Loyola Marymount University.

title: David Mirkin
text: After graduating, he became a stand-up comedian, and then moved into television writing.

title: David Mirkin
text: He wrote for the sitcoms "Three's Company", "It's Garry Shandling's Show" and "The Larry Sanders Show" and served as showrunner on the series "Newhart".

title: David Mirkin
text: After an unsuccessful attempt to remake the British series "The Young Ones", Mirkin created "Get a Life" in 1990.

title: David Mirkin
text: The series starred comedian Chris Elliott and ran for two seasons, despite a lack of support from many Fox network executives, who disliked the show's dark and surreal humor.

title: David Mirkin
text: He moved on to create the sketch show "The Edge" starring his then-partner, actress Julie Brown.

title: Filthy Rich & Catflap
text: Filthy Rich & Catflap is a BBC sitcom produced in 1986 and broadcast in 1987.

title: Filthy Rich & Catflap
text: The series featured former "The Young Ones" co-stars Nigel Planer, Rik Mayall, and Adrian Edmondson as its three title characters.

title: Filthy Rich & Catflap
text: It was written by Ben Elton (with additional material credited to Mayall), and produced and directed by Paul Jackson (who also directed "The Young Ones"), with film sequences directed by Ed Bye.

title: Filthy Rich & Catflap
text: The show's music was written by Peter Brewis.

title: Filthy Rich & Catflap
text: One series consisting of six half-hour episodes was produced.

title: Oh, No! Not THEM!
text: Oh, No!

title: Oh, No! Not THEM!
text: Not THEM!

title: Oh, No! Not THEM!
text: is a 1990 American television series remake of the British television show "The Young Ones".

title: The Young Ones (TV series)
text: The Young Ones is a British sitcom, broadcast in the United Kingdom from 1982 to 1984 in two six-part series.

title: The Young Ones (TV series)
text: Shown on BBC2, it featured anarchic, offbeat humour which helped bring alternative comedy to television in the 1980s and made household names of its writers and performers.

title: The Young Ones (TV series)
text: In 1985, it was shown on MTV, one of the first non-music television shows on the fledgling channel.

title: The Young Ones (TV series)
text: In a 2004 poll, it ranked at number 31 in the BBC's list of "Britain's Best Sitcoms".

title: The Young Ones (TV series)
text: The show's title relates to the song of the same name, written by Sid Tepper and Roy C. Bennett, and sung by Cliff Richard and The Shadows, which was a No. 1 UK hit single.

title: Ade Edmondson
text: Adrian Charles "Ade" Edmondson (born 24 January 1957) is an English comedian, actor, writer, musician, television presenter and director.

title: Ade Edmondson
text: He came to prominence in the early 1980s and was part of the alternative comedy boom.

title: Ade Edmondson
text: He is probably best known for his comedic roles in the television series "The Young Ones" (1982–84) and "Bottom" (1991–95), which he wrote together with his long-time collaborative partner Rik Mayall.

title: Ade Edmondson
text: Edmondson also appeared in "The Comic Strip Presents..." series of films throughout the 1980s and 1990s.

title: Ade Edmondson
text: For one episode of this he created the spoof heavy metal band Bad News, and for another he played his nihilistic alter-ego Eddie Monsoon, an offensive South African television star.

title: Roland Rat
text: Roland Rat is a British television puppet character.

title: Roland Rat
text: He was created, operated and voiced by David Claridge, who had previously designed and operated Mooncat a puppet in the Children's ITV television programme "Get Up and Go!

title: Roland Rat
text: " He worked for Jim Henson, then the second series of "The Young Ones".

title: Roland Rat
text: Claridge would later operate and voice Brian the Dinosaur for BBC's "Parallel 9"; create and direct "Happy Monsters", a preschool series for Channel 5; and shoot a CGI series "Mozart's Dog" for Paramount Comedy.

title: The Young Ones (video game)
text: The Young Ones is a video game based on the British comedy television series, "The Young Ones".

title: Sichuan–Shanghai gas pipeline
text: Sichuan–Shanghai gas pipeline () is a 1702 km long natural gas pipeline in China.

title: Sichuan–Shanghai gas pipeline
text: The pipeline runs from Pugang gas field in Dazhou, Sichuan Province, to Qingpu District of Shanghai.

title: Sichuan–Shanghai gas pipeline
text: An 842 km long branch line connects Yichang in Hubei with Puyang in Henan Province.

title: Sichuan–Shanghai gas pipeline
text: Two shorter branches are located near the Puguang gas field and one in the east near Shanghai.

title: Tinghu District
text: Tinghu District () is one of three districts of Yancheng, Jiangsu province, China.

title: Tinghu District
text: (The other two are Yandu District and Dafeng District).

title: Tinghu District
text: Prior to 2004, Tinghu District was called the Urban District ()of Yancheng.

title: Dafeng District
text: Dafeng () is a coastal district under the administration of Yancheng, Jiangsu province, China.

title: Dafeng District
text: Located on the Jiangsu North Plain with a coastline of 112 km , Dafeng was historically one of the largest salt-making areas in China and now is famed for its well preserved eco-system and numerous national conservation parks.

title: Dafeng District
text: The district has the largest national nature reserve for a rare deer species, Père David's Deer or Milu (麋鹿 ) in Chinese.

title: Dafeng District
text: It borders the prefecture-level city of Taizhou to the southwest.

title: Yandu District
text: Yandu District () is one of three districts of Yancheng, Jiangsu province, China.

title: Yandu District
text: (The other two are Tinghu District and Dafeng District).

title: Kasi (Pashtun tribe)
text: The Kasi (Pashto: کاسي‎ ) or Kansi (Pashto: کانسي‎ ) are a Pashtun supertribe son of Kharshbun son of Sarban tribal confederacy, primarily found in Pakistan, and Afghanistan.

title: Kasi (Pashtun tribe)
text: A large part of the Kasi tribe live in the city of Quetta Balochistan, and Pakistan.

title: Kasi (Pashtun tribe)
text: Another large part of the Kasi confederacy is known as Shinwari, mainly settled in the eastern valleys of Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan and around Landi Kotal in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas, and Kohat District Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Pakistan.

title: Prophetstown State Park
text: Prophetstown State Park, named after Tenskwatawa ("The Prophet"), a religious leader and younger brother of Shawnee leader Tecumseh, is located near the town of Battle Ground, Indiana, United States, about a mile east of the site of the Battle of Tippecanoe.

title: Prophetstown State Park
text: Established in 2004, it is Indiana’s newest state park.

title: Prophetstown State Park
text: The park is home to the Museum at Prophetstown, which recreates a Native American village and a 1920s-era farm.

title: Tecumseh's Confederacy
text: Tecumseh's Confederacy was a group of Native Americans in the Old Northwest that began to form in the early 19th century around the teaching of Tenskwatawa (The Prophet).

title: Tecumseh's Confederacy
text: The confederation grew over several years and came to include several thousand warriors.

title: Tecumseh's Confederacy
text: Shawnee leader Tecumseh, the brother of The Prophet, developed into the leader of the group as early as 1808.

title: Tecumseh's Confederacy
text: Deemed a threat to the United States, a preemptive strike against the confederation was launched resulting in the 1811 Battle of Tippecanoe.

title: Tecumseh's Confederacy
text: Under Tecumseh's leadership, the confederation went to war with the United States during Tecumseh's War and the War of 1812.

title: Tecumseh's Confederacy
text: Following the death of Tecumseh in 1813 the confederation fell apart.

title: Battle of Tippecanoe
text: The Battle of Tippecanoe ( ) was fought on November 7, 1811, in what is now Battle Ground, Indiana, between American forces led by Governor William Henry Harrison of the Indiana Territory and Native American warriors associated with the Shawnee leader Tecumseh.

title: Battle of Tippecanoe
text: Tecumseh and his brother Tenskwatawa (commonly known as "The Prophet") were leaders of a confederacy of Native Americans from various tribes that opposed US expansion into Native territory.

title: Battle of Tippecanoe
text: As tensions and violence increased, Governor Harrison marched with an army of about 1,000 men to disperse the confederacy's headquarters at Prophetstown, near the confluence of the Tippecanoe and Wabash Rivers.

title: Tippecanoe order of battle
text: The following units of the U.S. Army and state militia forces under Indiana Governor William Henry Harrison, fought against the Native American warriors of Tecumseh's Confederacy, led by Chief Tecumseh's brother, Tenskwatawa "The Prophet" at the battle of Tippecanoe on November 7, 1811.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: Ẓafār or Dhafar (Ar ظفار) "Ðafār " (museum: UTM: 435700E, 1571160 N zone 38P, 14°12'N, 44°24'E, deviating slightly from Google Earth) is an ancient Himyarite site situated in Yemen, some 130 km south-south-east of today's capital, Sana'a.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: Given mention in several ancient texts, there is little doubt about the pronunciation of the name.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: Despite the opinion of local patriots in Oman, this site in the Yemen is far older than its namesake there.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: It lies in the Yemenite highlands at some 2800 m.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: The closest large town is Yarim, which is 10 km directly to the north-north-west.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: Zafar was the capital of the Himyarites (110 BCE - 525 CE), which at its peak ruled most of the Arabia.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: The Himyar are not a tribe, but rather a tribal confederacy.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: For 250 years the confederacy and its allies combined territory extended past Riyadh to the north and the Euphrates to the north-east.

title: Zafar, Yemen
text: Zafar was the Himyarite capital in Southern Arabia prior to the Aksumite conquest.

title: Ziri ibn Atiyya
text: Ziri ibn Atiyya (Berber language: Ziri n Ɛaṭiyya Ameɣraw) also known as Ziri ibn Atiyya ibn Abd Allah ibn Tabādalt ibn Muhammad ibn Khazar az-Zanātī al-Maghrāwī al-Khazarī (died 1001) was the first tribal leader of the Berber Maghrawa tribal confederacy and kingdom.

title: Battle of Fallen Timbers
text: The Battle of Fallen Timbers (August 20, 1794) was the final battle of the Northwest Indian War, a struggle between Native American tribes affiliated with the Western Confederacy, including support from the British led by Captain Alexander McKillop, against the United States for control of the Northwest Territory (an area north of the Ohio River, east of the Mississippi River, and southwest of the Great Lakes).

title: Battle of Fallen Timbers
text: This land had been ceded to the United States in accordance with the Treaty of Paris (1783), but the Native Americans (who had not been party to the treaty) refused to comply with the treaty and relinquish control.

title: Battle of Fallen Timbers
text: British army bases were maintained there to support their Native allies.

title: Battle of Fallen Timbers
text: This ultimately led to the American offensive and subsequent British-Indian withdrawal from the territory altogether following the Treaty of Greenville.

title: Battle of Fallen Timbers
text: The battle, which was a decisive victory for the United States, ended major hostilities in the region until Tecumseh's War and the Battle of Tippecanoe in 1811.

title: Tecumseh
text: Native American Shawnee warrior and chief, who became the primary leader of a large, multi-tribal confederacy in the early years of the nineteenth century.

title: Tecumseh
text: Born in the Ohio Country (present-day Ohio), and growing up during the American Revolutionary War and the Northwest Indian War, Tecumseh was exposed to warfare and envisioned the establishment of an independent Indian nation east of the Mississippi River under British protection and worked to recruit additional members to his tribal confederacy from the southern United States.

title: Tenskwatawa
text: Tenskwatawa (also called Tenskatawa, Tenskwatawah, Tensquatawa or Lalawethika) (January 1775 – November 1836) was a Native American religious and political leader of the Shawnee tribe, known as the Prophet or the Shawnee Prophet.

title: Tenskwatawa
text: He was a younger brother of Tecumseh, leader of the Shawnee.

title: Tenskwatawa
text: In his early years Tenskwatawa was given the name Lalawethika ("He Makes a Loud Noise" or "The Noise Maker"), but he changed it around 1805 and transformed himself from a hapless, alcoholic youth into an influential spiritual leader.

title: Tenskwatawa
text: Tenskwatawa denounced the Americans, calling them the offspring of the Evil Spirit, and lead a purification movement that promoted unity among the American Indians, rejected acculturation to the American way of life, and encouraged his followers to pursue traditional ways.

title: By the Beautiful Sea (song)
text: "By the Beautiful Sea" is a popular song published in 1914, with music written by Harry Carroll and lyrics written by Harold R. Atteridge.

title: By the Beautiful Sea (song)
text: The sheet music was published by Shapiro, Bernstein & Co.

title: Robin Hood (2018 film)
text: Robin Hood is an upcoming American action-adventure film directed by Otto Bathurst and written by Joby Harold, Peter Craig, and David James Kelly based on the tale of Robin Hood.

title: Robin Hood (2018 film)
text: The film stars Taron Egerton, Jamie Foxx, Eve Hewson, Ben Mendelsohn, Jamie Dornan, Tim Minchin, Björn Bengtsson, and Paul Anderson.

title: Robin Hood (2018 film)
text: It will be released by Lionsgate's Summit Entertainment in all IMAX theatres on September 21, 2018.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: Beautiful Young Minds was a documentary first shown at the BRITDOC Festival on 26 July 2007 and first broadcast on BBC 2 on 14 October 2007.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: The documentary follows the selection process and training for the U.K. team to compete in the 2006 International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO), as well as the actual event in Slovenia.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: Many of the young mathematicians featured in the film had a form of autism, which the documentary links to mathematical ability.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: The team goes on to win numerous medals at the IMO, including four silver and one bronze.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: It was directed by Morgan Matthews, edited by Joby Gee and featured music by Sam Hooper.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: It was also screened at the Bath Film Festival in October 2007.

title: Beautiful Young Minds
text: The documentary inspired the 2014 film X+Y, which was also directed by Morgan Matthews, based on IMO participant Daniel Lightwing.

title: Samuel Sim
text: Samuel Sim is a film and television composer.

title: Samuel Sim
text: He first gained recognition with his award winning score for the BBC drama series "Dunkirk".

title: Samuel Sim
text: Since then he has written the music for a wide variety of film and television productions, most recently scoring the film "Awake" for The Weinstein Company and the BBC/HBO drama series "House of Saddam".

title: Samuel Sim
text: His most recent acclaimed music is the soundtrack for Home Fires.

title: Samuel Sim
text: Home Fires (Music from the Television Series) released May 6, 2016 by Sony Classical Records.

title: Joby Talbot
text: Joby Talbot (born 25 August 1971) is a British composer.

title: Joby Talbot
text: He has written for a wide variety of purposes and an accordingly broad range of styles, including instrumental and vocal concert music, film and television scores, pop arrangements and works for dance.

title: Joby Talbot
text: He is therefore known to sometimes disparate audiences for quite different works.

title: King Arthur: Legend of the Sword
text: King Arthur: Legend of the Sword is a 2017 epic fantasy film directed by Guy Ritchie and written by Ritchie, Joby Harold and Lionel Wigram, inspired by Arthurian legends.

title: King Arthur: Legend of the Sword
text: The film stars Charlie Hunnam as the eponymous character, with Jude Law, Àstrid Bergès-Frisbey, Djimon Hounsou, Aidan Gillen and Eric Bana in supporting roles.

title: Awake (film)
text: Awake is a 2007 American conspiracy thriller film written and directed by Joby Harold.

title: Awake (film)
text: It stars Hayden Christensen, Jessica Alba, Terrence Howard and Lena Olin.

title: Awake (film)
text: The film was released in the United States and Canada on November 30, 2007.

title: Gidget Goes to Rome
text: Gidget Goes to Rome is a 1963 Columbia Pictures Eastmancolor feature film starring Cindy Carol as the archetypal high school teen surfer girl originally created by Sandra Dee in the 1959 film "Gidget".

title: Gidget Goes to Rome
text: The film is the third of three Gidget films directed by Paul Wendkos and expands upon Gidget's romance with boyfriend Moondoggie.

title: Gidget Goes to Rome
text: The screenplay was written by Ruth Brooks Flippen based on characters created by Frederick Kohner.

title: Gidget Goes to Rome
text: Veterans of previous Gidget films making appearances include James Darren as "Moondoggie", Joby Baker, and Jean "Jeff" Donnell as Gidget's mom, Mrs. Lawrence.

title: Gidget Goes to Rome
text: The film has been released to VHS and DVD.

title: Here (1954 song)
text: "Here" is a popular song, with music written by Harold Grant and lyrics by Dorcas Cochran, published in 1954.

title: Here (1954 song)
text: (Most sources show music and lyrics by both, but Cochran was a lyricist and Grant a composer.)

title: Here (1954 song)
text: The melody was adapted from the operatic aria, ""Caro nome,"" from the opera "Rigoletto" by Giuseppe Verdi.

title: Blog Wars
text: Blog Wars is a 2006 documentary film about the rise of political blogging and its influence on the 2006 midterm Connecticut senate election.

title: Blog Wars
text: Original musical score is composed by Samuel Sim.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: People of Irish descent form the largest single ethnic group in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: Once a Puritan stronghold, Boston changed dramatically in the 19th century with the arrival of European immigrants.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: The Irish dominated the first wave of newcomers during this period, especially following the Great Irish Famine.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: Their arrival transformed Boston from an Anglo-Saxon, Protestant city into one that has become progressively more diverse.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: The Yankees hired Irish as workers and servants, but there was little social interaction.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: In the 1840s and 50s, the anti-Catholic, anti-immigrant Know-Nothing movement targeted Irish Catholics in Boston.

title: History of Irish Americans in Boston
text: In the 1860s, many Irish immigrants fought for the Union in the American Civil War, and that display of patriotism helped to dispel some of the prejudice against them.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: The Pinpu tribe peoples, also called the Pepo or Plains tribes, are peoples that mainly settled in the western plains of Taiwan.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: They led a primitive agricultural life before the mass arrival of Han immigrants.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: Since the 17th century, they have faced the strong forces from outside, such as the Dutch, the Spanish, and the Han Chinese, and they have failed to resist their fate to be assimilated.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: By the end of 19th century, most Pingpu tribes had been almost completely Hanised (hanhua), and they have lost their languages and cultures.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: They have become an invisible ethnic group in a society highly dominated by the Han Chinese.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: During the period of Japanese rule, Japanese scholars conducted investigations and research on the Plains tribes based on anthropology and ethnology.

title: Pingpu peoples
text: The present categorization of the Plains tribes has resulted from their thorough study as the following:

title: Black Bermudian
text: African Bermudians or Bermudians of African descent are Bermudians whose ancestry lies within the continent of Africa.

title: Black Bermudian
text: The population descented from Black Africans, exported to Bermuda as slaves.

title: Black Bermudian
text: Some Black Bermudians were Free Blacks who chose to immigrate to the island to work as indentured servants during the 17th century.

title: Black Bermudian
text: By the 19th century the Black population surpassed the White population and became Bermuda's largest ethnic group, which was initially classed as being "Coloured" alongside all other non-white ethnicities of Bermuda.

title: Black Bermudian
text: "Black Bermudian" became a recognised ethnic group in Bermuda in the 20th century, by which time it was the largest ethnic group on the island.

title: Oku people (Sierra Leone)
text: The Oku people, also commonly known as Oku Mohammedans or "Aku Mohammedans"in Sierra Leone and as the "Aku Marabou" or "Oku Marabou" in the Gambia, are an ethnic group in Sierra Leone and the Gambia.

title: Oku people (Sierra Leone)
text: The Oku people are the descendants of liberated Africans of Yoruba descent from Southwest Nigeria who were liberated or came to Sierra Leone as settlers in the mid 19th century and formed a distinctive ethnic group The Oku are virtually all Muslims and are known for their conservative muslim population.

title: Oku people (Sierra Leone)
text: The British colonial government provided official recognition to the Oku Mohammedan community as a distinctive community in Sierra Leone.

title: Oku people (Sierra Leone)
text: Although the Sierra Leone government officially considered the Oku people as members of the Creole ethnic group, many Sierra Leoneans consider the Oku people as a distinctive ethnic group.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Czechs in Ukraine, often known as Volhynian Czechs (Czech: "Volyňští Češi"), are ethnic Czechs or their descendants settled mostly in the Volhynia region of Ukraine, in the second half of the 19th century.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Between 1868 and 1880, almost 16,000 Czechs left Austria-Hungary for Tsarist Russia.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: The reasons for their departure were the difficult living conditions in the Czech lands, and the rumors of prosperity in the Russian realm, where there was a large amount of unused agricultural land.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: The local government in the region attracted new immigrants with a number of advantages, such as the right to purchase their own land for low prices, and the establishment of manufacturing businesses.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Also, they gave the migrants the right to national education, self-government and religious freedom.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Immigrants were exempt for 20 years from tax, and exonerated from military duty.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: The bulk of the Czechs settled in the regions of Volhynia, Zhytomyr, Lutsk and other areas.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Some villages were set up in flat meadows, while others were located near existing Ukrainian villages.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Local Czech naems for the villages they lived in were formed from the original name of the village, which was supplemented with the word "Czech" (eg České Noviny, Český Malín, Český Boratín, Český Straklov, etc.) Apart from agriculture, Czech immigrants began to engage in other activities, such as industry, trade and crafts.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: The income for most ethnic Czechs had its foundations in the engineering, breweries, mills, cement plants, etc.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: In their communities, schools, churches, and libraries were founded, and because of this, cultural and social life flourished.

title: Czechs in Ukraine
text: Czech immigrants have made a major contribution to increasing the economic and cultural level in the built-up areas.

title: Ancient Order of Hibernians
text: The Ancient Order of Hibernians (AOH) is an Irish Catholic fraternal organisation.

title: Ancient Order of Hibernians
text: Members must be Catholic and either born in Ireland or of Irish descent.

title: Ancient Order of Hibernians
text: Its largest membership is now in the United States, where it was founded in New York City in 1836.

title: Ancient Order of Hibernians
text: Its name was adopted by groups of Irish immigrants in the United States, its purpose to act as guards to protect Catholic churches from anti-Catholic forces in the mid-19th century, and to assist Irish Catholic immigrants, especially those who faced discrimination or harsh coal mining working conditions.

title: Ancient Order of Hibernians
text: Many members in the coal mining area of Pennsylvania had a background with the Molly Maguires.

title: Ancient Order of Hibernians
text: It became an important focus of Irish American political activity.

title: Shiners' War
text: The Shiners' War was a conflict between Irish Catholic immigrants and French Canadians in Bytown from 1835 to 1845.

title: Shiners' War
text: The war started when Peter Aylen, a major Irish timber operator, organized a group of Irishmen to attack other timber operations.

title: Shiners' War
text: This group was known as the "Shiners."

title: Shiners' War
text: They attacked French Canadian timber rafts and fought against the French Canadian on the streets of Bytown.

title: Irish Canadians
text: Irish Canadians (Irish: "Gaedheal-Cheanadaigh" ) are Canadian citizens who have full or partial Irish heritage including descendants who trace their ancestry to immigrants who originated in Ireland.

title: Irish Canadians
text: 1.2 million Irish immigrants arrived from 1825 to 1970, and at least half of those in the period from 1831–1850.

title: Irish Canadians
text: By 1867, they were the second largest ethnic group (after the French), and comprised 24% of Canada's population.

title: Irish Canadians
text: The 1931 national census counted 1,230,000 Canadians of Irish descent, half of whom lived in Ontario.

title: Irish Canadians
text: About one-third were Catholic in 1931 and two-thirds Protestant.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: People of Irish descent form the largest ethnic group in the city of Philadelphia and its surrounding counties.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: The Irish have lived in Philadelphia since the pre-American Revolution period.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: Irishmen had participated in pro-Revolutionary activities in Philadelphia during the Revolutionary War.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: Like many American cities in the 19th century, Philadelphia, which was once a Quaker stronghold, changed dramatically with the influx of European immigrants.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: The first major influx of Irish came in 1844 from rural areas, spurred by the Irish Famine.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: Because of the Quakers belief and pledge of religious tolerance, Irish Catholics and Protestants, amongst others, made the city incredibly diverse.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: Philadelphia at the time had a need for industrial labor, and at the time Philadelphia was becoming a major industrial center in the United States.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: Irish took industrial positions.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: In the 1840s and 1850s, anti-Catholic sentiment grew against the Irish, and eventually led up to riots, such as the Philadelphia nativist riots and the Lombard Street riot.

title: History of the Irish Americans in Philadelphia
text: Eventually the Irish gained financial and social status in the latter half of the 19th Century and founded institutions during the period.

title: Americo-Liberians
text: Americo-Liberians, or the Congo people in Liberian English, are a Liberian ethnicity of African-American, Afro-Caribbean, and liberated African descent.

title: Americo-Liberians
text: The sister ethnic group of Americo-Liberians are the Sierra Leone Creole people, who shared similar ancestry and related culture.

title: Americo-Liberians
text: Americo-Liberians trace their ancestry to free-born and formerly enslaved African Americans who immigrated in the 19th century to become the founders of the state of Liberia.

title: Americo-Liberians
text: They identified there as Americo Liberians.

title: Americo-Liberians
text: (Some African Americans, following resettlement in Canada, also participated as founding settlers in Sierra Leone and present-day Côte d'Ivoire.)

title: Americo-Liberians
text: Although the terms "Americo-Liberian" and "Congo" had distinct definitions in the nineteenth century, the terms "Americo-Liberian" and "Congo" are currently interchangeable and refer to an ethnic group composed of the descendants of the various free and ex-slave African American, Caribbean, Recaptive, and Sierra Leone Creoles who settled in Liberia from 1822.

title: A Thing of Beauty
text: A Thing of Beauty is a novel by author A. J. Cronin, initially published in 1956, with the alternate title of "Crusader's Tomb".

title: A Thing of Beauty
text: It tells the story of Stephen Desmonde, an English painter who struggles for recognition in a conventional world, sacrificing everything for his passion for art.

title: A Thing of Beauty
text: The title is a reference to John Keats' 1818 poem, "Endymion", which begins with "A thing of beauty is a joy for ever."

title: Who Goes There? (collection)
text: Who Goes There?

title: Who Goes There? (collection)
text: is a collection of science fiction stories by author John W. Campbell, Jr..

title: Who Goes There? (collection)
text: It was published in 1948 by Shasta Publishers in an edition of 3,000 copies, of which 200 were signed by Campbell.

title: Who Goes There? (collection)
text: The 1951 film, "The Thing from Another World", and 1982 version "The Thing" by John Carpenter, are based on the title story.

title: Who Goes There? (collection)
text: The stories originally appeared in the magazine "Astounding" under Campbell's pseudonym Don A. Stuart.

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: Joshua D. Zimmerman (born 1966) is Professor of History at Yeshiva University, where he holds the Eli and Diana Zborowski Professorial Chair in Interdisciplinary Holocaust Studies.

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: He is the author of "The Polish Underground and the Jews, 1939-1945" by Cambridge University Press (2015, hardback) and of "Contested Memories.

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: Poles and Jews during the Holocaust and Its Aftermath" by Rutgers University Press (2003, hardcover) as well as "Poles, Jews and the Politics of Nationality: The Jewish Labor Bund and the Polish Socialist Party in Late Czarist Russia, 1892–1914."

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: <ref name="yu.edu/faculty"> </ref> Zimmerman graduated from the University of California at Santa Cruz in 1989 with a BA(Hons) in History, and with the M.A. in History from UCLA in 1993.

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: In February 1998 he completed his PhD thesis in Comparative History at Brandeis University, and in the summer 2004 was appointed to the position of Associate Professor of History at Yeshiva University in New York City.

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: Zimmerman is an American author proficient in Yiddish, Polish, Hebrew, Russian, and French.

title: Joshua D. Zimmerman
text: <ref name="yu.edu/cv"> </ref>

title: Patrick Kavanagh Poetry Award
text: The Patrick Kavanagh Poetry Award is an Irish poetry award for a collection of poems by an author who has not previously been published in collected form.

title: Patrick Kavanagh Poetry Award
text: It is confined to poets born on the island of Ireland, or of Irish nationality, or a long-term resident of Ireland.

title: Patrick Kavanagh Poetry Award
text: It is based on an open competition whose closing date is in July each year.

title: Patrick Kavanagh Poetry Award
text: The award was founded by the Patrick Kavanagh Society in 1971 to commemorate the poet.

title: Marta Vergara
text: Marta Vergara Varas (1898–1995) was a Chilean author, editor, journalist and women's rights activist.

title: Marta Vergara
text: Introduced to international feminism in 1930, she became instrumental in the development of the Inter-American Commission of Women (CIM) helping gather documentation on laws which effected women's nationality.

title: Marta Vergara
