text: She pushed Doris Stevens to broaden the scope of international feminism to include working women's issues in the quest for equality.

title: Marta Vergara
text: A founding member of the Pro-Emancipation Movement of Chilean Women (Spanish: "Movimiento Pro-Emancipación de las Mujeres de Chile (MEMCh)" ), she was editor of its monthly bulletin "La Mujer Nueva".

title: Marta Vergara
text: When she was ousted from the Communist Party she moved to Europe and worked as a journalist during the war.

title: Marta Vergara
text: At war's end, she returned to Washington, D.C. and worked at the CIM continuing to press for women's suffrage and equality, before returning to Chile, where she resumed her writing career.

title: The Most Incredible Thing
text: “The Most Incredible Thing" (Danish: "Det Utroligste" ) is a literary fairy tale by Danish poet and author Hans Christian Andersen (1805–1875).

title: The Most Incredible Thing
text: The story is about a contest to find the most incredible thing and the wondrous consequences when the winner is chosen.

title: The Most Incredible Thing
text: The tale was first published in an English translation by Horace Scudder, an American correspondent of Andersen's, in the United States in September 1870 before being published in the original Danish in Denmark in October 1870.

title: The Most Incredible Thing
text: "The Most Incredible Thing" was the first of Andersen's tales to be published in Denmark during World War II.

title: The Most Incredible Thing
text: Andersen considered the tale one of his best.

title: Australian property law
text: Australian Property Law is the system of laws regulating and prioritising the rights, interests and responsibilities of individuals in relation to "things".

title: Australian property law
text: These things are a form of "property" or "right" to possession or ownership of an object.

title: Australian property law
text: The law orders or prioritises rights and classifies property as either real and tangible, such as land, or intangible, such as the right of an author to their literary works or personal but tangible, such as a book or a pencil.

title: Australian property law
text: The scope of what constitutes a thing capable of being classified as property and when an individual or body corporate gains priority of interest over a thing has in legal scholarship been heavily debated on a philosophical level.

title: Creacionismo
text: Creationism (Spanish: creacionismo ) was a literary movement initiated by Chilean poet Vicente Huidobro around 1912.

title: Creacionismo
text: Creationism is based on the idea of a poem as a truly "new" thing, created by the author for the sake of itself—that is, not to praise another thing, not to please the reader, not even to be understood by its own author.

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: The Viola Concerto by William Walton was written in 1929 for the violist Lionel Tertis at the suggestion of Sir Thomas Beecham.

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: The concerto carries the dedication "To Christabel" (Christabel McLaren, Lady Aberconway).

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: But Tertis rejected the manuscript, and composer and violist Paul Hindemith gave the first performance.

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: The work was greeted with enthusiasm.

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: It brought Walton to the forefront of British classical music.

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: In "The Manchester Guardian", Eric Blom wrote, "This young composer is a born genius" and said that it was tempting to call the concerto the best thing in recent music of any nationality.

title: Viola Concerto (Walton)
text: Tertis soon changed his mind and took the work up.

title: Man Booker International Prize
text: The Man Booker International Prize is an international hosted in the United Kingdom.

title: Man Booker International Prize
text: The introduction of the International Prize to complement the Man Booker Prize was announced in June 2004.

title: Man Booker International Prize
text: Sponsored by the Man Group, from 2005 until 2015 the award was given every two years to a living author of any nationality for a body of work published in English or generally available in English translation.

title: Man Booker International Prize
text: It rewarded one author's "continued creativity, development and overall contribution to fiction on the world stage", and was a recognition of the writer's body of work rather than any one title.

title: Man Booker International Prize
text: The judges for the year compiled their own lists of authors, and submissions were not invited.

title: Bjarkøy Fixed Link
text: The Bjarkøy Fixed Link (Norwegian: "Bjarkøyforbindelsen" ) is a proposed fixed link which will connect the three islands of Bjarkøya, Sandsøya, and Grytøya in the municipality of Harstad in Troms county, Norway.

title: Bjarkøy Fixed Link
text: Grytøya and Bjarkøya will be connected by a subsea road tunnel and a bridge will connect Grytøya and Sandsøya.

title: Bjarkøy Fixed Link
text: The tunnel to Bjarkøya will be 3.25 km long.

title: Bjarkøy Fixed Link
text: The bridge to Grytøya would be 300 m long plus a 900 m long causeway.

title: Bjarkøy Fixed Link
text: The project also includes 3 km of road on Grytøya to connect the existing roads to the new undersea tunnel.

title: Bjarkøy Fixed Link
text: The Bjarkøy Tunnel will be part of Norwegian County Road 867, while the Sandsøya Bridge will be part of Norwegian County Road 124.

title: Øresund Bridge
text: The Øresund/Öresund/Oresund Bridge (Danish: "Øresundsbroen" , ] ; Swedish: "Öresundsbron" , ] ; hybrid name: "Øresundsbron ") is a combined railway and motorway bridge across the Øresund strait between Sweden and Denmark.

title: Øresund Bridge
text: The bridge runs nearly 8 km from the Swedish coast to the artificial island Peberholm in the middle of the strait.

title: Øresund Bridge
text: The crossing is completed by the 4 km Drogden Tunnel from Peberholm to the Danish island of Amager.

title: Sweden
text: Sweden (Swedish: "Sverige" ), officially the Kingdom of Sweden, is a Scandinavian country in Northern Europe.

title: Sweden
text: It borders Norway to the west and north and Finland to the east, and is connected to Denmark in the southwest by a bridge-tunnel across the Öresund.

title: Sweden
text: At 450295 km2 Sweden is the third-largest country in the European Union by area.

title: Sweden
text: Sweden has a total population of 10.0 million of which 2.3 million has a foreign background.

title: Sweden
text: It has a low population density of 22 PD/km2 ; the highest concentration is in the southern half of the country.

title: Sweden
text: Approximately 85% of the population lives in urban areas.

title: Øresund
text: Øresund or Öresund (Danish: "Øresund" , ] ; Swedish: "Öresund" , ] ), commonly known in English as the Sound, is a strait which forms the Danish–Swedish border, separating Sjælland (Denmark) from Skåne (Sweden).

title: Øresund
text: The strait has a length of 118 km and the width varies from 4 km to 28 km .

title: Øresund
text: It is 4 km wide at its narrowest point between Helsingør in Denmark and Helsingborg in Sweden.

title: Malmö Harbour Heliport
text: Malmö Harbour Heliport (IATA: JMM, ICAO: ESHM) , is an heliport serving Malmö, Sweden.

title: Malmö Harbour Heliport
text: Before the Öresund Bridge was opened in 2000 and before Sweden entered the Schengen Area in 2001, Malmö Harbour Heliport and port had passport and customs check, and there were helicopter and speedboat connections directly to Copenhagen Airport transfer area.

title: Öresund Committee
text: The Öresund Committee (Swedish: "Öresundskomiteen" ) was an organisation which described itself as a platform for regional political collaboration in the Öresund region.

title: Öresund Committee
text: The Öresund region comprises Sweden's most southerly province of Skåne and the Danish islands of Zealand, Lolland, Falster and Bornholm.

title: Öresund Committee
text: The Öresund region has a total population of 3.7 million inhabitants.

title: Øresund Region
text: The Øresund or Öresund Region (Danish: "Øresundsregionen" ; Swedish: "Öresundsregionen" ] ) is a transnational metropolitan area in northern Europe, centred around the Øresund strait and the two cities which lie on either side, Copenhagen, Denmark and Malmö, Sweden.

title: Øresund Region
text: The region is connected by the Øresund Bridge, which spans the strait at its southern end, and the HH Ferry route between Elsinore, Denmark (Danish: "Helsingør") and Helsingborg, Sweden at the narrowest point of the strait.

title: City Tunnel (Malmö)
text: The City Tunnel (Swedish: "Citytunneln" ) is a 17-kilometre rail link in Malmö, Sweden, running between Malmö Central Station (Malmö C) and the Öresund Line (Öresund Bridge), of which six kilometres under Malmö city centre is in tunnel, to increase capacity on the Scanian network by changing Malmö C from a terminus to a through station.

title: City Tunnel (Malmö)
text: The work was projected to cost 9.45 billion SEK.

title: City Tunnel (Malmö)
text: Under construction since March 2005, the line was inaugurated by King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden on December 4, 2010, and revenue service commenced on December 12, 2010.

title: Copenhagen Malmö Port
text: Copenhagen Malmö Port AB (CMP) operates the ports in Denmark's capital Copenhagen and in Sweden's third largest city, Malmö.

title: Copenhagen Malmö Port
text: The ports are located either side of Øresund, a strait between the two countries.

title: Copenhagen Malmö Port
text: The combined Øresund Region is the Nordic countries' largest metropolitan area in terms of population.

title: Copenhagen Malmö Port
text: The region is connected by the Øresund Bridge, which spans the strait at its southern end, and the HH Ferry route between Helsingør, Denmark and Helsingborg, Sweden.

title: European route E47
text: European route E 47 is a highway going from Lübeck in Germany via Copenhagen, Denmark to Helsingborg, Sweden, which is also known under the name Vogelfluglinie and Sydmotorvejen.

title: European route E47
text: The road has motorway standard all the way except for 28 km in Germany, the part inside Helsingør (6 km/4 miles city street), and there are also two ferry connections.

title: European route E47
text: The route has a ferry connection between Germany and Denmark.

title: European route E47
text: A fixed link is planned there by the year 2020.

title: European route E47
text: The discussion of a bridge or tunnel was settled when the 'Danish parliament rejected plans for a bridge across the Fehmarn Strait in favour of the tunnel, deciding it would be safer and greener'.

title: European route E47
text: Also, there is a ferry connection between Denmark (Helsingør) and Sweden (Helsingborg).

title: European route E47
text: There is a bridge-tunnel combination between Denmark and Sweden further south, but still the ferry Helsingør-Helsingborg has a dense schedule.

title: Pat Hingle
text: Martin Patterson "Pat" Hingle (July 19, 1924 – January 3, 2009) was an American actor who appeared in hundreds of television shows and feature films.

title: Pat Hingle
text: His first film was "On the Waterfront" in 1954.

title: Pat Hingle
text: He often played tough authority figures.

title: Pat Hingle
text: Hingle was a close friend of Clint Eastwood and appeared in the Eastwood films "Hang 'em High", "The Gauntlet" and "Sudden Impact".

title: Longhorn Ballroom
text: The Longhorn Ballroom is a music venue and country western dance hall in Dallas, Texas (USA).

title: Longhorn Ballroom
text: It was known in the early 1950s as Bob Wills' Ranch House when the large ballroom was built and operated by O.L. Nelms, an eccentric Dallas millionaire, for his close friend, western swing bandleader Bob Wills.

title: Longhorn Ballroom
text: When Wills left, O.L. Nelms leased the sprawling dance club to Jack Ruby who later killed Lee Harvey Oswald, John F. Kennedy's accused assassin.

title: Longhorn Ballroom
text: O.L. Nelms then sold the property to his close friend and business partner Dewey Groom.

title: Alie Ward
text: Alison Ann Ward is a writer, a painter, American TV actress and co-host of the 2013 Cooking Channel travel-food television series, "Tripping Out with Alie & Georgia".

title: Alie Ward
text: She is also a correspondent for the CBS series "Innovation Nation".

title: Alie Ward
text: Ward has written for L.A. Weekly and the "Los Angeles Times".

title: Alie Ward
text: She has appeared in a handful of TV shows, including "Nash Bridges".

title: Alie Ward
text: She achieved notoriety from her "Alie and Georgia" online videos and television appearances, where she and her close friend, Georgia Hardstark, offer up their recipes for some rather odd culinary concoctions, such as the infamous McNuggetini.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: During the making of the film Manthiri Kumari in 1950, A.C.Trilogchander was working as a junior assistant on the sets and during the shooting of this film became a close friend of M.G.Ramachandran.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: Producer A.V. Meiyappan noticed his talent and gave A.C.Trilochander his break as the director in 1962 film Veerathirumagan.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: With the success of his debut film, he got one more film to direct under AVM banner which was bilingual made simultaneously as "Main Bhi Ladki Hoon" in Hindi and as "Nannum Oru Penn" in Tamil.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: The latter won the National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Tamil at 11th National Film Awards and also won Filmfare Award for Best film.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: With this he became a permanent fixture as director with AVM films.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: He became like the fifth son of Mr. A. V. Meiyapan and became close friend of A. V. M. Saravanan.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: Trilogchander directed the fiftieth film produced by AVM banner - Anbe Vaa, a romantic comedy film, in 1966 with M.G.Ramachandran in the lead.He directed for the film produced by K. Balaji - Thangai in 1967.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: He was not only adept at directing social dramas like "Babu" (1971) with Sivaji Ganesan in the lead, "Ramu" (1966) with Gemini Ganesan as the hero but also romantic dramas such as Iru Malargal and Anbalippu as well as the romantic comedies Anbe Vaa and Anbe Aaruyire.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: He was given the task of directing the first bilingual suspense thriller film from AVM banner in 1967 which was Ave Kallu in Telugu and Adhey Kangal in Tamil.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: He directed the pair Sivaji Ganeshan and Jayalalitha in 5 films - Deiva Magan, Dharmam Engey, Engirundho Vandhaal, Enga Mama, Avanthan Manidhan.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: He directed Rajesh Khanna in "Babu" in 1985 which became a hit.

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: His other acclaimed Tamil films include "Thirudan", "Aval", "Dheerga Sumangali", "Vasandatil Oru Naal", "Bhadrakali", "Anbe Aaruyire" and "Bharata Vilas".

title: A. C. Tirulokchandar
text: He was known to co-ordinate the colour schemes of the actors' outfits with the sets designed for the film.

title: Kyle Craig
text: Kyle Craig is a fictional character and antagonist in James Patterson's series of novels featuring Washington, D.C. detective Alex Cross.

title: Kyle Craig
text: Craig, a Special Agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is initially a close friend of Cross and assists the detective in his high-profile investigations, and also occasionally asks Cross for help with his own cases.

title: Kyle Craig
text: However, in the 2001 novel "Roses Are Red", Craig is revealed to be a criminal who calls himself "The Mastermind", having organized a series of brutal bank robberies and murders.

title: Kyle Craig
text: He is eventually brought to justice by Cross.

title: Kyle Craig
text: From "Violets Are Blue" onwards, Craig is one of Cross' most formidable adversaries.

title: Kyle Craig
text: In the film adaptations of Patterson's novels "Kiss the Girls" and "Along Came a Spider", Craig is played by Jay O. Sanders.

title: Damon Dark
text: Damon Dark is an independent public access TV series and web series from Australia about a heroic and obsessive investigator of UFO incidents and other strange cases, created by Australian writer, actor and film maker Adrian Sherlock.

title: Damon Dark
text: Damon James Dark became a dedicated alien investigator after a close encounter during his teenage years.

title: Damon Dark
text: He is associated with both the secret service and friendly aliens, including a character called Vincent Kosmos (an alien time traveller) and Trans-Dimensional Control (an alien law enforcement agency).

title: Damon Dark
text: The character of Damon Dark has appeared in a 5-week TV series on Community TV 31 in Melbourne Australia, a self-published novel ("Biodome") on Amazon's createspace platform and a long running web series on YouTube.

title: Damon Dark
text: He has also been involved in related web series "Young Damon Dark" and "Vincent Kosmos."

title: Damon Dark
text: He has also been the focus of a one actor stage drama.

title: Damon Dark
text: The character of Damon Dark has been played by Adrian Sherlock, Bruce Hughes, Aiden Sherlock and Jack Knoll.

title: Damon Dark
text: Damon Dark is a loner, dresses in black, has a huge experience of aliens and their technology.

title: Damon Dark
text: Damon is characterized by his high intelligence, idealistic moral outlook and wry sense of humor.

title: Damon Dark
text: His best friend in the series is the long-suffering Gary Sutton, played by actor Robert Trott.

title: Damon Dark
text: Damon Dark began in 1999, with a five-part weekly series on Melbourne's Community TV 31, (although the pilot was shot in 1996 and the show had been in development since 1990) following a screening of a 65-minute version of the story "Maddox" at the 57th World Science Fiction Convention (Aussiecon Three) held in Melbourne.

title: Damon Dark
text: The series was later revived as a YouTube webseries which inspired several related webseries, including "The Young Damon Dark Adventures" in which the character is played as a teenager, and Vincent Kosmos, (created by and starring Chris Heaven, , an Italian actor and musician, about a renegade alien character who is a friend of Damon.

title: Dr. Kildare (TV series)
text: Dr. Kildare is an NBC medical drama television series which originally ran from September 28, 1961 until August 30, 1966, for a total of 191 episodes over five seasons.

title: Dr. Kildare (TV series)
text: Produced by MGM Television, it was based on fictional doctor characters originally created by author Max Brand in the 1930s and previously used by MGM in a popular film series and radio drama.

title: Dr. Kildare (TV series)
text: The TV series quickly achieved success and made a star of Richard Chamberlain, who played the title role.

title: Dr. Kildare (TV series)
text: "Dr. Kildare" (along with an ABC medical drama, "Ben Casey", which premiered at the same time) inspired or influenced many later TV shows dealing with the medical field.

title: Virginia Foster Durr
text: Virginia Foster Durr (August 6, 1903 – February 24, 1999) was an American and a white civil rights activist and lobbyist.

title: Virginia Foster Durr
text: She was born in Birmingham, Alabama in 1903 to Dr. Sterling Foster, an Alabama Presbyterian minister, and Ann Patterson Foster.

title: Virginia Foster Durr
text: At 22 she married lawyer Clifford Durr, with whom she had 5 children, one of whom died in infancy.

title: Virginia Foster Durr
text: Durr was a close friend of Rosa Parks and Eleanor Roosevelt, and was sister-in-law (through her sister's marriage) to and a good friend of Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black who sat on many crucial civil rights cases.

title: Virginia Foster Durr
text: Her circle of friends extended to Alger Hiss.

title: Virginia Foster Durr
text: She was inducted into the Alabama Women's Hall of Fame in 2006.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: Clinton Eastwood Jr. (born May 31, 1930) is an American actor, filmmaker, musician, and political figure.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: After achieving success in the Western TV series "Rawhide", he rose to international fame with his role as the Man with No Name in Sergio Leone's "Dollars" Trilogy of Spaghetti Westerns during the 1960s, and as antihero cop Harry Callahan in the five "Dirty Harry" films throughout the 1970s and 1980s.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: These roles, among others, have made Eastwood an enduring cultural icon of masculinity.

title: Dirás que estoy loco
text: "Diras que estoy loco" is a 2006 song recorded by Spanish singer and actor Miguel Ángel Muñoz.

title: Dirás que estoy loco
text: It was the lead single from his album "MAM" and was released first in 2004 in Spain, then in June 2006 in other countries.

title: Dirás que estoy loco
text: The song was originally performed by the character he performed, Roberto Arenales, in TV series "Un Paso Adelante".

title: Dirás que estoy loco
text: In 2004, the song was ranked #1 in Spain for eleven consecutive weeks, with over 180,000 units sold.

title: Dirás que estoy loco
text: It was released two years later and achieved success in France, Spain and Italy where it was a top three hit, supported by a new version of the music video.

title: Fire regime
text: A fire regime is the pattern, frequency, and intensity of the bushfires and wildfires that prevail in an area over long periods of time.

title: Fire regime
text: It is an integral part of fire ecology, and renewal for certain types of ecosystems.

title: Fire regime
text: If fires are too frequent, plants may be killed before they have matured, or before they have set sufficient seed to ensure population recovery.

title: Fire regime
text: If fires are too infrequent, plants may mature, senesce, and die without ever releasing their seed.

title: Fire regime
text: Fire is a type of disturbance regime that can define an ecosystem.

title: Fire regime
text: Disturbance regimes like fire can change soil erosion, soil formation, nutrient cycles, energy flow, and other ecosystem characteristics.

title: Fire regime
text: Disruption of an ecosystem can allow changes in species dominance and mutations in individual species.

title: Fire regime
text: Fire regimes can change with the spatial and temporal variations in topography, climate, and fuel.

title: Fen
text: A fen is one of the main types of wetland, the others being grassy marshes, forested swamps, and peaty bogs. Along with bogs, fens are a kind of mire.

title: Fen
text: Fens are minerotrophic peatlands, usually fed by mineral-rich surface water or groundwater.

title: Fen
text: They are characterised by their distinct water chemistry, which is pH neutral or alkaline, with relatively high dissolved mineral levels but few other plant nutrients.

title: Fen
text: They are usually dominated by grasses and sedges, and typically have brown mosses in general including "Scorpidium" or "Drepanocladus".

title: Fen
text: Fens frequently have a high diversity of other plant species including carnivorous plants such as "Pinguicula".

title: Fen
text: They may also occur along large lakes and rivers where seasonal changes in water level maintain wet soils with few woody plants.

title: Fen
text: The distribution of individual species of fen plants is often closely connected to water regimes and nutrient concentrations.

title: Marsilea minuta
text: Marsilea minuta, or dwarf waterclover is a species of aquatic fern in the Marsileaceae family.

title: Marsilea minuta
text: Not to be confused with "Marsilea minuta" , which is a synonym for "Marsilea vestita".

title: Marsilea minuta
text: Other common names include gelid waterklawer, small water clover, airy pepperwort, and pepperwort, though the lattermost also applies to plants in the genus Lepidium.

title: Marsilea minuta
text: In French it is called

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: Araripesuchus is an extinct genus of notosuchian crocodyliform that lived in Gondwana during the Cretaceous Period.

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: The genus includes at least five species found throughout Western Africa and South America.

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: The relationship of the individual species within this genus is hotly debated, specifically, the placement of Araripesuchus wegeneri.

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: "A. wegeneri" is a small bodied crocodyliform characterized by relatively elongate limbs, an upright gait, and marked heterodonty.

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: The tooth morphology, when combined with tooth wear and orientation, suggests that this animal may have been an omnivore or herbivore.

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: Additionally, the gracile limbs and their orientation imply that this was a terrestrial animal.

title: Araripesuchus wegeneri
text: These features demonstrate that "Araripesuchus wegeneri" stands in stark contrast to its modern-day relatives, crocodiles and alligators.

title: Marsileaceae
text: The Marsileaceae are a small family of heterosporous aquatic and semi-aquatic ferns, though at first sight they do not physically resemble other ferns.

title: Marsileaceae
text: The group is commonly known as the "pepperwort family" or as the "water-clover family" because the leaves of the genus "Marsilea" superficially resemble the leaves of a four-leaf clover (a flowering plant).

title: Marsileaceae
text: Leaves of this fern have sometimes been used to substitute for clover leaves on Saint Patrick's Day.

title: Marsileaceae
text: In all, the family contains 3 genera and 50 to 80 species with most of those belonging to "Marsilea".

title: Brabejum
text: Brabejum is a genus of a single species of large evergreen tree, Brabejum stellatifolium in the Proteaceae, commonly called wild almond, bitter almond or ghoeboontjie.

title: Brabejum
text: It is restricted in the wild to South Africa's Western Cape Province, where it grows in thickets along the banks of streams.

title: Brabejum
text: The plant is of botanical interest as being Africa's only member of the large grevilleoid subfamily.

title: Brabejum
text: It is a bushy small tree with branches widely at ground level and numerous erect vigorous stems.

title: Brabejum
text: Leaves to 6 in (15 cm) long, narrow and bluntly toothed, appear at intervals along the branches, mostly in whorls of 6.

title: Brabejum
text: In summer, the plant bears white flowers densely crowded on spikes arising from rusty buds at the leaf axils.

title: Brabejum
text: The fruits to 2 in (5 cm) long, magenta to reddish brown, similar to an almond, appear in autumn.

title: Brabejum
text: The nut is too bitter to eat; however, in earlier times it was boiled, roasted, and ground to make a "coffee" drink.

title: Leptospermum
text: Leptospermum is a genus of shrubs and small trees in the myrtle family Myrtaceae commonly known as tea trees, although this name is sometimes also used for some species of "Melaleuca".

title: Leptospermum
text: Most species are endemic to Australia, with the greatest diversity in the south of the continent but some are native to other parts of the world, including New Zealand and Southeast Asia.

title: Leptospermum
text: Leptospermums all have five conspicuous petals and five groups of stamens which alternate with the petals.

title: Leptospermum
text: There is a single style in the centre of the flower and the fruit is a woody capsule.

title: Leptospermum
text: The first formal description of a leptospermum was published in 1776 by the German botanists Johann Reinhold Forster and his son Johann Georg Adam Forster, but an unambiguous definition of individual species in the genus was not achieved until 1979.

title: Leptospermum
text: Leptospermums grow in a wide range of habitats but are most commonly found in moist, low-nutrient soils.

title: Leptospermum
text: They have important uses in horticulture, in the production of honey and in floristry.

title: Myiodynastes
text: Myiodynastes is a genus of birds in the family Tyrannidae.

title: Myiodynastes
text: Created by Charles Lucien Bonaparte in 1857, the genus contains five species which are collectively referred to as "sulphur-bellied flycatchers"; that name is also given to one of the individual species in the genus.

title: Myiodynastes
text: The genus name "Myiodynastes" is a compound word composed from two Greek words: "muia", meaning "fly" and "dunastẽs", meaning "ruler".

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: Sinocyclocheilus is a genus of freshwater fish in the family Cyprinidae endemic to China, where only found in Guangxi, Guizhou and Yunnan.

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: Almost all of its species live in or around caves and most of these have adaptions typical of cavefish such as a lack of scales, lack of pigmentation and reduced eyes (some are completely blind).

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: Several species have an unusual hunchbacked appearance and some of the cave-dwellers have a "horn" on the back (above the forehead), the function of which is unclear.

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: In contrast, the "Sinocyclocheilus" species that live aboveground, as well as a few found underground, show no clear cavefish adaptions.

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: They are relatively small fish reaching up to 23 cm in length.

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: The individual species have small ranges and populations, leading to the status of most of the evaluated species as threatened.

title: Sinocyclocheilus
text: Many species populations in the genus have yet to be evaluated.

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: The Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard ("Acanthodactylus beershebensis") is a species of lizard in the Lacertidae family.

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: It is a member of the subgenus Lacertinae, and the tribe Acanthodactylus (spiny footed lizards).

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: Considered a separate species based on morphological distinction, and isolated location; it shares a large portion of its genetics with "Acanthodactylus pardalis" in this genus.

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: Many of the individual species under this genus are similar, but varying coloration explains why each species have been separated.

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: Like all "Acanthodactylus", the beershebensis lays eggs, varying from three to seven eggs at a time.

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: Adults vary in size from 17 to 20 centimeters, but can get much larger.

title: Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard
text: It is endemic to the loess scrublands of the Negev desert in Israel and the Palestinian Territories, a biodiversity hotspot.

title: Blackman-Bosworth Store
text: Blackman-Bosworth Store, also known as Bosworth Store Building, S.N. Bosworth's Cheap Cash Store, David Blackman's Store, and Randolph County Museum, is a historic general store located at Beverly, Randolph County, West Virginia, United States.

title: Blackman-Bosworth Store
text: It consists of the original section, built about 1828, with an addition built in 1894.

title: Blackman-Bosworth Store
text: The original section is a two-story brick building on a cut-stone foundation.

title: Blackman-Bosworth Store
text: In addition to being operated as a general store into the 1920s, the building had short-term use as county courthouse, post office and semi-official meeting place.

title: Blackman-Bosworth Store
text: In 1973, the Randolph County Historical Society purchased the property, and it now serves as the Randolph County Museum and as a meeting place.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: The Grange Hall in Somerset Township, Jackson County, Illinois, is the historic meeting place of Somerset Township's chapter of The Grange.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: Built in 1912, the building was Somerset Grange #1553's second meeting hall; the first building was built in 1876 and burned down in 1909.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: The red brick building was built by contractor W. A. Pitman in the Commercial style.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: The Grange Hall served as a meeting place for local farmers to discuss agricultural affairs and propose farm policy to legislators.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: The National Farmers Union's newspaper, the "Union Farmer", was published from the Somerset Grange Hall until 1914.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: The building also served as a local social center and hosted township elections, club meetings, and community events.

title: Grange Hall (Murphysboro, Illinois)
text: The hall was rehabilitated in 1988; it still serves as a township polling place.

title: St James's Palace
text: St James's Palace is the most senior royal palace in the United Kingdom.

title: St James's Palace
text: Located in the City of Westminster, although no longer the principal residence of the monarch, it is the ceremonial meeting place of the Accession Council and the London residence of several members of the royal family.

title: President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada
text: In the Canadian cabinet, the President of The Queen's Privy Council for Canada (French: "President du Conseil privé de la Reine pour le Canada" ) is nominally in charge of the Privy Council Office.

title: President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada
text: The President of the Privy Council also has the largely ceremonial duty of presiding over meetings of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada, a body which only convenes in full for affairs of state such as the accession of a new Sovereign or the marriage of the Prince of Wales or heir presumptive to the Throne (see Monarchy in Canada).

title: President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada
text: Accordingly, the last time the President of the Privy Council had to preside over a meeting of the Privy Council was in 1981 on the occasion of Charles, Prince of Wales' engagement to Lady Diana Spencer.

title: President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada
text: It is the equivalent of the office of Lord President of the Council in the United Kingdom.

title: Brady Hotel (Tulsa)
text: The original Brady Hotel, a three-story wood frame building, was built in 1903 at Archer and North Main in Tulsa, Oklahoma by W. Tate Brady.

title: Brady Hotel (Tulsa)
text: It was the first hotel in Tulsa with baths, conveniently located to the Frisco railroad depot, and very popular among the oil men attracted by the new oil discoveries at Glen Pool.

title: Brady Hotel (Tulsa)
text: This was also the meeting place where Charles N. Haskell announced his candidacy to become the first governor of the new state of Oklahoma.

title: Brady Hotel (Tulsa)
text: It also served as a meeting place for Democrats, who laid the groundwork to control the Constitutional Convention and maintain segregation.

title: Warriparinga
text: Warriparinga (meaning "Windy Place" in the local Kaurna language) is a nature reserve comprising 3.5 ha in the metropolitan suburb of Bedford Park, in the southern suburbs of Adelaide, South Australia.

title: Warriparinga
text: It has historical, cultural and environmental significance as a traditional Kaurna ceremonial meeting place and as a site of early European settlement.

title: Warriparinga
text: Also known as Fairford, Laffer's Triangle and the Sturt Triangle, Warriparinga is bordered by Marion Road, Sturt Road and South Road, and is traversed by the Sturt River as it exists from Sturt Gorge to travel west across the Adelaide Plains.

title: Great Hall of the People
text: The Great Hall of the People is a state building located at the western edge of Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

title: Great Hall of the People
text: It is used for legislative and ceremonial activities by the People's Republic of China (PRC) government and the ruling Communist Party of China.

title: Great Hall of the People
text: The Great Hall functions as the meeting place for the full sessions of the Chinese parliament, the National People's Congress (NPC), which occurs every year during March along with the national session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), a political advisory body.

title: Great Hall of the People
text: It is also the meeting place of the National Congress of the Communist Party of China, which, since 1982, has occurred once every five years.

title: Pollokshields Burgh Hall
text: The Pollokshields Burgh Hall stands at the edge of Maxwell Park, Glasgow, Scotland.

title: Pollokshields Burgh Hall
text: Designed by Henry Edward Clifford and constructed in 17th-century Scottish Baronial style, this was opened in 1890 by Sir John Stirling Maxwell as a Masonic Meeting Place and for the use of the community but served the independent burgh of Pollokshields only until 1891 when the rapidly expanding city swallowed up the area.

title: Pollokshields Burgh Hall
text: The hall contained various council offices and a courtroom.

title: Pollokshields Burgh Hall
text: It continues to this day as a Masonic meeting place, hence the numerous Masonic symbols in the carvings (especially at the back of the building) and in the stained-glass windows.

title: Accession Council
text: In the United Kingdom, the Accession Council is a ceremonial body which assembles in St James's Palace upon the death of a monarch (Demise of the Crown), to formally proclaim the accession of his or her successor to the throne.

title: Accession Council
text: Under the terms of the Act of Settlement 1701, a new monarch succeeds automatically.

title: Accession Council
text: The proclamation confirms by name the identity of the heir who has succeeded.

title: Crowther Masonic Hall
text: Crowther Masonic Hall or Freemasons' Hall in Kollam is a part of the Grand Lodge of India and it was a meeting place for many Masonic Lodges in the Quilon(Kollam) area.

title: Crowther Masonic Hall
text: It is near Kochupilamoodu in Kollam city and has been a Masonic meeting place since 1806.

title: Crowther Masonic Hall
text: The building is now considered as a historic monument of Freemasonry activities in ancient Travancore area.

title: William Levett (baron)
text: William Levett (also spelled William de Livet) (ca. 1200 – ca. 1270) was lord of the manor of the South Yorkshire village of Hooton Levitt, a village named in part for his ancestors, and became the owner of the patronage of Roche Abbey on marriage to the granddaughter of the Abbey's cofounder Richard FitzTurgis, a Norman baron who co-founded Roche with the great-nephew of one of England's most powerful Norman barons, Roger de Busli.

title: University of Leeds
text: The University of Leeds is a Russell Group university in Leeds, West Yorkshire, England, established in 1831.

title: University of Leeds
text: Originally named the Yorkshire College of Science and later simply the Yorkshire College, it incorporated the Leeds School of Medicine and became part of the federal Victoria University alongside Owens College (which became the University of Manchester) and University College Liverpool (which became the University of Liverpool).

title: University of Leeds
text: In 1904, a royal charter, created in 1903, was granted to the University of Leeds by King Edward VII.

title: History of the East Riding of Yorkshire
text: The East Riding of Yorkshire is a local government district with unitary authority status, and is a ceremonial county of England.

title: History of the East Riding of Yorkshire
text: It is named after the historic East Riding of Yorkshire which was one of three ridings alongside the North Riding and West Riding, which were constituent parts a Yorkshire ceremonial and administrative county until 1974.

title: History of the East Riding of Yorkshire
text: From 1974 to 1996 the area of the modern East Riding of Yorkshire constituted the northern part of Humberside.

title: Bedale
text: Bedale is a market town and civil parish in the district of Hambleton, North Yorkshire, England.

title: Bedale
text: Historically part of the North Riding of Yorkshire, it is situated 34 mi north of Leeds, 26 mi south-west of Middlesbrough and 7 mi south-west of the county town of Northallerton.

title: Bedale
text: It was originally in Richmondshire and listed in the "Domesday Book" as part of Catterick wapentake, which was also known as Hangshire (so named from Hang Bank in Finghall and because of the many gallows used to execute marauding Scots); it was split again and Bedale remained in East Hang.

title: Bedale
text: Bedale Beck is a tributary of the River Swale, which forms one of the Yorkshire Dales, with its predominance of agriculture and its related small traditional trades, although tourism is increasingly important.

title: Nidderdale Museum
text: The Nidderdale Museum is housed in a former workhouse in the market town of Pateley Bridge, North Yorkshire, England.

title: Nidderdale Museum
text: Exhibits focus on rural life and include such period room and business displays as a cobbler's workshop, schoolroom, Victorian parlour, general store, 1930s hairdresser's shop and a kitchen.

title: Nidderdale Museum
text: Other displays include historic costumes, agriculture tools and equipment, local industries and transport vehicles.

title: Norman Yardley
text: Norman Walter Dransfield Yardley (19 March 1915 – 3 October 1989) was an English cricketer who played for Cambridge University, Yorkshire County Cricket Club and England, as a right-handed batsman and occasional bowler.

title: Norman Yardley
text: An amateur, he captained Yorkshire from 1948 to 1955 and England on fourteen occasions between 1947 and 1950, winning four Tests, losing seven and drawing three.

title: Norman Yardley
text: Yardley was named Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1948 and in his obituary in "Wisden Cricketers' Almanack", he was described as Yorkshire's finest amateur since Stanley Jackson.

title: Maurice Ward
text: Maurice Ward was an English inventor best known for his invention of Starlite, a thermal shielding material.

title: Maurice Ward
text: He was a former hairdresser from Yorkshire, England.

title: Maurice Ward
text: His demand that he keep 51% ownership of the formula for Starlite, and belief that the technology was worth billions of dollars, stunted its commercial success.

title: West Yorkshire Association Football League
text: The West Yorkshire Association Football League is a football competition based in Yorkshire, England.

title: West Yorkshire Association Football League
text: It was previously known as the Leeds League until the name change in 1939.

title: West Yorkshire Association Football League
text: Although it is named the "West Yorkshire" League, clubs from the Harrogate and York areas of North Yorkshire also play in the competition.

title: Starlite
text: Starlite is a material claimed to be able to withstand and insulate from extreme heat.

title: Starlite
text: It was invented by amateur chemist and hairdresser Maurice Ward (1933–2011) during the 1970s and 1980s, and received much publicity in 1993 thanks to coverage on the science and technology show "Tomorrow's World".

title: Starlite
text: The name Starlite was coined by Ward's granddaughter Kimberly.

title: Bradley, North Yorkshire
text: Bradley is a village in the Craven district of North Yorkshire, England.

title: Bradley, North Yorkshire
text: The village is situated between Skipton and Keighley.

title: Bradley, North Yorkshire
text: It is approximately 1/2 mi from the A629 and 2 mi from the nearby town of Skipton.

title: Bradley, North Yorkshire
text: Bradley is divided into two parts; High Bradley and Low Bradley, known collectively as Bradleys Both although traditionally the village used to be named Bradley Ambo.

title: Bradley, North Yorkshire
text: While physically in North Yorkshire and under the council of North Yorkshire, it has a West Yorkshire postal town and dialling code.

title: One Raffles Link
text: One Raffles Link (Chinese: 莱佛士连道一号) is an office building located at Marina Centre, Singapore.

title: One Raffles Link
text: The building is six storeys high with a basement and is managed by Hongkong Land.

title: One Raffles Link
text: Completed in 2000, it was jointly designed by world-renowned architect, Kohn Pedersen Fox and Aedas LPT Architects.

title: One Raffles Link
text: The development costs S$340 million and is a Grade A office building.

title: One Raffles Link
text: VISA, Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs and Citibank are major tenants of the building.

title: One Raffles Link
text: Built on an elongated slip of land, the building offers the largest columnless floor-plates in the city.

title: One Raffles Link
text: The development includes CityLink Mall, Singapore's first subterranean mall, which links One Raffles Link with the City Hall MRT Station, Raffles City, Marina Square, Suntec City and the Esplanade.

title: Raffles Place
text: Raffles Place is the centre of the Financial District of Singapore and is located south of the mouth of the Singapore River.

title: Raffles Place
text: It was first planned and developed in the 1820s as Commercial Square to serve as the hub of the commercial zone of Singapore in Raffles Town Plan.

title: Raffles Place
text: It was renamed Raffles Place in 1858 and is now the site of a number of major banks.

title: Raffles Place
text: It is located in the Downtown Core within the Central Area, and features some of the tallest buildings and landmarks of the country.

title: Tanjong Pagar Centre
text: Tanjong Pagar Centre, also known as Guoco Tower, is a S$3.2 billion mixed-use development located in Tanjong Pagar, Singapore.

title: Tanjong Pagar Centre
text: With a height of 290 m , it is currently the tallest building in Singapore, breaking the record held jointly by UOB Plaza, One Raffles Place and Republic Plaza for over 20 years.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: The city of São Paulo, Brazil's largest city, has an impressive skyline.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: With 6,467 buildings, it is considered to have the 3rd-greatest concentration of buildings in the world, behind only New York City and Hong Kong; Within the city and its metropolitan area, there are 193 buildings taller than 100 meters, mostly concentrated in the downtown along the Paulista Avenue and in the neighborhood of Brooklin.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: At one time, the city was home to the tallest building in Latin America, the Martinelli Building, which opened in 1929 at a height of 130 meters.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: The Mirante do Vale, the largest building in the city, is 170 meters in height and was opened in 1960.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: Today, São Paulo is a city of low buildings, which rarely reach more than 80 meters and are mostly residential in nature.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: Municipal laws limit the construction of large skyscrapers and the tallest skyscrapers are located in three different regions.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: The city's financial center, fully occupied by skyscrapers, has moved.

title: List of tallest buildings in São Paulo
text: The city of São Paulo has the 10th highest number of buildings in the world taller than 90 meters, behind Hong Kong, New York City, Tokyo, Shanghai, Bangkok, Guangzhou, Chicago, and Singapore, respectively.

title: Raffles Place MRT Station
text: Raffles Place MRT Station (NS26/EW14) is an underground Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) cross-platform interchange station on the North South Line and the East West Line in Downtown Core, Singapore.

title: Raffles Place MRT Station
text: It is directly underneath the centre of the financial area of Raffles Place, located in the Downtown Core area, south of the Singapore River.

title: Raffles Place MRT Station
text: It is one of the more prominent and busier stations within Singapore's transport system, especially being an interchange station located within the Central Area.

title: Raffles Place MRT Station
text: The station has a large number of entrances/exits, the two main ones facing the Raffles Gardens, with the building being a miniature facade of the historic John Little building.

title: CapitaGreen
text: CapitaGreen, also known as Market Street Tower, is an office tower located in Raffles Place, Singapore.

title: CapitaGreen
text: The building was designed by Toyo Ito and completed in 2014.

title: CapitaGreen
text: With a height of 242 m , it is one of the tallest skyscrapers in Singapore.

title: One Raffles Place
text: One Raffles Place, formerly Overseas Union Bank Centre or OUB Centre is one of the tallest skyscrapers in the city of Singapore.

title: One Raffles Place
text: It was the tallest together with the UOB Plaza and Republic Plaza until the construction of Tanjong Pagar Centre in 2016.

title: One Raffles Place
text: At 280 m , it was also the tallest building in the world outside North America at the time of its completion in 1986, surpassing South Korea's 63 Building completed one year earlier, until it was succeeded by the Bank of China Tower.

title: One Raffles Place
text: The building sits at the city centre of Raffles Place.

title: Republic Plaza (Singapore)
text: Republic Plaza (Chinese: 共和大厦) is one of the three tallest skyscrapers in Singapore, located at the Southern end of Raffles Place in the Downtown Core, the central business district of Singapore.

title: Republic Plaza (Singapore)
text: It shares the title of "tallest building" with the OUB Centre and UOB Plaza One.

title: Republic Plaza (Singapore)
text: Built at 280 metres (919 feet) tall, it was completed in 1995, and incorporates earthquake proof features despite the city being relatively far from earthquake zones.

title: Chevron House
text: Chevron House, formerly called Caltex House, is a high-rise skyscraper located in the central business district of Singapore.

title: Chevron House
text: It is located on 30 Raffles Place, in the financial district of Raffles Place.

title: Chevron House
text: The building is near several buildings and landmarks, such as Singapore Land Tower, Hitachi Tower, Change Alley and The Arcade, all of which are less than 100 m away.

title: Chevron House
text: The development has direct underground access to Raffles Place MRT Station.

title: Chevron House
text: Hitachi Tower, a nearby neighbour of Chevron House, shares a four-level retail podium with the building.

title: One Marina Boulevard
text: One Marina Boulevard, sometimes called NTUC Centre, is a 32-storey, 110 m skyscraper at 1 Marina Boulevard, in the zone of Raffles Place and Marina Bay, in the central business district of Singapore.

title: One Marina Boulevard
text: The building is near other skyscrapers, such as One Raffles Quay, The Sail @ Marina Bay and Ocean Building, all of which are around 100 metres away.

title: One Marina Boulevard
text: It has a direct link to Raffles Place MRT Station via an air-conditioned underground mall.

title: Criminal law in the Marshall Court
text: The Marshall Court (1801–1835) heard forty-one criminal law cases, slightly more than one per year.

title: Criminal law in the Marshall Court
text: Among such cases are "United States v. Simms" (1803), "United States v. More" (1805), "Ex parte Bollman" (1807), "United States v. Hudson" (1812), "Cohens v. Virginia" (1821), "United States v. Perez" (1824), "Worcester v. Georgia" (1832), and "United States v. Wilson" (1833).

title: Baker v. Nelson
text: Richard John Baker v. Gerald R. Nelson, 291 Minn. 310, 191 N.W.2d 185 (1971) is a case in which the Minnesota Supreme Court ruled that a state law limiting marriage to persons of the opposite sex did not violate the U.S. Constitution.

title: Baker v. Nelson
text: Baker appealed, and on October 10, 1972, the United States Supreme Court dismissed the appeal "for want of a substantial federal question."

title: Baker v. Nelson
text: Because the case came to the U.S. Supreme Court through mandatory appellate review (not "certiorari"), the dismissal constituted a decision on the merits and established "Baker v. Nelson" as precedent, though the extent of its precedential effect had been subject to debate.

title: Baker v. Nelson
text: In May 2013, Minnesota legalized same-sex marriage and it took effect on August 1, 2013.

title: Baker v. Nelson
text: Subsequently, on June 26, 2015, the U.S. Supreme Court explicitly overruled "Baker" in "Obergefell v. Hodges" making same-sex marriage legal nationwide.

title: United States v. Binion
text: United States v. Binion, 132 F. App'x 89 (8th Cir.

title: United States v. Binion
text: 2005), is a case in which the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit applied two recent U.S. Supreme Court decisions ("United States v. Booker", 543 U.S. 220 (2005) and "United States v. Fanfan", 543 U.S. 220 (2005) in reviewing the sentencing decision by the trial court and upheld by the Federal District Court for the Eastern District.

title: Lau Kong Yung v Director of Immigration
text: Lau Kong Yung v. Director of Immigration was a 1999 right of abode case in the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal following closely on the heels of the landmark "Ng Ka Ling v. Director of Immigration" decision earlier that year.

title: Lau Kong Yung v Director of Immigration
text: After "Ng" and the two prior actions in "Lau", but before the case came before the CFA, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPCSC) of the People's Republic of China issued an interpretation of the Basic Law which affected the rights of Lau and his fellow applicants.

title: Lau Kong Yung v Director of Immigration
text: "Lau" thus became the first case in which the CFA had to take into account an NPCSC interpretation in applying the Basic Law.

title: Craig v. Boren
text: Craig v. Boren, 429 U.S. 190 (1976) , was the first case in which a majority of the United States Supreme Court determined that statutory or administrative sex classifications were subject to intermediate scrutiny under the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause.

title: United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc.
text: United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc., 334 US 131 (1948) (also known as the Hollywood Antitrust Case of 1948, the Paramount Case, the Paramount Decision or the Paramount Decree) was a landmark United States Supreme Court antitrust case that decided the fate of movie studios owning their own theatres and holding exclusivity rights on which theatres would show their films.

title: United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc.
text: It would also change the way Hollywood movies were produced, distributed, and exhibited.

title: United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc.
text: The Court held in this case that the existing distribution scheme was in violation of the antitrust laws of the United States, which prohibit certain exclusive dealing arrangements.

title: R v Van der Peet
text: R v Van der Peet,  2 S.C.R. 507 is a leading case on Aboriginal rights under section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982.

title: R v Van der Peet
text: The Supreme Court held that Aboriginal fishing rights did not extend to commercial selling of fish.

title: R v Van der Peet
text: From this case came the Van der Peet test for determining if an Aboriginal right exists.

title: R v Van der Peet
text: This is the first of three cases known as the Van der Peet trilogy which included "R v NTC Smokehouse Ltd" and "R v Gladstone".

title: City of Norwood v. Horney
text: Norwood, Ohio v. Horney 110 Ohio St.3d 353 was a case brought before the Ohio Supreme Court in 2006.

title: City of Norwood v. Horney
text: The case came upon the heels of "Kelo v. City of New London", in which the United States Supreme Court ruled that commercial development justified the use of eminent domain.

title: City of Norwood v. Horney
text: "Kelo" had involved the United States Constitution, while the issue in "Norwood" was the specific limitations of the Ohio State Constitution.

title: Block booking
text: Block booking is a system of selling multiple films to a theater as a unit.

title: Block booking
text: Block booking was the prevailing practice among Hollywood's major studios from the turn of the 1930s until it was outlawed by the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in "United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc." (1948).

title: Block booking
text: Under block booking, "independent ('unaffiliated') theater owners were forced to take large numbers of  studio's pictures sight unseen.

title: Block booking
text: Those studios could then parcel out second-rate product along with A-class features and star vehicles, which made both production and distribution operations more economical."

title: Block booking
text: The element of the system involving the purchase of unseen pictures is known as blind bidding.

title: Criminal law in the Waite Court
text: During the tenure of Morrison Waite as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States (March 4, 1874 through March 23, 1888), the Supreme Court heard an unprecedented volume and frequency of criminal cases.

title: Criminal law in the Waite Court
text: In just fourteen years, the Court heard 106 criminal cases, almost as many cases as the Supreme Court had heard in the period from its creation to the appointment of Waite as Chief Justice.

title: Criminal law in the Waite Court
text: Notable cases include "United States v. Cruikshank" (1875), "United States v. Reese" (1875), "Reynolds v. United States" (1878), "Wilkerson v. Utah" (1879), the "Trade-Mark Cases" (1879), "Strauder v. West Virginia" (1880), "Pace v. Alabama" (1883), "United States v. Harris" (1883), "Ex parte Crow Dog" (1883), "Hurtado v. California" (1884), "Clawson v. United States" (1885), "Yick Wo v. Hopkins" (1886), "United States v. Kagama" (1886), "Ker v. Illinois" (1886), and "Mugler v. Kansas" (1887).

title: Concord Pavilion
text: Concord Pavilion (formerly known as Sleep Train Pavilion and Chronicle Pavilion) is an amphitheatre located in Concord, California.

title: Concord Pavilion
text: It is owned by the City of Concord and operated by Live Nation.

title: Concord Pavilion
text: The Pavilion has a capacity of 12,500 people and opened in 1975 as the Concord Pavilion.

title: Concord Pavilion
text: It is used for concerts, local community events (including an annual jazz festival) and local high school graduations.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The Kertha Gosa pavilion is an example of Balinese architecture located on the island of Bali, in the city Klungkung, Indonesia.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The Kertha Gosa Pavilion at Klungkung Palace was first built in the early 18th century by Dewa Agung Gusti Sideman.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The first function of the pavilion was for the court of law in 1945.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: Kertha Gosa was repainted in the 1920s and again in the 1960s.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The people who discovered the pavilion knew there was an extensive history behind the pavilion.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The discovery of Kertha Gosa pavilion was only known by people writing about it here or there to others outside of Bali.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The Kertha Gosa Pavilion at Klungkung has the story of Bhima Swarga painted around the ceiling.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: Bhima Swarga is a Hindu epic referenced from the Mahabharata.

title: Kertha Gosa Pavilion
text: The story at the Kertha Gosa Pavilion is not the whole Mahabharata but one small section called Bhima Swarga.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: The Oleson Park Music Pavilion, also known as the Karl King Bandshell, is located in Fort Dodge, Iowa, United States.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: The pavilion is associated with Karl King, a famed composer for concert and military bands, who advocated for its construction.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: It was designed by Henry L. Kamphoefner, a Sioux City architect at that time, who had previously designed the Grandview Park Music Pavilion in Sioux City.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: It was built as a Works Progress Administration (WPA) project.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: The WPA paid for 85% of its construction, with the City of Fort Dodge paying the rest.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: The poured concrete structure was built in a Modernist style with Art Deco overtones.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: It rises to a height of 36 ft , and it is known for its acoustical excellence.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: The pavilion replaced a bandstand that was built in the 1920s in the city square.

title: Oleson Park Music Pavilion
text: It was dedicated to King in 1976, and listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2003.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: A sala (Thai: ศาลา ] ; Khmer: សាលា ] ), also known as a sala Thai, is an open pavilion, used as a meeting place and to protect people from sun and rain.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: Most are open on all four sides.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: They are found throughout Thailand in Buddhist temple areas, or wats, although they can also be located in other places.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: A person who builds a sala at a temple or in a public place gains religious merit.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: A sala located in a temple is called a "salawat" (ศาลาวัด).

title: Sala (architecture)
text: Some temples have large salas where laity can hear sermons or receive religious instructions.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: These are called "sala kan parian" (ศาลาการเปรียญ), meaning pavilion where monks learn for the Parian examination.

title: Sala (architecture)
text: The city halls or offices of the province governors are called "sala wa kan" (ศาลาว่าการ, literally meaning "government pavilion") or "sala klang changwat" (ศาลากลางจังหวัด, literally meaning a provincial main pavilion).

title: Darling's Waterfront Pavilion
text: The Darling's Waterfront Pavilion (originally known as the Bangor Waterfront Pavilion) is an open-air amphitheater located within the Waterfront Park in Bangor, Maine.

title: Darling's Waterfront Pavilion
text: The venue is a temporary structure built alongside the Penobscot River.

title: Darling's Waterfront Pavilion
text: The venue typically operates from July until October.

title: Corus Quay
text: Corus Quay, originally named First Waterfront Place, is an eight-storey commercial office tower located on a 2.5 acre waterfront site in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

title: Corus Quay
text: The $160 million building is the first major development planned for the East Bayfront district, and completed construction at the foot of Jarvis Street.

title: Corus Quay
text: Corus Quay is Corus Entertainment's new Toronto headquarters, consolidating its 10 locations and 1,200 employees into one site.

title: Corus Quay
text: The building was being developed by the Toronto Economic Development Corporation (TEDCO), a city agency.

title: Corus Quay
text: Funding for the project came from TEDCO's equity, city loans and a $12.5 million contribution from the city contributed via Waterfront Toronto.

title: Silver Line Way (MBTA station)
text: Silver Line Way is a surface bus rapid transit station on the MBTA Silver Line, located on Silver Line Way at Pumphouse Road between Massport Haul Road (Trilling Street) and D Street near the South Boston Waterfront.

title: Silver Line Way (MBTA station)
text: The station is a block south of the Boston Fish Pier; it also serves the Boston Renaissance Waterfront Hotel and the Blue Hills Bank Pavilion.

title: Zuiweng Pavilion
text: The Zuiweng Pavilion (, is a pavilion lying to the south east of Chuzhou City, Anhui Province, People's Republic of China.

title: Zuiweng Pavilion
text: Located in The Northern Song Dynasty whilst the structure that exists today dates to the Qing Dynasty (1644–1911).

title: Zuiweng Pavilion
text: The pavilion takes its name from the Northern Song poet Ouyang Xiu, who called himself the "Old Toper" and wrote a poem entitled "Zuiweng Tingji" or "An Account of the Old Toper's Pavilion".

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The Grandview Park Music Pavilion is a historic structure located in Sioux City, Iowa, United States.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The Monahan Post Band raised money in 1930 to build a modest music shell in the park.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: Construction was already underway when the park's neighbors objected to the design.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The project was put on hold as the band raised more money and sought a more suitable design.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: After President Franklin D. Roosevelt created the Civil Works Administration (CWA) in 1933, the city applied to have the new music shell included in Sioux City's projects.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: Henry L. Kamphoefner, an unknown Sioux City architect at that time, drew up the plans for the structure.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The sculptural plaques on the front of the pavilion were designed by Herschel Elarth.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The CWA approved the project on February 26, 1934 as CWA Project Number 217.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The construction project required 52 tons of reinforcing steel, 4,200 bags of Portland cement, and 300 bags of white cement, and it was completed on October 17, 1934.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: Seating was constructed for 5,000 in the natural amphitheater.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The pavilion was built using $47,436 from Federal Relief funds and $3,800 in materials from the city.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: It was dedicated in the spring of 1935.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The Monahan Post Band continued to play here until 1948, when they became the Sioux City Municipal Band.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: They continue the summer-time tradition.

title: Grandview Park Music Pavilion
text: The music pavilion was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2011.

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: Paulus Hook is a community on the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City, New Jersey, located one mile across the river from Manhattan.

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: The name Hook comes from the Dutch word "hoeck" which translates into "point of land."

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: This "point of land" has been described as an elevated area, the location of which is today bounded by Montgomery, Hudson, Dudley and Van Vorst Streets.

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: The neighborhood's main street is the north- and south-running Washington Street.

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: The waterfront of Paulus Hook is along the basin of the Morris Canal in a park with a segment of Liberty State Park.

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail has a Paulus Hook stop at Essex Street and the Liberty Water Taxi at Warren Street.

title: Paulus Hook, Jersey City
text: The introduction of the light rail and development of office buildings on the Hudson Waterfront have brought more businesses to Morris Street including a number of restaurants with outdoor seating and small neighborhood shops.

title: 2008 Kansas City Wizards season
text: The 2008 Kansas City Wizards season was the first season played at the temporary home Community America Ballpark in Kansas City, Kansas.

title: 1998 Kansas City Wizards season
text: The 1998 Kansas City Wizards season was the third MLS history.

title: 1998 Kansas City Wizards season
text: Played at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: 1998 Kansas City Wizards season
text: MLS did not allow matches to end in ties in 1998 and thus Shootouts were used to decide draws, the stats that follow do not include shootout goals scored and the teams actually point total in the regular season was 32 even though it is shown below as 36.

title: 1998 Kansas City Wizards season
text: Shootout win= 1 point, Shootout loss= 0 points.

title: 1999 Kansas City Wizards season
text: The 1999 Kansas City Wizards season was played at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: 1999 Kansas City Wizards season
text: MLS did not allow matches to end in ties in 1999 and thus Shootouts were used to decide draws, the stats that follow do not include shootout goals scored and the teams actually point total in the regular season was 20 even though it is shown below as 24.

title: 1999 Kansas City Wizards season
text: Shootout win= 2 points, Shootout loss= 0 points.

title: 1999 Kansas City Wizards season
text: The Wizards first ever manager Ron Newman was let go and replaced with Bob Gansler.

title: Shawnee Mission District Stadium
text: Shawnee Mission District Stadium is a multi-purpose sport stadium located in Overland Park, Kansas.

title: Shawnee Mission District Stadium
text: The facility is primarily used by Shawnee Mission North High School, Shawnee Mission Northwest High School and Shawnee Mission East High School, as well as FC Kansas City of the National Women's Soccer League.

title: Shawnee Mission District Stadium
text: Sporting Kansas City, then called the Kansas City Wizards, played at the stadium in a match against the Colorado Rapids during the 2008 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

title: All-time Sporting Kansas City roster
text: This list comprises all players who have participated in at least one league match for Sporting Kansas City (formerly known as Kansas City Wiz and Kansas City Wizards) since the team's first Major League Soccer season in 1996.

title: All-time Sporting Kansas City roster
text: Players who were on the roster but never played a first team game are not listed; players who appeared for the team in other competitions (US Open Cup, CONCACAF Champions League, etc.) but never actually made an MLS appearance are noted at the bottom of the page.

title: Curt Johnson (soccer)
text: Curt Johnson currently serves as the President of the NASL's (North American Soccer League) North Carolina FC and NWSL's North Carolina Courage.

title: Curt Johnson (soccer)
text: Johnson's professional soccer administrative resume also includes holding the General Manager position with the Richmond Kickers (at the time members of the A-League/Division 2) and Major League Soccer's Kansas City Wizards (now known as Sporting Kansas City).

title: Children's Mercy Park
text: Children's Mercy Park (formerly Sporting Park and Livestrong Sporting Park) is a soccer-specific stadium in Kansas City, Kansas, United States, and is the home of Sporting Kansas City.

title: Children's Mercy Park
text: The stadium is located near Kansas Speedway and it opened during the 2011 season of Major League Soccer on June 9, 2011 with a match against the Chicago Fire.

title: Children's Mercy Park
text: The stadium has a seating capacity of 18,467 seats, which can expand to 25,000 for concerts.

title: Children's Mercy Park
text: Most SKC games attract around 21,000 because of different stadium modes.

title: Children's Mercy Park
text: The stadium is Sporting Kansas City's third home venue; then known as the Kansas City Wizards, the team played in Arrowhead Stadium from 1996 to 2007 and CommunityAmerica Ballpark from 2008 to 2010.

title: Children's Mercy Park
text: In 2013, the stadium hosted the MLS All-Star Game, the United States men's national soccer team, and the MLS Cup, three of the most prestigious matches in the United States, and is the only stadium to host all three in the same year.

title: CommunityAmerica Ballpark
text: CommunityAmerica Ballpark is a baseball park in Kansas City, Kansas, located in the Kansas City neighborhood of Piper, Kansas.

title: CommunityAmerica Ballpark
text: It is home of the Kansas City T-Bones of the independent American Association, and the former home of the Kansas City Wizards (now Sporting Kansas City) of Major League Soccer.

title: CommunityAmerica Ballpark
text: It is located in the Village West area at 1800 Village West Parkway.

title: CommunityAmerica Ballpark
text: Many local area High School teams, including Bonner Springs High School, in there annual Butch Foster Memorial Baseball Classic play at the ballpark and it is also the home of the Kansas City Kansas Community College Blue Devils.

title: CommunityAmerica Ballpark
text: It has also been used for concerts and some community events.

title: 1997 Kansas City Wizards season
text: The 1997 Kansas City Wizards season was the second in team and MLS history.

title: 1997 Kansas City Wizards season
text: Played at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: 1997 Kansas City Wizards season
text: MLS did not allow matches to end in ties and thus Shootouts were used to decide draws, the stats that follow do not include shootout goals scored and the teams actually point total in the regular season was 49 even though it is shown below as 63.

title: 1997 Kansas City Wizards season
text: Shootout win= 2 points, Shootout loss= 0 points.

title: MLS Cup 2004
text: MLS Cup 2004, the ninth edition of Major League Soccer's championship match, was played between D.C. United and the Kansas City Wizards to decide the champion of the 2004 season.

title: MLS Cup 2004
text: The match that took place at The Home Depot Center in Carson, California on November 14, 2004.

title: MLS Cup 2004
text: D.C. United defeated Kansas City 3-2 on an own goal by Wizards defender, Alex Zotinca.

title: MLS Cup 2004
text: It was D.C. United's fourth MLS Cup victory and their first since MLS Cup '99.

title: Boortsog
text: Boortsog, boorsoq, bauyrsaq, or baursak (Bashkir: бауырһаҡ , Kazakh: бауырсақ ] , Kyrgyz: боорсок ] , Mongolian: боорцог ] , Russian: баурсак , Tatar: бавырсак , "bawırsaq " , Uzbek: "bog'irsoq" ] , Tajik: бусроқ ] , Turkish: "pişi, bişi, tuzlu lokma, halka" , Turkmen: pişme ) is a type of fried dough food found in the cuisines of Central Asia, Idel-Ural, Mongolia and the Middle East.

title: Boortsog
text: It is shaped into either triangles or sometimes spheres.

title: Boortsog
text: The dough consists of flour, yeast, milk, eggs, margarine, salt, sugar, and fat.

title: Boortsog
text: Tajik boortsog are often decorated with a criss-cross pattern by pressing the bottom of a small strainer on the dough before it is fried.

title: Henry Hall (American revolution)
text: Captain Henry Hall was an American from Dennis, Massachusetts who fought in the American Revolutionary War, who later was the first to successfully cultivate cranberries.

title: John Adlum
text: John Adlum (April 29, 1759 – March 14, 1836) was a pioneering American viticulturalist who was the first to cultivate the Catawba grape.

title: John Adlum
text: He is known as "the father of American viticulture" (grape-growing).

title: John Adlum
text: He also served in the American Revolutionary War; was a well-known surveyor; was one of the first associate judges in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania; and served in the United States Army in the War of 1812.

title: List of fossils with consumulites
text: This list of fossils with consumulites contains fossil specimens discovered to contain the preserved remains of food that the deceased animal had ingested during life.

title: List of fossils with consumulites
text: Such consumulites are a type of bromalite, the broader term applied to fossilized material ingested by an animal including waste expelled from the body like feces (coprolites) and vomit (regurgitalites).

title: List of fossils with consumulites
text: Consumulites are divided into three categories food in the animal's mouth when it died (oralites), food in the animal's throat when it died (esophagolites), partially digested stomach contents (gastrolites, not to be confused with gastro"liths"), and food found in the animal's intestinal tract (cololites).

title: Hall Caine Airport
text: Hall Caine Airport was an airfield on the Isle of Man which was located near Ramsey.

title: Hall Caine Airport
text: It was named after the author Sir Thomas Henry Hall Caine CH, KBE by his sons Gordon Hall Caine and Derwent Hall Caine, who were the project initiators and Hall Caine Airport flourished for a short period prior to the outbreak of the Second World War.

title: Hall Caine Airport
text: From 1935 to 1937 it handled domestic scheduled passenger flights to English, Scottish and Irish airports.

title: Hall Caine Airport
text: By 1937 it had fallen into disuse, primarily due to its location.

title: Cuisine of Karachi
text: Karachi cuisine (Urdu: کراچی پکوان‎ ) refers to the food found mainly in the city of Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan.

title: Cuisine of Karachi
text: The cuisine of Karachi is strongly influenced by the city's Urdu speaking Muslims, also known as Muhajir population, who came from northern India and settled in Karachi after the independence of Pakistan in 1947.

title: Cuisine of Karachi
text: Most Urdu speaking Muslims have traditionally been based in Karachi, hence the city is known for Muhajir tastes in its cuisine.

title: Cuisine of Karachi
text: Urdu speaking Muslims maintained their old established culinary traditions, including variety of dishes and beverages.

title: Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site
text: Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site, is a national historic district and open-air museum located in Camden, Kershaw County, South Carolina.

title: Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site
text: Roughly 40 minutes away from Columbia, South Carolina the state capitol it is one of the states largest tourist attractions.

title: Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site
text: The 107-acre site is also known as Historic Camden Revolutionary War Restoration and as the British Revolutionary War Fortifications.

title: Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site
text: Camden contains preserved structures and grounds that are representative of the Southern theater of the American Revolutionary War.

title: Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site
text: The site is managed by a consortium of private donors and local governments, the area is also an affiliated unit of the National Park Service.

title: Robert Plampin
text: Vice-Admiral Robert Plampin (1762 – 14 February 1834), was a British Royal Navy officer during the late 18th and early 19th centuries, serving in the American Revolutionary War, the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars, but best known for his time as commander of the British colony of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic during the period when former Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte was imprisoned there.

title: Robert Plampin
text: Born into a Navy family, Plampin went to sea at age 13 and fought throughout the American Revolutionary War, based principally in the Caribbean Sea.

title: Robert Plampin
text: During the French Revolutionary Wars, Plampin served in a number of ships with mixed success, once being involved in a shipwreck and twice serving ashore during sieges.

title: Robert Plampin
text: After the Peace of Amiens, Plampin took command of the ship of the line HMS "Powerful" and operated successfully in the Atlantic and the Indian Ocean.

title: Robert Plampin
