text: In 1816, following the defeat and capture of the French Emperor, Plampin was placed in command of the squadron at the Cape of Good Hope, which also had responsibility for Saint Helena, which Plampin regularly visited and had numerous conversations with Napoleon.

title: Blanket bog
text: Blanket bog or blanket mire, also known as featherbed bog, is an area of peatland, forming where there is a climate of high rainfall and a low level of evapotranspiration, allowing peat to develop not only in wet hollows but over large expanses of undulating ground.

title: Blanket bog
text: The blanketing of the ground with a variable depth of peat gives the habitat type its name.

title: Blanket bog
text: Blanket bogs are found extensively throughout the northern hemisphere - well-studied examples are found in Ireland and Britain, but vast areas of the Russian and North American tundra also qualify as blanket bogs.

title: Carnival Cravings
text: Carnival Cravings (also known as Carnival Cravings with Anthony Anderson) is an American television series on Food Network about unique food found at American carnivals.

title: Carnival Cravings
text: The series features actor/host Anthony Anderson as he samples culinary creations only available at carnivals, fairs and festivals around the country.

title: Carnival Cravings
text: The show premiered on August 12, 2015 and airs on Wednesdays at 10:00 p.m. EDT.

title: A&W Restaurants
text: A&W Restaurants, Inc. is a chain of fast-food restaurants distinguished by its draft root beer and root beer floats.

title: A&W Restaurants
text: Its origins date back to when Roy W. Allen opened a walk-up root beer stand in Lodi, California, in 1919.

title: A&W Restaurants
text: Allen's employee Frank Wright partnered with him and founded the first A&W restaurant in Sacramento, California, in 1923.

title: A&W Restaurants
text: The company name was taken respectively from the initials of their last names—Allen and Wright.

title: A&W Restaurants
text: The company became famous in the United States for its "frosty mugs," where the mugs would be kept in the freezer and eventually get filled with A&W Root Beer before they are served to customers.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: Jacob D. Robida (June 13, 1987 – February 5, 2006) was a Massachusetts teenager who attacked three patrons at a New Bedford gay bar on February 2, 2006.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: He fled the state and drove to Charleston, West Virginia, where he kidnapped Jennifer Rena Dunlap Bailey and drove southwest.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: He was stopped by Gassville, Arkansas Police Officer James W. Sell at the Brass Door Restaurant parking lot on the afternoon of February 4, 2006 for an apparent traffic violation.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: Robida shot and killed Sell and fled east.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: He turned onto Arkansas Highway 201 headed south and continued to Arkana, where he fired at Arkansas State Police Sgt. Van Nowlin.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: Deputies from the Baxter County Sheriff's Office had a spike strip deployed a short distance away.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: Robida drove over the spike strip, flattening both front tires on his Pontiac.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: He continued to Arkansas Highway 5, where he turned south and drove into the small town of Norfork.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: In the middle of town he lost control of the car due to the front tires, spun out, and hit two parked vehicles.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: He then shot Bailey, his kidnap victim, in the head with a Ruger 9mm semi-automatic pistol, killing her instantly.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: Police then opened fire on Robida.

title: Jacob D. Robida
text: He shot himself in the right side of the head.

title: Coronado, Panama
text: Coronado is a coastal city and resort located about an hour from Panama City.

title: Coronado, Panama
text: It is a vacation town visited yearly by thousands of national and international tourists.

title: Coronado, Panama
text: Coronado was Panama's first resort development, and for this reason has several years of advantage over other surrounding beach towns.

title: Coronado, Panama
text: The town has full scale supermarkets, pharmacies, restaurants, ranging from low cost "fondas" and fast-food restaurants to beachside bistros, medical and veterinary clinics, a hospital, gardening centers, hardware stores, banks, apparel shops, outdoor markets, a shopping plaza and a new shopping mall.

title: Strip search phone call scam
text: The strip search phone call scam is a series of incidents that extended over a period of about ten years before an arrest was made in 2004.

title: Strip search phone call scam
text: The incidents involved a man prank calling a restaurant or grocery store, claiming to be a police officer and then convincing managers to conduct strip searches of female employees, and to perform other bizarre acts on behalf of "the police".

title: Strip search phone call scam
text: The calls were most often placed to fast-food restaurants in small towns, located in rural areas of the United States.

title: Devyani Khobragade
text: Devyani Khobragade is an Indian Foreign Service officer.

title: Devyani Khobragade
text: While serving as Indian Deputy Consul General in New York, she made international headlines when she was arrested by US law enforcement for making false statements on a visa application for her housekeeper, paying her maid $3.99 an hour despite promising on the maid's visa application to pay the minimum legal wage.

title: Devyani Khobragade
text: Khobragade was arrested after dropping off her daughters at school in Manhattan.

title: Devyani Khobragade
text: She was subjected to a body-cavity search commonly called a "strip search", presented to a judge and released the same day.

title: Devyani Khobragade
text: This led to a major diplomatic standoff between India and the United States.

title: Devyani Khobragade
text: In 2016, she entered the world of fiction with her first book, "The White Sari".

title: Police perjury
text: Police perjury (or testilying in United States police slang) is the act of a police officer giving false testimony.

title: Police perjury
text: It is typically used in a criminal trial to "make the case" against a defendant who the police believe to be guilty when irregularities during the suspect's arrest or search threaten to result in acquittal.

title: Police perjury
text: It has broader meanings.

title: Police perjury
text: It also can be extended further to encompass substantive misstatements of fact for the purpose of convicting those whom the police believe to be guilty, or even to include statements to frame an innocent citizen.

title: Police perjury
text: More generically, it has been said to be: "Lying under oath, especially by a police officer, to help get a conviction."

title: Ringer Hut
text: Ringer Hut (リンガーハット ) is a Japanese chain of fast-food restaurants, specializing in Nagasaki dishes Champon and Sara udon.

title: Ringer Hut
text: The Hamakatsu Co. of Nagasaki, founders of the chain in 1974, borrowed the name of the former Ringer House which had been purchased by Nagasaki City and opened as a tourist attraction in 1966.

title: Ringer Hut
text: It is likely that the company borrowed the word "hut" from "Pizza Hut."

title: Ringer Hut
text: Ringer Hut operates over 550 restaurants in Japan, Taiwan, and San Jose, California along with 100 Hamakatsu Restaurants (tonkatsu restaurant chain).

title: Ringer Hut
text: Ringer Hut has two headquarters located in Fukuoka and Tokyo.

title: Body cavity search
text: A body cavity search, also known simply as a cavity search, is either a visual search or a manual internal inspection of body cavities for prohibited materials (contraband), such as illegal drugs, money, jewelry, or weapons.

title: Body cavity search
text: Body cavities used for concealment include nostrils, ears, mouth, navel, penis (urethra and foreskin) or vagina, and rectum.

title: Body cavity search
text: It is far more invasive than the standard strip search that is typically performed on individuals taken into custody, either upon police arrest or incarceration at a jail, prison, or psychiatric hospital.

title: Body cavity search
text: Often the procedure is repeated when the person leaves the institution.

title: Compliance (film)
text: Compliance is a 2012 American thriller film written and directed by Craig Zobel, and starring Ann Dowd, Dreama Walker, and Pat Healy.

title: Compliance (film)
text: The plot focuses on a prank caller who, posing as a police officer, convinces the manager of a fast food restaurant to carry out intrusive and unlawful procedures on an employee.

title: Compliance (film)
text: The film is based on the strip search prank call scam that took place at a Mount Washington, Kentucky McDonald's restaurant in Bullit County.

title: Compliance (film)
text: Dowd's performance as Sandra, the manager, won her the National Board of Review Award for Best Supporting Actress.

title: Part-time job terrorism
text: Part-time job terrorism (バイトテロ , baito tero ) is a Japanese social phenomenon; part-time employees perform pranks and stunts, such as climbing into ice cream freezers or holding their body horizontally suspended, more colloquially termed 'planking', on the counter-tops at fast-food restaurants, usually with the sole purpose of gaining recognition from their peers through the photos and/or videos they later display on social media sites.

title: Part-time job terrorism
text: This social phenomenon commonly involves people with high job dissatisfaction—a factor which is commonly cited by the media alongside low pay and arduously long working hours.

title: Part-time job terrorism
text: Although pranks such as the aforementioned would not be seen as shocking by many other cultures, they are considered disgraceful in Japanese culture.

title: Eastern Air Lines Shuttle
text: Eastern Air Lines Shuttle (or Eastern Air Shuttle) was the brand name of Eastern's air shuttle.

title: Eastern Air Lines Shuttle
text: It began operations on April 30, 1961 and was sold in 1989 to Donald Trump, and later became the Trump Shuttle.

title: Eastern Air Lines Shuttle
text: In April 1992, the shuttle service began as the USAir Shuttle (presently American Airlines Shuttle).

title: Eastern Air Lines Shuttle
text: The shuttle originally flew between New York City, Boston, Washington, D.C. and Newark.

title: Eastern Air Lines Shuttle
text: The shuttle's slogan was "Imagine life without us."

title: Denver International Airport
text: Denver International Airport (DEN), (IATA: DEN, ICAO: KDEN, FAA LID: DEN) , is an airport in Denver, Colorado, United States.

title: Denver International Airport
text: At 33,531 acres (52.4 sq mi), it is the largest airport in the United States by total land area.

title: Denver International Airport
text: Runway 16R/34L, with a length of 16000 ft , is the longest public use runway in the United States.

title: Denver International Airport
text: As of 2016, DEN was the 18th busiest airport in the world and the sixth busiest in the United States by passenger traffic with over 58 million passengers.

title: Denver International Airport
text: It also has the third largest domestic connection network in the country.

title: Denver International Airport
text: s of 2017 , the airport features 135 gates spread out over three detached, yet internally connected, linear concourses (A, B & C).

title: Dubai International Airport
text: Dubai International Airport (IATA: DXB, ICAO: OMDB) (Arabic: مطار دبي الدولي‎ ‎ ) is the primary international airport serving Dubai, United Arab Emirates and is the world's busiest airport by international passenger traffic.

title: Dubai International Airport
text: It is also the 3rd busiest airport in the world by passenger traffic, the 6th busiest cargo airport in world, the busiest airport for Airbus A380 and Boeing 777 movements, and the busiest airport in the world operating with only two runways.

title: Dubai International Airport
text: In 2016, DXB handled 83.6 million passengers, 2.59 million tonnes of cargo and registered 418,220 aircraft movements.

title: Townsville Airport
text: Townsville Airport (IATA: TSV, ICAO: YBTL) is a major Australian regional airport that services the city of Townsville.

title: Townsville Airport
text: The airport is also known as Townsville International Airport, and Garbutt Airport, a reference to its location in the Townsville suburb of Garbutt.

title: Townsville Airport
text: Townsville Airport is serviced by major Australian domestic and regional airlines, and in 2011/12 handled 1.7 million passengers making it the 11th busiest airport in Australia.

title: Coimbatore International Airport
text: Coimbatore International Airport (IATA: CJB, ICAO: VOCB) is the primary airport serving the city of Coimbatore in Tamil Nadu.

title: Coimbatore International Airport
text: It is located at Peelamedu, about 13 km from the center of the city.

title: Coimbatore International Airport
text: Previously known as Peelamedu Civil Aerodrome, it is the 19th busiest airport in India in terms of passengers handled, 16th busiest in terms of total aircraft movement and 14th busiest in terms of cargo handled.

title: Coimbatore International Airport
text: The airport is the second largest airport in terms of passenger traffic and cargo after Chennai International Airport In Tamil Nadu.

title: Coimbatore International Airport
text: About five domestic and three international airlines serve the airport.

title: Coimbatore International Airport
text: The Airport also serves as a growing hub for Cargo transportation.

title: Pitt Meadows Airport
text: Pitt Meadows Airport (ICAO: CYPK) is a Canadian general aviation airport located in the southwest of corner of Pitt Meadows, British Columbia.

title: Pitt Meadows Airport
text: In 2016, it was the 17th busiest airport in Canada with 109,188 aircraft movements and is the 4th busiest airport in the Lower Mainland.

title: Charlotte Douglas International Airport
text: Charlotte Douglas International Airport (IATA: CLT, ICAO: KCLT, FAA LID: CLT) is a joint civil-military public international airport located in Charlotte, North Carolina, United States.

title: Charlotte Douglas International Airport
text: Established in 1935 as Charlotte Municipal Airport, in 1954 the airport was renamed Douglas Municipal Airport after former Charlotte mayor Ben Elbert Douglas, Sr. The airport gained its current name in 1982 and, as of September 2017, it is the second largest hub for American Airlines after Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, with service to 161 domestic and international destinations.

title: Charlotte Douglas International Airport
text: As of 2016 it was the 5th busiest airport in the United States, ranked by passenger traffic and aircraft movements.

title: Charlotte Douglas International Airport
text: It was also the 7th business airport in the world ranked by aircraft movements Charlotte is the largest airport in the United States without any nonstop service to Asia.

title: Charlotte Douglas International Airport
text: The airport serves as a major gateway to the Caribbean Islands.

title: Charlotte Douglas International Airport
text: CLT covers 5,558 acres (2,249 ha) of land.

title: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport
text: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport (IATA: DLC, ICAO: ZYTL) is the airport serving the city of Dalian in Liaoning Province, China.

title: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport
text: It is located in Ganjingzi District, about 10 km northwest of the city center.

title: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport
text: In 2014 the airport handled 17,203,640 passengers, making it the busiest airport in Northeast China and the 16th busiest nationwide.

title: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport
text: The airport is the hub for Dalian Airlines and a focus city for China Southern Airlines and Hainan Airlines.

title: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport
text: As Zhoushuizi Airport has reached its designed capacity, the new Dalian Jinzhouwan International Airport is being built on reclaimed land to replace it.

title: American Airlines Shuttle
text: American Airlines Shuttle is the brand name for American Airlines' hourly air shuttle service operating in the Northeastern United States.

title: American Airlines Shuttle
text: It serves Logan International Airport in Boston, LaGuardia Airport in New York City, and Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Washington, D.C.

title: Kazan International Airport
text: Kazan International Airport (Russian: Международный аэропорт Казань , Tatar: Казан Халыкара Аэропорты / Qazan Xalıqara Aeroportı ; IATA: KZN, ICAO: UWKD) is an airport located in Tatarstan, Russia, around 25 km southeast of Kazan.

title: Kazan International Airport
text: It is the largest airport in Tatarstan, and the 15th busiest airport in Russia.

title: Kazan International Airport
text: Kazan Airport served nearly 3.8 million citizens of the region .

title: Ehretia
text: Ehretia is a genus of flowering plants in the borage family, Boraginaceae.

title: Ehretia
text: It contains about 50 species.

title: Ehretia
text: The generic name honors German botanical illustrator Georg Dionysius Ehret (1708–1770).

title: Xanthoceras
text: Xanthoceras sorbifolium (yellowhorn, shiny leaf yellowhorn, goldenhorn, Chinese flowering chestnut) is a woody perennial in the soapberry family, Sapindaceae, and the only species in the genus Xanthoceras.

title: Xanthoceras
text: It is native to northern China in the provinces of Gansu, Hebei, Henan, Liaoning, Nei Monggol, Ningxia, Shaanxi, and Shandong.

title: Xanthoceras
text: It is also cultivated in Russia, having been imported there since the 19th Century.

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: In baseball, batting average (AVG) is a measure of a batter's success rate in achieving a hit during an at bat.

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: In Major League Baseball (MLB), it is calculated by dividing a player's hits by his at bats (AB).

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: In MLB, a player in each league wins the "batting title" each season for having the highest batting average that year.

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: The American League (AL) winner is known as the "Rod Carew American League Batting Champion", while the National League (NL) leader is designated the "Tony Gwynn National League Batting Champion".

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: Under current rules, a player must have 3.1 plate appearances (PA) per team game (for a total of 502 over the current 162-game season) to qualify for the batting title.

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: However, if a player's lead in AVG is sufficiently large that enough hitless at bats can be added to reach this requirement and the player still would have the highest batting average, he wins the title.

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: Tony Gwynn, for example, had 159 hits in 451 ABs in 1996 (.353 average) but only 498 PAs.

title: List of Major League Baseball batting champions
text: Gwynn's batting average would have dropped to .349 (159 hits in 455 ABs) with four hitless ABs added to reach the 502 PA requirement, but this would still have been higher than the next-highest eligible player (.344 average), so he was awarded the 1996 NL batting title.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: John Paul "Jack" Fox (May 21, 1885 – June 28, 1963) was a professional baseball player whose career spanned 11 seasons, including one in Major League Baseball.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: During that one season in 1908, Fox played with the Philadelphia Athletics.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: Fox compiled a major league batting average of .200 with two runs, six hits and two stolen bases in nine games played.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: Fox also played in the minor leagues with the Class-C Poughkeepsie Colts (1906), the Class-B Albany Senators (1906–07), the Class-A Jersey City Skeeters (1908), the Class-A Memphis Egyptians (1908), the Class-B Wilkes-Barre Barons (1909), the Class-B Troy Trojans, the Class-A Lincoln Railsplitters (1910–11), the Class-B Harrisburg Senators (1912–14), the Class-D Bradford Drillers (1914) and the Class-B Scranton Miners (1915–16).

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: He started his minor league career as an outfielder, but later converted into a pitcher.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: Fox compiled a career minor league batting average of .251 with 670 hits in 694 games played.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: As a pitcher, he compiled a win–loss record of 90–63 in 185 career minor league games pitched.

title: Jack Fox (baseball)
text: Fox batted and threw right-handed.

title: Frank Crossin
text: Francis Patrick "Frank" Crossin, Sr. (June 15, 1891 – December 6, 1965) was a professional baseball player whose career spanned seven seasons, three of which were spent in Major League Baseball (MLB) St. Louis Browns (1912–14).

title: Frank Crossin
text: Over his Major League career, Crossin, a catcher, compiled a .147 batting average with eight runs scored, 17 hits, one double, one triple, and seven runs batted in (RBIs) in 55 games played.

title: Frank Crossin
text: He made his professional debut with the minor league Binghamton Bingoes in 1912.

title: Frank Crossin
text: His MLB debut came on September 24, 1912.

title: Frank Crossin
text: Crossin played parts of the next two seasons in the majors.

title: Frank Crossin
text: In 1915, a year after his MLB career ended, he returned to the minors.

title: Frank Crossin
text: Over his career in the minors, Crossin compiled a .261 batting average with 303 hits in 381 games played.

title: Frank Crossin
text: He batted, and threw right-handed.

title: Frank Crossin
text: During his career, he stood at 5 ft , and weighed 160 lb .

title: Dick Kauffman
text: Howard Richard "Dick" Kauffman (June 22, 1888 – April 16, 1948) was a professional baseball player whose career spanned 11 seasons, two of which were spent in Major League Baseball (MLB) with the St. Louis Browns (1914–15).

title: Dick Kauffman
text: Kauffman, a first baseman, compiled a career major league batting average of .259 with 10 runs scored, 36 hits, nine doubles, two triples, and 16 runs batted in (RBIs) in 44 games played.

title: Dick Kauffman
text: His professional career began in 1911 with the minor league York White Roses.

title: Dick Kauffman
text: Kauffman's first MLB season came in 1914.

title: Dick Kauffman
text: He was again called-up in 1915.

title: Dick Kauffman
text: After that season, he played exclusively in the minor leagues.

title: Dick Kauffman
text: He has a career minor league batting average of .279 with 1,239 hits in 1,217 games played.

title: Dick Kauffman
text: In the minors, he played with the York White Roses (1911–12), Elmira Colonels (1913–14), Atlanta Crackers (1915, 1920–21), and Nashville Volunteers (1916–19).

title: Dick Kauffman
text: Before turning professional, Kauffman, an East Lewisburg, Pennsylvania native, attended Bucknell University, and Susquehanna University, respectively.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: Charlie August "Cholly" Engle (August 27, 1903 – October 12, 1983) was an American professional baseball infielder.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: He played shortstop for the Philadelphia Athletics during the 1925 and 1926 seasons and the Pittsburgh Pirates during the 1930 season.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: Engle made his major league debut in a game against the New York Yankees on September 14, 1925.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: This was the only game he played in the season and he did not get at bat.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: In the 1926 season he played in 19 games with a batting average of .105.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: He played in the minor leagues for the Memphis Chickasaws and had a batting average of .302 in 1929.

title: Charlie Engle (baseball)
text: He was subsequently drafted into the Pirates in the 1930 major league season.

title: 1921 Detroit Tigers season
text: The 1921 Detroit Tigers finished in sixth place in the American League, 27 games behind the Yankees, with a record of 71–82.

title: 1921 Detroit Tigers season
text: Despite their sixth-place finish, the 1921 Tigers amassed 1,724 hits and a team batting average of .316—the highest team hit total and batting average in American League history.

title: 1921 Detroit Tigers season
text: Detroit outfielders Harry Heilmann and Ty Cobb finished No. 1 and No. 2 in the American League batting race with batting averages of .394 and .389, and all three Detroit outfielders (Heilmann, Cobb, and Bobby Veach) ranked among the league leaders in batting average and RBIs.

title: 1921 Detroit Tigers season
text: As early proof of the baseball adage that "Good Pitching Beats Good Hitting", the downfall of the 1921 Tigers was the absence of good pitching.

title: 1921 Detroit Tigers season
text: The team ERA was 4.40, they allowed nine or more runs 28 times, and only one pitcher (Dutch Leonard) had an ERA below 4.24.

title: Chick Shorten
text: Charles Henry "Chick" Shorten (April 19, 1892 – October 23, 1965) was an American baseball player.

title: Chick Shorten
text: He played professional baseball as an outfielder for 18 years from 1911 to 1928, including eight seasons in Major League Baseball with the Boston Red Sox (1915–1917), Detroit Tigers (1919–1921), St. Louis Browns (1922), and Cincinnati Reds (1924).

title: Chick Shorten
text: He was a member of the 1916 Red Sox team that won the World Series, and Shorten compiled a .571 batting average in the 1916 World Series.

title: Chick Shorten
text: In eight major league seasons, Shorten appeared in 527 games, including 352 as an outfielder, and compiled a .275 career batting average.

title: Germán Barranca
text: Germán Barranca Costales (born October 19, 1956 in Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, Mexico) is a former Major League Baseball second baseman.

title: Germán Barranca
text: On August 26, 1974 he was purchased by the Kansas City Royals from the Mexico City Reds.

title: Germán Barranca
text: He was listed at 6 feet tall and 160 pounds.

title: Germán Barranca
text: German made his major league debut on September 2, 1979 at the age of 22 with the Kansas City Royals vs the New York Yankees.

title: Germán Barranca
text: German played 5 games that year and also played 7 games with the Royals in 1980 with a batting average of .600 On January 21, was traded by the Kansas City Royals to the Cincinnati Reds for Cesar Geronimo.

title: Germán Barranca
text: Played for the Cincinnati Reds in 1981 with a batting average of .333 and 1982 batting average of .255 German last game in the MLB was July 11 1982 vs. CHC at age 25.

title: Germán Barranca
text: German was batting .250 and leading the National League in triples before the all star break was sent to Indianapolis the triple A of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Germán Barranca
text: On September 7, 1982 was sent to the Detroit Tigers by the Cincinnati Reds as part of a conditional deal.

title: Germán Barranca
text: German played 4 years in Major League Baseball (2 years in the American League played 12 games ) and ( 2 years in the National League played 55 games ) with a total of 67 games, 62 AB, 19 Runs, 18 hits, 2 doubles, 3 triples, 5 stolen bases a fielding % of .893 and batting average of .290

title: Frank Thomas (designated hitter)
text: Frank Edward Thomas Jr. (born May 27, 1968), nicknamed "The Big Hurt," is an American former first baseman in Major League Baseball who played for three American League (AL) teams from 1990 to 2008, all but the last three years with the Chicago White Sox.

title: Frank Thomas (designated hitter)
text: One of the most fearsome and devastating hitters of his era, he is the only player in major league history to have seven consecutive seasons (1991–1997) with a .300 batting average and at least 100 runs batted in (RBI), 100 runs scored, 100 walks and 20 home runs; over that period, he batted .330 and averaged 36 home runs and 118 RBI per year.

title: Frank Thomas (designated hitter)
text: A perennial MVP candidate through the 1990s, he was named the AL's Most Valuable Player by unanimous vote in 1993 after becoming the first White Sox player to hit 40 home runs, leading the team to a division title; he repeated as MVP in the strike-shortened 1994 season after batting .353 and leading the league in slugging average and runs.

title: Frank Thomas (designated hitter)
text: After two subpar seasons, he lost the MVP in a close vote in 2000 after posting career highs of 43 home runs and 143 RBI, also earning AL Comeback Player of the Year honors, as Chicago finished with the AL's best record.

title: Ron Herbel
text: Ronald Samuel Herbel (January 16, 1938 – January 20, 2000) was a right-handed Major League Baseball pitcher.

title: Ron Herbel
text: His .029 career batting average is the lowest batting average in Major League history for a player with a minimum of 100 at-bats.

title: Evermore (Beauty and the Beast song)
text: "Evermore" is a song written by composer Alan Menken and lyricist Tim Rice for the musical fantasy film "Beauty and the Beast" (2017), a live-action remake of Disney's 1991 animated film of the same name.

title: Evermore (Beauty and the Beast song)
text: Originally recorded for the film by English actor Dan Stevens, who performs the song in his starring role as the titular Beast, "Evermore" was first released as a single by American singer Josh Groban on March 3, 2017.

title: Evermore (Beauty and the Beast song)
text: Stevens' version was made available on March 10, 2017 when the film's soundtrack was released online, while Groban's single is played in closing credits.

title: Robby Benson
text: Robin David Segal (born January 21, 1956), better known by the stage name Robby Benson, is an American actor, director, singer and educator.

title: Robby Benson
text: He is known as the voice of The Beast in the Disney animated film "Beauty and the Beast" and its numerous sequels and spin-offs, and for directing several episodes of the popular sitcom "Friends".

title: Belle (Disney song)
text: "Belle" is a song written by composer Alan Menken and lyricist Howard Ashman for Walt Disney Pictures' 30th animated feature film "Beauty and the Beast" (1991).

title: Belle (Disney song)
text: Originally recorded by American actress and singer Paige O'Hara and American actor Richard White, "Belle", a mid-tempo French and classical music-inspired song, incorporates both Broadway and musical theatre elements.

title: Belle (Disney song)
text: The film's first song and opening number, "Belle" appears during "Beauty and the Beast "as a large scale operetta-style production number that introduces the film's heroine Belle, considered a book-loving nonconformist by the townspeople of the village, who has grown weary of the provincial life in which she is supposed to live, and Gaston, the film's narcissistic villain who wishes to desire her hand in marriage despite Belle's rejections.

title: Be Our Guest
text: "Be Our Guest" is a song written by lyricist Howard Ashman and composer Alan Menken for Walt Disney Pictures' 30th animated feature film "Beauty and the Beast" (1991).

title: Be Our Guest
text: Recorded by American actor Jerry Orbach and English actress Angela Lansbury as Lumiere and Mrs. Potts, respectively, "Be Our Guest" is a large-scale Broadway-inspired musical number that takes place during the first half of "Beauty and the Beast", performed by the castle's staff of enchanted objects in an elaborate attempt to welcome Belle.

title: Be Our Guest
text: Menken initially intended for the melody of "Be Our Guest" to be temporary but was ultimately unable to compose a satisfying one with which to replace it.

title: Be Our Guest
text: The song had originally been intended for Belle's father Maurice.

title: Be Our Guest
text: However, "Be Our Guest" had to be entirely re-written as the story evolved in order to return its focus to Belle.

title: Anna Simpson
text: Anna Simpson (born March 23, 1985) is an American actress and singer born in Brooklyn, New York.

title: Anna Simpson
text: She is best known for the film, "Our Song", alongside Kerry Washington and Melissa Martinez (2000).

title: Anna Simpson
text: She has a daughter named Chasity who she gave birth to at the age of 15.

title: Anna Simpson
text: Simpson is a survivor of sexual abuse.

title: Paige O'Hara
text: Donna Paige Helmintoller, better known as Paige O'Hara (born May 10, 1956), is an American actress, singer and painter.

title: Paige O'Hara
text: O'Hara began her career as a Broadway actress in 1983 when she portrayed Ellie May Chipley in the musical "Showboat".

title: Paige O'Hara
text: In 1991, she made her motion picture debut in Disney's "Beauty and the Beast", in which she voiced the film's heroine, Belle.

title: Paige O'Hara
text: Following the critical and commercial success of "Beauty and the Beast", O'Hara reprised her role as Belle in the film's two direct-to-video follow-ups, "" and "Belle's Magical World".

title: Beauty and the Beast (Disney song)
text: "Beauty and the Beast" is a song written by lyricist Howard Ashman and composer Alan Menken for the Disney animated feature film "Beauty and the Beast" (1991).

title: Beauty and the Beast (Disney song)
text: The film's theme song, the Broadway-inspired ballad was first recorded by British-American actress Angela Lansbury in her role as the voice of the character Mrs. Potts, and essentially describes the relationship between its two main characters Belle and the Beast, specifically how the couple has learned to accept their differences and in turn change each other for the better.

title: Beauty and the Beast (Disney song)
text: Additionally, the song's lyrics imply that the feeling of love is as timeless and ageless as a "tale as old as time".

title: Beauty and the Beast (Disney song)
text: Lansbury's rendition is heard during the famous ballroom sequence between Belle and the Beast, while a shorted chorale version plays in the closing scenes of the film, and the song's motif features frequently in other pieces of Menken's film score.

title: Beauty and the Beast (Disney song)
text: "Beauty and the Beast" was subsequently recorded as a pop duet by Canadian singer Celine Dion and American singer Peabo Bryson, and released as the only single from the film's soundtrack on November 25, 1991.

title: Marissa Perry
text: Marissa Perry (born May 5, 1985) is an American actress and singer born in Waterbury, Connecticut.

title: Something There
text: "Something There" is a song written by lyricist Howard Ashman and composer Alan Menken for Walt Disney Pictures 30th animated feature film "Beauty and the Beast" (1991).

title: Something There
text: Sung by the majority of the film's main cast, the song was recorded by American actors Paige O'Hara as Belle and Robby Benson as the Beast via voice over, featuring actors Jerry Orbach, Angela Lansbury and David Ogden Stiers as Lumiere, Mrs. Potts and Cogsworth, respectively.

title: Something There
text: The only song performed by the Beast, "Something There" is heard midway through "Beauty and the Beast "during a scene in which Belle and the Beast finally begin to acknowledge their own feelings for each other.

title: Belle (Disney)
text: Belle is a fictional character who appears in Walt Disney Pictures' 30th animated feature film "Beauty and the Beast" (1991).

title: Belle (Disney)
text: Originally voiced by American actress and singer Paige O'Hara, Belle is the non-conforming daughter of an inventor.

title: Belle (Disney)
text: Belle yearns to abandon her predictable village life in return for adventure.

title: Belle (Disney)
text: When her father Maurice is imprisoned by a cold-hearted beast, Belle offers him her own freedom in exchange for her father's, and eventually learns to love the Beast despite his unsightly outward appearance.

title: Babe Ruth
text: George Herman "Babe" Ruth Jr. (February 6, 1895 – August 16, 1948) was an American professional baseball player whose career in Major League Baseball (MLB) spanned 22 seasons, from 1914 through 1935.

title: Babe Ruth
text: Nicknamed "The Bambino" and "The Sultan of Swat", he began his MLB career as a stellar left-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, but achieved his greatest fame as a slugging outfielder for the New York Yankees.

title: Babe Ruth
text: Ruth established many MLB batting (and some pitching) records, including career home runs (714), runs batted in (RBIs) (2,213), bases on balls (2,062), slugging percentage (.690), and on-base plus slugging (OPS) (1.164); the latter two still stand today.

title: Babe Ruth
text: Ruth is regarded as one of the greatest sports heroes in American culture and is considered by many to be the greatest baseball player of all time.

title: Babe Ruth
text: In 1936 , Ruth was elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame as one of its "first five" inaugural members.

title: Charles Teague (baseball)
text: Charles Clyde Teague (born 1924) was an American professional baseball player.

title: Charles Teague (baseball)
text: A second baseman, he played in minor league baseball.

title: Charles Teague (baseball)
text: As a college baseball player for Wake Forest University, he was named an All-American in three seasons.

title: Charles Teague (baseball)
text: In 2010, he was inducted into the National College Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: USC Trojans baseball
text: The USC Trojans baseball program represents the University of Southern California in college baseball.

title: USC Trojans baseball
text: Established in 1888, the team is a member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Pac-12 Conference.

title: USC Trojans baseball
text: The head coach of the Trojans is Dan Hubbs, who has held the position since the start of the 2013 season.

title: USC Trojans baseball
text: USC home's field is Dedeaux Field, which is named in honor of former head coach and National College Baseball Hall of Fame inductee Rod Dedeaux.

title: Dizzy Dean
text: Jay Hanna "Dizzy" Dean (January 16, 1910 – July 17, 1974), also known as Jerome Herman Dean, was an American professional baseball player.

title: Dizzy Dean
text: He played in Major League Baseball as a pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, Chicago Cubs and the St. Louis Browns.

title: Dizzy Dean
text: A brash and colorful personality, Dean was the last National League pitcher to win 30 games in one season.

title: Dizzy Dean
text: After his playing career, he became a popular television sports commentator.

title: Dizzy Dean
text: Dean was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1953.

title: Dizzy Dean
text: When the Cardinals reopened the team Hall of Fame in 2014, Dean was inducted among the inaugural class.

title: Greatest Sports Legends
text: Greatest Sports Legends is a sports anthology series on the lives and careers of noted athletes.

title: Greatest Sports Legends
text: First aired in 1972, the series was produced with 10 new episodes per year nestled amongst 42 reruns.

title: Greatest Sports Legends
text: 207 episodes were produced, with athlete hosts including Michael Jordan,Tom Seaver, Paul Hornung, Reggie Jackson, Steve Garvey and Celebrity Hosts George Plimpton, Ken Howard and Jayne Kennedy interviewing the featured athlete.

title: Greatest Sports Legends
text: The series won one Emmy award out of three nominations.

title: Robin Ventura
text: Robin Mark Ventura ( ; born July 14, 1967) is an American former professional baseball third baseman and manager.

title: Robin Ventura
text: Ventura played 16 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Chicago White Sox, New York Mets, New York Yankees and Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Robin Ventura
text: He was also the manager for the White Sox for five seasons.

title: Robin Ventura
text: The White Sox selected Ventura with the tenth overall pick in the 1988 amateur draft from Oklahoma State University (OSU).

title: Robin Ventura
text: He is a six-time Rawlings Gold Glove winner, two-time MLB All-Star selection and a National College Baseball Hall of Fame inductee.

title: Tim Jorgensen
text: Timothy Scott Jorgensen (born November 30, 1972) is a former professional baseball player and high school baseball coach.

title: Tim Jorgensen
text: As a college baseball player for the University of Wisconsin–Oshkosh, Jorgensen set Division III all-time records for most home runs in a single season and for most career home runs.

title: Tim Jorgensen
text: He played professional baseball until 1999 and was later inducted into the National College Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Eddy Furniss
text: Wilburn Edward "Eddy" Furniss III (born September 18, 1975) is an American retired professional baseball first baseman and designated hitter.

title: Eddy Furniss
text: A standout college baseball player for Louisiana State University (LSU), Furniss has been inducted into the College Baseball Hall of Fame, the LSU Athletic Hall of Fame, and the Louisiana Sports Hall of Fame.

title: Mickey Mantle
text: Mickey Charles Mantle (October 20, 1931 – August 13, 1995), nicknamed The Commerce Comet and The Mick, was an American professional baseball player.

title: Mickey Mantle
text: Mantle played his entire Major League Baseball (MLB) career with the New York Yankees as a center fielder and first baseman, from 1951 through 1968.

title: Mickey Mantle
text: Mantle was one of the best players and sluggers, and is regarded by many as the greatest switch hitter in baseball history.

title: Mickey Mantle
text: Mantle was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1974 and was elected to the Major League Baseball All-Century Team in 1999.

title: Emma Carney
text: Emma Elizabeth Carney (born 29 July 1971) is an Australian professional triathlete and two time World Triathlon Champion.

title: Emma Carney
text: Emma is a Sport Australia Hall of Fame inductee (athlete member) (2016), World Triathlon International Triathlon Union Hall of Fame Inductee (2014) and Triathlon Australia (2012) Hall of Fame inductee.

title: Emma Carney
text: Emma is one of the few triathletes in the world to have won two ITU world titles.

title: Emma Carney
text: She was the world number one triathlete according to ITU rankings in 1995, 1996 and 1997, and achieved 19 World Cup wins, faster than any other triathlete.

title: Emma Carney
text: With seven wins in 1996, she also holds the record for the greatest number of ITU World Series wins in a single season.

title: Shinbone Alley
text: Shinbone Alley (sometimes performed as archy & mehitabel) is a musical with a book by Joe Darion and Mel Brooks, lyrics by Darion, and music by George Kleinsinger.

title: Shinbone Alley
text: Based on "archy and mehitabel", a series of "New York Tribune" columns by Don Marquis (illustrated by Krazy Kat author George Herriman), it focuses on poetic cockroach archy (who wasn't strong enough to depress the typewriter's shift-key), alley cat mehitabel, and her relationships with theatrical cat tyrone t. tattersal and tomcat big bill, under the watchful eye of the newspaperman, the voice-over narrator and only human being in the show.

title: Conferencier
text: Conférencier is the proper term for the master of ceremonies appearing in European cabaret.

title: Conferencier
text: The term appeared in the 1920s and became synonymous with these persona who not only emceed cabarets, but were well known for their political and social commentary.

title: Conferencier
text: They became controversial in the eye of the Nazi regime, who eventually cracked down and banned such commentary, keeping a watchful eye over these conférenciers.

title: Charles de Lorme
text: Charles de Lorme, Delorme, d'lorm, or De l'Orme (1 January 1584 – 31 December 1678), was a medical doctor.

title: Charles de Lorme
text: Charles was the son of Jean Delorme (a professor at Montpellier University), who was the primary doctor to Marie de' Medici.

title: Charles de Lorme
text: This ultimately opened doors for Charles' medical career soon after he graduated from the University of Montpellier in 1607 at the age of 23.

title: Charles de Lorme
text: He first came to Paris after graduation to practice medicine under the watchful eye of his father, until he was ready to practice as a regular doctor on his own.

title: Charles de Lorme
text: There are no records of his marriages, except that he married for the third time at the age of 78.

title: Charles de Lorme
text: This wife died within a year.

title: Salisbury Woodland Gardens, Blackpool
text: Salisbury Woodland Gardens is an open space located in the east of Blackpool, flanked by East Park Drive and Woodside Drive and linking Blackpool Zoo with Stanley Park.

title: Salisbury Woodland Gardens, Blackpool
text: Known simply as the 'Woodland Gardens' to local people, the site was acquired in 1924 by Blackpool Corporation and was originally developed as a shelter belt for the adjacent Stanley Park Golf Course.

title: Salisbury Woodland Gardens, Blackpool
text: The gardens were later developed in the 1940s as an arboretum and public open space for all to enjoy.

title: Salisbury Woodland Gardens, Blackpool
text: It was renovated in 1967 by Peter Perry and his 'Flying Squad (see below).

title: Salisbury Woodland Gardens, Blackpool
text: Popular once as a wedding photograph location, the site went into decline during the 1990s.

title: Salisbury Woodland Gardens, Blackpool
text: The Council's Ranger Service manage and protect the gardens which they took over in September 2006 and have been funding and undertaking the restoration of the woodland.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: Kiyoshi Daniel Kohatsu, or Daniel Kiyoshi, is an animation director and producer.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: He was born in Lince, Lima, Peru in March 1971.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: Of Japanese descent, Kiyoshi attended primary and secondary school at La Union School.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: He enrolled the Faculty of Arts of the Catholic University of Peru.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: Uncontented with the escolasticics of "artsi farsi", Kiyoshi decided to leave the university and moved to Tokyo and then to Vancouver, Canada to follow studies in cinema.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: Later, he graduated from Vancouver Film School as an animation artist.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: Under the tutelage and watchful eye of animator and director of cartoons Marv Newland, founder of "International Rocketship", Kiyoshi started a career dedicated to production of animation.

title: Kiyoshi Kohatsu
text: As a freelancer, Kohatsu worked on several projects for Dreamworks, Warner Bros., MTV, Nickelodeon and Disney,

title: Toby Sibbick
text: Toby Peter Sibbick (born 23 May 1999) is an English footballer who plays for AFC Wimbledon.

title: Toby Sibbick
text: Toby went to St Lawrence R C Primary School in Feltham, West London where he learnt his football trade under the watchful eye on Rory McCormack who was St Lawrence R C Primary School's Headteacher and school football team coach.

title: Toby Sibbick
text: Toby began as a more attacking playing ending up top goalscorer for the school and winning the school championship.

title: Toby Sibbick
text: Toby attended Gunnersbury Boys' School secondary school where he represented the school in many sports with football being the main sport.

title: Double Trouble (U.S. TV series)
text: Double Trouble is an American sitcom that aired on NBC from April 4, 1984 to March 30, 1985.

title: Double Trouble (U.S. TV series)
text: The series stars identical twins Jean and Liz Sagal as Kate and Allison Foster, two teenagers living under the watchful eye of their widowed father.

title: Double Trouble (U.S. TV series)
text: The show was considered an updating of the "twins in mischief" concept seen in films like "The Parent Trap" or the "Patty Duke Show" of the 1960s.

title: Double Trouble (U.S. TV series)
text: The Sagal sisters acknowledged that Norman Lear, the Sagal family's godfather, was the one who held influence over the show's concept.

title: Patan minara
text: Patan Minara is believed to be a 5000 year old Buddhist monastery situated eight kilometers from Rahim Yar Khan city, located in Pakistan.

title: Patan minara
text: Patan minara was built during Hakrra valley civilization during the Mauryan period (250BC).

title: Patan minara
text: It was once the capital of Hindu kingdom in 10 AD as mentioned by Colonel Toy.

title: Patan minara
text: Some archeologists believe that the structure was built by Alexander the Great when he passed through this area during his military expedition to India.

title: Patan minara
text: As was his practice, Alexander set up a cantonment here under a Greek governor and tower served for keeping a watchful eye on the local tribes.

title: Patan minara
text: There is a mystery behind it that there was once treasure hidden in that historical building.

title: Patan minara
text: By the 18th century when Patan Minara was demolished they discovered a brick with sanskrit written on it.

title: Sasquatched! The Musical
text: Sasquatched!

title: Sasquatched! The Musical
text: The Musical is a two-act musical written by Phil Darg in 2012.

title: Sasquatched! The Musical
text: The piece is a musical comedy that depicts "Bigfoot" (Arthur the Sasquatch) as a talking, intelligent, and dignified creature whose sudden presence in the fictional Columbia National Park precipitates a series of humorous encounters with quirky locals.

title: Sasquatched! The Musical
text: Set to a pop-rock musical score, Arthur does his best to convince the park patrons that he is worthy of their respect and friendship – while countering "Bigfoot" stereotypes and eluding the watchful eye of the media, who are attempting to expose and exploit Arthur and all of the Sasquatches.

title: List of The Thick of It characters
text: "The Thick of It" is a British television comedy programme that premiered in 2005 on BBC Four.

title: List of The Thick of It characters
text: The series satirises the inner workings of modern British government.

title: List of The Thick of It characters
text: It follows the running of a fictional Department of Social Affairs and Citizenship, and most episodes focus on that department's incumbent minister and a core cast of advisors and civil servants, under the watchful eye of Number 10's enforcer, Malcolm Tucker (Peter Capaldi).

title: List of The Thick of It characters
text: The supporting characters include people in government, in the opposition, and in the media.

title: Accompaniment
text: Accompaniment is the musical parts which provide the rhythmic and/or harmonic support for the melody or main themes of a song or instrumental piece.

title: Accompaniment
text: There are many different styles and types of accompaniment in different genres and styles of music.

title: Accompaniment
text: In homophonic music, the main accompaniment approach used in popular music, a clear vocal melody is supported by subordinate chords.

title: Accompaniment
text: In popular music and traditional music, the accompaniment parts typically provide the "beat" for the music and outline the chord progression of the song or instrumental piece.

title: Accompaniment
text: The accompaniment for a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be played by a single musician playing an instrument such as piano, pipe organ, or guitar.

title: Accompaniment
text: While any instrument can in theory be used as an accompaniment instrument, keyboard and guitar-family instruments tend to be used if there is only a single instrument, as these instruments can play chords and basslines simultaneously (chords and a bassline are easier to play simultaneously on keyboard instruments, but a fingerpicking guitarist can play chords and a bassline simultaneously on guitar).

title: Accompaniment
text: A solo singer can accompany herself by playing guitar or piano while she sings, and in some rare cases, a solo singer can even accompany himself or herself just using his or her voice and body (e.g., Bobby McFerrin).

title: Bukkehorn
text: A bukkehorn (Norwegian) or bockhorn (Swedish), also called ′′Billy Goat Horn′′ in English, is an ancient Scandinavian musical instrument, made from the horn of a ram or a goat.

title: Bukkehorn
text: The horn is usually made from a goat horn harvested 5 to 7 years before the instrument is crafted.

title: Bukkehorn
text: It was traditionally used by shepherds and milkmaids on summer dairy farms in the mountains, as a signal-instrument or as a scaring instrument.

title: Bukkehorn
text: When the horn later got finger holes it became possible to play melodies with it.

title: Bukkehorn
text: The instrument has two blowing-techniques: the trumpet-principle is the most common, but the clarinet-principle is also used.

title: Chander Bari
text: Chander Bari is a 2007 Bengali film directed by Tarun Majumdar.

title: Chander Bari
text: The film centers on a middle class joint family.

title: Chander Bari
text: The film is based on a Bengali story written by Pracheta Gupta.

title: Chander Bari
text: Majumdar used some Rabindra Sangeets in this film.

title: Koto (instrument)
text: The koto (Japanese: 箏) is a traditional Japanese stringed musical instrument derived from the Chinese zheng, and similar to the Mongolian yatga, the Korean gayageum, and the Vietnamese đàn tranh.

title: Koto (instrument)
text: The koto is the national instrument of Japan.

title: Koto (instrument)
text: Koto are about 180 cm length, and made from "kiri" wood ("Paulownia tomentosa").

title: Koto (instrument)
text: They have 13 strings that are usually strung over 13 movable bridges along the width of the instrument.

title: Koto (instrument)
text: There is also a 17-string koto variant.

title: Koto (instrument)
text: Players can adjust the string pitches by moving the white bridges before playing.

title: Koto (instrument)
text: To play the instrument, the strings are plucked using three finger picks, otherwise known as plectra, (on thumb, index finger, and middle finger).

title: Sousaphone
text: The sousaphone ( ), is a brass instrument in the same family as the more widely known tuba.

title: Sousaphone
text: Created around 1893 by J.W. Pepper at the direction of American bandleader John Philip Sousa (whom the instrument was then named after), it was designed to be easier to play than the concert tuba while standing or marching, as well as to carry the sound of the instrument above the heads of the band.

title: Sousaphone
text: Like the tuba, sound is produced by moving air past the lips, causing them to vibrate or "buzz" into a large cupped mouthpiece.

title: Sousaphone
text: Unlike the tuba, the instrument is bent in a circle to fit around the body of the musician; it ends in a large, flaring bell that is pointed forward, projecting the sound ahead of the player.

title: Sousaphone
text: Because of the ease of carrying and the direction of sound, it is widely employed in marching bands, as well as various other musical genres.

title: Sousaphone
text: Sousaphones were originally made out of brass but in the mid-20th century started to be made from lighter materials like fiberglass; today both types are in wide use.

title: Embouchure
text: Embouchure or lipping is the use of the lips, facial muscles, tongue, and teeth in playing a wind instrument.

title: Embouchure
text: This includes shaping the lips to the mouthpiece of a woodwind instrument or the mouthpiece of a brass instrument.

title: Embouchure
text: The word is of French origin and is related to the root "bouche ", 'mouth'.

title: Embouchure
text: Proper embouchure allows instrumentalists to play their instrument at its full range with a full, clear tone and without strain or damage to their muscles.

title: Udaka vadya
text: Udaka Vadya is an Indian musical instrument.

title: Udaka vadya
text: It is assumed either this musical instruments had been Jal tarang or similar to it.

title: Udaka vadya
text: This percussion instrument has been categorized in medieval musical treatise under Ghan Vadya (diophonic instruments where the sound is produced by striking a surface).

title: Udaka vadya
text: This instrument has been mentioned in Vatsyayana's Kamasutra, also Sangeeta Parijata of the 17th century mentioned about this instrument.

title: Udaka vadya
text: The skill to play this instrument was one of the essential 64 kala to be learnt by a woman.

title: Experimental musical instrument
text: An experimental musical instrument (or custom-made instrument) is a musical instrument that modifies or extends an existing instrument or class of instruments, or defines or creates a new class of instrument.

title: Experimental musical instrument
text: Some are created through simple modifications, such as cracked drum cymbals or metal objects inserted between piano strings in a prepared piano.

title: Experimental musical instrument
text: Some experimental instruments are created from household items like a homemade mute for brass instruments such as bathtub plugs.

title: Experimental musical instrument
text: Other experimental instruments are created from electronic spare parts, or by mixing acoustic instruments with electric components.

title: Asset classes
text: An asset class is a group of instruments which have similar financial characteristics and behave similarly in the marketplace.

title: Asset classes
text: We can often break these instruments into those having to do with real assets and those having to do with financial assets.

title: Asset classes
text: Often, assets within the same asset class are subject to the same laws and regulations; however, this is not always true.

title: Asset classes
text: For instance, futures on an asset are often considered part of the same asset class as the underlying instrument but are subject to different regulations than the underlying instrument.

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: The keyboard glockenspiel (French: "jeu de timbre") or organ glockenspiel is an instrument consisting of a glockenspiel operated by a piano keyboard.

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: It was first used by George Frideric Handel in the oratorio "Saul" (1739).

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: It was also used in the 1739 revivals of his "Il Trionfo del Tempo" and "Acis and Galatea", and the next year in "L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato".

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: Half a century later, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart employed a "strumento d’acciaio" in "The Magic Flute" (1791) to represent Papageno's magic bells, and this instrument is believed to have been a keyboard glockenspiel.

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: This part is nowadays sometimes taken by a celesta.

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: Maurice Ravel preferred the keyboard version of the instrument because it can play a true ff dynamic for brilliance and iridescence in orchestral climaxes.

title: Keyboard glockenspiel
text: In the late 20th century, the firm of Bergerault began manufacturing a three-octave (F2–E4) mallet instrument with a damping mechanism operated by a foot pedal, which is capable of dealing with the wide range called for in contemporary scores.

title: The Dragon, the Hero
text: The Dragon, The Hero is a Hong Kong martial art movie directed by Godfrey Ho and starring Philip Ko,Dragon Lee, Tino Wong Cheung and Liu Chung-Liang.

title: The Dragon, the Hero
text: The movie is considered as one of the best martial arts movie that Godfrey Ho directed outside of the martial arts movie fanbase.

title: The Dragon, the Hero
text: The movie is also known as Dragon on Fire.

title: Jamie Harris (actor)
text: Jamie Harris (born May 15, 1963) is a British actor.

title: Jamie Harris (actor)
text: He is best known for his role as The Hook-Handed Man in "Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events", Rodney in "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" and Gordon in Marvel's "Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.".

title: Usman Ally
text: Usman Ally is an American film, stage and television actor.

title: Usman Ally
text: In 2015, Ally won an Obie Award for his role in "The Invisible Hand".

title: Usman Ally
text: He has appeared in several stage productions including "The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity", "The Jungle Book" and a production of "Around the World in 80 Days".

title: Usman Ally
text: He is known for his on screen roles such as Vincent on "Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D." and The hook-handed man in "A Series of Unfortunate Events".

title: Midnight Sun (2006 film)
text: Song to the Sun, known in Japan as Taiyō no Uta (タイヨウのうた , Song of the Sun ) , is a movie directed by Norihiro Koizumi starring the Japanese artist and singer Yui.

title: Midnight Sun (2006 film)
text: In the movie, she plays the role of Kaoru Amane (雨音 薫 "Amane Kaoru"), a 16-year-old girl who has the rare skin condition xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a disease that makes the ultraviolet radiation of sunlight potentially lethal to her.

title: Midnight Sun (2006 film)
text: Yui's character is partly based on herself, as she is a singer and guitarist, and she performs three of Yui's songs in the movie; "It's Happy Line", "Good-bye Days" and "Skyline".

title: Midnight Sun (2006 film)
text: There has been a 2006 Japanese TV drama starring Takayuki Yamada and Erika Sawajiri, a manga by Bandō Kenji and Minatsuki Tsunami, a 2015 Vietnamese / Japanese drama, and a 2017 American remake, all based on the movie.

title: Jalam (film)
text: Jalam is a 2016 Malayalam-language movie directed by M. Padmakumar starring Priyanka Nair in the lead role.

title: Jalam (film)
text: This is a world's first charity movie, a CSR film by Aries Group directed by M. Padmakumar and produced by Sohan Roy.

title: Jalam (film)
text: Multiple songs from the movie are now in contention for nominations in the Original Song Category for the 88th Academy Awards.

title: Jalam (film)
text: ‘Bhoomiyilenganumundo’, ‘Kooduvaykkam’, ‘Yaathra Manoradhamerum’ and ‘Pakalppathichari’ are the songs from Jalam that are competing for the nomination in the category.

title: Jalam (film)
text: The movie also vies for nominations in the Best Picture Category at the Oscars.

title: Badla Jatti Da
text: Badla Jatti Da (Punjabi:ਬਦਲਾ ਜੱਟੀ ਦਾ) is a 1991 Punjabi action movie directed by Ravinder Ravi.

title: Badla Jatti Da
text: This movie stars Gugu Gill and Yograj Singh in lead roles.

title: Badla Jatti Da
text: The villain role played by Yograj Singh is considered one of his best.

title: Badla Jatti Da
text: The movie was a blockbuster hit across Punjab.

title: Maurice Walsh
text: Maurice Walsh (baptised 23 April 1879 – 18 February 1964) was an Irish novelist best known for the short story "The Quiet Man" which was later made into an Oscar-winning movie directed by John Ford and starring John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara.

title: Maurice Walsh
text: He was one of Ireland's best-selling authors in the 1930s.

title: Estelle Hemsley
text: Estelle Hemsley (May 5, 1887 - November 5, 1968) was a prominent early African American actress of stage and screen.

title: Estelle Hemsley
text: She appeared in the stage and screen versions of "Take a Giant Step", earning a Golden Globe nomination for Best Supporting Actress in the 1959 movie directed by Philip Leacock.

title: Estelle Hemsley
text: Her other notable film roles include playing Grandmother Topouzoglou in Elia Kazan's 1963 movie "America, America" (nominated for the Oscar for Best Picture), the role of Cla-Cla in Mel Ferrer's 1959 film "Green Mansions", the mother of Ruby Dee in "Edge of the City" (1957), and Catherine in Robert Mulligan's 1965 movie "Baby the Rain Must Fall".

title: Man Against the Mob
text: Man Against the Mob (also known as "Trouble in the City of Angels") is a 1988 NBC television movie directed by Steven Hilliard Stern, starring George Peppard, Kathryn Harrold and Max Gail.

title: Man Against the Mob
text: "Man Against the Mob" is a precursor of the 2013 theatrical feature "Gangster Squad", in that it deals with the post-war formation of a special LAPD unit set up to suppress Organized Crime in Los Angeles.

title: Man Against the Mob
text: It may have been inspired by the success of the 1987 theatrical feature "The Untouchables", a period drama which also depicted an elite law enforcement unit pitted against mobsters.

title: Man Against the Mob
text: This was designed around the actor George Peppard as a tough LA cop in the late 1940s.

title: Man Against the Mob
text: A 1989 TV-movie followup, "Man Against the Mob: The Chinatown Murders" is a sequel that also stars Peppard.

title: Man Against the Mob
text: The first movie was a pilot of a proposed NBC series entitled "City of Angels" but ended up panning out as only the two TV movies before George Peppard died in 1994.

title: Pahada Ra Luha
text: Pahada Ra Luha is a 2015 Indian regional Odiya language movie directed by Sabyasachi Mohapatra.

title: Pahada Ra Luha
text: The movie is best known for its national award for Best Feature Film in Oriya category.

title: Jane Ward (volleyball)
text: Jane Lois Ward (born April 30, 1932) is an American former volleyball player.

title: Jane Ward (volleyball)
text: She played for the United States national team at the 1959 Pan American Games, the 1963 Pan American Games, the 1964 Summer Olympics, the 1967 Pan American Games, and the 1968 Summer Olympics.

title: Jane Ward (volleyball)
text: She was born in Buffalo, New York.

title: Brian MacLaren
text: Brian MacLaren (born 21 December 1943) is a Canadian sprinter.

title: Brian MacLaren
text: He competed in the men's 400 metres at the 1972 Summer Olympics.

title: Brian MacLaren
text: He finished second in the 1967 Pan American Games 4 × 400 metres relay (with Bill Crothers, Ross MacKenzie, and Robert McLaren) and third in the 1967 Pan American Games 800 metres.

title: Brian MacLaren
text: He won a silver medal in the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games 4 x 440 yards relay with Don Domansky, Ross MacKenzie and Bill Crothers.

title: 2015 Pan American Games
text: The 2015 Pan American Games, officially the XVII Pan American Games and commonly known as the Toronto 2015 Pan-Am Games (French: "Jeux panaméricains de 2015 à Toronto" ), were a major international multi-sport event celebrated in the tradition of the Pan American Games, as governed by Pan American Sports Organization (PASO).

title: 2015 Pan American Games
text: The games were held from July 10 to 26, 2015 in Toronto, Ontario, Canada; preliminary rounds in certain events began on July 7, 2015.

title: 2015 Pan American Games
text: These were the third Pan American games hosted by Canada, and the first in the province of Ontario.

title: 2015 Pan American Games
text: The Games were held at venues in Toronto and seventeen other Golden Horseshoe communities.

title: 2015 Pan American Games
text: The Pan American Games and 2015 Parapan American Games were organized by the Toronto Organizing Committee for the 2015 Pan and Parapan American Games (TO2015).

title: Dave Bailey (athlete)
text: David Bailey (born March 17, 1945 in Toronto, Ontario) is a retired track and field athlete, who represented Canada at the 1968 Summer Olympics in the men's 1.500 metres.

title: Dave Bailey (athlete)
text: He was the first Canadian to run the mile in less than 4 minutes (3:59.1) in San Diego, CA on June 11, 1966 and the first Canadian to the run the mile in less than 4 minutes in Canada (3:57.7)in Toronto on July 22, 1967.

title: Dave Bailey (athlete)
text: A resident of Willowdale, Ontario he won the bronze medal in this event at the 1967 Pan American Games and the silver medal in this event at the 1968 World University Games He was two-time Canadian Universities Track and Field Athlete of Year (1965, 1967) and two-time inductee into the University of Toronto Sports Hall of Fame (individually 1998 and team 2003).

title: Dave Bailey (athlete)
text: He was a member of 9 Canadian National Track and Field Teams competing at World University Games, Budapest 1965 and Tokyo 1967, Commonwealth Games, Kingston, Jamaica, 1966, Pan American Games, Winnipeg, 1967, Commonwealth vs USA, Los Angeles, 1967, Pre-Olympic Games, Mexico City, 1967, Soviet Union Tour, 1968, European Tour, 1968, Olympic Games, Mexico City, 1968.

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: The 2011 Pan American Games, officially the XVI Pan American Games, was an international multi-sport event that was held from October 14–30, 2011, in Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico.

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: Some events were held in the nearby cities of Ciudad Guzmán, Puerto Vallarta, Lagos de Moreno and Tapalpa.

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: It was the largest multi-sport event of 2011, with approximately 6,000 athletes from 42 nations participating in 36 sports.

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: Both the Pan American and Parapan American Games were organized by the Guadalajara 2011 Organizing Committee (COPAG).

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: The 2011 Pan American Games were the third Pan American Games hosted by Mexico (the first country to do so) and the first held in the state of Jalisco.

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: Previously, Mexico hosted the 1955 Pan American Games and the 1975 Pan American Games, both in Mexico City.

title: 2011 Pan American Games
text: The 2011 Parapan American Games were held 20 days after the Pan American Games have ended.

title: Ross MacKenzie (athlete)
text: Ross MacKenzie (born 18 July 1946) is a Canadian sprinter.

title: Ross MacKenzie (athlete)
text: He competed in the men's 400 metres at the 1968 Summer Olympics.

title: Ross MacKenzie (athlete)
text: He finished second in the 1967 Pan American Games 4 × 400 metres relay (with Brian MacLaren, Bill Crothers, and Robert McLaren).

title: Ross MacKenzie (athlete)
text: MacKenzie also finished fifth in the 1967 Pan American Games 400 metres.

title: Ross MacKenzie (athlete)
text: He won a silver medal in the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games 4 x 440 yards relay with Don Domansky, Brian MacLaren and Bill Crothers.

title: Harry Prowell
text: Harry Prowell A.A.(10 July 1936 – 27 June 2000) was a Guyanese long distance runner who represented Guyana in the Marathon at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City, Mexico.

title: Harry Prowell
text: He is known to be one of the greatest Marathon runners Guyana has ever produced, setting the national record in 1968.

title: Harry Prowell
text: To date, he is the only Guyanese ever to compete in the Marathon at the Summer Olympic Games and one of the most prominent Indo-Caribbean long distance runners of his time.

title: Harry Prowell
text: He also participated in the 10,000 metres at the 1967 Pan American Games in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada and represented Guyana at the 1970 British Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh, Scotland.

title: Kavita Tungar
text: Kavita Tungar (née "Raut" on 5 May 1985) is an Indian long-distance runner from Nashik, Maharashtra.

title: Kavita Tungar
text: She holds the current national record for 10 km road running with a timing of 34:32 as well as the current national record in the half marathon with a timing of 1:12:50.

title: Kavita Tungar
text: She won the bronze medal in 10,000 metres race at the 2010 Commonwealth Games, the first individual track medal by an Indian woman athlete at the Commonwealth Games.

title: Kavita Tungar
text: She also won the silver medal in 10,000 metres race at the 2010 Asian Games.

title: Nora Rocha
text: Nora Leticia Rocha de la Cruz (born December 18, 1967 in Monclova, Coahuila) is a retired female track and field athlete from Mexico, who competed in the 5000 and 10,000 metres.

title: Nora Rocha
text: She claimed the gold medal in the women's 10,000 metres at the 1999 Pan American Games in Winnipeg, Canada.

title: European 10,000m Cup
text: The European 10,000m Cup is an annual 10,000 metres race for European athletes which was first held in 1997.

title: European 10,000m Cup
text: The competition is organised by the European Athletics Association and first began as the European 10000 Metres Challenge after the event was removed from the European Cup programme.

title: European 10,000m Cup
text: The competition has roots in the Iberian 10,000 metres Championships – a competition between Spanish and Portuguese athletes that was held between 1991 and 1996 – and the first five editions of the European 10000 Metres Challenge were held in the Iberian Peninsula.

title: European 10,000m Cup
text: The event was first held under its current title in 2005.

title: Surfer hair
text: Surfer hair is a tousled type of hairstyle, popularized by surfers from the 1950s onwards, traditionally long, thick and naturally bleached from high exposure to the sun and salt water of the sea.

title: Surfer hair
text: In the late 1960s and 1970s, the long hair and general lack of personal grooming was closely associated with hippie culture.

title: Surfer hair
text: Today, hairstyling companies brand their own hair gels, shampoos and hair wax to achieve the "surfer look", with hairstyles, often shorter than traditionally, which often require more grooming to achieve the permanent hair lift or intentional windswept look.

title: Surfer hair
text: Amongst women, fashion magazines have referred to "sun streaked surfer hair" as a desirable look for women, although genuine surfer hair is often heavily damaged by the elements.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: Chrysalis: A Magazine of Women's Culture was a feminist publication produced from 1977 to 1980.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: The self-published magazine was founded by Kirsten Grimstad and Susan Rennie at the Woman's Building in downtown Los Angeles.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: "Chysalis" grew from Grimstad and Rennie's editorial work on the self-help resource books, The New Woman's Survival Catalog and The New Woman's Survival Sourcebook.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: "Chrysalis" distinguished itself from other feminist publications through an organic integration of politics, literature, cultural studies, and art.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: The magazine was produced through a collective process that grew out of the feminist practice of consciousness-raising.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: Unusually broad in scope, "Chrysalis" did not substitute breadth for quality.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: The authors, poets, essayists, and researchers contributing to the magazine reveals a veritable who's who of towering intellects of the feminist movement: black lesbian activist Audre Lorde; the magazine's poetry editor, Robin Morgan, who later served as editor of Ms. from 1990-1993: award winning poet Adrienne Rich; novelist Marge Percy; artist Judy Chicago; science fiction writer Joanna Russ; art critic Lucy Lippard, plus Mary Daly, Dolores Hayden, Andrea Dworkin, Marilyn Hacker, Arlene Raven, and Elizabeth Janeway.

title: Chrysalis (magazine)
text: Over a three-year span, the all volunteer staff produced ten issues before they were forced to disband in 1981 due to financial difficulties.

title: List of magazines in Austria
text: The magazine sector in Austria is under the dominance of Germany.

title: List of magazines in Austria
text: This influence decreased at the end of the 1990s, but it continued on the women's magazines and fashion magazines.

title: List of magazines in Austria
text: However, business magazines have not been subject to the dominance of Germany.

title: List of magazines in Austria
text: The major fields of Austrian magazines are news, popular science and special interest topics.

title: List of magazines in Austria
text: On the other hand, since the Austrian press market is divided between magazines and newspapers, magazines have a significant function in the press market.

title: List of magazines in Egypt
text: The following is an incomplete list of current and defunct magazines published in Egypt.

title: List of magazines in Egypt
text: They may be published in Arabic or in other languages.

title: List of magazines in Egypt
text: The history of Egyptian magazines is long, dating back to the 1890s.

title: List of magazines in Egypt
text: The earliest magazines also included women's magazines as well as those published in Turkish from 1828 to 1947.

title: List of magazines in Egypt
text: The first children's magazine was published in 1893.

title: Rick Wilber
text: Rick Wilber is an American author, poet, and editor.

title: Rick Wilber
text: He has published more than thirty-five short stories in magazines such as "Aboriginal SF", "Analog", "Asimov's Science Fiction", "Fantasy & Science Fiction", "Pulphouse", and "SF Age"; and in anthologies such as "Alien Sex" and "Chrysalis".

title: Rick Wilber
text: In addition to his short stories, he has written the novels "Rum Point", "The Cold Road", and "Alien Morning", as well as a memoir, "My Father's Game: Life, Death, Baseball", and several textbooks, including "Modern Media Writing" and "Magazine Feature Writing".

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: The first women's magazine was published in Malaysia in 1932.

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: In the 2000s there were nearly fifty local titles addressing women in the country.

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: These magazines also include those having an Islamic perspective.

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: Some international women's magazines are also published in Malaysia.

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: One of them is "Elle Malaysia", which was first published in March 2014.

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: Another one, "Women’s Health", was started in April 2015.

title: List of magazines in Malaysia
text: Comic magazines and film magazines are also common in Malaysia.

title: Lifestyle magazine
text: Lifestyle magazine is an umbrella term for popular magazines concerned with lifestyle and is often used to encompass a number of men's magazines, women's magazines and magazines about health and fitness, tourism, leisure, fashion, decorating, or culture.

title: Lifestyle magazine
text: The concept is chiefly used in reference to a magazine's tone.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
text: The Transition House Association of Nova Scotia (abbreviated THANS and TRANS) is a Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada-based organisation that runs women's shelters. Pamela Harrison is THANS's executive director, and also serves as provincial co-ordinator.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
text: Rhonda Fraser, the executive director of Chrysalis House, is a member of THANS.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
text: THANS organises an annual purple ribbon awareness campaign in memory of the École Polytechnique massacre.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
text: THANS was founded in 1989.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
text: THANS conducted interviews with 34 physically abused women who subsequently sought resolution through family law mediation.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
text: In 2000, THANS released a report based on these interviews, stating that most of the women would not recommend legal mediation to other abused women.

title: Transition House Association of Nova Scotia
